title: Sally Goldfarb Weds Joseph N. Straus
description: Sally Fay Goldfarb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldfarb of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Joseph Nathan Straus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Straus 3d of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi Simkha Y. Weintraub performed the ceremony at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.

title: Denise E. Schlanger Weds R. A. Kahn on Long Island
description: Denise Ellen Schlanger and Richard Allen Kahn were married yesterday at the Roslyn Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I., by Rabbi Charles Agin.

title: WHY WESTWAY IS RIGHT
description: Among the chief victims of further delay in building Westway are blue- collar workers, partcularly minorities.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Iran Says Advance Against Iraq Goes On

title: 'MINI M.B.A.,' FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS
description: Many high school students enter the business world through the modern-day school of hard knocks. They spend their summers frying hamburgers in fast-food outlets or scooping ice cream at the local soda shop.

title: Leak Shuts Down Reactor
description: A leak of radioactive water shut down the Brunswick Unit 2 nuclear reactor at Southport, but technicians found the source and hope to have the plant back in operation this week, officials of the Carolina Power and Light Company said today. ''The water was only slightly contaminated,'' said Wayne Ennis, a spokesman for the utility, adding that the public was never in danger.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Old and Eager

title: ALBERT W. LEWITT
description: Albert W. Lewitt, a public relations specialist who worked in political campaigns for two Senators from New Jersey and for Hubert H. Humphrey, died of cardiac arrest at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington Friday. Mr. Lewitt, a Washington resident, was 84 years old.

title: ARIZONA, IN ANTIDRUG EFFORT, REQUIRES LICENSES FOR DEALERS
description: A new state law requires drug dealers to buy a license and pay a luxury tax on their illegal sales, but it is intended to be only another means of punishing dealers who are arrested, says the sponsor of the measure.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:French Win Impressively To Gain World Semifinals

title: City Ballet to Tour Europe
description: The New York City Ballet will tour Europe this summer and fall, performing in London, Copenhagen and Paris for two weeks each. The company's programs will feature ballets by George Balanchine, Jerome Robbins, John Taras and Peter Martins, and will include 10 European premieres. The troupe is scheduled to leave Aug. 22 and return Oct. 2.

title: No Headline
description: Sky Diver Dies as Chutes Fail

title: Iran Lifts Oil Price 20 Cents, to $27.10 TEHERAN, Iran, July 31 (Reuters) - Iran is raising the price of its heavy crude oil by 20 cents a barrel, to $27.10, according to the national press agency, IRNA.
description: The agency said Saturday that Deputy Oil Minister Abbas Honardoust had confirmed the increase, which will take effect Aug. 20.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Reliving a Miracle

title: DEMIC IS HOPING TO REBOUND FOR KNICKS
description: Larry Demic had the look of a man in search of more pleasant things as his brow became peppered with perspiration as he battled for rebounds at the Knicks' rookie and free agent camp last week at Princeton University.

title: 8 Cut by Knicks
description: The Knicks cut eight players yesterday to reduce their roster of draft choices and free agents to 14. The eight were: Troy Lee Mikell, Mike Lang and Charles Jones, draft choices, and Tony Guy, Otis Howard, Ralph McPherson, Rick Bullock and Mike Brown, free agents.

title: No Headline
description: Peddling a New Soviet CycleThe history of economic management in the Soviet Union is a history of alternating cycles of centralization and decentralization. One era brings decision-making to the top to provide Purpose, Planning and Priorities, until the troops are found to be confused, careless and contrary. The next cycle encourages Independence and Initiative, until these produce unbearable dislocation, distortion and dissension.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Multinational Vault

title: TREASURY DOMINATES WEEK'S ISSUES
description: The Treasury market, where four days of auctions are scheduled, is expected to dominate the credit markets this week.

title: No Headline
description: Former Pemex Director Jailed on Fraud Charges

title: Brent Ballard, a Law Student, Weds Ann Marriott
description: Ann Marie Marriott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Marriott Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Brent Doyal Ballard, son of Mrs. William Cody of Pepper Pike, Ohio, and Dr. Lester A. Ballard of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The Rev. Edward Howley performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: SIDNEY KAUFMAN, A FIGURE IN FILM PRODUCTION
description: Sidney Kaufman, a film producer and teacher who also played a major role in financing arrangements for movies, died of cancer in Wellington Hospital in London on Saturday. He was 73 years old and had residences in London, Los Angeles and New York.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Is 'Correction' Beginning? THE stock market looked at the bond market
description: last week, and what it saw was enough to

title: GOVERNORS WARN OF RISING DEFICIT AS THREAT TO ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: Record Federal budget deficits threaten to make the economic recovery a short one, some of the nation's governors warned today.

title: DR. BERNARD STRAUS, BETH ISRAEL DIRECTOR AND EDUCATOR, DIES
description: Dr. Bernard Straus, director emeritus of medicine at New York's Beth Israel Medical Center, died of cancer Friday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Carmel, N.Y.

title: 2D-QUARTER PROFITS REBOUND SMARTLY
description: Corporate profits, which were dismal a year ago, recovered strongly in the second quarter, although sectors as diverse as steel and home electronics tarnished the overall picture.

title: COE LOSES AGAIN, FINISHING 4TH IN 800
description: Sebastian Coe of England suffered his fourth consecutive defeat when he was beaten soundly in an 800- meter race today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Former Garfinckel Chief Plans Own Store Chain

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A Chrysler Rescuer Is Retiring Again

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: 6 African Lands Impose New Rule on Journalists

title: COOK DEFEATS MILLER ON 6TH PLAYOFF HOLE
description: John Cook won the Canadian Open today by blasting out of bunkers three times in succession and then going on to beat Johnny Miller on the sixth hole of a playoff. The first two explosion shots saved par 4's on the 16th and 17th holes, and the third was good for the birdie 4 that tied Miller, who had finished a few minutes earlier with a birdie.

title: PATRIOTS SEE TRUCE WITH COACH
description: SMITHFIELD, R.I.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: International Specialist Is Hired by Korn/Ferry

title: MEDIATOR HOPES TO AVERT STRIKE ON THE L.I.R.R.
description: A Federal mediator in the talks between the Long Island Rail Road and four of its unions said yesterday that he was ''hopeful'' that a strike against the railroad threatened for Wednesday could be averted.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Bronx Opera House

title: OPERA: PREMIERE OF SOLTI-HALL 'GOTTERDAMMERUNG'
description: This has not been one of the great weeks in Bayreuth history. The combination of nearly unbearable heat and the new ''English'' production of the ''Ring of the Nibelungs'' that never seemed to know where it was headed or why made for long, stifling evenings in the Festspielhaus that Wagner built to house his music dramas.

title: IS THERE ROOM FOR MEL AND DUKE TOO?
description: The Great Pickle War of Connecticut Avenue is about to be joined.

title: 3 Big Range Fires Burn 7,000 Acres in Nevada
description: About 1,000 firefighters in northern Nevada today were battling three major range fires that had scorched about 7,000 acres of brush, officials said. The fires were among at least 30 blazes ignited by lightning Saturday night.

title: NICARAGUA VOTE: HOW WHITE HOUSE RAN AGROUND
description: News Analysis

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Ex-Executive and Wife Are Slain in Georgia

title: Sting Sets Back Cosmos by 2-1
description: Although they lost to the Chicago Sting on Saturday night for the third time in three games this season, Coach Julio Mazzei saw enough in the Cosmos' performance to overcome the disappointment of the 2-1 defeat at Soldier Field in Chicago.

title: Two Motorcyclists Die in Race Crash
description: Norman Brown of Northern Ireland and Peter Hueber of Switzerland died today after a collision during the British 500cc Motorcycle Grand Prix.

title: COLORADO GOVERNOR SEEKS TO HALT ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: For several years, Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado has been at the leading edge of a national drive to reform America's immigration laws, including cracking down on illegal aliens from Mexico.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Reactivated Tippy Martinez, pitcher, from the 21-day disabled list and sent Paul Mirabella, pitcher, to Rochester of the International League.

title: TWO STANDOUTS IN ELECTRONICS
description: For Jack Tramiel, the losses at Texas Instruments' home computer division are sweet revenge.

title: DEAD WHALE FOUND FLOATING IN RIVER
description: Responding to a call yesterday that a capsized sailboat had been spotted, the police found instead a dead 40-foot whale floating in the Hudson River off Manhattan's West Side.

title: JAZZ: FARMER AND FREEMAN
description: THE fluegelhorn player Art Farmer and the tenor saxophonist Chico Freeman warily shared an engagement at the Blue Note last week. In Thursday's first set, they played together on only one tune, concluding a set in which each of them fronted Mr. Farmer's quartet while the other left the room.

title: CHRYSLER OFFER BY SHEARSON
description: Shearson/American Express, the big Wall Street investment house, said yesterday that it had offered to buy the Government's rights to 14.4 million shares of the Chrysler Corporation, but that the Government had rejected the offer.

title: Karen Mesberg, Teacher, Marries Scott M. Univer
description: Karen Mesberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Mesberg of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Sagaponack, L.I., was married yesterday to Scott Michael Univer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving O. Univer of Philadelphia. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Mesberg home in Sagaponack.

title: E.R.A.'S TIME IS GONE
description: After 49 years of wise forbearance, Congress in 1972 succumbed to temptation and submitted the Equal Rights Amendment to the states for their ratification. In the next eight months, 22 states voted to ratify it without pausing to determine what it meant and would do.

title: W. A. Becker Married To Sherri Gale LeBolt
description: Sherri Gale LeBolt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. LeBolt of Closter, N.J., was married yesterday to William August Becker, son of Ralph M. Becker of Atlanta and Cecelia J. Korsen of Los Angeles. Rabbi William Rothschild performed the ceremony at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: OFFICIAL El SALVADOR AGAINST HEALTH AIDES
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE CONNECTICUT IMPERIALISM IS WANTED
description: * To the Editor:

title: EGRETS, PROTECTED BY TREATIES, TERMED HEALTH PERIL IN TEXAS
description: Cattle egrets, a type of protected waterfowl, have taken over this town of 600 people in northeastern Texas, leaving ankle-deep droppings and a stench of ammonia in their rookery while outraged and outnumbered residents watch helplessly.

title: HOWARD DIETZ, SONGWRITER, DIES AT 86
description: Howard Dietz, who put words to more than 500 songs, including such popular classics as ''Dancing in the Dark,'' ''That's Entertainment,'' and ''You and the Night and the Music,'' died of Parkinson's disease Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: SHUTOUT FOR ORIOLES' BODDICKER
description: Three months ago, injuries to Jim Palmer and Mike Flanagan put the Baltimore Orioles badly in need of a starting pitcher, so they called up Mike Boddicker from Rochester of the International League.

title: BLOOD SHORTAGE IS SAID TO EASE IN CITY REGION
description: The acute shortage of blood in the New York metropolitan area has eased, the director of the Greater New York Blood Program said yesterday.

title: Margot Louise Stein Weds D. M. Azen in Westchester
description: Margot Louise Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen A. Stein of Larchmont, N.Y., was married at the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck, N.Y., yesterday to David Marc Azen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Azen of Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbis Irving Koslowe and Charles Kroloff officiated.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. Ray Fontenot, who has won three games without a defeat, faces Floyd Bannister in the finale of the four-game series.

title: CALIFORNIA'S GOVERNOR: A SHIFT IN STYLE
description: News Analysis

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TWO GALAS FOR TWO CUBAS
description: Fidel Castro's Cuba had an anniversary this week and opened its doors to the world for the celebration. Cuba also had its carnival, the yearly burst of dancing, drinking and dressing up in costumes that goes back to the country's Spanish and African past.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Of Art and Games

title: Andretti Ends His Losing Streak
description: Mario Andretti ended a two- year stretch without a victory today, taking the lead with three laps remaining and racing to a victory in the CART Provimi Veal Indy-car race at Road America.

title: LONG-TERM RATES ARE UP
description: On the eve of the largest Treasury financing ever, the outlook for interest rates is more uncertain than any time in the past year.

title: BAYLOR GETS SLAM
description: The Yankees took command of a close, contentious game with six runs in the 11th inning today for a 12-6 victory over the White Sox that ended a two-game slide and quieted Billy Martin's concern about his team. Don Baylor hit a grand slam in the winning rally.

title: A DUBIOUS PROSPECT
description: Can negotiations, as frequently urged in Washington, bring an end to the Salvadoran civil war? Interviews here and with dissident Salvadorans in Nicaragua do suggest that some antigovernment elements are eager for a ''political solution.'' But don't hold your breath until it happens.

title: Rachel Bookspan Weds a Physician
description: Rachel Raissa Bookspan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bookspan of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Murray Sobel, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sobel of Philadelphia. Rabbis Morris Dembowitz and Allan Nadler performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House in New York.

title: JAN STEPHENSON WINS BY ONE
description: Jan Stephenson, the 31-year-old Australian who said she liked hot weather and was used to it, nearly wilted at the finish but held on to win the 38th annual United States Women's Open championship today by one shot over JoAnne Carner and Patty Sheehan.

title: WEST BANK ARABS FORESEE EXPULSION
description: -Occupied West Bank - Palestinians were angered but not really surprised last week when masked gunman opened fire on students and teachers at the Islamic College in Hebron, in the West Bank, killing 3 people and injuring more than 30. The incident confirms and encourages widespread Palestinian fears of Jewish vigilante violence - and of the possibility that Israel may intend one day to expell all Palestinians from the West Bank, using whatever means are available to drive us across the river to Jordan.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 1, 1983 International The President's special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, met for the first with a leader of El Salvador's rebels, according to the President of Colombia. President Belisario Betancur said in Bogota that he had acted as a ''go-between'' in a meeting held by Mr. Stone and Ruben Zamora, a director of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, one of five leftist guerrilla organizations fighting the United States-backed Salvadoran Government. (Page A1, Column 6.) The United States accused Libya of ''open aggression'' against Chad, its southern neighbor, and called for an immediate withdrawal of Libyan forces from the former French colony. The charge followed reports from Chad's capital that Libyan planes had twice bombed a strategically important town since Saturday. (A1:4.)

title: SURVEY FINDS LACK OF NONSEXIST TOYS
description: Despite the abundance of new toys available for children, 75 percent of the more than 10,000 women who responded to a recent survey by the National Association for Female Executives feel that there aren't enough toys that ''provide a positive role for the executive woman.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KING SOLOMON. By Romain Gary. 255 pages. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: SOVIET SHIFT IN VIENNA
description: When the Soviet Union departs even partly from traditional secretiveness in military matters to accept on-site inspection, this is important news, not least because of its great potential importance for the entire spectrum of arms control talks, conventional and nuclear.

title: HOW NOT TO TRIM THE NEW YORK BASS HARVEST
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerue Seeking Jet Spot
description: Mark Jerue couldn't understand why he was short of breath.

title: Racing Agency Hires Diener Hauser Bates
description: Edward P. Seigenfeld, vice president-marketing of the New York Racing Association, has hired Diener Hauser Bates to do the media buying for his advertising campaigns. Diener Hauser, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, specializes in advertising for the entertainment world.

title: ARMENIAN TERROR: TANGLE OF MOTIVES
description: A recent series of Armenian terrorist incidents, most in Western Europe, is the result of internal disputes within Armenian terrorist organizations and of international political developments that have little direct connection with the Armenian cause, according to Western officials and Armenian political leaders.

title: COMMODITIES
description: WHEN the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said last week that it was setting up a unit in Chicago to trade futures for its own account as well as act as broker for the general public, it further acknowledged the increasing integration of the financial services industry with the futures markets.

title: At 41, Campaneris Is Good Insurance
description: A longtime Yankee hater, writing in The Chicago Sun-Times last week, lamented the fact that despite their record, these are not the big, bad Yankees of old. ''How can you hate and fear a team that has Bert Campaneris in its starting lineup?'' the columnist wondered.

title: ISRAEL SAYS U.S. AGREES TO PLANS ON PULLOUT ISSUE
description: Israeli officials said today that as a result of talks with Reagan Administration officials in Washington last week there was virtually no disagreement between Israel and the United States on the situation in Lebanon.

title: HOW THE GRAPHIC ARTS FEATS IN 'ZELIG' WERE DONE
description: Even the most jaded movie audiences, the ones already bored with today's most sophisticated special-effects wizardry, may never stop marveling at the technical feats accomplished in Woody Allen's ''Zelig.''

title: FERRARO DISMISSED AS INDIAN MANAGER
description: Mike Ferraro was dismissed as manager of the last-place Cleveland Indians today and was replaced by Pat Corrales, who lost his job as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies less than two weeks ago.

title: COLECO STRONG IN MARKETING
description: ''We move with blinding speed,'' said Arnold C. Greenberg, president and chief executive officer of Coleco Industries. ''And we never try to be the lowest-priced competitor.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Second Look

title: PROGRESS ON WORLD DEBT CITED
description: Compared to Mexico and Brazil, where tens of billions of dollars are involved, the numbers were not very large. But a spate of reschedulings, refinancings or new loan agreements last week for six different countries underscored the international dimensions of the debt crisis.

title: Man With Knife Is Shot After Stabbing Officers
description: A man menacing people on a Bronx street with a knife was shot in the chest by a policeman after the man stabbed the policeman and his partner, according to a police spokesman.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Kinder-Care Learning Centers has agreed with Drexel Burnham Lambert, Merrill Lynch International and Alexander Brown & Sons to sell $50 million of 6.25 percent convertible subordinated guaranteed debentures of its Netherlands Antilles unit.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: FROM THE FRENCH

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: U.S. Agents Once Held Barbie Son, Relative Says

title: RIGHTS GROUP HEAD CRITICIZES REAGAN
description: Characterizing black Americans as a people without a political party, the president of the National Urban League said today that the overwhelming majority of blacks would advise President Reagan not to run for re-election.

description: * To the Editor:

description: Six-Letter Words

description: The Musical Navigator

title: METS TAKE 2 FROM PIRATES
description: Throughout the Mets' losing streaks, Manager Frank Howard has complained loudly and often about their lack of scoring and occasional lack of effort.

title: WHY A SOCIAL TIME BOMB'S 'EXPLOSIVE CORE' IGNITED
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE OFFICIALS HEAR PLEAS ON THE NEEDS OF CHILDREN
description: In the chandeliered ballroom of the Eastland Hotel here, speaker after speaker reeled off chilling statistics. Twelve million children live in poverty, they said, and are far more likely than their better-off peers to fall victim to abuse, delinquency, truancy, disease and even death. Moreover, they said, poor children are not confined to Appalachia or inner-city ghettos. Today they live everywhere, dependent on a single parent or two parents who have no jobs or simply low-paying ones.

title: SUSPECT IN CALIFORNIA SLAYINGS CAPTURED AFTER RAPE ON BOAT
description: A suspect in the hatchet slayings of four people was captured Saturday after eluding a two- month manhunt by staying aboard a sailboat, the authorities said today.

title: POP: THE FUTURISTIC SEAGULLS
description: AFLOCK of Seagulls, the English quartet that headlined last Thursday at Radio City Music Hall, represents the giddier side of futuristic pop. Using evocative, otherworldly backdrops, dry ice and colored lights, the group cavorted in a carnival atmosphere that suggested the inside of a video game.

title: EXPOS LOSE LEAD BUT WIN, 6-5
description: The Montreal Expos, who had led by 5-0 after the fifth inning, needed a home run by Tim Wallach in the bottom of the eighth to salvage a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in Montreal yesterday.

title: AUSSIE YACHTSMEN CHARGE HARASSMENT
description: Representatives of the America's Cup contender Australia II accused the New York Yacht Club of harassment today after learning of plans to challenge the legality of its mysterious keel. The accusation was made before Australia II scored another impressive victory in the challenger trials, defeating France 3 by 3 minutes 13 seconds.

title: Lease for Expos
description: The Montreal Expos said today that they had reached an agreement in principle with the Olympic Installations Board that will keep them in Olympic Stadium through the 1987 season. The board is the provincial government body that administrates stadium operations. The lease also gives the Expos a renewal option for five additional years through 1992.

title: Dubrovnik Curbs Fire Threat
description: More than 2,000 firefighters battled through the night to control a forest fire threatening this resort on the Adriatic. Officials said the fire, which began in pines on the hills over the walled medieval city, moved away just after dawn when the wind changed. About 30,000 foreign and 25,000 Yugoslav tourists are in the city at present.

title: Canadian Brass Concert
description: The Canadian Brass will give a free concert Aug. 10 from 6 to 7 P.M. on the North Plaza of Lincoln Center in conjunction with their Mostly Mozart Festival performance at Lincoln Center the next day.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Indian Summer In the City

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Sri Lanka Death Toll Now Put at 200

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Dog Accused of Robbery Is Banished From Seattle

title: POP MUSIC: RENAISSANCE AND AMERICA
description: IT started to rain about half an

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Aug. 1, 1983 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Acme-Cleveland Corp., Cleveland, has named B. Charles Ames chairman and James T. Bartlett president and chief operating officer.

title: CongressmanCharges New York Police Bias
description: Representative Major R. Owens charged yesterday that the New York City Police Department used screening methods to eliminate minority applicants who had already passed the Civil Service examination to become police officers.

title: TV: 'BRANAGAN AND MAPES,' STEPFATHER AND HIS CHILDREN
description: ''BRANAGAN & Mapes'' is a comedy about a widowed stepfather, three cute kids and a meddlesome aunt. Its heart is in the right place; it even goes in for a little poignancy.

title: Drewitt Defeats Alexander
description: Brad Drewett outlasted John Alexander, a fellow Australian, on a third-set tiebreaker today to capture the men's title at the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: SWEDES SELL ROBOTS IN JAPAN
description: The task of selling robots to Japan, the world's champion robot manufacturer, could be likened to selling coals to Newcastle - especially if Newcastle were to raise import barriers in the bargain.

title: A NEIGHBORHOOD ON STATEN ISLAND WONDERS IF ITS SHIP HAS COME IN
description: Down in the decaying business district, along the derelict piers and up among the restored Victorian houses that dot the hills, the talk yesterday was much the same all over the Staten Island neighborhood of Stapleton.

title: OUTDOORS: TRYING TO PROTECT THE BLACK DUCK
description: WATERFOWL hunters in the Atlantic and Mississippi flyways will have less opportunity to bag black ducks this coming fall and winter. They will also be asked to take part in a Federally sponsored effort to sharpen their waterfowl-identification skills so that there will be less chance of their shooting black ducks by mistake.

title: TEXTILES PRODUCERS IN AMERICA ASSAIL PACT WITH CHINESE
description: Officials of the American textile industry today denounced a textile trade agreement between the United States and China, complaining that the flow of Chinese- made apparel into this country could damage the industry.

title: U.S. ACCUSES LIBYA OF BOMBING RAIDS AGAINST CHAD CITY
description: The United States accused Libya today of ''open aggression'' in bombing a strategic town in Chad, its southern neighbor.

title: RAPE CASE: VENGEANCE AND FUROR
description: On the morning of July 5, a 10-year-old girl was abducted and raped, and that night her father was arrested and charged with stabbing the man accused in the case.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday incorrectly identified a book by John I. Goodlad on American schools to be published this summer by McGraw-Hill. It is ''A Place Called School: Prospects for the Future.''

title: LOW-COST COMPUTER COURSES
description: Alissa Van Horn, 4 years old, has not yet learned to read or write, but she began computer school this week. She was accompanied by her grandmother, Virginia Van Horn, who is also taking her first computer class. In a nearby classroom, Ruth Shollenbarger is starting to acquire computer literacy at the age of 82.

title: Advertising; Journey to Warwick's Presidency
description: WILDER B. BAKER, a 51-year-old Yalie, is president and chief operating officer of Warwick Advertising, his ninth employer. He is living proof that job hopping is not the kiss of death in adland.

title: S.I. BASE CALLED BEST TYPE OF U.S. AID
description: Military spending is more beneficial to local economies than Federal expenditures on social services, of which New York State is one of the largest recipients, according to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and economic analysts.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Audit Shows Millions Wasted in Army Repairs

title: FRIENDSHIP: ON THE JOB AND AFTER 5
description: ON-THE-JOB socializing involves more than the company bowling team. It's not just a matter of stopping for a quick one on the way to the train. There is more going on than window openers versus window closers and smokers versus nonsmokers.

title: YOUNG STOWAWAYS ASK ASYLUM FROM ETHIOPIA
description: One hot evening this summer, two Ethiopian boys fled their homeland. By moonlight, they dived into the Red Sea, swam to a ship anchored offshore and climbed aboard. By the time they were discovered, it was too late for the ship, bound for New York, to turn back.

title: Bank Loans To Lance NASHVILLE, July 30 (UPI) - Bert Lance, budget director during the administration of President Jimmy Carter, received more than $2 million in loans from banks controlled by Jake and C. H. Butcher, it was reported today. The banks have since failed.
description: The report, in The (Nashville) Tennessean, said Federal officials were investigating Mr. Lance's failure to report most of those loans to the Government. The officials said he still could file an amended list of loans without penalty. Mr. Lance could not be reached for comment, and did not return phone calls.

title: FOUR ENTER BASEBALL HALL AMID CHEERS AND TRIBUTE
description: Brooks Robinson and Juan Marichal were inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame today in a rare kind of international fiesta that included speeches in Spanish, the singing of the Dominican Republic anthem and hundreds of Baltimore Oriole balloons, caps and banners.

title: No Headline
description: Linda A. Lowengrub Marries S. L. Blasnik

title: SHULTZ AFTER A YEAR IN OFFICE:LOOKING FOR A SUCCESS ABROAD
description: As Secretary of State George P. Shultz begins his second year in office, he remains to all appearances a cautious and philosophically conservative man in what many officials still see as an inexperienced and divided Administration.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on June 30 from Oxford, England, about a reunion of Rhodes Scholars included one name incorrectly. Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, was unable to go because the Senate was in session.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Trout & Ries Selected

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.60

title: No Headline
description: When Children Bear Children''It cannot go without notice,'' Justice Thurgood Marshall said recently, ''that adolescent children apparently have a pressing need for information about contraception.'' That was a personal opinion given in the context of a Supreme Court decision. But it is true.

title: 4 HEAT-RELATED DEATHS IN CHICAGO PROMPT INQUIRY ON NURSING HOME
description: A Cook County grand jury is to begin an investigation Monday into the deaths of four nursing home patients in 105-degree heat last weekend.

title: BALLET: GANIO STARS IN 'L' ARLESIENNE'
description: -week season by Roland Petit's National Ballet de Marseilles, which closed Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, that of Denys Ganio in Mr. Petit's colorful and lyric ballet ''L'Arlesienne'' should not be overlooked.

title: No Headline
description: The Calendar

title: STIFF ANTITRUST LAWS CALLED REIN ON U.S.
description: Although the United States economy still ranks as the most productive in the world, Japan and other competitors are mounting a strong challenge in a number of fields, including high technology, automobiles and textiles.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A ground ball is hit to the first baseman, who grabs it in his bare hand. He dives to the base and touches the bag with the ball in his hand. Is the batter safe or out? What happens if he touches the bag with his gloved hand, which does not contain the ball?

title: ARGUELLO GETS ANOTHER SHOT
description: HE entered the midtown restaurant the other day and could nearly have passed for just another businessman out to embroider his expense account. But not quite. He wore a blue suit, black shoes and a strawberry-red tie. His dark hair was very clean-cut, his black mustache was very neatly trimmed, and his nose was quite flat.

title: WHAT IT TAKES TO MAKE A JEWISH STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: A SLOWING OF GROWTH IN 2D HALF
description: The rate of recovery in the national economy should slow substantially in the second half of the year, according to a spot check of professional business forecasters, but nevertheless the economy is likely to continue to grow.

title: POP: MELANIE'S NEW MOOD
description: -music exponents of the late 60's ''flower child'' ethic, made a rare local appearance over the weekend at the Other End. While the singer still radiates a gentle but determined humanitarianism, she no longer strives for the extremes of hippie sentimentality that characterized her performances a decade or more ago.

title: No Headline
description: 90YouthsSeizedinTimesSq. In Second Sweep of Weekend

title: JAVITS BEING TESTED FOR A NEW THERAPY FOR NEUROLOGICAL ILL
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits entered a Los Angeles hospital Friday for tests to determine if he might benefit from an experimental new hormone therapy for his degenerative neurological disease.

title: PASSAGE FROM CHILDHOOD CAN SEEM BITTER IN INDIA
description: Of all the people who populate the lane outside the kitchen window, the pole banger is the most insistent. But Rani, while she was there, was the most fetching. The street is not the same without her.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a new effort in the process of the search for peace in Central America.'' - President Belisario Bentancur of Colombia. (A1:6.)

title: No Headline
description: Robinson Confronted SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (UPI) - Several Dodger players confronted Frank Robinson after the first game of a doubleheader today because they thought the Giant manager made gestures concerning the Dodger reliever Steve Howe's past problems with cocaine.

title: Washington WatchJonathan Fuerbringer An Economist Changes Sides WASHINGTONTHE Reagan Administration, which was famous for the infighting over economic policy
description: between the Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget, has accomplished one of the more interesting trades of this or any other season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 1, 1983

title: BOROUGH CHIEFS' BUDGETS SHOW DIFFERING POLICIES
description: New York City's five borough presidents will spend a total of $13.5 million in the new fiscal year in ways that point out the sharp administrative contrasts in their offices, according to a review of city budget and financial disclosure documents.

title: Transmedica Plans TV Show for Physicians
description: The latest hands to begin to probe into the seemingly bottomless purse of the pharmaceutical industry's promotional funds belong to the people at Transmedica, who next January expect to go on the air with MDTV, a weekly television show for physicians that will feature fantastically high advertising rates.

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY PROFITS AND SALES AT 272 COMPANIES
ACTION PLAN BY REGENTS
description: News Analysis

title: JIM DANDY TO A PHENOMENON
description: Angel Penna Jr. figured to be happy after sending out a colt named A Phenomenon to victory in the Jim Dandy Stakes today at Saratoga Race Track, but the winning trainer's enthusiasm dimmed when he was asked about the colt's next start.

title: TANGLEWOOD: BRAHMS AND BRUCKNER
description: On a humid weekend in the Berkshire Mountains, Klaus Tennstedt conducted the Boston Symphony in two concerts at Tanglewood. The heat relented neither Friday nor Saturday evening, and the severity of the elements matched in a way Mr. Tennstedt's choice of music. There were no cool musical drinks to soothe his overheated audiences. Both events dealt seriously and solemnly with matters of life and death.

title: Sara Lee Kessler of TV Weds Robert M. Miller
description: Sara Lee Kessler, co-anchor and principal writer for WOR-TV's ''News at Noon'' program, was married yesterday to Robert M. Miller, a founding partner of Cogan & Miller, an advertising agency in New York. Rabbi Herschel Cohen performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: Swift to Shut Iowa Plant
description: Swift & Company said today that it will close its Clinton poultry processing plant on or before Dec. 30.

title: PRIVILEGED STATUS ASKED BY BAR, REGULATOR SAYS
description: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, speaking at the American Bar Association convention here today, denounced what he called an effort to give lawyers privileged status.

title: OPERA BOARD FIRM ON STRIKE, BUT APPEARS SPLIT INTERNALLY
description: The board of directors of the New York City Opera, the powerful but largely hidden element in the negotiations to resolve the company's 26-day labor dispute, seems united in its strong stand against the striking orchestra musicians and for Beverly Sills's policies as general director.

title: EAST GERMAN SPORTS: POLITICS EVERYWHERE
description: LEIPZIG, East Germany

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Words of Welcome In Many Tongues'Bienvenidos,'' ''Witajcie,'' ''Kalosorisate'' and ''Bonnarrize'' are the words of welcome in four new pamphlets for four of Brooklyn's recent immigrant populations.

title: Reforms at London Exchange
description: Opposition politicians grumbled about a deal in a smoke-filled room. One leading newspaper speculated that it had been sealed over glasses of port at Brooks, a luxurious Establishment club.

title: No Headline
description: Amherst President Is Named

title: ; WHERE CONNECTICUT IMPERIALISM IS WANTED
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Victoria Dachs Wed
description: Amy Victoria Dachs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Dachs of Florham Park, N.J., and Peter Michael Rojcewicz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Rojcewicz of Worcester, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Roy Rosenberger and the Rev. John G. Wollsey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Governor Morris Inn in Morristown, N.J. The bride will become showroom manager at John William Ltd., a Philadelphia interior design firm, in September. Mr. Rojcewicz lectures on folklore at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is a doctoral candidate.

title: Scholarship Applicants List
description: The National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts has started a Scholarship List Service to provide colleges, universities and performing- arts companies with the names of high school seniors who register for its talent search. Among the institutions subscribing to the service are the Juilliard School of Music and the University of Michigan.

title: THE FISH ARE FEWER, BUT THE TOURISTS ARE MANY
description: The Talk of Provincetown

title: Run Record Set
description: John McLaughlin of Belfast, Northern Ireland, representing the Warren Street Athletic Club, set a meet record of 30 minutes 9 seconds yesterday in winning the sixth annual Heights-Inwood 10-kilometer run.

title: No Headline
description: For Whom Bell TollsLocal phone companies can breathe a bit easier. Now that they're losing subsidies from long-distance calls, the Federal Communications Commission plans to compensate by charging personal phones $2 more a month next year and business phones $6. That should ease pressure to raise the prices of other local services and the related pressure to halt the nationwide breakup of Ma Bell.

title: THE MAJORITY LEADER IS 'RIDING HIGH'
description: As he was about to return here from a recent visit to Caracas, where the heads of six Andean countries were commemorating the bicentennial of the birth of Simon Bolivar, Representative Jim Wright received word that Belisario Betancur, the president of Colombia, wanted to see him. Mr. Wright could not stay for such a meeting, and instead, sat down and wrote Mr. Betancur a letter in Spanish.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,464,000 for the quarter and $2,724 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.d-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $46,000.

title: INCREASE IN PRIME SEEN
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, with most of the increases coming in the afternoon after the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market jumped a quarter point, to 9 3/4 percent.

title: Court Remands Male-Clubs Case
description: The Appellate Division of State Superior Court ruled today that the State Division on Civil Rights should give a full hearing to a woman whose challenge to the all-male membership policies of three dining clubs at Princeton University had been rejected.

title: SAFEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results reflect an acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: ANCIENT LABYRINTH OF AQUEDUCTS FEEDS 'FIERY OASIS' IN CHINA
description: THE locals do not exaggerate when they claim that you can fry an egg on the desert sand surrounding this oasis in eastern Xinjiang Province. Turpan has the dubious reputation as the hottest town in China, and is one of the hotter areas in the world.

title: AUSTRALIA II IS BACKED ON KEEL
description: Crews of the seven foreign yachts in the America's Cup challenge trials rallied today behind Australia II and its mysterious keel, maintaining that the series leader is a valid 12-Meter yacht and should not be disqualified.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 2, 1983
description: International

title: Award Planned for Boy Who Ran to Get Police
description: An award and a college trust fund will be given to the 11-year-old boy who called police to help a girl being raped before a crowd of people who did nothing but watch.

title: At Home on Stage
description: There was a threat of rain as the Naumburg Orchestra tuned up for a free concert Saturday night in the Damrosch Park Bandshell at Lincoln Center.

description: b-Net loss

title: Northwest Air Reports Profit
description: Northwest Airlines yesterday reported a second-quarter profit of $14.4 million, or 66 cents a share, on revenues of $537.5 million.

title: TYING CHARITY'S HANDS
description: While President Reagan has urged that private charities take over many of the Government's social welfare functions, his Administration has systematically undermined the nation's nonprofit organizations to try to silence them as advocates for the rights of the poor, women, minorities and the disenfranchised.

FIXING SCHOOLS THAT FAIL
description: IT is a question that every school district has to confront now and again, and a problem that New York City is never without: What should be done with unsuccessful schools? Or, as Anthony J. Alvarado, the city's Chancellor of Schools puts it: How do you fix schools that ''don't work?''

SHULTZ PROPOSES THAT REAGAN EASE SOVIET TRADE CURB
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige have recommended relaxation of controls on the export of oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today.

title: Kodak Profits Fall 31.8%; Boeing Has 29.6% Rise
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, citing a continuing sales slump for photographic equipment and the adverse impact of currency fluctuations, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter plunged 31.8 percent, to $169.4 million, or $1.02 a share, from the year-earlier quarter. Sales slipped 1.2 percent.

title: Flxible Bus Sale
description: The Grumman Corporation said it would receive $41 million from the General Automotive Corporation for its Flxible bus division.

title: Lawmakers Are Said to Agree On Production of Nerve Gas
description: Senate and House conferees tentatively agreed today to let the Pentagon end a 14-year-old moratorium on production of nerve gas by the United States, according to Congressional sources.

title: Commodore Is Moving Account From Gargano
description: Commodore Business Machines, a computer-making subsidiary of Commodore International, Valley Forge, Pa., is moving its multimillion dollar account out of Ally & Gargano after just over a year. And, although it has an agency repository in mind for it, it is temporarily withholding that information.

title: NEW COUNTS POSSIBLE
description: Egypt's Supreme Court of Ethics ordered today that the brother of Anwar el-Sadat and three of the slain President's nephews be released from prison.

title: SCOUTING
description: Bean's Blooper

title: NO FOREIGNERS NEED APPLY
description: When last we left Young Donald Trump in this space, a couple of months ago, I had praised him - tongue in cheek - for his revolutionary plan to solve New York's homeless problem.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the experimental hormone therapy that may be used for former Senator Jacob K. Javits incorrectly described the usual course of the hormone in the body. Thyrotropin-releasing hormone is produced in the hypothalamus gland and stimulates the pituitary gland to release a second hormone, which stimulates the thyroid gland.

title: ATLANTIC SOUTHEAST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCIENCE WATCH
description: Self-Mutilation on the Rise

title: Mark Lasky, 29, Dies; Did 'Nancy' Cartoons
description: Mark Lasky, a cartoonist for United Feature Syndicate who had been the artist and writer for the comic strip ''Nancy'' since last August, died of cancer Sunday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 29 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WORK PLACE DANGERS NOT FOR WOMEN ONLY
description: To the Editor:

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANAGRS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized gains of $3,261 for the quarter and $23,547 for the 6 months.

title: SALVADOR REBEL PLANS MORE TALKS WITH U.S.
description: One of the highest-ranking members of El Salvador's leftist political opposition said today that preparations were under way for ''a meeting with an open agenda'' between the Salvadoran left and representatives of the United States Government.

title: HENRY MAYER, FILLED A MANAGEMENT ROLE AND ADVISED UNIONS
description: Henry Mayer, an authority on labor law in the telephone industry and a staunch defender of union rights and civil liberties, died Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Electrical Arcing Noted In Fatal Airliner Fire
description: A tape recording from the cockpit of Air Canada Flight 797 added new weight today to the theory that an electrical short, probably in wires to a lavatory motor, ignited the fire that killed 23 passengers in the jetliner.

title: Survey Called Biased Against Anchorwoman
description: A communications expert testified today that a viewer survey that prompted the demotion of a television anchorwoman contained biased questions and comments.

title: Testing Service Assailed at Trial
description: A lawyer for four recent high school students accused of cheating on their college entrance examinations said today that the country's largest testing service had used ''a piece of statistical garbage'' to invalidate their test scores.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP 2.6% IN JUNE
description: Spending for new construction rose 2.6 percent in June from May's level, the third consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TRACKING EL NINO: IS MORE DESTRUCTION TO COME?
description: ''STAND by to launch,'' cracks a voice over the intercom. Suddenly an explosion rocks the floor of the turboprop, a P-3, cruising high over the Pacific. ''Away,'' drones the voice above the

title: MUSIC: MOZART FESTIVAL
description: ALTHOUGH, statistically speaking, the title ''Mostly Mozart'' is something of a misnomer this year, last Friday evening's edition of New York's favorite summer music festival filled Avery Fisher Hall with some joyful noise indeed. The program opened with Mozart's neglected Symphony No. 30 in D; Alexander Schneider was at the helm, and the festival orchestra responded reflexively to his vigorous direction.

title: Futures Prices Climb For Corn and Soybeans
description: Concern over the continuing drought and heat wave in the Middle West and other grain-growing areas sent corn and soybean futures prices soaring by their daily limits yesterday before light selling at the close shaved some gains.

title: NETWORK SECURITY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: REAGAN GETS APPLAUSE AND CRITICISM
description: Black political leaders and lawyers, along with representatives of women's bar groups and civil libertarians, criticized President Reagan's speech today to the American Bar Association. At the same time, the President's message was warmly received by the 3,000 lawyers at the organization's convention.

title: Advertising; A New Ad Medium For TV
description: TELEVISION syndication, which has been a factor in the business as long as stations have needed programming, has moved into a bright new day as a major advertising medium that might some day challenge the three commercial networks.

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTHWEST AIRLINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January.

title: THE CITY;
description: New York City sold $1.15 billion in notes and bonds in the fiscal year that ended June 30, the largest amount since it returned to the credit markets four years ago, city officials said yesterday.

title: GIANTS A TEST FOR JETS' ROOKIES
description: Once, it might have been contested by hardened veterans at a pace that frightened their coaches. But as far as the Jets are concerned, next Sunday's game against the Giants will display more rookies and second- stringers than regulars looking to protect their images.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EFFORT ON AIDS CALLED FAULTY
description: There is no comprehensive Federal plan for dealing with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDs, and the delay in formulating one is due partly to the fact that many of its victims are homosexual, witnesses told a Congressional panel today.

title: AILING COE BOWS OUT OF HELSINKI
description: Sebastian Coe, after suffering four straight defeats in the last few weeks, withdrew tonight from the first World Track and Field Championships in Helsinki, Finland, because of a glandular infection.

title: JOSEPH NEWMARK DEAD AT 82
description: Joseph M. Newmark, president of Atlantic Cruise Lines, died of pneumonia yesterday at White Plains Hospital after becoming ill while visiting relatives in Westchester. Mr. Newmark was 82 years old and had lived in North Miami Beach, Fla., for the last 15 years.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical error, an article about the golfer Jack Newton in some copies of Sports Pages on Friday omitted several lines that affected the meaning. It is reprinted today on page B7.

title: Ford Callback
description: The Ford Motor Company said 725 hourly workers would be recalled from indefinite layoff over the next four weeks at its Sharonville, Ohio, transmission plant because of increased production of light trucks and mid-sized cars. But the company said 150 workers were being placed on indefinite layoff at a Livonia, Mich., plant. The Sharonville plant produces C6 automatic transmissions used in F-series pickup trucks, Econoline vans and Club Wagons, and C5 transmissions used in mid-sized LTD, Thunderbird, Marquis and Cougar autos, as well as the compact Ranger truck and new Bronco II utility vehicle.

title: Rudin in New Post
description: Jack Rudin , a realtor and the chairman of the New York City Marathon, was named by Mayor Koch yesterday as the sixth member of the city's new Sports Commission, the chairman of which is the former governor of New York, Hugh Carey . One of the commission's primary tasks is expected to be to persuade the Jets not to leave the city but to renew their Shea Stadium lease, which expires after the coming football season.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 18, 1983.

title: COMBINED NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bid on Chrysler Stock Rights
description: Two big Wall Street brokerage houses have entered the bidding to buy the Government's rights to 14.4 million shares of the Chrysler Corporation, Prudential-Bache Securities said yesterday. Prudential-Bache said it was joining with Goldman, Sachs & Company to bid for the rights, known as warrants.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: JERSEY COURT AFFIRMS LOW-INCOME HOUSING RULES
description: The power of New Jersey's three major land-use agencies to require developers to build low-income housing was affirmed today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: FOOD PEDDLERS' DIRTY DEPOTS CONCERN NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: A record number of food peddlers are thronging the midtown streets of Manhattan this summer, and some are storing and preparing food in dirty and vermin-infested depots, City Health Department records and visits to the locations show.

title: Commercial Paper At Record in June
description: Commercial paper outstanding in the United States rose by $1.62 billion in June, to a record total of $171.12 billion, seasonally adjusted, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

title: EASTMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MANHATTAN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Charlotte Curtis; A Pink Party at the Vineyard
description: FROM the beginning, everybody in Vineyard Haven, Mass., called it ''The Pink Party.'' They said the recent gathering was named for what may have been Virginia Foster Durr's childhood longing for a pink dress. Or the remembrance of a pink dress past. Or simply the desire for a pink birthday cake. But everybody knew the real reason, and they delighted in it. The Pink Party was pink in frank celebration of Mrs. Durr's politics.

title: INTERPACE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest second quarter include a pretax gain of $8,384,000, or $1.28 a share, from the sale of the company's Parsipanny, N.J., headquarters building and land and expenses of $3,531,000 related to the pending merger with Clevepak Corp.

title: CHAD REPORTS MORE LIBYAN AIR ATTACKS
description: Chad's Information Minister said today that Libyan planes had carried out new bombing raids on the northern oasis town of Faya-Largeau.

title: I.M.F. Talks In Portugal
description: An International Monetary Fund team in Lisbon for talks on a $300 million credit has stayed longer than expected because of Portuguese resistance to conditions the fund wishes to impose, Government sources said today.

description: The Security Pacific National Bank said today that it had acquired a seat on the New York Stock Exchange for $415,000 and that it expected to begin trading Friday.

title: ON THE WORTH OF MANAGERS
description: On Sunday, Walter Emmons Alston, former Dodger manager, was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame. On the same day, Mike Ferraro, hired at the beginning of the season as manager of the Indians, was fired, and Pat Corrales, fired two weeks ago by the Phillies, was hired by the Indians.

description: When the Minnesota Vikings and St. Louis Cardinals play a National Football League exhibition game Saturday at Wembley Stadium in suburban London, the field and its markings will be standard but crowd reactions may be quite different from those at American stadiums.

title: RACIAL TENSION SAID TO UNDERLIE CAMBODIAN'S DEATH IN DALLAS

description: National Public Radio went on the air today with its first fund-raising drive, four days after the network averted bankruptcy by negotiating an emergency loan from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: TIGER SETS SALE OF ITS RAIL CAR UNIT
description: Tiger International Inc., which has reported a string of large losses in recent months, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell a large portion of the assets of its only profitable operating unit to a subsidiary of the General Electric Company for about $140 million.

title: Treasury Trading Back to Old Hours The expansion of New York trading hours in the Treasury market was short-lived. Major brokers reverted late last week to a 9 A.M. opening rather than the 8 A.M. opening that began at some firms on July 12.
description: The over-the-counter market in Government securities is not bound by limits set by an exchange, so many dealers will continue to do business with foreign customers from their homes during off hours.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Agusta Aviation Corp., Philadelphia, has appointed Raffaello Teti deputy chairman, replacing Piero Fascione, who resigned.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 4 Policemen Hurt in Collision Of 2 Cars Responding to Call
description: Four policemen were injured last night when their cars collided at a Bronx intersection while rushing to answer a call, the police said.

title: G.M. Workers' Stock Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation said that 90,000 of its employees in the United States received $558 million today through the auto maker's savings- stock purchase program.

title: Market Place; Adviser Turns Less Bullish
description: EARLY on the morning of June 23, following the previous day's close at 1,245.69 for the Dow Jones industrial average, the Block Trader advised clients of a significant change in its outlook for stocks. Since its origin last November, this market timing service had taken a bullish view. But now, after analyzing various technical indicators, it envisioned a far less optimistic scenario immediately ahead for equities.

title: New President Named For Environmental Air
description: Richard V. Dempster, a longtime executive at the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, has been named president of Environmental Air Control Inc., a Hagerstown, Md., company that produces contamination control systems - ''clean rooms'' - for industry and medicine.

PREFERRED RISK LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAILER AND RANDOM HOUSE SIGN A$4 MILLION CONTRACT
description: Norman Mailer, the 60-year-old novelist who has been a major literary force since publication of ''The Naked and the Dead'' when he was 25 years old, has signed a four-book contract with Random House. According to an industry source, Random House will pay Mr. Mailer more than $4 million for all publishing rights to the books.

title: DISCLOSURE ON CIULLA CALLED 'DANGEROUS'
description: A Federal prosecutor charged today that the Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau had acted in an ''outrageous'' and ''dangerous'' manner when it revealed last week where Anthony Ciulla, the convicted race-fixer, has been living in hiding under a new identity.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY SALVADOR PARLEY IS A POSITIVE STEP
description: A meeting between President Reagan's envoy to Central America and a Salvadoran rebel leader was described by Administration officials today as a ''positive'' step. But they said it was only a ''preliminary'' move toward talks between the Salvadoran Government and the rebels.

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 18
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $547,000 for the latest first quarter and $511,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Reading and Writing
description: ''Dear Miss Spalding,'' the letter read. ''Please help me! I'm desperate right now and want an exciting, worthwhile method to get my school kids interested in reading.''

title: LUZINKSI BATTERS YANKS
description: The designated hitter for the White Sox and the lawyer for the umpires' union launched separate attacks on the Yankees tonight, with Greg Luzinski hitting a pair of two-run home runs and Richie Phillips calling for a league review of Billy Martin's behavior.

title: Salem 2 Is Shut
description: An electrical problem automatically shut down the Salem 2 nuclear power plant this morning, a day after it returned to operation Sunday, the operator of the plant said.

title: IN JAPAN, A CRIME WAVE IS MEASURED IN DROPS
description: To hear the national police tell it, Japan had better start worrying about crime.

title: Knicks Top Nets
description: Tony Simms, a sixth-round draft choice, scored 16 points to lead the Knicks to a 114-92 victory over the Nets tonight in the first game of the Princeton summer basketball league.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NIGERIA PUTS ITS COMMITMENT TO DEMOCRACY TO MAJOR TEST
description: Nigeria is now moving into the final stages of campaigning for a series of elections that will not only determine who will lead Nigeria for the next four years but will also test its commitment to democracy.

title: Tennis Payoffs
description: The director of a 16-player, $150,000 tennis tournament, the Hamlet Challenge Cup, said yesterday that he was paying appearance money to some players. The field for the Aug. 23 event in Jericho, L.I., includes some of the top professionals.

title: Judge to Provide Rules For School Bible Classes
description: Sponsors of private Bible classes in public schools said today they hope the lessons can resume this fall under guidelines from a Federal district judge who ruled against the classes in their present form.

title: Eurobonds Off In Light Selling
description: - Fixed-interest dollar bonds extended early declines by a further 1/8 point in some areas in light professional selling today, dealers said. Market sentiment remained concerned about higher United States interest rates following Friday's increase in the net borrowing position of United States banks by $64 million, to $353 million, dealers said.

title: Chess: Vlastimil Hort Is the Winner Of the Berlin Open Tourney
description: The Berlin International Open Tournament in West Germany was won by the Czech grandmaster Vlastimil Hort with an 8 1/2- 1/2 score.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MANSIONS It was a sort of elite homesteading that changed the neighborhood back in 1903 when Andrew Carnegie set up housekeeping in his new, somewhat overbearing Renaissance-Georgian mansion at 91st Street and Fifth Avenue. In 1977, the place was taken over by the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, and its halls began to echo to the tread of public feet.

title: 3 Die in Crash Of Small Plane
description: A single-engine plane crashed in a heavily wooded area of Marlborough, Conn., Sunday night, as it tried to land at a small private airfield, killing three of the four people aboard, the state police reported yesterday.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $500,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $13,500,000.

title: Clothing Retailers Now Expect Stable Prices
description: Importers and retailers, who a month ago charged that retail prices of inexpensive clothing would rise 20 percent because the Reagan Administration had limited imports of these goods from the Far East, said yesterday that the textile agreement reached with China over the weekend would keep prices stable or even lower them.

description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that apartheid in South Africa cast ''an obscene shadow on humanity as a whole.''

title: Drug Raid in Peru Nets 4 Colombian Officers
description: Four retired Colombian Air Force officers were captured by Peruvian policemen at a secret jungle airport with more than a ton of cocaine paste over the weekend in what the police said today was the largest drug seizure in Peru's history.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'JOAN' IN PERFORMED IN PARK
description: THOUGH outdoor performances of opera ordinarily eliminate opportunities for subtlety and suppleness, the unusual performance of Verdi's ''Giovanna d'Arco,'' by the New York Grand Opera under the direction of Vincent La Selva at the Central Park Bandshell on Wednesday night, did just the opposite.

title: Conair Acquisition
description: The Conair Corporation of Edison, N.J., agreed to buy Zotos International Inc., a privately owned maker of professional hair care products, for $74 million in cash and notes. The agreement is subject to expiration of the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act waiting period and other closing conditions. Conair said Ralph Evans Jr. would continue as president and chief executive of Zotos and would join Conair's board.

title: Talking Business with Mahoney of Monsanto Farm Subsidy Complications
description: Two weeks ago Richard J. Mahoney was named chief executive officer of the Monsanto Company, America's fourth-largest chemical manufacturer and a leading producer of herbicides and other agricultural products.

title: Haji-Sheikh Injures Foot
description: Ali Haji-Sheikh, the ninth-round draft choice from the University of Michigan and serious competition to Joe Danelo for the job as the Giants' kicker, injured his kicking foot during a practice this afternoon. Haji-Sheikh had just kicked off during a special-teams drill and started to follow the coverage when he slowed to a stop and said something was wrong with his heel.

title: 200 PROTESTERS SEIZED BY M.P.'S AT ARMY DEPOT
description: Military policemen arrested more than 200 women this afternoon as about 1,900 women protesting nuclear arms rallied at the Seneca Army Depot.

NEW YORK PHONE SEEKS RATE RISE OF $775 MILLION
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday asked for a $775 million rate increase that would mean an average rise of 6.6 percent in residential telephone costs in the state.

title: RUSH OF CONTRADICTORY IDEAS ON SCHOOL REFORM
description: CRITICISM of the schools and proposals on how to reform them are rushing in from all directions. This outpouring of concern is a welcome sign of public awareness after years of indifference. But the mass of proposals and the contradictory remedies could well neutralize each other. A confused public may grow impatient with all the talk and countertalk, and tune out again. Then, nothing would happen beyond some minor cosmetic readjustments. It may therefore help to lay out some of the options of what is being proposed.

title: 20 Die in Bangladesh Bus
description: A passenger bus collided head on with a truck today, killing 20 people and injuring about 50 others. The crash occurred at Bhaluka, some 45 miles west of Dhaka as the bus was headed to the district town of Mymensingh.

title: Bank Reopens In Tennessee
description: The First Peoples Bank of Washington County, the ninth Tennessee bank to fail this year, reopened today as the First American National Bank-Eastern.

title: HALFWAY HOUSE FOR RENT IN DISPUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFIDENT PORT CHIEF
description: When Navy officials start to navigate their way through the New York City bureacracy, advancing their plan to make Staten Island the home port for a seven-ship force led by the battleship Iowa, Susan Frank will be their pilot. ''It's going to move quickly,'' Miss Frank said yesterday of the home port plan - the biggest municipal maritime development in years - just before Mayor Koch swore her in as the city's Commissioner of Ports and Terminals.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $115,000. c-Net loss.

title: RECTIFER RE-EMPHASIZES ELECTRONICS
description: Standards are so strict in the semiconductor manufacturing plant owned by the International Rectifier Corporation here that a specialized ventilation system changes the air seven times a minute and only the faces of the technicians are left uncovered by sanitized clothing.

title: ARTHUR CONAN DOYLE IS PILTDOWN SUSPECT
description: RESEARCH sleuths have a new prime suspect in the case of the Piltdown Man, the most celebrated hoax in the history of science. He is none other than the creator of that master detective, Sherlock Holmes - Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

title: BOXER'S BIG FIGHT IS AGAINST TIME
description: Contemplating retirement, but not quite resigned to it, Teddy Mann watched a tape of his best fight. It was last January in Hancock's Bridge, N.J., and he was with his wife, Leah, who had left it to him alone to decide about his future. They sat in the living room of their new home that was in need of renovation at considerable expense. Mann, once the World Boxing Association's eighth-ranked middleweight, had applied for maintenance work at a nearby power plant.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to give effect to the merger with Chemical Data Systems on May 31, 1982.

description: Less than three years ago, Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, was under heavy pressure from the Federal Government to find a merger partner. The problem, he complained at the time, was that ''nobody wants to dance.''

title: Clerc Sets Back Gomez in Final
description: Jose-Luis Clerc continued his clay-court winning streak today as he defeated Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 6-3, 6-1, in the final of the $255,000 Volvo tennis tournament.

title: FOLK-POP: A STADIUM FULL OF SIMON AND GARFUNKEL
description: AN arena the size of Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., hardly seems like a desirable place to hear music as delicate and wistful as Simon and Garfunkel's brand of urban folk-pop. Yet using a 30-foot- wide television screen and an excellent 400-unit speaker system, Simon and Garfunkel were able to create an absorbingly intimate atmosphere there on Sunday. More than 49,000 people attended the concert, which is part of the duo's first American tour in 13 years.

title: NEW YORK SAYS IT CUT TOO MANY FROM ITS PAYROLL
description: Governor Cuomo cut too many people from the state work force and now must hire new workers to fill some of the vacancies he created, state officials said today.

title: Datatronic Moving to U.S.
description: The head of Sweden's leading manufacturer of computer programs, Datatronic, said today he was moving the company's main operations to the United States to protest a Government proposal to impose a new tax on profits. Mats Gabrielsson, Datatronic's managing director, said he expected other companies to follow Datatronic's example if the Government went ahead with plans to set up union-controlled investment funds at the expense of companies.

Union members on Saturday rejected the company's contract offer 6,073 to 537. The strike vote followed about four months of negotiations.

description: Ivan A. Benediktov, a top farm official under Stalin who later came under criticism and served as Ambassador to India and Yugoslavia, died Thursday at the age of 81, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.

Larry Micheaux, a 6-foot-9-inch rookie forward from the University of Houston, signed a three-year contract with the Kansas City Kings.

POLAND: PLANNING A DISASTER
description: In recent weeks, the Polish Government has lifted martial law, released 53 political prisoners and promised amnesty for hundreds of others. With this and a flurry of new ''special regulations,'' Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski hopes to achieve at least the appearance of national reconciliation. In reality, these policies are a prescription for yet another explosion of Polish unrest, perhaps more violent than any in the past.

title: Japanese Win
description: Japan defeated Guam today, 3-0, and, with a 5-0 record, won the Far East Little League baseball championship. Japan will represent the region in the Little League World Series at Williamsport, Pa., Aug. 22-26. The victory ended a six-year control of the region by Taiwan, which lost to Japan, 2-0, last Thursday.

description: After relinquishing his chance for an Olympic medal by signing a professional football contract, the sprinter Stanley Floyd was cut by the Atlanta Falcons yesterday. The 22- year-old Floyd, who holds National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor records in the 50-yard and 55-meter dashes and competed in college for Auburn and Houston, signed as a free agent with the Falcons last spring. He had not played football since his junior year in high school.

title: No Headline
description: THE FIFTH GENERATION. Artificial Intelligence and Japan's Computer Challenge to the World. By Edward A. Feigenbaum and Pamela McCorduck. 275 pages. Illustrated with diagrams. Addison-Wesley. $15.75. THIS isn't just another of those books that says Japan is better than we are and therefore is going to keep on whipping us in productivity. ''The Fifth Generation'' goes considerably further than that. It points with a trembling finger at Japan's commitment to produce within a decade a new generation of computers so immensely powerful that they will in effect constitute a new and revolutionary form of wealth.
