'SAFE' FORM OF RADIATION AROUSES NEW WORRY
description: UNLIKE the dangerous ionizing radiation emitted by nuclear fission and X-rays, the nonionizing radiation that issues from radio transmitters, radar, electric power lines, microwave ovens and a vast array of modern devices has long been considered relatively safe. But a spate of recent scientific reports has fueled concern that low doses of nonionizing radiation can cause subtle biological effects in humans and animals that might, conceivably, cause health damage as well.

title: FLEET WILSON STEALS THE GAME FOR METS
description: Mookie Wilson's chief offensive tool has been his ability to steal bases. On Sunday, the Mets' fleet center fielder did something new: He stole a run.

title: SUMMONSES FOR NOT CLEANING UP AFTER DOGS INCREASE SHARPLY
description: In the first six months of this year, the number of summonses issued by the Sanitation Department to people who fail to clean up after their dogs has already far surpassed the number it issued during the the first full year the law was in effect.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 2, 1983
description: International

title: Job Offers to Graduates Said to Decline Sharply
description: The improvement in the nation's economy has not helped this year's college graduates, who have encountered a sharp decrease in the number of job offers, according to a survey by the College Placement Council.

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OMNIMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $90,000 from discontinued operations. c-After income of $200,000 for the quarter from discontinued operations and a loss of $134,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXPLORATION SURVEYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $150,999 for the quarter and $427,246 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $3,619. d-Net income.

title: CARLTON STRIKES OUT 12 CUBS
description: Steve Carlton struck out 12 and earned his 295th career victory tonight as he pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: ZIMBABWEANS EXPEL A BBC CREW UNDER A NEW CURB ON JOURNALISTS
description: The Zimbabwe Government ordered a three-man BBC television team to leave the country today under a day-old decree by six black African nations barring entry to journalists based in South Africa.

title: 30 YEARS AFTER THE ARMISTICE: SEOUL'S HALF-MIRACLE
description: Three decades after the armistice that ended the Korean War on July 27, 1953, South Korea is half a miracle come true.

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: The attorney conceded that his client, the tennis champion Martina Navratilova , was guilty of speeding. But he argued that she was innocent of a second charge - cursing a police officer - because her language was ''constitutionally protected'' free speech.

title: 50% BRITISH STAKE IN ROTHSCHILD
description: L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, the Wall Street firm, said yesterday that a British group would invest $33.6 million to double its stake in the firm, to 50 percent.

title: NEW SOFTWARE FOR SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING
description: RECENTLY a reader wrote to ask if I was feeling all right, since a number of software reviews from my pen of late have been actually favorable. Though I receive many more letters than I can respond to individually, I would like to assure this particular correspondent that everything is, indeed, ticking along as usual up here at the farm-cum-computer parlor. I mention it now because what follows is an overview of another remarkable software product.

title: KROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
JOHN S. TENNANT 2D, COUNSEL FOR UNITED STATES STEEL, DIES
description: John S. Tennant 2d, a former general counsel of the United States Steel Corporation who was active in providing legal aid for the poor, died Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 77 years old and had homes in Summit and in Rainbow Lake, N.Y., and St. Croix, V.I.

title: WEBB, DEL E, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Sohio Raises Price of Oil
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) raised its selling price yesterday for Alaskan North Slope crude oil by between 50 cents and $1 a barrel following similar moves by Mexico, Iran and Venezuela, industry sources said. Sohio officials could not be reached for comment.

title: Failures Up In Houston
description: Despite predictions of a turnaround in Houston's oil-shattered economy, business failures continue to rise, and the effect is beginning to be felt in the overbuilt commercial real estate sector.

title: Morgan Rebuffed In Archer Case
description: A Federal judge in New York has denied an application by Morgan Stanley & Company to block the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company's redemption of its 16 percent debentures due in 2011.

title: PHOENIX STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results are restated for an accounting change.

title: MARYLAND CUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in January 1983.

title: FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $699,000 for the quarter and a loss of $6.4 million for the year from discontinued operations.

title: REPORT PLAYS DOWN CLASS DIVISION AMONG BLACKS
description: A report issued today by the National Urban League challenged the perception that class differences are creating an ever- widening gulf among black Americans.

title: The Monrovski Doctrine?
description: The Administration has set out to engage Nicaragua in what was called brinkmanship in the days of John Foster Dulles.

title: CORDURA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IOWA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $1,443,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LISBON'S CHIEF TACKLES HARD TIMES
description: ''It is not very pleasant to govern Portugal at this time,'' Mario Soares, the new Socialist Prime Minister, said a few weeks ago.

title: IT TAKES MORE THAN MONEY TO CONQUER DISEASES LIKE AIDS
description: MIGHT the infusion of more money for biomedical research at an earlier point in the epidemic of acquired immune deficiency syndrome have led to the discovery of its cause and produced a cure by now?

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Injuries Take Toll
description: The Miami Dolphins, defending American Football Conference champions, have lost their outstanding cornerback, Don McNeal , for at least two months. McNeal ruptured his Achilles' tendon in a scrimmage Saturday. . . . Joe Senser , the Minnesota Vikings' all-pro tight end, was reportedly scheduled to undergo knee surgery and would be lost to the team for at least eight weeks.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE OF NEW MEXCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RATE PARITY MAY SPARK MONEY ACCOUNT BATTLES
description: The equalization of rates paid by money market mutual funds and their archrivals, money market deposit accounts at banks and savings associations, is likely to spark an increase in the already fierce competition between the two popular savings devices.

title: HEALTH-MOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GIBSON-HOMANS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid July 27, 1983.

title: TEXAS ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
RESTAURANT GUIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: PURCHASE OF U.S. GRAIN: SHIFR IN SOVIET STRATEGY
description: The Soviet decision to buy at least nine million metric tons of American grain a year between 1983 and 1988 reflected a shrewd assessment of domestic requirements, including a need to rebuild depleted reserves and to strengthen livestock herds, according to Western agricultural experts here.

title: Debt Issues
description: Ryland Acceptance Corp. filed an offering of $250 million of G.N.M.A.- collateralized bonds, series A, due in 2013.

title: TV: 'REGGIE,' MIDLIFE CRISIS COMEDY
description: REGGIE has problems - sexual, professional and familial. To cope, he has fantasies, none lingering, all fleeting, the stuff of which sight gags are made. Reggie, 47 years old, is afflicted by midlife crisis. He is the title character in ''Reggie,'' a new ABC series, which airs its first episode at 9:30 tonight. On Thursday, the series will move into its regular time period at 9.

title: PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes equity in the earnings of the Westmoreland Coal Co.

title: FIRST CAROLINA INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $325,000 for the 6 months.

title: TIMES HAVE CHANGED, BUT STOCKMAN IS STILL STRONG
description: The heady days of being both star and czar of economic policy seem to be over for David A. Stockman.

title: UNLIKELY SETTING FOR A CONSPIRACY IN RETAILING
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN A LIBRARY PLANS A MAJOR PURCHASE
description: To the Editor:

title: DECA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bamberger Fine, Has No Regrets
description: ''I'm feeling good, I've got myself back together,'' George Bamberger said yesterday, about two months after he had resigned as manager of the Mets. Speaking from New Freedom, Pa., at the home of his daughter, Nancy, who is expecting her third child in a few days, Bamberger said that his project for the afternoon of his 58th birthday was cutting the grass in his daughter's backyard.

title: Philbin Is Saved
description: Gerry Philbin, the former Jet defensive lineman, was in satisfactory condition at Central General Hospital today after nearly drowning Saturday in the swimming pool at his home in Asharoken, L.I.

title: UNOFFICIALLY, THE BATTLE IS ON IN IOWA
description: Last month, after President Reagan selected former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to head a commission on Central America, the office of Senator Roger W. Jepsen issued an unusual news release criticizing ''another Iowa lawmaker.''

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $73,000.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Angolan Rebels Say 78 Died in Attack on Train
description: Angolan guerrillas said today that 78 people were killed and 319 were hurt when a train carrying Government troops and Cuban advisers was destroyed by a mine in eastern Angola last week.

title: EMERGENCY PLANS ARE MADE AS L.I.R.R. TALKS CONTINUE
description: As the Long Island Rail Road and four of its unions continued negotiations yesterday, Nassau and Suffolk Counties announced emergency transportation plans to take effect in the event of a strike, threatened for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Fancy and Plain
description: In its way it was as if Tiffany's had advertised rhinestones or Brooks Brothers had pushed Italian suits.

title: Misplaced Energy; Speed the Oil for the Nation's Reserve
description: The Senate has a rare opportunity to rectify egregious inconsistency in the Administration's energy policy. It can urge haste in filling the nation's strategic petroleum reserve now that oil prices are at rock bottom while supply, as always, is subject to crisis in the Middle East. And it can impose restraint on the hurried leasing of Federal coal, most of which will not be needed for another decade.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After a tax credit of $31,000. c-Net loss

title: NEW DATA DOUBLE AGE OF GALAPAGOS
description: STUDENTS of evolution have long marveled at the speed with which species inhabiting the Galapagos Islands evolved into forms very different from their relatives elsewhere. The islands, scientists have believed, first rose from the sea a comparatively short 1.5 million years ago.

title: Scali Gets Don Q Rum
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which in early July won the Harvey Bristol Cream Sherry business from the Heublein bundle that had been resigned by D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/ New York, has been tapped for Don Q Puerto Rican Rum. It will do the English-language advertising for Don Q, which had also been in the bundle. Leading National Advertisers, which measures advertiser media spending, could only find less than $1 million spent on Don Q last year.

title: Arkla-Sonat Deal
description: Arkla Inc. of Shreveport, La., said it had agreed to supply Sonat Inc.'s Southern Natural Gas Company subsidiary up to 1.5 trillion cubic feet of gas over 15 years under a contract beginning in November 1985. Arkla said the transaction, the largest in the company's history, could yield the company gross revenues of from $5 billion to $7 billion at current sales prices.

title: Christiaan Barnard Retiring
description: Dr. Christiaan Barnard, who performed the first human heart transplant 15 years ago, is retiring at the age of 60 because arthritis has impaired the use of his hands. Dr. Barnard has asked to take early retirement as chief specialist in the heart surgery department at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town.

title: NEW YORK HOSPITAL UNVEILS ADVANCED DIAGNOSTIC TOOL
description: The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center has become the first hospital in the metropolitan region to acquire a high-powered magnet that may make it possible in some cases to forgo surgery and other painful methods of diagnosis.

title: HEALTH CARE FUND reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ADACORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $287,000.

title: Pacer Sets Mark
description: Sansom posted a track record for 2-year-old pacers with a time of 1:55 2/5 for the mile tonight at the Meadowlands and led 11 other qualifiers into the $1.7 million Woodrow Wilson Pace next Monday.

title: CAPITOL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Iran Announces Boycott Of the 1984 Olympics
description: Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi of Iran has announced that Iran will boycott the 1984 Olympic Games to be held in Los Angeles, the official Iranian press agency reported.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW COOLING SYSTEM HAS POTENTIAL IN SPACE
description: Officials at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory have disclosed a method of refrigeration that generates temperatures as low as minus 424 degrees Fahrenheit without the use of electricity and with few moving parts.

title: Highwire Magazine Gets a New Name
description: Highwire magazine, which got its name from the idea that teenagers are walking a tightrope between adolescence and adulthood, will change the name to Teenage with its October issue.

title: REAGAN STRONGLY DEFENDS POLICIES ON MINORITY AND WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: The Reagan Administration has sharply reduced the size of the Department of Education in the past two years and is planning to cut back Government programs that promote school desegregation and educational opportunities for women, according to department officials and agency documents.

title: GULF ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Keeping Informed
description: Gale Catlett , the West Virginia University basketball coach, said he learned by reading Florida newspapers on a recent vacation that his program was under investigation by the N.C.A.A. for possible recruiting violations. ''There's a difference between an investigation and an inquiry,'' said Catlett, whose program was censured and reprimanded last year by the N.C.A.A. for minor violations.

title: Arvida Sale Set
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had proposed to sell in a public offering a majority of its equity in the Arvida Corporation, its wholly owned real estate development subsidiary.

title: SRI LANKA ROUNDS UP LEFTIST PARTY MEMBERS
description: The Government rounded up members of three banned leftist political parties today and temporarily lifted a nationwide curfew, giving people the chance to buy food after a week of ethnic fighting in which more than 200 people have been reported killed.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $500,000 from the sale of store properties.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When Peter G. Peterson surprised Wall Street last week with the announcement that he was stepping down as chairman and co-chief executive of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., he added that he would be going into partnership with Eli S. Jacobs. The question for many was, ''Eli who?''

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GULF UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $528,000 for the quarter and $81,000 for the 6 months. c-Including capital gains of $10,000 for the quarter and $28,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary credit of $5.6 million for the quarter and 6 months from an exchange of stock for debentures.

title: RECORDING OF SUSPECTS PLAYED AT U.S. BRINK'S TRIAL
description: A tape-recorded conversation of two suspects discussing what the prosecution described as plans to kill two informers was played yesterday at the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan.

title: PATRICK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,250,000 from the sale of assets.

title: F.C.C. EXPECTED TO ALTER RULES ON SYNDICATION
description: The Federal Communications Commission is expected this week to approve a compromise on changing its financial interest and syndication rules for television programs following hearings today by the House Telecommunications Subcommittee on whether to block any F.C.C. action.

title: GREENSPAN URGES ACTION ON DEFICIT
description: Alan Greenspan, a New York economist with close ties to the Reagan Administration, today called for an economic summit meeting between the Congress and the White House to work out a political agreement to lower Federal budget deficits.

title: NEW YORK STATE'S COSTLY RETIREMENT LURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble at Home
description: Trouble has struck behind the plate for the Los Angeles Dodgers, whose only healthy catcher is a rookie named Jack Fimple . Fimple played in his first major league game Sunday, replacing Steve Yeager after Yeager suffered a fractured right wrist when hit by a pitch during the first game of a doubleheader in San Francisco.

title: SECURITY WEAKENS
description: Six different armies were involved in clashes inside Lebanon today, underlining the steady deterioration of the country's security situation.

title: Hart Takes Credit Line At Saudi-Owned Bank
description: Senator Gary Hart, an aspirant for the Democratic nomination, has borrowed $350,000 from a Saudi-owned bank in Washington to help finance his 1984 campaign, an aide says.

title: REAGAN CALLS FOR 'NO HOLDS BARRED' EXAMINATION OF HUNGER REPORTS
description: President Reagan said today that he was perplexed at reports of people going hungry in the United States despite Federal programs to help them and he directed a group of experts to examine the reported increasing hunger.

title: NEW-HOME SALES SLID 2.9% IN JUNE
description: Sales of new single-family houses dropped 2.9 percent in June from the May level, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 638,000, the Government reported today.

title: RAYMOND INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. VETOES A U.N. CENSURE OF ISRAELIS OVER SETTLEMENTS
description: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution that said Israel's settlement policies in the occupied Arab lands ''have no legal validity'' and ''constitute a major and serious obstruction'' to peace.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CANCER GROUPS URGES X-RAY BREAST TESTS IN YOUNGER WOMEN
description: The American Cancer Society announced new guidelines yesterday for breast cancer detection, stating that women 40 to 49 years old should now have regular mammograms. It previously recommended the specialized X-ray technique on a routine basis only for women over 50.

title: STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for 1983 reflect the June operations of the newly acquired Enesco Imports Corp.

title: TOP HEALTH OFFICIAL REBUTE BIAS CHARGE IN COMBATING AIDS
description: Reagan Administration officials today denied that prejudice against homosexuals was slowing the fight against the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS. They also outlined steps the Government had taken to combat the disease.

title: Digital Purchase
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, Maynard, Mass., said it agreed to buy preferred stock representing a 9 percent stake in Trilogy Ltd. for $26 million. Digital also acquired an option to license advanced semiconductor technology from Trilogy. Gene M. Amdahl is chairman of Trilogy.

title: MEDICAL SOCIETY ADOPTS MISCONDUCT GUIDELINES
description: The Medical Society of the State of New York yesterday issued its first guidelines for investigating and reporting complaints of incompetence or misconduct by physicians.

title: TV CO-ANCHOR TESTIFIES ABOUT PAY
description: Brenda Williams, who replaced Christine Craft as co-anchor at KMBC-TV in August 1981, testified today that the station management gave her the impression that they would never pay a woman newscaster as much as a man.

title: 'Little Odessa'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Registered Dietitians
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: POP: MEN AT WORK
description: MEN AT WORK did a smart thing in its show Monday at Pier 84. Instead of trying to copy its records, which have sold in the millions, the Australian pop band kept making small changes in the arrangements.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TENTATIVE PACT IS REACHED IN L.I.R.R. DISPUTE
description: The Long Island Rail Road and four of its unions announced tentative agreement on new contracts early this morning, averting a strike that had been scheduled to begin at midnight last night.

title: Chrysler Credit Line
description: The Chrysler Corporation is investigating ways of raising cash or credit to terminate a Government lien on its assets in moves, financial sources say, that could lead to a connection with a foreign company.

title: TEXTBOOK DEBATE BROADENS IN TEXAS
description: Groups asserting that American education has been undermined by what they see as censorship by political and religious conservatives opened a concerted counterattack today.

description: Lonrho P.L.C. should sign a contract with the Government of Tanzania in about two weeks to recover about $13.5 million in assets nationalized in 1978, a company spokesman said today.

title: THE VICTORIES OVER NEWBORNS' DISABILITIES
description: To the Editor:

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock Exchanges. There were 117.3 million shares outstanding in the latest quarter against 113.1 million shares in year-ago period.

title: Ex-Executive Becomes Cheese Entrepreneur
description: Much of the entrepreneurship these days is in high technology. But that does not mean there are not opportunites in other businesses. Cheese, for instance.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Q & A
description: Q. On many occasions I would have liked to serve a hot souffle as dessert for guests but was inhibited by the timing. Can a souffle be prepared for the oven in advance?

title: House Backs Holiday On Dr. Kings Birthday
description: The House today passed a bill making the Jan. 15 anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. a national holiday to honor ''a person who shook the moral conscience of this nation.'' The vote was 338 to 90.

title: Sardinia Sentences 39 In Red Brigades Trial
description: A court convicted 39 people today of forming a Red Brigades terrorist cell on this Mediterranean island and sentenced two of them to life imprisonment for killing a policeman.

title: Aamco Withdrawing Guarantee Commercial
description: The Aamco Transmissions commercial that talks about a guarantee for ''the life of the car'' is going to be withdrawn by the company at the request of New York State's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, who characterized it as misleading.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago 6 months earnings were favorably impacted by a nonrecurring gain of $28 million, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of equity interest in United Kingdom affiliate. Both quarters include insurance and finance revenue of $1.5 billion. The 6-month figures include insurance and finance revenue of $2.9 billion for the latest period and $3 billion for the year-earlier period. There were 149 million shares outstanding in the latest quarter compared with 147 million shares in the year-earlier period.

title: DANGER FOR G.O.P. IN 1984
description: Does the Republican Party still represent the creditor class and financial markets - and their disinflationary demands? Or must it, as Representative Jack Kemp and other ''Populist'' conservatives suggest, abandon the economics of pain and embrace constituencies demanding economic stimulus? The outcome of this debate, now dividing the Reagan Administration, will be a crucial factor in the 1984 elections.

description: b-Net loss.

Walesa Said to Deny Being Pressed by Pope
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity labor union, denied in an interview made public today that Pope John Paul II urged him during their meeting in Poland last June to retire from politics.

title: Museum Group Favors Repatriation of Relics
description: The International Council of Museums today called for the return of important relics to their countries of origin, a move Greek officials interpreted as support for their claim to the Elgin Marbles.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $659,000.

title: REAGAN'S PATH TO WAR
description: Unless he is stopped by Congress - and only Congress and the force of public opinion can stop him - Ronald Reagan could plunge this country into the most unwanted, unconscionable, unnecessary and unwinnable war in its history, not excepting Vietnam.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Eighteen years ago, when the Federal Government took over the Ocean Manor apartments here through a mortgage foreclosure, the 10-story complex was considered a white elephant - a home for moderate-income elderly people in the shabbiest part of a shabby city.

'Jedi' Tops $200 Million; Fox Says It's a Record
description: ''Return of the Jedi'' has exceeded $200 million in ticket sales and 20th Century-Fox today acclaimed it the fastest money-making film in history.

description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. takes issue with those who, in his words, think of the Senate as ''an all-male, vested-suited, Gucci-loafered, silver-haired private club.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Iowa Changes Slogan For Auto License Plates
description: Worried that it would be misunderstood or even ridiculed, Iowa transportation commissioners have reversed themselves and voted not to put the slogan ''Iowa: A State of Minds'' on license plates.

description: Rumblings coming in from east of Times Square have it that Commodore Business Machines, now that it has split with Ally & Gargano, one of the nation's outstanding advertising agencies, could be returning to Kornhauser & Calene, which had previously done the usual brief tour that a Commodore agency usually does.

title: BUMBLE HUMBLES YANKS
description: When The Case of the Excessively Pine Tarred Bat burst on the public last week I made a bet with myself that somebody would call it ''Batgate'' before the week was out, and collected a few hours later while listening to a man read the sports news on a New York TV station.

title: Drug Fight Urged
description: Baseball officials and other sports authorities may be starting to get tough with athletes who use drugs, but according to John Candelaria , the Pittsburgh Pirate pitcher, they are not being tough enough. ''They should say, 'Hey, if you get caught, you're out of baseball' '' said Candelaria, who complained specifically about what he considers the lenient treatment given Steve Howe , the Los Angeles Dodger pitcher, who was fined after he continued to use cocaine after rehabilitation treatment.

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Canadian Banks Raise U.S. Prime
description: The Royal Bank of Canada yesterday raised its United States base lending rate, or prime rate, to 11 percent, from 10 3/4 percent, and was later followed by the Bank of Montreal. Last Friday, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce moved to 11 percent.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pretax charge of $74.5 million for the closing of two plants. c-Including a gain of $17.2 million for the quarter and 6 months on the retirement of debentures. Year-ago results have been restated for the Celeron merger.

TRIAL OPENS IN U.S. LAWSUIT AGAINST YONKERS OVER BIAS
description: The Federal Government, in a landmark civil-rights suit that charges discrimination in housing and education, opened its case yesterday against the City of Yonkers and its Board of Education.

title: Wickes Toy Sale
description: Wickes Companies Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif., said it has sold the assets of its Toy World division for about $5.5 million to the Kay-Bee Toy unit of the Melville Corporation.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE comes a time in almost everyone's life when it is necessary, desirable or merely common sense to hide something. This urge to conceal usually happens just before taking off on a trip or before going out of town for a long weekend, when it seems like a good idea to put credit cards and jewelry that won't be needed in some place that will outfox a possible intruder.

title: AMEX LINK TO CHICAGO BOARD SET
description: The American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday announced an agreement that gives members of each exchange trading rights to the other's stock index products.

title: WHITE IS ACCUSED BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: A senior South African security official said today that an exiled white Communist had planned the May 20 car bombing in Pretoria that killed 19 people, including the two blacks who planted the bomb.

description: International

description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 50 percent stock dividend paid last month.

description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in July.

title: REVIVAL IN STEEL ORDERS STALLS
description: After their worst year in more than two decades, steel manufacturers were suddenly deluged with new orders in February and March. Certain that the worst was over, manufacturers restarted dormant blast furnaces and expressed confidence that 1983 would be the year of steel's comeback.

title: Suspect in Plot to Sell Arms Also Faces New York Charges
description: A 45-year-old Brooklyn man jailed last week on Federal charges of conspiring to sell arms to Iran and the Irish Republican Army has been indicted on state charges of conspiring to provide weapons to undercover police officers posing as terrorists.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: Certain-so-called natural alliances in food are flavors that complement each other when put together. Juniper berries, for example, complement game, a Madeira sauce goes well with boiled tongue and a little nutmeg always adds tantalizing character to melted-cheese dishes.

description: The nation's governors ended their annual meeting here today with a partisan skirmish over how far they should go in condemning President Reagan's economic policies.

description: CHIAT/DAY of Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York has just moved onto the Bristol- Myers agency roster. And, considering the fact that the huge toiletries, health and beauty aids and pharmaceuticals company spends more than $200 million a year domestically on advertising, that's not a bad place to be.

title: CONCERT: PETER GABRIEL
description: PETER GABRIEL cut an unusual figure onstage at Forest Hills Stadium on Friday. For a rock singer just now reaching the stadium circuit in the United States, Mr. Gabriel was peculiarly self-effacing, almost egoless.

title: CONCERT: MOSTLY MOZART
description: the horn soloist Monday night at the Mostly Mozart festival concert in Avery Fisher Hall - appeared, at first, to be casually making his way through Weber's Concertino for Horn and Orchestra in E minor (Op. 45), displaying a patrician virtuosity. But that musical demeanor went along with sophisticated and refined instincts; the music itself emerged with crisp integrity.

title: Security Cameras Tested on Buses
description: Surveillance cameras similar to those used in banks and department stores have been installed in seven N.J. Transit buses in an experiment designed to improve passenger safety, the state agency said Tuesday.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: NOW it begins, the angst of August, the subject of novels, the time when the guardians of our psyches depart collectively for Truro and the Hamptons and other watering places, leaving the patients high and dry.

title: BASSETT-WALKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EX-HEAD OF ARNOLD CONSTABLE
description: Isaac Liberman, former president and chairman of Arnold Constable Inc. and a civic leader and philanthropist, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97 years old.

title: IN SOVIET, THE DEATH PENALTY PERSISTS WITHOUT ANY DEBATE
description: The reports of death sentences in the Soviet Union have a sameness to them.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,185,497 for the quarter and $1,256,888 for the year.

title: OSBORNE CLOSES PLANT
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation, one of the pioneers in the market for personal portable computers, said yesterday that it had closed its manufacturing plant in Monmouth Junction, N.J. Analysts said the move indicated a weakening of demand for the closely held company's products, and was further evidence of its reported cash-flow problems.

title: MINNESOTA LAW MANDATES BYSTANDER HELP IN CRISIS
description: Being a ''Good Samaritan'' is now a duty, not an option, in Minnnesota, where a new provision in state statutes provides up to a $100 fine for people who fail to aid in an emergency.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK BIDS FOR NORTHEAST BANCORP
description: The Bank of New York Company and the Northeast Bancorp of Connecticut announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge, despite a state law prohibiting mergers of New York and Connecticut banks.

title: THE DANCE: AMOS HETZ
description: THERE are a number of systems of dance notation that record, in graphic symbols, the steps, gestures and timing that make up a particular dance or movement sequence. Last Saturday at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio, Amos Hetz, a visiting dancer and lecturer from Jerusalem, presented 15 duets and a solo he had choreographed through the use of the Eshkol-Wachman Movement Notation System. It was an interesting evening.

title: STANLEY DANCER BOUNCES BACK
description: He had never given his name to a horse, and he had never given his heart so completely to a horse, either. There were tombstones for seven of his greatest horses at his farm in New Jersey, but Stanley Dancer never dreamed there would be an eighth so soon.

title: SHULTZ'S FIRST YEAR
description: George Shultz has just completed his first year as Secretary of State. He has been here before as Secretary of Labor (1969-70), Director of Management and Budget (1970-72), Secretary of the Treasury and Assistant to the President (1972- 74). And at age 62, he has obviously learned something about the wayward ways of officials and reporters, and knows how to talk about his job without saying too much.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''VIDEO KILLED THE RADIO STAR'' was a modest hit for a duo called Buggles a few years back. It was a pleasant tune, too chirpy and lightweight to be taken seriously. But from today's perspective, ''Video Killed the Radio Star'' was positively prophetic. Almost overnight, it seems, promotional video clips have become the most effective and highly publicized means of introducing new pop music and new pop artists to the record-buying public.

description: A Hempstead couple unable to have children of their own adopted six children today, all with emotional problems or learning disabilities.

title: MANAGING THE BOOKS INTERNALLY
description: IN announcing a new code of ethics for management accountants, Charles T. Smith Jr., president of the National Association of Accountants, declared recently: ''Management fraud can be attacked.''

title: Challenger Moved to Pad
description: Crews delivered the space shuttle Challenger to its launching pad today and began checks in preparation for the first nighttime launching of a shuttle on Aug. 30.

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 3, 1983
description: Markets

title: Honduran Leader's Condition Is Grave After Heart Attacks
description: President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras had two heart attacks within 12 hours and is in ''grave'' but improving condition, doctors said today.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*Piecework Fashion

title: JOHN I. BROKAW
description: John I. Brokaw, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Midshipmen Pause On Summer Cruise
description: Sunlight glinted off the East River as two patrol craft docked yesterday at the Water Club, at 30th Street, disembarking about 80 midshipmen - including half a dozen women - in brilliant whites.

title: 7 SOUTH ASIAN LANDS DECIDE TO WORK FOR REGIONAL 'SELF-RELIANCE'
description: Representatives of seven South Asian nations today formally launched a move for closer regional cooperation among their countries to promote ''collective self-reliance'' in nine areas including agriculture, telecommunications and science and technology.

title: Jacobs Purchase
description: Irwin Jacobs, the Minneapolis businessman who heads a company specializing in merchandise liquidation, has bought into a similar company in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. Mr. Jacobs and Theodore Deikel, former executive vice president of the American Can Company, acquired a half interest in C.O.M.B. Inc. Spokesmen declined to reveal the purchase price. The company is now equally owned by Mr. Jacobs, Mr. Deikel, C.O.M.B.'s chairman, Dennis Carlson, and its president, J. Clinton Shaver. C.O.M.B. sales were $22.7 million last year.

title: REPUBLICANS BAR PANEL'S BID TO VOTE ON A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today prevented Democrats from voting on a resolution calling for a ''mutual and verifiable freeze'' in nuclear armaments.

title: Default on Energy Management Debt
description: Energy Management Corporation, a Denver-based company, said it is in default on $785,000 worth of monthly principal payments and $322,000 in interest payments.The company's bank loans have an outstanding balance of $25 million, but a company spokesman said the banks are not planning any immediate action, though they have reserved the right to demand payment. Energy Management is planning to present a debt restructuring proposal by early September.

title: Sale of 2 Large Buildings in Manhattan Stirs Interest
description: About Real Estate

title: Political Fund Paid Jane Byrne's Husband
description: Former Mayor Jane M. Byrne paid her husband, Jay McMullen, $166,000 from her political fund last year, an amount nearly three times her salary, campaign data show.

title: Tax Fraud Figure Fights Prison
description: The wife of a diamond company owner, serving time for her part in a $5 million fraud, filed suit yesterday to block her transfer to a West Virginia prison, where she says she was sexually attacked and mistreated.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Complaints on Pills

title: Burial Rites for David Niven Held in Small Swiss Village
description: The actor David Niven was buried today in this tiny Swiss mountain resort after modest ceremonies attended by his family, Prince Rainier of Monaco, the actress Audrey Hepburn and other friends.

title: Bridge: Stasha Cohen of New York Winner
description: One might reasonably suppose that impending maternity would be a handicap in card-playing, but the reverse seems to be true. The most notable case involving an expert occurred in 1966, when Sue Sachs finished second in the world women's pairs in Amsterdam and flew back to her home in Baltimore in the nick of time.

title: Delay Seen in Boston Vote
description: Elections scheduled this fall to choose members of the City Council and the School Committee faced almost certain postponement after a Federal District judge refused to reconsider his earlier ruling that new districts, challenged by black and Hispanic groups, were improperly drawn and violated the principle of one man, one vote. Today Judge Andrew Caffrey ruled that all parties had agreed to the facts in the case and reconsideration was thus moot. The case has been appealed.

title: Limit on Role of Banks Urged
description: The Security Pacific National Bank's purchase of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange ''highlights the current confusion'' over the role of banks and securities firms, the president of the Securities Industry Association said yesterday.

description: A $7.6 billion appropriations bill for the Interior Department has been snarled in a debate over whether Congress should become involved in the multibillion-dollar bond default of the Washington Public Power Supply System.

FOR PARIS, 'A RESTAURANT IN YOUR HOME'
description: The pen drawing on the company's logotype shows a chef in a fluffy white toque and apron pedaling a delivery cart. The ''chef'' is a French banker who is pioneering home delivery of meals in an attempt to provide weary Parisians with the kind of service New Yorkers enjoy.

title: U.S. Warship Is Said to Hail Soviet Vessel Off Nicaragua
description: A United States warship hailed the Soviet freighter Ulyanov off Nicaragua's Pacific coast and asked it to identify itself, list its cargo and give its destination, Cuba's official press agency said today.

MISSISSIPI OFFICIALS IN GUBERNATORIAL RUNOFF
description: Former Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Gandy, trying to become Mississippi's first woman governor, and Attorney General Bill Allain today earned spots in an Aug. 23 runoff election by leading the voting in the five-way Democratic gubernatorial primary.

title: TO LOSE WEIGHT, MORE EXERCISE IS THE KEY
description: IF you ask almost any joggers or other regular exercisers their primary motivation, the chances are that most would reply ''to look better'' or ''to lose weight'' or ''to be able to eat what I want without gaining.'' Nonexercisers tend to think that the active are just punishing themselves for their gluttonous indulgences. As a sedentary friend remarked, ''Wouldn't it be a lot easier, cheaper and less time-consuming to eat one less bagel a day and skip the running?''

title: REAGAN ASSERTS HE IS OPTIMISTIC ON LATIN PEACE
description: President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Republican Congressional leaders today that they were optimistic that tensions in Central America could be peacefully resolved.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: FILM OF ART The Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street (570-3651), not only takes note of the art of films, but it also reserves a special place for films of art.

title: Orioles Drop 2 to Indians
description: Andre Thornton drove in two runs and three Cleveland pitchers combined on an eight-hitter as the Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 4-3, and swept a doubleheader tonight. The victories were the third and fourth straight for the Indians under Pat Corrales, their new manager.

title: VEGETARIAN DISHES NOW SEEN IN THE BEST PLACES
description: ALTHOUGH there are a few chefs who take exception, most restaurateurs no longer regard vegetarians as escapees from a commune who have accidentally strayed into their establishments. In many city restaurants where a three-course dinner for one without wine costs $50, vegetarians now dine as well as their meat-eating companions and receive equally cordial treatment. In others, where vegetables are considered garnishes to accentuate the meat, but certainly not to be eaten alone, vegetarians must be content with larger portions of those side dishes, a salad and a soup - and perhaps a less than warm reception from the captain.

title: TEXAS-NEW MEXICO POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Orders Up by 3.9%; Inventories Down
description: Orders to United States factories for manufactured goods rose 3.9 percent in June, the biggest one-month jump in almost three years, with a push from military buying, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WINE TALK
description: A RECENT two-day judging of Finger Lakes wines here provides an opportunity to talk about New York's oldest and largest wine-producing area. From this vantage point there is good news and, well, less-good news.

title: Let 'Em Be Grease Monkeys
description: There's something about the Army's attitude toward female soldiers that could lead a cynic to suspect it wouldn't weep if they all up and left. Until 1977, when the Carter Administration declared women eligible for all noncombat occupational specialties, there weren't enough female soldiers to irritate apologists for ''this man's Army.'' Yet three years later the Army, responding to Congressional demands, had to order commanders to deal ''swiftly and fairly'' with sexual harassment.

title: Economic Scene; Employment Incentives
description: AT present, 11.6 million Americans are unemployed. The average unemployed person has been out of work for more than five months and can expect to remain unemployed for at least another three months. This high level of unemployment is in part a consequence of the economy's poor performance during the past three years.

title: 6 REPUBLICAN WOMEN AND A SPECIAL CONSTITUENCY
description: ''I never considered myself a feminist before I got this job,'' said Representative Claudine Schneider, a Rhode Island Republican. ''But then I started looking at the laws, and I recognized that many of them were written with a slant against women.''

description: Eurodollar bonds were little changed in price today in quiet trading.

description: A $125 million issue of Citicorp floating rate notes with a final maturity of 1998 was offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Aug. 1, 1983.

title: Coach Drops Lawsuit
description: Tom Meyer , who was dismissed and then reinstated as the basketball coach at the University of Illinois- Chicago last April, yesterday dropped a $1 million lawsuit he had filed against the school charging that his dismissal had violated his constiutional rights. In dropping the suit, Meyer, who will now pursue his complaint at a university grievance hearing, retained the right to reinstate it within six months.

title: Iraq Reports Killing 1,200 Iranian Soldiers
description: Iraq said today that its forces killed 1,200 Iranian soldiers and captured many tanks on Monday in some of the heaviest fighting since the Iran-Iraq war began nearly three years ago.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 45-year-old man, Antonio Yanegas, was killed, and 24 people, including 16 firefighters, were injured in a Washington Heights fire that started at 11:30 P.M. on Monday and was not brought under control until 1 A.M. yesterday. The blaze, which heavily damaged a six-story apartment building at 2185 Amsterdam Avenue, near 168th Street, was declared to be of suspicious origin. . . . Vandals climbed over a fence onto a Brooklyn Heights pier at 3 A.M. and caused thousands of dollars in damage to cargo and fork-lift trucks, which they drove around while a guard was patrolling a different part of the property.

title: Heritage Shifts Ad Plan Again

description: The dollar fell slightly in value today, its sharp rise of recent days halted temporarily by the intervention of the central banks of the United States, West Germany, France Japan and Switzerland.

description: Tyco Laboratories Inc. said it agreed to sell back to the Allied Corporation its investment in Allied's convertible preferred stock, series D, for $54.3 million in cash, a move that will result in an after-tax gain of $6.9 million, or 75 cents a share.

title: COACH IS ASSAILED ON STUDIES
description: Charles Alan Wright, the chairman of the infractions committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, told a sports seminar at Wesleyan University today that the graduation rate of basketball players during Abe Lemons's tenure as coach at Texas was ''a disgrace.'' Lemons was dismissed in the spring of 1982 after six years at the university.

title: 'THE TOMATO SAUCE YEARS' OF A PICKY YOUNG EATER
description: UNTIL my son, Jake, reached the age of 5, he ate every culinary confection I put on our table, from avocado to squid salad, from falafel to feijoada. I was pleased and flattered by this until I realized that at that tender age, he also swallowed coins and buttons with equal enthusiasm.

title: Gas Plant Costs
description: The Northwest Alaskan Pipeline Company said it cut the cost estimate for its proposed natural gas processing plant, to be built on Alaska's North Slope, by $900 million, to $3 billion, by incorporating a process designed by BASF A.G., of West Germany. Northwest Alaskan, a subsidiary of the Northwest Energy Company, is leading a consortium planning a 4,800-mile gas pipeline from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay oil and gas fields to the lower 48 states.

description: Richie Phillips, the counsel for the Major League Umpires Association, has asked the American League to consider a ''substantial suspension'' for Billy Martin as punishment for the Yankee manager's postgame remarks about Dale Ford on Sunday in Chicago.

title: Soccer Complaint
description: His club has lost eight straight games, attendance has been lagging and Robert Lifton , the principal owner of Team America, has renewed his complaint that the North American Soccer League has not given the team sufficient support. ''The N.A.S.L. did not do what it said it was going to do, which was give us the best of the American players,'' said Lifton, whose club, which will also serve as the United States national team, was formed this year with players drawn from other N.A.S.L. clubs. Howard Samuels , the league president, called Lifton's frustration understandable and said he was working on a plan to get the team a ''major player'' from another N.A.S.L. club next season when Team America will represent the United States in the preliminary rounds for the 1986 World Cup competition.

title: GENERAL DETAILS U.S. ROLE IN HONDURAS EXERCISES
description: The commander of American forces in Central America said today that United States maneuvers with Honduran troops over the next six months would emphasize tactics to stop infiltrators, counteract guerrillas and repel artillery and tank attacks.

title: ITT Increases 1.3%; Grumman Up 83.9%
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter edged up 1.3 percent from the year-earlier period and that sales slipped 8.9 percent. The company said the results were in line with its targets.

description: President Reagan said today that he will nominate Robert Miller, a Foreign Service officer and former United States Ambassador to Malaysia, as the new Ambassador to the Ivory Coast. The Senate must confirm the nomination.

description: The Senate approved legislation today to prevent drastic reductions in pension checks for a million retired railroad employees.

title: SRI LANKA ROUNDING UP COMMUNISTS
description: The Sri Lanka Government, which accused an unnamed foreign power of instigating ethnic riots last week, has arrested the leaders of the outlawed pro-Moscow Communist Party.

title: MEM CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: SELF-HELP VIDEOTAPES, FROM COOKING TO CAR REPAIR
description: Some people call them how-to cassettes or life- style videos. Others call them tip tapes. By whatever name, dozens of these self-help tapes are invading the video-cassette market, making it possible for people to exercise or learn more about their hobbies in the privacy of their own homes. If you own a video- cassette recorder, you can now learn the fundamentals of photography, magic, Chinese cooking, tennis, golf, crocheting, billiards, ballroom dancing, dog training, blackjack, craps, roulette, massage, weight lifting, plumbing, car repair, Spanish, Italian, German, wine, first aid, bridge, speed reading and how to grow roses, dahlias, irises and African violets while you sit in front of your television set.

description: b-Net loss.

title: ESMARK ARRANGES $1.2 BILLION CREDIT
description: Esmark Inc. has arranged a $1.2 billion credit with nine banks to finance its $1.05 billion acquisition of Norton Simon Inc., Esmark's chairman, Donald Kelly, said today.

description: KEN MCINTYRE led the Contemporary African American Music Orchestra in an ambitious, uneven concert Sunday at Soundscape. The 18-member group included violins, violas, guitar and cello as well as standard big-band instruments.

description: Teddy Mann won a 10-round split decison over Dwight Walker tonight in a middleweight fight at the Tropicana Hotel.

title: YANKEES DROP PAIR DESPITE 8 HOMERS
description: Eight Yankee home runs were wasted tonight when the Blue Jays swept a doubleheader, winning the first game on Dave Collins's 10th-inning single and the second because of ineffectivness by three New York pitchers.

title: Virginia Housing Bonds Are Priced
description: A $75.1 million issue of Virginia Housing Development Authority bonds, which are rated Aa/Ax, was tentatively priced by a Kidder, Peabody & Company group with interest- paying bonds yielding from 5.75 percent in 1984 to 10.3 percent in 2003.

On July 15 Enterprise Oil & Gas changed its name to Enterprise Technologies Inc.

title: A REAL LIVE SOAP OPERA? STAY TUNED
description: All is not well in Henderson, the mythical small town in which the NBC-TV daytime soap opera ''Search for Tomorrow'' takes place every weekday afternoon. Sometime over the weekend of July 22, the tape of tomorrow's episode disappeared from an editing room.

description: Players and former players involved with illegal drugs are hardly something new to the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Krugerrand Sales Drop
description: International Krugerrand sales fell sharply in July, to 117,760 ounces, from 407,580 in June, the International Gold Corporation said today. July sales were also down from 147,060 ounces in July 1982, but sales from January to July rose to about 2.2 million ounces, from 2 million in the 1982 period.

title:
Market Place;
Wholesale Grocer Stocks
description: WHOLESALE grocer stocks might seem like a dull way to play the market. But in their quiet way, such issues have been good performers, and in most cases their price/ earnings ratios still appear modest when compared with high flyers in some other sectors.

description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split in January 1983.

title: NOBEL INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BankAmerica Is Fined
description: The BankAmerica Corporation has agreed without admitting any wrongdoing to pay a $108,000 fine arising out of charges that it violated Federal regulations prohibiting aid to the Arab boycott of Israel, the Commerce Department announced today. It was the largest fine ever imposed on a United States bank and the ninth penalty imposed for the offense in the last 10 months.

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1

title: Debt Issues
description: Citicorp said an average rate of 9.914 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.537 percent at last week's auction.

title: POVERTY RATE ROSE TO 15% IN '82, HIGHEST LEVEL SINCE MID-1960'S
description: The national poverty rate rose last year to 15 percent, the highest in 17 years, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: COKE TO BUY NEW SEARLE SWEETENER
description: G. D. Searle & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to supply its low-calorie sweetener, aspartame, to the Coca-Cola Company for use in its diet soft drinks. It was the first agreement for use of the newly approved sweetener in American diet carbonated drinks.

title: Wichita Life Groups Get Ban on Burning Fetuses
description: Wichita officials have banned the practice of disposing of human fetuses at a city- owned incinerator.

description: SHE is on assignment from the State Department, a ''contract escort officer'' charged with leading a group of university lecturers from Africa on a five-week tour of the United States.

title: O.E.C.D. Borrowing
description: International borrowing by industrialized nations fell in July, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: 11 Free on Bond In Nuclear Protest
description: Eleven women arrested at an antinuclear protest at the Seneca Army Depot were released today on $500 bonds.

title: LONG-TERM RATES STABILIZE
description: Long-term interest rates, which had been rising sharply in the past three months, stabilized yesterday as the Treasury completed the first leg of a three-part, $15.75 billion financing. It sold $6.5 billion of new 11 3/8 percent three-year notes at an average yield of 11.43 percent.

title: ASTORIA STUDIO REVIVES FILM ERA IN NEW YORK
description: WHERE a forlorn silence once prevailed, workmen now swarm over scaffolding, and the air resounds with the racket of construction. Sleek black limousines prowl through the streets of the modest residential neighborbood, and a shuttle bus has begun to ferry people to and from Manhattan every half-hour.

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brown Upsets Jose Higueras
description: Jimmy Brown, ranked 77th in the world, upset Jose Higueras, the defending champion, today in the second round of the United States Open Clay-Court championships, 6-2, 6-2. The 18-year-old Brown, from Brentwood, Tenn., joined the pro circuit a year ago and has not won a tournament.

title: TRANSIT WITHOUT TOKEN OR TAXI
description: EAST SIDE, West Side, all around the town, people are traveling in novel ways in an attempt to beat cab fares, traffic jams and subway heat.

description: Hambletonian Week began in earnest at the Meadowlands tonight with an $875,000 race for 2-year-old trotters, some of whom had raced only three or four times, and the victory went to one of the more experienced youngsters, Why Not.

description: Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives said today that they were trying to scale down spending bills to avoid a veto battle with President Reagan.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Pursuit of Cancerous Crime
description: Judge Irving Kaufman is right to think of his inquiry into organized crime as ''cancer research.'' The Mob is a cancer that has eluded the most diligent pursuers. One reason may be that only the Bad Guys have been under the microscope. It's time to look as well into the errors, misconceptions and harmful pieties of the Good Guys.

title: LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: In the fall, Hopkinson & Blake, a subsidiary of the E.M. Guild Company, will increase the circulation of its Careers magazine to 400,000, double the number it distributed free to high school juniors and seniors last spring.

description: The American Bar Association's house of delegates voted today to support an amendment to the Federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 that would prohibit discrimination against women and members of minorities in private business clubs.

title: PITTSBURGH-DES MOINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WAYS THAT S.I. CAN LEAVE CITY LISTED IN STUDY
description: State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that Staten Island had the legal, political and financial power to secede from New York City and should secede if Federal courts took away its independent role in city government.

title: 'BIAS INCIDENT' AT STATEN ISLAND'S MILLER FIELD: A TALE OF TWO NEIGHBORHOODS
description: Gregory Cotton had adjusted the tan leather cap on his head to a jaunty angle and was returning to the punchball game when he found his path blocked by two husky teen-agers.

title: RANDOLPH COLLIER, 'FATHER' OF COAST FREEWAYS
description: Randolph Collier, ''the father of the California freeways,'' died of chronic pulmonary obstruction today in Sacramento, where he had lived since losing his State Senate seat in 1976. He was 81 years old.

title: CHAD SAYS ITS ARMY IS PURSUING REBELS
description: The Government said today that the Chadian Army, under the personal command of President Hissen Habre, was chasing rebels loyal to former President Goukouni Oueddei toward Libya. The Government denied a report from Tripoli that Mr. Habre had been killed in action.

title: EX-CONGRESSMAN UNABLE TO MOVE BAR GROUP TO BACK HOMOSEXUALS
description: Former Representative Robert E. Bauman, a conservative Republican from Maryland, announced at the American Bar Association convention here today that he would actively lobby for Federal legislation to protect homosexual men and women against discrimination.

description: * Amfac Inc., San Francisco, has named Bruce C. Hraba president.

title: Nursing Home Deaths Laid to an Employee
description: A 24- year-old kitchen worker at a residence for the elderly here has been charged with raping and murdering two of the women residents.

title: BIG TRUCKS BANNED ON 3 ROADS
description: The State Department of Transportation has banned all through trucks weighing 10 tons or more from parts of three state highways in southern Orange County, an official announced today.

title: FLORIDA'S GLOBAL-BASED TAX PROTESTED
description: Companies in Florida used to complain that the state's poor education system hindered business growth. But three weeks ago Florida acted to raise more money for education by taxing overseas corporate income, and major companies have been objecting bitterly ever since.

title: Yield at 1983 High On Housing Notes
description: Local housing authorities around the country sold almost $1.4 billion of short-term, tax-exempt notes yesterday.

title: Trade Peace With China
description: The new quota for textile imports from China is hardly a monument to free trade, but it is a sensible compromise of the United States' domestic and foreign interests. American textile producers find it too liberal; they want maximum protection at every opportunity. This time they met their match in equally needy exporters and an overriding national concern.

title: LIBERTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: ''Secession is not only feasible, it is also legally and politically viable.''

KEEL CONTROVERSY CONTINUES AT TRIALS
description: The Italian team in the America's Cup challenge trials today backed off slightly from the support given to Australia II by the other foreign yachts in the face of a challenge from the New York Yacht Club concerning Australia II's radical keel.

title: Healthdyne Cuts
description: Healthdyne Inc., the Atlanta-based manufacturer of an electronic crib monitor, said today that it laid off 75 middle management employees without prior notice as a result of the recent $63 million acquisition of Narco Scientific Inc., a Fort Washington, Pa., manufacturer of high-technology hospital products. A Healthdyne spokesman said the positions had become redundant.

title: Final Loan Agreement Signed Saving National Public Radio
description: National Public Radio signed a formal agreement today for an $8.5 million loan from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

description: Two of President Reagan's top civil rights enforcement officers told the National Urban League today that they were aggressively defending the rights of minority groups. But they shared the platform with two opponents who charged the President's policies belied his public statements of support.

UTENSILS OF MANY USES
description: SELECTING an efficient battery of kitchen equipment is somewhat like choosing a wardrobe. The quantity of items you own is not important if the ones you have are versatile. I find that in my home kitchen a single piece of equipment may have various uses beyond the one it was originally designed for - a welome dividend that saves money and storage space.

title: Setback for Chacon
description: Bobby Chacon will not have his day in court until after another fighter is crowned the World Boxing Council's superfeatherweight champion.

description: A son of the French stallion Riverman attracted a bid of $675,000 from the British Bloodstock Agency to top the opening night of the Fasig- Tipton Saratoga Select Yearling Sales tonight. The colt was purchased on behalf of a syndicate of unidentified American buyers.

title: BORROWING IN A NOVEL IS ADMITTED
description: Avon Books is recalling 60,000 copies of a novel published three months ago that its author acknowledged was ''modeled'' on a 1974 novel by John D. MacDonald, the bestselling mystery writer.

description: Year-ago results for the quarter and 6 months include a gain of $200,874 from the sale of substantially all of the assets of the company's Paragon Plastics division. Year-ago share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split payable June 1983.

title: SWAN FINALLY WINS
description: Manager Frank Howard has been maintaining that the Mets could play .500 ball after the All-Star break if they would put together two or three winning streaks in August and September. Before Sunday, the chances of that happening seemed laughable. Now they seem plausible.

title: Passengers Subdue Would-Be Hijacker
description: A Spanish speaking man tried to hijack a Miami-to-Houston jetliner tonight but was subdued by passengers and tied up.

BILL WOULD ALTER SOME TAX CREIDTS

title: Ready to Rest

''I played in 34 games in the last 10 months - 12 for North Carolina, 2 all-star games and 20 games for the Stars.

title: BOB VAN ALLEN, HOME-FURNISHINGS DESIGNER
description: Bob Van Allen, a designer of home furnishings whose contemporary stylings ranged from fabric patterns to china, flatware and lighting fixtures, died July 23 of complications resulting from an intestinal infection at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reilly Hurt in Drill
description: Under the terms of his suspension from the National Football League, Mike Reilly , the Los Angeles Ram linebacker who is serving a one-year sentence for vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving, can continue to work out with the team but cannot suit up for games. Even so, Reilly, who is participating in a work-furlough program at an Orange County jail, was not working out with the team yesterday. According to a club spokesman, he was being treated for a pulled groin muscle suffered in practice on Monday.

title: Nabisco Complains To Custom Creamery
description: As the result of last Friday's column on the Flavor Factory made-to- order ice cream franchises, the parent company, Custom Creamery, received a letter from Nims, Howes, Collison & Isner, lawyers for Nabisco Brands, makers of the famous Oreo cookie.

title: CBS Undecided
description: Officials of CBS Sports in Caracas, Venezuela, recommended yesterday that the network follow through with plans to televise 16 hours of the Pan American Games starting Aug. 14. Terry O'Neil, the executive producer of the CBS team, said that the network had received assurances of broadcast control from organizers of the games and Venezuelan Government officials. But as late as Monday afternoon, he said, whether the network would televise the games remained in doubt.

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

New Help for Drivers On the Telephone
description: City motorists will be able to ask questions of the State Department of Motor Vehicles with their fingertips for at least the next five months. And if they have a push-button telephone, they can also say what they think of the answers.

title: New TV Pact
description: The Devils reached a multiyear agreement yesterday under which the Madison Square Garden Network will produce about 40 of the team's games a season for cable television and about 20 more for broadcast over WOR-TV, Channel 9. The agreement ends the Devils' affiliation with SportsChannel, which televised their games last season. The MSG Network is a subsidiary of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, as are the Rangers, a rival of the Devils in the National Hockey League's Patrick Division.

title: Market Place; Upbeat View Of Oil Stocks
description: SIGNS of more stability on the global oil front are a marked change from the eroding prices and psychology that followed the peak for energy stocks in November 1980. ''Industry fundamentals appear to be turning around,'' said Alvin D. Silber of Dean Witter Reynolds, ''although supporting statistics take three to six months to develop.''

title: ISRAEL REJECTS LEBANESE REQUEST FOR PULLOUT TIMETABLE
description: The American special envoy to the Middle East conveyed a Lebanese request to Israel today that it publish a timetable for the withdrawal of its forces from Lebanon. Israel rejected the request, officials here said.

title: REAGAN'S JOKE SOURS HIS APOLOGY TO WOMEN
description: An embarrassed President Reagan promised a women's convention today to ''do penance'' for a mix-up that forced the cancellation of the group's White House tour on Tuesday. But later the leader of the group said she felt a Presidential joke about the influence of women was degrading and offensive.

title: Military Bill Conferees Back Nerve Gas Plans
description: Congressional negotiators, drafting a compromise version of the 1984 military authorization bill, reportedly reaffirmed plans today to permit the Defense Department to produce nerve gas for the first time since 1969.

title: Gunmen Rob 2 In Car Ride to S.I.
description: Two young gunmen jumped a tavern owner and a plainclothes police officer outside a bank in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday, forced them into the tavern owner's car, drove them to Staten Island and took nearly $3,500 and the officer's gun, the police said.

title: Belgian Jobless Rate Up
description: The Belgian Government said today that the number of jobless in the country rose by 19,824 in July, to almost 511,000, a record 12.3 percent of the workforce. Unemployment was 11.8 percent in June. The sharp rise in July reversed a four-month decline from a February peak of 510,000, or 12.2 percent, the Government said.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MANY ASPECTS OF ZUBIN MEHTA'S JOB WITH PHILARMONIC
description: WHO will replace Carlo Maria Giulini when he steps down as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic late next year? There are rumors - all roundly denied - that it might be Zubin Mehta, the director of the New York Philharmonic, who came here from the Los Angeles five years ago. There are also reports, printed recently in these pages, that some members of the orchestra here wish he would go back to Los Angeles.

He was 86 years old and had lived in Pennswood Village in Newtown, Pa., since 1980.

title:
CURRENCY INTERVENTION: A CALCULATED DECISION;
News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration appears to have taken a calculated political gamble in its decision to join other major industrial nations in substantial intervention in foreign-exchange trading to try to guide the value of the dollar. Senior officials in the Administration said they remained convinced that transactions of this sort, if they were effective at all, had only a momentary impact on prices in the currency markets. Currency values, they believe, are determined by such basic factors as differences in the rate of growth in the money supplies of nations and by inflation among nations - not by the vicissitudes of day-to-day trading in world financial markets.

title: CONCERT: QUARTET
description: TUESDAY night's Mostly Mozart Festival concert in Avery Fisher Hall belonged to the Emerson String Quartet; it was an occasion for polished and intelligent music making. The players - Eugene Drucker and Philip Setzer, violins; Lawrence Dutton, viola, and David Finckel, cello - carefully thought everything through, whether it was the way in which accents and syncopations work in Mozart's String Quartet in G (K. 387) or the way a bass line and harmonic figuration can shape and support a clarinet solo in Mozart's Clarinet Quintet in A (K. 581).

Daniel McKay, 35 years old, of Beecher, Ill., did not speak except to answer questions at his arraignment Tuesday in Cook County Circuit Court. Mr. McKay, held on $200,000 bail, remains in the psychiatric unit of Cermak Hospital.
