TV: ABC SERIES 'EYE ON HOLLYWOOD' STARTING
description: ''EYE ON HOLLYWOOD'' looks at more than Hollywood; it looks at all of southern California. You thought, of course, that it was just one big collection of hot rods, starlets, body builders and beach freaks. You were wrong. There are penguins out there, too. ''Eye on Hollywood'' proves it. The new ABC series starts at 8 tonight.

title: LOSS OF NERVE
description: There have been many occasions this summer for alarm about the direction of U.S. foreign and military policy, notably in Central America. But for me, one event most depressingly indicated where we are headed. That was the July 13 Senate vote - 50 to 49, with Vice President Bush breaking a tie - to authorize a new family of nerve gas weapons.

title: POLYCAST TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: BROOKLYN TRAINS WILL BE DELAYED IN BRIDGE REPAIR
description: Subway riders, already suffering from a summer of poor service, will encounter a new delay beginning Monday when trains that run on the Manhattan Bridge are rerouted to make way for reconstruction work.

title: Austerity For France
description: France's austerity program is working but needs to be continued, especially given the strength of the dollar against the franc, Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy told the Council of Ministers today.

title: MCDONALD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: The company went public on July 20. The results for the latest quarter are for the partnership before the public offering.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Marc Rich Negotiations
description: Government lawyers continued negotiations yesterday with Marc Rich & Company A.G., the Swiss-based commodities trading organization, to eliminate the need for a Federal court order freezing up to $55 million of the company's United States assets.

title: Florida Utility Bonds Priced to Yield 10.3%
description: A $181 million issue of Gainesville, Fla., utility system revenue bonds was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10.3 percent for bonds due in 2013 by underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: PROTESTS DELAY STEINBECK BIOGRAPHY
description: Hundreds of enthusiasts of the novelist John Steinbeck who arrived here for the fourth annual Steinbeck Festival were surprised to learn that Viking Press has delayed publication of a long-awaited authorized biography of the novelist.

title: G.M. IS SUED BY U.S. ON X-CAR DEFECTS INVOLVING BREAKS
description: The Justice Department sued the General Motors Corporation today, charging that the company had sold 1980 X-model cars knowing they had hazardous brake defects.

title: LATIN MARSHALL PLAN?
description: Faced by the mess in Central America, a disparate group of people have desperately run up the Marshall Plan flag. This is a misuse and potential misapplication of one of the United States' most generous and imaginative acts. At best it is disingenuous even to suggest that a Marshall Plan for Latin America is the answer to the agony of this region.

title: U.S. SENDS AWACS TO EGYPT, ADVISERS TO CHAD
description: With concern rising over the fighting in Chad, Pentagon and State Department spokesmen announced today that two Awacs reconnaissance planes had been flown to Egypt and several military advisers had been sent to Chad.

title: Long-Driving Winner
description: Terry Forcum , a former rodeo bull rider, has won the National Long Driving Championsip in Pacific Palisades, Calif. Forcum, who owns a welding shop in Ponca City, Okla., drove 307 yards. Next was John Slaughter , a member of the University of Houston golf team, who drove 305 yards 28 inches.

title: A TV ACTRESS
description: The movie and television actress Carolyn Jones, who was best known for her role as the ghoulish Morticia in the television series ''The Addams Family,'' died of cancer today at her home here. She was 50 years old.

title: Dioxin Tests Find No Danger
description: Governor Kean said today that additional tests for dioxin contamination near the site of a former herbicide plant in Newark indicated that all housing in the area was safe.

title: METS WIN 4TH STRAIGHT
description: The force is with the Mets these days. As they did last Sunday, the Mets and Jesse Orosco won again on a force play at Shea Stadium last night.

title: EL PASO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
People
description: * Venetia Hands joining D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York on Aug. 15 as senior vice president, director of research.

title: RAYMOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a reduction of $617,000 reflecting the minority interests created by the December 1982 public sale of Raymond Engineering Inc. common stock.

title: 2 U.S. Banks To Aid Brunei
description: J.P. Morgan & C mpany's Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Citicorp's Citibank will take over advising the Sultanate of Brunei on the investment portfolio from Britain's Crown Agents, a spokesman for the Crown Agents said today.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS SEEK TROOP CURB
description: President Reagan met for an hour today with his special envoy to Central America as Democrats in Congress stepped up their opposition to American policy in the region.

title: NUTRITION WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid November 1982.

title: AIDED JEWS IN WAR
description: Josiah E. DuBois Jr., a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials and a leader in efforts to rescue Jews during World War II, died of cancer Monday at Underwood-Memorial Hospital in Woodbury, N.J. He was 70 years old and lived in Pitman, N.J.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to July 9
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1983.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: COMMERCIAL BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH thousands of American houses are destroyed or damaged every year by lightning, only a small percentage - less than 5 percent by one estimate - are protected against it. Many homeowners do not realize that such protection can be permanently installed. Once in place it will last almost indefinitely and requires no maintenance, yet the original cost will ordinarily be no higher than that of the insurance premiums on the house for a year.

title: POLICE TO INVEST PENSION FUNDS IN CITY HOUSING
description: The city's Police Pension Fund will invest $50 million in rehabilitating apartments in deteriorating city neighborhoods, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday. He said it was the first time any public pension fund in the country had invested in upgrading housing.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Financial Times Accord
description: A tentative settlement has been reached in the 10-week strike that has shut down The Financial Times. According to Alan Hare, chairman of the daily paper, publication could resume with next Tuesday's edition.

title: JAZZ: SONNY FORTUNE ON SAX
description: WITH the quartet he is leading at the Village Vanguard through Sunday, the saxophonist Sonny Fortune has reached a new plateau of authority and invention.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: OPERA STRIKE NEGOTIATIONS BREAK OFF
description: Negotiators for the New York City Opera and its striking orchestra met yesterday afternoon in the law offices of Martin J. Oppenheimer, chief negotiator and spokesman for the opera, but the talks broke off again with no new session scheduled.

title: SCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $185,000. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $455,000 for the quarter and $594,000 for the 6 months.

title: Bowling Marks Set
description: Anne Marie, a 20-year-old rookie from Cyprus, Calif., bowled two 300 games and a 299 yesterday to break three women's records in the $25,000 Ladies Pro Bowlers Tournament Bonanza Classic in Dearborn Heights, Mich. Competing in only her fourth professional tournament, Miss Pike bettered Women's International Bowling Congress records for four- and eight-game series, and became the first woman to bowl two three- game 800 series in the same year. Pike, however, advanced no further than third place.

title: A CONSULTANT TESTIFIES IN TV CO-ANCHOR CASE
description: A consultant whose viewer surveys helped lead to the demotion of Christine Craft as co-anchor at KMBC-TV here in 1981 testified today that comments he made were designed to draw out participants, not prejudice them against her.

title: Italian Socialist Reports Accord on Cabinet
description: Prime Minister-designate Bettino Craxi announced today that he had reached agreement with four political parties to form Italy's first Socialist-led Government.

title: Home Where 4 Died To Be Fined $190,000
description: The Board of Health today ordered fines of $190,000 for a nursing home where four people died after the air-conditioning broke down in a heat wave.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Vote, Old Tradition

title: OZARK AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Dresser Purchase
description: Dresser Industries signed a $40 million contract to buy Polish-built bulldozers, Polish officials said today.

title: Freedom Savings
description: The Freedom Savings and Loan Association, of Tampa, Fla., said that it had agreed in principal to a $26 million investment in Freedom by a group of private investors and that, as a result, it was no longer seeking a purchaser. The investor group eventually could own from 31.4 percent to 33 percent of the company's common stock, up to a maximum of 1,315,000 shares. As a result, the number of common shares outstanding could increase from the current 2,875,000 shares to as many as 4,190,000.

description: b-Net loss.

title: HERO IN HIJACKING CASE TO BE REHIRED
description: A man laid off last month by Pan American World Airways broke up an attempt to hijack a Pan Am Boeing 747 to Havana Tuesday night. Company officials responded today by offering him a new job.

title: Congressman Says Salvador Should Insure Safe Elections
description: A senior member of Congress warned the Reagan Administration today that he would tie approval of $3.4 million in election financing for El Salvador to the guaranteed safety of all candidates and voters.

title: SAUL, B F, REAL ESTATE INVVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of property of $1,440,000 for the quarter and $8,644,000 for the 9 months, and extraordinary tax credits of $594,000 for the quarter and $3,362,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a gain of $613,000 for the 9 months from the sale of property.

title: Advertising; A Golf Superstar For Hertz
description: SINCE a celebrity can add considerable impact to a TV commercial that is battling to be heard above the competitive clutter, why not two?

description: b-Net income.

title: Douglas to End Its DC-10 Line
description: Production of the DC-10 airliner, plagued by financial losses, tragedy and a virtual collapse of orders, is ending, the Douglas Aircraft Company announced.

title: YANKS, GUIDRY BEATEN
description: Ron Guidry said that he was not tired and that he was throwing the ball well. Yet tonight the left-hander lost his second complete game in a row, 6-2, to the Blue Jays. And he had thrown 294 pitches in his last two outings.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day Friday gave an incorrect date for the founding of the company that owns the Bank Leumi Trust Company. It was 1902.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alabama Automated Clearing House Association, Birmingham, has elected A. W. Redmon president.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALENDAR OF EVENTS: LECTURE ON ESTATES
description: ''Great Estates,'' Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street), 212-935-3960.On Wednesday at 12:30 P.M., James Bleecker, a graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design, will discuss notable New York estates and give two slide presentations, ''Vanished Long Island: The Gold Coast'' and ''Hudson River Estates.''

title: Nadler & Larimer Absorbing Subsidiaries
description: Nadler & Larimer Advertising, a subsidiary of the Mickelberry Corporation, is digesting a pair of subsidiaries of its own.

title: 3 in Yonkers Rob Howard Johnson's
description: Three masked gunmen invaded a Howard Johnson's restaurant at 12:45 A.M. today, took thousands of dollars from a safe, robbed 17 customers and escaped, the police reported.

title: Officer Is Accused Of Punching Cleric
description: A police officer was suspended yesterday after he was charged with punching a Brooklyn minister he had arrested in Times Square on June 2.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of assets of $1,392,000 for the quarter and $3,044,000 for the 9 months. c-Including gains on the sale of assets of $918,000 for the quarter and $1,487,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $295,000 for the 9 months on mortgage repurchase.

title: A LIBERAL UNION CHIEF ON THE POLITICS OF '84
description: For the first time in its history, the A.F.L.- C.I.O., the 15-million-member coalition that includes most of the country's labor union membership, will convene a special meeting late this year to try to get two-thirds of those attending to endorse one of the Democratic candidates for President. This effort, and its timing, will be a major issue when the federation's executive council opens its annual summer meeting in Boston on Monday.

title: American Doused With Blood By a West German Activist
description: Gen. Paul Williams of the United States Army was doused with human blood today by a member of West Germany's Green Party as a protest against American policies.

title: ST JUDE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOR BABIES: THE BEST OF EVERYTHING
description: BACK in 1927 when baby made three in the song ''My Blue Heaven,'' children were being born into rather different life styles than today's infants. For one thing, their parents were younger, heaven was often a mortgaged cottage, and as the years went by, baby was was usually joined by several other siblings. Nursery equipment and clothes were passed down from child to child.

title: DENG, NOT MAO, IS PEKING'S LATEST LITERARY LION
description: The author has been praised for ''creative initiative'' and ''revolutionary boldness.'' His work is considered ''a brilliant book marking a period of great historic change'' and ''a major event in the political life of the Chinese people.''

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $246,000 for the quarter and $594,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $2,035,000 for the quarter and $3,534,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $128,000 for the quarter and $3,215,000 for the 6 months and extraordinary items of $3,645,000 for the quarter and $8,563,000 for the 6 months. The extraordinary item of $3,645,000 for the 1982 quarter includes a tax credit of $944,000 and a gain from the cash tender offer for American Investment Co. debt of $2,701,000. The extraordinary item of $8,563,000 for the 1982 6 months includes a tax credit of $4,702,000, a gain from a tender offer for 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures of $1,160,000, and a gain related to the cash tender offer for American Investment debt of $2,701,000.

title: ALASKA BALKS AT SALMON TREATY WITH CANADA
description: After two years of seemingly successful negotiations, an intricate treaty between Canada and the United States on the division of west coast salmon catches was suddenly upset by an Alaskan reservation.

title: Sheik Gets Top Colt
description: After tonight's second session of the Fasig-Tipton Saratoga Select Yearling Sales, the sales topper remained a son of the French stallion Riverman, who was purchased Tuesday by the Aston Upthorpe Stud, owned by Sheik Mohammed ibn Rashid al Maktoum of Dubai.

title: ONE-HITTER BY RYAN GAINS 1-0 VICTORY
description: Nolan Ryan allowed only one hit, a one-out single by Tim Flannery in the third inning, and Dickie Thon's run-scoring triple gave the Houston Astros to a 1-0 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight.

title: CAREY SETS WORLD MARK IN BACKSTROKE
description: Rick Carey set a world record in the 200-meter backstroke in a preliminary heat today and, nine hours later, easily won the the final on the opening day of the United States long-course national swimming championships.

title: F. ARNOLD DAUM
description: F. Arnold Daum, a former senior partner in the New York City law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, died Tuesday in Freeport, the Bahamas, while undergoing treatment for a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Lloyd Neck, L.I.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISOMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP 37.1%
description: The Big Three auto makers reported today that sales surged 37.1 percent in the last 10 days of July, continuing the recovery that has been pushing up sales sharply since April.

title: NEW JERSEY BELL TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Scales of Justice
description: When Eddie Mustafa Muhammad was found to be 2 1/2 pounds over the 175-pound weight limit before last month's scheduled light-heavyweight title bout against the champion, Michael Spinks , in Washington, he charged that the official weigh-in scales were wrong and he refused to try to take off the excess poundage. This led to the cancellation of the fight and made Mustafa Muhammad unpopular in the boxing community.

title: CAE INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOAN IS SET FOR PUBLIC RADIO
description: Four days after it almost slid into bankruptcy, National Public Radio signed a formal agreement Tuesday for an $8.5 million loan.

title: SCHERER, R P, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AN ARTIST TO RIVAL AUDOBON
description: Starting today, visitors to the American Museum of Natural History will have an opportunity to view a full-scale exhibition of the work of Louis Agassiz Fuertes, who, with John James Audubon, is certain to maintain a place in history as one of the most talented artists to have painted the birds of North America.

title: CONGRESS VOTES HIGHER PAYMENTS FOR HOSPICE CARE
description: A Senate vote today gave final Congressional approval to an increase in maximum Medicare payments to hospice programs that care for the dying.

title: Bulldozers Slow Jersey Forest Fire
description: Firefighters used bulldozers today to cut wide swaths through pine woods and swampland in an effort to contain a fire that had charred 1,200 acres in the Wharton State Forest.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Large yellow-beige stains have appeared in the ceiling next to an apartment fireplace, stains that seem to be caused by creosote from the chimney. The landlord applied a primer, then painted over the stains, but they reappeared. Is there anything to cover them permanently?

title: STOCKS REVERSE THEIR SLIDE
description: The stock market managed to stage a moderate recovery yesterday after its recent sell-off, with all of the major indicators ending higher in accelerated trading.

title: Cavaliers Go Modern
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers recently got new owners, and now the Nattional Basketball Association team is getting an entirely new look, complete with new uniforms, new colors and a punchy new logo with a not-so- new nickname. In place of the old wine and gold, the team's new colors are burnt orange, white and royal blue, and the new logo, which replaces the old swashbuckling swordsman in billowing cape encircled with the words ''Cleveland Cavaliers,'' is simply the nickname ''Cavs'' with the ''V'' designed to look like a net with a basketball starting to go through it.

title: A Chorus of Governors and Gnomes
description: The governors of the United States and the banking gnomes of Zurich now send Washington the same message: You can't walk away from those looming budget deficits.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cigna Corp.'s acquistion of Crusader insurance and Continental Corp.'s acquisition of Lombard Insurance will not be referred to the Monopolies Commission of the British Government, the Department of Trade announced.

title: CALPROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOSCO CORP. REPORTS $194.5 MILLION DEFICIT
description: The Tosco Corporation reported yesterday that it had a second-quarter loss of $194.5 million, in contrast to earnings of $106.7 million, or $4.63 a share, a year earlier.

title: ARAFAT'S DECLINE
description: The Syrian-supported rebellion in Yasir Arafat's Al Fatah - now in its fourth month - may well herald the beginning of the end of Mr. Arafat's domination of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Intransigent and weak as Mr. Arafat has always been, his likely decline is not necessarily a good thing for Middle East peace. His fall may make it much more difficult for Palestinians to participate in or endorse a negotiated solution of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Maritime Satellite Bids
description: The International Maritime Satellite Organization today invited bids for a $500 million project to build satellites to link the world's merchant ships to shore.

title: WHICH WAY INTEREST RATES?
description: Last August, the decline in interest rates helped ignite the stock market's most explosive rally ever. Nearly a year later, however, the pressure on those rates is upward and the market has turned jittery.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HAMMOND RECALLS AN ANGRY YOUTH
description: One spring afternoon in the late 1960's, when William H. Carr Junior High School of Whitestone, Queens, conducted tryouts for its boys' softball team, one of the school's finest athletes refused to take part.

title: HERS
description: IF you look at the latest statistics, you'll see that 40 percent of all marriages end in divorce. Which means, according to my calculator, that 60 percent don't. And that's what has me bothered. The experts don't know why these folks are not rushing to the divorce courts - certainly they're not pinning it on fidelity - but the consequences are clear: once again it's the children who suffer. If you find yourself caught in the midst of a happy marriage, before you decide to stay together, think of the kids.

description: A $152,000- a-year tax exemption enjoyed by the exclusive Burning Tree Club outside Washington violates the State Constitution because the club does not admit women, Maryland's Attorney General ruled today.

description: Merck & Company has agreed to acquire slightly more than 50 percent of the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company of Tokyo in a transaction valued at about $313.5 million, the companies announced yesterday.

title: The President's Perplexity
description: That Ronald Reagan is ''disturbed'' or ''saddened'' by reports of hunger in the United States should come as no surprise. But why is he, as he puts it, ''perplexed''?

ROMERO SCORES 2 AS COSMOS TRIUMPH
description: The Cosmos made up for the absence of their two top scorers tonight and defeated the San Diego Sockers, 3-1, at Giants Stadium.

Nickel Production
description: Inco Ltd. and Falconbridge Ltd. resumed nickel production this week at most of their operations.

title: A.T.& T., U.S. AGREE ON FINAL ASPECTS OF BELL BREAKUP
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the United States Justice Department yesterday agreed to a Federal judge's final changes in their antitrust settlement, effectively clearing the way for A.T.& T. to dismantle the Bell system on Jan. 1.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 4, 1983
description: International

title: FEDERAL GRANT AWARDED TO RESTORE VERMONT INN
description: The Federal Government will help this town restore a historic but deteriorating 18th-century inn that gave shelter to two Presidents.

title: U.S. WILL GIVE YALE $11 MILLION TO BUILD NUCLEAR ACCELERATOR
description: Yale University has received a two-year, $11 million Federal grant to build one of the world's most powerful and precise nuclear accelerators for scientific research.

title: TREASURY NOTES YIELD 11.96%
description: The Treasury yesterday sold new 11 7/8 percent notes due in 10 years at an average yield of 11.96 percent. By the end of the day, the new notes were trading at roughly the yields of Tuesday as long-term interest rates were mixed and short-term rates fell sharply.

title: Bonds Offered By Massachusetts
description: A $100 million issue of Massachusetts bonds was offered with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 7.5 percent in 1988, 8.9 percent in 1993 and 9.8 percent in 2003, through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Crime Victims' Fund A Victim of Its Success
description: A fund to compensate victims of crime in Rhode Island is becoming insolvent, a victim of its own success.

title: AGENCY TO SELL POWER CHEAPLY TO GRUMMAN
description: The New York Power Authority announced today that it would sell inexpensive power from an upstate nuclear plant to the Grumman Corporation. Grumman said that in exchange for the power it would go ahead with an expansion plan on Long Island.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE PRACTICAL GARDENER
description: THESE are the days of ennui in the garden. Many hoe-and-trowel people would rather rest on their labors than get to work. And so it should be, for this is a time to enjoy the outdoors. The major harvest is beginning, annuals are in full bloom and late-summer perennials are showing off. Nonetheless, there are things to be done; a few essential tasks lie ahead. Lawns

title: Women Refuse to Wear Miniskirts and Win Case
description: Two Cape Cod women were awarded more than $18,000 today when a state commission ruled they had been illegally forced to leave their supermarket jobs for refusing to wear shorts or miniskirts.

title: Ironic Political Advice
description: Lew Lehrman didn't finish first in last November's gubernatorial race. But his 1983 Committee to Make New York No. 1 Again released yesterday a half-inch-thick campaign manual for Republican candidates.

title: URUGUAYAN JUNTA ISSUES BAN ON POLITICAL ACTIVITY
description: The military Government has decreed that political parties must limit their activities to internal organization and has prohibited any form of unauthorized propaganda.

title: Bill on Insiders Goes to House
description: The Energy and Commerce Committee of the House of Representatives today approved a bill that would sharply increase the penalties for people who trade securities using illegally obtained inside information.

title: 2 Are Indicted In Illegal Dumping
description: Two officers of a Queens company dealing in steel drums were arrested yesterday and charged with the illegal disposal of hazardous wastes in New York City landfills. Officials said the arrests were the first in the city under a revised state law that makes such actions felonies punishable by prison terms.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times Tuesday about remedial efforts for unsuccessful schools incorrectly located the new High School for the Humanities. It is to open in September in the former Charles Evans Hughes High School, 351 West 18th Street, in Manhattan.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
HEAVY FENCE, VINYL-COATED
description: CHAIN-LINK fencing, generally found in industrial or public installations, is increasingly being used to fence home swimming pools, dog pens, gardens and apartment terraces, for homeowners appreciate its durability.

title: FOR CUSTOMERS, CONFUSION LOOMS
description: On Jan. 1, when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is scheduled to divest itself of its 22 Bell System subsidiaries, consumers could be confused by the wide choices of local and long- distance telephone services.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE goal was to do something new, using traditional stained-glass methods, so Richard Spaulding, a craftsman who moved here from Seattle a year and a half ago, has opened a studio that specializes in stained glass. ''My idea is to do functional and secular designs,'' said Mr. Spaulding, who is shown at right with a small window piece he designed for himself at a cost of $1,800.

title: DEFENSE ATTACKS THE TRANSCRIPTS OF BRINK'S TAPES
description: Defense lawyers attacked the prosecution's case yesterday as they cross- examined an F.B.I. agent who prepared the transcripts of tape-recorded conversations presented in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan.

title: DESIGNED FOR LIVING WITH LESS-OR MORE
description: ''I SUBTRACT,'' says the women's fashion designer Zoran, describing how he created what may be New York's pre-eminent subminimal loft. His Greenwich Village home has no stove, no closets, no chairs, no shelves, no hooks, no bathroom sink, no closets, no paintings, no photographs, no interior doors, no knobs. The designer, known for his minimalist approach to fashion, has even dropped his family name. Just Zoran.

title: DOLE TAKES CONGRESS AND REAGAN TO TASK ON BUDGET
description: Senator Bob Dole, arguing that the economic recovery was being jeopardized, said today that Congress had put spending ''on automatic pilot'' and charged that President Reagan has failed to provide sufficient leadership in reducing the budget deficit.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DONALD V. M'DONALD
description: Donald V. MacDonald, former manager of the commodities department of Fahnestock & Company, the Wall Street brokerage house, died Monday at Emma Laing Stevens Hospital in Granville, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Granville.

title: NOLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10.9 million for the quarter and $23.8 million for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the sale of First Texas Financial Corp. in November 1982.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include a gain of $8.9 million, or $1.12 a share, from a United States Supreme Court decision permitting an Equitable subsidiary to price certain volumes of its natural gas production in accordance with pricing provisions of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 rather than on a lower cost of service basis.

title: BANK CITES POWER UNIT FOR FRAUD
description: Chemical Bank, trustee for thousands of Washington Public Power Supply System bondholders, filed suit in Federal court here today charging the system and its sponsoring utilities with fraud and negligence in issuing $2.25 billion in bonds to finance two canceled nuclear power plants.

title: STUDY FINDS POLLUTANTS EMITTED BY GAS HEATERS
description: Government researchers said today that unvented gas space heaters might produce dangerous levels of pollution in homes.

title: Selective Service Getting Young Men's Addresses
description: The addresses of men of draft age with California driver's licenses are being turned over to the Selective Service System in what one state senator calls a ''Big Brother'' invasion of privacy.

title: Suit on Oil Prices
description: Alaska filed a motion to intervene in an antitrust suit charging that eight companies conspired to depress artificially the price paid for crude oil in California, the Alaska Attorney General's office said. The $100 million suit filed by the State of California and the City of Long Beach charges that the Standard Oil Company of Caliofrnia, Texaco Inc., the Exxon Corporation, the Union Oil Company of California, the Mobil Corporation, the Shell Oil Company, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Thums Long Beach Company reduced the royalties paid for oil produced on state and city land by holding down the price of the oil produced.

title: Kuhn Presided Over Revolutionary Era; Faced Many Problems
description: To the club owners who hired him 15 years ago, Bowie Kuhn was a lawyer with Washington connections and an upright manner. To the 650 players in the big leagues, he was ''the owners' commissioner.'' To Charles O. Finley, his leading critic, he was ''the village idiot.'' To Happy Chandler, one of his predecessors and a leading supporter, he was ''the man who preserved the integrity of the game.''

title: 2 GROUPS OF DEVELOPERS VIE TO BUILD TIMES SQUARE MART
description: Two teams of developers are vying for the designation to build a 2.4million-square-foot merchandise mart in the heart of a proposed $1 billion Times Square redevelopment project, according to officials of both groups. The Times Square Redevelopment Corporation is expected to make its choice soon.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A DEALER'S LIFE IN ARCHITECTURL ANTIQUE
description: Looking rather like one of the stone cherubs congregated in his Mayfair showroom only much more mischievous, Derek Crowther is telling the story of his most exhilarating find:

title: CANDIADTES FACE MAJOR DEBTS IN LONG CAMPAIGN
description: In the long campaign for the Presidency, money troubles are taking a toll on some candidates. Senator Gary Hart's campaign needed a $350,000 loan; Senator Alan Cranston expects his campaign debts to reach $1 million by the end of the year.

title: Racal Contract
description: Racal Electronics P.L.C. said it had received a Ministry of Defense contract, initially valued at more than $45 million, to equip 23 British frigates with electronic warfare systems. The systems are designed by Racal and the contract involves the further development of the company's support measures system.

title: Pratt & Whitney Gets Airline Job
description: Singapore's national airline said it would buy Pratt & Whitney engines valued at $275 million for 16 aircraft it has ordered.

title: NORTHWEST ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $900,000 from discontinued operations. Income in the latest quarter wasn't sufficient to cover a preferred stock dividend requirement of $1,600,000.

title: EMBATTLED COAST THRIFT UNIT
description: Former employees of the State Savings and Loan Association, the thrift unit of the giant Financial Corporation of America, have charged in recently filed court documents that officers of State engaged in fraud, kickbacks and misappropriation of company funds two years ago as its profits began a marked rise.

title: ELIZABETH A. WHITEHEAD, 55, LEADER IN ARCHEOLOGY STUDY
description: Elizabeth Augustus Whitehead, who promoted interest in classical, North American and Chinese archeology as a leader of several American archeological organizations, died of pulmonary fibrosis yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: SOLIDARITY CALLS A DAY'S BOYCOTT OF MASS TRANSIT
description: The Solidarity underground, pledging to continue to resist the Polish authorities, has called for a boycott of public transportation and other demonstrations to mark the third anniversary of the founding of the independent union on Aug. 31.

title: Peter Arne, British Actor, 62, Is Found Murdered in London
description: Peter Arne, 62 years old, a British character actor who specialized in villains, was found bludgeoned to death in his apartment in the Knightsbridge section of London, the police said Tuesday.

title: TALKS INTENSIFY IN CON ED STRIKE
description: Top negotiators in the 46-day-old strike against the Consolidated Edison Company intensified their efforts last night to resolve remaining differences and reach a settlement before a mass meeting of the 16,000 strikers set for this morning.

title: Police Lieutenant Files Bias Suit
description: A black police lieutenant has filed a suit charging the city's Police Department and its top officials with racial discrimination and retaliation.

title: AZTECH INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Hitler 'Diaries' Ruling Upset
description: Gerd Heidemann, the journalist who sold the bogus Hitler diaries to the West German magazine Stern, was back in police custody today after the state prosecutor appealed a judge's decision Tuesday to release him. A higher court said Mr. Heidemann might tamper with evidence or leave the country.

title: Two Runoff Candidates Open Mississippi Drives
description: Former Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Gandy opened her runoff campaign for the Democratic nomination for the governorship today by attacking her opponent, Attorney General Bill Allain, as an adversary of the Legislature.

title: Two Changes in Baseball
description: Baseball's restructuring effort, which moved slowly during the owners' dispute over Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, went forward today with the owners' action in two areas - centralization and voting.

title: U.S.F.L. Scouts Given a Warning
description: Vince Dooley, the football coach at Georgia, will not welcome any visitors from the United States Football League to his practice field. Last February, he lost Herschel Walker, his all-America running back, who won the Heisman Trophy as a junior, to the New Jersey Generals of the fledgling league.

title: A MILLION PEOPLE IN NEED OF U.S. FOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: EFFORT TO CURB ABUSE OF CHARITY DEDUCTION URGED
description: The key member of a Presidential committee that studied the abuse of tax laws by people who overvalue their charitable gifts to institutions said today that the Government must make a strong effort to ''get a handle on charitable giving - both for its tax implications and for its impact on recipients.''

title: Cyclotron Used to Heal Brain Abnormalities
description: Proton beams fired from a cyclotron into the brain destroyed blood vessel malformations in some patients, averting a hemorrhage that can cause fatal stroke or severe neurologic damage, researchers said today.

title: Chief Financial Officer Takes Post at EG & G
description: John K. Buckner, the former chief financial officerat the PriRe Computer Corp oration, has joined EG & G Inc. as its chief financial officer, replacing Eugene J. White, who retired on May 1.

title: HOUSE, 217-211, APPROVES RISE IN U.S. CONTRIBUTION TO THE I.M.F.
description: The House of Representatives tonight approved by a narrow 217-211 vote an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund. The vote ended weeks of doubt that House leaders would ever muster enough votes for passage.

title: CHASING DOWN UNUSUAL PERIOD PROPS
description: DONNA CORTLANDT, who is in the process of divorcing Palmer Cortlandt, her second husband and one of the richest men in the world, has moved into a large but furnitureless guest room in the mansion owned by Phoebe Wallingford, her first husband's grandmother and the social matriarch of Pine Valley. As a result Bill Mickley spent a recent afternoon seeking out just the right furniture, including an Art Nouveau double headboard and Art Nouveau vanity.

title: Two Gunmen Abduct and Rob Policeman and a Bar Owner
description: Two young gunmen jumped a tavern owner and a plainclothes police officer outside a bank in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday, forced them into the tavern owner's car, drove them to Staten Island and took nearly $3,500 and the officer's gun, the police said.

title: Bridge: 50th Anniversary Is Noted
description: The foundation of the American Bridge Association 50 years ago makes it, in a sense, senior to the larger American Contract Bridge League, which resulted from a merger of two other bodies four years later.

title: U.S.F.L. Loses San Antonio Vote
description: In a move that may keep a new United States Football League franchise out of San Antonio entirely, the City Council voted in a closed-door meeting Tuesday not to amend a restriction adopted in 1939 that prohibits professional sports at Alamo Stadium.

title: QUAKER CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE BACKS $4 BILLION PLAN OF HEALTH CARE FOR JOBLESS
description: The House of Representatives today passed a bill that would create a two-year, $4 billion program of health care benefits for workers who lose their health insurance as a result of losing their jobs.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of properties and investments of $1,188,000, or 37 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,224,000, or 38 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Includes gains from the sale of properties and investments of $83,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $117,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 4, 1983
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: HANNA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NAVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Operating loss. c-Net loss.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Retina Is Surgically Repaired
description: The retina in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's right eye was repaired in an operation today, a spokesman announced tonight.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: US FIDELTY & GUARANTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Senate Bailout Plan
description: The Senate today defeated a procedural effort to stop passage of a new financing plan for the Bonneville Power Adminstration that would allow the Federal agency to complete two Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear power projects.

title: LOSING GROUND ON DRUGS
description: The recent suspension of four professional football players for involvement with drugs undermines last year's collective bargaining agreement on rehabilitation and will do little or nothing to solve the problem of drug abuse in the National Football League. Instead of taking punitive action that discourages players from coming forth for treatment, the N.F.L.'s commissioner, Pete Rozelle, should clearly state a policy of rehabilitation and - if that fails - create a progressive schedule of fines and penalties.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: HALL, FRANK B, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $901,000, or 8 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: New Israeli Envoy in London
description: A new Israeli envoy, Yehuda Avner, presented his credentials to Queen Elizabeth today to replace Ambassador Shlomo Argov, who was gravely wounded by Arab guerrillas in a London hotel more than a year ago. Mr. Avner, a former journalist, has been a career diplomat since 1964.

title: FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $96,971 for the latest first quarter and $122,739 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: THE PAGE SYSTEM: REFORMED, BUT STILL VULNERABLE
description: In the House's recent debate over censuring two of its own members for having sexual relations with teen-age pages, Representative Bill Frenzel won a round of applause by suggesting that the page system be abolished.

title: VOLCKER DISAVOWS ROLE IN RATE RISE
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, disavowed today any role by the Fed in the rise in interest rates in recent days. He said the ''bump'' in rates had been caused by the huge Federal budget deficit and Treasury efforts to finance it.

title: TIC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $15,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $52,000.

title: St. Gobain Stock Option
description: The state-owned Compagnie de St. Gobain-Pont- a-Mousson said today that it had acquired an option to purchase 900,000 shares, or 27 percent, of Generale d'Entreprise/Sainrapt et Brice from Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, the state-owned utility that owns 51 percent of Sainrapt. St. Gobain said in a statement that C.G.E. had the option to sell the shares on Dec. 30, when the selling price will also be fixed.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Sports of the Times; HIGH DRAMA IN BOSTON
description: One of the first to appear was Gene Autry, ex-troubadour and fearless foe of rustlers, wearing an aqua-blue leisure suit, attire unexpected to one accustomed to seeing him on the silver screen in chaps. He did wear black pointy cowboy boots, though, and carried a brown business folder.

title: 5 Thrift Units Get U.S. Aid
description: Federal regulators today authorized $1,675,000 in aid for five savings and loan associations. That brings to 30 the number of institutions receiving a total of $14.1 million under a new Government program.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DIOXIN LEAVES MARK ON A CITY CALLED NITRO, BUT EXTENT OF IMPACT IS AT ISSUE
description: The toxic chemical dioxin has left its mark on this city of 8,500 people, but just how deeply or extensively is at issue.

title: Kozlovs to Dance At Garden State Center
description: Leonid and Valentina Kozlov will appear Aug. 17 at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J. The Kozlovs, former members of the Bolshoi Ballet who now dance with the New York City Ballet, will head Kozlov and Stars, a company that also includes Katherine Healy, a 14-year-old gold medalist at the 1983 International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria, and her partner, Marin Boieru, a 1976 Varna gold medalist and principal dancer with the Pennsylvania Ballet.

title: 1944 REFUGEES MEET, THIS TIME AS GUESTS
description: ''Wait a minute,'' said Edith Bronner Klein, squinting at the man before her, trying somehow in a confused instant to wipe out the decades that had made his face unfamiliar. ''Weren't you in our barracks, the ones near the cemetery?''

title: The Worm and the Apple; Rest Stops; Comforting the Public
description: When, several months ago, we awarded our first worm to the Police Department for not being tough enough with those who use the city's streets as toilets, many protested. ''Where does one answer the call of nature?'' ran a typical letter.

title: No Headline
description: CHICKENHAWK. By Robert Mason. 339 pages. Viking. $17.75.

title: SALVADOR GUERRILLAS RETURN TO A KEY PROVINCE
description: Leftist guerrilla forces who slipped away two months ago when El Salvador began a major effort to pacify a key province have now returned in sizable numbers with the aim of wrecking the pacification program, Salvadoran officers said today.

title: ALASKA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ballad to Pine Tar
description: Billy Martin of course, his voice gettin' hoarse, Was screamin' as he thrashed about; He claimed that the tar was up too far, Then the umpire called Brett out.

title: A CHRONOLOGY
description: Jan. 8, 1982: The American

title: Japan Vehicle Sales Up
description: Japan's domestic sales of passenger cars, trucks and buses climbed 10.1 percent in July from a year earlier, to 450,577 units, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today.

title: Azzurra, Victory '83 Gain
description: Azzurra of Italy and Victory '83 of Britain scored victories today and were assured berths in the semifinals of the trials to select the America's Cup challenger.

title: PALM BEACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE LIMIT OF OUR OBLIGATION IN SOUTERN AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: For weeks in contract talks with four of its unions, the Long Island Rail Road had insisted on two key points. It wanted the right to hire outside contractors to do some routine maintenance, and it wanted to change work rules so that members of one union could perform minor jobs normally done by members of another union. ''If we can do it cheaper and faster by contracting out, that's what we're going to do,'' Arthur G. Perfall, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, stated during the negotiations.

title: Charger Bauer Retires
description: Hank Bauer , the San Diego Chargers' running back known for his reckless downfield hits on the club's special teams, retired yesterday, citing a persistent neck injury, and was given a one-year contract by the Chargers as a special teams coach. Bauer, who played six seasons for the Chargers, led the club's special teams in tackles for the last four seasons.

title: Hannah May Return
description: The New England Patriots have opened discussions with John Hannah designed to get the all-pro guard back in uniform within the next two weeks. Hannah, who retired earlier this year as a result of his dissatisfaction with the game in general and Coach Ron Meyer in particular, said he was giving ''serious thought'' to rejoining New England.

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $25,400,000 from the sale of assets. c-Net loss. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CALLIGRAPHY STUDIOS FOR FINE LETTERING
description: IF your penmanship is not perfect, there are studios and artists that will do the work for you in the beautiful handwriting known as calligraphy. Some studios do engrossing, the elaborate writing that appears, for example, on traditional Jewish wedding documents.

title: Australian Reports K.G.B. Recruiting Effort
description: The K.G.B. tried to recruit a lobbyist with close connections to the ruling Labor Party, Prime Minister Bob Hawke said today at a hearing on Australia's security services.

title: WITHOUT AIR-CONDITIONING, THE GIFT OF A CITY BREEZE
description: AROUND 5 o'clock on hot summer mornings in New York a breeze springs up from the south. It stays around just long enough to clean the air, then dies at sunrise. For an hour or so my bedroom is cool, cool enough for me to wake and fumble for the sheet I've tossed off during the night.

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: The Worm and the Apple; Rest Stops; A Pleasurable Plaza
description: New Yorkers who once ate their lunch in Harley Plaza on East 41st Street have found spikes lining the ledges. Those who find the gloom of Grace Plaza on West 43d Street a good place to shoot craps continue to do so.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pretax loss of $220,000,000 on the writedown of refining assets and related employee terminations. c-Net income which includes a pretax gain of $184,000 from the sale of interest in the Colony Shale project and an extraordinary credit of $11,251,000.

title: Text of Kuhn Statement
description: Following is the text of Bowie Kuhn's statement to the major league owners yesterday in which he withdrew his name from further consideration as commissioner.

title: WADELL EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. '62 Quarantine Of Cuba Is Recalled
description: Unlike the incident off the Nicaraguan coast last weekend, a naval quarantine depends on the use of force.

title: Newton 'Critical'
description: Jack Newton, the 33-year-old Australian golfer who was severely injured July 24 when he accidentally walked into the spinning propeller of a small airplane, was in critical condition today after abdominal surgery. Doctors had been waiting for Newton to recover from the initial shock of his injuries before operating. But, after the surgery was performed overnight, his condition deteriorated today.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $19,803. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid January 1983.

title: Argentine Upsets Carling Bassett
description: Ivanna Madruga-Osses of Argentina moved into the women's quarterfinals of the United States Clay-Court championships with a 6-4, 6-1 upset of seventh-seeded Carling Bassett today.

title: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
N.J. TRANSIT TO INCREASE BUS AND TRAIN FARES BY 8%
description: The directors of the N.J. Transit Corporation today approved bus and rail fare increases averaging 8 percent, effective Sept. 1 for trains and intrastate buses and Oct. 1 for interstate buses.

title: Alaska Housing's $100 Million Issue
description: A $100 million issue of Alaska Housing Finance Corporation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 7.75 percent in 1988, 9.2 percent in 1993 and 10.11 percent in 2001, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. All but $39 million of the issue was sold by late in the day, underwriters said.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 4, 1983
description: Companies

title: HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Feb. 28.

title: BAR GROUP DECLINES TO OPPOSE AID ON TUITION
description: The American Bar Association today narrowly rejected a proposal that it oppose legislation backed by President Reagan to grant tax benefits to parents of children attending private and religious schools.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The income figures represent gross income. The second quarter and 6 months results are restated for the acquisition on July 2 of the Dailey International Group, on a pooling of interests basis.

title: BOWIE KUHN STEPS ASIDE TO PUT AN END TO ACRIMONY
description: Having decided that his continued candidacy would do ''more harm than good,'' Bowie Kuhn surprisingly stepped out of the running today to succeed himself as commissioner of baseball.

title: Brazil Acts On Savings
description: The debt-burdened Brazilian Government, trying to encourage savings, announced today that interest rates on savings accounts would be compounded monthly instead of every 90 days. It also raised interest rates on short-term loans and created a panel of officials to control public spending.

title: LAW ON CABLE-TV SMUT OVERTURNED
description: The city of Miami had good intentions but it nonetheless violated free-speech guarantees in its attempt to outlaw soft-core pornography on cable television, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $30,000. c-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in April.

title: Malta World Bank Bid
description: An application by Malta to join the World Bank will be voted on before the end of the year, World Bank officials said today. The Mediterranean nation first applied for membership in 1973.

title: URBAN LEAGUE PUTS RENEWED EMPHASIS ON SERVICING CLIENTS
description: The National Urban League is turning more attention to meeting the increasing needs of its constituents, but with fewer resources, officials of the organization say.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOUTH OF SHAKESPEARE

title: ADVERTISING ; Results Up at JWT And Interpublic
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies and JWT Group Inc., both holding companies for advertising agencies, yesterday announced improved results for the second quarter.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: J. Edward Houston, president and chief executive of the Barnett Bank of South Florida Inc., announced his resignation yesterday.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: C. Calvert Knudsen, who in 1977 took the helm of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., British Columbia's giant forestry products company, is stepping down Oct. 1 as chairman and chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: C.& N.W. Repairs
description: The Chicago & North Western Transportation Company said it had begun a $50 million, two-year program to repair the main line of the former Rock Island Railroad between Minneapolis and Kansas City, Mo. C.& N.W., which bought the line from the Rock Island's bankruptcy trustee in June, said it would initially spend about $15 million to install ties and surface about 500 miles of track to allow the railroad to increase its speeds. The additional $35 million will be spent later to allow further increases in speeds.

title: CLC OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $282,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Tour of America
description: Rowan Mostert, a 28-year-old advertising art director from Johannesburg, is about to take his first long look at the United States. While seeking a site for a prospective photography-enlargement business, he is planning a trip by bicycle from New York to Los Angeles with his first lengthy stop scheduled for Niagara Falls.

title: MIDLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of June 31
description: Assets figures represent net assets.

title: RIOTING REDUCES SRI LANKA'S HOPES FOR STABLE DEMOCRACY TO RUINS
description: Less than a year ago, this tropical nation seemed to be an island of democratic stability and impressive economic gains in a generally turbulent and impoverished part of the world.

title: AMAREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. c-After a $154.4 million writedown of the company's investment in oil and gas properties, an $8.5 million writedown of inventories and a $3.3 million provision for loss on doubtful accounts.

title: Lomas Settlement
description: The Federal Trade Commission said the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, the nation's largest mortgage banker, had agreed to maintain practices that would ensure timely payment of obligations payable from home owners' escrow accounts. A commission complaint accused the company of having failed to pay hazard insurance premiums on time from funds available in home owners' escrow accounts in 1979 and 1980, causing policies to be canceled. The F.T.C. said the settlement was intended to correct these inadequacies in the operations of the company, which is based in Dallas.

title: NEEDLESS INSISTENCE ON 'SAFE' JOBLESS LEVELS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMERS WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $424,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Iraq Changes Report On Fighting With Iran
description: Iraq said today that its forces had repulsed another Iranian attack in the central sector of the war front, killing several hundred Iranian soldiers and destroying 10 tanks and other equipment. Later, it said the fighting was continuing into the night.

title: Charges Dropped On Protest March
description: Disorderly conduct charges brought against 53 women Saturday following a confrontation with local residents during a protest march near the Seneca Army Depot were dismissed today in Waterloo Village Court.

title: MANVILLE'S CANADIAN UNIT
description: The Manville Corporation said today that it had reached agreement with a group of Canadian investors on terms for the investors' purchase of Johns-Manville Canada Inc., which operates the Jeffrey asbestos mine in Asbestos, Quebec. Manville had announced in June that it intended to sell the unit to the investors, although terms had not been agreed on.

title: UNPAID U.S. FINES TOTAL $185 MILLION, PANEL TOLD
description: The Government has failed to collect more than $185 million in Federal criminal fines, mostly for tax and narcotics offenses, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

title: Sea Trial for Competition
description: The owners of oceangoing tankers built with Federal subsidies want to return a half-billion dollars and give up the right to an additional billion. But instead of cheers and brass bands, they're getting powerful resistance. Indeed, competing shipping interests failed by only a small margin to pass a law prohibiting such repayment. And Elizabeth Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, must still run a political gantlet to reclaim the taxpayers' cash.

title: THE PARCELLS STYLE HAS GIANTS RELAXED
description: Pro football players say their most difficult task is to survive the physical strains and boredom of training camp. Many of the Giants say the problem has been eased this year because Bill Parcells, the new head coach, is so relaxed and tries to keep his players that way.

title: FILM AUDITION PRODUCES CROWD SCENE
description: Sandra Hillary, wearing a new wide-brimmed hat, said she had decided to end her retirement from acting to audition for a part in ''Cotton Club,'' a movie about the famous Harlem nightclub of the 1920's and 30's.

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
K.G.B. AGENTS, WELCOME TO THE (PEACE) CLUB!
description: To the Editor:

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 3 percent stock dividend distributed April 22, 1983.

title: Reactor Leaks Tritium At a Station in Canada
description: A nuclear reactor in Pickering, Ontario, leaked a small amount of radioactive tritium after an accident that began Monday, the Canadian authorities announced yesterday, prompting officials in Ontario and in New York State to step up air sampling.

title: 'LANGLOIS' AT PUBLIC
description: TO herald the publication of Richard Roud's biography of Henri Langlois, the Public Theater is offering free showings of ''Langlois,'' a spirited testimonial to this quintessential film enthusiast, the late founder of the Cinemathe que Fran,caise. This 52- minute documentary, made in 1971, offers a whimsical, anecdotal portrait, interspersing interviews with Mr. Langlois's admiring associates with footage of him as he walks around Paris, holding forth on anything from a house in which Jean Renoir once lived to the black and white swans he spies in a park.

title: NATIONAL KINNEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $4,920,000. c-Includes a provision of $3,500,000 for loss on the disposition of discontinued operations. d-Net loss after a provision of $8,550,000 for loss on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Alexander & Alexander Net Off 44%
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income plunged 44 percent, to $7 million, or 28 cents a share, from $12.5 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier. The company, the parent of the international insurance broker, said operating revenues edged up to $143.7 million, from $142.3 million.

title: Car Bomb Explodes In Lesotho's Capital
description: A car bomb exploded in the center of the Lesotho capital today, sending metal fragments flying and breaking windows over a wide area, witnesses said. There were no immediate reports of casualties and no official indication who was responsible.

title: A.T. & T. TALKS STALL AS A STRIKE DEADLINE NEARS
description: Although faced with a strike deadline this weekend, the full negotiating committees for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Communications Workers of America were in recess today and no resumption of full- scale talks was scheduled.

AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in October 1982 and a dividend of one share of Class B common stock for each two outstanding shares of Class A common stock distributed in July 1983.

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $63,000 from the early retirement of debt.

title: PROVIDENCE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $441,000 from an accounting change.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's recent expression of concern about hunger represents, at the very least, a dramatic change in emphasis for an Administration that has been voicing alarm about the ''explosive'' growth and abuse of food assistance programs. Democratic members of Congress, including the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., scoffed at the President's creation of a group to study hunger. They made three basic assertions: That Mr. Reagan's own budget-cutting policies had exacerbated hunger caused principally by unemployment and the recession; that hunger would be much worse if Congress had approved all his proposals, and that now was the time for action, not more studies.

title: NEW YORK FOLK FESTIVAL BEGINS TODAY
description: STREET musicians will serenade on the sidewalks of Times Square. The bluegrass veteran Peter Stampfel will bring his new quintet, Bottlecaps, to Folk City. The Lone Star Cafe will be host to a doo-wop show. And David Amram, New York's ubiquitous ''man of all musics,'' and his quintet, will give two concerts celebrating the ethnic diversity of the city's musical culture. These are a few of the nearly two dozen events in the third New York Folk Festival, which begins today and runs for nine days in the clubs and parks and on the street corners of Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: RIGHTS GROUPS SEE BIAS IN POLICIES ON REFUGEES
description: United States immigration policy is coming under increasing attack from human rights organizations whose officials assert people from Communist countries have a far easier time obtaining asylum than do those fleeing non-Communist countries.

title: SHULTZ SAYS FLEET DOES NOT PURSUE LATIN SHOWDOWN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that United States military forces exercising in Central America and the Caribbean were not seeking a confrontation and would withdraw if attacked.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTON, GEORGE, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,768,000 for the quarter and $2,788,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,047,000 for the quarter and $3,616,000 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: BANK BOARD BACKS FINANCIAL'S MERGER
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today unanimously approved the Financial Corporation of America's acquisition of the First Charter Financial Corporation to form the largest savings and loan in the nation. The endorsement included two requirements not normally asked in thrift unit mergers.

title: RSR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $424,000 for the quarter and $942,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax benefits of $951,000 for the quarter and $843,000 for the 6 months.

Changing Tide
description: Although the University of Alabama used the wishbone offense over the last dozen years while winning 115 games and losing only 19, the Crimson Tide will present a new offensive look when it opens its season Sept. 10 at Georgia Tech.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $203,000 for the quarter and $492,000 for the 6 months.

title: Former Aide Sues Exxon
description: A former employee of the Exxon Corporation has filed a $20 million lawsuit against the company, charging that it tried to steal trade secrets from a Union Carbide plant in Greenville County, S.C. In the suit, filed Wednesday, Wilton Gregory, a former Exxon Enterprises purchasing agent, said Exxon and Alex James, an industrial consultant, set up several companies, including the Princeton Company, to participate in stealing trade secrets from Union Carbide and cover up the plan with kickbacks and payoffs. Both the Union Carbide plant and the nearby Exxon plant produce carbon fibers. Mr. James, described in the suit as an agent for Exxon, said, ''It's absolute hogwash and I certainly am not going to lose any sleep over it.''

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net loss.

title: Seoul Reports Sinking North Korean Boat
description: South Korean patrol boats assisted by planes and shore troops sank a North Korean patrol boat cruising near a nuclear power plant on the southeast coast today, the Defense Ministry said.

title: BRITAIN PREPARES FOR THE N.F.L.
description: Two days before the National Football League makes its European debut here at Wembley Stadium, the hallowed seat of championship soccer, the event's promoters could use a timeout.

HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS

title: BONN CONTRITE OVER ACTIVIST WHO SPILLED BLOOD ON GENERAL
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher apologized to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today for the behavior Wednesday of a Green Party regional deputy who spilled blood on an American general.

title: FOR LUCILLE LORTEL, A NEW FORMAT
description: No sooner had Lucille Lortel said it than she took it back.

description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

description: Norwest Mortgage Inc. yesterday sold $200 million of mortgage passthrough certificates that are being offered by a Salomon Brothers group with yields of about 13.28 percent.
