TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Top Islander Choice Joins Olympic Club
description: Pat LaFontaine, the American- born hockey star who was the Islanders' first-round draft choice in June, announced yesterday that he would play on the United States Olympic team for next February's Winter Games but hoped to join the Islanders in time to help them win a fifth consecutive Stanley Cup next spring.

title: 4 JERSEY STUDENTS LOSE SUIT ON INVALIDATED S.A.T. SCORES
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that the Educational Testing Service had acted fairly in invalidating the scores of four high school students whom it had suspected of cheating on their college entrance examinations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Chicago, has promoted Dale A. Holmer to vice president.

title: Preparing a Defense
description: Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins, said that Tony Peters, the team's strong safety who was charged on Wednesday with selling cocaine, had been given a leave of absence with full pay so he could concentrate on preparing his legal defense. Saying that Peters was legally innocent until proven guilty, Cooke said that the club would arrange counsel for Peters, who was freed on an unsecured $50,000 bond following his arraignment in Federal court in Alexandria, Va. A preliminary hearing has been set for Aug. 16.

title: Again, the Tilt Toward Bias
description: While President Reagan promises to weed out Federal statutes and rules that discriminate against women, his Justice Department is trying to undermine bedrock law against sex bias in higher education.

title: FABRIC WHOLESALERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effective June 20, 1983.

title: 100 RAFTS IN CONNECTICUT RIVER RACE
description: About 100 homemade rafts, fanciful and traditional, will push off tomorrow in the ninth Connecticut River raft race, a colorful, bizarre and sometimes raucous contest that can be watched from more conventional boats or from either bank along the almost-five-mile course.

title: MOSCOW FROM SOVIET STUDY ON THE NEED FOR AN OVERHAUL OF THE ECONOMY
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a confidential memorandum on Soviet economic reorganization, as translated by The New York Times.

title: CUOMO BEGINS HIS CAMPAIGN FOR BOND ISSUE
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday began the campaign for a $1.25 billion transportation bond issue to ''rebuild New York'' amid signs of opposition and uncertainty from industry groups and public officials.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include gains of $725,000 for the quarter and $1,625,000 for the 6 months from liquidation of LIFO inventory quantities. Year-ago results reflect a provision of $800,000 for the quarter on the disposal of the company's interest in Furnco Construction Corp. and a gain of $650,000 for the 6 months from land sales.

title: FRANCES SLOAN
description: Frances Sloan, the president of the Congress of Advocates for the Retarded, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home in Manhattan.

title: KENNEDY CONCENTRATES ON THE SENATE
description: The invitations still arrive, one after the other, day after day, from automobile workers and public employee unions, nuclear freeze organizations and health care groups. In recent weeks, state Democratic parties in Idaho, Washington, Oregon and Florida have sought him for the head table.

title: Mideast Envoy Meets With Beirut Leaders
description: President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East, Robert C. McFarlane, met with Lebanese officials today and gave them Israel's reply to Lebanon's demand for a timetable on the complete withdrawal of Israeli forces.

title: Charity Gift Valuations
description: The Commissioner of Internal Revenue today told a House panel studying the valuation of gifts to charitable institutions that experts such as art appraisers and accountants should police themselves rather than expect the Internal Revenue Service to enforce standards for them.

title: Alaska Housing Bonds Offered
description: A $75 million issue of double- A-rated Alaska Housing Finance Corporation 12 7/8 percent bonds due in 1993 is being offered at 99.35 to yield 13 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. Interest on the bonds is taxable.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Questions of deployment and how many cops and where they were deployed divert attention from the very serious issue of whether a city like this can tolerate kids who just decide that they're going to maraud and terrorize other people.

title: Quintet at Sweet Basil
description: The bassist Richard Davis is leading a quintet tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South. The others in the group are Jon Faddis on trumpet, Ricky Ford on tenor saxophone, Kenny Barron on piano and Freddie Waits on drums. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $7.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: FLORIDA CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mattel to Lay Off 400 In Electronics Division
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it would lay off 400 more white-collar employees at its Hawthorne, Calif., headquarters, and a spokesman indicated that the company was considering whether to discontinue marketing its sole entry in the home computer market.

title: ALL-MALE GOLF CLUB GREETS BIAS SUIT WITH 'NO COMMENT' STANCE
description: Attorney General Stephen H. Sachs of Maryland filed a lawsuit here today against the Burning Tree Club, the Washington area's toniest country club, charging that its policy of excluding women was ''arbitrary, invidious and irrational'' and in violation of the State Constitution.

title: Todd Works Out as Punter
description: The Jets are apparently priming Richard Todd as a secret weapon.

title: STAGE: ESTELLE PARSONS IN 'ORGASMO ADULTO'
description: DON'T tell Estelle Parsons that biting political satire is all but extinct in the American theater. With heroic persistence, she is determined to contradict that fact. In ''Orgasmo Adulto Escapes From the Zoo,'' the actress spends almost five hours (divided over two nights) performing a cycle of largely satirical one-woman plays by the highly regarded, leftist Italian husband-and-wife team of Dario Fo and Franca Rame.

title: KOCH WANTS BILL ON EAST RIVER PROJECT REDRAFTED
description: Mayor Koch yesterday repudiated legislation that had been proposed by his administration to let the Port Authority start a major development on the Queens shore of the East River.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ALTHOUGH there should be nothing unusual about finding a new Italian restaurant in Little Italy, the five-month-old Georgine Carmella, on Mulberry Street, between Broome and Grand Streets, comes as something of a surprise. Little Italy has never before seen quite this level of sophistication, neither in food nor decor. Both would be more at home in SoHo or Greenwich Village. Less corny looking than the old-fashioned Neapolitan restaurants that typify the area, and more restrained than the gussied-up stage settings of newer establishments, the rose-pink dining room is as casual and elegant as a silk shirt. The soft lighting is comfortable, and so are the large, widely spaced tables. The only flaw is loud and insistent music, which drowns out the voices of the staff members, who, in affected whispers, recite intricate details of the nightly specials. Omitted, however, are the prices. Service also tends to be slow, especially between appetizers and main courses.

title: Lea of Expos Halts Mets' Streak at 4;  Expos 2 Mets 1
description: The Mets' run at next-to-last place in the National League East came to a standstill yesterday for the time being. The Montreal Expos, among three teams making a run at first place, ended the Mets' four-game winning streak with a 2-1 victory before a crowd of 11,703 at Shea Stadium.

title: Walter Landauer Is Dead; A Partner in Piano Duo
description: The pianist Walter Landauer, a partner in the Rawicz and Landauer piano duo for 40 years, died Wednesday at Hillingdon Hospital in London at the age of 72.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIDAY, AUGUST 5, 1983
description: International

title: INDUSTRIAL ACOUSTICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Warsaw Pours Scorn On Solidarity Pledge
description: The Polish Government spokesman said today that a pledge by underground members of the outlawed Solidarity union to continue their struggle despite the lifting of martial law showed that its leaders had learned nothing.

title: Southwestern Bell Expands
description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, chose the name the Southwestern Bell Corporation for a holding company it is forming. It is to be the parent of four subsidiaries, including the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, a yellow pages directory subsidiary, a division to market business telecommunications systems and a cellular mobile telephone group.

title: WHEN EVEN 'TEMPORARY' WANT IS UNACCEPTABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: PETER HYAMS DIRECTS 'STAR CHAMBER'
description: PETER HYAMS has shown himself, with films like ''Busting,'' ''Outland'' and ''Capricorn One,'' to be a stylish, flippant director, capable of generating a great deal of suspense as well as action scenes that really pack a wallop. ''The Star Chamber,'' which opens today at Loews Tower East and other theaters, begins so excitingly that Mr. Hyams appears to have outdone himself.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,247,000 for the quarter and $2,287,000 for the 6 months.

title: MONTEDISON: SHIFT IN STRATEGY
description: Although Montedison, the giant Italian chemicals company, appears to be drowning in red ink, its stock is soaring, and so is morale at company headquarters here.

title: The Fun of Fooling Fish In Prospect Park Lake
description: The rules are few and simple.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARVESTER UNIT TO GET FRENCH FINANCIAL AID
description: The International Harvester Company said today that the French Government had agreed to grant some form of financial assistance to its French subsidiary, a move that could prevent the closing of Harvester's tractor plant in St. Dizier.

title: 5 OF 7 REVIEWED FOR TOP COURT GET HIGH RANKING OF BAR UNIT
description: An organization of 13 bar groups in New York State yesterday issued ratings on the seven candidates proposed for a vacancy on the State Court of Appeals.

title: INTRA-AGENCY RIFTS LAID TO NICARAGUAN OPERATION
description: United States covert operations in Nicaragua have proved to be a mixed blessing for the Central Intelligence Agency, the organization is responsible for financing and managing 10,000 Nicaraguan rebels.

title: F.A.A. Says Vigilantes Are Threat In Hijacking
description: ''John Wayne'' heroics do not belong in airplane cabins, even when the plane is being hijacked to Cuba, a Federal aviation official says.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article July 21 describing the arrival of Siberian Pentecostals in St. Louis erred in a reference to the Christian calendar. Pentecost and Trinity Sundays are a week apart.

title: Clay Felker Coming Back With an East Side Weekly
description: Clay S. Felker, who founded New York magazine and lost control of it to Rupert Murdoch in 1977, will be back in competition when he takes over the weekly East Side Express in mid-September.

title: 'VALENTINA' FROM SPAIN
description: PEPE, we are told at the beginning of Antonio Jose Betancor's ''Valentina,'' is ''a typically intelligent and sound Spanish man, capable of making his dignity a kind of religion.'' The film begins with the news that Pepe has been killed during World War II, and it flashes back to his childhood to explain how he came to be a person of such conviction.

title: Plan to Allow TV Ads For Lawyers in Jersey
description: New Jersey lawyers would be able to advertise on television and radio under strict guidelines proposed today by the State Supreme Court.

title: BURR-BROWN RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column Wednesday gave a horse owner's first name incorrectly. She is Hilda Silverstein.

title: DIVIDEND FOR BANKS
description: It will be deeply unfortunate if President Reagan signs the bill repealing withholding on dividends and interest. Yet the odds are that he will sign it, despite earlier statements that he would veto it. If he does, the record will be there for all to see: a spineless Congress, joined by a wilted executive, touching their collective forelocks, doing the bidding of the banking and savings and loan industries.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Harland Receives 4 Ship Contracts
description: Harland & Wolff, once the world's biggest shipyard, may be saved from collapse by a $105 million order for four ships.

title: RAIL MUSEUM IS MOVING TO SCRANTON
description: In memory of the railroads that once carried its coal to market and in the hope of attracting tourists, Scranton is providing a new home to Steamtown U.S.A.

GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $3,251,540 from insurance proceeds, net of certain employment contract costs. c-Including tax credits of $144,910 for the quarter and $174,810 for the 6 months.

title: JURY TO INVESTIGATE MURDER OF A CHINESE-AMERICAN
description: A Federal grand jury in Detroit will investigate the murder of a Chinese-American man to determine if any civil rights laws were violated, the Justice Department said today.

title: Jazz at Summerpier
description: Summerpier will present three free jazz concerts at the South Street Seaport this weekend at Pier 16 near Fulton Street. Tonight, the New York Samba Band will perform at 8; tomorrow night, the bassist Saheb Sarbib will lead his quintet at 8, and the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band will perform Sunday at 6 P.M. Free tickets are available two hours before show time at the South Street Seaport Museum, 669-9400.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''WHO needs Europe in the summer when we have places like the South Street Seaport?'' Bob Schuler was asking his wife, Patrice Munsel, and Cyndy Garvey. At the other end of the table Marvin Hamlisch was telling Arlene Dahl, ''New York is wonderful in the summer,'' and in the background, Wendy Blanc was playing summery selections on her harp.

title: AMERICAN INVESTMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including $672,000 income for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations and extraordinary credits of $11,629,000 for the quarter and $12,384,000 for the 6 months.

title: Sheik Sets Another Mark
description: Sheik Mohammed ibn Rashid al Maktoum of Dubai, who set a world record last month by purchasing a yearling thoroughbred for $10.2 million in Kentucky, set a Saratoga Sales record tonight by paying $3 million for a son of Spectacular Bid out of Northern Dancer's daughter Mrs. Peterkin during the third night of the Fasig-Tipton Saratoga Select Yearling Sales. The bay colt was consigned by Newstead Farm.

title: ART: LARRY RIVERS: PERFORMING FOR THE FAMILY' AT EAST HAMPTON GUILD HALL
description: ''LARRY RIVERS: Performing for the Family'' at the Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton, L.I., is what its title suggests - a nonstop performance in half-a-dozen media by a longtime resident of the area who likes to work for an extended family of friends and lovers and who has always been seen center stage in whatever he is doing at the time.

title: Air on Long Island
description: The jazz trio Air, with Henry Threadgill on saxophone, Fred Hopkins on bass and Steve McCall on drums, will appear tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Inter-Media Art Center, 253 Bayville Avenue in Bayville, L.I. Tickets are $6, and the number for information and reservations is (516) 628-8585.

title: American Medical Must Sell Unit
description: American Medical International Inc. will be required to sell French Hospital in San Luis Obispo, Calif., the Federal Trade Commission announced.

title: MANHATTAN NIGHTCLUBS ECHO TO A LATIN BEAT
description: At 10 P.M. Monday, Ottavio was hawking La Carmencita cigarros to the people waiting in line outside the Village Gate. White convertibles settled like mosquitoes into double park. Young people carried cassette players as big as suitcases. The line grew quickly, curving from Bleecker onto Thompson Street. Why? The appearance of Ruben Blades, a handsome young Latin singer who is blond, wears tight white trousers and is currently numero uno in the hearts of New York's Latin music fans.

title: A JAZZ FESTIVAL FOR LONG ISLAND
description: JAZZ and the blues are indoor pursuits until the beginning of summer. Then, all of a sudden, the music makes its way into the open air, from Montreux, Switzerland, to Nice, France, from Pori, Finland, to the South Street Seaport. Tomorrow night at 8, Long Island begins its own jazz festival, a modest but well-chosen group of free concerts presented at Heckscher State Park in Islip by International Art of Jazz, whose advisory council includes The New York Times jazz critic John S. Wilson.

title: ART: 'THREE FRENCH ARTISTS' AT ZABRISKIE GALLERY
description: IN ''Three French Artists,'' the Zabriskie Gallery, at 724 Fifth Avenue, has brought to New York three artists - Pierre Buraglio, Bertrand Lavier and Georges Rousse - almost totally unknown in the United States. None of the three were included in the contingent of more than 20 French artists shown in the city last year. None have any real affinity with the current vogue of Neo-Expressionism, known in France primarily as Figuration Libre. What these artists share with one another and with some artists in the gallery is an interest in humble materials and a resistance to traditional categories that can be both provocative and refined.

title: Confusion in ZIP 10128
description: Lenore Pollak, who lives on the Upper East Side, says she has had no first-class mail delivery since last week; a check she mailed two weeks ago within her 10128 ZIP-code area was delivered Tuesday. Fred Harte, who lives in the same new ZIP area, says he is waiting for his bank statement - due two weeks ago - but is getting plenty of third-class mail.

title: Bridge: New Uses for a Dying Bid: The Old Strong Jump Shift
description: On the endangered bridge species list, with survival distinctly doubtful, is the strong jump shift. For the past quarter of a century many experts have preferred the weak jump shift, allowing the responder to show immediately a long suit and a bad hand.

title: MISS LAVELLE CITED ON FELONY COUNTS
description: Rita M. Lavelle was indicted today on five felony counts of lying about her actions when she headed the Environmental Protection Agency's toxic waste cleanup program.

title: Coast Thrift Unit Set to Sell Stock
description: The Central Savings and Loan Association, San Diego, said it planned to offer 3.2 million units, each consisting of one common share and one five-year warrant to buy one common share, as part of its conversion to stock ownership from mutual ownership.

title: KEY MINISTERS GO TO OTHER PARTIES
description: Bettino Craxi was sworn in today as the first Socialist Prime Minister of Italy. Most of the key ministries in his five-party coalition Cabinet were assigned to non-Socialists, however, precluding significant shifts in Italy's usual middle-of-the-road policies or in ties with its Western European and American allies.

title: Tokyo Troupe Due
description: The Wakabayashi Troupe from Tokyo will perform Matsuri-Bayashi music, instrumental music from the Japanese folk tradition, at the Ear Inn, 326 Spring Street, on Sunday at 4 P.M. Tickets are $3. Information: 226-9060.

title: AND NOW WE HAVE 'SON OF CARLUCCI'
description: Add to the lexicon on trimming military spending a new entry: ''Son of Carlucci.''

title: HOUSE ACTS TO REQUIRE REPORTING PF SMALL BUSINESSES' TOXIC WASTE
description: The House of Representatives today adopted an amendment that would require small businesses to report the toxic wastes they produce.

title: ZAPATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $969,000 for the quarter and $2,028,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,631,000 for the quarter and $5,795,000 for the 6 months.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Edinburgh, Venice, Deauville, Toronto - are gearing up, and the other night, Ruda Dauphin, the American director for the Deauville bash brought prospective participants together at a nice French restaurant uptown.

description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET SAYS CHESS STAR WON'T PLAY IN CALIFORNIA
description: The Soviet Union insisted Wednesday that it would not allow its young chess star Gari Kasparov to compete in California on Saturday in the semifinal of the world chess challengers' competition. In a related matter, Abu Dhabi withdrew as the host of the other semifinal. Florencio Campomanes, the president of the International Chess Federation (FIDE), said that there were strong rumors that the Russians feared that Mr. Kasparov would defect, but that he could not confirm them.

title: At Sales, Prices Soar but Spirits Drop
description: The same old sales crowd seems up to its usual pace this week, spending hundreds of thousands on yearlings and tossing back gin-and-tonics while swapping royal gossip outside the bars and paddocks at the Fasig-Tipton Select Yearling Sales. Something is different, though, in a lack of the giddy excitement that has buoyed the sales world for several years. In its place is a reticence, a dullness of spirit that many owners, breeders and horsemen here have noticed. They suggest it traces back to what happened in Lexington, Ky., on July 19.

description: b-After a loss of $839,000 from discontinued operations, a loss of $1,570,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations, and an extraordinary credit of $518,000. c-After a loss of $149,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $1,448,000 from discontinued operations.

title: REPORT COULD UNDRCUT ATOMIC VETERANS' CASES
description: The scientists whose studies are most heavily relied upon by American veterans to show they were harmed by atomic radiation have just completed a new study that casts doubt on that likelihood.

description: Shane Rawley became the first Yankee starter in a week to win a game tonight when he beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-1, and gave his team its only victory in the four-game series at Exhibition Stadium.

description: A confidential memorandum circulating among Soviet officials argues that economic performance will improve only with an overhaul of the economic system that would reduce the powers of the bureaucracy and increase the scope for initiative at the plant level.

title: School Standards Cost Money
description: The welcome debate about how to improve education has so far produced mostly political pieties and simplistic ideas about merit pay for teachers. That makes all the more welcome the ideas and standards recently put forward by New York's Board of Regents. They seem promising indeed - if the public is willing to pay the cost.

description: The United States submitted additional evidence to the United Nations today to bolster charges that chemical and toxin weapons had been used in Southeast Asia.

title: FROM ONE NATION 'UNDER GOD' TO 'WITHOUT GOD'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Avco Files Suit Against Canadair
description: The Avco Corporation said it filed a $100 million lawsuit against Canadair Ltd. of Quebec, claiming the company broke an agreement to buy 600 jet engines. Avco's action comes three months after Canadair charged that the Greenwich-based company failed to fulfil its contractural obligations and filed a $109.6 million (Canadian currency) damage suit in a Superior Court in Quebec.

title: Fear Voiced on Cracks At Five Nuclear Plants
description: Suspected pipe cracks in five nuclear power plants that some Government officials wanted to shut down this month may be deeper than previously believed, the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was told today.

title: UNITED FIRST FEDERAL S&L ASSN (SARASOTA, FLA) Qtr to June 30 reports earnings for 1983
description: b-Net loss.

title: BEIRUT MASSACRES: AN IGNORED REPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: SOME TAME GAZELLE. By Barbara Pym. 252 pages. Dutton. $13.95. ABOUT a third of the way through this lovely, muted novel, Belinda turns to her sister and declares, ''Today has been rather trying, hasn't it really - too much happening.'' What has happened, it turns out, is that the archdeacon's wife has left on holiday that morning; and the archdeacon himself has come to pay the Bede sisters, Harriet and Belinda, a tea-time visit. So circumscribed are the lives of the English spinsters and clergymen who populate Barbara Pym's novels that such events pass as high drama. And yet Miss Pym's depiction of these timid lives is so skillful that the reader not only cares enormously about what happens but also experiences , along with the characters, the significance of these everyday events.

title: 6-MONTH SURGE IN AIDS REPORTED
description: The number of cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome that are reported weekly has more than doubled in the last six months, Federal health officials said today.

title: KEEL RULING SOUGHT FROM WORLD BODY
description: The New York Yacht Club, which sponsors the America's Cup races, continued its efforts today to question the use by Australia II of a radical keel in the trial races among challengers. The club's America's Cup Committee officially requested in a letter a ruling on the validity of the keel from the sport's international authority.

title: MARRIOTT HOTEL BUILDERS TO HIRE MORE MINORITIES
description: The developers of the Marriott Marquis Hotel near Times Square agreed yesterday to hire 20 additional black and Hispanic workers and to consider hiring more minority-owned companies as subcontractors.

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Food Stamp Budget Wins Block's Praise
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that a food stamp budget kept him, his wife, their daughter and her friend well fed for a week, but he acknowledged, ''It's impossible to really appreciate the plight of the poor.''

title: ACCOUNTING METHOD SHELVED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today imposed a temporary ban on the use of an accounting method that more than a dozen computer software companies, including some giants, have used to increase their earnings.

title: Economic Scene; Symptoms Of Myopia
description: THE view that shortsightedness on the part of business is to blame for this country's current economic woes seems to be widely held. Robert Reich, a leading Democratic proponent of industrial policies involving a greater Government role in the economy, has argued that the rise of ''paper entrepreneurialism'' has led managers to focus excessively on the short run in allocating capital and labor.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS AT RECORD IN PERIOD
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, one of the nation's biggest military contractors, said yesterday that it posted its best-ever profit in the second quarter on the strength of improved performance in its aerospace and submarine-building programs.

title: REAGAN SEEKS TO LIMIT A LAW BANNING SEX BIAS IN SCHOOLS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to file a brief Monday at the Supreme Court saying that an educational institution may continue to receive Federal funds for some programs even if programs in the school that are not federally aided do discriminate against women.

title: YOUTH 18, GETS TWO-YEAR TERM IN FATAL BEATING
description: An 18-year-old youth was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison in connection with the fatal beating of a black transit worker by white youths on a Brooklyn street 13 months ago.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The share earnings and shares outstanding for fiscal 1982 were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid on May 20, 1983.

title: Barclays Bank Earnings Rise
description: The Barclays Group, which operates Britain's largest clearing bank in terms of assets, today reported that pretax profits rose 11 percent in the first half of the year, to $:262 million, or $393 million, up from $:236 million last year. Charges for bad and doubtful debts were increased sharply, to $:193 million, from $:115 million a year before.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 50 FILM CLASSICS AT CARNEGIE

title: 30-YEAR BONDS SOLD AT 12.08%
description: The Treasury sold a record $4 billion of 30-year bonds bonds yesterday at an average yield of 12.08 percent, as weak investor demand prompted securities dealers to raise yields to the highest levels since last September.

title: Arson Rate in Boston May Reach 4 - Year Low
description: Fewer buildings have been burned deliberately this year in Boston than last year, when there was a rash of fires caused by arsonists. Officials predicted that the 1983 arson rate would be the lowest in four years.

title: LOGETRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After equity in income of subsidiary of $98,000 for the quarter and $155,000 for the 6 months. c-After equity in income of subsidiary of $56,000 for the quarter and $58,000 for 6 months. d-Net income

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CRAFT TRIAL DEPOSITION READ
description: A consultant warned Christine Craft before she started work as a television anchor that Kansas City was a conservative town and that she would have to take special care with her dress and appearance, according to testimony today.

title: SIPPICAN OCEAN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect 5-for-4 stock split paid February.

title: New Applications by Jobless For Benefits Continue to Fall
description: New applications for unemployment compensation payments continued to decline in late July, signaling the likelihood of further improvement in the nation's double-digit jobless rate, a Government report said today.

title: Myers to Bills
description: Tommy Myers, the New Orleans Saints' free safety who missed last season with a shoulder injury, was traded to the Buffalo Bills yesterday for an undisclosed draft choice. The trade was arranged after Myers, who had been expected to retire, proved that he was still able to play by making three tackles and successfully defending against a pass in the Saints' exhibition opener against the Pittsburgh Steelers on Saturday.

title: Crisis doodles by Kennedy.
description: A SHEET of doodling that President John F. Kennedy is said to have penciled during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis is one of seven items bearing his handwriting that will be offered in a sale by Charles Hamilton Galleries next Thursday at 7:30 P.M. at the New York Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 55th Street. All the Kennedy material - the sheet of doodling, four letters, an invitation to the Inauguration and an autographed copy of ''Profiles in Courage'' - have been consigned by Aine Tubridy Gibson, daughter of Dorothy Tubridy, to whom most of the material is addressed. Mrs. Tubridy, long a close friend of the Kennedy family, is the widow of Michael Tubridy, an Irish horse trainer and rider. She lives in Dublin.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $10.4 million from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $22.4 million from discontinued operations.

title: Market Place; The Parts Of A.T.& T.
description: JOHN L. CLENDENIN is among a corps of telephone company executives poised to march into a competitive new world next Jan. 1. That is the breakup date set for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, an event in which its 3.2 million stockholders also hold a stake.

title: Court Backs CSX Merger
description: A Federal appeals court today cleared the way for the CSX Corporation to take over the Texas Gas Resources Corporation in a transaction valued at $1.07 billion. The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia had blocked the merger July 8 at the request of the Water Transport Association, which represents the commercial barge industry.

title: Reports Differ on Loan for Nigeria
description: Nigeria and the International Monetary Fund have reached agreement on a new credit to help the country out of a severe recession caused by a drop in oil sales, Transport Minister Umaru Dikko said today. He told reporters he could not say how much Nigeria would draw under the agreement, but added that the fund had waived its usual requirement of a devaluation as part an austerity program that would make more money available for foreign payments while domestic spending was cut back.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jet With 252 Aboard Is Hijacked to Cuba
description: A man who said he had dynamite on board hijacked a Capitol Airlines jetliner with 252 people to Cuba tonight, the ninth hijacking to Cuba this year, the authorities said.

title: Different Games
description: Before joining the Detroit Tigers, Sparky Anderson managed the Cincinnati Reds to four pennants and two world championships between 1970 and 1976.

title: Jury to Weigh Death for Mother
description: A 20- year-old mother of five convicted of murder in the fatal beating of her 3-year-old son testified today before a jury that must decide if she should become the first woman executed in New Jersey since 1906.

title: SUNRISE SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMGEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tokyo Airport Fees
description: Airlines using Tokyo's new international airport at Narita will have to pay higher fuel transport fees beginning in January, an airport spokesman said today. The spokesman for the new Tokyo International Airport Authority said the Transport Ministry approved its application for a unilateral 12 percent staged increase in the fuel transport fee.

title: Colts Beat Oilers
description: Johnnie Wright scored on a 4-yard run, and Vernon Maxwell, a rookie linebacker, made three sacks tonight to lead the Baltimore Colts to a 15-0 exhibition victory over the Houston Oilers. The Colts, who were 0-8-1 last season in the National Football League, won for the first time since they beat the Chicago Bears, 26-17, last Sept. 4 in an exhibition game. The Oilers played without their star running back, Earl Campbell, who has a pulled leg muscle.

title: Reagan's Industrial Committee
description: President Reagan named a 21-member commission today to determine how the United States can compete better in the technological revolution and turn industrial innovations into profits.

title: LIBYA SAID TO STRIKE DEEPER
description: The State Department said today that the United States would increase aid to Chad to $25 million from the present package of $10 million to help it fight a Libyan-backed insurgency.

title: THE LAST GESTURE
description: Champagne was being sprayed all over the dock, but it was not French champagne. Some very happy Italian sailors were dousing themselves and their supporters late Wednesday afternoon after Azzurra had qualified for the next round of the America's Cup.

title: MCGUIRE PRAISES HIS OFFICERS FOR RESTRAINT AMID CHARGES
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that his officers have been ''incredibly restrained'' in the face of allegations of police brutality.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Funds Drop $61 Million
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $61 million, to $164.9 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: VOLUNTEER FIRE FORCES ATTACKED OF SEX BIAS
description: Last January, the chief of the volunteer fire force here received a letter from the Nassau County chapter of the Civil Liberties Union requesting a copy of the bylaws of his department for a countywide survey on discrimination against women.

title: ALLEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRINK'S WITNESS TELLS OF SUSPECTS' MEETINGS
description: A surprise witness took the stand in the Brink's trial in Manhattan yesterday and identified several suspects as members of a group that used her apartment for meetings before the 1981 Brink's robbery and shootout in Rockland County.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Buyer Passes Muster
description: A week after Steve Belkin withdrew his bid to buy the Boston Celtics because of publicity about gambling activities of the relatives of one of his business associates, an official of the National Basketball Association said that the league's investigation of Belkin had found him to be ''clean.''

title: Akzo Cited by E.E.C.
description: The European Economic Community has ordered Akzo N.V. to stop what it called predatory price cuts aimed at putting a British company, Engineering and Chemical Supplies, out of business. The British concern makes benzoyl peroxide, which it exports for use as a catalyst in plastics manufacture.

title: AT PEACE WITH ISRAEL
description: Today, more than six years after Prime Minister Menachem Begin came to power and a little more than a year after the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, relations between Israel and the United States are more harmonious and tranquil than at almost any time since the October 1973 war.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July.

title: Munoz Ends Holdout
description: Abandoning his demand for a renegotiation of his contract, Anthony Munoz, the star tackle for the Cincinnati Bengals, ended his holdout and reported to training camp yesterday. ''I just thought it was time to swallow some pride and just get back,'' said Munoz, who has three years and an option year left on his contract.

title: ALBERTA ENERGY CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a special gain of $21.1 million on oil sands development agreement.

title: The Threat From Brazil
description: Brazil deserves at least as much of the Reagan Administration's attention as Nicaragua - and more understanding. It is a dynamic country, by far the most powerful and promising in Latin America. The burden of its $90 billion foreign debt threatens its stability, the cause of democracy in South America and even the foundations of world finance.

title: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 1983
description: b-Net income.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.3 million for the quarter and $2.2 million for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.4 million for the quarter and $2.2 million for the 6 months. d-Net loss.

title: WAYNE-GOSSARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $720,503 for the quarter and $757,578 for the 6 months, and a charge of $520,000 from the loss of discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a gain of $63,636 for the quarter from discontinued operations and a loss from discontinued operations of $5,386 for the 6 months. Year-ago results are reclassified.

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
RADCLIFFE COLLEGE DEAN IN 20'S
description: Bernice Brown Cronkhite, an educator and former dean of Radcliffe College, died Wednesday at the Stillman Infirmary of the Harvard University Health Services in Cambridge, Mass. She was 90 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AN ABANDONED STANCE AGAINST THE ARMS RACE
description: To the Editor:

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIDAY, AUGUST 5, 1983
description: Markets

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $175,000 for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations and securities losses of $8,000 for the quarter and $6,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $450,000 for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations, a securities loss of $4,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a gain of $208,000 for the 6 months on the sale of investments. d-Net loss.

title: Letter: On M.T.A. Purchases Bad Faith on 'Buy American'
description: To the Editor:

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A.T.& T.-Hilton
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has purchased the Terrace Hilton in Cincinnati for $15 million, resulting in a $7.6 million net gain for Hilton. A.T.&T. has been the major tenant for the office space in the hotel, where it ran a training center, and its employees coming for training generally occupy one third of the hotel rooms, according to an A.T.&T. spokesman. He said the purchase made sense from a cost standpoint and did not signify an attempt by A.T.&T. to go into the hotel business. Hilton will manage the hotel under contract to A.T.&T.

title: F.C.C. BACKS CHANGES IN SYNDICATION RULES
description: The Federal Communications Commission today tentatively agreed to relax rules that prevent television networks from making a profit on reruns of shows that have appeared on prime- time television.

title: DILUTING COMPASSION
description: El Salvador is a poor and violent country in which few Americans would choose to live. Thousands of Salvadorans leave their country every year and illegally come to the United States. Once they are in the United States, should they all be allowed to stay?

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Thorn EMI Names A New Chairman Peter Laister, managing director of Thorn EMI P.L.C. since 1979, has been named to replace Sir Richard Cave, 63 years old, as chairman and chief executive of the British-based home entertainment and electronic equipment group. Mr. Laister will assume most of his new duties in October, the company said.

title: THE WAGES OF HATRERD
description: The recent upsurge of Armenian terrorism raises some complex problems. Despite intermittent clucks of revulsion, there hasn't been a strong enough international stand on terrorism to provide a clear answer.

title: AMSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IF THERE'S BAGAGE ON THE SCENE, IT MUST BE FRIDAY
description: It's 8.30 A.M. and a working day, but there's something different about the streets in midtown Manhattan. There are crowds, of course, but that's not all. Today is Friday, and if it's Friday and the sun is shining, a good percentage of the swirling humanity disembarking from buses, subways and taxis is staggering under the weight of stuffed carryalls, totes, duffel bags and luggage of every description.

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses after losses of $13,728,000 for the quarter and $13,500,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: WATSON STUMBLES TO A 75 IN THE P.G.A.
description: The 65th championship of the Professional Golfers Association got off to a breezy start today with the usual uneven developments of an opening round. One was that a club professional held the lead briefly. Another was that Tom Watson practically blew his chance to win with a 7 on the second hole and another 7 on the 11th hole of the 72-hole tournament. Watson, one of the heavy favorites, shot 75 and may be pressed to make the 36-hole cut Friday.

title: STOCKS OFF, DOW FALLS BY 14.73
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in heavy trading because of investor concern over rising interest rates.

title: IACOCCA ASKS DELAY OF WARRANT SALE
description: The Chrysler Corporation will ask the Federal Government to postpone the sale of the 14.4 million Chrysler stock warrants it holds until the auto maker seeks a Congressional review of the matter, the company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said today.

title: CIRCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUYING FRESH SWEET CORN AT HUDSON VALLEY FARMS
description: Later than usual, the sweet-corn harvest is now on in the Hudson Valley. Until the first frost in October, farmstands will be offering fresh corn, one of the vegetable delights of the summer.

title: AUSTRALIAN 'KITTY'
description: DONALD CROMBIE'S ''Kitty and the Bagman'' takes place in a very odd part of Australia: the part that adjoins the old Warner Bros. back lot, or so it seems. That, at least, is the feeling of this colorful gangster movie, with its unlikely Australian air.

title: Failure to Refuel Led To Emergency Landing
description: The crew of a Republic Airlines DC-9 forced to make an emergency landing at an Air Force base when it was nearly out of fuel did not take on fuel at its previous stop because the pilot and co-pilot thought they had enough, transcripts of a cockpit conversation showed today.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 5, 1983
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: BRIDGE IN OLD SAYBROOK IS CLOSED
description: A 67-year-old wood and iron bridge here was closed indefinitely today after inspectors from the state's Transportation Department found it to be ''very rapidly deteriorating.''

title: FILM: PAUL BRICKMAN'S 'RISKY BUSINESS'
description: ALTHOUGH Paul Brickman's ''Risky Business'' shows an abundance of style, you would be hard pressed to find a film whose hero's problems are of less concern to the world at large. Joel Goodsen (Tom Cruise) is an affluent suburban teen-ager, sex- starved yet smug, whose erotic daydreams begin to come true, once his parents go on vacation and leave him to hold the fort.

title: L.I. OFFERS SCULPTURE IN WOODED SITES
description: A LITTLE more than five miles from the New York City line, the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art, just off Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor, sits in 145 acres of landscaped grounds. The handsome, neoGeorgian building, constructed in the 1904 and originally called Clayton, was formerly a Frick family mansion, but many of its rooms have now been effectively adapted as gallery space for exhibitions. A group show of new work by seven Long Island artists will open there Aug. 14.

title: Net at Ogilvy Declines 15.1%
description: Ogilvy & Mather International released its second quarter figures yesterday, the first of the four public agencies so far to show a decline. Although revenues were $86.3 million, a gain of 5 percent from the $82.2 million in the quarter last year, net income was down 15.1 percent, to $3.7 million, or 85 cents a share, from $4.4 million, or $1.03.

title: Yuri B. Levitan, 69; Moscow Announcer
description: Yuri B. Levitan, a radio announcer whose voice chronicled the battles of World War II for millions of Soviet citizens, died today, Tass, the Soviet press agency reported.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: MORTON GOULD TRIBUTE PLAYED BY GUGGENHEIM BAND
description: THE temptation is to be critically generous when listening to outdoor music, particularly when the music is actually appropriate to the setting, as was the case in the concert given by the Guggenheim Concert Band in Damrosch Park on Wednesday night.

title: CUOMO VETOES BILL TO LET 3 UNJUSTLY IMPRISONED SUE THE STATE
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday vetoed special bills that would have allowed three people who had wrongfully been imprisoned to sue the state for damages.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch July 26 from Wilkes-Barre, Pa., about competition between two newspapers there located the city on the wrong river. It is on the Susquehanna.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED AFTER KUHN LEAVES
description: The person who replaces Bowie Kuhn could survive in the job more easily because of a change that is expected in the method to elect the baseball commissioner and because of the likely creation of an owners' board of directors.

title: Quality of Life in the Bronx
description: At Mayor Koch's ''town hall meeting'' the other evening, at Junior High School 135 in the Pelham Parkway area of the Bronx, there were several complaints from an exuberant crowd of several hundred that hoodlums were gathering on Pelham Parkway itself - drinking and playng radios until all hours of the night.

title: Settlement Approved In Test Score Dispute
description: A Federal district judge has approved a settlement that allows the disputed test scores of a group of prospective medical school students to stand until they can retake the admissions test.

title: No Headline
description: Capt. Thomas Sankara, a left-wing paratroop commander, announced today that he seized control Thursday night from Jean-Baptiste Ouedraogo, the President of Upper Volta.

title: UNITED TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTMIN RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3,600,000 share private placement in March. The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: COLON, LAVOE AND TORO WITH VARIATIONS ON SALASA
description: WILLIE COLON, Hector Lavoe and Yomo Toro, the headliners in tomorrow night's pop concert at Pier 84, 12th Avenue and 45th Street, once made an album together called ''The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.'' Which was which?

title: Advertising; A Tale of Two Cable Magazines
description: TV-CABLE WEEK magazine appears be having troubles, judging by the fact that last week it replaced its publisher.

title: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes unrealized foreign currency gains of $236,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $2,707,000, or 11 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Includes unrealized foreign currency gains of $4,081,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $8,313,000, or 32 cents a share, for the 6 months. Results for 1983 include a gain of $1,699,000, or 7 cents a share, from vessel sales.

title: State Senator Gets Reprimand on Fee
description: State Senator James R. Hurley, who received a $10,000 fee in a land deal for a state park in his hometown, received a reprimand today from a legislative ethics committee.

title: Prime at 11% At Texas Bank
description: - Banctexas Group Inc. said it is raising its prime rate to 11 percent, from 10 1/2 percent, effective Friday. The bank holding company has assets of $2 billion and 14 member banks in the Dallas, Houston and Tyler, Tex., markets.

title: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'ONE NATION!' IS THE CRY FOR NIGERIANS ON THE STUMP
description: In the surprisingly cool air of morning, a caravan of Mercedes and Peugeot sedans wends its way through the streets of this state capital, a jumble of cinder-block buildings and corrugated metal shacks insinuated into a lushly verdant tropical forest.

title: Piranha Bites 2 in Iowa
description: A piranha found living in a fountain has bitten two employees of Iowa State University. Jim Kalkhoff, who saw the fish in the campus fountain, which he was cleaning, was bitten when he picked the fish up. Another worker, Dawood Jamael, was bitten when he tried to pick it up.

title: FLAME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income after a tax charge of $78,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $581,000 for the 9 months.

title: CONGRESS ADJOURNS AS HOUSE TRIES TO LIMIT CHANGES IN RIGHTS PANEL
description: Congress adjourned today for five weeks after the House approved a five- year extension of the Civil Rights Commission. The measure included language that could stop President Reagan's three nominations to the commission, and it therefore risked a veto.

title: Miss Caulkins Wins Title
description: Tracy Caulkins won her 46th national title, and 18-year-old Ricardo Prado of Brazil became the first foreign winner of the meet in tonight's finals at the United States long course swimming championships.

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings were restated to reflect 2-for-1 stock splits effective Oct. 22, 1982 and July 29, 1983.

title: PAUL BRICKMAN'S 'RISKY BUSINESS'
description: ALTHOUGH Paul Brickman's ''Risky Business'' shows an abundance of style, you would be hard pressed to find a film whose hero's problems are of less concern to the world at large. Joel Goodsen (Tom Cruise) is an affluent suburban teen-ager, sex- starved yet smug, whose erotic daydreams begin to come true, once his parents go on vacation and leave him to hold the fort.

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHITE HOUSE AIDS DRAW G.O.P. BARBS
description: House Republican leaders have bluntly told President Reagan's closest White House aides that Administration officials must demonstrate more ''political smarts'' in their dealings with Capitol Hill.

title: Ex-Hospital Aide Guilty in Theft
description: A former controller of Cohoes Memorial Hospital has pleaded guilty in Albany County Court to stealing more than $93,000 from the upstate institution.

title: TRADING MILLIONS IN MINUTES
description: ''I need Swissie!'' a metallic-sounding voice barked over an intercom on the circular trading desk. ''I need Swissie!''

title: K-TRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $13,097 for the quarter and $124,960 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $128,348.

title: First Jersey National Merger
description: The First Jersey National Corporation of Jersey City and Guarantee Bancorp Inc. signed a definitive agreement for First Jersey National to acquire Guarantee Bancorp.

title: Woman to Serve as Justice
description: Caroline Glassman, a Portland attorney, was unanimously confirmed today by the State Senate as the first woman to sit on the Maine Supreme Court in its 163- year history. Her husband, Harry P. Glassman, was a justice of the same court for only 20 months when he died in 1981 at the age of 53. Mrs. Glassman, 60 years old, is to fill a vacancy left by the appointment of Gene Carter as a Federal district judge.

title: Quiet Farewells For Yastrzemski
description: Carl Yastrzemski has announced that this season, his 23d for the Boston Red Sox, will be his final one as a player. He is not exactly limping to the end of the trail.

title: Judge Backs Convictions Of Two in Abscam Case
description: While saying the conduct of investigators in the Abscam case ''bordered on the outrageous,'' a judge cleared the way today for sentencing former Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. three years after his conviction for bribery.

title: U.S. WARSHIPS WILL MEET SOVIET VESSELS IN LATIN ZONE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that every Soviet ship that enters waters off Central America in coming weeks would meet a United States Navy warship. The aim, they said, is to underscore to the Soviet Union the American military presence in the region.

title: Woolworth Unit Gets Third Chief in a Year
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company has named Theodore T. Bierman as president and chief executive officer of its J. Brannam off-price retail division. Mr. Bierman, 56, comes from the Jamesway Corporation, a retail discount store operation, where he was senior vice president for merchandising. At Woolworth, he will be the third president of the Brannam chain in a year.

title: U.S. Telephone Chief Resigns
description: U.S. Telephone Inc. said today that James Devlin, its chairman, president and chief executive officer, had resigned for personal reasons.

title: PUBLISHING: PRO AND CON ON MULTIBOOK CONTRACTS
description: NORMAN MAILER'S recent $4 million contract to write four books for Random House may be the most profitable multibook agreement ever signed by an author, but the concept of multibook contracts is hardly new. As a matter of fact, Mr. Mailer had a previous four-book contract with Little, Brown, but it was later revised by mutual consent to include only two books.

title: IRONY IN HONDURAS
description: Honduras, with its central and strategic location bordering on Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala, has become a primary base for the Reagan Administration's military response to what it sees as the Communist threat in Central America. It would be ironic indeed, tragically so, if the embryonic democracy of Honduras should be undermined as a result.

title: LANDLORDS' NEMESIS
description: To the Editor:

title: FORD TO REDUCE HEALTH BENEFITS
description: The Ford Motor Company will require its 56,000 salaried workers to pay up to $750 annually for health care benefits, starting next year, in an effort to cut costs, the company said today.

title: TOURING THE COUNTRYSIDE IN SEARCH OF ART
description: THE crop of art in museums just outside the city is unusually diverse this summer, and this weekend may be just the time to go out and have a look. These museums, many of them set in rolling expanses of greenery, can provide attractive destinations for a day's excursion to the country, with perhaps a picnic stop along the way. And what is to be seen once there is likely to surprise the most jaded city dweller:

title: Guyana Loans Canceled
description: The United States Government has canceled two loans to Guyana because it defaulted on the conditions, a United States Embassy spokesman said yesterday. The spokesman gave no details.

title: SALVADOR REBELS URGED BY ALLIES TO SEEK ACCORD
description: Cuba and Nicaragua are putting pressure on the Salvadoran guerrillas to seek a political settlement with the Government, foreign diplomats and sources close to the guerrillas here say.

title: A Condominium Project Is Rising in Throgs Neck
description: Like father like son, and nowhere so much as in the construction business.

description: b-Includes a special gain of $5,886,000 from the sale of LAC Minerals Ltd shares by LAC. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the effect of proposed reassessments of mining duties in a LAC Group company.

Share earnings for the latest 6 months include a 4-cent increase due to changes in accounting of financial statement from foreign units. Results for the year-ago 6 months include a $1,700,000 writeoff of certain receivables.

title: CZYZ RETURNING
description: Bobby Czyz, the middleweight boxer who has been out of action sinceundergoing hand surgery last November, will meet Bill Medei at the IceWorld Arena in Totowa, N.J., Sept. 24. ... Albert Davila of Pomona, Calif. and Kiko Bejines of Guadalajara, Mexico, will fight for the vacant World Boxing Council bantamweight championship Spt. 1 at Los Angeles.

title: White Sox 4, Tigers 2
description: Richard Dotson scattered six hits in eight innings, and a run-scoring double by Julio Cruz sparked a four-run sixth inning for Chicago. Dotson (12-6) earned his fourth consecutive victory with relief from Dennis Lamp after Larry Herndon opened the Detroit ninth with his 14th home run.

title: BRIEFING
description: White House Women

title: BROADWAY
description: Producer's 'vision' bringing 'Marilyn' to Minskoff in fall. HAILING a taxi at dawn in Manhattan after completing a business deal two winters ago, William May suddenly clasped his chest and declared, ''I have a vision.'' This prompted a sour look from his fellow producer, Malcolm Cooke, who is not given to histrionics. ''I see 'Marilyn' written in lipstick on the Winter Garden!,'' Mr. May continued. And that's how a new musical was born.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A PARAGON OF PROFESSIONALISM
description: The tall, baldish man who glares challengingly at the world through owlish spectacles and today became the first Socialist to preside over an Italian Government represents the triumph of a cool political professionalism that is as new to his country as is his Socialist-led Government. So complete has been Bettino Craxi's triumph that hardly anyone in Italy seems to take exception at its exceptional nature or the break with tradition that the new Prime Minister represents. Mr. Craxi's professionalism has made Italy take for granted not only that he should head the Government, although his party holds only 11.4 percent of the seats in the Chamber of Deputies, but also that he should be many things that the heads of the 43 Cabinets that preceded his were not.

title: WESTERN CASUALTY & SURETY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN CAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $5.6 million, or 29 cents a share, from an exchange of 387,267 shares of common stock for $18.4 million principal amount of sinking fund debentures. c-Including a gain of $6 million, or 32 cents a share, from stock transactions of James River Corp. in which the company has an equity position. d-Including a gain of $3.5 million, or 19 cents a share, from the exchange of common stock and cash for certain sinking fund debentures.

title: Coldwell Banker
description: Coldwell Banker, the real-estate subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, won a court injunction giving the company the right to offer its customers retail discounts for home merchandise at Sears. The injunction blocks the Illinois Department of Registration and Education from preventing Coldwell Banker's discount program for customers who buy or sell their homes through the company.

title: STRIKERS REJECT IT
description: Negotiators for Consolidated Edison and its striking workers reached a tentative agreement early yesterday, but union members rejected it by a narrow margin in a secret ballot.

title: U.S.F.L. PLAYER SIGNED BY CHARGES
description: The San Diego Chargers became the first National Football League team to raid the rival United States Football League today by signing Gary Anderson of the Tampa Bay Bandits.

title: One Big Toss
description: ''Ringer'' is not a popular word at a race track, but tomorrow at Longacres Race Course in Renton, Wash., just south of Seattle, most of the expected crowd of 20,000 may be rooting to see one.

title: Skipper Dismissed
description: Jean-Louis Fabry, a noted yachtsman, has been dismissed as the skipper of the French yacht Passion for the remainder of the Admiral's Cup series, triggering a mass walkout by the yacht's crew and forcing her owner to find replacements for the key Fastnet race, which begins Saturday. Fabry was dismissed by the yacht's owner, Alain Forgeot, after Passion did poorly in the first four races of the five-race series that is regarded as a premier event on the European yachting calendar.

title: PITTWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'JUST A LITTLE MORE LOVE,' NBC SPECIAL
description: ''JUST A LITTLE MORE LOVE'' has much the same purpose as an Army training film, which sounds like a putdown but really isn't. Actually, it's a lot more attractively done than an Army film, but in its heart it wants to instruct and inform. If it makes you a little weepy, that's fine, too. This one- hour NBC special will be seen Sunday at 7 P.M. on Channel 4.

title: ALGOMA STEEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title:
PATENTS;
A Pill Counter With Digital Readout
description: A pill counter has been patented for Programs & Analysis Inc., of Burlington, Mass.

title: Uneasy New York Easements
description: There's an easy way to restrict obtrusive development in New York's Catskill and Adirondack Parks, maintain the scenic splendors of the Hudson Valley and preserve historic buildings in New York City. It's called a ''conservation easement'': In return for tax deductions, the owners guarantee that their property will never be developed.

title: IN CONNECTICUT TOWN, BIGGEST HIT IS SOFTBALL
description: Last winter, Phil Buckley and his friends decided to enter a team in a softball league here. And just to be safe, they applied to the town's Recreation Department in March, more than two months before opening day.

title: TV NEWSWOMAN'S SUIT STIRS A DEBATE ON VALUES IN HIRING
description: A jury in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday began deliberating a television newswoman's charge that she was demoted on a news program because she was ''unattractive, too old and not deferential to men.'' She is seeking reinstatement, lost wages and damages.

title: DATE TO BEGIN REAGAN BID SET
description: President Reagan's political strategists have set Oct. 15 as the target date for the formation of a committee to run his re-election campaign, but White House officials said today that Mr. Reagan had still not informed his aides if he has decided to run.

title: U.S. LISTS MANIFEST OF SOVIET VESSEL
description: The White House today made public what it said was part of a cargo manifest for a Soviet freighter being unloaded in Nicaragua that listed two military helicopters and spare parts for an air transport.

title: Elway Excels
description: John Elway, the top pick in the National Football League draft, completed five of his first six passes as he led Denver to a 10-7 victory tonight over the Seattle Seahawks in his professional debut.

title:
PATENTS;
Patent Conference Set On Computerized Data
description: A conference with the European and Japanese Patent Offices will be held in Washington by the Patent and Trademark Office Oct. 17 to 19, according to Gerald J. Mossinghoff, a commissioner. He said the meeting would be an important step toward the goal of an international exchange of computerized data by 1990. The three agencies already have cooperative automation agreements.

title: CONNELLY CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BOBBING AND WEAVING ON NICARAGUA: QUESTIONS FROM AN ANXIOUS CONGRESS
description: News Analysis

title: TEXAS ECONOMY SEEMS EXEMPT FROM RECOVERY
description: Unemployment figures released today seem to show that although the nation is recovering from recession, the once-booming oil- producing economy of Texas has become a glaring exception.

title: A Takeover of Games
description: Bitter squabbling among Venezuelan organizers of the IX Pan American Games has led to a surprise takeover by the Pan American Sports Organization of final preparations for the Aug. 14-29 event.

title: ANGRY COMPTROLLER QUITS, THEN ACTS TO HIDE OFFICE
description: Ron Holtzscheiter felt he was indispensable as the Norfolk Circuit Court comptroller and deserved better treatment, so he set out to prove it when he quit for the fourth time - by hiding his office.

title: Walesa Calls New Laws Throwback to the 50's
description: Lech Walesa today criticized the Government's new regulations that replaced martial law, saying they were a throwback to the Stalinist era of the 1950's.

title: WINFIELD CHARGES WILL BE DROPPED
description: The Yankees received one favorable decision yesterday when Norman Matusiak, a senior Crown Attorney in Canada, announced that he would appear in court on Aug. 12 and ask that criminal charges against Dave Winfield be dropped. Winfield was arrested in Toronto Thursday night on charges of cruelty to animals after accidentally killing a seagull with a baseball.

title: NEW YORK'S JOBLESS RATE INCREASED TO 10.6% IN JULY
description: New York City's unemployment rate rose sharply in July, to 10.6 percent from 8.9 percent in June, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Reagan Acts to Restore Artificial Limb Funds
description: The Reagan Administration restored about $600,000 in Federal funds today to three regional centers that provide artificial limbs and braces for children. The action came after President Reagan learned through news reports that the centers had had lost the money.

title: New Threats Reported Against Guru in Oregon
description: An anonymous telephone caller warned an Indian guru whose hotel was bombed last week that a group in Seattle has offered $10,000 for someone to kill him, the police said today.

title: AEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Moving Gingerly, Big Bird And Friends Visit Museum
description: ''Feathers, please!'' shouted one assistant. Another aide wheeled in a five-foot cascade of sunny yellow plumes wearing a tie and topped by a long beak and sky-blue goggle eyes.

title: ONTARIO'S BIG NEW GOLD FIND
description: This bump-in-the-road village, so tiny that it warrants no mention in such definitive reference works as the Columbia Lippincott World Gazetteer or the Rand McNally Commercial Atlas, is about to be put on the map by gold.

title: Boston Elections Held Violation of Fairness
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit today reaffirmed a lower court decision delaying City Council and School Committee elections scheduled this fall.

description: To the Editor:

title: Construction Rule By Koch Is Upset
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has ruled that Mayor Koch exceeded his authority when he ordered that city agencies seek to insure that 10 percent of city construction projects go to small businesses that have worked in depressed areas or employ poor people.

title: DOMINION TEXTILE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses after a special charge of $11.5 million for the quarter and year. The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: Miss van Wierk Weds David Plant, a Lawyer
description: Gretchen M. van Wierk and David W. Plant were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Shepard in South Windsor, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Millan of the First Church of Christ Congregational in West Hartford, Conn.

title: JOBLESS RATE FELL TO 9.3% IN JULY, A SHARP DECLINE
description: With the economic recovery apparently gathering strength, the national unemployment rate dropped half a percentage point to 9.3 percent in July, the Labor Department announced today.

title: AUSTRALIA II KEEL DEFENDED
description: Alan Bond, the head of the Australia II syndicate, today accused the New York Yacht Club, which runs the America's Cup races, of ''overreacting'' to his yacht's speed, and said that Australia II ''without a doubt measures as a 12-Meter.''

title: NOVELIST WAS 79
description: I J. Kapstein, a novelist, professor of English and a Hebrew scholar, died of cancer today at Miriam Hospital here. He was 79 years old.

title: ADMINISTRATOR OF COURTS NAMED FOR STATE SYSTEM
description: Robert J. Sise, a judge who has helped manage the state's courts for the last six years, was named statewide administrative judge yesterday.

title: Bridge: Beating a Bad Trump Split Is One Mark of an Expert
description: Overcoming a bad trump break is one of the marks of an expert card player, and there are few more expert than Dan Rotman of Chicago.

title: New Celtic Chapter
description: Harry Mangurian, the owner of the Boston Celtics, announced that he was close to completing a new deal to sell the club, but he would not identify the prospective purchaser. ''This is a very solid person, a man I think will make a good owner for this team,'' he said.

description: WHEN scanning newspaper and magazine advertisements for the best buys in travel packages and tours, consumers may want to keep a magnifying glass and a calculator close at hand.

description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation today that will impose criminal penalties on doctors and nurses who turn away critically ill patients at hospitals in New York City.

description: With a terse, one-sentence announcement, President Reagan today signed into law the repeal of tax withholding from interest and dividend payments, which he had earlier threatened to veto.

title: Tests Show 2 Sites Are Free of Dioxin
description: New test results show that streets in Kearny and a chemical manufacturing plant in Linden are free of suspected dioxin contamination, Environmental Commissioner Robert E. Hughey announced today.

title: Santec-China Deal
description: The Santec Corporation, which makes computer printers, has completed the sale of $2 million of its stock to China in that country's first investment in a foreign technological company since 1949.

description: Bruce Harper once did everything for the Jets, and so well that he became known as one of the best all-purpose backs in pro football.

KEEPING FIT PRUDENTLY DURING PREGNANCY
description: Sooner or later, a pregnant woman's thoughts turn to the shape of things to come - mainly her shape. ''A blob - I saw myself turning into a blob,'' said Lillian Brash, a former department manager at Bloomingdale's who is now in her seventh month. Her classmates at Exercise Plus, an exercise studio in Manhattan, agreed.

title: French Aide, in Cuba, Discusses Latin Crisis
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France, on the second day of an official visit to Cuba, met today with Vice President Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, a specialist in international relations.

title: Agents Sue Dorsett
description: The agents who helped Tony Dorsett, the Dallas running back, negotiate with the Cowboys three years ago have filed suit against him, contending that he had never paid a commission on the deal. The suit was filed in Federal court in Pittsburgh by Consolidated Management Enterprises Inc., which said that Dorsett had never complaned about the company's representation but never paid for its services. Dorsett was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment.

description: The Occidental Petroleum Company said that it expected to announce contracts over the weekend with China's National Offshore Oil Corporation for oil exporation in two large offshore tracts in the South China Sea.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $236,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $197,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income which includes extraordinary gains of $603,000 for the quarter and $1,115,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to correct quarterly tax provisions and profit sharing plan contributions.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: CHAMBER PROGRAM
description: No Mozart - at least in the main body of Thursday's Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall. Instead, there was a spread of less familiar chamber pieces stretching from the Baroque to the 20th century.

title: Palmer Sent Down
description: Jim Palmer, the Baltimore Oriole pitcher who has missed much of the season because of a persistent shoulder injury, has asked the Orioles to send him to the minor leagues for rehabilitation, and the club has granted the request. ''A rehabilitation assignment is the obvious way to get back,'' said Hank Peters, the club's general manager.

title: Chrysler Warrants
description: The Chrysler Corporation Loan Guarantee Board will consider the auto maker's request that the board delay selling the 14.4 million Chrysler stock warrants it holds, a spokesman for the panel said today.

title: PARTS OF I.M.F. BILL ASSAILED
description: Some executives of major banks criticized yesterday amendments to a House bill that restrict bank lending as a quid pro quo for House approval of an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Willie Wilson Sued
description: A Milwaukee woman has filed a $10,000 suit against Willie Wilson of the Kansas City Royals, charging that he punched her in the face during a dispute in a Milwaukee hotel room after the Royals' game against the Brewers on Wednesday.

title: Man Is Sentenced For Raping Wife
description: The first man in New York State to be convicted of raping his wife was sentenced today to three to nine years in prison.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC ENTERRISES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAFETY AGENCY ASSAILED AS LAX IN G.M. INQUIRY
description: A General Accounting Office study, made public today, concludes there were ''serious problems'' in the Government's handling of potential safety-related defects in General Motors 1980 X-model cars.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RCA RECORDS 'CAGE' BEFORE OPENING
description: In a cluttered RCA Corporation recording studio on the Avenue of the Americas, the composer and lyricist Jerry Herman was smiling as he listened to the orchestra, chorus and George Hearn sail through the title song of the new musical ''La Cage aux Folles.'' A little later he was still smiling as the show's forces tore into ''The Best of Times.''

title: SUTTON IS P.G.A. LEADER BY 3
description: Jack is back. So is Ben. And Tom. But Hal still leads.

description: Dr. Minta Elizabeth Phillips and Frank Reuter Cheney were married yesterday at the Boston Athenaeum in Boston in an Episcopal ceremony performed by the Rev. Howard Park.

description: People Express Airlines said it had agreed to purchase 14 Boeing 727-200 aircraft from Delta Airlines for $91 million.

THACKERAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Food Aid for Guatemala
description: The United States will give Guatemala $50 million in food credits and $7 million in food in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1, Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block announced today as he arrived on the first stop of a 10-day visit to Latin America.

description: Striking employees of the Consolidated Edison Company on Staten Island have rejected a tentative contract only a day after members of another union representing strikers in the other boroughs and Westchester County turned down a proposed agreement.

Librarian Investigated In Possible Film Theft
description: A valuable collection of movies, including such classics as ''Mutiny on the Bounty'' and ''The Wizard of Oz,'' have been recovered from a film librarian who is being investigated for possible theft of the motion pictures, authorities said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Sound-Muffling Cup For Enraged People
description: One of the week's patented inventions is described as a sound-muffling cup, into which an enraged person can shout to release tension while avoiding disturbing other people.

title: Castle & Cooke In A & W Deal
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it had formed with two other companies a new corporation, A & W Brands Inc., to purchase the A & W Root Beer business from the United Brands Company for an undisclosed price. United Brands said it realized about $55 million from the sale, although it does not expect to realize a material gain or loss on the transaction.

title: ALLIED SECURITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Slow Can Be Bad
