description: Slow play is ''one of our most serious problems, if not the number one in golf,'' according to Frank Hannigan, senior executive director of the United States Golf Association. He said, ''The U.S.G.A., the PGA Tour and the L.P.G.A. can do something about it at the level of the best competitive golf in the world for men and women, because fear is a very potent thing, unfortunately.''

title: PLAINCLOTHES POLICE ARREST 100 SUSPECTS IN TIMES SQ. SWEEP
description: More than 100 youths were arrested last night during the first eight hours of a police crackdown on roving gangs in the Times Square area, the police said.

title: 8 Closed Beaches On L.I. Reopened
description: Eight popular beaches along Hempstead Harbor that were closed Thursday because of a pollution scare reopened today after a cracked sewer line was repaired.

title: Rockland Teen-Ager Is Killed Chasing Thief in Bryant Park
description: A Rockland County teen-ager was fatally stabbed in Bryant Park early this morning while chasing a man who had snatched the youth's gold neck chain, the police said.

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BRICK WALL COLLAPSE KILLS WOMAN IN CAR ON A ST. LOUIS ROAD
description: A brick wall of a five-story turn-of-the-century building on the south side collapsed onto an interstate highway at the beginning of rush hour this afternoon, killing a young woman and injuring another woman and a man.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
2-GAME BAN FOR MARTIN
description: Billy Martin was suspended for two games yesterday by the American League for his latest confrontation with umpires, and promptly said that he was a victim of ''pressure'' from the umpires' union.

title: NEW PRESIDENT OF A UNIVERSITY IN DIFFICULTY
description: When David P. Gardner took over as the 15th president of the University of California this week, many people said they could think of no one better fitted for the job at one of the most difficult times in the system's 113-year history. The nine-campus, 139,000-student university has lost the awesome influence it once had in the State Capitol. The departing president says years of budget cutting in Sacramento have left the physical plant in poor condition, forced student fees up and kept faculty salaries too low, and still more cuts are likely.

title: TRADE DEFICIT AT RECORD $14.9 BILLION
description: A sizable jump in United States imports, mostly the result of a 24 percent increase in imports of petroleum and petroleum products, widened the nation's merchandise trade deficit to a record $14.9 billion in the second quarter, from $8.7 billion in the first, the Government reported today.

title: Nikon FA Camera
description: Nikon Inc. has introduced the Nikon FA camera with a computer- aided system that it says is ''a major innovation'' in light-metering.

title: WHEN SWEETNESS SURPRISES
description: In his brilliant short story, ''The Door,'' E.B. White describes the madness induced when people are suddenly faced with situations and objects that are not what they expect them to be.

title: EARLY MORNING BLAST LEVELS 2 BUILDINGS IN ASTORIA
description: A powerful explosion followed by a fire early yesterday leveled two buildings, knocked down a wall of a Post Office branch and shattered windows in Astoria, Queens.

title: ONE CENTRAL PARK CONCERT'S CRIMINAL BYPRODUCT
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BARRY, R G, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Tough Chargers
description: With a defense as lowly rated as the San Diego Chargers' was last season, 25th among the National Football League's 28 teams, it stood to reason the club would invest heavily in defensive players in the 1983 college draft. And it did, using two of its three first-round draft choices on Billy Ray Smith of Arkansas and Gill Byrd of San Jose State.

title: Cessna Cutback
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company said it would close assembly lines at its Pawnee and Wallace production plants in the Wichita and Winfield areas from Aug. 15 to Sept. 26, and reduce engineering and marketing work to minimum levels.

title: ENDURANCE TEST FOR FIREFIGHTERS REVISED BY CITY
description: After five years of controversy over the fairness of physical tests for women seeking to become New York City firefighters, a new test has been developed - and has quickly become embroiled in controversy.

title: LENDING RESTRICTIONS IN I.M.F. LEGISLATION
description: Following are some of the restrictions on the International Monetary Fund and commercial banks in the House-passed bill authorizing an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the fund. The fund restrictions are directives to the United States executive director to oppose loans under certain circumstances. It is not clear, however, that a ''no'' vote by the United States would block I.M.F. action in all cases.

title: Energy Unit Draws 8 Bids
description: Seven companies, including the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Rockwell International Corporation, submitted proposals by today's deadline to take over the Government's $2 billion Oak Ridge energy reservation, an Energy Department spokesman said.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the quarter and $294,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $229,000.

title: AIR FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WILLIAM L. WISNER JR.
description: William L. Wisner Jr., who under the name Bill Wisner wrote or helped write 18 popular books and many articles about sport fishing and the sea, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Brightwaters, L.I. He was 69 years old.

title: World Airways Loss Narrows
description: World Airways said today that its second-quarter loss narrowed to $9.5 million from $15.5 million the year before.

title: MASTERS MERCHANDISE MART reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'Errors' at Prospect Park
description: Free performances of Shakespeare's ''Comedy of Errors'' will be given by Shakespeare and Company from Aug. 31 to Sept. 4 in Brooklyn's Prospect Park. The shows will go on at 8 P.M. in the park's bandshell, Prospect Park West and 11th Street.

title: 13 KILLED IN COUP IN UPPER VOLTA
description: A pro-Libyan paratroop captain who was dismissed as Prime Minister of Upper Volta in May seized power in the West African country today in a coup that reportedly left 13 people dead and 15 wounded. Diplomats in Upper Volta said 6 of the wounded were French nationals.

title: BROADVIEW FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to defer gains from the sale of real estate and to recognize such gains as interest income over the lives of projects.

title: NEWSWEEK RESIGNATION
description: Charles J. Kennedy, senior vice president and publisher of Newsweek Inc., has resigned effective Sept. 1, the magazine company said yesterday.

title: THE VILLAGE TALK OUTSIDE HELSINKI
description: In the main auditorium, where some of Finland's future engineers normally take notes from lecturers at the Dipoli Polytechnic Institute, Carol and Carl Lewis recounted for a room full of journalists how they first met Jesse Owens and what their goals were for the first world track and field championships.

title: DAXOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Law Judge Urges Lilco Rate Rise
description: An administrative law judge recommended today that the State Public Service Commission approve a temporary $64.3 million electricity rate increase for Long Island Lighting Company customers.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: CSX-Texas Gas
description: The CSX Corporation said it plans to resume its $1.07 billion tender offer for Texas Gas Resources Corporation. Yesterday a Washington Federal appeals court lifted an injunction yesterday blocking the merger and later, Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. refused to delay the CSX tender offer. A spokesman for CSX said the company has extended its $52-a-share offer for the remaining Texas Gas issues until midnight tonight. CSX has already bought 18.9 million of the 20.6 million outstanding Texas Gas shares, he said, and will give 0.684 share of its common stock for each Texas Gas share not tendered already.

title: West German G.N.P.
description: The West German gross national product will grow next year by a maximum of 2 percent in real terms and probably less, the Rhine-Westphalia Economic Research Institute said today.

title: MUNCHKINS GATHER IN CHESTER, PA., FOR TOAST TO OZ
description: The Munchkins of the International Wizard of Oz Club will be arriving in Chester, Pa., today.

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,469,000 from a debt-for-equity swap. There were no share earnings for the latest quarter because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Thursday on the rerouting of some subway trains because of construction work on the Manhattan Bridge gave incorrect changes for QB trains. Beginning Monday, QB trains from Coney Island to 57th Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan will be suspended for three months. Alternate service will be provided by the M train between Coney Island and DeKalb Avenue and on the N and RR trains from DeKalb Avenue to Manhattan stops.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income after a loss of $4,963 from discontinued operations.

title: A.T.&T. BREAKUP APPROVED
description: A Federal judge, as expected, today gave final approval to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's plan to split itself into seven regional companies on Jan. 1.

title: WOMEN'S GROUPS CRITICIZE REAGAN OVER SEX BIAS LAW
description: The Reagan Administration told the Supreme Court today that it opposed an ''expansive interpretation'' of a law forbidding sex discrimination at federally assisted schools, and women's groups responded with sharp criticism of the President.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: I.B.M. to Expand An Upstate Plant
description: International Business Machines announced today that it planned to buy 160 acres west of its 450-acre plant and laboratory in Dutchess County to expand production of semiconductor devices and other products.

title: JAPANESE DOCTOR SAYS BOMB AVERTED FAMINE
description: Japan was probably ''saved'' and spared widespread starvation by the atomic bomb the United States dropped on Hiroshima at the end of World War II, according to a leading Japanese physician.

title: Savings Bank Mergers
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had approved the acquisitions of two savings and loan associations in Florida and two in Virginia by the Metropolitan Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

title: Miss Rizzo Leads by a Shot
description: Patti Rizzo, the 1982 rookie of the year, withstood a charge by Sue Ertl, another sophomore on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour, and clung to a one-stroke lead today at the halfway mark of the $175,000 Boston Five Classic.

title: SANDWICH CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,274,000.

title: Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation and its Swedish partner, KemaNobel, Sweden's largest chemical company, said they had agreed to sell all their shares in Uniofos Kemi, a polyethylene producer, to Neste, the Finnish state oil company. KemaNobel also said it had begun negotiations with Norway's Norsk Hydro and Neste on the sale of its polyvinyl chloride and polyethylene plants in Sweden.

title: LEBANON CAR BOMB KILLS 19 AT MOSQUE
description: A car bomb exploded here today in front of a crowded mosque in Syrian-controlled northern Lebanon, and the police said at least 19 people were killed and 43 injured.

title: 30 HURT IN RACE CAR ACCIDENT
description: Two race cars traveling at 90 miles an hour spun off the track at the Stafford Springs, Conn., Motor Speedway tonight and crashed into the packed grandstands, injuring as many as 30 people.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices ended with small gains yesterday in slower trading after dropping sharply on Thursday.

title: PACER TECHNOLOGY & REOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEVER ENOUGH PRISONS
description: Mario Cuomo has made a promising beginning as Governor. In matters of style and substance he has broken away from his predecessors and has made his mark as a sensible and even innovative leader. But his record is marred by costly mistakes in one area: prisons.

title: CUOMO SIGNS A LAW SUBSIDIZING AIDS RESEARCH
description: Legislation that provides $5.3 million for medical research into acquired immune deficiency syndrome and for community assistance to AIDS victims was signed into law yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: 2 Fillies Speediest
description: It looks as if the two fastest sprinters in the country this year are fillies. Everyone knows about Gold Beauty, the champion sprinter last year as a 3-year-old and unbeaten in three starts this year.

title: RIGHETTI WINS 12TH AS YANKEES ROMP
description: The Yankees came home last night with six losses in eight games and punished the Detroit Tigers, scoring five runs in the fourth inning and four in the seventh.

title: ZENTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income. Results for 1983 include the operations of Shasta General Systems which was acquired on June 1.

title: Correction
description: An Associated Press dispatch in Business Day yesterday about a $100 million lawsuit by the Avco Corporation against Canadair Ltd. reported the wrong number of aircraft engines at issue. Avco said Canadair broke an agreement to buy 300 jet engines.

title: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $10,800,000 associated with a writedown of the company's investment in the Pebble Springs nuclear project.

title: ASTRADYNE COMPUTER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $98,700 for the quarter and $178,900 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $117,570 on the disposal of discontinued operations. d-Net loss after a loss of $289,970 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: KENYANS SEE DOLLAR SIGNS AS U.S. FLEET STEAMS IN THE TALK OF MOMBASA
description: In much of Africa, the United States has become a synonym for imperialism and, when some African leaders gather, it is the vogue to denounce one, the other or both. But not in Mombasa.The radical message does not seem to have percolated through the coastal heat to reach Kenya's second city. This is a place where United States Navy baseball caps, emblazoned with ships' names, are a fashion, a trophy and almost a form of currency. It is a place, too, where the spirit of private enterprise flutters free.

title: Betsy Reid Is Married To Dr. Michael Lewis
description: Betsy Reid and Dr. Michael M. Lewis were married yesterday at their apartment in Manhattan in a ceremony performed by Rabbi Ira S. Youdovin.

title: BAR CONVENTION RITUALS: TALK, DRINKS, MORE TALK
description: In the course of the American Bar Association's convention, Ernest T. Guy did not lack for work.

title:
PATENTS;
Launching Lifeboats In Difficult Conditions
description: A structure for launching lifeboats under difficult conditions has been invented by a father-and-son team. Patent 4,395,967 was granted this week to John J. McGlew, a New York patent attorney, and John J. McGlew Jr., a Boston University graduate who recently became an examiner in the Patent and Trademark Office.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Vacation From Critics

title: Interest on Checking Urged for Businesses
description: The Reagan Administration urged Congress today to allow Federal regulators to authorize banks and savings institutions to pay interest on checking accounts held by businesses.

title: SATURDAYSPORTS
description: Baseball

title: ONE CENTRAL PARK CONCERT'S CRIMINAL BYPRODUCT
description: To the Editor:

title: Travenol Insider Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that a settlement was reached on charges of insider stock trading by the director of corporate communications of Travenol Laboratories Inc., a subsidiary of Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. James DeYoung was charged with fraud for purchasing stock of Medcom Inc. based on nonpublic information immediately prior to its announcement of a merger into Baxter's Medtrain Inc. subsidiary. Mr. DeYoung consented to an injunction and agreed to give up profits of $51,464 from the stock sale, the S.E.C. said. A company spokesman in Deerfield, Ill., said Mr. DeYoung had agreed to leave the company.

title: IN THE LAND OF SONY, THE ABACUS IS STILL KING
description: Japan produced 58 million electronic calculators last year, but that does not necessarily mean that people count on them for anything.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
PSA Expansion
description: PSA Inc., the holding company for Pacific Southwest Airlines, said it had expanded the energy-related activities of its subsidiary, Pacific Southwest Exploration, in transactions totaling $40 million. They include the purchase of interests in oil and gas leases with P.S.E.'s partner, the Espereanza Energy Corporation, and a loan to E.E.C.'s principal, John H. Hill, secured by his interest in various wells.

title: Atomic Bomb Protests Begin
description: Four protesters who released doves in the lobby of a nuclear research laboratory were arrested yesterday at the beginning of a weekend of demonstrations marking the atomic bombing of Japan in World War II.

title: MAJOR CRIMES REPORTED IN CITY DROP BY 9.4%
description: Reports of major crimes in New York City dropped 9.4 percent for the first half of 1983, compared with the same period last year, according to statistics released by the city's Police Department.

title: New Chairman At Hudson Bay
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company Ltd. said today that Allen T. Lambert was appointed chairman, effective Aug. 1

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Data Source On Companies CORPORATE annual reports rarely make for sparkling reading. And often, some of the driest prose appears in the section formally entitled ''Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.''
description: Yet this segment may provide the most incisive information available on a company. The facts could be valuable indeed to those willing to study the data that is sometimes given on liquidity, capital resources, working capital and other topics.

title: Argentine's Odyssey
description: The raffle was in Carlos Liberti's barbershop in Elmhurst, Queens. The borough's Argentine community raised $400 for Pedro Alejandro Gatica, a 49-year-old compatriot making the second visit to New York of a self-imposed ''peace odyssey.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD India Attaching Notes To Book on Kissinger
description: Copies of a book by Seymour M. Hersh that are sold in India will carry a note about President Nixon's policies on India and about the author's contention that former Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai was a paid informant for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $127,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of real estate and other investments. c-Including a gain of $279,000 on the sale of real estate and other investments.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from the return of excess funds in a company pension plan and the extinguishment of debt of $584,000 for the quarter and $1,300,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $875,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the disposition of securities and other assets, a gain of $6,700,000 for the 6 months in insurance proceeds on aircraft loss, and a gain of $1,500,000 for the 6 months from the extinguishment of debt. Year-ago results are restated.

title: A.T.&T. AND UNIONS STILL TALKING
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and three unions held low- level subcommittee meetings today as expiration of the current contract approached.

title: Blue Put on Waivers
description: The Kansas City Royals asked waivers on the veteran left-handed pitcher Vida Blue yesterday and replaced him with Eric Rasmussen of the team's Triple-A affiliate in Omaha.

title: Marcos Repeals Decrees On Imprisoning Rebels
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos issued two decrees today repealing earlier orders under which many people suspected of being rebels have been imprisoned.

title: A BLOW AGAINST NEWSPEAK
description: What Radio Moscow's announcer, Vladimir Danchev, did on May 23 had never been done in the Soviet Union before: In a worldwide English-language broadcast he called things by their true names, that is, he called the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan ''an occupation,'' the Soviet troopers there ''the bandits'' and the local tribesmen ''the defenders against the Soviet invaders.'' Now the news has reached the West that Mr. Danchev has refused to renounce his action as a ''personal mistake.'' For this mistake he was banished from Moscow to an insane asylum in faraway Tashkent.

title: Harvester Unit In Renault Talks
description: The International Harvester Company said that negotiations between Regie Nationale des Usines Renault and its French farm equipment subsidiary have been resumed at the request of the French Government. Renault, which makes autos and also has a small farm equipment business, is Government-controlled.

title: TIME SORE SPOT: TV-CABLE WEEK
description: Its seven profitable magazines make Time Inc. one of the most successful publishers in America, and its cable system is by far and away the nation's largest. In theory, then, a magazine that combines Time's publishing skills with its cable experience should succeed.

title: Cecil I. Crouse, 85, Is Dead; A Retired Borden Executive
description: Cecil I. Crouse, retired vice president and director of the Borden Company, died last Sunday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: 7 SLAIN IN BUNGLED ROBBERY AT HOTEL IN SOUTHERN FRANCE
description: Robbers shot seven people dead early today in a luxury hotel in the southern French city of Avignon during a bungled attempt to break into the hotel's safe-deposit boxes.

title: Mexico Price Index Up
description: The Bank of Mexico said today its Consumer Price Index rose 4.9 percent in July to 626.7, from a 1978 base, following rises of 4.3 percent in May and 3.8 percent in June. The index rose 47.8 percent in the first seven months of the year, compared to 38.8 percent for the same 1982 period. The rise brought the increase in the 12 months ended July to 118.8 percent, compared with 54.3 percent for the 12 months ended July 1982.

title: Relief, Not Comfort
description: The one-half of 1 percent drop in unemployment and the half-million gain in jobs last month were indeed spectacular. All can rejoice that the double- digit rate of joblessness is behind us. But let no one forget how bad it was, what caused it and how much remains to be done before a stable recovery is assured.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ONE CENTRAL PARK CONCERT'S CRIMINAL BYPRODUCT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Envoy to Benin Named
description: The White House said today that it was nominating George Moose, a career Foreign Service officer, to replace James Engle as Ambassador to Benin. The nomination is subject to Senate confirmation.

title: JOIE DE VIE IS TROTTER TO BEAT
description: A certified public accountant from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, who gave up a hectic New York existence for the quieter life of California, hopes to recapture some of that excitement and win a half-million dollars at the Meadowlands Saturday.

title: BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (CALIF) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Caterpillar Truck Deal
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today that its Towmotor Corporation subsidiary had entered into an agreement with Kaldnes Mek. Verksted A.S. of Tonsberg, Norway, for production of new, large lift trucks. The truck, the V925, will be manufactured in Norway and marketed through Caterpillar lift truck dealers worldwide. It will be the largest in Caterpillar's lift truck line

title: STAR-GLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $17,000 for the quarter and $32,000 for the 6 months.

title: FEUD LEAVES LOUISIANA LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR WITHOUT BUDGET
description: On a slow day some months ago, a New Orleans television reporter conducted a man- on-the-street survey to find out if anyone knew the name of Louisiana's Lieutenant Governor. After his election four years ago, the state's second-highest elected official had appeared to fade quietly away.

title: NORTHWEST ENERGY GETS HALT IN STOCK TRADING
description: The Northwest Energy Company asked the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to halt trading in its stock amid Wall Street speculation that the big natural gas pipeline company would soon announce some sort of takeover development.

title: Ericsson Planning U.S. Honeywell Tie
description: LM Ericsson, the Swedish multinational company, plans an extensive link with Honeywell Inc. to compete in the United States in telecommunications, data processing and office automation, it said in a statement today.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chrysler Callback
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would call back 1,500 laid-off auto workers to reactivate a second shift at a suburban truck plant in Warren, Mich. The new shift, which begins Oct. 3, also means means jobs for about 100 additional salaried workers at the Warren facility, said Stephan Sharf, Chrysler's executive vice president of manufacturing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The July figures over all provide little support for the view that the national recovery has come to New York City in any real way.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
REPRIEVE IS URGED FOR THE COLISEUM
description: A leader of New York City's hotel industry said yesterday that he would like to see the New York Coliseum remain open after the city's new Convention Center is completed.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: WILLIAM A. PRATT
description: William A. Pratt, a former Olympic skater, died Thursday in St. Peter's Hospital of a heart condition.

title: DOLLAR HIGH DESPITE SUPPORT
description: The value of the dollar rose to new highs against other major currencies, although European central banks continued to intervene, selling dollars in an attempt to hold down its value.

title: U.S. TO GET MARC RICH DOCUMENTS
description: Under intense Government pressure, Marc Rich & Company A.G., one of the world's largest commodity traders, agreed last night to turn over documents subpoenaed more than a year ago by a Federal grand jury investigating the company for tax evasion.

title: People Who Don't Know Systolic From Diastolic
description: Under the marquee of Carnegie Hall, a man and two women in medical whites were offering blood- pressure readings for $2 each. As Melvin Bernhardt emerged from lunch Thursday, he stopped for one.

title: Let a Thousand Taxis Bloom
description: It's been a year since a blue-ribbon committee recommended major changes in New York City's taxi system. No reforms are yet apparent, but dramatic improvements are on the way if Mayor Koch holds to his present plans.

title: A CRISIS IS LOOMING IN CHESS WORLD
description: A crisis in the world of international chess appeared inevitable today as a young Soviet grandmaster scheduled to begin a championship semifinal match in Pasadena, Calif., on Saturday did not take the last flight that could have got him there on time.

title: TEXAS GAS RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Judge Delays Butcher Trial
description: A Federal judge today delayed Jake Butcher's bankruptcy trial so the financier's lawyers could have more time to respond to motions filed by creditors owed about $15 million. United States Bankruptcy Judge Clive Bare's decision means that a ruling on whether Mr. Butcher is bankrupt will not be made for at least two weeks.

title: A Quiet Visitor Watches No. 56
description: When will Lawrence Taylor end his contract dispute with the Giants and rejoin the team? Well, No. 56 was playing linebacker in the Giant workout Thursday afternoon at Briarcliff High School in Westchester County. Lawrence Taylor was there and recorded on film.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Debt Bill Delay For Bonneville
description: Caught in the Congressional rush to go home for its August recess, a Senate bill giving the Bonneville Power Administration almost $1 billion in new borrowing authority to help complete two stalled nuclear plants has been put off until at least September.

title: 'Desert Song' Scheduled
description: Sigmund Romberg's ''Desert Song'' will be presented by the Light Opera of Manhattan from Aug. 10 through Aug. 28 at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street.

title: WILLIAMS, T E, PHARMACEUTIALS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
; A GREAT BRIDGE, A SEAPORT-AND A SLUM
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Reduces Power Of Federal Magistrates
description: An appeals court struck down today laws that empowered Federal magistrates to enter judgments in civil trials.

title: Tritium-Laced Water Leaks Into Lake Ontario
description: About one and a half gallons of heavy water laced with a tiny amount of radioactive tritium leaked into Lake Ontario from a nuclear generator, the Ontario Hydro utility said today.

title: SKIRTING THE BUDGET
description: Federal credit has gotten out of hand. In fiscal year 1983, Federally related borrowing will take half of all available new credit in the United States, by far an historic high. This incredible drain of savings from the nation's economy drives up interest rates and creates pressures to expand the money supply. While a depressed economy is the clear result, the causes of Federal credit growth are more obscure.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BIG AND SMALL SEEK TO SUE UNCLE SAM
description: Two or three times a day, someone with a beef against the Federal Government files a complaint in a little-known office facing Lafayette Square, across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. There, inside a sleek but somnolent building, is the United States Claims Court, for many citizens the last chance to get a hearing on a grievance against Uncle Sam.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRANSITRON ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-After a net charge of $390,000 related to various adjustments. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $700,000 from the utilization of tax benefits.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.2 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday reported a $1.2 billion rise in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended July 27, disappointing investors who have been awaiting a slowdown in growth that would ease the pressure on interest rates.

title: DANCE: TOUR OF MIAMI
description: Miami isn't all that much different from New York City, or any other big American city. Or so it seemed from a performance of Mary Luft's ''Miami, See It Like a Native'' Thursday in the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater, which opened the Dance Theater Workshop's sixth annual Out-of- Towners festival.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 6, 1983
description: The Economy

title: Mt. St. Helens Erupts Again
description: Mount St. Helens shot a blast of steam, ash and rocks up to 6,000 feet above the rim of its gaping crater Thursday, the authorities said. Seismic levels beneath the volcano slightly increased then, said Charles Camisa, a spokesman for the geophysics center of the University of Washington.

title: SCHOOLYARD DINNER: AID FOR THE HUNGRY
description: They begin arriving each weekday at 2 P.M. in the yard of Junior High School 22 on College Avenue in the South Bronx. There, between 3:30 and 5:30 P.M., free dinners are distributed to 150 neighborhood children.

title: Couple Found Slain
description: A young couple were found bound and slashed to death early yesterday in a room at a midtown Manhattan hotel, the police said.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RED TAPE HORROR STORY
description: Even in this high-tech age of Atari and extraterrestrials, the unyielding torpidity of bureaucracy can still bring harried physicians to their knees in defeat. I have recently encountered a notable example of such a bureaucratic victory.

title: FOSTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $530,000 for the quarter and $1,430,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $184,000. d-Including a tax credit of $41,000.

title: OROSCO WINS 4TH IN WEEK
description: Jesse Orosco today became the first pitcher in New York Mets history to gain four victories in less than a week. And he also drove in his first run in the major leagues during a six-run rally in the seventh inning that enabled the Mets to beat the Chicago Cubs, 9-4, at Wrigley Field.

title: LESLIE MILLS
description: Leslie Mills, a retired partner in Price Waterhouse & Company, the accounting concern, died of Alzheimer's disease Wednesday at the home of a niece in Hendersonville, N.C. He was 74 years old and lived in Kent, Conn.

title: CHADWICK-MILLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KERR GLASS MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Elderly Smash Windows To Escape High Heat
description: A 100-year- old man and two elderly companions smashed windows with a cane to escape the sweltering, closed-up house where they were being kept by a member of a religious sect, the police said,

title: KEY U.S. DEMANDS DROPPED IN TALKS ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: The United States has dropped several key demands in strategic arms negotiations with the Soviet Union to ease the way toward a new strategic arms agreement, but the two sides have not achieved a breakthrough on the central issues, the chief American strategic arms negotiator disclosed today.

title: James Jamerson Dies at 45; Bassist Backed Detroit Stars
description: James Jamerson, whose electric bass backed many of Detroit's biggest musical stars, died Tuesday, his wife said today. He was 45 years old.

title: Button Up Your Overt Coat
description: Mitchell Flowers, who says he is 14, wants to grow up and become a great spy for the C.I.A., but he is now having second thoughts. His letter says these are occasioned by the great publicity given recently to our Government's covert operations against the Marxist leaders of Nicaragua.

title: The Tempest Over Chad
description: South of Libya and west of the Sudan, the desert yields to a whirlwind, also known as Chad. For much of its two decades of independence, Chad has been consumed by civil war among an array of ethnic and ideological factions. These conflicts have proved an irresistible temptation to foreign meddlers, who periodically threaten to draw in not just Chad's neighbors, but also Egypt, France and even the United States.

title: Waldorf Lets It Hair Down
description: Workman in hospital masks chipped away at the elegant mirrored panels, while others blasted out moldings yesterday. The ceiling of the stage, for decades home of the witty toast as well as the witless speech, was bandaged in wood scaffolding.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $1,450,000 from the settlement of a lawsuit with the U.S. Government. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1983.

title: BEIRUT HOLDS A LEBANESE IN U.S. EMBASSY ATTACK
description: Investigators here are holding a Lebanese employee of the United States Embassy on suspicion of complicity in the bombing of the embassy in April, it was disclosed today.

title: Oakland Receives a Setback In Its Effort to Keep Raiders
description: The California Court of Appeal today refused to order the Los Angeles Raiders to play their 1983 home games in Oakland while the city appeals a ruling that approved the team's move to Los Angeles.

title: Triumph Cycles
description: The Triumph Motorcycle cooperative, established in 1975 with $7.5 million of Government aid, said it would be liquidated as a result of mounting debts and a lack of orders for its 650- cubic-centimeter Bonneville machine aimed primarily at North American buyers. Workers and bosses at the cooperative all drew the same wage.

title: China Trade Back on Track
description: Chinese textile and apparel exports to the United States have been taking too many great leaps forward, as American manufacturers see it, but in seven months of difficult bargaining to set ceilings, Peking hung tough. It squeezed United States trade, halting purchases of soybeans, cotton and synthetic fibers that had been running at more than $300 million a year and announced reductions in American grain imports that totaled more than $1.2 billion in 1982.

title: HAS THE REGIONAL THEATER FULFILLED ITS PROMISE?
description: Theater in America used to mean Broadway. The great playwrights wrote for Broadway and Broadway was their showcase, the place where things began. All that has changed. Partly, economics have made it practically unthinkable for a straight play to originate on Broadway. But if Broadway is no longer synonymous with the theater in America, that is largely because of the regional theater movement that took root in this country over the last 25 years. That movement has created opportunities for theater artists to live and work in such cities as Atlanta, San Francisco, Chicago, Louisville and Seattle, instead of having to migrate to New York to be where the action is. It has nurtured writers as diverse as Sam Shepard and Beth Henley, David Mamet and Lanford Wilson, Marsha Norman and Charles Fuller. Many of the plays that go to Broadway have originated in one of these regional theaters, and an entire repertory of American drama of merit has sprung up from all over the country, which has made it possible for a play to have a life without ever treading the Great White Way.

title: SEAFOOD ON THE GRILL
description: ONE THING that has fascinated us about reader correspondence over the years is the constant demand for the most basic recipes. In the middle of summer, we receive endless queries about the simplest ways to grill fish and other seafood.

title: REAGAN SHEDS REAGAN
description: Many a President has abandoned unpopular policies, denying all the while that he was making any change. But has it ever happened wholesale? That is the amazing political phenomenon of today: Ronald Reagan reversing or disavowing one after another of his positions on major domestic questions.

title: STATEN ISLAND WONDERS IF SECESSION CAN SUCCEED
description: The notion that the ''forgotten borough'' of Staten Island could become a former one is so melodramatic that many New York City officials find it hard to take seriously. But State Senator John J. Marchi, one of the city's more thoughtful politicians, wasn't smiling when he brought the idea up last week. He supported it with fresh research from the Senate Finance Committee, which he heads, showing how a legal separation would be a boon to the island and could be effected without the rest of the city's permission.

title: AT HOME IN COUNTY CORK
description: Last summer, my wife and I rented a small house a mile outside a town called Schull, in southwesternmost Ireland. I had been to Ireland once before, in the summer of 1976, and had scooted around the country in a rented car, seeing the usual tourist sights. The place stayed with me like the most vivid of dreams; the landscape, which varies from rugged mountains to placid farmland to stormy seacoast, is lovely beyond description, and the people beguile you with their odd mixture of boisterousness and truculence and mischievousness and vigorous, colorful conversation. In short, I wanted to go back and live for a while in one place. I got the name of a land agent in southwest Cork - a part of the country I hadn't visited - from a friend who lives in London. He himself had been to Schull and he said the area was one of the most beautiful places he had ever seen. I wrote to the agent describing what we were looking for - a house or cottage for the month of July with a good view of something or other for about $150 a week.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: ATLANTIC BEACH
description: SALTY breezes drift almost constantly through the quiet, residential streets and wide boulevards of Atlantic Beach, L.I., a secluded oceanside community of Spanish-style homes and cabana clubs. For years, purveyors of its real estate solicited the business of wealthy New Yorkers with promises of healthful, seasonal living, away from Manhattan. ''At Atlantic Beach, days spin on, a bright and never-pausing wheel in time, evolving what cannot miss becoming the queen of American resorts,'' said an early advertising pamphlet. '' Atlantic Beach is the incarnation of a successful New York at ease and at play.'' Today, Atlantic Beach is a year-round community, within commuting distance of Manhattan and stone's-throw distance of miles of private beaches. ''The ocean, the sand and the quietness of the community, and the fact that there's very little commercialism, make this an ideal village for many New York businessmen,'' said Fred P. Lager, a stockbroker who has been Atlantic Beach's Mayor since its incorporation in 1962. Perched on a narrow spit of land between the sandy, white shores of the Atlantic Ocean and the grassy harbor-ends of Reynolds Channel, Atlantic Beach is a community of about 4,000 year-round residents, according to the 1980 census. It includes four unincorporated areas of single-family homes, called Atlantic Beach Estates, and the incorporated Village of Atlantic Beach. While the Estates and the village are contiguous, the use of the beaches, crucial to the community's appeal, is restricted almost exclusively to village residents and private club members.

title: Brewers 3, Blue Jays 0
description: Paul Molitor hit his 13th homer, and Chuck Porter pitched a six-hit shutout to lead Milwaukee.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED IN COMMENTING ON EDUCATION
description: BETWEEN 89 and 96 percent of the American public have critical opinions about American education. Criticism has reached epidemic proportions.

title: WOMAN ON THE RUN
description: EUGENE, OREGON'S SECOND LARGEST CITY (pop. 106,000), bills itself, not without justification, as Track Town. Situated in the lush fruit region of the Willamette Valley, Eugene is the home of the University of Oregon, which is to track and field what Notre Dame and Alabama are to intercollegiate football. It has also been, for some years now, the foster home of some of the world's swiftest human beings. Alberto Salazar, the fastest marathon runner in history, lives there; the fabled Steve Prefontaine ran for the University of Oregon, then settled in Eugene and broke every American record from 2,000 to 10,000 meters before he died in an automobile accident in 1975 at the age of 24.

title: INSANITY PLEA: DOCTORS VS. LAW
description: THE successful insanity defense by John W. Hinckley, the would-be assassin of President Reagan, spurred a national concern and indignation at the insanity defense.

title: NEED FOR LAWYERS?
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
A PLACE OF UNSTUDIED CASUALNESS
description: The attention-catching name is appropriate for this restaurant that calls itself a bistro (but is more than that) yet clearly has higher aspiration (but is at this time less than that). The place has a bit of posh mixed with the ingenuous; it is casual, but with a touch of class.

title: New Rules Needed for Indy
description: A rash of serious leg and ankle injuries in Indy car racing this season may lead to rule changes that would require car builders to provide more protection for the drivers. The rules that have governed America's premier form of open-wheel racing for the last three years expire at the end of this season, and Championship Auto Racing Teams, the group that controls that form of the sport, is evaluating proposals to change car specifications.

title: AT DEATH'S DOOR; The Public Ear
description: National Public Radio's financial troubles have been of immediate concern to its unpaid employees and its anxious creditors. But an audience of nine million is also among the network's assets, and they have matched Federal help with membership dollars to individual stations.

title: STALKING THE ELUSIVE MOUNTAIN
description: Climb it? I couldn't even find it. We were about 100 miles to the north. I had come to Alaska, bearing my ski parka into the sweltering city of Fairbanks, to teach at the Midnight Sun Writers' Conference at the University of Alaska. Fine invitation, happy to accept. Longing to lay eyes on Denali, ill advisedly called Mount McKinley. But where was it?

title: Miss Christensen Becomes a Bride In Massachusetts
description: Anne Carter Christensen, daughter of Mrs. John Marshall Nosworthy of Greenwich, Conn., and Mattapoisett, Mass., and the late Viggo Christensen, was married yesterday to Howard Macfarland Fish 3d, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Fish Jr. of Lawrenceville, N.J., Lake Placid, N.Y., and Barbados. The bridegroom's father, a Congregational minister and chaplain at the Lawrenceville School, performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Mattapoisett.

title: Lisa Pedicini Marries
description: Lisa Claire Pedicini, daughter of Dorothy Harrod Pedicini of Topsfield, Mass., and the late Remo Matthew Pedicini, was married yesterday to Joseph J. Magliocco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Magliocco of New York. The Rev. David T. Dougherty performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The bride is a reporter in New York for HFD Retailing Home Furnishings. Mr. Magliocco is a partner in Peerless Importers, a wine and spirits concern in Brooklyn, of which his father is founder and chairman.

title: AS LAWMAKERS HEAD HOME, ECONOMIC FEARS TAG ALONG
description: In the summer of 1981, Congress passed President Reagan's economic program and rode home on a jetstream of fiscal optimism. During their recess, the lawmakers were peppered with alarming news about rising interest rates. When they returned to Washington, they were not nearly so euphoric.

title: ANGLO-SAXON, FUNDAMENTALIST, RURAL: A PORTRAIT
description: To the Editor:

title: PUMPS HERE, THERE AND EVERYWHERE
description: As the numbers of service stations decline, those that remain in business are becoming larger, leaner and more efficient.

title: RELIEF ON RATES-AT WHOSE EXPENSE?
description: A FEW years ago, before the Rockies terminated their National Hockey League franchise with Denver and became the New Jersey Devils, Sonny Werblin ''seriously threatened'' to move the New York Rangers to the Meadowlands unless certain concessions were forthcoming immediately. High on his list was the demand for a reduction in the electric rates charged the Madison Square Garden Corporation by Con Edison.

title: TRIATHLON TO BENEFIT HOSPITAL
description: TO mark its 75th anniversary this year, St. Agnes Hospital is sponsoring the first triathlon in the county. The three- sport competition, which is expected to attract as many as 500 participants, is scheduled for Sept. 11.

title: SOME MISSIONS AND OMISSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: ONETIME COMMONER NOW PUTTING ON THE RITZ
description: IN centuries past, lobsters were so plentiful along our shores that serving them for dinner was more likely to evoke groans of boredom than smiles of delight. According to ''Eating in America'' by Waverley Root and Richard de Rochemont, ''When there was a storm at Plymouth, lobsters piled up in the windrows two feet high on the beach; they were considered fit only for the poor, who could afford nothing better; in 1622 . . . Governor William Bradford was deeply humiliated because his colony was so short of food that the only 'dish they could present their friends was a lobster.' ''

title: UNDERWRITING MAN'S INGENUITY AND NATURE'S SHIFTING MODDS
description: FAILING farms and the looming budget deficit have made agricultural policy a hot political question.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: MICHALA PETRI, RECORDER SOLOIST
description: Michala Petri, the young, Danish recorder player who so endeared herself to Thursday's Mostly Mozart audience, returned to Avery Fisher Hall Friday night, this time to play with the Festival's orchestra and its conductor for the weekend, Pinchas Zukerman. There were two other soloists as well - Mr. Zukerman, himself, in the Telemann Viola Concerto in G, and Joseph Kalichstein taking the piano part of Mozart's Concerto No. 5 (K. 175).

title: A GREAT NOVEL'S JOURNEY TO FILM
description: It is a poignant irony that Werner Rainer Fassbinder's ''Berlin Alexanderplatz,'' which has been acclaimed by some critics as a masterwork, is the tale of a man who struggles to be honest and upright - a lusty struggle that brings him women, friendship, vitality - but who finally succumbs, first to an earthly satan and then to the banality of a petty job polishing rich men's limousines. Throughout his short, frenzied and astonishingly prolific life, the Wunderkind of the postwar German film was mesmerized by the figure of Franz Biberkopf, the proletarian protagonist of Alfred D"oblin's ''Berlin Alexanderplatz,'' a novel that enjoys a place in modern German letters akin to Joyce's ''Ulysses.''

title: GIFT AIDS U.S.-SPONSORED TEACHER PROGRAM
description: A private foundation has announced a $500,000 grant to a program run by a Federal agency to help high school teachers improve their skills.

title: Data Bank; August 7, 1983
RELIVING A LOESSER LEGEND
description: ON Aug. 20, 1947, during the first season of Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theater in Westport, Conn., a musical revue, ''No Casting Today,'' was being tried out. In it, a diminutive newcomer performed ''The Understudy's Prayer.''

title: THEATER
description: Lee Kalcheim's ''Breakfast With Les and Bess'' is a domestic farce in the buoyant, well-made style of Broadway's more genteel past. Carefully crafted and intelligent - never vulgar or cheap - it reminds us of what boulevard comedies looked like before television taught playwrights to condescend to audiences.

title: READERS MAY LOOK TO BOOKS FOR WHAT'S NOT ON SCREEN
description: As a pre-adolescent movie fan, I once read ''West Side Story.'' That's right, read it: read the love scenes, read the rumble, and read the dance at the gym. I liked the movie, and so I accumulated, along with a soundtrack recording and a souvenir photo album, a little paperback book that more or less told its story. In view of that, I can't pretend that the appeal of movie novelizations, at least for very young viewers, is entirely incomprehensible to me. But I'm still surprised at the extent to which the novelization business has been booming.

title: Sports of The Times;  'The Spirit of the Rules' -- Part II
description: UNTIL last week, the summer's biggest sports controversy was the George Brett pine-tar bat. Perhaps by now you've heard of it. The uproar in baseball is now being matched by a flap in the America's Cup of 12-Meter yacht racing. The controversy involves an unorthodox winged keel on Australia II, which passed the regular rating procedure and then swept to a huge lead in the first challengers' round.

title: BALLET: A STAR-FILLED OUTDOOR NIGHT IN NEW JERSEY
description: The stunning backdrop of the Manhattan skyline proved an almost insurmountable distraction on Friday night when ''Ballet/Stars'' was presented on an outdoor stage erected in Jersey City's handsome Liberty State Park. But there certainly were dance stars on hand, and they managed to shine fairly brightly, despite the exotic limitations of the setting and the insubstantial nature of such programs.

title: Sutton Leads P.G.A. by 2
description: On a hot, humid day in which none of the contenders moved much more than a stroke forward or backward, Hal Sutton retained his lead over Ben Crenshaw today in the third round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: CUOMO EXPANDS ROLE IN SHOREHAM ISSUE
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO is gradually escalating his commitment to help Long Island businesses and families cope with the shock of sharp increases in electric rates to pay for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Q AND A
description: No More 3-Year Leases Question:

title: WITHOUT INDEPENDENCE, NO INITIATIVES
description: AT an early-morning press conference on Oct. 6, 1979, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took command of the economic policy of the United States. The President, his Treasury Secretary and other high-ranking Carter Administration officials stood meekly by. Despite the circumstance that he is neither elected nor subject to removal by any elected official, Mr. Volcker has determined economic policy ever since.

title: TEXAS OIL LAWSUIT BECOMES POLITICAL CONFLICT
description: A once-obscure lawsuit over oil royalties has grown into a political and financial conflict pitting the Texas Attorney General against the Mobil Oil Corporation and a leading local law firm.

title: NEWARK CITYSCAPE: EMPTY CONTAINERS
description: FROM afar, they look like modern office or school buildings: block-long red structures oddly uniform among the jumbled warehouses and factories of the city's Ironbound Section.

title: DEBTORS FACING IRE OF STATE TREASURER
description: THE state's Treasurer is ''putting the squeeze'' on the 195,000 New Jerseyans who owe the state $400 million.

title: Mary Fuller Is Wed To Martin W. Bond
description: Mary Woodbridge Fuller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hudson Fuller of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Martin William Bond, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Clarence Bond, also of Wilmington. The Rev. John Cartmell performed the ceremony at Westminister Presbyterian Church.

title: Gets 30 More Days To Plan Cuban Release
description: The Federal Government has 30 days to plan the release of about 1,000 Cuban immigrants now in Atlanta's Federal penitentiary.

title: Debora L. Jones To Wed Sept. 17
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jon Rex Jones of Albany, Tex., and Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debora Lynn Jones, to Allan Oberly Benz of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Benz of Ridgewood, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla. The wedding is to be Sept. 17.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
REMOVE THE FREEDOM TO SNUB CONGRESS
description: THE independence of the Federal Reserve is a historical accident, not the result of conscious design. The central bank was created in 1913 to help avert bank panics and mass insolvencies. It was given the power to regulate banks and to control the supplies of money and credit, and it was given the independence thought to be appropriate for a regulatory agency. There was no general understanding at that time of the importance of using money and credit policies to stabilize the economy.

title: Poles Begin Their Holy Trek
description: Tens of thousands of Poles set out today on treks from all directions to the shrine of the Black Madonna in Czestochowa. Lines of men, women and children stretched more than four miles on the highway south of Warsaw. People were taking part in similar marches from other cities.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IN nearly 12 years of dispensing free business advice, the county's chapter of the Service Corps of Retired Executives has depended on the generosity of civic and business organizations to provide space for its operation. On Monday, however, the 15-member chapter opened its first permanent office, at Empire State College, at 11 Mitchell Place in White Plains. For the hundreds of entrepreneurs expected to seek help from the retired executives this year, Score volunteers will be available in the new location each weekday except Tuesday from 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: NEIL YOUNG AND BILLY JOEL REVISIT THE ROOTS OF ROCK
description: How relative is that quality in a cultural artifact that we call innocence! In the late 1950's and early 1960's, the era that has been labelled ''the golden age of rock and roll,'' rock was suspected by many of being morally subversive for its sexual suggestiveness. Yet the very title of Billy Joel's new album, ''An Innocent Man'' (Columbia BL 38837), implies the same dewy-eyed romanticism that Glenn Miller's ''Moonlight Serenade'' symbolizes to an older generation. Indeed, the album's 10 songs, which pay homage to the 1955- 65 era of pop records, exalt that bygone time when courtship rituals and sexual roles were far more clearly defined than they are today.

title: REAGAN'S MIDEAST ENVOY HOLDS TALKS WITH SYRIAN
description: The special United States envoy to the Middle East, Robert C. McFarlane, met with Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam today, and Syrian broadcasts said the American official would propose a temporary demilitarized zone to separate forces in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon.

title: South Tyrol
description: To the Editor:

title: Gandhi's Legacy
description: If Robert Trumbull thinks my observations about Gandhi ''extreme,'' like those of V.S. Naipaul about India, he has plainly not been keeping up with the profusion of articles on Gandhi that have been appearing in recent months (''Gandhi's Living Legacy,'' July 3). Salman Rushdie, winner of Britain's Booker Prize but born and reared in Bombay, wrote of the movie ''Gandhi'' that in order to make the Mahatma palatable for Western audiences, the film makers turned him into Jesus Christ. I, in my moderate way, had only suggested St. Francis of Assisi.

title: CRASH NEAR AIRFIELD STIRS MARLBOROUGH
description: TOWN leaders in Marlborough indicate that they will review closely the circumstances of a plane crash last Sunday near the site of what developers hope will be Somerset, the state's first community built around an airport.

title: 36,000 CONTRIBUTE TO FRESH AIR FUND
description: In 1937, when Nancy Nitchie was 7 years old, her mother let her open a lemonade stand on Martha's Vineyard provided she agreed to contribute any money she earned to the Fresh Air Fund to help give underprivileged children from the city summer vacations in the country. She earned $7.

title: Clipping Away At Education
description: President Reagan holds a bouquet in one hand and lopping shears in the other when he approaches the subject of education. Last week he declared his ''unshakable commitment to eliminate discrimination.''

title: PENNY BANKS AS MINIATURE BUILDINGS
description: Architecture in the late 19th century transformed far more than cities - it radically altered the design of virtually everything in the decorative arts, including penny banks. This can be seen in ''A Penny Saved: Architecture in Cast Iron Toy Banks,'' an assemblage of these miniature interpretations in metal of modest and grandiose American and British buildings. They are on view at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street, through Oct. 23.

title: Q and A
description: Question:

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE state's nearly one million acres of farmland have been subjected to a series of extreme climatic conditions over the spring and summer that have reduced crop production considerably. Agricultural officials say the effects will be felt through the fall.

title: FOR THE VERY YOUNG, BOOKS WITH A SPECIAL FEEL
description: ''There are many parents who put books in their child's crib, even if he only chews them or throws them around,'' says Andy Mayer, a California book designer. ''They feel that a child can become familiar with books even as an infant, and later relate to them better.''

title: Moyers Stars as Cosmos Win
description: The pursuit of first place in the overall stariding, which appeared to be beyond reach for the Cosmos, is now within grasp after they defeated the Montreal Manic, 4-2, today at Olympic Stadium.

title: MUSIC
description: In the 1960's, ''folk music'' was widely considered to be something played by long-suffering guitarists in Greenwich Village. But the New York Folk Festival, now entering its second week, takes the term in its original, broader meaning - as music transmitted through an aural tradition - and is offering jazz, rock and country concerts along with guitar pickers.

title: Spit Curl Takes the Alabama
description: In a race that came out almost exactly in reverse of horsemen's and horseplayers' expectations, Spit Curl ran off to a surprising but impressive 8 1/2-length victory today in the $109,800 Alabama Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: BOOM DAYS FOR POLITICAL RISK CONSULTANTS
description: BACK in November 1979, armed Iranian students stormed the gates of the United States Embassy in Teheran and took 62 Americans - and America - hostage.

title: ROLAND PETIT TRANSCENDS A LITERARY SOURCE
description: If the charge of superficiality has frequently been leveled at Roland Petit, especially in his native France, it is easy to see why. As a choreographer who works mainly in dance-drama, he is one of ballet's most incomplete storytellers.

title: Officers Ball Rallies To Win Sorority Stakes
description: Officers Ball rallied in the stretch to capture the $213,750 Sorority Stakes for 2-year-old fillies today at Monmouth Park.

title: For Whom the Phone Rings
description: Ma Bell, as the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is known, made it official last week - she will not only give up her children but will also, with some reluctance, change her name. In agreeing not to fight court-imposed modifications to its antitrust settlement with the Justice Department, A.T.& T. cleared the way to dismantle the Bell system on Jan. 1, a decade after the Government filed suit.

title: A 2D AIDS EPIDEMIC
description: A double epidemic is spreading across the land. One, a growing fear and intolerance of homosexuals, is fueled by the other, the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, and neither is being adequately addressed.

title: Sports News Briefs;  232 Yachts Compete In the Fastnet Race
description: A fleet of yachts from 15 nations set sail today in the Fastnet race, the final event of the 1983 Admiral's Cup.

title: WESTERN SHEEP RANCHERS FIGHTING TO SURVIVE
description: Only three years ago ranchers grazed more than 40,000 sheep on the lush fields amid the sagebrush hills along the Snake River.

title: SUNDAY, AUGUST 7, 1983
description: International

title: UNTAPPED RESOURCE OF CONDOMINIUMS
description: MOST times in history are characterized by certain signs, whether they are economic, sociological, political or cultural. One of the county's ''signs of the times'' is the dramatic increase of newly built and newly converted condominium and cooperative housing units.

title: PAYING OFF EARLY HAS ATTRACTIONS
description: HOMEOWNERS who have been paying off a mortgage for 15 years or more often reach the point where they would like to wipe out the debt entirely.

title: EGYPTIANS SILENT ON U.S. MANEUVERS
description: Egyptian officials have imposed a virtual news blackout on arrangements for joint military maneuvers with the United States and some Western diplomats here say the growing conflict in Chad is a factor.

title: STATION HOUSE RISES, BUT NOT HIGH
description: Some time before the end of the year, Queens will get a new police precinct, designated the 115th, which will cover the Jackson Heights section. To house its personnel, a new station house is being built on the corner of Northern Boulevard and 92d Street.

title: HOW TO RENT A COTTAGE ABROAD
description: Although the ''self-catering'' vacation - renting a house, cottage or apartment and doing your own housekeeping - now ranks as one of the most popular types of vacation for Europeans, it remains near the bottom of the list of choices for Americans when they go to Europe. Last year, for example, some 60 percent of people in Britain vacationing in their own country decided to rent a do- it-yourself holiday home. Only 5 percent of Americans visiting Britain chose such an option, the majority staying in conventional accommodations, be they bed and breakfast or the Ritz, or staying with family or friends.By renting a vacation home, and shopping in the village grocery and making excursions to the open-air market in the nearest town, the vacationer inevitably savors more of local life than staying in a resort hotel. Getting to grips with local customs, away from tourist crowds, is one of the delights of self- catering in Europe.

title: STATE READIES PLAN FOR AIDING ELDERLY
description: GOVERNOR O'NEILL is expected to approve and submit to the Federal Government by Aug. 17 the state's new Plan on Aging.

title: THE REDISCOVERY OF H.D.
description: ''SHE was beautiful, reckless, one of the poetesses whose poetry (was) feared and wondered over.'' With this single, somewhat enigmatic sentence, D. H. Lawrence characterized H. D. (Hilda Doolittle, 1886-1961) in ''Kangaroo,'' his 1923

title: BISHOPS WITHDRAW SHARP CRITICISM OF MARCOS
description: The Roman Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines announced today that a pastoral letter sharply criticizing President Ferdinand E. Marcos was withdrawn Friday after Mr. Marcos decreed the repeal or modification of his powers to arrest suspected rebels and subversives.

title: California Ordered To Improve San Quentin
description: A judge has ordered an end to ''cruel and unusual'' conditions at San Quentin Prison and demanded a state plan to end overcrowding there.

title: Mayotte Upsets Lendl
description: Tim Mayotte upset Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, and Jimmy Connors struggled in overcoming Mats Wilander of Sweden today to advance to the final of the $300,000 High Stakes tennis tournament.

title: Poles Declining Amnesty Offer
description: Post-martial law Poland as viewed from below still looked uninviting last week to 300 or so underground Solidarity activists who have spurned the Polish Government's two-week-old amnesty offer. Only 18 have come out of the cold, the Government admitted, and one on its lists, Krzyszstof Wyszkowski, a former Solidarity editor, said even that total was exaggerated.

title: BALLETOMANES DEBATE THE STYLE OF TODAY'S DANCERS
description: Has the look of ballet companies changed in the last 30 years? Where are the glamorous stars of old? What has become of corps dancers with dramatic impact? Has individual personality and temperament been sacrificed for a uniformity of look and a better technique? These are days of heated discussions among balletomanes about the new look of ballet companies and the glories of the way things used to be. Though clearly today's ballet has many devoted admirers and defenders, some veteran dancegoers are staying away from the theater because, they say, today's companies lack the style of the old.

title: BELL LABS IS LOSING ECONOMICS CENTER
description: THE American Telephone and Telegraph Company antitrust settlement whose final changes were made last week has indirectly brought about the demise of Bell Laboratories' small but prominent Economics Research Center here.

title: E.P.A. IS CALLED LAX ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: AN OFFICIAL of a national environmental organization charged last week that, since 1980, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has been violating court agreements and its own regulations by allowing oceangoing waste barges to discharge higher-than-normal concentrations of sewage sludge off the New Jersey coast.

title: Abigail M. Murphy, Student, Marries John Kean Jr., a Bank Account Officer
description: Abigail Margaret Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Bradford Murphy of Little Silver, N.J., was married yesterday to John Kean Jr., son of Joan Jessup Kean of New York and Hobe Sound, Fla., and Mr. Kean of Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. Ronald Jaynes performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWERS THAT COMBAT HEAT AND DROUGHT
description: IT takes a tough perennial to stand up well in the herbaceous border during the summer, yet there are a few that stand out in their ability to withstand heat and drought. Liberal use of these durable plants will assure continuance flowering for all but the most adverse conditions.

title: Civil Liberties And Waiter's Research
description: A July 3 story (''A Fire, an Inquiry and a Waiter's Research for a Thesis'') carried remarks attibuted to me that may have appeared to disparage the case of Mario Brujaha, a Stony Brook graduate student. Mr. Brujaha is asserting a scholar's privilege to protect from a Nassau County grand jury notes that the District Attorney believes may be helpful in an investigation of suspected arson at a restaurant where Mr. Brujaha worked as a waiter in the course of his study of restaurant sociology.

title: Royals 4, Red Sox 0
description: Eric Rasmussen became the first Kansas City pitcher to record a completegame shutout since last September as he held Boston to seven hits.

title: Nina Virginia Cohen Weds John Barrows
description: Nina Virginia Cohen, daughter of Mary Frohman of Larchmont, N.Y., and Dr. Burton D. Cohen of New York, was married yesterday to John Craig Barrows, son of Jeannette B. Molzer of Little Silver, N.J., and Donald B. Barrows Jr. of St. Louis. The Rev. George LaPorte of the Unitarian Community Church in Manhattan performed the ceremony at Bargemusic in Brooklyn.

title: Lauren Ingersoll, Thomas Murray, Exchange Vows
description: Lauren Reeve Ingersoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps Ingersoll Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Anthony Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Brady Murray of Earlysville, Va. The Rev. Thomas Lamont performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of Manhasset.

title: JUST HOW 'SERIOUS' ARE THE GENEVA ARMS NEGOTIATIONS?
description: DESPITE sharp words over Central America and Chad, Soviet-American relations have been showing signs of improvement. A new agreement will raise grain exports to Moscow and last week, Secretary of State George P. Shultz urged relaxation of export controls on oil and gas equipment in effect since the jailing of two Soviet dissidents and tightened after Russia invaded Afghanistan.

title: INDIVIDUAL EXPRESSION MARKS WORK OF PAINTER FROM CHINA
description: ''EACH artist wants to use his own language to express his own feelings,'' says Yuan Yunshen, a painter from China who is currently visiting this country under the auspices of the United States Information Agency. This attitude has caused him considerable personal difficulty in his homeland, where his work has been criticized and censored for its unorthodox approach to the figure.

title: A Dangerous Deal For State Police
description: As a working member of the 1973 Governor's Commission on Services and Expenditures (the Etherington Commission), I had the responsibility to study the operation of the Connecticut State Police. With the cooperation of Commissioner Fussenich and his staff, our group came to a sound understanding of, and a deep respect for, the department.

title: Joan Esther Morse Marries Robert James Drelles
description: Joan Esther Morse was married yesterday in Quincy, Mass., to Robert James Drelles of Cambridge, Mass., in a ceremony performed at the Bethany Congregational Church by the Rev. Joel Huntington.

title: Todd Assured as Jet Leader
description: Sometimes, Richard Todd will turn around to Joe Walton and question a suggestion.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: UNDER a pink and white candy-striped tent on the lawns behind the Wheeler House, a Victorian mansion in the center of Westport, Joanne Woodward and Paul Newman met 800 of their neighbors and friends last Wednesday evening. The event was the annual summer party of the Westport Historical Society. And although it was the third time that the couple had been the hosts of the gathering, designed primarily to raise money for the restoration of the Wheeler House as the society's headquarters and museum, it was perhaps the most festive.

title: AT 80, A MUSICIAN LOOKS BACK
description: Abram Chasins will be celebrating his 80th birthday on Aug. 17. The former music director of WQXR, author of ''Speaking of Pianists,'' ''Stokowski'' and other books, commentator on music, performing pianist, student of Josef Hofmann, composer, raconteur and educator, is eager to share some of his musical impressions - many of which he is now putting into his memoirs.

title: MARATHON FOR THE BARD'S FANS
description: LURKING in the aisles and hovering behind a section of seats near the stage, the Duke of Gloucester - later Richard III - begins the soliloquy ''Now is the winter of our discontent . . .'' as Edward IV is being crowned king of England.

title: Joyce Cummings Is Married
description: Joyce Marie Cummings, daughter of Roberta A. Lerch of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to David Stuart Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Thompson of Ottawa. The Rev. Anthony Della Villa performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Australians Rule the Sea
description: EVEN the navigator on the leading American boat believes it is likely that the United States will not win the America's Cup this year.

title: WILL LP QUALITY SURVIVE?
description: With the LP record being chivvied by such younger rivals as the laser disk and tape cassettes, many listeners worry that record companies - concentrating on the newer media - may grow lax in maintaining quality standards for LP. Assurances to the contrary naturally flow from official sources, and both RCA and CBS emphasize that the bulk of their business is still in the form of conventional records and that this alone is a compelling reason for keeping LP pressings up to par.

title: COAST DEMOCRATS FEAR RUIN IN SPECIAL ELECTION
description: An event four months away is dominating politics in California this summer: a special election Dec. 13 on a Republican- sponsored reapportionment plan that, if approved, would almost certainly cause a fundamental shift of political power in the nation's most populous state.

title: Defect Brings An Unwelcome First' for G.M.
description: A deadly defect in 1980 X-model cars built by General Motors may wind up sending both the company and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration into a skid. The Justice Department sued G.M. for $4 million last week, accusing the automaker of giving the agency false information. The chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the agency charged it had carried on a coverup of its own.

title: PEACE AND PLENTY-TWO WEEKS AT EASE IN RURAL FRANCE
description: To love France is, sooner or later, to love her countryside. Paris, we are told, is where good Americans go when they die (and good Germans, and good Swedes, and good Australians, and good Japanese), but even Paris, for all its vitality and style, is in the end a big city with the big-city disadvantages - noise, fumes, bustle, expense, a life lived among hordes of strangers. In the countryside, with its seasonal rhythms and accustomed relationships, we find our roots and recover our real identity. It offers a reflective solitude totally different from the ghastly loneliness that afflicts people in cities. The life we find there links us with our traditions. Country people grow food and look after animals; the work they do was, until a few generations ago, the characteristic work of the human race.

title: THOUGHTS ON THE THREAT
description: THINKING ABOUT NATIONAL SECURITY Defense and Foreign Policy in a Dangerous World. By Harold Brown. 288 pp. Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press. $17.95. THE WIZARDS OF ARMAGEDDON By Fred Kaplan. Illustrated. 452 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: CHECKING INTO ANOTHER ERA
description: If you were born too late to sail on the fabled trans-Atlantic superliners - or simply bemoan their passing - an unusual treat awaits you in Long Beach, Calif. There, the liner Queen Mary, a beloved monarch of the sea for more than 30 years, is still welcoming ''passengers.'' Of course, you never leave port, but you manage nonetheless to get a taste of the halcyon days of ocean travel.

title: COMEDIAN WAS 66
description: Judy Canova, a comedian, singer and actress who usually played the role of the country bumpkin, died Friday at Hollywood (Calif.) Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

title: IN ITALY, ESPRESSO IS THE ELIXIR OF LIFE
description: The one Italian word that is understood all over the world is espresso. It means concentrated black coffee, expressly brewed for immediate consumption - and it also means the place where it is served.The potent instant pick-me-up is quintessential Italy. The country wouldn't be the same - probably couldn't even function the way it does - without the millions of small cups of the powerful brew Italians drink every day.

title: DOLE ASSAILS BIAS-LAW STANCE
description: Senator Bob Dole criticized the Reagan Administration today for its narrow legal opinion on a statute designed to prevent discrimination against women in educational programs.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Feels Fit After Retina Surgery
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher left the hospital today, three days after eye surgery, and said she felt ''101 percent fit.''

title: Lucie L. Kinsolving to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Lee Kinsolving of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucie Lee Kinsolving, to Richard Lippincott McElhiney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. McElhiney of Washington. An October wedding is planned.

title: PENTAGON SAYS SOVIET STRESSES ARMS BUILDUP
description: The Defense Intelligence Agency has reported to Congress that Soviet military spending, while not increasing as fast as it did several years ago, is still growing more rapidly than the Soviet economy.

title: Lisa Ann Hyman Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hyman of Old Bridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Hyman, to Robert Fisher, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Martin Fisher of Brooklyn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: HERE COMES THE 'RING' ON A SHOESTRING
description: It is cheeky, deliciously bold. The Metropolitan Opera in New York hasn't done it in decades.
