But on the strength of one man's vision and contagious drive, the Boston Lyric Opera Company - previously a small operator in the operatic world - has just mounted productions of all four parts of Richard Wagner's mammoth epic, ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' in one week.

title: FOLLOWING THE BOUNCING BALL
description: ALAN MESSER, tanned and wearing a navy blue tennis shirt bearing an ''NJTO'' emblem, asked for quiet from the group surrounding him, then said:

title: Top Marathoners Ready in Helsinki
description: At the age of 17, Grete Waitz of Norway competed here in the 800-and 1,500-meter runs at the European track and field championships. She did not survive the opening heats.

title: WASTE OF MIDNIGHT OIL
description: When you create a new idea or new move to rehabilitate a long-disfavored opening variation the chief worry is whether you have calculated everything correctly or taken into account all the new directions into which the game can veer.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: The Price of the Rose

title: Drying Out a State
description: There was one licensed liquor outlet in Alaska for every 234 residents. There was one alcoholic or problem drinker for every 14 residents.

title: SWEET USES OF ADVERSITY
description: UNEMPLOYMENT may be hazardous to your health. It may also - believe it or not - be helpful to your marriage. In the six months since my husband said those fateful words - ''I got fired, honey'' - I've learned that, for us, there can be a silver lining in even the darkest cloud.

title: TODAY'S COMPOSERS AND PLAYERS MAY YET BE ALLIES
description: The composer Charles Wuorinen recently appeared on a panel sponsored by the Music Critics Association that was devoted to the relationship between the recording industry and contemporary music. In the course of the discussion, Mr. Wuorinen tossed off the following proposition, which warrants wider dissemination and discussion:

title: Condor Chicks Are Female
description: Sex tests on two California condor chicks show the birds are females, raising hopes that a captive-breeding program could save the endangered species, a spokesman for the San Diego Zoo and Wild Animal Park said today. The eggs had been taken from nests in the wild as part of the California condor recovery program, a joint state and Federal effort to prevent extinction of the birds, which now number about 20.

title: THE DOOR IS OPEN FOR PERSON-TO-PERSON SALES ON L.I.
description: AS she had done so many times before, Val DeLeonardis gleefully crumbled a Ritz cracker on someone else's rug. She then demonstrated a small brown ''electrostatic carpet sweeper,'' the Fuller Brush Company's best-selling product. ''The cracker disappears as if by magic,'' the saleswoman said, and the green rug in the dining room of Patricia Gottlieb's home was spotless once more.

title:
NONFICTION IN BRIEF;
 BY LITTLE AND BY LITTLE
description: The Selected Writings of Dorothy Day. Edited and Introduced by Robert Ellsberg. 371 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Development Agency And Waldbaum Project
description: In the interest of an accurate record, I would like to make the following corrections and comments regarding the July 17 article ''Waldbaum Wins - at a Price'':
Size: Averages 24 inches.

title: NATURE, FANTASY, ART
description: THE KINGFISHER By Amy Clampitt. 149 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $6.95. PERU By Herbert Morris. 80 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $14.50. Paper, $6.95. THE ISLAND-MAKER By Roy Marz. 100 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Ithaca House. Paper, $6.

title: JAPANESE BUILD ON E. 79TH ST.
description: During the past 15 years, Nissho-Iwai, a Japanese trading company, made its name in real estate by building some 18,000 condominium units throughout Japan. Now the company is making its bid for a share of the New York condominium development market with its first project in the United States: a 21-story condominium apartment building at 124 East 79th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

title: Yankees and Fontenot Rout Tigers, 13-3
description: Suspensions and sea gulls aside for the time being, the Yankees kept winning last night with another extravagant display of power that buried the Detroit Tigers, 13-3.

title: NEW GROUP PUSHES NATURAL-LAWN IDEA
description: AT A TIME when most suburbanites are spending more hours and money keeping their lawns neat, green and free of weeds, some gardeners and landscapers are letting theirs turn naturally into flowering meadows.

title: Perils of Biography
description: John Steinbeck may have been the only novelist in his family, but apparently there are a couple of editors in the bunch, as Jackson J. Benson discovered recently. Mr. Benson, who worked 15 years on an authorized Steinbeck biography that was to have been released last week, found that publication would have to be delayed because some Steinbeck family members were hinting they might sue unless some things in his manuscript were changed. The San Diego State University English professor conceded some of them might find parts of the book embarrassing, but said making the revisions was nevertheless ''a terrible ordeal.''

title: TAXES ARE ISSUE AS NORTHAMPTON EYES INCORPORATION
description: AS voters in the northwestern section of Southampton Town give final consideration to the issues surrounding the controversial incorporation of Northampton village, a county study released last week has concluded that the new village would cost its residents additional taxes. But supporters of Northampton village say that incorporation will result in a slight tax decrease and stimulate growth, reviving the area's eroding tax base.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Not Knowing From Beans

title: CAN THE BEAUMONT BECOME A VITAL COMPANY?
description: It was 25 years ago in May that the philanthropist Vivian Beaumont Allen gave $3 million to Lincoln Center to further, in her words, the ''cherished hope that our country might one day have a national theater comparable in distinction and achievement to the Comedie Fran,caise.'' Mrs. Allen died in 1962; the theater bearing her name opened in 1965; we all know what has happened since. The Vivian Beaumont resembles the Comedie Fran,caise only in that its dilemmas often have the flavor of farce.

title: Newman Top Qualifier In 2d Trans-Am Trials
description: The actor Paul Newman, the defending champion, was the fastest qualifier today for the Pepsi Trans-Am auto race Sunday at Brainerd International Raceway.

title: WHY ROBOTS WHOULD SELL YOU A CAR
description: NOW that automobile companies have discovered the benefits of robots in their plants, they might well consider putting them on their sales floors. Don't scoff. The need is there. If the salesmen I have been encountering in the county are typical, the first company with a robot sales force is going to capture the market.

title: MOSQUITO OUTBREAK IS ABOUT NORMAL
description: JULIUS ELSTON'S ammunition is monstrous. One machine measures 32 feet long and 11 feet wide. Using it, combined with other forms of warfare and an army of 10 men, he contends he is 95 percent effective in eliminating the enemy - which he considers to be ''the worst pest affecting man and animals.''

title: THE FULFILLING WISDOM OF ISAIAH 55:2
description: AN hour before church, I pick up the Sunday paper, pull out the magazine and head for a cider and donut shop on Old Highway 22, my movable will nudged by the irresistible force of the hot, fresh doughnuts. ''One cinnamon, one sugar and black coffee, please.'' I feel very virtuous about the no-cal black coffee.

title: Miss Mayo Weds John L. Moore 3d
description: The marriage of Dorothy Ward Mayo to John Leonard Moore 3d took place yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Breed Mayo of Swampscott, Mass., parents of the bride. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gerald Porter, an Episcopal priest.

title: The 2 Newports Mix For a Busy Season
description: IN one quiet corner of this resort, behind the greenhouses of The Breakers, Cornelius Vanderbilt's Italianate palazzo, Helen Winslow wonders which arrangements of snapdragons, delphinia, dahlias and daisies will be most suitable for the Preservation Society of Newport County's triennial America's Cup Ball two weeks hence.

title: Rangers 6, Indians 1
description: Frank Tanana (5-4) tossed a five-hitter, and Jim Sundberg drove in three runs as Texas won its third straight game after eight consecutive losses. Cleveland suffered its fourth straight defeat.

title: TRENTON: A THEME OF SADNESS
description: ROBERT SPENCER would have fashioned a singular spot for himself in American Impressionism were it only for his unusual subject matter.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: JUDGE KAUFMAN IS WRONG FOR THE ORGANIZED-CRIME COMMISSION
description: To the Editor:

title: INVENTING ANNIHILATION
description: NUCLEAR HOSTAGES By Bernard J. O'Keefe, 252 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $14.95.

title: Louganis Wins 24th Title
description: Greg Louganis captured his 24th national diving title today when he rallied on his sixth dive and held the lead to win the platform final at the United States outdoor diving championships.

title: APPROVAL FOR PINE BARRENS HOUSING IS VOIDED
description: State approval for a major housing project outside Atlantic City, which had been challenged by state and national environmental organizations, has been ruled invalid by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: POP: MISS MANCHESTER PERFORMS AT RADIO CITY
description: Out of all the stars who were nurtured by the New York cabaret circuit of the early 1970's, Melissa Manchester is the most traditional as well as the most musically self-sufficient. An old-fashioned pop diva in the Judy Garland-Barbra Streisand mold, Miss Manchester does not need the vaudevillian stagecraft of contemporaries like Bette Midler and Peter Allen.

title: THE GOING GETS TOUGH AT THE NUCOR MINIMILL
description: THE scene is like something from Dante's Inferno. With temperatures reaching 100 degrees outside, workers inside the Nucor Corporation steel mill here shovel manganese into the open front of a furnace where molten steel is bubbling at 2,980 degrees. Their bodies are swaddled in asbestos suits, their eyes are covered with dark glasses and they stand a mere arm's length from the flames that lick the inside of the furnace and, sometimes, flare out its open door.

title: HAROLD KORZENIK
description: Harold Korzenik, a Brooklyn civic leader and counsel to the United Knitted Outerwear Association, the National Textile Processors Guild, the Knitwear Employers Association and the Knitwear Manufacturers Council, died Thurday of a heart attack at New York University Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Boiler Explosion Kills One
description: A man died early today and four others were in critical condition with burns after a boiler exploded at the Municipal Light and Power Plant late Friday, blowing 825-degree water, bricks and broken glass over a large area, a utility official said. The dead man was identified as Richard Lemos, 32 years old, of Coffeyville. The cause was not immediately known.

title: Amie Knox Is Married
description: Amie Clare Knox, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. Graham Knox of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Patrick Kelley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kelley of Aurora, Colo. The Rev. Michael McCafferty of the University of Notre Dame performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: WHAT SAM ERVIN THINKS WOMEN WANT
description: To the Editor:

title: Cora J. Collette Becomes a Bride
description: Lieut. Cora Jane Collette, a physician in the Naval Medical Corps, was married yesterday to Lieut. Daniel A. Scott, also a Navy physician, in a nondenominational ceremony performed by the Rev. John Kingwood at a naval officers' club in Coronado, Calif.

title: More and Safer Breast X-Rays
description: Breast cancer is the leading cause of death among American women aged 40 to 49. Many doctors, however, have feared that annual X-rays to detect cancers might induce the disease among these women, who would live long enough to suffer from radiation's cumulative effects.

title: AIRPORT HOTEL CONSTRUCTION GROWS AS PROFITABILITY SOARS
description: A MIAMI hotel developer is seeking to build a 300-room Hilton hotel near La Guardia Airport, a proposal that reflects a strong industrywide trend toward construction of large, luxury airport hotels.

title: Musical Feasts
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors;  Striped Bass Stir Dispute
description: OFTEN lost in reports of the struggle between commercial and recreational fishing interests over whether New York State should further restrict the taking of striped bass is the somber truth that the numbers of this highly prized food and game fish have declined alarmingly along the East Coast in the last decade.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWERS THAT COMBAT HEAT AND DROUGHT
description: IT takes a tough perennial to stand up well in the herbaceous border during the summer, yet there are a few that stand out in their ability to withstand heat and drought. Liberal use of these durable plants will assure continuance flowering for all but the most adverse conditions.

title: WHY MUST WOMEN FOLLOW THE 'AND'?
description: IN THE 20 years since the publication of ''The Feminine Mystique'' by Betty Friedan, it would seem that every conceivable affront to the female sex has been detected and dissected.

title: THE TAINT OF QUAINT
description: I was not surprised to discover that Nantucket had suffered a severe outbreak of cobblestones in my absence. The symptoms of an onset were obvious before I left in January when a telltale rash of electrified fake gas street lamps was beginning to spread along the sidewalks.

title: Poorer America
description: The percentage of Americans living in poverty, says the Census Bureau, is the highest in 17 years. The numbers mislead, responds the White House.

title: COLONIAL TOUCH
description: In 1898 Ernest Flagg, the architect of the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., built an estate on Staten Island called Stone Court. For the main house he drew upon Dutch colonial and Caribbean architectural influences, as well as the American colonial tradition.

title: Agency to Resume Benefits For Children of Slain Soldiers
description: The Veterans Administration says it will resume paying survivors' benefits to the dependent children of soldiers who died on active duty or as a result of military service.

title: Laurels Time
description: Televised coronations of sports abound this week. Champions will be crowned in Los Angeles, Indianapolis, Helsinki and Syracuse. The Professional Golfers Association championship at the Riviera Country Club in Los Angeles will be broadcast by ABC today, Sunday, at 3:30 P.M. Also today, the men's finals in the U.S. Open Clay Court Tennis championships at the Indianapolis Sports Center will be telecast on CBS at 1:30 P.M. Through the week, NBC will present a total of 11 hours of the first World Track and Field Championships in Helsinki (coverage ends with three more hours next Sunday), winding up with a decathalon special from 4 to 6 Saturday afternoon.

title: A POPULAR WATERFRONT SPOT
description: WATERFRONT dining has a special appeal in the summer, and it would be hard to find a more serenely pretty spot than a waterside table at Allen's Clam and Lobster House, overlooking Old Mill Pond in Westport.

title: P-Q4 OPENING MOVE GIVES KORCHNOI CHESS VICTORY
description: Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union forfeited a semifinal match in the world chess championships today when he failed to appear for the first game.

title: Hotel Memo
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAPING UP THE WATERFRONT COMMISSION
description: Thirty years ago this week, the Rev. John M. Corridan's ship finally came in. After his long crusade against corruption on the docks, President Eisenhower agreed to create the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: A GUIDE TO RENTAL VACATION PROPERTIES AVAILABLE IN EUROPE
description: IRELAND

title: U.S. PLANNING TO VETO GUYANA DEVELOPMENT LOAN
description: The United States has decided to veto a $40 million loan to Guyana that is under consideration by the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: It's Lonely Being No. 2
description: Playing second fiddle in politics, a difficult task under the best of circumstances, is just about impossible with an instrument that has no strings. The Governor of Louisiana has unstrung his lieutenant, cutting off his and his staff's salaries.

title: THE EMPIRE AND EGO OF DONALD TRUMP
description: HE made his presence known on the island of Manhattan in the mid 70's, a brash Adonis from the outer boroughs bent on placing his imprint on the golden rock. Donald John Trump exhibited a flair for self-promotion, grandiose schemes - and, perhaps not surprisingly, for provoking fury along the way.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Weed and water...Mail bulb orders for fall planting...Keep up with Japanese beetle attacks either by trapping of hand picking. Groundcovers

title: HOW TO SPOT THE TURNAROUND STOCKS
description: IN this age of last-minute debt rescheduling, corporate turnaround artists and Government loan guarantees, it should be no surprise that companies like Chrysler are alive - indeed, are thriving. But who would have thought that Chrysler's stock, written off by analysts as a dog in 1981 after trading as low as $3, would rise from the dead - it closed at $25.50 on Friday - and become one of Wall Street's biggest winners this year?

title: SOME MISSIONS AND OMISSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTO INSURANCE: MORE TALKS SET ON LEGISLATION
description: GOVERNOR KEAN and several legislative leaders felt the pressure of rising expectations last week after their latest meeting on the state's automobile-insurance problems.

title: JEWELERS CHANGE POLICIES ON CREDIT
description: At Tiffany & Company, charge-account customers now have a plastic card to call their own - in Tiffany's distinctive blue. At Harry Winston, in the last three months clients have been able to put their purchases on American Express cards.

title: Weight Lifting's Not Just for Men
description: Michael Cavanaugh's moving tribute to the gyms of yesteryear (''A Salute to Old-Fashioned Gyms,'' July 3) smacks of sexism. Granted, some of the new spas are little more than glorified singles spas, but it is the democratization of the sport of weight lifting to which Mr. Cavanaugh objects.

title: Suzanne Carbery Weds Jonathan Willard Emery
description: Suzanne Carbery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Carbery of Bonner Springs, Kan., was married yesterday to Jonathan Willard Emery, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donovan Emery of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: EVEN GOREN CAN'T BEAT LADY LUCK
description: Many years ago a middle-aged lady at a dinner party thought she could identify another diner and whispered an inquiry to her neighbor: ''Isn't that Charles Goren at the end of the table?''

title: TWO-PRONGED ASSAULT ON AMERICAN HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 16 food outlets last week for violating the health code.

title: Urban High Schools Will Get 1,000 Computers From Xerox
description: The new chairman of the National Urban League says the Xerox Corporation plans to give 1,000 computers to urban high schools with large minority enrollments.

title: Sri Lanka Confirms Report of Army Slayings
description: Sri Lankan Army troops pulled 20 civilians off a bus and executed them two weeks ago in retaliation for a Tamil guerrilla attack that killed 13 soldiers, a Government spokesman confirmed today.

title: Sports News Briefs;  Soviet TV Agreement Reached on Olympics
description: Soviet authorities have reached agreement with the Los Angeles Olympics Organizing Committee on a $3 million deal for television rights to the 1984 Games, the committee president said today.

title: ELSIE T. O'BRIEN AND S.H. AUBREY EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Elsie Talbott O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank O'Brien Jr. of Boston and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Stever Hixon Aubrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stever Aubrey of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. J. Clark Grew, assisted by the Rev. John Greely, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown.

title: THE ROCK COMPETITION STEPS UP A BEAT
description: This summer, the televisaon schedule is reverberating with new rock/video shows, as network, local and cable programmers attempt to exploit the success of MTV, the cable subscriber service that has shaken up both the television and record industries by pioneering an all-rock video format. Even programming executives with no ear for rock music are alert to the jingle of coin, and the enviable growth of MTV has spurred them to try to shape its 24-hour-a-day format into 90-minute or two-hour packages.

title: FROM VIDEO GAMES TO ARMS CONTROL
description: WHEN the social history of our time comes to be written, it is altogether likely that a place in it will be reserved for William A. Higinbotham of Bellport.

title: Chiefs Defeat Bengals, 24 to 7
description: Thomas Howard returned a blocked field-goal attempt 52 yards for a touchdown, and the rookie Phil Bruneau returned a fumble recovery 21 yards for another score tonight as the Kansas City Chiefs defeated the Cincinnati Bengals, 24-7, in an exhibition game.

title: DEAR CHILDREN
description: SINCE you two went off to Camp Empty Purse it has been very quiet here. I miss you a lot and the food is awful. All we get here is adult-type things like barbequed chicken and green salad. Please send me some of your Mr. Goodbars. Make sure you wrap them in a package marked ''Books'' so Daddy won't know I'm cheating on my diet.

title: By SUSAN JACOBY; Susan Jacoby is the author of "Inside Soviet Schools.'' Her ''Wild Justice: The Evolution of Revenge'' will be published this fall.
description: MOSCOW WOMEN Thirteen Interviews. By Carola Hansson and Karin Liden. Translated by Gerry Bothmer, George Blecher and Lone Blecher. Introduction by Gail Warshofsky Lapidus. Illustrated. 194 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: STATE G.O.P. CHIEF IS PRESSING U.S. ON JOB FOR EX-LEGISLATOR
description: George L. Clark Jr., the Republican state chairman, is pressing the White House to appoint James L. Emery, the former minority leader of the Assembly, as administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

title: Traveling Alone
description: When we first became aware of the ''About Men'' column, we assumed it would deal with issues confronted by the contemporary male in our society (''Traveling Alone,'' by Drew Middleton, July 3). However, from the very first article, we have been amazed by the irrelevance and superficiality of the series.

title: PLAYING THE GAME THEY LOVED
description: INVISIBLE MEN Life In Baseball's Negro Leagues. By Donn Rogosin. Introduction by Monte Irvin. Illustrated. 283 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95. BASEBALL'S GREAT EXPERIMENT Jackie Robinson and His Legacy. By Jules Tygiel. Illustrated. 392 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95.

title: VOTE DRIVES UNDER WAY TO REGISTER CITIES' POOR
description: VOLUNTEERS in Connecticut's four largest cities have embarked on campaigns to register thousands of new voters, largely from poor neighborhoods, by the end of summer.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ''PRINCESS DOE'S'' tombstone is already in place in Cedar Ridge Cemetery in Blairstown, specifically in a shady corner overlooking a steep ravine that leads down to Jacksonburg Creek.

title: WHERE THE SOUNDS ARE LIKE A SILENCE
description: WHEN I decided to retire at the age of 57, the announcement brought comments that were unanimous:

title: Synagogue in Johannesburg Is Damaged by an Explosion
description: An explosion damaged a synagogue in Johannesburg early today only hours before President Marais Viljoen was scheduled to attend ceremonies to mark the 50th anniversary of Reform Judaism in South Africa.

title: Political Mileage
description: Chicago yawns at charges that campaign funds have been used to buy votes, but the city took notice last week when it was disclosed that former Mayor Jane M. Byrne had used political money to buy a car. Mrs. Byrne, who was defeated in a re-election bid this year, denied reports that a new Mustang, paid for in part with $4,000 in campaign funds, was for her daughter's personal use.

title: BRIDGE HAS I-95 TRUCKS IN A SLUMP
description: THE mood in the Secondi Truck Stop Diner in Milford was somber. On the juke box, Gene Watson sang ''Farewell Party.'' The few truck drivers there nodded their heads sadly to the music.

title: FOR FUN IN THE SUN, LESSONS ON SAILING ARE OFFERED
description: DURING the hot, humid days of August, what better way is there to spend a weekend than on the sea, learning to sail. Even the occasional capsizing by beginners becomes an excuse to cool off in the water.

title: Freedom to Study
description: To the Business Editor:

title:
MUSIC;
AN UNCONVENTIONAL SOPRANO
description: RED BANKTHALIA VANVAKAS is an opera singer determined to make it to the top, but in her own unconventional way.

title: New Voice in Brink's Case
description: Of the more than 100 witnesses who have testified in the Federal Brink's trial, few seemed more valuable to the prosecution and perhaps none was more surprising to the defense than Sondra Margo Mitchell. Taking the stand last week, she identified three of the six defendants as members of a group that used her Mount Vernon, N.Y., apartment for meetings prior to the 1981 armored- car robbery and other holdups.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: AH! THE CORN OF SUMMER
description: A SPECIAL kernel of Connecticut's summer pleasure has arrived. Fresh corn. Hand- scrawled signs boasting ''It's here! Native corn!'' abound on roadside stands and supermarket bins.

title: No Headline
description: The marriage of Melanie Claire Allewelt and David C. Kwan took place yesterday at St. Dunstan's of Canterbury Episcopal Church in Modesto, Calif. The Rev. John Wilcox performed the ceremony.

title: Seoul Says Spy Ship Was Forced to Flee
description: South Korean military officials, who said Friday that they had sunk a North Korean spy ship, reported today that a second spy vessel escaped during that incident.

title: ON BALANCING FILMMAKING AND NEWS JOURNALISM
description: The documentary is a news form; the documentary is an art form, too. It is also a creature of television. The networks, however, honor documentaries more by applauding them in the abstract than by allowing talented people in their news departments to go out and make them. It is public television that is now, and has been for some time, the documentary's home. No one is keeping an accurate count, but a fair estimate is that public television presents some 100 documentaries each season, which is rather more than the networks combined.

title: Valerie H. Hertz Married to Michael Gerard Boyle
description: Valerie Helen Hertz, daughter of Valerie Ann McCabe and Daniel L. Hertz Jr., both of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Gerard Boyle, son of Mrs. Roy Sokoler of Holmdel, N.J., and Francis G. Boyle. The Rev. Harry Sorenson performed the ceremony at All Saints' Memorial Episcopal Church in Navesink, N.J.

title: WISHES COME TRUE FOR SICK CHILDREN
description: ELIZABETH BOBBY MACALUSO of clifton, a 10-year-old suffering from a rare and incurable muscle disease, and Rocky Johnson, a muscular championship- level wrestler, have something in common. Both are fighters, and they recently met here at the New Jersey headquarters of the Make-a-Wish Foundation.

title: The Major Oil Spills And Well Blowouts
description: Following are some of the major oil spills and oil well blowouts since 1967: July 19, 1979 - The tankers Atlantic Empress and Aegean Captain collide off Tobago, spilling a total of three million barrels. June 3, 1979 - An oil well off Mexico blows out, spilling three million barrels over the next nine months.

title: SOME SHORT CUTS AMIDS ELEGANCE
description: IT was over three years ago that L'Endroit in East Hills moved to its present location. It is still as elegant as ever, the dining room warmly intimate with each table bathed in a pool of light from a small lamp. Mirrored panels visually enlarge the space, lace curtains cover the windows and table settings are tastefully formal.

title: More Heat Than Comfort
description: Few quarreled with Martin S. Feldstein's assessment of the week's last bit of hard economic news. The drop in the unemployment rate in July, to 9.3 percent from 9.8 percent was ''spectacular,'' President Reagan's chief economic adviser said, ''a clear indication that economic activity in the third quarter has gotten off to a very strong start.''

title: NEW STAGE LIFE FOR 'EARNEST'
description: THE John Drew Theater is taking time out from its summertime ''something for everyone'' programming philosophy for what is being called a ''summer theater production,'' Oscar Wilde's ''The Importance of Being Earnest.''

title: RIGHT ATTITUDE ABOUT TENNIS
description: THERE is truly a ''time to every purpose.'' In the summer, my purpose is to make other people feel good about their tennis.

title: Sports News Briefs;  N.C.A.A. Completes Wake Forest Inquiry
description: An official judgment is expected soon from the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which has finished investigating Wake Forest's recruiting of Mark Cline, a basketball player, said Dr. Jack Sawyer, athletic department chairman.

title: Diamond Gains Met Final
description: Mark Diamond of Pine Hollow, and all-American from Rollins College in Florida, defeated John Baldwin of Meadow Brook, 5 and 4, today and gained the final of the Metropolitan Golf Association Amateur championship at Sleepy Hollow.

title: Tambay Holds the Pole For German Grand Prix
description: The Ferrari turbos of the French drivers Patrick Tambay and Rene Arnoux lead the field for Sunday's German Grand Prix, the 10th race of 15 events in the 1983 World Championship.

title: CONFEREES WEIGH WORK WITH GENES
description: The craggy rocks on this island 10 miles off Portsmouth teem with natural life, from the single-celled plankton in the tidal pools to the deep-voiced gulls shrilly warning intruders away from their rookery. Theologians and scientists gathered in this natural setting this week to discuss what some might consider unnatural life: the results of genetic manipulation.

title: SOME EXPERTS WOULD BET THE SOVIET'S STAKE IS SMALL
description: PRESIDENT Reagan has repeatedly spoken of the spread of revolutions in Central America as ultimately inspired and even controlled by the Soviet Union. But to a range of scholars and Administration analysts, the Soviet stake in the region is small - except for the preservation of a Communist regime in Cuba - and Soviet policy is very cautious.

title: U.S. BLACKS' LIFE EXPECTANCY UP SINCE 1900
description: The life expectancy of blacks in the United States has lengthened since 1900, but a Texas researcher says the death rate for black infants is nearly double that for whites.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWERS THAT COMBAT HEAT AND DROUGHT
description: IT takes a tough perennial to stand up well in the herbaceous border during the summer, yet there are a few that stand out in their ability to withstand heat and drought. Liberal use of these durable plants will assure continuance flowering for all but the most adverse conditions.

title: Hugh Taylor Jr. Wed to Carolyn Eaton
description: Carolyn Witsell Eaton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mellon Eaton of New York and Sugar Hill, N.H., was married yesterday to Hugh Gibbs Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor of Cundys Harbor, Me. Canon Charles A. Carter performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Sugar Hill.

title: PHILOSOPHER FINDS THAT PRISONS DO THEIR JOBS
description: MANY profound and philosophical thoughts have come from men in prison - Milton and Cervantes are two examples - but few philosophers put themselves in jail voluntarily.

title: BOOKING THE RIGHT TRAVEL AGENT
description: If you tried to call a major airline or charter operator early this summer, when everybody seemed to be going somewhere, you probably found one strong reason to use a travel agent: Chances are the airline put you on seemingly interminable hold, if you reached the reservations number at all. So, you might have asked, why not let an agent do the inquiring and booking?

title: THE OTHER FIRE ISLAND: A PLACE FROZEN IN TIME
description: THERE are no skunks in Skunk Hollow; there is neither a whale house nor a point at Whalehouse Point; the inlet at Old Inlet closed up and drifted over long before the Civil War. These places, whose names evoke a feeling of history, are still marked on some maps of Long Island, but, like the past that they belong to, they lie beyond the boundaries of roads and bridges, of sidewalks and bicycle paths.

title: LARCHMONT BUSINESSES POLLED ON CRIME
description: FOR the second time in three years, the Larchmont Chamber of Commerce is conducting a survey among more than 500 businesses and professionals in the village of Larchmont and the surrounding town of Mamaroneck to determine the scope and effects of what it perceives as a wave of vandalism, burglary and robberies.

title: Tracy Newman Weds in Virginia
description: Tracy Stewart Newman, daughter of Mrs. Carson Boru Newman of Falls Church, Va., and the late Mr. Newman, was married yesterday to Ricardo A. Mestres 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mestres Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York performed the ceremony at Green Spring Farm in Alexandria, Va.

title: WORLD CHURCH BODY: DISPLAY OF UNITY
description: The supreme governing body of the World Council of Churches has been meeting here in an outward display of unity despite growing debate about some of its programs.

title: CASINO ASSOCIATION WEIGHS NEW ROLE
description: HOBBLED by sharp internal differences and mounting competition for gambling dollars, the Atlantic City Casino Hotel Association is expected to vote before the end of the month to curtail its activities.

title: On 'Red Carpet'
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NIGERIA VOTING IS CALM BUY MARRED BY DELAYS
description: Millions of Nigerians voted today in the second presidential election held here since military rule ended four years ago. Despite widespread fears of violence, the voting appeared to be proceeding peacefully.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN VANCOUVER
description: Earlier this summer, the local satraps officially opened Canada's first and only domed stadium with full fanfare and hoopla, and now, while the squeaky clean and relaxed young guides lead three daily tours of the bubble-top ball field, rumors are being carefully positioned that Vancouver is ready to snare a major- league baseball franchise. Whatever the details may be, there can be no doubt that this city, once nicknamed the Village-on-the-Edge-of-the-Rain- Forest, is undergoing a period of self- assertive ascendancy and is staking its claim to major-league status in terms of tourism, conventions and relaxed hedonism.

title: PIONEERING A NEW DIRECTION
description: The association of Halston and J.C. Penney is likely to alter their images.

title: U.S. REPORTS SLIGHT ABATEMENT OF SOIL EROSION
description: Soil erosion has abated slightly over the last five years while the amount of land used for growing crops or raising livestock remained about the same, according to Federal figures.

title: Monique Van Vooren Admits Lying to Jury
description: The actress Monique Van Vooren has pleaded guilty to lying to a Federal grand jury investigating charges that she stole more than $18,000 in Social Security payments from her dead mother's bank account, Federal prosecutors said yesterday. Miss Van Vooren has agreed to repay the Government, the prosecutors said.

title: More Power to Grumman, More Jobs for L.I.
description: It isn't necessary to move to the Sun Belt if the New York Power Authority takes a shine to you. The agency last week agreed to provide low-cost electricity to the Grumman Corporation, which promptly halted talk of expanding elsewhere and said it would go ahead with a $30 million addition to its Bethpage, L.I., plant, creating 1,000 new jobs.

title: Kathleen Lyons Marries John Wallace
description: Kathleen Mary Lyons, daughter of Dr. Kathleen Hausmann Lyons of Litchfield, Conn., and Dr. William B. Lyons of Southbury, Conn., was married in Litchfield yesterday to John James Wallace, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward F. Wallace Jr., also of Litchfield. The Rev. George Burnett and the Rev. Stanley Kwasnik performed the ceremony at the St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church.

title: A BID TO TAKE BIG OIL'S STATIONS AWAY
description: With profit margins perilously thin at the pump and hundreds of stations being forced out of business each month, a high-stakes battle is being waged between the major oil companies and the thousands of small businessmen who operate - and generally own - independent service stations.

title: Hawaii
description: To the Editor:

title: Rome
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: A SAXOPHONE QUINTET
description: Lately, instrumentalists have been ganging up all around the city. There is a group of tubas (Gravity), an all- percussion group (M'Boom) and a group of clarinets (Licorice Factory).

title: ON 'RED CARPET'
description: To the Business Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Cornelia Parsons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Parsons of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Edward Thornburgh of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wesley Thornburgh of Cincinnati. The Rev. Robert Greene performed the ceremony at the Norfield Congregational Church in Weston, Conn.

title: KOREN'S AFFABLE 'THINGS' AT THE HUDSON
description: THE fluffy pen-and-ink drawing shows a large, amorphous lump. Animal, vegetable or mineral, it could have been carved or modeled or merely found somewhere; to the artist-historian Daniel Robbins (who may have inside information), it is a burning bush. But whatever the medium, the thing is most definitely an art object. You can tell not only from the pedestal it stands on, in a park, but also from the kind of people hanging out at its base. They wear the pointedly unpretentious clothes and serene expressions that so often mark the esthetically aware.

title: BOTHA'S ATTEMPT TO DILUTE WHITE RULE MAY END HIS
description: The show was billed initially as ''Healthy Power Sharing.'' According to the script prepared by Prime Minister P.W. Botha, it would astonish the world and achieve a catharsis of interracial understanding in South Africa without disturbing existing power relationships in any fundamental way.

title: Embarassment of Niches
description: While Governor Cuomo was busy pushing state workers off the payroll, he seems not to have noticed how many were jumping voluntarily. Too many, Mr. Cuomo's aides conceded last week, adding that ''Help Wanted'' signs would soon be sprouting in a capital where ''the largest reduction in the state's workforce in history'' had just ended.

title: SLOW TRAIN TO JERUSALEM
description: The well-versed traveler to the Holy Land is familiar with the legendary Israeli, his qualities and his roadside manners. Intense, in a rush, he speeds, tailgates, beeps and passes on the four-lane Tel Aviv-Jerusalem highway, the scene of horrific car accidents every week.

title: Expos 7, Pirates 3
description: Andre Dawson's two home runs backed the six-hit pitching of Bryn Smith as Montreal won their third straight game. It was the Pirates' third consecutive loss.

title: U.S. SENDING AWACS AND F-15 FIGHTERS TO SUPPORT CHAD
description: The United States announced today that two Awacs electronic surveillance planes, F-15 fighter escorts, aerial tankers and other reconnaissance planes had been dispatched to support Chad against Libyan-backed rebel forces.

title: COLLEGES GET A TV PARTNER
description: STARTING next month, cable television subscribers in Hartford and northwest Connecticut will be able to take college-credit courses in their living rooms, through a new cable television network formed by the Board of Trustees of Regional Community Colleges. It is called the Community College Instructional Television network, and its motto is: Where the People of Connecticut Turn to Learn.

title: Churchill
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAIN THAT MAY FEED MORE THAN SOVIET MOUTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VAUDEVILLIANS ARE SERIOUS ABOUT THEIR CLOWNING
description: It's been over a decade since Stephen Sondheim first wondered where the clowns were, but they are, finally, here - and in droves.

title: Bears 27, Bills 17
description: Vince Evans, a reserve quarterback, engineered two third-quarter touchdowns for Chicago. Evans, used only in the third quarter, completed 5 of 7 passes for 99 yards to set up touchdown runs of 9 yards by Matt Suhey and 1 yard by Dennis Gentry.

title: Miss Adams Plans to Wed Mark Foster
description: Mrs. Madsen Adams of New York and Warren Sanford Adams 2d of Coral Gables, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cornelia Madsen Adams, to Mark Edward Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Foster of Whitesboro, Tex. An Oct. 22 wedding in New York is planned.

title: A COOPERATIVE EFFORT FOR ILL CHILD
description: THE story of Karina Dominguez, an infant who may need a liver transplant, began earlier this year in her native Uruguay. By June, however, concern for her plight had spread - first to Connecticut, then to Westchester and New Jersey. Scores of people, largely drawn from Latin American communities in the three states, have donated time, money and goods, hoping to bring about what many call ''un milagro'' - a miracle.

title: Malfunction of Device Shuts Indian Pt. Plant
description: A malfunction in a warning device caused the Indian Point nuclear generator of Consolidated Edison Company to automatically shut down for more than seven hours today, a Con Ed spokesman said.

title: Orioles Defeated By White Sox, 6-4
description: Floyd Bannister allowed five hits in seven innings and posted his sixth consecutive victory as the Chicago White Sox posted a 6-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

title: Great Divide In Yonkers
description: The Saw Mill River Parkway divides Yonkers demographically as well as geographically. Black and Hispanic residents mostly live to its west, whites to its east.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: EVERY summer, little and big monsters emerge from local playgrounds to attend the Monster Convention at the Bergen Mall in Paramus.

title: L.I. YACHT RACE YIELDS ADVENTURE
description: TEN days ago, 174 yachts left Great Kills Harbor on Staten Island in a race around Long Island that would end 198 miles later in Hempstead Harbor.

title: SATELLITE-COMMUNICATIONS CENTER SEEKS CUSTOMERS IN NEW JERSEY
description: ALTHOUGH formal agreements with customers have not been signed, the partners of the Teleport, a $225 million satellite-communications center that will be constructed on Staten Island, are busy lining up commercial users in New Jersey.

title: NEED FOR LAWYERS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynthia Jacoby, a Teacher, Marries Paul E. Matthews
description: At St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J., yesterday Cynthia Marie Jacoby and Paul Edward Matthews, graduates of New England College, were married by the Rev. Edward F. Kavin.

title: PRIESTS AT HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: For the last month, the Rev. Brian Ettlinger has led the worship for parishioners of St. Mary the Virgin Episcopal Church here in an American setting unusually familiar to the 55-year-old British clergyman. The gothic church set on a hill above the Chappaqua library is a smaller replica of the parish he serves in Monken Hadley, a town north of London.

title: Article 079579 -- No Title
description: THE Board of Legislators last week began to consider requests by the county government to issue $55,690,500 in bonds to pay for 48 projects, including the purchase and installation of a noise-monitoring system at the County Airport.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWERS THAT COMBAT HEAT AND DROUGHT
description: IT takes a tough perennial to stand up well in the herbaceous border during the summer, yet there are a few that stand out in their ability to withstand heat and drought. Liberal use of these durable plants will assure continuance flowering for all but the most adverse conditions.

title: Miss Weinschreider Weds A. J. Rudel
description: Kristy Weinschreider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Weinschreider Jr. of Hinsdale, Ill., and Rockport, Mass., was married yesterday to Anthony Jason Rudel, son of Julius Rudel and Dr. Rita G. Rudel of New York. Justice Barry Salman of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

title: Public Radio Listeners Pledge $2 Million in Aid
description: The financially troubled National Public Radio announced today that its listeners had pledged more than $2.15 million in a three-day on-air solicitation in the past week. Of the total, $800,000 will go directly to the network and the balance to stations that have pledged $4.8 million to prevent the network from going bankrupt.

title: Lori Rizzo Is Married
description: Lori Rizzo and Dr. Joel Vinikoor were married yesterday at the Manor in West Orange, N.J., in a nondenominational ceremony performed by the Rev. Robert F. Streetman, minister of the Waterloo, N.J., United Methodist Church. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rizzo Jr. of Fair Lawn, N.J., is a graduate of Rutgers University and a fourth-year student at the New York College of Podiatric Medicine. Her husband, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Vinikoor of St. Petersburg, Fla., graduated from the Ohio College of Podiatric Medicine.

title: AN ITALIAN CONCERN CHARTS UNKNOWN OPERATIC TERRITORY
description: To the typical music history student of 25 years ago, Romantic Italian opera meant a brief discussion of Giuseppe Verdi with a nod in the direction of three predecessors and a sole heir. Nowadays, thanks to the bel canto revival and to musicology's stately forward march through the centuries, we are on much more familiar terms with Rossini, Bellini and Donizetti - but for most operagoers, large stretches of Italian history remain terra incognita. Who preceded the predecessors? Did Verdi have any competition in midcentury? What became of the inheritance when the heir, Giacomo Puccini, died in 1924?

title: DANCE
description: There is so much dance going on in New York that it's easy to forget there are people dancing around the rest of the country, too. But for six years now the adventurous little Dance Theater Workshop has been doing New York dancegoers' exploring for them in a summer series called the ''Out-of-Towners.''

title: Drug Testing Announced
description: The International Olympic Committee today asked track and field officials to be more severe in disciplining athletes caught forbidden drugs.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: GRENADIANS ANXIOUS OVER NEW INFLUENCE OF SOVIET AND CUBA
description: Public support for the Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, who seized power in a coup four years ago, is diminishing rapidly as Cuban and Soviet influence here grows, according to many Grenadians.

title: John K. Conway Wed To Patricia A. Joseffer
description: Patricia Ann Joseffer and John Kevin Conway were married yesterday at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in North Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Salvatore Fiore performed the ceremony.

title: REAGAN EMPHASIZES 'GOOD NEWS' IN TALK ON ECONOMIC DATA
description: President Reagan said today that the sharp decline in unemployment in July, combined with other economic developments, indicate ''things are looking up for America.''

title: ROCK-AND-ROLL: SET BY B-52'S AT THE FOREST HILLS STADIUM
description: In ''Song for a Future Generation'' - an amusing evocation of the current baby boom on their new album, ''Whammy!'' - the B-52's reel off such familiar media images of glamorous people as ''The Empress of Fashion'' and ''The Captain of the Enterprise,'' as they conjure up a goofy series of mythic couples meeting to populate the future. The song is all in good fun, but it also carries an edge of seriousness.

title: FAMILY THAT CIRCUMNAVIGATES TOGETHER
description: ''IT'S a dream trip,'' said Mary Ann Baker, as she sat with her husband, Norman, in the yard of their New Rochelle home and discussed plans to circumnavigate the globe on a wooden sailing ship, the Anne Kristine. The ship, which the Bakers recently purchased, was built in Norway in 1869.

title: ZIMBABWE IMPOSES PRESS CURBS
description: Zimbabwe has imposed strict controls, including censorship, on news coverage of antiterrorist operations.

title: REID IN NEW THRUST IN EXECUTIVE RACE
description: FORMER Representative Ogden R. Reid, the Westchester Democrat who is seeking the post of County Executive, stepped up his election effort last week by opening campaign offices in White Plains and Yonkers, increasing personal appearances and beginning a broad attack against the Republican incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: Mailbox; Tennis Balls In Schoolyards
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Changes Are Bringing Order From Rams' Chaos
description: Like so many other interested but distant followers of the Los Angeles Rams in recent years, John Robinson found a certain amusement in their daily exploits.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: In the Craft World, Christmas Is Now Jay's Yarns, a business begun 48 years ago in Yonkers that moved to Hartsdale after a fire, reopened in Yonkers across from the Post Office on South Broadway in 1977. But the Hartsdale location offers by far the larger selection of materials for knitting, crocheting, needlepoint or tapestry, crewel embroidery, latch hooking for rugs, candle wicking, string art and holiday-gift preparation, with finished samples of each craft displayed for inspiration and for sale to anyone in a hurry.

title: WASTE NOT, WANT NOT
description: THIS is your television eyewitness reporter. Your name, please?

title: Texan Sues to Bar Magazine From Publishing His Wealth
description: A Texas industrialist is suing Forbes magazine to keep it from saying how rich he is as part of its annual list of the 400 richest people in America.

title: Retouching a Master's Work
description: It is hard to tell from the color reproductions just what interior designer Linda Holtzschue ''loaded'' this Frank Lloyd Wright house with (''Retouching a Master's Work,'' by Veronica McNiff, June 26). Veronica McNiff writes of its ''monochromatic hues,'' ''honey pale'' in color.

title: Bergman's ''Fanny And Alexander''
description: In her article ''Ingmar Bergman: Summing Up a Life in Film,'' (June 26), Michiko Kakutani seems to have missed the rather complicated political-religious parable in Bergman's ''dream play,'' ''Fanny and Alexander.''

title: THE NATION'S GOVERNORS CONVENE, COMPLAIN AND CONSPIRE
description: For three days last week in the old port city of Portland, Me., the nation's governors spoke with a sense of unity and urgency about the dominant issue on their agenda: concern that Federal budget deficits will choke off the economic recovery and bring a new round of fiscal troubles to the states.

title: HOBOKEN PRESSES HOUSING REHABILITATION
description: BY most accounts, Hoboken's brownstone revival has been a runaway success that transformed what was a grimy city on the Hudson River into a chic urban colony of artists, musicians and young professionals.

title: Chavez Joins Marchers In Boycott of Campbell
description: Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers, today joined about 100 migrant farm workers who are on the last segment of a monthlong walk through Ohio and Pennsylvania symbolizing their demands for better pay and working conditions from the Campbell Soup Company.

title: LIFE IN THE NORTH WOODS: HILLBILLIES AND HYPERBOLE AMID THE RED PINES
description: Those who live in this neck of the woods, where wood is the only major product besides babies, sometimes refer to strangers as ''Flatlanders.'' The term is puzzling in view of the local topography, which is as flat as a beaver's tail.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: DAYLILY FESTIVAL

title: WHEN FIGURE PAINTINGS CAPTURE THE ENERGIES OF LIFE
description: Not so long ago ''figure painting'' meant pictures of people doing nothing in particular. They stood around, sat around, lolled around. Dressed or undressed, they showed no feeling. Tantrums were out. So were displays of authority. Even sneezing was out. Their job was to keep still while the painter got on with his work.

title: A.T.& T. IS STRUCK BY THREE UNIONS
description: Three unions struck the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today after negotiations failed to reach agreement on a new contract before the current one expired at 12:01 A.M.

title: BRITISH LABORITES FIND UNITY ELUSIVE
description: Two months after their defeat in the general election, and two months before they meet in Brighton to choose a new leader, there are signs that the ranking figures in Britain's Labor Party are finding unity as elusive a goal as it was during the election campaign.

title: HOW TO APPRECIATE THE INSECT WORLD
description: Behind every green thumb is a keen eye. Developing it to observe insects provides a never ending challenge in which skill always lags behind aspiration.

title: A New Team Makes a Try In Middle East
description: A new American team tried its hand at solving Middle East problems last week, and quickly learned at first hand how frustrating and violence-ridden the region can be. Taking up where Philip C. Habib left off, special envoy Robert C. McFarlane tried to extract from the Israelis a timetable for withdrawal from Lebanon that he could take to the Syrians.

title: THE LUCK OF THE DRAW
description: THE FIRST THING TO BE said in poker's behalf is that it is absolutely unedifying; it is not intellectually stimulating or morally uplifting. For regular groups like mine and, I imagine, for others across this poker-infatuated land, the game exists on a sphere of its own, rooted in a time before career obligations and responsibilities to love ones ruled our lives. When the seven of us meet on the first Thursday of the month, it is determinedly away from family and job. In our game, it is an offense to bring up an extreneous subject such asillness or divorce or unemployment while the cards are ont he table.

title: IN WAKE OF BUDGET, YONKERS PREPARES FOR PRIMARY VOTE
description: WITH a struggle over the city's budget finally resolved, Yonkers politicians have turned their attention to the fall elections, which one Councilman described last week as the ''most confusing in quite some time.''

title: NEW U.S. JUDGE TAKES BENCH
description: WHILE Peter C. Dorsey was a student at Yale University, he drove trucks for his father's trucking company in New London. Mr. Dorsey, who was sworn in July 29 as a United States District Court judge serving the Hartford area, now will be bringing a touch of the rough- hewn truck driver to the bench.

title: ROBERT CREELEY'S CONTINUUM
description: THE COLLECTED POEMS, 1945-75. By Robert Creeley. 671 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $28.50.

title: Ready, Aim, Negotiate
description: If you are confused about the Reagan Administration's approach to Central America, the news of the last two weeks is excuse enough. What was billed as strictly routine - sending battle fleets and staging massive maneuvers - is now said to have been calculated, peaceful therapy. And, Secretary of State Shultz says, ''It is showing results.''

title: Inescapable Taxes
description: Four years ago, when he was 12 years old, Jody Gerard was responsible for reforming New York State's sales tax law. He was selling worms to fishermen at his home in Eddyville in Ulster County when the State Tax Department found out about it and required him to pay it 64 cents in sales taxes.

title: Theresa M. Grace Weds Richard Sears
description: At St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Northeast Harbor, Me., Theresa Mary Grace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Peter Grace of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Michael Sears, son of Jacqueline M. Sears of Concord, Mass., and the late John Sears. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur McCormack.

title: TRAVELING AND SEEKING
description: A JOURNEY IN LADAKH By Andrew Harvey. 236 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After consultation with other concerned governments, including the French, we have moved some of our aircraft to where they could be most useful in monitoring the situation in Chad.'' - Joseph Reap, a State Department spokesman. (1:6.)

title: Views of Sport;  How Baseball Became Unstuck by a Rules Dispute
description: TO my recollection, no single regular-season incident in baseball history has captured so much attention as did that of George Brett and his pine-tarred bat. Popular sentiment was certainly on Brett's side. It rubbed the American spirit of common sense and fair play the wrong way when four umpires ruled that one of America's favorite players should be deprived of a pivotal home run in a crucial game situation.

title: 2d Swim Record To Carey
description: Rick Carey of Mount Kisco, N.Y., broke his second world record in four days and then cheered Matt Gribble during another record performance at the United States Long Course Swimming Championships today.

title: Chain Snatcher Kills Rockland Teen-Ager
description: A Rockland County teen-ager on a date in Manhattan was stabbed and killed early yesterday by a mugger who had stolen the youth's gold neck chain, the police said.

title: Edythe Sanchez Becomes a Bride
description: Edythe Aurora Sanchez, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rafael Sanchez- Ubeda of Englewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Kurt Saylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Saylor of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Charles Dolan assisted by the Rev. Patrick Gleeson performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church.

title: COURT ALLOWS A SELF-INCRIMINATING STATEMENT
description: In the latest turn in a protracted murder prosecution, a state appeals court has ruled that a defendant's incriminating statement to the police can be used against him when he is tried in the 1980 killing of a high school student in Queens.

title: Soviet Retains the Title In Modern Pentathlon
description: The Soviet Union retained the modern pentathlon world title today, with Hungary second and France third.

title: INTERVIEW EXCERPTS
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Prime Minister Maurice Bishop:

title: CONSUMER RATES
He's Out!
description: No baseball player's argument with an umpire was ever more futile than Bowie Kuhn's hope that major league owners would reverse their decision last November to let his contract as commissioner expire this week.

title: THE TREES OF WARSAW
description: WHEN I RETURNED TO Warsaw, I saw the trees in leaf. I stared at them in wonderment and could not take them in. For when I was writing in Warsaw, I never saw the trees.

title: Sarah Peck Wed To D.B. Wofford
description: Sarah Emily Peck, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Peck of Mahwah, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Bigelow Wofford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris L. Wofford Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Rabbi Abraham Krantz and the Rev. Phyllis Taylor Wofford, a Congregational minister and the bridegroom's grandmother, performed the ceremony at Skylands Manor in Ringwood, N.J.

title: MINIMALLY MINIMAL
description: THE MINIMAL STYLE OF INTERIOR design may look like simplicity itself, but the process of achieving it is an old-fashioned structure is often nothing short of baroque. For every wall torn down, ther are gaps in flooring that must be filled, as well as electrical wiring and plumbing lines that may have to be rerouted at great bother and expense. Still, such pains are routinely taken by modernists in their quest for clean, open space.

title: P.L.O. Central Council Rallies Behind Arafat
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization's central council, rallying behind Yasir Arafat, the group's chairman, expressed ''regret and great pain'' today over his expulsion from Syria in June.

title: Money Belts
description: To the Editor:

title: FESTIVALS ENDING
description: NOW that August has arrived, the county's four big summer festivals are concluding their seasons. Last night, in fact, was the end of the musical festivities at Lyndhurst. Today marks the end of the fourth Summerfare at the State University of New York at Purchase, and it is quite a full finale.

title: HOW TO HANDLE HEATED AIR TO HELP KEEP THE HOUSE COOL
description: THE summer heat has caused a lot of homeowners to think about what they can do to help keep the house cooler during the day - aside from buying more air-conditioners and letting them run longer. Fortunately, there are a number of other, much less expensive, steps the homeowner can take to help ''heatproof'' the house; that is, to help keep the heat outside and thus keep the inside cooler.

title: Mailbox; Spaldeen Games Beyond Stickball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: OUT FOR BIG STAKES

title: Miss Lock Gains 3-Shot Lead on 68
description: Jane Lock completed a bogey-free round of 68 with a 12-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to grab a three-shot lead after three rounds of the $175,000 Boston Five Classic golf tournament.

title: Weinberger Promises to Aid Women's Rights in the Army
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has pledged in a letter to assure that women in the Army are not barred from promotion though they are excluded from combat-related jobs.

title: N.F.L. Is a Hit With British
description: American professional football, and everything convivial that goes with it, from cheerleaders to pregame tailgate parties, was welcomed to Europe tonight as the Minnesota Vikings met the St. Louis Cardinals in an exhibition game at Wembley Stadium, the hallowed home of championship soccer.

title: AFTER INVADING NICARAGUA
description: The current debate on Central America has surfaced a school of thought that favors a full- scale invasion of Nicaragua by tens of thousands of United States troops, if that is what it takes to overthrow the leftist Sandinista regime. Let us imagine that this view prevails and that, in the months to come, the United States does launch an open military invasion of Nicaragua. What then?

title: BOLT OF LIGHTNING KILLS 2 SHELTERED UNDER TREES IN FLUSHING MEADOWS
description: Two Bronx men were killed and a third man and his 8-year-old son were injured yesterday afternoon when they were struck by lightning in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The United States tried to stop the appreciation of the dollar by intervening on foreign currency markets for the first time since last October. But the efforts were in vain. The Federal Reserve, which began selling dollars and buying West German marks nine days ago, was later joined by the central banks of Germany, Japan, France and Switzerland. The intervention lasted through last week and is expected to continue. Analysts estimate that more than $2 billion was poured into the market to depress the dollar. Nevertheless, the dollar continued its surge, closing at a nine- year high against the mark. The move represented a yielding of the Treasury to pressure from the State Department and the Federal Reserve and was essentially a political gesture to America's trading partners. The Fed may have locked itself in. Since the dollar continued to soar desite heavy selling, imagine what might happen if the Fed suddenly halted its intervention.

title: SUMMER BASKETBALL GAINS
description: MORE often than not this summer the ''winter game'' outdraws the ''summer game'' at Scalzi Park in Stamford, even though the baseball fields far outnumber the outdoor basketball courts.

title: RELIVING THE LOESSER LEGEND
description: ON Aug. 20, 1947, during the first season of Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theater in Westport, a musical revue, ''No Casting Today,'' was being tried out. In it, a diminutive newcomer performed ''The Understudy's Prayer.''

title: HAMLET FIGHTS U.S. TO KEEP POST OFFICE
description: ''WHERE'S the coffee?'' asked Ruth Hardy, entering the one-room post office in the Windsorville hamlet of East Windsor.

title:
ANTIQUES;
CASE HISTORY OF A RESTORED VILLAGE
description: CAPE MAYTHIS city at the southern tip of the state has long been known not only as a summer resort, but also for its impressive Victorian mansions edged with gingerbread.

title: FROM HARRY TO BESS
description: DEAR BESS, The Letters From Harry to Bess Truman, 1910-1959. Edited by Robert H. Ferrell. Illustrated. 593 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $19.95.

title:
STAMPS;
FLOWERS AND BIRDS DISPLAYED BY MANY NATIONS
description: On stamps, as in nature, flowers are in full bloom. Some of the fullest blooms are seen on a set of four commemoratives from Great Britain which celebrate four centuries of English gardens.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN''AROUND summer,'' Leroy said in February, glancing at our wall calendar, ''I'll be taking another look at her for you, and, er, you ought to get some money together by then.''

title: STUDY OF POPULATION FINDS OLDER, POORER PHILADELPHIA
description: When Samuel Marino retired three months ago, he discovered how groundless one of his worst fears had been. There was much more to do than sit with Queenie, his 18-year-old dog, on the marble steps of his red-brick row house in South Philadelphia.

title: UNDER-THE-TABLE TENNIS
description: SHORT CIRCUIT, By Michael Mewshaw. 306 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95. THE real mark of a muckraking journalist's success is having his work lead to changes in the system he exposed. Michael Mewshaw is no Lincoln Steffens or Seymour Hersh, and corruption in professional tennis is hardly as consequential as corruption in city government or duplicity in foreign policy. But it is unlikely that very many investigative reporters ever saw their writing spawn changes as swiftly as Mr. Mewshaw has.

title: Mailbox; MacPhail Hailed For Brett Ruling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: REAPING THE BIG PROFITS FROM A FAT CAT
description: IT'S not rags to riches. His father was an insurance broker in Patterson, N.J., and his grandfather made a comfortable fortune in textiles, until the Depression wiped most of it out.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Is it possible to make a Neo-Expressionist photograph? Georges Rousse, a young French artist currently living in New York, gives it a go in an exhibition at the Zabriskie Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue. Mr. Rousse's large (4-by-5-foot) color pictures record the ''additions'' he has made to the inside walls of derelict buildings - primitive, mosaic-like paintings in which lurk huge and slightly ominous figures. Each painting consists of thousands of small patches, each of which bears a number; the effect is much like a child's coloring book.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: ''HELLO, my name is Dan, and I am a recovering workaholic,'' reads the first line of a letter announcing a self-help group formed a few months ago. The similarity to a phrase well-known at meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous is no coincidence; the founder of the new group contends that compulsive working is not that different from compulsive drinking, compulsive gambling or compulsive overeating.

title: Miss Lavelle Indicted Again
description: Last month a jury found sympathy for Rita Lavelle's failure to show up at a House of Representatives hearing in March, judging her not guilty of contempt of Congress. Now the former ''Superfund'' manager at the Environmental Protection Agency may get a chance to see whether a jury will be less sympathetic if it determines that when she did show up, she lied.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS An Intimate Biography. By Dakin Williams and Shepherd Mead. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Arbor House. $16.95.

title: NEW PLAN SET FOR BRIDGEPORT WATERFRONT
description: AN ambitious plan to rebuild a 135-acre section of the vast rundown waterfront area of Bridgeport was made known last week by Mayor Leonard S. Paoletta and a group of participating developers, planners and builders.

title: ABUSE OF THE AGED LARGELY UNREPORTED
description: A MIDDLE-AGED MAN in Bergen County locked his mother in the house every day before going to work to ''protect her.''

title:
SPIRITS;
GIN: A SUMMERTIME TONIC
description: The martini, along with gin's appeal as a mixer, has made

title: 104 Missing After Boat Sinks Off Indonesia
description: An overloaded passenger boat sprang a leak and sank in the Java Sea, and 104 people were reported missing, authorities said today.

title: LAW FOR RETARDED GETS MIXED RATING
description: A RECENTLY revised state law on the rights of mentally retarded people has been hailed as enlightened and comprehensive, but it has also caused some worries for families of the retarded and problems for staff at state facilities for the retarded.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 127 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 119 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. Tied with ''The Name of the Rose.'' 3321

title: The Fairness Doctrine
description: In his article, ''Reassessing the Fairness Doctrine'' (June 19), Judge Irving R. Kaufman eloquently rebuts the usual arguments given for imposing a Government ''fairness doctrine'' on broadcast journalism.

title: JAPAN OBSERVED
description: THE JAPANESE MIND The Goliath Explained. By Robert C. Christopher. 352 pp. New York. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $16.95. ENCOUNTER WITH JAPAN By Herbert Passin. 193 pp. New York: Kodansha International/Harper & Row. $15.

title: Down and Out And Reagan
description: In Washington last week, there was much parsing of the causes of poverty and much predicting of the effects of policy and the economy on the the number of Americans officially classified as poor. The numbers in an annual Census Bureau survey spoke for themselves.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The Second Sex in Sales

title: A COVENANT SNAGS CONVERSION
description: An all-but-forgotten covenant setting restrictions on housing built under New York City's postwar slum-clearance program has thrown three Manhattan apartment buildings in various stages of conversion into uncertainty.

title: Topics; At Death's Door; Help For Hospices
description: For most Americans, the facts of living are a family, friends and familiar sights and sounds. But the facts of dying are a strange room, and people whose sole role in life is to try to delay its ending.

title: Duenna Takes the Hambletonian
description: Stanley Dancer today drove the filly Duenna to victory in the 58th Hambletonian Trot, a race he had expected to watch from the stands at the Meadowlands.

title: WHERE THE FRENCH DINE IN LONDON
description: The French go arrogantly to Spain, hardly to Germany, and with a trace of trepidation to England. If maps were Rorschach tests, the Gallic brain, fixing on Spain, would probably respond: noise-cheap-hot. Germany gets treated, personally if not politically, rather like Saul Steinberg's notion of what lies west of the Hudson River; a Parisian woman who was asked at dinner a while ago if she had ever been there replied, ''Why?'' But England, the English, London, make the French nervous. The place is self-possessed, the people not easily dazzled. No amount of posing or feigned superiority move it, and the French, who often expect the world to shield its eyes from their brilliance, are thrown off in advance, knowing that the English won't blink. Since the French are basically most comfortable at embracing countries they think they have discovered, or where they suppose they are greatly admired, another approach is required.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: IT'S A JINGLE OUT THERE

title: COMPUTERS AND TEACHERS CROSS WIRES
description: When Newark schools began researching computer purchases a few years ago, their leaders didn't know where to go. ''We had no guidance on how to best spend our dollars,'' said Joe Harris, a chief administrator in a district of 57,000 mostly poor, black children. ''What we did have was an assistant superintendent, who didn't know much about it, buy a couple of computers.''

title: Another Sphere, Another Show of U.S. Force
description: The thousands of miles that separate Chad from Central America were bridged last week by the Reagan Administration's resort to military means to ward off threats. In the desertic African state, the threat was seen as coming from an old Administration nemesis, Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who, despite his denials, was reported to be once again trying to extend his power southward by sending warplanes and armor to back a rebel force fighting to overthrow the pro-Western President, Hissen Habre.

title: MIDWIVES SEEK DELIVERY FROM DISCRIMINATION
description: Susan Sizemore and Victoria Henderson, two certified nurse-midwives who had attended about 500 births in Nashville General Hospital, decided that 1980 was the year to set out on their own. They wanted to continue collaborating with obstetricians in hospitals, but they also wanted the flexibility and financial independence of a private practice.

title: LEBANON'S ARMY WORKING INTO SHAPE
description: For the past year the Lebanese Army has been quietly building its strength almost unbeknown to the Lebanese people. Training in empty lots and sandpits, carrying out live fire exercises in secluded mountain valleys and unobtrusively recruiting teen-agers from the country's former militias, the army has managed to double its effective manpower in 12 months and now tops 33,000 men. ''I don't think many Lebanese realize just how big their army has become,'' remarked Col. Arthur T. Fintel, the American officer helping to supervise the modernization program. ''They have been so successful in recruiting that they are bringing in men faster than we can train and equip them.''

title: PLANS UNDER WAY FOR 2 NEW ARMORIES
description: THE county will have two modern armories by late 1986 instead of one 65-year-old fortress-like building in Yonkers, and it will have three times as many National Guardsmen as it does now, some of them Manhattan residents who will come to Westchester as ''weekend warriors.''

title: LEGAL AID MEASURE TO HELP DISABLED
description: Poor and disabled New Yorkers whose Federal benefits were terminated will be given legal representation to fight for restoration of the aid under a bill signed by Governor Cuomo, the Governor's office said today.

title: Mets Win on Rookie Pitcher's 2 Homers
description: With a two-run homer in the third inning and another in the fourth, Walt Terrell today became the first pitcher to hit two home runs in a game for the Mets, who beat the Chicago Cubs, 4-1.

title: Mary A. Nastuk, M. J. Zackin Wed
description: Mary Alden Nastuk, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Nastuk of Tenafly, N.J., and Northport, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Jon Zackin, son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Jerome Zackin of Marblehead, Mass. Judge Yale L. Apter of the Essex County Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court performed the ceremony at the Englewood Club.

title: Peek at the Books
description: To the Business Editor:

title: KOCH PLANS BID TO TURN DEMOCRATS FROM 'LEFT'
description: Mayor Koch says he is planning a series of speeches around the country in the coming months to try to turn the Democratic Party away from ''left wing'' special-interest groups and toward the concerns of the middle class.

title: THE 'GOLDEN YEARS' CAN BE TARNISHED ONES
description: ''WHAT I resent is being on the edge of old age, and suddenly the curtain is coming down and I'm stuck with caring for someone else,'' said the 58-year-old Bergen County woman. Call her Sara A.

title: Karen Perez Wed To P. P. Miller 3d
description: Karen Lea Koenig Perez, a second secretary of the United States Embassy in Cairo and director of the American Cultural Center there, was married yesterday to Peter Paul Miller 3d, a correspondent for NBC News in Paris. The Rev. Edward Koenig, father of the bride and retired minister of the Elms Haven Seventh-day Adventist Church in Deer Park, Calif., performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y.

title: Jeanne Marie Cohan Marries Kevin Clune
description: Jeanne Marie Cohan and Kevin Patrick Clune were married yesterday in a ceremony performed by Msgr.

title:
DINING OUT;
MAKING A CAREER OUT OF A HOBBY
description: IT IS ENCOURAGING to see the revival of Lambertville, the charming but formerly sleepy town across the Delaware River from New Hope, Pa., with renovations of its old buildings and spruced-up storefront restaurants in which innovative young chefs are turning out appealing fare.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Pressure on the Prime

title: Duane Lueders Is Married To Patricia Lee Mastriani
description: Patricia Lee Mastriani and Duane Lueders were married yesterday at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Waterbury, Conn., in a ceremony performed by the Rev. John Blanchfield.

title: VACATION-HOME MARKET IS ON THE UPSWING
description: THE Market in vacation homes in the Northeast is experiencing a strong rebound from a year ago, according to sales brokers in some of the region's most popular vacation centers.

title: Italy Gets A Socialist
description: Bettino Craxi's calculations worked out last week as the 49-year- old Milan politician became Italy's first Socialist Prime Minister. But as head of the 44th Government since World War II, he may not enjoy the experience.

title: Wendy Mae Schwartz Is Mount Kisco Bride
description: Wendy Mae Schwartz and Thomas David Gardner were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., by the Rev. Jack Silvey Miller.

title: ARTS FESTIVAL SET FOR SOUTH NORWALK
description: THE first branch of the Brookfield Craft Center will open on Washington Street in South Norwalk next April, according to its director, John Russell.

title: SLAYINGS SHATTER IMAGE OF IDYLLIC GEORGIA ISLAND
