description: The palms, pines and towering old live oaks dripping with moss, the tropical plants, the manicured lawns dotted with the reds of hibiscus and snapdragons and the yellows of alamandas and marigolds and ranunculus, the Spanish- and Mediterranean-style houses covered with fig vine and ivy, the sandy beaches along the Atlantic and the clear sky make it easy to understand why some residents of this resort community think of it as a paradise.

title: EIGHT RICH AND BUSY DAYS
description: OVERDRIVE, A Personal Documentary. By William F. Buckley Jr. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $16.95

title: SOME MISSIONS AND OMISSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME POINTERS ON POSING FOR YOUR OWN PICTURE
description: As with many others who love photography, I find my greatest frustration is lack of time to shoot pictures. Family and friends have long wearied of posing for me and I have no time to travel to picturesque locations.

title: ETHICS CODE ISN'T OPEN AND SHUT
description: Honest lawyers serve as officers of the court upholding the rule of law and as defenders of those unjustly accused. To the despair of many and the surprise of none, they also act as hired guns protecting the interests of stock swindlers, corporate polluters, whiplash fakers and drug dealers. Small wonder, then, that the legal profession's hardest problem has not been what to do about dishonest lawyers, but what to tell honest lawyers to do about dishonest clients.

title: AID AWAITS POLICE WHO DRINK
description: LIEUT. RICHARD KELLY of the West Orange Police Department isn't making any excuses for anyone when he talks about the stress that law-enforcement personnel face.

title: Struck Company Says It Will Hire Outsiders
description: Phelps Dodge, which has used supervisors and office workers to keep its Arizona mines and smelters open despite a 37- day strike, says it will begin hiring replacement employees.

title: WHEN ART AND CRAFTS INTERTWINE
description: THERE is art and there are crafts, and, generally, the twain rarely meet outside of street fairs and festivals. Insisting, however, that serious expressions of the two are not mutually exclusive but share common ground, a group of East End craftsmen, museum directors, collectors and entrepreneurs, led by Jack Lenor Larsen, the designer who is president of the American Craft Council, have joined forces to produce ''Art in Craft Media.''

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: INDECENT EXPOSURE: A True Story of Hollywood and Wall Street. By David McClintick. (Dell, $3.95.) The discovery that funds had been embezzled from Columbia Pictures by one of its executives in 1977 ''grew into a dramatic, angry and Machiavellian battle for control of a corporation's destiny,'' Robert Lindsey noted in his review of this best seller. Part soap opera and part detective story, ''Indecent Exposure,'' by David McClintick, formerly a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, reveals the inner operations of a corporation and the way modern Hollywood works, and gives insights about ''how people live and about what they do to one another.'' SOMETHING LIKE AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY. By Akira Kurosawa. (Vintage, $6.95.) ''Just the way most moviegoers remember his work - the murky glade in 'Rashomon,' the wake in 'Ikiru,' the plunging horses of 'Kagemusha,' the tired ronin leader of 'Seven Samurai' looking wistfully back at the farmers he has saved - so Akira Kurosawa looks back on his own life in terms of scenes and portraits done with quick brushstrokes,'' Frank Gibney said in his review. The great director's engrossing autobiography, sensitively translated by Audie E. Bock, is ''first, last and always a book about movies.''

title: AIDES ASSERT REAGAN MAY SHIFT TO SUPPORT HOLIDAY FOR DR. KING
description: President Reagan is ''inclined'' to reverse his opposition to making the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. a Federal legal holiday, White House and Congressional officials said today.

title: COPING WITH NOISE IN THEIR EARS
description: IRA ARNOWICH woke up hearing a noise inside his ear, a crackling sound he could not ignore. ''I was frightened,'' said the Woodbury resident, a successful businessman and father of four. ''I was afraid the noise would never go away.''

title: BODY BUILDERS MATCH MUSCLES IN BRONX
description: Anthony Riera moved into his building on East 181st Street in the Bronx when he was 5 years old and skinny. Now Anthony is 16, he is a body builder and his torso looks as if it were sculptured by Michelangelo.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PEDALING BASH

title: AN ECLECTIC SHOW IS SET FOR KENT
description: CONNECTICUT'S oldest summer exhibit and sale, the Kent Antiques Show, will celebrate its 35th season Aug. 18-20 at the Community Center on Route 7.

title: LIBEL CASE DIVIDES AN APPEALS COURT
description: A divided Federal appeals court here has sent a libel suit against two syndicated columnists back for possible trial, holding that purported expressions of opinion might be libelous if they contained false statements or suggestions of fact.

title: ZAMBIAN ARCHBISHOP QUITS UNDER FIRE
description: The Vatican today announced the resignation of the Archbishop of Lusaka, the capital of Zambia, who had been accused by many churchmen of faith-healing and exorcism practices inconsistent with Roman Catholicism.

title: HE'S GROWING A GARDEN OF SCULPTURE
description: ON Long Island, an open house in an artist's home-cum- studio is commonplace along the modish reaches of the Hamptons or in sprawling Victorian houses perched high above the Sound in Sea Cliff. But next Sunday at 2 P.M., visitors to that kind of exhibition will be traveling to an unaccustomed location, the sculpture garden of Laurence Faust.

title: WITH NEW SEGMENT, UPSTATE EXPRESSWAY NEARS COMPLETION
description: A 19-mile-long segment of the Southern Tier Expressway, which cost $60 million to build, has opened in western New York State.

title: ANCIENT BATHS OF PAMUKKALE
description: Imagine yourself floating in warm, bubbling champagne amid sunken marble columns and carved stones. Behind you stretches a dazzling white landscape of fantastic cliffs and terraces. Have you wandered on to the set of some movie?

title: Illinois Said to Alter Jobless Data in Campaign
description: Government documents show that the administration of Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois altered unemployment statistics during his re-election campaign last year to prevent loss of extended Federal benefits to 50,000 unemployed people, The Washington Post reported in today's issue.

title: FOR LATECOMERS TO PREGNANCY
description: WITH more and more women opting to have children later in life, a hospital here has established the first comprehensive program in the state, and possibly in the country, for motherhood over 30.

title: CUTTING TRAIN COSTS IN EUROPE, BATTLEFIELDS REVISITED
description: Windsurfing In Barbados There are slalom competitions, but the sport is not skiing; there are marathons, but the sport is not running; there are freestyle races, but the sport is not swimming.

title: Wider Horizons For Fair Housing
description: In Mount Laurel I and again in Mount Laurel II, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that towns across the state must require housing to be built for the poor. Last week, in what seemed destined to be known as Mount Laurel III, the court extended that obligation to three major land- use agencies that between them control 1.7 million acres, of more than a third of the state.

title: THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE --
description: When Judge Kaufman says, ''. . . our election campaigns must above all be protected from becoming a battle of budgets with political office awarded to the biggest spender,'' he isn't dealing with the distant future. The problem is in our laps right now.

title: Isabel C. Murphy to Wed Dr. Stephen A. Hoffman
description: The engagement of Isabel Catherine Murphy to Dr. Stephen A. Hoffmann has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Murphy of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn. The couple will be married in October at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: JOHN GAW MEEM, ARCHITECT WHO LED IN 'SANTA FE' STYLE
description: John Gaw Meem, a leading exponent of the ''Santa Fe style'' of architecture, died Thursday at St. Vincent Hospital in Santa Fe, N. M., one of the many buildings he designed throughout the American Southwest. He was 88 years old and lived in Santa Fe.

title: ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE AFFLICTS FAMILIES, TOO
description: WHEN Helen Mahood describes the confusion, helplessness and ignorance she felt when her mother was diagnosed as having Alzheimer's disease, she adds that she wants to make sure that ''no one goes through what I did.''

title: Recent Sales
description: Newtown, Conn. $160,000 *2*Lake road, 4-bedroom 2 1/2-baths, *2*6 year-old colonial, 2 fireplaces, lake rights, *2*2 acres, taxes $2,248. New Fairfield, Conn. $175,000 *2*14 Timber Spring Road, 4 bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*2-year old colonial, electric heater, valley views, *2*2 acres, taxes $2,002. Redding, Conn $167,500 *2*49 Chestnut woods, 4 bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*8 years old contemporary, horse barn, *2*Japanese gardens, 3.5 acres, taxes $2,686. Bronxville, N.Y. $134,000 *2*131 Lockwood Avenue, 3 bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, *2*17 year old brick/frame colonial, sun room, *2*eat in kitchen, aluminum siding, taxes $2,900 Mount Vernon, N.Y. $117,000 *2*177 Hillcrest Road, 3 bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, *2*53 year old frame/stucco, Tudor Norman den, *2*finished basement, taxes $2,039. South Salem, N.Y. $125,000 *2*Old Church Lane, 4 bedroom, 2 bath, *2*30 year old frame ranch, den, suna, goal barn, *2*wood stoves, 2.3 acres taxes $3,042. OTHER AREAS Hauppauge, L.I. $79,000 *2*69 Eagle Lane, 3 bedroom, 2 bath, *2*19 year old ranch, den, formal dining room, *2*full basement, deck, taxes $2,200. Ridge, L.I. $79,000 *2*27 Woodbrook Drive, 3 bedroom, 1-bath, *2*1 year old ranch, eat in kitchen, den; *2*taxes $1,800. Holmdel $295,000 *2*27 Ladwood Drive, 5 bedroom, 2 1/2 bathe, *2*2 year old, contemproary, 1.8 acres, furnished *2*basement, fireplace taxes $3,439.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CUOMO GOES HIS OWN WAY ON A-PLANTS
description: Governor Cuomo has been outspoken on the issue of nuclear power during his first months in office, but so far Mr. Cuomo's fellow governors do not seem to share his views.

title: LIFE IN 'EXILE' TAXES THE POOR
description: For the last eight months, 31-year-old Joanne Gigante and her children have been shifted from one hotel to another by New York City's Human Resources Administration. At the moment, they are housed at the Lincoln Motel on Broad Street here.

title: CRISIS AND HOPE
description: The quiet reflective thoughts here about the Administration's recent actions in Central America are less dramatic than the noisy headlines.

title: U.S. Clay Crown To Miss Temesvari
description: Top-seeded Andrea Temesvari over-powered Zina Garrison, 6-2, 6-2, today and won the women's title at the 74th United States Clay Court tennis tournament.

title: L.I.R.R. SETTLES, WITH EYE ON THE FUTURE
description: ALTHOUGH the Metropolitan Transportation Authority gave in on a major issue - the hiring of outside contractors to do some routine car maintenance - to avoid a strike on the Long Island Rail Road by four of its unions at midnight last Tuesday, the M.T.A. remains hopeful that the unions will eventually see it their way.

title: Mayer Martin Roberts to Marry W. C. Baker Oct. 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. William James Martin of Lakeland, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mayer Martin Roberts, to William Clayton Baker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin May Baker of Baltimore. An Oct. 1 wedding there is planned.

title: DOING WELL WHILE DOING GOOD
description: INVESTORS wishing to put their money into companies deemed socially or morally responsible are becoming a more active and visible presence on Wall Street. This month two new ''social responsibility'' mutual funds join the four already operating and the growing assortment of advisers and brokers eager to help investors avoid companies with poor records on such issues as equal opportunity, pollution or South Africa.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: IN PRAISE OF WHAT PERSISTS Edited by Stephen Berg. 289 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: Christine Marino Wed To Robert Gartner Jr.
description: Christine L. Marino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank X. Marino of Smithtown, L.I., and Robert L. Gartner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gartner of Ridgefield, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Donald Magnetti, the bridegroom's cousin and a law professor at Fordham University, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Infant Jesus in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. Francis Pizzarelli.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IN the continuing saga of the Garden City Hotel, the recently dismissed general manager said last week that his dismissal ''came as a complete surprise.'' The former manager, Jean-Pierre David , was discharged two weeks ago after about two months on the job. Mark Ferretti , the hotel's food and beverage manager, also departed at the same time.

title: Teacher, Scanlon Gain Final
description: Recovering from a poor start, Brian Teacher defeated his practice and doubles partner, Scott Davis, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, today and gained the final of the Buckeye Classic. The first prize is $20,000.

title: INDUSTRY IN ORBIT: HOW TO WIN IN SPACE
description: THIS year marks the 25th anniversary of NASA, the Federal agency that has nurtured and guided our nation's exploration and development of space.

title: Mary Womrath To Wed Oct. 15
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Womrath of Wilton, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Womrath, to Douglas L. Olson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walton Olson of Madison, Wis.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDAL HONORS SOVIET 'PRISONER OF CONSCIENCE'
description: The Soviet Union's policies on human rights have prompted many protests, but few have been as compelling, or as silently effective, as a stunning new medal honoring one of the victims of those policies. The medal, issued by the Judah L. Magnes Memorial Museum of Berkeley, Calif., pays tribute to Anatoly Shcharansky, a Soviet Jew who spent nearly six-and-a-half years as a ''prisoner of conscience'' in prison and labor camps.

title: Administration Grinds Its Gears On Rights Issues
description: The White House stepped up its counteroffensive on civil and women's rights last week in a series of moves that included a few stumbles and a self-inflicted wound.

title: RADIO OPERATOR AIDS SICK CHILD
description: THE story of Karina Dominguez, an infant who may need a liver transplant, began earlier this year in her native Uruguay. By June, however, concern for her plight had spread - first to Connecticut, then to Westchester and New Jersey. Scores of people, largely drawn from Latin American communities in the three states, have donated time, money and goods, hoping to bring about what many call ''un milagro'' - a miracle.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
ARCHITECTURAL STUDIES WHICH REFLECT HUMAN CONDITIONS
description: A funny thing about architectural photographs is that they start out being about buildings and wind up being about the human condition. This may not be true of picture postcards, but it is certainly true of many of the architectural photographs on view at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, through Oct. 16. The more than 170 photographs in this beautiful and fascinating exhibition are drawn from the collection of the Canadian Centre for Architecture, which chose them primarily for their combination of photographic excellence and architectural interest. Yet, again and again they seem to be making statements about human life.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: UP IN THE PARK

title: Bowler Wing $250,000 Prize
description: Scott Mouis, a 25-year-old drugstore clerk from Aurora, Ill., outlasted 491 amateur opponents to win the $250,000 first prize today in the Lucky Strikes Again American Dream Classic.

title: KEY BLACKS IN BALTIMORE SUPPORT WHITE MAYOR
description: The unusually intense mayoral election campaign here this humid summer has been labeled ''A Tale of Two Cities'' by one of the challengers, but it is at least equally a saga of two opposing black families, the Murphys and the Mitchells.

title: De La Rue Hospitalized
description: Michael De La Rue of Queens was released from St. Vincent's Hospital early yesterday after being treated for injuries suffered in a 10-round welterweight bout Friday night with Robert Adams of Philadelphia at Felt Forum.

title: IN MISSISSIPPI, WHO VOTED MEANT AS MUCH AS WHO WON
description: Mississippi, according to James H. Meredith, the man whose enrollment at Ole Miss required the intervention of President Kennedy and the National Guard, ''still has that magic name'' when it comes to questions of racial friction and obstruction of the voting rights of blacks.

title: HAWAII
description: To the Editor:

title: A FAR-FLUNG ARCTIC PEOPLE STRUGGLE FOR SYMBOLS OF UNITY
description: As Bernadette Limmaroitik tells it the Inuits, or Eskimo peoples of the Far North, are at the same time quick to adapt and fatalistic. ''We have an Inuit expression, 'ajuarnarmat,' which means 'it can't be helped.' You hear that a lot when somebody dies in an accident,'' the young Canadian said. ''Maybe it is time we stopped saying 'ajuarnamat' about what happens in the Arctic.''

title: Giants' Attitude Low Key
description: Once it was a war, an exhibition game between New York City's two pro football teams that for many people had become more important than a regular-season game. Now, to the relief of the coaches, it is just what an exhibition game is intended to be -- another step in preparing for the games that count.

title: ADIEU TO SERVICE WITH A SMILE
description: When business is bad, you expect service to be better than usual. But where gas stations are concerned, that's not the case. In fact, the friendly attendant who cleans your windshield is being replaced, almost overnight, by the fully automated - and computerized - station.

title: Bitter Honey
description: Maybe you think beekeeping is all honey. California beekeepers, who own some 10 percent of the nation's honey bees, know better.

title: Pressures on the Black College Athlete
description: The following article is a background paper on black athletes prepared by the National Urban League for a forum on the status of black athletes held at the organization's annual conference last week in New Orleans. The statistics on the black athlete are taken from a report on race in sports prepared by Dr. Harry Edwards for the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Linda M. Yu Is the Bride Of Alan Bien
description: Linda Maria Yu, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Yu of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Alan Bien, son of Julia H. Bien of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late Alexander H. Bien, were married yesterday. The Rev. Walter Anthony performed the ceremony at Old St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco.

title: WHERE THE SOUTH'S FORTUNES TURNED
description: LANDSCAPE TURNED RED, The Battle of Antietam. By Stephen W. Sears. Illustrated. 431 pp. New Haven & New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: Sports People
description: Killilea Joins Nets

title: Letters; Need for Lawyers?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. JURY TO WEIGH HEROIN CHARGES AGAINST 8
description: Jury deliberations are scheduled to begin tomorrow in the Federal narcotics trial of five men and three women charged with operating a major heroin ring in New York City.

title: RECOLLECTING BOOKS
description: When William Wordsworth set out to chronicle the growth of a poet's mind in ''The Prelude,'' he found, looking back on his life, moments he called ''spots of time.'' These were memories so potent, they seemed to stand apart from the continuous stream of biographical events. These recollections, possessing an almost physical presence, seemed to be locations - spots - in the poet's past, bearing ''a renovating virtue,'' a healing power.

title: GUATEMALAN LEADER CALLS SUPERPOWERS UNCARING
description: President Efrain Rios Montt says he does not believe that either the United States or the Soviet Union are interested in the overall welfare of Central America.

title: CAN WE TALK?
description: THE anxiety created in Central America by President Reagan's dispatch of warships and troops has brought new urgency to talk of political settlements. There was optimism last week after Mr. Reagan's special envoy, Richard B. Stone, met for the first time with a Salvadoran rebel leader and agreed to try to bring the Salvadoran adversaries face to face.

title: Sports of The Times;  The Many Poses of Bowie Kuhn
description: BOWIE KUHN's resignation as commissioner of baseball on Wednesday was strange. It was strange because he had already been dismissed. His term did not expire until Aug. 12, but he was hoping to get reinstated. When that became clearly hopeless, he resigned, as he called it. That's not resigning. That's simply making a virtue of necessity.

title: Moira E. Dingley Married Upstate
description: Moira Elizabeth Dingley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Dingley of Glens Falls, N.Y., was married in the Keene Valley (N.Y.) Congregational Church yesterday to Alan Charles Oppenheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Oppenheim of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Wallace.

title: Padres Rout Reds
description: Bobby Brown scored the go-ahead run in the seventh inning and highlighted an eight-run eight with a grand slam to lead the San Diego Padres to an 11-4 rout of the Cincinnati Reds in the first game of a twi-night doubleheader tonight.

title: U.S. Carrier Extending Stay Along Latin Coast
description: The Defense Department said today that the aircraft carrier Ranger, which had been scheduled to leave Central America for the western Pacific today, would remain off the Pacific coast of Nicaragua ''for several more days.''

title: NEW PENSION FUND ROLE: SAVING HOUSING
description: The wide-spread use of public-employee pension funds to finance the rehabilitation of older apartment buildings in New York City was predicted last week as the city's Police Pension Fund made the first commitment to such a program.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: RESURGENCE OF ALUMINUM RECYCLING BRINGS CASH TO THE POOR
description: Paul Deane's two shopping carts, tied end to end, bounced up and down along Boone Avenue in the South Bronx, his load of empty beer cans clanking with every pothole.

title: Metropolitan Buys 3 Savings Units
description: The Metropolitan Savings Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had acquired three savings and loan associations in Florida and Virginia and that it had received regulatory approval to acquire a fourth, also in Florida. Terms of the acquisitions were not disclosed.

title: Uruguay Police Arrest 150 Demonstrators
description: The police arrested about 150 people during Saturday night's demonstrations against Uruguay's military Government, police sources said today.

title: REAGAN CENSORS
description: In the next few weeks, the Government plans to put into effect what is perhaps the most far-reaching system of censorship in United States history.

title: Parrish Is Seized On Drug Charges
description: Lemar Parrish, a former all-pro defensive back, was released on $5,000 bond today after his arrest on drug charges.

title: Chilean Groups Form Opposition Alliance
description: The head of Chile's Christian Democratic Party, Gabriel Valdes, has announced the creation of a five-party opposition Democratic Alliance.

title: SUTTON WINS BY A STROKE
description: Under the pressure of Jack Nicklaus's presence beside the 18th green, with Nicklaus waiting against the possibility of a one-stroke error that would force a tie, Hal Sutton made the par 4 he needed on the final hole today and won the 65th Professional Golfers' Association Championship by one shot.

title: 'Desert Song' Scheduled
description: Sigmund Romberg's ''Desert Song'' will be presented by the Light Opera of Manhattan from Aug. 10 through Aug. 28 at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street.

title: LIKE IT OR NOT, AROUND VINELAND, THERE'S NOT PLANT LIKE EGGPLANT
description: The young boy's mother put one hand behind his head as her other hand guided a heaping forkful of limp, gray eggplant inexorably toward his mouth. He opened his mouth slightly only after closing his eyes, and gulped down the goo with an awful grimace.

title: JESUITS TO MEET TO ELECT NEW SUPERIOR GENERAL
description: Jesuits throughout the world will soon be traveling here, where early next month they are to elect a new Superior General. The election will put an end to a confrontation that began two years ago when, for the first time in the nearly 450 years of the order's history, a Pope named his own man as the Jesuits' leader.

title: COLLEGE DAYS, GEORGIA STYLE
description: LAST winter, a junior at the University of Georgia had decided, as have hundreds of thousands of other college students, to leave school and accept employment. He said he would return to school later - in fact he is on campus now - to complete work for his degree.

title: METS WIN IN 10TH FOR A SWEEP
description: Hubie Brooks reached out and pulled a single just by Ron Cey at third base to drive in Mark Bradley and Mookie Wilson with the winning runs in the 10th inning today as the Mets beat the Cubs, 6-4, for their first sweep of a series in two years and first sweep of a road series in four years.

title: SYRIAN CHIEF AGAIN ASSAILS U.S. OVERTURES ON LEBANON
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria told the United States today that his country would continue to oppose the United States-backed plan for the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: Miss Ford to Try Again With a Fashion Line
description: Charlotte Ford, whose 1960 debutante ball cost her father, Henry Ford 2d, $250,000, has spent a good deal of her life among rich and well-dressed people. ''I was always interested in clothes,'' she said. ''My mother was on the best-dressed list.''

title: FORMER ISRAELI CABINET AIDE ORDERED TO PRISON FOR THEFT
description: Aharon Abuhazira, the first Israeli Cabinet minister to be convicted of theft, was sentenced today to three months in jail by the Supreme Court.

title: UPPER VOLTA SAYS IT IS NONALIGNED
description: Upper Volta's new leader, Capt. Thomas Sankara, says he seized power three days ago because President Jean-Baptiste Ouedraogo had shunned democracy and failed to install social justice, the state-run radio reported today.

title: TO KEEP BASIC TELEPHONE SERVICE AFFORDABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: BARNARD ADJUSTS TO COMPETITION WITH COLUMBIA
description: Competing for the first time for female students, both Barnard and Columbia College officials say they are pleased with the freshman classes they were able to attract for the fall.

title: Fond Send-Off
description: Even with 14 rooms, the turreted house in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn wasn't big enough for the Maude family's weekend reunion. Members have lived there since it was built in 1904 - as a summer retreat from Park Slope.

title: Turf, Race and Human Relations
description: The police call them ''confirmed bias incidents'' - violence inspired by bigotry. One that occurred a few months ago on Staten Island, scrupulously tracked in a recent Times article by our colleague, Howard Blum, underlines the crying need for efforts to mediate human relations.

title: Keel Is Discussed
description: New York Yacht Club officials met with Australia II representatives for two hours today, and the Australians left further convinced that their keel is legal and that the top foreign contender will win the America's Cup in September.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: A FIREWORKS BUSINESS AND NEIGHBORS IN BATTLE
description: When Felix Grucci Sr. was born here 78 years ago, he lived in a virtual wilderness. And when he started his fireworks business in 1929, he tested the first fireworks by shooting them over vast empty acres of bush and scrub.

title: OIL THREAT OFF CAPE TOWN EASES AS WINDS TAKE SLICK OUT TO SEA
description: A Government crew towed the oil-laden bow of a wrecked Spanish supertanker out to sea today and winds blew the oil slick from the leaking tanker away from land.

title: Arens Holds Talks With Arabs In West Bank Town of Hebron
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens visited the West Bank town of Hebron today, a center of violence between Jews and Arabs, and met Palestinian leaders for the first time since taking office five months ago.

title: Chiat/Day Executive Is Returning to D.D.B.
description: Montgomery N. McKinney, 73- year-old chairman of the executive committee of Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, is returning to Doyle Dane Bernbach/ West in September.

title: FARMERS WARY ON EXPORT OUTLOOK
description: The new farm trade agreements with the Soviet Union and China have improved prospects for United States agriculture exports, but American farmers are not cheering yet.

title: Julie R. Harris Is Married To Kenneth L. Silverstein
description: Julie R. Harris and Kenneth L. Silverstein, graduates of Brown University and third-year students at the New York University School of Medicine, were married at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday. Rabbis Mordecai Waxman and Robert Widom, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel.

title: Marschalk to Handle Cooper Laboratories
description: The Marschalk Company, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has become an agency for Cooper Laboratories, Palo Alto, Calif.

title: OLD WAYS PAY OFF FOR DALE CARNEGIE
description: In the late 1970's many executives dressed for success, looked out for No. 1 and dismissed old-line self-improvement methods as declasse. In a sea of flashy image-building alternatives, however, the venerable Dale Carnegie course hewed to its basic teachings on how to win friends and influence people.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day July 21 reporting China's purchase of telephone equipment from a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation referred incorrectly to the United States position on the transfer of the technology involved. The United States had objected to the sale, but dropped the objection.

title: FORECASTS ON RATES COVER WIDE RANGE
description: It is not often that bond investors are offered such conflicting advice about the direction of interest rates.

title: ATTEMPT TO ABDUCT RICH BUSINESSMAN IN IRELAND IS FOILED
description: Antiterrorist police, tipped off about the planned kidnapping of a millionaire businessman, staked out his house and engaged seven masked gunmen in a shootout today, seriously wounding four of them.

title: Leslie S. Yalof Is Bride Of H. Douglas Garfield
description: The marriage of Leslie Sue Yalof and H. Douglas Garfield, law students at the University of Florida, took place at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Saudi Currency
description: Saudi Arabia today devalued the riyal to 3.47 to the dollar from 3.45, effective immediately, a Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency spokesman said in Riyadh.

title: Sidney Goldmann Dies at 79; Jersey Administrative Judge
description: Sidney Goldmann, a presiding judge and administrative judge on New Jersey's Superior Court before his retirement in 1971, died Saturday at his home in Trenton. He was 79 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEAT GENERATION The Marimba Ponies, you may be surprised to learn, come from Japan. They are nine youngsters who are members of a percussionist troupe that was organized in 1977, and they have been making themselves heard internationally ever since - including a performance in Carnegie Hall. What's more, they will perform here at noon today in the sanctuary of St. Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, as part of the programming offered by the church and the Citicorp Center.

title: ESKIMOS TRY TO TAKE ESSENCE OF PAST INTO FUTURE
description: In the high school gymnasium of this tundra town, Eskimo delegates from scattered settlements in Alaska, Greenland and Canada recently spent a week trying to devise some way of gaining control over their destiny in a fast-changing polar environment.

title: AUDIENCE BESIEGES FAN NAMED TAYLOR
description: Hundreds of Giants fans turned toward Lawrence Taylor after an early Jet touchdown tonight and, more imploring than in anger, shouted, ''L.T., L.T.''

title: SHULTZ VOWS NO ATTACK ON NICARAGUA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he saw no possibility that the United States would intervene militarily with its own forces to topple the Government of Nicaragua.

title: MRS. WAITZ TAKES WORLD MARATHON TITLE
description: Grete Waitz of Norway won the most important marathon of her career today in the opening of the first world track and field championships, but Alberto Juantorena's gold-medal racing days may have been ended by a freakish finish-line injury.

title: News Analysis
description: Reagan Administration officials say Saturday's dispatch of two American Awacs surveillance planes and an escort of F-15 fighters to help Chad is aimed at countering what Washington perceives to be an effort by Libya to create its own sphere of influence across Africa.

title: Commodities; Integrating the Markets
description: WHEN the American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade last week announced plans to give their members access to each other's stock index futures and options markets, it marked the next to last round in the eventual integration of the securities and futures markets.

title: LITTLE DISRUPTION REPORTED BY STRIKE OF PHONE WORKERS
description: Some 675,000 telephone workers across the nation were on strike today against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell System, but few serious interruptions in service were reported.

title: POP MUSIC: BERMUDA TRIANGLE
description: WATCHING the Bermuda Triangle, the zany rock-blue grass trio who performed at Folk City on Saturday night, was like being caught in a time warp. One could easily imagine that the club was a Berkeley coffee house, circa 1967, when the end of the folk music boom began intermingling with psychedelic rock.

title: Article 086238 -- No Title
description: Senators facing the voters in 1984 have already amassed campaign chests approaching $10 million.More than 15 months before the election, at least three incumbents have more than $1 million each in cash to spend against opponents, according to reports to the Federal Election Commission.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: PALMER GETS A TASTE OF THE LOW MINORS
description: "To give up runs will be embarrassing,'' Jim Palmer said today before pitching for the Hagerstown Suns against the Durham Bulls in a minor league game.

title: RESIDENTS FORM A CO-OP TO SAVE DYING BUILDING
description: Four years ago, the six-story apartment building at 2215 Newkirk Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, abandoned by its owner in all but name, seemed destined to become another example of housing dilapidation in New York.

title: FOR COMPUTER WHIZZES, GAMES PAY TUITION
description: Alon Goren, who will be 18 later this month, created his 40th video game recently, sitting at home in front of a computer screen. He has made about $20,000 this year - much of it this summer - selling his game programs to a computer software company.

title: Advertising; Agency And Tax Charges
description: JOHN L. ERNST, chairman and co-founder of Advertising to Women, pleaded guilty last Thursday to evading income taxes by listing as company business expenses his personal spending. He also pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the Government by letting favored employees do the same.

title: Chicago's Court System Is Under F.B.I. Inquiry
description: As many as 10 Cook County judges and 25 lawyers are targets of a three-year undercover investigation into bribery and corruption, two newspapers report.

title: Speakes Is Promoted To Chief Spokesman
description: President Reagan has named Larry Speakes to be assistant to the President and chief White House spokesman, adding to Mr. Speakes's salary and prestige but leaving the disabled James S. Brady with the title of press secretary.

title: STOCKS SIR OPTIMISM IN ITALY
description: Although the trading floor of the Milan Stock Exchange has just been encased in anti-terrorist bulletproof glass, there is a new mood of optimism here.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A TIGER FOR MALGUDI. By R. K. Narayan. 176 pages. Viking Press.

title: Pocketing Success
description: Since reaching the summit of the college basketball world last April, Jim Valvano has seen greener pastures open wide for him.

title: WRISTON SEES RATE RISE 'BLIP'
description: Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp, said that he believed that short-term interest rates would rise in the next few weeks and that the prime rate might climb to 11 1/2 percent or 12 percent, from the current 10 1/2 percent.

title: WHEN IS A FOREIGN INTEREST 'VITAL?'
description: President Reagan has stated over and again that ''defense of the Caribbean and Central America against Marxist-Leninist takeovers is vital to our national security.''

title: Mary Blitzer Wed To Robert I. Field
description: Mary Upham Blitzer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Blitzer of Cambridge, Mass., and Bradford, N.H., was married yesterday to Robert Isaac Field, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Field of Manhattan. Rabbi Benjamin Rudovsky performed the ceremony in the Meeting House of Bradford Center, N.H.

title: INDUSTRIAL EXPANSION INDEX UP
description: The economic recovery accelerated sharply in July, with a broad- based index of industrial expansion reaching its highest level in nearly 10 years, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its monthly report yesterday.

title: By the Sea, by the Sea
description: The shouts from the swimming pools and the handball and tennis courts were in Russian as well as English yesterday, when 600 Soviet emigres were guests of the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club.

title: Wilson Pace Gets A 12-Horse Field
description: Twelve 2-year-olds will compete Monday night in harness racing's richest race of the year, the $1.7 million Woodrow Wilson Pace at the Meadowlands.

title: People
description: * William S. Smith named executive vice president of client services of Leo Burnett, U.S.A.

title: Teen-Ager Is Killed in Manhattan Disco
description: A Manhattan teen-ager was fatally stabbed yesterday at a discoth eque on East 14th Street, the police said.

title: BLOCK'S EFFORT TO CUT FARM COSTS SUSTAINS SETBACK
description: When the Senate adjourned last week without acting on President Reagan's demand for a freeze on grain and cotton subsidy levels, the Administration suffered another setback in its effort to curb spending for farm aid next year.

title: OUR ZONING CONTROLS MUST NOT BE FOR SALE
description: To the Editor:

title: CANDIDATES FOR TOP JOB
description: SINCE Bowie Kuhn announced he would no longer be a candidate for another term as baseball commissioner, a number of other candidates have begun to emerge. They didn't want to seem to covet Kuhn's job while he was still trying to convince the Marx Brothers he had not totally run baseball into the ground.

title: Tose's Bet Losses Put in Millions
description: Leonard Tose, the owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, gambled away millions of dollars in Atlantic City before telling the National Football League commissioner that he would never place another casino bet, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today.

title: Bangladesh Flood Toll at 41
description: Three boats carrying flood victims sank in a storm, raising to 41 the death toll in weeklong floods throughout Bangladesh, officials said today. Sixty people are missing after their boat sank Friday during a storm.

title: Patricia Ann O'Neill Weds
description: Patricia Ann O'Neill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius O'Neill of Massapequa Park, L.I., was married yesterday to David Patrick Delevante, son of Mrs. Raymond Scoza of North Babylon, L.I., and the late Harold Delevante.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beatrice Foods Co. has named Warren Lewis president of its refrigerated warehouse division and I. Donald Rosuck president of its newly formed home products division.

title: AMATEUR ATHLETES: SOME MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS
description: DURING the United States team trials in whitewater canoeing last May, a group of the athletes were asked to submit $100 checks to confirm their hotel reservations for the world championships in Merano, Italy. When the team manager tried to cash the checks, however, a handful of the checks bounced.

title: ILLINOIS ALTERED JOBLESS FIGURING
description: In the midst of the 1982 Illinois governor's race, the incumbent administration changed its way of calculating unemployment statistics so that more than 50,000 unemployed workers kept receiving Federal benefits, according to Labor Department officials.

title: THE AGA KHAN LIFTS ITALY'S SAILS
description: PRINCE KARIM EL HUSEINI SHAH, the fourth Aga Khan, relaxed with a cup of coffee in the living room of Oceanview, the rambling oceanfront mansion he has rented here, as he discussed a wide-range of sporting interests, from Australia II's controversial keel to the loss of his kidnapped thoroughbred Shergar and his recent formation of a world foundation to promote sports in developing countries.

title: CHINESE DEFECTOR FLIES JET TO SEOUL
description: Officials here said that a Chinese Air Force test pilot defected to South Korea today in a MIG-21 fighter plane, setting off air-raid warnings all over the country.

title: FRANCE RULES OUT TROOPS OR PLANES TO HELP CHADIANS
description: France's Defense Minister said today that the Government had ruled out sending combat planes or ground troops to its former colony of Chad, where Libyan-supported forces are seeking the overthrow of President Hissen Habre.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday on strategic arms talks between the United States and the Soviet Union incorrectly described the 7,500 ballistic missile warheads that American negotiators say the Soviet Union has. The figure includes both land-based and sea-based missiles.

title: The I.M.F. Bill Still Needs Help
description: The close vote in the House for enlarging the International Monetary Fund is a clear warning that this bill remains in deep trouble. Its enactment is essential to the fund's capacity to step in when member countries are unable to pay what they owe for imports and debt. Its opponents have loaded the bill with amendments that would damage the fund and hobble commercial bank lending. The Administration, banks and all who want stability in the world's finances have a lot of work to do.

title: Rally Fails, Yanks Lose
description: Sparky Anderson said he could live with his team's 10-run loss to the Yankees on Saturday night, or its 9-run defeat on Friday. Those were laughers, the kind you put behind, that don't cost you sleep.

title: Arnoux's Ferrari Wins in Germany
description: Rene Arnoux of France, driving a Ferrari turbo, took the lead on the second lap and went on to win the German Grand Prix today.

title: SENATOR TOWER BACKS U.S. MILITARY SUPPORT FOR CHAD
description: Senator John Tower, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today that the United States ''should provide all of the logistical support possible'' to Chad to prevent the incursion of Libyan forces into that African nation.

title: 68 LIFTS PATTI RIZZO TO FIRST TRIUMPH
description: Patti Rizzo erased a three-shot deficit in the first seven holes and went on to shoot a 68 today to win the $175,000 Boston Five Classic by two strokes for her first professional victory.

title: CUOMO SEEKING WAY TO REFINANCE LILCO DEBT TO AVERT RATE INCREASES
description: Governor Cuomo has begun discussions with financial experts on ways to refinance the more than $1 billion in debts that the Long Island Lighting Company incurred in building the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: DALLAS VOTING THIS WEEK ON $8.9 BILLION SUBWAY-BUS SYSTEM
description: When Dallas tried to set up a regional transportation authority in 1980, residents turned it down in a 3-to-1 vote. When Houston voted on a $2.3 billion rail plan last month, the defeat was almost as crushing.

title: Martha Gerson Marries Joseph Lufkin
description: Martha Blythe Gerson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel C. Gerson of Millersville, Md., and Joseph C. F. Lufkin, son of Col. and Mrs. Daniel H. Lufkin of Frederick, Md., were married yesterday at the Cosmos Club in Washington. Cantor Sigfried Rowe officiated.

title: VAST CORAL REEFS DYING IN 2 OCEANS
description: Corals are dead or dying over vast stretches of the Pacific Ocean and in some areas of the Atlantic in what may be the most extensive reef devastation in modern times.

title: Chairman to Retire At SCA Services
description: John M. Fox, former head of the United Fruit Company and of H. P. Hood Inc., a major New England berry enterprise, has reached his 70th birthday and is cutting back on his role in business.

title: PHILLIES AND EXPOS ROLL ALONG
description: The Eastern Division race in the National League tightened up further yesterday as the Montreal Expos and the Philadelphia Phillies continued their winning streaks.

title: OF MARIGOLDS IN THE MORNING
description: Each day, the Senate has what it calls the Morning Hour, a time of senatorial dronings about war and taxes and mankind's myriad failings.

title: NUCLEAR TROJAN HORSE
description: The Navy's decision to make Staten Island the home port of seven warships raises some unpleasant questions about nuclear weapons and possible accidents, and these questions should be answered before the ships arrive in 1984.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 8, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FAMED FOSSIL SITE IS STICKY ISSUE FOR LOS ANGELES SUBWAY PLAN
description: Los Angeles, the ultimate automobile city, has flirted with the notion of a subway many times. In recent weeks, thanks to promises of Federal money, it has drawn closer than ever to actually getting one.

title: OUTDOORS: BEACHCOMBING JOYS RUN DEEP
description: BEACHCOMBING'S charm is its infinite variety, and its rewards are not confined to objects acquired. One may comb, instead, coherent thoughts from the wrack left in one's mind by emotional storms.

title: Letter: On Fishing A Safety Net for Striped Bass
description: To the Editor:

title: FINLAND'S BOOMING SHIPYARD
description: The doorstep of the Soviet Union is not normally regarded by capitalists as prime investment territory. But precisely because of their heavy trade with the Soviet Union, a number of companies here at the gateway to northern Russia scarcely noticed the recent worldwide recession.

title: Pining for George
description: The fading pine-tar controversy that hurt feelings in Kansas City and then New York, has been kept alive by a Kansas City publisher with a soothing sense of humor and a charitable bent.

title: DANCE: LIVE WEIGHT PERFORMS MODERN WORKS
description: THERE are times when the pleasures of smallness, intimacy and comfort can outweigh strict artistic considerations. It was not that the dances presented by Live Weight on Saturday at Our Studios in Chelsea were insignificant. But Live Weight has charms of its own as a dance company that have nothing to do with the work.

title: Dr. Freedman Is Wed To Dr. Lee J. Brooks
description: Dr. Ellen P. Freedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Freedman of Rydal, Pa., and Margate, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Lee J. Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martyn Brooks of Brooklyn. Rabbi Harold B. Waintrup performed the ceremony at the Atlantic City Country Club in Northfield, N.J.

title: Debra S. Silverman Married to Jeffrey S. Marcus
description: Debra Sue Silverman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Silverman of Oceanside, L.I., and Jeffrey Samuel Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Marcus of Beachwood, Ohio, were married yesterday. Rabbi Gary Creditor and Cantor Yitzchak Lefkowitz performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: 46th St. Shootout Wounds a Diner
description: Three gunmen burst into a restaurant on West 46th Street on Saturday and shot and wounded a diner, the police said.

title: Venezuela Oil Swap
description: Venezuela will renew a lapsed oil agreement with the Soviet Union this month, sending 20,000 barrels per day of crude oil to Cuba, oil industry sources said Saturday. In exchange the Soviet Union will send 20,000 barrels per day of Soviet export blend oil to refineries jointly owned by Petroleos de Venezuela and Veba Oel, the West German state-controlled oil company.

title: Quaker Sees New Markets for Gatorade; Sports Drink Image in Flux
description: When Gatorade, the cloudy, citrus- flavored drink, hit the market in 1967, it quickly became the drink of champions - and would-be champions.

title: Nigerian Woman Is Shot In Election Violence
description: A woman was shot and wounded and more than 58 people were arrested in incidents connected with Nigeria's presidential election on Saturday, published reports said today.

title: TERRORISM'S VICTIMS AS AN AFTERTHOUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFERENCE SEEKS WAYS TO PROTECT ANIMAL RIGHTS
description: Pamela Marsen spied a customer. She stood up from behind the desk full of lipsticks, perfumes and bottles of brightly colored nail gloss, and her spiel began.

title: O'NEILL CENTER IS HOST TO 5 RUSSIANS
description: Oleg Efremov, artistic director of the Moscow Art Theater and heir to the teachings of Stanislavsky, discussed with a Connecticut critic his view of the proper approach to staging Chekhov.

title: HOYT OF WHITE SOX TOPS ORIOLES AND RETURNING FLANAGAN, 4-3
description: Greg Luzinski hit his third homer in three games and LaMarr Hoyt won his fourth straight decision as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4-3, today.

title: Travers Shapes Up As Anybody's Race
description: The sun is slowly browning the infield and the mosquitoes are are driving everyone crazy, but it might as well be January for the 3-year-olds who will run in the 114th Travers Stakes here Saturday. After months of indecisive and topsy-turvy racing, the division lacks a leader and the race for its championship is beginning anew.

title: HANDICAPPED NEWBORNS PROTECTED BY LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE MARC RICH AGREEMENT
description: Marc Rich & Company A.G., one of the world's largest commodity traders, agreed to hand over documents subpoenaed more than a year ago by a Federal grand jury because of rising fears among the firm's customers and suppliers that the Government was preparing to seize the company's United States operations, executives familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: Dr. Senior Abel Moreinis, 57, Teacher of Clinical Dentistry
description: Dr. Senior Abel Moreinis, a professor of clinical dentistry and assistant dean of students at the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, died Saturday after heart surgery at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: 10,000 in New Bedford Welcome Studds at Feast
description: Representative Gerry E. Studds was greeted by an estimated 10,000 applauding voters today when he returned to his district for the first time since his censure by the House for having had a homosexual affair with a House page.

title: WHEN WHALES VISITED
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Gas-CSX Acquisition
description: Another Supreme Court Justice declined Saturday evening to block the $1.07 billion takeover of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation by the CSX Corporation.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Meeting Canceled

title: Accounts
description: * Eyelab Inc., to Herman & Rosner Enterprises.

title: Trainer of Mets Loses Bet to Heat
description: Larry Mayol, the Mets' trainer and an enthusiastic runner, made a friendly bet with Bobby Valentine, a Mets coach, and John Stearns, the Mets' catcher currently on the disabled list. Mayol bet that he could beat them by 10 minutes in a race from the team's Chicago hotel to Wrigley Field this morning - a distance of five miles.

title: A DICTATOR OR SOMETHING
description: In the long and discouraging annals of Latin American autocrats, President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala may be an original.

title: BIGGER PERIL
description: The nation's debate over Central America and United States policy toward that hapless region is misdirected. The Central American melee, while serious, is much less of a threat to United States interests than the potentially devastating political, social and economic consequences of the debt crisis - and crisis it remains - facing virtually all of Latin America today.

title: INVENTOR SAYS DEVICE TURNS ANGRY SHOUT INTO ANGRY SHOUT
description: Unless he appeals, Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, will be banned from two games this week for ''public remarks reflecting upon the honesty and integrity of an American League umpire.''

title: Cosmos' Cabanas Gets Star Rating
description: Roberto Cabanas has been so impressive for the Cosmos this season that the coach believes he has the potential to reach the level of a Pele.

title: Connors Wins
description: Jimmy Connors defeated Tim Mayotte, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2, today in the final of a $300,000, eight-player event today.

title: AIDS Articles to Be Speeded
description: To improve public information on acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the editors of four major scientific journals say they are expediting publication of articles on the mysterious deadly disease.

title: CUOMO STRIVING FOR NEUTRALITY IN PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Despite Governor Cuomo's efforts to keep Democratic Party and public officials neutral in the upcoming Presidential campaign, some leading New York Democrats are already committing themselves to candidates.

title: SOME POLITICS IN SENATE DISAPPOINTS LAUTENBERG
description: From the futuristic painting of a computer hanging on an office wall to his initial legislative forays dealing with cable television and telephone deregulation, there is ample evidence of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg's former business interests as he adapts to the ways of the Senate.

title: A CAR BOMB KILLS 33 AND WOUNDS 125 IN LEBANESE TOWN
description: A car packed with more than 200 pounds of dynamite exploded at the entrance of the fruit and vegetable market in the central Lebanese town of Baalbek today, killing at least 33 people and wounding 125 others, according to Red Cross workers on the scene.

title: A NEW SITUATION IN ADOPTION
description: With two young boys to bring up and jobs that barely covered the monthly bills, Dan and Brenda were much like any other married couple struggling to get by. But after Brenda became pregnant again this year, she and her husband made a painful and unusual decision: They plan to give their baby up for adoption.

title: Jet With 102 Aboard Is Damaged on Takeoff
description: A tire blew out as a Republic Airlines DC- 9 took off today, knocking a six-inch hole in a wing and forcing the plane to land after it circled for an hour to dump fuel, passengers and a fire official said.

title: Addenda
description: * Leona Sills, associate publisher-director of creative services of Conde- Nast's Bride's magazine, is setting up her own consulting firm at 7 East 75th Street.

title: ARIAS CAPTURES CROWN
description: Jimmy Arias today became the first American in four years to win the men's title at the United States Clay- Court tennis championships.

title: Can You Spare a Dime?
description: The 5-cent cigar that America was once said to need has given way to the 10-cent cigarette.

title: Superfeatherweight Title to Camacho
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho won the vacant and disputed World Boxing Council superfeatherweight title today when he stopped Rafael (Bazooka) Limon in the fifth round of their scheduled 12-rounder.

title: California Magazine Sold
description: Alan Bennett and his backers, who are owners of four-year-old Savvy magazine, on Friday signed the papers to acquire California magazine from Mediatex, publishers of Texas Monthly.

title: O'Brien of Jets Has Fine Debut
description: The Jets didn't wait long to show off their No. 1 draft pick, the quarterback Ken O'Brien from California- Davis.

title: No Headline
description: Bobby Murcer, who spent the better part of his 19-year career in a Yankee uniform, was honored before yesterday's game with speeches, gifts and the loving applause of the Yankee Stadium fans. The ceremony marked his retirement earlier this season, when he moved into the broadcast booth to begin a second Yankee career.

title: No Headline
description: Tough new measures were ordered today in Yuri V. Andropov's campaign against idlers and drunkards in Soviet factories and other enterprises.

title: Racial Study
description: More than 35 years after Jackie Robinson broke the major league color barrier, a new study suggests that blacks and whites who play baseball together play better than those who don't.

title: PAUL TAUBMAN
description: Paul Taubman, who had a law practice in Great Neck, L.I., and was director of staff relations for the New York City Department of Highways from 1962 to 1974, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Plapler Picks Up Car Rental Account
description: Plapler & Associates, which already has People Express Airlines, has now picked up some ground support, Greyhound Rent-A-Car of Miami.

title: A Specialist in Dealing With Soviet on Grain
description: As a private trader and as a public servant, Daniel G. Amstutz has figured in all of this country's grain-trade agreements with the Russians, beginning with the first one in 1962, when he worked for Cargill Inc., the grain company.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 8, 1983
description: International

title: Iraq Says Fighting Continues on 2 Fronts
description: Iraq said today that Iraqi and Iranian forces were still fighting on the northern and central fronts in the Persian Gulf war, more than two weeks after Iran launched the first of two recent offensives.

title: Coast Bank Auctions Repossessed Property
description: The Heritage Bank grossed $10.5 million for a variety of repossessed homes, condominiums, lots and offices over the weekend in what was billed as the largest single auction liquidation of property ever held in the United States.

title: Gary L. Dennis Is Wed To Merrill L. Drapkin
description: Merrill Louise Drapkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Drapkin of Hollis Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Gary L. Dennis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Dennis of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Deborah Hirsch performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Appearance at work in an inebriated condition, or drinking liquor at the workplace will be considered a most serious breach of discipline.'' - Pravda, Soviet Communist Party paper. (A8:3.)

title: DOLLAR RISE IS SEEN CONTINUING
description: The dollar, which has soared to record highs against other major currencies in recent weeks on the strength of rising domestic interest rates and stronger-than-expected economic growth, is likely to continue its runup for the next few months, according to foreign exchange specialists and international economists.

title: TREASURY SLOWS PACE OF BORROWING
description: The credit market will have an opportunity this week to digest the $15.75 billion of Treasury notes and bonds sold last week, as the only scheduled Treasury auctions are 3- and 6-month bills on Monday and 1-year bills on Tuesday.

title: President Plans Stops On His Vacation Trip
description: President Reagan will leave for a California vacation Friday, making working stops along the way in Florida, Texas, Mexico and Louisiana. The itinerary includes a meeting with the President of Mexico.

title: AFTER 12 YEARS, A PROFIT FOR 'HAROLD AND MAUDE'
description: In 1971, ''Harold and Maude'' was a box-office disaster. In 1983, it is, at last, a profitable movie.

title: Gulf Nations Cut Gas Price
description: The countries along the Persian Gulf have cut their selling price for liquefied natural gas to match a price reduction announced last week by Saudi Arabia, oil industry sources said today.

title: 1982 CASE OF AMERICAN PROFESSOR MISSING IN MEXICO STILL UNSOLVED
description: United States officials say they are frustrated by lack of progress in solving the case of Nicholas Schrock, a University of Colorado professor who disappeared last year on his way to a teaching job in Mexico.

title: 208 DETAINED IN NUCLEAR PROTEST AT AIR FORCE BASE NEAR OMAHA
description: Air Force police officers seized 208 antinuclear protesters yesterday for trespassing at Strategic Air Command headquarters near Omaha. It was one of several protests nationwide marking the 38th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: Caterpillar Truck Deal
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that its Towmotor Corporation subsidiary had entered into an agreement with Kaldnes Mek. Verksted A.S. of Tonsberg, Norway, for production of new, large lift trucks. The truck, the V925, will be made in Norway and marketed through Caterpillar lift truck dealers worldwide, Caterpillar said last week.

title: Nuptials for Penny Sokotch
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue yesterday, Penny Susan Sokotch, who teaches science and mathematics at the Simon Baruch Junior High School in Manhattan, was married to Craig Schiller, counsel to the New York law firm of Malcolm A. Hoffmann.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WEDDING AT A BUS STOP
description: A bus stop where thousands begin a trip to work each day will be the scene next month of a journey of another kind - a marriage.

title: PLASTIC BOTTLES SEEKING MARKETS OUTSIDE SODA
description: Nathaniel C. Wyeth, a research engineer at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, was dismayed by the flimsy plastic bottles available in the 1950's. ''Fill one with a carbonated beverage,'' the now-retired Mr. Wyeth says, ''and the next morning you'd have a basketball.''

title: Strong Quake Jolts Tokyo
description: A strong earthquake shook the Tokyo area today, the Central Meteorological Agency said.

title: MAURICE HIRSCH
description: Maurice Hirsch, counsel to the Houston law firm of Hirsch & Westheimer, and whose career in law, the military and philanthropy spanned nearly 70 years, died Friday in Hong Kong, where he was on vaction.

title: ANTHONY BURGESS TALKS ABOUT HIS 'LYING CRAFT'
description: Not for the first time, Anthony Burgess, best known for that controversial novel and film, ''A Clockwork Orange,'' finds that he has to explain what he's up to creatively these days. Some of the critics were underwhelmed by his current novel, ''The End of the World News,'' wondering about its multimedia style. Divided into three parts, the novel includes a Broadway musical comedy about Leon Trotsky, a ''televisualized'' life of Sigmund Freud and a science-fiction tale of the planet Earth clobbered by an intruder from a distant galaxy.

title: TARDY ADVICE ON A 'NUCLEAR TURKEY'
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO GRANDES DAMES: FROM OBSCURITY TO ACCLAIM
description: Two grand old women, plucked from their private lives, have left their marks on ''Zelig,'' Woody Allen's latest hit movie.

title: Waterborne Nuptials
description: The bride, a Doyle Dane Bernbach copywriter, wore white (calf- length). The bridegroom, a Wells, Rich, Greene copywriter, wore seersucker. They were married on the foredeck of the Selisa M. as the 112- foot motor yacht rounded lower Manhattan, on her way to the Hudson from an East River moorage

title: Brazil Inflation Rate Up
description: Brazil's July inflation rose to 13.3 percent, from 12.3 percent in June and 6.1 percent in July 1982, the Getulio Vargas Foundation announced.

title: Photographer Is Slain On Broadway at 46th
description: A 27-year-old street photographer was fatally stabbed on Broadway at 46th Street as after-theater crowds packed the sidewalks, the police said.

title: Karen Lynne Schaefer Weds Craig Hollis Grosby
description: Karen Lynne Schaefer and Craig Hollis Grosby were married yesterday at the Merion Tribute House in Merion, Pa., by District Justice Francis J. Lawrence of Montgomery County.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A runner slides home, but misses the plate as the ball escapes the catcher and rolls into the dugout. The catcher realizes the runner has failed to touch the plate, but the runner does not and heads for the dugout. How does the catcher appeal since the ball in the dugout is dead?

title: Shelley Burtt Marries Donald Meltzer
description: Shelley Garland Burtt, daughter of Carleton Davis Burtt of New York and Mrs. Iain Paul Mackay of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Donald Meltzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Meltzer of New York. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: OPERA: GLUCK'S 'ORFEO ED ERIDICE' AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Gluck's opera ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' might seem an improbable choice for Tanglewood, where it was presented in a semistaged version Saturday night. And yet at least from a seat within the Shed itself, the occasion proved both musically rewarding and dramatically engrossing, with the singing especially serving to do honor to Gluck's not entirely secure modern reputation.

title: VERMONT TOWNS GET A VOICE IN SKI RESORT EXPANSION PLAN
description: A major Vermont ski resort has won preliminary approval for expansion under an agreement that gives the state and nearby communities a better chance to monitor the development.

title: TV: CBS MAKES A PILOT FROM THE MOVIE 'DINER'
description: ''DINER'' was a wonderful movie, an evocation of time and place. At first glance, however, it would not seem to be much of an idea for a television comedy, although now CBS has mounted it as a half-hour pilot, which means it could grow into a series. The pilot is promising, a couple of notches and then some above what's been around this summer. It will be seen on Channel 2 at 8:30 tonight.

title: Lia M. Cooper Marries Reed Atherton
description: Lia Maureen Cooper, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Keith W. Cooper of Berkeley Heights, N.J., and Reed W. Atherton, son of Ambassador and Mrs. Alfred L. Atherton of Cairo, were married yesterday. The Rev. Edward Holborow, a Presbyterian minister and great-uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at Atherton Farms, a sheep ranch in Monmouth, Ore., owned by the bridegroom's brother, Michael Atherton.

title: Market Place; Deteriorating Indicator Noted
description: THOSE hairline cracks in the structure of the stock market are starting to widen. Last week the Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.93 points, to 1,183.29, finishing just above the 1,180 figure that has provided firm support to sagging markets since mid-April. This brought the aggregate drop for the past two weeks to 47.88 points.

title: Antisuicide Sculpture In Search of a Home
description: For three months, the brightly painted eight-foot human figure had been poised near the top of the 140-foot column and hadn't jumped yet. But it was too realistic for users of Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, so yesterday the sculptor, Scott Siken, took it down from the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument.

title: Bridge: Association's Top 2 Players Take Home the Belsaw Cup
description: Put two top-ranked players together and you are likely to get - a top score. That happened Friday in the Belsaw Cup, opening event of the American Bridge Association's Summer Nationals at the New York Statler Hotel.

title: WHEN TOTS JOIN ADULTS UNINVITED
description: TOGETHERNESS is one thing, but when you find that whither thy friends go their children go too, that's trouble. It's a disaster if they whither everywhere.

title: Debt Issues
description: * DCS Capital Corp., Midland, Mich., filed a shelf registration statement covering up to $400 million of debt securities. Proceeds will be used to refinance commercial paper outstanding that financed loans to Alberta Gas Ethylene Co.

title: Some Volcanoes Are Human
description: Sri Lankans are cleaning up the physical debris of last month's violence, but the political debris is not so easily cleared. One frightful week of communal clashes between the majority Sinhalese and minority Tamils left hundreds slaughtered, many most horribly.

title: Patti Diane Shwartz Weds Dr. Michael Worthen
description: Patti Diane Shwartz, daughter of Sheila Alpert Shwartz of Madison, Conn., and New York, and Dr. Alvin Howard Shwartz of South Dartmouth, Mass., was married in Portland, Conn., yesterday to Dr. Michael Worthen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Worthen of Dallas. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony in the garden of Saint Clement's Castle, owned by Wesleyan University.

title: GIANTS DEFEAT JETS IN EXHIBITION, 23-16
description: The best linebacker in professional football sat in the stands tonight and watched a rookie who played his position lead the Giants to a 23-16 preseason victory over the Jets.

title: SERVICE CHAPLAINS PONDER WAR LETTER
description: Lieut. Col. John Mahon puts in full days as a chaplain at Lackland Air Force Base here, adapting the mass to the needs of browbeaten recruits, comforting those wracked by homesickness, and otherwise helping young men and women make the harrowing adjustment to military life.

title: British Utility Proposals
description: The British Government is exploring several plans to inject private capital into the nation's gas and electric utilities, including a proposal to take the state-owned British Gas Corporation private, Government sources said today. The sources emphasized, however, that no detailed plans have yet been drawn up.

title: A BOON TO NEW YORK?
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Compromises On I.M.F. Bill
description: THE Administration barely won House approval of an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund last week. And now, in an effort to win approval of a House-Senate compromise bill this fall, Administration officials are ready to accept some of the amendments that helped attract critical Democratic and Republican votes.

title: Briton Wins Golf
description: Ken Brown of Britain sank an eight-foot putt on the final hole today to edge Vaughan Somers of Australia and Jose Canizares of Spain and win the $120,000 Dutch Open golf tournament. Brown shot a 69 for a 274 total - one shot in front of Somers, who had a 70, and Canizares, who shot a 65. The $20,000 first prize gives Brown a place on Europe's Ryder Cup team that meets the United States in October.

title: NICARAGUANS ASSERT U.S. PLANS ATTEMPT TO TOPPLE REGIME
description: Nicaraguan officials charged today that the Reagan Administration was using the Kissinger commission and prospects of Central American peace negotiations to stall for time while it focuses on an armed effort to topple the Sandinista Government.

title: Rambling Willie Sets Money Mark
description: Rambling Willie, a 13-year-old gelding, tonight became the richest American harness horse when he took second place in the fourth race at Sportsman's Park, giving him career earnings of $2,019,218.

title: FOR NEW HONG KONG ACADEMY, WORLD ARTS ROLE
description: A multilevel, vaguely triangular, $53 million building rising on the shore of Victoria Harbor here will not be the most imposing structure of this ever-changing waterfront, but it could be among the more important.

title: HOW OUR MILITARY SURGEONS MUST BE TRAINED
description: To the Editor:

title: TURTLE BAG HITS A SNAG
description: A six-year battle to save the endangered Ridley turtle has suffered a setback. Only a quarter of the transplanted turtle eggs have hatched, according to a biologist.

title: WORTHWHILE 'TINKERING' BY COMPUTER STUDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NUMBER OF SECRETS IS UP, BUT NOT BY THAT MUCH
description: For a year now, the Reagan Administration has been trying to bring order to the Federal Government's chaotic system of keeping secrets, first by making fewer secrets, then by imposing tighter safeguards to prevent them from slipping out.

title: TEST-TUBE BABOON BORN IN PRIMATE STUDY CENTER
description: A FEMALE black baboon, believed to be the first nonhuman primate conceived in a laboratory dish, has been born at the Southwest Foundation for Research and Education in San Antonio. The baby, named E. T., for embryo transfer, was born July 25, six months after its ''test-tube'' fertilization and, coincidentally, on the fifth birthday of Louise Brown, the first human conceived ''in vitro.''

title: Joe Harper, Former Anchor Of News Program, Dies at 61
description: Joe Harper, co-anchor of a WPIX Channel 11 news program from 1973 to 1976, died Friday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan after a brief illness.

title: Jury Considering Death for Mother
description: An Essex County jury deliberated for more than six hours today without deciding whether a 20-year-old mother of five children should become the first woman ever executed by New Jersey.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Tenacious Nurse Wins Use of Car
description: A 26-year-old private nurse was given free use of a 1983 Pontiac for one year after outlasting 15 opponents by clinging to the new car for more than 93 hours in a showroom.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Inmates Are Killed At Prison in Louisiana
description: Prison violence left three inmates dead of stab wounds and a fourth injured early today at the state penitentiary at Angola, the Corrections Department said.

title: No Testimony From Cowboys
description: Testimony ended today in the cocaine conspiracy trial of Lauriberto Ignacio, a former pro soccer player, without two Dallas Cowboys ever being called to the stand.

title: PHILHARMONIC FILLS PARK WITH PEOPLE AND PICNICS
description: THE performance in Central Park last night of Tchaikovsky's ''1812'' Overture, with Zubin Mehta leading the New York Philharmonic, would have been difficult to recreate in the concert hall. It was part of the opening concert in the 19th season of the orchestra's parks concerts and, according to the police, it attracted the largest audience ever for a Philharmonic concert - over 200,000.

title: Mobil-E.P.A. Accord
description: The Mobil Corporation agreed today to pay $620,000 to settle a charge by the Environmental Protection Agency that the company discharged pollutants illegally at an oil drilling site in upper Cook Inlet, Alaska. The settlement is the largest ever paid for settling violations of the Clean Water Act in the agency's Alaska, Idaho, Washington and Oregon region, an E.P.A. spokesman said.

title: G.P.U. Credit Accord
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, which owns the disabled Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant, has received tentative approval on a credit extension from a group of banks, the company said today. The revolving credit agreement, scheduled to expire Dec. 31, would be extended to March 31, 1985, if the extension is approved.

title: CHIEF OF ARMY ASSAILS INDUSTRY ON ARMS FLAWS
description: The Army's new Chief of Staff, Gen. John A. Wickham Jr., asserted today that poor performance of arms and equipment in his service was largely due to deficiencies in quality control in American industry.

title: CHINA'S DILEMMA
description: The loud objections of China's leaders to the Reagan Administration's decision to sell $530 million in arms to Taiwan must be viewed in the broader context of Peking's momentous decision to modernize China through a careful opening to the West.

title: CEILING CRASHES AT PATH CENTER, KILLING 2 AND INJURING 8 IN JERSEY
description: A 13,000- square-foot ceiling crashed down at the PATH railroad line's Journal Square center here today, killing two people and injuring eight others.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
Getty Oil Find
description: The Getty Oil Company said it made a crude oil discovery in California's Santa Maria basin, where a test well produced 3,600 barrels of oil daily in three tests. The discovery was made on block 463, about nine miles southwest of Point Arguello, which Getty acquired in May 1981 for $9.4 million and in which it has a 100 percent interest.

title: PRESIDENT SAID TO BACK AWAY FROM TAX ON FRINGE BENEFITS
description: The White House has told the Treasury not to support a new effort in the House of Representatives to tax such employee fringe benefits as free airline tickets or use of company cars, according to a top Treasury official.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST, 9, 1983
description: International

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIR WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RETURN OF LAND-SALES FIGURE FOR FLORIDA JAILING IS ASSAILED
description: The State of Florida is in a tug-of-war with the Federal Government and Canada over a 58- year-old Toronto businessman, seized outside his home two years ago by American bounty hunters and then convicted in Florida in a case involving defective land deeds.

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: RYDER'S AGGRESSIVE MARKETING PAYS OFF
description: As a college student, Tony Burns drove commercial trucks to help pay his way.

title: Business and the Law
description: THE returns are in on the fight over the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978 - and both sides are claiming victory.

title: Jury Selection Starts In Seattle Slayings Trial
description: Stringent security was in effect today as jury selection began in the trial of a 20-year- old man who is charged with killing 13 people in a Chinatown gambling club Feb. 19.

title: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lisbon Agrees To Debt Pact
description: The Portuguese Government has agreed to tough conditions from the International Monetary Fund as part of a $300 million loan agreement, official sources said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday regarding withholding taxes and foreign trade incorrectly described imports from the Caribbean that can enter the United States duty free. Textiles, apparel, leather goods and watches from the area cannot enter duty free.

title: Required Reading; So-Called Camps
description: Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, in testimony on a bill that he co-sponsored to redress the grievances of Americans of Japanese ancestry who were interned during World War II. July 27, 1983:

title: AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including realized capital gains of $45,488 for the quarter and $327,162 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: DOW DROPS BY 20.23, TO 1,163.06
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in slightly brisker trading after most major banks increased their prime lending rates.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
