description: b-Includes a gain of $288,000 from the sale of the assets of the Alaska unit, $129,000 from the sale of Arizona real estate, and income from discontinued operations of $33,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $240,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $67,000.

title: CONGRESS NOTIFIED ON CHAD SUPPORT
description: President Reagan told the leaders of Congress today that the deployment of military equipment to support Chad in its fight against Libyan-backed rebels would be for ''a limited period to meet the urgent requirements posed by the present situation.''

title: G.O.P. and Vote by Women
description: Women are voting in ever-increasing numbers in key Southern states, a trend that could threaten the 1984 election hopes of President Reagan if he should run and other Republican candidates, according to a study by a Republican consulting concern.

title: Aug. 18 Date Urged For Yanks-Royals
description: Lee MacPhail, the president of the American League, said yesterday he hoped the Yankees and Kansas City Royals would agree on Aug. 18 as the date for completion of their ''pine tar'' game and that he would like to see the matter resolved by today or Wednesday.

title: BEYOND MOTHER EARTH NEWS
description: The energy crisis may be over, but don't tell Mother.

title: GROUP INSURERS TO ADD BENEFITS FOR ALCOHOLISM
description: Group health insurers in New York State will be required to pay for at least 60 days of outpatient treatment a year for alcoholism under a bill signed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Singer Arrested On Drug Charges
description: Harold Melvin, the soul singer, and three members of his Blue Notes Band and six others were arrested on drug charges Sunday at Caesars Boardwalk Regency Hotel Casino, the police said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARRY PECK
description: Harry Peck, founder and former president of Advertising Distributors of America, a direct-mail advertising and marketing concern in Manhattan, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Free Magazine Set for Diabetics
description: Because there are so many kinds of health maintainance products that a diabetic can buy without a prescription, they can also be targets of free magazines, just like physicians.

title: Bridge: 2 Where When to Use Blackwood
description: The line between four no-trump bids that are Blackwood and those that are not is difficult to draw. Most textbooks are content to point out that direct raises of no-trump are natural, but there are other situations.

title: Chinese Flier May Seek Asylum in Taiwan
description: A Chinese Air Force colonel who flew his MIG-21 to South Korea to defect may be allowed to seek political asylum in Taiwan, where a $3 million reward awaits him, a top Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chipwich Adviser
description: Chipwich Inc. announced that it had retained the investment banking firm of Morgan Grenfell Inc. as its financial adviser to evaluate inquiries from potential purchasers. Chipwich, noting that it had ''received several approaches'' from interested companies, said Morgan Grenfell would examine each of the inquiries and advise on a course of action. Chipwich, a privately held company based in Fort Lee, N.J., makes chocolate chip cookie ice cream sandwiches and related products.

title: Ford-Toyo Mexican Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was discussing plans to build cars in Mexico with its Japanese partner, the Toyo Kogyo Company, but denied a report that two-thirds of the vehicles would be sold in the United States.

title: New Data Satellite Successful in Relay
description: The $100 million data relay satellite that was almost given up for lost four months ago has successfully ''talked'' to another satellite in orbit for the first time, officials said today.

title: C.A.B. BID ON AIRLINE BOOKINGS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board will probably issue an invitation Wednesday for comments on what rules should govern computerized reservation systems used by travel agents to book airline flights, the board's chairman said today.

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: ITT Financial Corporation is a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation.

title: Market Place; A High Return From Abroad
description: AT the end of last year, the Scudder International Fund held no positions in companies based in France, Spain or Italy. But since then, the mutual fund has made investments in all three countries.

title: LAW FIRM DISPUTES RIGHTS ASPECT OF SEX BIAS SUIT BY AN ASSOCIATE
description: A large and influential Atlanta law firm invoked the First Amendment guarantee of freedom of association today in asking the Supreme Court to rule that it could not be sued in connection with a charge of sex discrimination in choosing partners.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $37,000 for the for the quarter and $134,000,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $14,000.

title: Advertising; Videotape Promotion On Radio
description: CURRENTLY, almost all advertising for videotape runs in magazines, as does the majority of promotion for audio tapes, which also get a push in television.

title: From the Subway To the Stage
description: ''Center School Subway,'' the sign reads, ''Uptown Express.'' Among the passengers: An old woman with red stockings, a shopping cart filled with rags in a bag and a pink-feathered hat perched rakishly on her head.

title: FRANCE ASSERTS U.S. FAILED TO CONSULT ON CHAD
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today that the United States had not consulted with France before sending Awacs electronic surveillance planes and military equipment to help the Chad Government fight Libyan-backed rebels.

title: GEORGIA BONDED FIBERS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $459,229.

title: People
description: * Jean Arena and Robert Steigelman have been elected senior vice presidents at Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising.

title: A Double Victory Counted by Giants
description: According to Coach Bill Parcells, his Giants beat the Jets twice Sunday night in their exhibition opener at Giants Stadium.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Firstborn of Quintuplets Showing Improvement
description: The 5-day-old firstborn of a set of quintuplets was removed from the critical list today and breathed on her own for eight hours before being reconnected to a respirator.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SMALL STAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For the four years of high school, the school locker is a home away from home.'' - Associate Justice Daniel J. O'Hern of the New Jersey Supreme Court. (A1:1.)

title: Harvester Wages
description: Workers at an International Harvester Company plant have overwhelmingly approved a plan linking their wages directly to productivity, in return for a promise to keep the Melrose Park factory open. The four-year incentive plan, which starts in November, gives bonuses provided workers increase productivity above a plant performance index, but it would cut their pay if productivity drops.

title: JOHN OTTO SACHAU
description: John Otto Sachau, a retired investment banker, died of cancer Saturday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Holmdel, N.J.

title: Gasohol Tax Planned
description: The Treasury said it intends to impose a 4-cent-a-gallon tax on gasohol sold by producers or importers. The Treasury added that it is interpreting a section of the Internal Revenue Code as amended by the 1982 Highway Revenue Act as giving it the authority to tax the fuel.

title: NEW PORTLAND MUSEUM PURSUES A HUMAN SCALE
description: The new Portland Museum of Art - housed in the recently opened $11.6 million Charles Shipman Payson Building - is both the most ambitious museum ever built in Maine and an institution that sees itself as providing a needed alternative to a big-city museum experience.

title: Aaron's Suggestion
description: Although his name is seldom prominently mentioned when baseball observers discuss candidates to succeed Bowie Kuhn, Henry Aaron remains the only announced candidate for baseball commissioner. And he is not without ideas for the game either.

title: GAZ METROPOLITAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
SUTTON MAINTAINS POISE
description: Just before the final round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship Sunday in Pacific Palisades, Calif., Jack Nicklaus told friends that if he could shoot 65, Hal Sutton, the leader, ''would have to break par to beat me, and that's hard to do for a young player going for his first major championship.''

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Net income.

description: b-Net losses including tax credits of $323,000 for the quarter and $337,000 for the 9 months.

title: Cost Estimate Up On Kindergarten
description: School officials said yesterday that they expected the new all-day kindergarten classes to cost more than the $15 million now in the city budget for the program, because of an anticipated increase in the kindergarten population.

title: Arson Fires in California Town Sizzle in Surrounding Valleys
description: Eight fires, caused by arson, that fused together to destroy several homes, outbuildings and a century-old ferryboat, sizzled through tinder-dry brush around historic Port Costa, Calif., yesterday.

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52 as of Jan. 1, 1983. Revenue figures represent gross billings.

title: MARC RICH PAYS FINE, DROPS SUIT
description: Marc Rich & Company A.G., the big commodity-trading concern under investigation for possible tax evasion, paid a fine of $1.25 million yesterday. The fine was part of an agreement reached Friday with Government investigators to resolve a year-long fight over documents subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury.

title: INDIA'S TREES FALL TO THE AX AND FLOODING FOLLOWS
description: Gurcharan Lal, a 34-year-old farmer whose thin limbs, tattered T-shirt and faded shorts suggest what life is often like on northern India's vast, populous Ganges Plain even in the best of times, was telling what it is like in the worst, when the floods come.

title: Board Sought In Far East
description: The Vancouver Stock Exchange, one of the partners in the International Options Clearing Corporation, said today that negotiations were under way to add a Far East exchange to the clearing corporation.

Results are restated to reflect Milford and Modulus Fastener divisions as discontinued operations.

title: DiGregorio Cut
description: The Nets announced that four players from their rookie camp had been invited to join the veterans at Princeton on Sept. 28. Among the names missing was that of Ernie DiGregorio , the former rookie of the year who was attempting a comeback at age 32.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 9
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid Sept. 16.

title: PROTEST MARKS OPENING OF BRINK'S MURDER TRIAL
description: Jury selection was completed today and opening statements begun in the Brink's murder and robbery trial, but the three defendants left the courtroom in a dispute with the judge.

title: Spectra-Physics Loss of $10 Million
description: Spectra-Physics Inc., a laser development and manufacturing company, said that it had lost $10 million through a series of unauthorized foreign exchange transactions.

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 15
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $147,000 for the quarter and $96,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary credit of $25,000.

title: ELECTION LOSS PERLEXES HISPANIC POLITICIANS
description: A few weeks after an intensive voter registration drive gave Chicago its first black mayor, another mayoral election took place here in what has been called the Middle West's only predominantly Hispanic city.

description: b-After gain on debt restructure of $1,801,712, or 35 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on ''Chad at a Glance'' yesterday misidentified the former president who now leads a rebellion in the country. He is Goukouni Oueddei.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. COUNCIL URGES NEW IDUSTRIAL POLICY FOR NATION
description: The A.F.L.- C.I.O.'s executive council today called for a national industrial policy in which labor would join business and government in modernizing older basic industries and developing technologically advanced new industries.

title: AARON RENTS OF ATLANTA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SANDS HOTEL & CASINO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings include tax benefits.

title: PILOT PRESENTED BY CHAD AS LIBYAN ASSERTS PLANES DROPPED NAPALM
description: A man presented by the Chadian Government as a captured Libyan Air Force pilot said today that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces had used napalm in support of rebel troops besieging Chad's northern oasis of Faya-Largeau.

title: JACK McPHAUL
description: Jack McPhaul, a former newspaper reporter whose articles helped rescue a man from a wrongful murder conviction and inspired the movie ''Call Northside 777,'' died Saturday in a Danville nursing home. He was 79 years old.

title: Antinuclear Vigil
description: Marking the 38th anniversary of the Hiroshima-Nagasaki atomic bombings, a coalition of antinuclear groups, including the War Resisters League and the Catholic Peace Fellowship, staged the first in a week of demonstrations yesterday at 330 West 42d Street, headquarters of the Riverside Research Institute.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago net is restated for an accounting change which added 32 cents a share to net income.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 9, 1983
description: Markets

title: DRUKEN DRIVING MEETS GRASS-ROOTS RESISTANCE
description: Rowe Killingsworth, driving his truck through Oklahoma, saw an automobile moving erratically and suspected that the driver was either drunk or sleepy. He picked up his citizens' band radio and alerted another truck driver to the danger.

title: ARMY IS CHECKING TEAR GAS REPORT
description: Army investigators tried to determine today who tear-gassed a dozen campers during war games that called for Green Berets to organize ''citizens'' against a mock Soviet invasion.

title: ROYAL CROWN GETS SEARLE'S ASPARTAME
description: G. D. Searle & Company said yesterday that it had reached agreement with the Royal Crown Companies to use the pharmaceutical company's low-calorie sweetener, aspartame, in Royal Crown's carbonated soft drinks.

title: AN OLYMPIC TOUCH TO TRACK COVERAGE
description: Flipping on the television set in the middle of NBC's coverage of the world track and field championships could give a viewer the sensation of being transported into the future. Is this the Olympic Games on the screen before us? It certainly looks and sounds that way.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESORT CLOTHES: A SUCCESS STORY
description: Seventh Avenue showrooms are filled this month with new collections for the season called resort. These are warm-weather clothes, once geared to women who could spend all or part of the winter playing in a warm climate. They traditionally begin arriving in the stores in November, in anticipation of the winter- vacation season.

title: TV EXECUTIVES UPSET BY KANSAS CITY FINDING
description: Television executives and some legal experts expressed concern that their abililty to hire and dismiss on- camera news reporters and anchors could be limited as a result of yesterday's finding by a jury in favor of a television anchorwoman in Kansas City.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The age of the earth is said to be about 4.5 billion years. How was this determined?

title: LAREDO'S HOPES PLUNGE ALONGSIDE MEXICAN PESO
description: Here on the Mexican border, success is a relative thing, and for Laredo, 1981 was a boom year of heady proportions. Money poured in from Mexico, unemployment fell below 10 percent in a city where 12 to 15 percent is normal, and officials were modernizing a city government that had been wracked with corruption.

title: BINGO KING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Good Intentions
description: The Suffolk County proclamation- makers apparently pay closer attention to won-lost records than their Nassau County counterparts.

title: B. F. Goodrich
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said it had concluded an agreement to provide the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation with technology needed to make vinyl products. Financial terms were not disclosed. The arrangement will allow Sabic to manufacture 300,000 metric tons a year of vinyl chloride monomer and 200,000 metric tons a year of polyvinyl chloride using Goodrich technology.

title: Cards May Lose Herr
description: The St. Louis Cardinals have lost seven games in a row and now are in danger of losing their second baseman as well. Tommy Herr, a .323 hitter this season, underwent an arthrogram yesterday on his left knee to determine if surgery was necessary. Although the results were inconclusive, more tests are scheduled for today, and Herr, who had surgery on the knee last December, did not accompany the Cardinals to Chicago for a three-game series.

title: Topics; No Substitutions; Pizza Therapy
description: Waste not, want not'' having been bred into the national psyche, the mere thought of acres of surplus dairy products just sitting in America's warehouses induces trauma. Thus we're happy the Agriculture Department has come up with therapy in the form of the Pizza Project.

title: OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BECK-ARNLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HELPED GUIDE NEW FRENCH CUISINE
description: Jean Troisgros, one of France's most influential chefs, died today of a heart attack while playing tennis at a hotel in Vittel, a spa in eastern France. He was 56 years old.

title: Investments In China
description: Foreign concerns invested nearly $5 billion in China between 1979 and 1982, including nearly $1 billion in offshore oil exploration, the China Daily reported today.

title: POLISH PRIMATE HALTS FARM AID TALKS
description: The Polish Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, has halted discussions over a highly publicized church-state agricultural aid program and has declined to meet with the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, because the Cardinal is frustrated that his human-rights petitions have been brushed aside, a high-ranking church adviser said today.

title: Grains, Soybeans Off; Metals Down Slightly
description: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in very active trading Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Jet Defensive Line Pays a Heavy Toll; Gastineau Only Healthy Regular
description: The Sack Exchange was hurt, the quarterback was hobbling and Coach Joe Walton repeated yesterday his concern about what multiple injuries on one unit could do to the Jets.

title: JOHN BRADEMAS PLUNGES IN
description: IN 1981, when former Indiana Representative John Brademas became president of New York University, an official close to the selection committee observed that ''Brademas seems to know everyone worth knowing in this country.'' And that he does.

title: TEST CASTRO TO LEARN IF HE WOULD NEGOTIATE
description: Both the United States and Cuba have reacted positively to the peace process initiated by the Contadora countries - Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama. It is time for Washington to test Fidel Castro - seriously, not cosmetically. This would give added credibility to the United States' policy in the hemisphere and help defuse some of the divisions at home. But any test has to be realistic about what Washington can expect from Mr. Castro.

title: An Eagle Departs
description: After 12 seasons as an offensive tackle in the National Football League, the last eight of them as a starter with the Philadelphia Eagles, Stan Walters has decided that he has had enough. Walters was injured in an exhibition game last week but said yesterday that the reason for his decision was lack of motivation.

title: LACK OF TEACHERS COULD SLOW GAINS IN SCIENCE
description: MORE and tougher science and mathematics requirements in the nation's high schools may hurt rather than help achievements in those fields, experts warn. Present low science and mathematics requirements are, of course, a serious deficiency; but far more pressing is the need for adequately trained teachers and an improved curriculum.

title: Tesoro Petroleum
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it had agreed to purchase 1.3 million shares, or 8.4 percent, of the Enstar Corporation's common stock from Roy M. Huffington Inc. at $31 a share. Huffington is Enstar's largest shareholder. Tesoro also said it had previously purchased 172,00 Enstar shares in the open market.

title: MCA DECLINES 3.6%
description: The Loews Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the second quarter soared 54.3 percent, while MCA Inc. reported a 3.6 percent earnings decline.

title: Merck Buys Unit
description: Merck & Company, a major United States pharmaceutical concern, will acquire for about $10.2 million a controlling interest in Torii Yakuhin K.K., a Japanese company that specializes in antibiotics, an official of the Japanese companysaid. Merck, based in Rahway, N.J., had agreed last week to acquire about 51 percent of the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company, another Japanese company.

title: RILEY'S DATASHARE reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After a loss of $86,800 from investments. c-Net income.

title: READY-TO-USE FORMULAS FOR FINANCE TO PHYSICS
description: THE equation-processing program for experienced computer users reviewed last week, TK! Solver, supplies such standard mathematical functions as absolute value, hyperbolic tangent and cosine, to name but a few, with which to solve complex formulas. But it does not in itself provide any applications equations. This is one of the program's strengths, in that instead of being limited to a couple of dozen equations, you can construct a mathematical model for almost any problem you might wish to solve, enter the variable data, and have the computer take over from there, doing all the number crunching for you.

title: SYNAGOGUE HIRES WOMAN AS RABBI
description: A synagogue in Clifton Park, N.Y., has become the first in Conservative Judaism to hire as a rabbi a woman who is a Conservative Jew. There have been several instances of Conservative synagogues hiring women in the Reform movement as rabbis.

title: Biegenwald Offers 3 Not-Guilty Pleas
description: Richard F. Biegenwald pleaded not guilty today in the slayings of three 17-year-old girls.

title: THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Indian Pt. Sirens TestedinRockland
description: A test of the sirens in Rockland County for an emergency at the Indian Point nuclear power plants was called a success today by Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello and Consolidated Edison, operator of the Indian Point 2 reactor.

title: Whale 'Roundup' Raises Opposition
description: Sea World wants to round up 100 killer whales for research in a project opposed by environmental groups.

title: Randolph Resists Feeling Rusty
description: Between June 27 and Aug. 5, Willie Randolph played in one baseball game. On July 12, he reinjured a hamstring muscle, forcing a second stay on the disabled list.

title: Tugboat Six Aboard Are Rescued
description: A 75-foot tugboat sank last night in the Kill van Kull, a busy waterway between Staten Island and Bayonne, N.J., blocking navigation through the strait into Port Newark and the Port of Elizabeth until the boat can be salvaged, the Coast Guard said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Consolidated Foods Corp., Chicago, announced the sale of L'erin Cosmetics to Andrea Products Corp.; terms were not disclosed.

title: Latins Should Settle Conflict Without the U.S., Paris Says
description: The Foreign Minister of France urged today that the Central American countries settle the region's conflict themselves, without United States intervention, saying in a radio interview: ''Those countries know the situation better than the United States.''

title: CIPRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
China's Trade With a Friend
description: Hu Yaobang, general secretary of China's Communist Party, tonight told Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, that the oil company's cooperation with China would win the Chinese people's friendship.

title: KOCH AGAIN URGES MCGUIRE TO STAY IN POLICE POST
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had again appealed to Robert J. McGuire to remain as Police Commissioner at least through 1985, when the Mayor's second term expires.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $9,737,000 for the quarter and $24,199,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a realized investment loss of $9,906,000 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $1,702,000 for the 6 months.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Grey Advertising Profit Up by 16.6% in Quarter

title: G.M. Imports
description: The General Motors Corporation will begin importing medium-duty trucks produced by the Japanese auto maker Isuzu by the end of the year, a trade journal reported.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Crime on Subways Increased in July
description: Major crimes on the city subways increased last month, in part because of a rise in incidents in which jewelry was snatched from passengers, the Transit Authority Police Department reported. The were 292 necklace snatchings last month, compared with 221 in July 1982.

title: Humana Offering To Yield 13.927%
description: A $100 million issue of Humana Inc. 13 3/4 percent debentures due in 2013 is being offered at a price of 98 3/4, to yield 13.927 percent, through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: To Collect a Debt to Children
description: A recent Census Bureau report says a 25-year-old female college graduate can expect lifetime earnings of $474,000. A male can expect $1,165,000. The reason for the enormous difference is simple. Contrary to much current propaganda, men and women have not exchanged roles, nor is society structured to let them share roles. It is still mostly the female who takes care of the kids, tends the ailing relatives and gives up the job when a spouse is transferred. The result is a lot of time-outs for a working woman, and much lower income.

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago per share figures were restated to reflect 50 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 26.

title: METS' OROSCO WINNER ON ERROR IN 10TH
description: The Mets and their amazing relief pitcher, Jesse Orosco, extended winning streaks tonight in a 6-5, 10-inning victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Winfield Gets An Apology
description: Paul Godfrey, the chairman of Metro Toronto, apologized to Dave Winfield last night over the dispute in Toronto last week when the outfielder accidentally killed a sea gull with a thrown ball. ''I said I was sorry for the way he was treated,'' said the municipal official, who was at Yankee Stadium for the doubleheader with the Blue Jays as part of a family vacation.

title: STUDY WARNS AGAINST SCRAPPING L.I. NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Monthly electric bills on Long Island could go up 76 percent in three years if the Shoreham nuclear plant does not open and 56 percent if it does open, according to a study released today by the Hudson Institute.

title: ALOHA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $302,000 for the quarter and $220,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income. d-Including a tax credit of $250,000.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Star to Team America
description: Mark Peterson , the North American Soccer League's player of the year in 1982, was acquired by Team America yesterday from the Seattle Sounders. Peterson, a 24-year-old from Tacoma, Wash., is currently tied for eighth in N.A.S.L. scoring with 30 points, including 13 goals. He is coming to Team America as part of a process for building the club in preparation for the qualifying rounds of the 1986 World Cup, to be held at the end of the 1984 N.A.S.L. season.

title: Subways Are Delayed
description: Tens of thousands of subway riders were delayed up to 15 minutes during the morning rush hour yesterday because of repair work on the Manhattan Bridge, the Transit Authority said.

title: BUFFTON OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BALBONI TRAVELING AN UNHAPPY ROAD
description: Steve Balboni could not forget the first time he was summoned to Yankee Stadium. He was in Toledo with the Columbus Clippers, the Class AAA farm team in the Yankee organization, with few belongings in his suitcase, little reason to expect a promotion and no idea of how frustrating his future as a Yankee would become.

title: Dunes Hotel Deal in Jeopardy
description: A complicated $185 million deal for brothers Clifford and Stuart Perlman to purchase the financially troubled Dunes Hotel appears to be in jeopardy.

title: SAYS IT HOPES FOR DEMOCRATIC RULE
description: The Reagan Administration reacted cautiously today to a coup in Guatemala that installed Defense Minister Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores as provisional President, in place of Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.

title: SEARCHES LIMITED IN JERSEY SCHOOLS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that students in school are protected by the Fourth Amendment against unreasonable searches and seizures.

title: UNITED STATES SHELTER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Truck Sales Up 29.6%
description: The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said sales of all trucks last month increased 29.6 percent, to 220,983, from 170,496 a year ago. The trade group said July sales of light trucks with less than 10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight went up 32.6 percent, to 204,136, from 153,956, and sales of heavier commercial trucks rose 1.8 percent, to 16,847, from 16,540.

title: Old Friends Keep Up On Current Events
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger, his Secretary of State, lunched together yesterday at Le Cirque, the restaurant on East 65th Street near Fifth Avenue, where both are regular customers.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: Mortgage Rates Jump
description: The interest rate charged for new mortgages jumped in July to 13.24 percent, the first increase in a year, the Government reported today. The new rate, quoted by major lenders on long-term, fixed-rate mortgages for newly built homes, was well above the 12.98 percent recorded for June, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include interest income of $2,382 for the quarter and $194,088 for the year. Year-ago results include interest income of $208,131 for the quarter and $1,206,764 for the year.

title: Oilers Drop Perry
description: Among the five players released yesterday as the Houston Oilers continued paring their squad was Vernon Perry , a strong safety who had been with the team since 1979. Perry, whose release continues a breakup of the Oilers' troubled secondary, faces charges in Jackson, Miss., of cocaine possession and selling alcohol after hours. . . . According to a source within the United States Football League, Doug Williams , quarterback of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, has agreed to switch leagues and sign with the Oklahoma Outlaws.

title: ROCK: ELVIS COSTELLO AND HIS BAND
description: BRITISH new-wave rock of the late 1970's has produced two undeniably great songwriters. One is Sting, of the Police. The other, Elvis Costello, is still struggling to find an American audience wider than the hip intelligentsia that has supported him through his metamorphosis from a punkish rocker into an ambitious pop classicist. And Sunday, in the first of three local appearances this week at Pier 84, the pop-classicist side of Mr. Costello shown more brightly than ever.

title: CARL ROSEN, 65, PHILANTHROPIST AND CHIEF OF PURITAN FASHIONS
description: Carl Rosen, a philanthropist and the chairman and chief executive officer of the Puritan Fashions Corporation in New York, died yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $240,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: BANKS' PRIME RATE RAISED, DEPRESSING THE STOCK MARKET
description: The nation's major banks raised their prime rate yesterday to 11 percent from 10 1/2 percent.

title: GUATEMALAN COMMUNIQUE ON OUSTER OF THE PRESIDENT
description: Following is a communique broadcast today by Guatemalan military leaders on their decision to depose President Efrain Rios Montt and appoint in his place Defense Minister Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores, as transcribed and translated by The Associated Press:

title: CANADIAN MANOIR INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: RANCHERS EXPLORATION & DEVEOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,599,000.

title: MCGILL MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
KALVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $387,000.

title: Prisoners in U.S. Reported At High in the First Quarter
description: The number of state and Federal prisoners rose by 13,288 in the first quarter of 1983 to a record 425,678 inmates, the Justice Department announced today.

title: FOXMEYER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings do not reflect application of proceeds from an offering of $2,030,854 common shares on July 12.

title: WEIGH IMPEACHMENT IN AN ILLEGAL WAR
description: Do we have any means to stop the President from waging an illegal war? On July 28, the House voted 228 to 195 to stop the invasion of Nicaragua by a mercenary army hired by the Central Intelligence Agency. President Reagan's response was, in effect, ''Try and stop me.'' Congress has not yet had recourse to what undoubtedly is its most effective check on the President - the possibility of impeachment.

title: Sri Lanka Restores Curfew in Some Areas
description: The Government reimposed a nighttime curfew in parts of Sri Lanka today to prevent new outbreaks of the ethnic violence that has already resulted in more than 300 deaths.

title: MIDWESTERN CONTRIBUTIONS TO ACID RAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SEE LESS STRAIN IN SOVIET TIES
description: On the strength of some favorable developments in several fields of negotiation with Moscow, senior Administration officials say the decline in Soviet-American relations has stopped. But they are uncertain whether a genuinely positive trend has taken hold.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY NAMES NEW PRESIDENT
description: Seagate Technology, a fast-growing maker of disk drives for computers and word processors, has named Tom Mitchell president and chief operating officer.

title: Libya Is Said to Send Arms to Upper Volta
description: Libyan aircraft arrived in Upper Volta today, apparently carrying military supplies to bolster the country's new Government, according to diplomats here.

title: AMERICAN FINANCIAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHONE WORKERS' STRIKE CAUSING SOME LOCAL SERVICE DELAYS
description: Flashing white lights and waving hands signaled for help yesterday at the Whitehall Directory Assistance bureau in Manhattan, as supervisors- turned-operators fielded thousands of requests for New York City phone numbers.

title: HUGE PARTICLE DETECTOR TO AID IN SEARCH FOR ELUSIVE NEUTRINOS
description: THE first steps are now being taken toward the construction of by far the largest atomic- particle detector ever built, a gigantic project in which 10 universities in four countries hope to place instruments in an enormous volume of water three miles beneath the surface of the Pacific Ocean off Hawaii.

title: Representative Stokes Is Convicted in Maryland
description: Representative Louis Stokes, the Ohio Democrat who is the chairman of the House ethics committee, was convicted tonight of driving under the influence of alcohol and running a red light in a Washington suburb last March.

title: NEW WAYS AT HAND FOR TOXIC DISPOSAL
description: SCIENTISTS, engineers and industrial managers are now developing a variety of methods aimed at eliminating the need for the toxic-chemical landfills that have in recent years been posing widespread public-health concerns. If a number of present trends continue, these landfills may eventually be largely replaced by other means of disposal, and those sites that remain may well be far less hazardous.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Revenue figures represent fee income.

title: ACQUISITION OF NORTHWEST ENERGY SET
description: The Northwest Energy Corporation, one of the nation's leading gas companies, said yesterday that it had accepted a $575 million takeover bid from an investor group headed by Allen & Company Inc., the Wall Street investment house.

title: Mount St. Helens Lets Off Steam
description: Mount St. Helens, which left 57 people dead or missing in a catastrophic eruption three years ago, released a plume of ash and steam for the third straight day today.

title: Topics; No Substitutions; Caviar on the Cob
description: It's an August ritual in the Hudson Valley. You get up early, before the sun has a chance to climb too high, and drive to a farm stand, maybe an old hay wagon with a makeshift roof. On the wagon the farmer has piled a few burlap sacks filled with the cool, firm ears harvested by hand that morning.

title: FROM A SPIRIT OF BIPARTISANSHIP CAME PRODUCTIVITY
description: Congress has gone on vacation after one of its most productive periods in recent history, and to this point, the 98th session of the nation's legislature could well be called ''the bipartisan consensus Congress.''

title: Chess: Castling on Opposite Wings Tu
description: It's a jungle out there when the players castle on opposite wings. Rooks become rhinoceroses, bishops become boas, knights become night stalkers, the queen even more of a virago than usual and every pawn a panther.

title: WOMAN IN TV SEX BIAS SUIT IS AWARDED $500,000 BY JURY
description: A woman who said she was demoted on a television news program because her employer considered her ''too old, unattractive and not deferential enough to men'' was awarded $500,000 in damages today.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes pretax gains from marketable securities of $116,000 for the quarter and $162,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $493,000 for the quarter and 6 months, and a loss of $38,000 for the 6 months from marketable securities.

title: Ma Bell's Last Child Gets a Name
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company chose a new name yesterday, bringing to an end the scramble for the labels and symbols that will identify Ma Bell's offspring when they set off on their own next Jan. 1.

title: CADENCE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $393,000 for the quarter and $1,367,000 for the 6 months and extraordinary gains of $81,000 for the quarter and $162,000 for the 6 months.

title: GUATEMALAN ARMY TOPPLES PRESIDENT IN A BRIEF BATTLE
description: The Guatemalan military overthrew the Government of Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt today in Guatemala's second coup in 17 months.

title: BAIRD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid in March 1983.

title: EMETT & CHANDLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $118,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earning are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid June 20.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 9, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $99,495 for the quarter and $122,859 for the 6 months.

title: IN COMMAND IN GUATEMALA
description: Brig. Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores, who became the provisional President of Guatemala today, is a career army officer with a reputation for devotion to the military and to its hard-line solutions to the country's problems. His ascension to power is expected to result in a change less in substance than in the style of the Government, which has been run for the last 17 months by Brig.Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, whose moralistic attitude had increasingly angered military officers, businessmen and politicians.

title: QUANTECH ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HUNGER FOR SALT FOUND TO BE POWERFUL INSTINCT
description: THE human hunger for salt, that bane of modern nutritionists, is not just a quirk of habit or upbringing, wide- ranging studies show. Instead it appears to be a deep-seated biological drive as fundamental and almost as powerful as those of thirst, sex and maternal behavior.

title: Return of the Perseids
description: Every year, on about August 11, the earth passes through a stream of debris thought to have been shed by Comet Swift-Tuttle. The result is a shower of meteors whose ''shooting star'' streaks all radiate from the constellation Perseus.

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amax Copper Inc., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed William D. Jones president of its United States Metals Refining Company division.

title: CUTOFF ORDERED OF U.S. FUNDS FOR A HOSPITAL
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered an immediate cutoff of Medicare and Medicaid funds to Jewish Memorial Hospital in Manhattan on the ground that its deficiencies ''threaten the health and well-being of its patients.''

title: EXIT 'CLOCKWISE'
description: To the Editor:

title: I.M.F. Contributions
description: Only 19 of the 146 countries in the International Monetary Fund have completed action on their shares of an increase of $32 billion in I.M.F. contributions, fund officials said today.

title: NO PROGRESS REPORTED IN TELEPHONE STRIKE TALKS
description: The first nationwide telephone strike in more than a decade did not affect direct dial telephone services around the country today, but many callers faced delays in getting telephone personnel to help them find an unknown number, place a person-to-person long distance call or repair a phone.

title: Canadian Deficit Grows
description: Canada's budget deficit rose to $2.89 billion in April from $2.7 billion in April 1982, the Finance Department said today. Revenues rose to $2.92 billion from $2.60 billion a year ago, and spending rose to $5.81 billion from $5.30 billion last year. The Canadian dollar is worth about 81 cents in United States currency.

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kuwait Stock Rules Backed
description: The Kuwaiti Cabinet has approved new rules for the country's official stock market aimed at preventing fraudulent stock transactions, the Kuwait news agency said today.

title: 2 LETTERS TO CHURCH PARLEY ASSAIL SOVIET
description: Two letters from dissidents accusing Soviet leaders of violating religious rights were made available today at the Sixth Assembly of the World Council of Churches.

title: COMMODORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for the year ended June 30, 1982 were equal to less than 1 cent per share.

title: ANXIETY RISES FOR CHILDREN OF BITTER COPPER STRIKE
description: The 3-year-old daughter of a nonstriking copper worker is in a hospital, shot in the brain. Children vandalize property or stand at picket lines jeering anyone who crosses.

title: WRIGHT, WILLIAM E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Missouri Officials Seek Dioxin Reimbursement
description: Missouri officials today asked three individuals and four companies to reimburse the state for the cost of cleaning up dioxin contamination at two sites.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Texas Pacific Oil's Thai Concessions
description: Thailand's mineral resources department said there is nothing to prevent the Texas Pacific Oil Company of Dallas, a unit of the Seagram Company, from selling its petroleum concessions off the Gulf of Thailand, but it had not been officially informed that such a move was planned. A spokesman made the statement when asked to comment on a published report that Texas Pacific had offered to sell its concessions for $120 million because of failure to reach a gas price agreement with the Government.

title: TARNISHED TECHNOLOGY ISSUES
description: In spite of the sharp tumble that technology stocks have taken in the last six weeks, analysts and other industry experts say that they expect a turnaround before the year ends.

title: INCREASE IN CLASS TIME IS GAINING IN FAVOR
description: CHILDREN across the country face the prospect of longer school days and longer school years as a result of a growing conviction that a key to improving elementary and secondary education is making sure that students get more of it.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a reduction of $16,600,000 as a result of a decsion to sell a significant portion of Williams Exploration Company's production and undeveloped acreage in the Rocky Mountain area and a re-evaluation of the balance of its holdings in this area.

title: IVACO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PURITAN FASHIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Police Made No Arrests In Park During Concert
description: The police said the audience at the Philharmonic concert last night was one of the best-behaved crowds ever to attend a concert in Central Park.

title: Free Series at Cloisters
description: ''Saturdays at the Cloisters,'' a free weekly series of lectures, crafts demonstrations and other events, begins on Sept. 10 at the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park.

title: Philippine Plane in Mishap
description: A Philippine Airlines plane with 81 people aboard skidded off a wet runway at Cagayan de Oro today and became mired in deep mud, officials said. Nobody was hurt but the airport, 500 miles south of Manila, may be closed until Wednesday. The plane was arriving from the southern city of Davao.

title: Histories of Two Parks Exhibited at the Library
description: Exhibitions celebrating the histories of Central Park and Washington Square Park will be on view from Sept. 1 to Oct. 18 at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: CRAXI'S COLOSSAL TASK
description: Though Bettino Craxi, as head of the 44th postwar Government, is Italy's first Socialist Prime Minister, his new coalition is anything but Socialist, either in composition or platform, which both mirror faithfully those of its recent predecessors. Nor, given Italy's intractable economic problems and political divisions, is the new Government likely to set new records for cohesiveness or duration.

title: Media Blitz Is Planned For New A.T.&T. Logo
description: By end of the week, modern media permitting, a majority of Americans will have seen the new logotype of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which in mid-July was stripped of its Bell name and Bell symbol by a Federal judge.

title: HOW OUR MILITARY SURGEONS MUST BE TRAINED
description: To the Editor:

title: Rival Palestinian Groups Again Battle in Bekaa
description: Heavy fighting erupted today between rival Palestinian guerrilla factions in the Bekaa, the eastern Lebanon valley, the Beirut radio reported.

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
CORRECTION
description: Question 9 of the News Quiz in some copies on Saturday incorrectly described the incidence of murder last year in Japan. Among all homicides, only 13 could be termed wanton murders.

title: Soiling the Altar of Freedom
description: In the crude arithmetic of terrorism, two wrongs make a headline. An indifferent world has indeed been reminded of past Turkish crimes against Armenians by a wave of killings morally indistinguishable from the massacres they protest.

title: COMBATANTS OF TEEN-AGE UNEMPLOYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dr. Zalman Grinberg Is Dead; Aided Death-Camp Survivors
description: Dr. Zalman Grinberg, a survivor of Dachau who served as chairman of the Central Committee of Liberated Jews in Munich after World War II and founded St. Ottelein Hospital near Munich and staffed it with physicians and nurses who had been in Nazi death camps, died of staphylococcal septicemia Sunday at Nassau (L.I.) Hospital in Mineola. He was 70 years old and lived in Seaford, L.I.

title: New Jersey Bank Merger
description: A Federal regulatory agency has approved the merger agreement between First National State Bancorporation and First National Bank of New Jersey, paving the way for the merger next month, officials announced today. The boards of the directors and shareholders of both institutions previously approved the action, which will result in a statewide bank holding company with assets of $6.1 billion and 192 offices.

title: TORSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $682,000 for the quarter and $860,000 for the 6 months, and a special gain from the sale of land of $1,538,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Triple Play Helps Twins' Victory
description: Gary Gaetti, the Minnnesota third baseman who started a triple play in the fourth inning, and Tom Brunansky led off the fifth inning with homers tonight as the Twins beat the California Angels, 4-2.

title: PEOPLES RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
LEWIS TAKES WORLD 100 TITLE
description: Twenty meters from the finish of the 100-meter dash final, a wide grin swept across Carl Lewis's face today: his first of three possible titles in the world track and field championships was assured.

title: ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT: THE PRIORITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: 34-1 Shot Wins Wilson Pace by a Nose
description: Only a nose separated the two top finishers in harness racing's richest event tonight, and a 34-1 shot, Carls Bird, was the winner of the $1.7 million Woodrow Wilson Pace over Trutone Lobell.

title: Hush Dear Wins
description: Hush Dear, a 5-year-old mare who has been selected to run in the Arlington Million Aug. 28, tuned up today with an easy 2 1/2-length victory in the second and slower division of the split Diana Handicap on the turf at Saratoga Race Track.

title: MIAMI LAWYER HANDLES 2 STORMY BANKRUPTCIES
description: When two of south Florida's most flamboyant entrepreneurs - William Alderdice and Alberto Duque - faced a dark financial hour earlier this year, both turned to a Miami lawyer, Thomas Tew.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 OKLAHOMA POLITICIANS ON TRIAL
description: Two of the most powerful figures in state politics, Speaker of the House Dan Draper and Joe Fitzgibbon, the majority leader, went on trial today on charges of committing vote fraud in an effort to get Mr. Draper's father elected to the Legislature.

title: Italians Leading
description: Italy's hopes of winning its first Admiral's Cup grew tonight as Pasqualle Landolfi's Brava built a four-hour lead in the final event, the Fastnet race. Brava, sailed by Gary Weisman, an American, was first round Fastnet Rock off the coast of Ireland. Late today, most of the yachts were still struggling to reach the turn point.

title: THE THEATER: CHRISTIE PLAY
description: THE scene is the lobby of the King Solomon Hotel in Jerusalem, which, at the moment, seems filled with members of the Boynton family - a loony daughter, two weak-willed sons and a sinister stepmother who once was a prison warden. Clearly the older woman has an overdue ''Appointment With Death,'' which happens to be the title of the Agatha Christie play currently running at the Apple Corps Theater.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PRIZED ROOKIE SPLITS LEAGUES
description: When the San Diego Charger rookies gathered for a minicamp shortly after the college draft last spring, Gary Anderson, one of their three first-round choices, ran and caught the ball so impressively that Coach Don Coryell and his staff began designing plays to take advantage of his versatility.

title: HISPANIC LEADERS OPEN VOTER DRIVE
description: Emboldened by their growing numbers and new political strength, 200 Hispanic American leaders from all over the country convened here today to open a national drive to register a million more of their people to vote by next year.

title: Washington State Pays More to Borrow Now
description: The State of Washington, home of the Washington Public Power Supply System, is paying a higher interest rate on its borrowings as a result of the utility's default on $2.25 billion of bonds for two nuclear power plants, securities dealers said yesterday.

title: Sensitive Issue
description: Although she has been a world- class marathon champion for many years, Grete Waitz of Norway remains relatively shy about her status. That was evident again at the first world track and field championships in Helsinki, Finland.

title: YANKS SWEEP BLUE JAYS
description: As recently as two weeks ago, when the Blue Jays were still clinging to their lead atop the American League East, a New York-Toronto series in early August appeared to be the perfect matchup for a pennant race. Last night before 40,598 at Yankee Stadium, it was the perfect mismatch.

title: Power Demand Sets A Record for Con Ed
description: The Consolidated Edison Company experienced a record demand for electricity yesterday as temperatures in its Manhattan, Bronx, Queens and Westchester County service areas hit a high of 95 degrees.

title: Rum Campaign By Kenyon & Eckhardt
description: Supplying the answer to one of the generation's most popular but least answered questions, Kenyon & Eckhardt's creative people have come up with, ''Rum. It's what's happening.''

title: BANKS GLOOMY AS ZAIRE DEBT GROWS
description: In the mid-1970's, Zaire, struggling to work its way out from under what at the time was viewed as a mountain of foreign debt, was the subject of one of the first rescheduling programs attempted by Western banks.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ONE WOMAN, AT 80, CONTINUES QUEST TO SOLVE PUZZLE IN PERUVIAN DESERT
description: DRAWN across the desert floor here in one of the driest spots on earth are a mysterious series of huge animal figures, geometric designs and a crisscross of long, incredibly straight lines.

title: Tough Clothes For Tough Times
description: Punk fashion, mod fashion, French fashion, Japanese fashion and now, ''protective fashion.''

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROPER LOBBYING AT LEGAL SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: 4rauma Centers
description: Four Manhattan hospitals have been designated ''911 trauma centers,'' the Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday.

title: HEAD OF TEXAS GAS TO FILL CSX POST
description: The CSX Corporation moved quickly after the Supreme Court refused to extend a temporary injunction against its purchase of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation.

title: Financial Corp. Sues Two Ex-Employees
description: The Financial Corporation of America filed suit seeking $70 million in damages from two former employees it charged with libeling the company in an effort to depress the price of its stock and thwart its acquisition of the First Charter Financial Corporation.

title: PHILODENDRON HEAT ENTHRALLS BOTANISTS
description: IN the dead of night all across America - in backyard gardens and maybe even living rooms, medical offices and corporate lobbies - a species of philodendron is busy producing a gigantic flowering stalk that, using a biological process previously thought to exist only in animals, heats part of itself up to 114 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE two materials making news in accessories are about as different as they can be: reptile skins and rubber. Some of the most luxurious reptiles can be found at a shop called Giovanna, at 202 East 60th Street. From Italy come shoulder bags of matte-finish crocodile that are structured yet roomy - a very businesslike look for the successful female executive to wear with suits and tailored coats. For evening, the store has a snakeskin clutch in black, taupe or garnet red that is as shiny as patent leather. Prices range from about $350 to maybe $800. We did say they were for successful women.

title: Interest Rates Broadly Higher
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, as traders continued to worry that the Federal Reserve could decide soon to tighten monetary policy another notch.

title: P & F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Upside-Down Danger
description: Hanging from the ceiling upside down wearing gravity inversion boots can harm your back and send your blood pressure through the roof, according to a Chicago osteopath. After studying 20 volunteers, Dr. Ronald M. Klatz said some effects of the latest health fad were potentially lethal.

title: Fannie Mae Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said its $500 million issue of debentures due Feb. 10, 1986, would be offered today at a price of 100 with a coupon of 11.70 percent. The association, known as Fannie Mae, is a federally chartered, privately owned company that maintains a secondary market for residential mortgages.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: THE ETERNAL PINE-TAR CASE
description: The George Brett bat issue remains as sticky as, well, you fill in the blank.

title: Miller on Kuhn
description: Marvin Miller, the former director of the Major League Baseball Players' Association, is doing some reading these days that some might think a bit ponderous for a man who's supposed to be playing tennis, dining with his wife and otherwise enjoying the pleasures of retirement. ''At the moment, I'm reading a deposition Bowie Kuhn gave over three days in a pending lawsuit about who owns the baseball television rights, the owners or the players,'' Miller said. ''And I don't know whether to laugh or cry about some of this.''

title: A.T.& T. IS SAID TO PLAN CHANGES IN CREDIT CARD
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to issue new, thicker credit cards with magnetic stripes to replace the very thin plastic cards now used by millions of consumers, according to sources in the credit card business.

title: The Hairs in the Guatemalan Soup
description: Yesterday's coup in Guatemala removes an eccentric President who ruled as if from a pulpit, and puts a tough paratrooper in his place. The new President, Defense Minister Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores, has the backing of the armed forces and possibly of other countries. Just Sunday, he met in Tegucigalpa with the defense chiefs of Honduras and El Salvador as well as officers from the U.S. Southern Command in Panama. In their frustration with the evangelical Efrain Rios Montt, they may have endorsed a quick fix - it's happened before in Guatemala.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BEAUTIFUL WOMEN; UGLY SCENES. By C. D. B. Bryan. 374 pages. Doubleday & Company. $16.95. WHEN it comes to depictions of marital strife and domestic discord, we tend to think of several contemporary literary models: Edward Albee's play ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf'' and such novels as John Updike's ''Couples,'' Philip Roth's ''My Life as a Man'' and Richard Yates's ''Revolutionary Road.'' C. D. B. Bryan's new novel ''Beautiful Women; Ugly Scenes'' possesses a similar visceral impact. The book is unwieldy, its prose at times opaque, but its portrait of a man and his collapsing marriage is also powerful and disturbing, and it invests the familiar banalities of upper-middle class life with seriousness and art.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Not Far From Wisdom
description: Nations usually erect battlefield monuments to celebrate glorious victories. It is with no small pride that the visitor discovers a very different and much more creditable motive for a national monument near the small Montana town of Wisdom. The monument marks the battlefield astride the Big Hole River, where in 1877 the Seventh Infantry under Colonel John Gibbon tried unsuccessfully to surround a group of Nez Perce Indians, led by the dignified and articulate Chief Joseph.

Another 600 A.M.C. workers will remain on indefinite layoff at the auto maker's Toledo, Ohio, Jeep plant, but Mr. Tippett said those workers may be called back later if A.M.C.'s new Jeep XJ model sells well.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALMOST every professional cook I know has his or her own special method of cooking lobsters. Some even go a mile or so into the ocean to get a gallon of water in which to cook them. Others prefer to steam them on a bed of fresh wet seaweed. Both techniques result in a fine cooked lobster.

title: A SIMPLE INDIAN WORK
description: GOOD cooking, no matter what the style, is the sum of many simple tasks performed well. By the same token, the best kitchen equipment is simple in design and made with the best materials. I thought about this recently when the Indian wok pictured here was brought to my attention by Julie Sahni, a cooking teacher and the author of several books about Indian cuisine.
