It blamed the fall on the cost of opening a Detroit office to serve Volkswagen/Porsche- Audi, the continuing strength of the dollar and clients shifting spending to the fourth quarter.

title: REFAC TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: EVIDENCE OF SECOND PLANETARY SYSTEM FOUND
description: The possibility that an infant planetary system is circling a nearby star has been raised by new evidence from an orbiting observatory.

title: Cable and Wireless
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., a British telecommunications concern, said it planned to lay networks of fiber optic cables along railroad lines in the United States.

title: 9 States Sue Copper Units
description: Nine states have filed suits against six major copper manufacturers, charging that they conspired to fix the price of copper pipe, Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York said today.

title: Digital Net Off 29.3%; Genstar, McDermott Up
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, citing price cuts and lower-than-expected equipment sales, reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth fiscal quarter, ended July 2, plunged 29.3 percent, while revenues increased 13.9 percent.

title: Hannah Coming Back
description: John Hannah has patched up his differences with Coach Ron Meyer and General Manager Pat Sullivan and will rejoin the New England Patriots, ending a brief retirement.

title: Landlord Sentenced In Harassment Case
description: A Brooklyn landlord and one of his sons was sentenced to probation and two other sons to 60 days in jail for crimes that were part of what authorities said was a harassment campaign to drive tenants from rent-controlled apartments.

title: CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SOME GRUMBLING IN THE I.M.F. ATRIUM
description: In the atrium below gracious porticoes, giraffelike Benjamin fig trees and flags of 146 nations, the functionaries come and go, talking of international finance, Lord Keynes - and the Congress of the United States.

title: FRANCE SENDING 180 SOLDIERS TO CHAD AS INSTRUCTORS
description: The French Defense Ministry announced tonight that it was ordering the dispatch of 180 paratroopers to Chad, where they will serve as instructors for Government forces battling Libyan-backed insurgents.

title: Synthetic Fuels Head May Quit
description: The president of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, Victor A. Schroeder, said today that he might resign over a controversy involving charges that he engaged in improper internal lobbying and had awarded consulting contracts to former business associates without competitive bids.

title: FREE M.D. CARE? YES
description: Does providing free medical care for those who cannot pay jeopardize doctors' income? On the contrary, fulfilling this moral obligation may prove to be an excellent marketing and political strategy.

title: OPERA: 'DAS RHEINGOLD' AT THE BEACON
description: THE whole venture seems comically improbable on the face of it. Here in New York, the New York City Opera has conspired along with its orchestra to deprive us of summer opera, and has never attempted any of that summa of operatic endeavor, Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.'' The Metropolitan Opera hasn't staged the complete ''Ring'' in years, or attempted it in decades within the short time-span Wagner envisaged.

title: THIS YEAR, THE PARTY POLITICAL CHIEFS ARE WOMEN
description: As the Republican and Democratic National Committees gear up for the 1984 Presidential election, they will both enter the contest for the first time with women as political directors.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Well, Not Quite

title: SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,758,000 from debt reduction. c-Net loss.

title: Gulf Oil Results
description: The Gulf Oil Company published test results from a well off the southeast coast of Ireland that Industry Minister John Bruton called encouraging. But it was still too early to say whether the well was commercial, he said. The figures had appeared in Irish newspapers over the previous few days, spurring hectic trading in the shares of Atlantic Resources, one of Gulf's partners in the well.

title: STUDY SAYS SEX GAP IN LIFE EXPECTANCY IS TIED TO SMOKING
description: Cigarette smoking is the ''overwhelming'' reason that men have a shorter life expectancy than women, but a rising incidence of smoking among teen-age girls suggests that women may lose their statistical advantage, according to a study of more than 8,300 people in Pennsylvania whose results were released today.

title: EARLY ACTION SET IN A.F.L.-C.I.O. ON 1984 CHOICE
description: The A.F.L.- C.I.O.'s executive council, seeking to strengthen its political muscle, voted today to advance the labor federation's endorsement of a Presidential candidate to October from December.

title: PERSIAN GULF NATIONS WORRY AS OIL SPILL GOES ON UNCHECKED
description: For the last seven months, some 4,000 to 5,000 barrels of oil a day have been spewing into the Persian Gulf from Iranian oil wells damaged in the war with Iraq.

title: AVIATION GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $366,000 for the quarter and $1 million for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $276,000. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1983.

title: PINOCHET ADDING CIVILIANS TO CHILEAN CABINET
description: Bending to public pressure, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean leader, shuffled his Cabinet today to include a majority of civilians in what officials called a step toward the restoration of democracy.

title: Toyotomi Kogyo Suing Kero-Sun
description: A Japanese kerosene heater manufacturer is suing Kero-Sun Inc. for $55 million, claiming the American company breached a contract by refusing delivery and payment for more than 200,000 heaters.

title: A.M.C. LOOKING PAST RED INK
description: Executives of the American Motors Corporation are not trying, as the saying goes, to lose money on each sale, but make it up in volume. It just looks that way at the moment.

title: Prices Move Modestly Higher; Low Quotes Draw Buyers
description: Prices for Treasury notes and bonds rose modestly yesterday, as investors and speculators were attracted to prices that were at or near the lowest levels since last September.

title: Boy, 10, Is Killed Playing With Guns
description: A 10-year-old Brooklyn boy was shot and killed yesterday by his 13- year-old cousin as they played with two handguns they had found in a bedroom, the police said.

title: Execution Is Stayed For Louisiana Convict
description: A Federal District judge today blocked the execution of Alvin Moore Jr., a convicted murderer who was scheduled to die in the electric chair Thursday.

title: GUATEMALAN LIFTS CURB ON FREEDOMS
description: Guatemala's new Chief of State, Brig. Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores, ended restrictions on civil liberties today and said that people should be able to pursue ''all the activities guaranteed by the law, including political activities.''

title: Quintuplet Returned To Critical List
description: Surgery to close a perforated intestine put the oldest Gaither quintuplet back on the critical list today, but Indiana University Hospital officials say she is expected to recover.

title: G.M. Sets Shutdown
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that a shutdown at its southeast Baltimore assembly plant would last for 20 weeks, starting at the end of next March. The shutdown is to allow for completion of a $270 million renovation of the nearly 50-year-old plant.

title: Peter Jennings Named Sole ABC Anchor
description: Peter Jennings, for the last five years the foreign-desk anchor of ABC's ''World News Tonight'' newscast, will be the program's sole anchor, the network announced yesterday.

title: Car Inventories Lower in July
description: Inventories of new American-built cars fell to a 48-day supply last month, a 10-year low, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: Woman Is Electrocuted
description: Shirley Foster of Washington, D.C., was electrocuted Monday when a yogurt-dispensing machine developed a short circuit in the cafeteria of the National Institutes of Health, the authorities said. The woman, whose age was not available, was killed as she tried to assist another woman who had received a shock from the machine, officials said.

title: ORIOLES BEATEN BY INDIANS, 4-3
description: Julio Franco tripled home the tying run in the sixth inning and scored on Ron Hassey's sacrifice fly, giving the Cleveland Indians a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

title: U.S. Envoy to Mideast Returns to Beirut
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the United States special envoy, who is seeking a way to get foreign troops out of Lebanon, returned here tonight to brief Lebanese leaders on his visits to Syria, Saudi Arabia and Jordan.

title: Moses Extends Hurdles Streak
description: The legend of Edwin Moses grows larger by the race. Tonight, the 27-year-old American won the 400-meter hurdles in the first world track and field championships, and he did it with one shoelace untied over the last three hurdles.

title: 'FANNIE FARMER' IN A NEW ROLE
description: WHEN people come up to Marion Cunningham and ask if she is really Fannie Farmer, her deep-blue eyes crinkle as she laughs and replies as kindly as possible, ''Even I am not that old!''

title: SCIENCE DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Grandchild for Lindsay
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay is a grandfather.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Police Captain Is Accused Of Unauthorized Use of a Car
description: Capt. Richard V. McDermott of the New York City Police Department was suspended without pay yesterday by William J. Devine, the first deputy police commissioner, for unauthorized use of a department vehicle.

title: No Headline
description: The Treasury yield curve is a widely used tool for investors and traders.

title: Bridge: Tournament
description: The Yankees had their Old-Timers' Day last month, and the American Bridge Association followed suit this month: Seven of the top-ranked players now active gathered with seven stars of yesteryear on a panel Sunday at the New York Statler Hotel, where the association is holding its Summer Nationals.

title: Change of Pace For Valentine
description: When George Bamberger was the manager of the Mets last year and his pitching staff was struggling, he looked longingly from time to time at Ellis Valentine, the strong-armed right fielder, as he tossed a ball on the sidelines during pre-game warm-ups. If he ever ran out of pitchers in a runaway game, Bamberger said, he would be tempted to try Valentine on the mound.

title: PHONES WORKING WELL DESPITE STRIKE
description: On the third day of the nationwide telephone strike, heavy users of communications equipment said yesterday that the complex network of phone lines, computers and switching systems that make up the Bell system appeared to be holding up well.

title: Film Crew Reports Reprisals for Testifying
description: Some members of the ''Twilight Zone'' movie crew say they are being blackballed for cooperating with an investigation of the helicopter crash that killed actor Vic Morrow and two children during filming.

title: CARHART PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include net gains of $1,675,581 in the quarter and $1,695,326 in the 6 months on leasehold sales.

title: Kurnit Leaving Calet for Raboy
description: Clients of Epstein, Raboy Advertising began to learn yesterday that there would soon be a new man at the shop, none other than Shepard Kurnit, agency founder, corporate good citizen and frequently one of the voices of the industry's conscience. The 58-year-old executive will be leaving Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector, where he has been chairman, to fill a gap left by the death in December of Mitchell Epstein, chairman of Epstein, Raboy.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BASED ON THRILLER, 'I MARRIED A SHADOW'
description: THROUGH a series of incredible but entertaining coincidences, two pregnant women exchange identities at the beginning of ''I Married a Shadow,'' the romantic thriller by Robin Davis that opens today at the Paris Theater.

title: Appeals Court Backs Army In Dispute Over Bid Rigging
description: An appellate court panel today dismissed charges that the Army was improperly influenced by Congressional pressure when it tried to deny Government contracts to a contractor that pleaded no contest to bid rigging.

title: ON THE ODDS OF FINDING A COOL SUBWAY CAR
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 common stock split paid on Oct. 15, 1982.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: JOBLESS IMPACT STATEMENTS
description: Economic policies bestow visible, intended benefits, but they also unintentionally victimize invisible groups. Congress, however, makes little attempt to forewarn or even identify victims. Fortunately, a simple remedy is available.

title: MANITOWOC CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Cuban Will Be Sworn To Kissinger Panel
description: The White House said today that a Cuban-born economics professor from Yale University, Carlos Diaz-Alejandro, would be sworn in as a member of the Reagan Administration commission on Central America despite objections by conservative groups.

title: Citibank Takeover Of Australia Bank
description: The Australian government has given conditional approval to a bid by New York's Citibank to take over the Australian merchant bank, Grindlays Australia Ltd. Grindlays is a subsidiary of Grindlays Bank P.L.C. of Great Britain, 49 percent owned by Citibank and 51 percent owned by Grindlays Holdings Ltd., a British public company.

title: YO-HO-HO AND A BOTTLE OF POUILLY-FUISSE!
description: THERE is a sailor who is content with a six-pack of beer or a bottle of rum. And there is the sailor who loves to go to sea with a wine that sails well. But not everyone agrees on what kinds of wine are most seaworthy. Do wines get seasick? Are reds - especially fine old reds - damaged by the boat's motion? Does Champagne suffer on the water? Is the old saw - white if by sea, red if by land - the wine rule to sail by?

title: ONE YEAR OF BULL MARKET KEEPS HOPES HIGH
description: A year ago this Saturday, when stock prices started to climb, there were few signs that the advance would turn into the biggest bull market since the Depression.

title: PLAN TO COMMEMORATE DR. KING'S 1963 MARCH MEETS RESISTANCE
description: A demonstration to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the historic civil rights march in Washington in August 1963 is suffering difficulty in the planning stage. Major Jewish organizations and some civil rights leaders are not supporting it. Organized labor, while endorsing it, has not thrown its full weight behind it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE EIGHT MILLION. Journal of a New York Correspondent. By Meyer Berger. 334 pages. Columbia University Press. $30, hardbound; $8.95 paperback.

title: FIRST CHICAGO IN PACT FOR AMERICAN NATIONAL
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its American National Corporation, owner of the American National Bank and Trust Company, to the First Chicago Corporation, owner of the First National Bank of Chicago, for $275 million.

title: U.S. RIGHTS PANEL CRITICIZES ADMINISTRATION'S VIEW OF SEX BIAS ROLE
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights criticized the Reagan Administration today for endorsing a narrow interpretation of the law barring sex discrimination in school and college programs receiving Federal aid.

title: LAFARGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Lafarge Corp. became a U. S. holding company for General Portland Inc. and Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd. in 1983.

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,600,000, or 45 cents a share, from the sale of land.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results include pre-tax expenses of $130,000 in connection with an unconsummated tender offer.

title: SALVADOR PARTIES BACK VOTE DELAY
description: Leaders of five of the six political parties representated in El Salvador's Constitutent Assembly have formally recommended that presidential elections be delayed until February, election commission members said today.

title: Union Pacific Sells Gas Unit
description: The Union Pacific Corporation announced the sale of its Mississippi River Transmission Corporation subsidiary to the Midcon Corporation, for $256.2 million in cash.

title: DEAK PICKS EXECUTIVE TO BECOME PRESIDENT
description: George J. Vojta, 47, has been named president of Deak & Company, succeeding Otto Roethenmund, who becomes vice chairman.

title: Accident to Twiggy Cancels Performance
description: Last night's performance of ''My One and Only'' at the St. James Theater was canceled after a stage prop on which Twiggy was perched tipped over and fell on her during a duet with Tommy Tune, the director and star of the musical.

title: Man and Machine
description: Schedules at the United States Open tennis tournament will be done by computer this year for the first time, and the man who used to do the job wonders if the machine is up to the task.

title: RCA ENDS PLAN TO SELL HERTZ
description: After 18 months on the auction block, the Hertz Corporation, a subsidiary of the RCA Corporation, is no longer for sale, RCA said late yesterday afternoon.

title: IN NICARAGUA, SIGNS OF RIGHTS ABUSES
description: To the Editor:

title: RALLY LIFTS DOW 5.21, TO 1,168.27
description: A late rally enabled the stock market to erase some of its early losses yesterday and close mixed, even though many investors remained apprehensive over rising interest rates.

title: THE HO-HUMS OF AUGUST
description: What is going on this August could be just the usual midsummer retreat - except for its resemblance, politically, to the months that have gone before it. The past year or so has been a time, for the American people, of evident withdrawal from political responsibility - and the dog days of August are an apt time to consider why.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,082,000 for the quarter and $1,447,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: 6 ARE CONVICTED OF PARTICIPATING IN BIG DRUG RING
description: A man, his wife and four other defendants were convicted yesterday of Federal charges involving the operation of a major heroin ring in New York City.

title: CANADA PERMANENT MORTAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Rating

title: White House Tax Comment
description: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today that the President had no plan to tax fringe benefits such as free airline tickets, discounts on clothes and use of company cars.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS BILL TO AID JEWS IN DIVORCE CASES
description: Jewish husbands who refuse to grant their wives divorces under Jewish religious law will be barred from obtaining civil divorces under a measure signed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $135,000 for the quarter from the sale of land and a gain of $57,100 for the 9 months from the sale of land.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Victory Would Put Next Cup Series in '87
description: The New York Yacht Club said today that if the United States entry successfully defended the America's Cup next month, the next series would be in 1987 rather than 1986, the customary three-year hiatus. Accordingly, the deadline for challenging would be Dec. 31, 1984.

title: Economic Scene; Back to Basics On Budgets
description: THE collaspe of faith in the Phillips curve-the purported trade-off between inflation and unemployment that was generally accepted in the 1960's - has led to a renaissance of the classical doctrine about Government finance, both among economists and statesmen. But evidently, the doctrine has not yet decisively influenced the United States Government.

title: Tribune Co. Turnaround
description: The Tribune Company reported earnings of $21.6 million for its second quarter, reversing the $29.7 million loss recorded in the same period of 1982.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN QUANDARY
description: To the Editor:

title: BOEING DEFENDS INSTRUMENTS IN TRIAL OVER CRASH
description: ''My instrument. Check your instrument,'' the frantic pilot of an Air India jetliner told his co-pilot as the 747 fell toward the Arabian Sea.

title: CARDIAC RESUSCITATOR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FREE SERVICES? NO
description: About a decade ago, when I was writing about medical and related affairs for The New York Times, I received a letter from a Manhattan woman who wanted me to ''expose'' a physician as a greedy monster. This physician, she wrote, had simply refused to provide her, free of charge, a psychoanalysis that might have lasted several years.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Babe Parilli was named offensive coordinator of the Denver Gold by Coach Craig Morton , who is familiar with Parilli's work as a coach. As quarterback coach of the Denver Broncos from 1977 to 1979, Parilli was credited with helping Morton make a comeback as the club's quarterback. . . . Fred Smerlas , the Buffalo Bills' holdout nose tackle, said he had renegotiated his contract and would report to the Bills' training camp. . . . Eamonn Coghlan , who holds the world best for the indoor mile, has entered the Fifth Avenue Mile Sept. 3.

title: Market Place; The Attraction Of Put Options
description: THE stock market's sharp decline recently has focused attention on put options, those contracts allowing holders to sell 100 shares of a stock at a set price during a specific time period. Speculators buy puts in hopes of reaping profits from falling stocks, while some investors may purchase these options as a form of portfolio insurance.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Barrier of Language Keeps Cambodian in Jail
description: A Cambodian facing a 10-day sentence on a shoplifting charge has spent over three months in a Texas jail, in part because he could not understand Vietnamese interpreters sent to interview him, officials say.

title: 2 Injured as Car Crashes Into Store
description: A speeding car went out of control early today and crashed into a Westchester County delicatessen, injuring the two people in the car and igniting a fire that destroyed the store, the state police said.

title: JERSEY BELL REPORTS 25 CASES OF VANDALISM DURING STRIKE
description: Vandals attacked and damaged 25 separate telephone cables and switching posts of the New Jersey Bell telephone system during the three days of a nationwide strike, the company reported early today.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a gain of $154,102 from the sale of the company's distance measuring equipment business lines.

title: IMPROVING BREAST SELF-EXAMINATION
description: A MORE scientific method of breast self-examination than that now employed was likened to the interpretation of Braille dots by the blind when it was introduced at the opening of the first MammaCare Center here yesterday.

title: AMERICAN PUBLIC RADIO EXTENDING ITS NETWORK
description: The mythical town of Lake Wobegon in Minnesota means music to the ears of more than two million public-radio listeners around the country.

title: Blue Is Questioned In Cocaine Inquiry; Some Royals Interviewed
description: The pitcher Vida Blue, released by Kansas City last week, is among several current and former members of the Royals who have been questioned in connection with a Federal cocaine inquiry, the United States Attorney in Topeka, James Marquez, said today.

title: Salvadoran Train Blown Up
description: A force of about 300 left-wing guerrillas ambushed and blew up a freight train today in central San Vicente Province, 30 miles from San Salvador, military sources said. Armed guards on the train fought a three-hour battle with the guerrillas who flagged the train down as it was heading through a rural area.

title: U.S. HAILS REMARK BY NEW GUATEMALA CHIEF
description: The United States today welcomed assurances from the new leader of Guatemala that he planned to restore democratic rule.

title: OAK HILL SPORTSWEAR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $112,000 for the quarter and $224,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $533,000 for the quarter and $996,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings reflect a 1-for-2 reverse stock split last month. The company was known formerly as Biomedical Sciences Inc.

title: PATH STATION TO BE CLOSED A WEEK TO ERECT SAFETY SCAFFOLDING
description: The PATH train station in Journal Square here will remain closed for about a week while scaffolding is installed under ceilings similar to the one that collapsed Monday and killed 2 people and injured 10, PATH officials said today.

title: Cause of Sinking Of Tug Is Sought
description: Divers today examined a tugboat that sunk in the Kill Van Kull, blocking the waterway. The six crewman aboard the tug were rescued when she sank Monday at 10 P.M.

title: Heller to Sell American National to First Chicago
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its American National Corporation, owner of the American National Bank and Trust Company, to the First Chicago Corporation, owner of the First National Bank of Chicago, for $275 million.

title: Cohen Part of Trio To Buy the Celtics
description: The Boston Celtics were sold tonight by Harry Mangurian to three businesmen, including Allen H. Cohen, who holds an interest in the New Jersey Nets.

title: MINIMUM SIZE OF STRIPED BASS RAISED BY STATE
description: Governor Cuomo today signed legislation sharply limiting the size of striped bass that can be legally caught in New York waters. The law is intended to reverse a sharp decline in the bass population on the Atlantic coast.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BALL BEARNGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PLAYS
description: The winner, Alberto Cova of Italy, beamed. A loser, Fernando Mamede of Portugal, cried. Mohammed Kedir of Ethiopia complained about being spiked, and Martti Vainio just missed winning a medal for the host country.

title: EX-MAYOR ELECTED IN CLEVELAND RACE
description: Former Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich, who held Cleveland's top office when the city plunged into fiscal default in 1978, won a seat on the City Council in a runoff election today.

description: b-There were no comparable share earnings for the year-ago periods because Kentron was a division of the LTV Corporation.

title: ARGOSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1983.

title: Polish Prelate in Hospital
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Polish Primate, was hospitalized for tests today, a church statement said. It did not identify the 53-year-old Cardinal's ailment, but Western diplomats said they had been told he had a gall bladder complaint.

title: Florida Police Chief Held In Federal Rackets Case
description: Five men reputed to be members of the Gambino crime family in New York and a police chief who has been a member of the Democratic National Committee were arrested today on loan sharking and bribery charges, the F.B.I. said.

title: Rolla N. Harger Dies; Invented Drunkometer
description: Dr. Rolla N. Harger, who in 1931 invented the Drunkometer to test intoxicated drivers, died Monday at his home here. He was 93 years old.

title: AUGUST IN JAPAN: HIROSHIMA, NAGASAKI AND BASEBALL
description: Matter of factly, as though he were recounting some minor experience on the subway that morning, he told how he probably would have died had atomic bombs not been exploded over Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: Futures Prices Decline For Corn and Soybeans
description: Despite the deteriorating condition of the corn and soybean crops, many futures traders again decided to take profits yesterday. Others kept their long positions but hedged them by selling equivalent amounts of contracts short.

description: Latest results include sales and earnings of Graham Electronics Supply Inc., acquired effective February 1983.

title: Autopsy Finds Homicide In Nursing Home Death
description: An autopsy has revealed that a third woman who died at a Philadelphia rest home earlier this year had been raped and murdered, the authorities said.

title: Politics at the Post Office?
description: Removing statues of former leaders is standard politics in some parts of the world, but here? Leo Sheiner wonders.

title: News Analysis
description: August was the crucible for Administration economic policy in 1981 and 1982, and it will be again in this third year of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

title: TRANSMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $88,000 related to the exercise of a stock option by the president of the company.

title: 1984 Democratic Candidates Are Urged to Hold Debates
description: One hundred House Democrats today urged the party's Presidential candidates to agree to a series of nationally televised debates this year.

title: REAGAN STUDIES PROPOSALS TO HELP CITIES ON THE U.S.-MEXICAN BORDER
description: President Reagan today received a series of proposals that Federal agencies be directed to channel Government help to economically troubled communities along the Mexican border.

title: Cricket Pioneer
description: Bert Smith refuses to be daunted by American resistance to imported sports - soccer, for example - and the West Indian native is devoting himself to promoting cricket in this country.

title: New Times Square Sign
description: The latest Times Square sign, between those of Canon and Citizen and surrounded by at least 18 other ads from Japanese manufacturers, is from Gold Star Electronics, a Korean company.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE person's fingers turn painfully blue, then white and numb in the cold, and even when not cold, his fingers are curled under as if his hands were claws. Another's facial skin has become tight and shiny, except around the mouth where she's as wrinkled as an old woman. One man has trouble breathing. Another has frighteningly abnormal heart rhythms. One woman's joints are painfully swollen and stiff as if arthritic. Another has problems swallowing and digesting food and has lost a great deal of weight.

title: Article 092023 -- No Title
description: The Harris Corporation said it had won a contract from the Comsat General Corporation worth more than $100 million.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: DYSLEXIC STUDENTS TO SKIP SOME TESTS
description: Under a new law, Massachusetts high school students with dyslexia and other language- learning disabilities no longer must take standarized aptitude tests to gain admission to state colleges and universities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is not France that is taking the initiative of starting the internationalization of the conflict.

title: Hot Line Talks Are Held
description: An American delegation held talks with Soviet officials today on ways of improving the Hot Line telex link between the White House and the Kremlin. President Reagan has proposed improving the link to provide more reliable means of contact in the current tense international situation.

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rockland Is Suing To Shut Indian Pt.
description: Rockland County filed a petition in Federal court here today, requesting that the nuclear reactors at Indian Point be shut down because emergency evacuation plans were inadequate.

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $98,000 for the quarter and $1,669,510 for the 9 months. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $21,000 for the quarter and $8,000 for the 9 months.

title: Helicopter Safety
description: ''This is called a pro-foxes contingent,'' said City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger, looking over helicopter-industry representatives who had come to testify yesterday at a Council hearing on helicopter safety. ''They're asking us to let them guard the chicken coop.''

title: SCREEN: BY FASSBINDER, 'BERLIN ALEXANDERPLATZ'
description: Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby that appeared in The New York Times of July 10, 1983. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza Cinema and Vandam Theater.

title: A Head Start
description: While the track and field world championships are winding up this weekend in Helsinki, Finland, 500 youngsters between the ages of 9 and 14 will be running and jumping for medals of their own in the finals of the Hershey's National Track and Field Program. The six-year old program, organized through local recreation departments, begins with meets around the country that feed talent into district and state competition and on to the national final in Hershey, Pa.

title: JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KOCH SEEKS CHANGE IN 2 PORT PROJECTS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed to change the terms of two multimillion- dollar waterfront projects and was immediately criticized by the other partners - the Port Authority and the state governments of New York and New Jersey.

title: Nigeria Challenger Leads President in Vote Count
description: Chief Obafemi Awolowo, a veteran politician defeated by President Shehu Shagari for the presidency in 1979, was ahead of Mr. Shagari today in incomplete returns from the presidential election Saturday.

title: LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $214,442 for the latest quarter and $130,174 for the year- earlier period and investment gains of $27,717 and $43,120 for the latest and year-earlier periods, respectively. c-Operating loss d-After loss from discontinued operations of $214,442 and investment loss of $27,163. e-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $192,665 and investment gain of $193,170.

title: Polish Debt Talks
description: Western creditor banks have told Poland that it must reply by Friday to proposals to reschedule $1.5 billion due in 1983 principal payments, banking sources said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: YES, we have no bananas, but we have two things to say on the subject. No. 1, bananas mean us no harm, really, even though at least two residents of the Big Apple, maybe more, are exhibiting symptoms of bananaphobia, which is to say, an irrational fear of elongated yellow fruit.

title: VINES THAT BLOSSOM AT DAWN OR DUSK
description: IN the morning before leaving for work, and then again at night upon returning, Kenneth Roman Jr., president of Ogilvy & Mather, checks two vines that clamber over a homemade trellis on his 16th-floor Manhattan terrace. An avid gardener, he enjoys the blossoms that open at dawn or dusk.

title: THE RECOVERY IN CAR RENTALS
description: The nation's rental car industry, benefiting from an upturn in air travel and an increase in demand for the used cars it sells to the public, is apparently recovering after two stagnant years.

title: PHONE TECHNOLOGY KEEPS PUBLIC FROM FEELING STRIKE IMPACT
description: The strike by 675,000 telephone workers against American Telephone and Telegraph and the Bell System illustrates a difficult, growing problem for labor unions, labor experts said yesterday: the inability of striking unions to have significant impact when the struck business is highly automated.

title: THERMODYNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings for the latest quarter were less than 1 cent.

title: Nuclear Referendum Upheld By Panel in Massachusetts
description: The State Ballot Law Commission has refused to remove from the November ballot a local referendum that would declare Cambridge ''nuclear free'' and ban all work related to nuclear weapons within city limits.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for 6 mos to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Corrected from Wednesday's editions.

title: NORRIS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp. announced that it had sold its lawn and garden tractor subsidiary, Wheel Horse Products Inc., for $8 million, to an investment group headed by Wheel Horse managers.

title: Rouge Steel Talks
description: The United Auto Workers union said it would resume wage and benefit talks with the Ford Motor Company at its Rouge, Mich., steelmaking subsidiary. Ford had said its Rouge Steel unit, the nation's seventh-largest steelmaker, would shut down part of its mill operations starting Monday, laying off 1,000 workers. Ford decided to partially close some of the unit's operations after failing last May to sell a major stake in the unit to a Japanese consortium led by Nippon Kokan K.K. It said the talks collapsed after the union declined to accommodate a substantial cut in wages and benefits.

title: BASKETBALL PAST RELIVED
description: Oscar Robertson, retired as a player for nearly 10 years and with a touch of gray in his sideburns, stood beside the empty court in the near-empty arena at Kutsher's Country Club Tuesday evening. He was waiting to be brought a basketball.

title: Joseph Matrange
description: Joseph Matranga, a former liquor sales executive and retired president of Local 2 of the Liquor Salesmen's Union, died Tuesday at his home in Dunedin, Fla. He was 72 years old and formerly lived in Westbury, L.I.

title: A FULL CHANGE OF MIND ABOUT RICHARD STRAUSS
description: A CRITIC'S change of mind is not generally a sharply defined event, like the changing of the guard. No ruffles and flourishes, no stamping of feet, no slapping of rifles. Shifts in his opinions and values tend to take place so gradually that he may be astonished and a little embarrassed when the change has become too obvious to overlook, even by himself. He is not hiding anything, usually. He simply may be the last to know.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $72,000 for the quarter and $13,000 for the 6 months. c-Including equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $122,000 for the quarter and $83,000 for the 6 months.

SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Mercantile Merger
description: The Mercantile Texas Corporation and Southwest Bancshares said today that they had reached a definitive merger agreement.

description: b-Includes capital gains of $4,333,000 for the quarter and $6,440,000 for the 6 months. c-After a capital loss of $337,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $3,412,000 for the 6 months.

title: GEOKINETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: POREX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
KOCH ABOLISHES TIMES SQ. PACT WITH THE STATE
description: New York City yesterday pulled out of an agreement with the state's Urban Development Corporation to redevelop Times Square and said it would complete the $1 billion plan itself.

title: Boston TV Station Sued For Sex Discrimination
description: A former assignment editor at WCVB-TV has sued the station for $1.5 million, alleging sex discrimination because she was demoted after a maternity leave.

title: RECOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid April 28.

title: U.S. and Canada Steel Talks
description: Canada is asking the United States to consider compensatory measures for its recently announced quotas on imports of speciality steel, American officials said today.

title: JUDGE BARS MARC RICH DEBT
description: Marc Rich & Company International Ltd., the commodity trading firm that has spent the last year and a half resisting prosecutors' requests for subpoenaed documents, yesterday asked a Federal judge for 12 more days to produce the documents.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $82,000 for the quarter and $189,000 for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $50,000.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PROTECTING JOINTS IN FURNITURE
description: Most owners of wooden furniture feel that dusting and polishing regularly and correctly and watching out for scratches and rings is all that is necessary. They are not usually aware that proper treatment of joints is equally important.

title: Pride a Factor in Celtic Sale
description: Harry Mangurian knew that the three men who wanted to buy the Boston Celtics from him had the money to do so, but he also wanted to make sure that they would perpetuate the tradition of the team, the most successful in the history of the National Basketball Association. Red Auerbach, the Celtics' veteran general manager, is sure that Mangurian was convinced.

title: BRIEFING
description: Oh, Those 'Old Values'

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the decision of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council to advance the date of the labor federation's Presidential endorsement incorrectly described the procedure. The federation's general board is to recommend a candidate to the convention.

title: MISSION INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEON SIGN, OUT 4 YEARS, GLOWS AGAIN IN BOSTON
description: To people visiting this city of the old North Church, a neon sign may seem less than historic. But to many Bostonians, the red, white and blue Citgo sign in Kenmore Square, which was relit tonight for the first time in four years, is a historic landmark.

title: G.M. Shutdown
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would close its southeast Baltimore assembly plant for 20 weeks, starting at the end of next March, to prepare for production of a new type of vehicle that G.M. has not identified. G.M. had announced the shutdown previously, but had not said when it would start or how long it would last. The shutdown is to allow for completion of a $270 million renovation of the nearly 50- year-old plant.

title: JURY REJECTS DEATH PENALTY FOR MOTHER
description: An Essex County jury tonight rejected the death penalty for a 20-year-old Irvington woman it convicted two weeks ago of the beating death of her 3-year-old son.

title: World Church Council Upholds Activist Role
description: The Sixth Assembly of the World Council of Churches ended today by addressing several global issues and vowing to maintain its activist stance.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIDES SAY U.S. MAY EASE ARMS STANCE AT GENEVA
description: Preliminary results from a new interagency study show that the United States may be able to relax demands for deep cuts in the throw weight of Soviet long-range missiles.

title: Q & A
description: Q. An 11-by-14-foot crawl space that is 42 inches high and has a concrete floor lies under an extension on our house. The space is cross-ventilated by two sliding slots 7 1/2 inches high by 15 wide. A window that connects the crawl space with the cellar is kept closed in the winter because a great deal of cold air comes through the slots. To keep the crawl space warmer, I would like to replace them with regular glass windows. Does this sound logical?

title: REVIVING BRICK-MAKING CRAFT
description: THE Royal River brickyard, a dusty lot strewn with heaps of clay, stacks of brick and 100- year-old machinery, looks more like an archeological dig than a restorationist's haven.

title: DATRICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Peace Marchers on Way
description: Aloft building on East 38th Street, bought recently by the Buddhist group Rissho Kosai-Kai, provided sleeping-bag space this week for 120 Scandinavian peace activists. Today they will start walking to Washington by way of Staten Island.

title: Divided Loyalties
description: The Detroit Red Wings signed a star player, announced it at a big news conference and called the National Hockey League office to register the new player's name on Detroit's reserve list. There was just one problem: His name was already on another team's reserve list.

title: OPERA: 'DIE WALKURE'
description: THE BOSTON LYRIC OPERA Company, a plucky organization of modest means, has had the splendid audacity to mount the Everest of music dramas. This week, at the Beacon Theater, the company is presenting Richard Wagner's mammoth ''Ring des Nibelungen,'' popularly known as the ''Ring'' cycle.

title: Bat Dor Dancers of Israel to Appear
description: The Bat Dor Dance Company of Israel will make its Manhattan debut at the Joyce Theater on Sept. 19 in a season that runs through Oct. 2. The company's repertory of 15 dances will include works by Paul Taylor, Jiri Kylian, John Butler, Robert Cohan and Domy Reiter-Soffer.

title: SPEECH CLASS HELPS WOMEN AT THE PODIUM
description: THE heart starts to pound, the upper lip trembles, the mouth dries out, the eyes blur, the butterflies start fluttering in the stomach. Many people know the meaning of these symptoms: It is time to give a public speech.

title: LIFELINE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $72,021 for the quarter and $97,810 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $1,641 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TV: 'THE LOUDS 10 YEARS LATER'
description: YOU remember the Louds. Ten years ago if you did not see them on television, you read about them in newspapers and magazines. They were everywhere, Bill, Pat, the five children, an upper middle-class family from Santa Barbara, Calif., telling us about themselves while we hung on listening to every word. HBO is offering a new documentary about their lives: ''American Family Revisited - The Louds 10 Years Later.'' It will be seen at 8 tonight.

title: Norway Oil Plan
description: The Norwegian Government and oil companies exploiting the Ekofisk field in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea have agreed in principle on a $2 billion water injection project to enhance crude oil recovery, Oil Ministry officials said. Work on the project, which could yield an extra 190 million barrels of oil during the remaining life of the field, is due to start in April 1984 and should end in 1991. The Phillips Petroleum Company Norway, the Ekofisk operator, has about a 37 percent interest in the field. Other interests include Norske Fina A.S., Norsk Agip A.S., Norsk Hydro Produksjon A.S., Elf Aquitaine Norge A.S. and Total Marine Norsk A.S.

title: State Boxing Bill Signed Into Law
description: Governor Cuomo has signed into law an omnibus boxing safety bill requiring the use of thumbless gloves, neurological examinations of all fighters both before and after their bouts, and a 90- day suspension of any fighter who is knocked out.

title: SHUTS STREETS AND BIG STORES
description: A raging underground electrical fire in midtown Manhattan yesterday plunged the garment center and the city's busy Herald Square commercial district into a chaotic, extended power failure.

title: LeRoux Loses in Suit
description: Buddy LeRoux and two limited partners failed today in their attempt to take control of the Boston Red Sox. In a 113-page decision, Judge James P. Lynch Jr. of Suffolk County Superior Court ruled that Haywood Sullivan and Jean Yawkey, two of the team's general partners, were correct in their contention that LeRoux, the third general partner, had no right to assert his control on June 6.

title: East German Economy
description: A decline in East Germany's economic growth was arrested in the first half of 1983 and workers' pay rose slightly, but consumers had less to buy, according to a report released here today. The report, by the German Institute for Economic Research, said produced national income, East Germany's key economic indicator, rose 4 percent, compared with the target for the year of 4.2 percent. Industrial production increased 3.8 percent.

title: Empire Swim Mark Set
description: The Empire State Games opened tonight with the ceremonial lighting of the flame, which will burn until the closing exercises on Sunday.

title: CALENDAR: URBAN GARDENING
description: Urban Gardeners'Courses, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, 212-622-4433. Beginning Saturday from 10:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will give a series of three courses for urban gardeners on planting and transplanting. The instructor, Jill Garfinkel, will give slide presentations and demonstrations.

title: West German Uptrend Seen
description: The West German economy will expand by nearly 1 percent this year and grow more rapidly in 1984, a Government economist said today.

title: Bridge: Association Looks for a Way To >TO>
description: The power failure in the Herald Square area yesterday created almost unprecedented problems for the organizers of the Summer Nationals of the American Bridge Association at the New York Statler Hotel.

title: ADM. PINHEIRO DE AZEVEDO, 66
description: Adm. Jose Batista Pinheiro de Azevedo, a navy career man who became Prime Minister and oversaw Portugal's first democratic elections in 48 years, died of a heart attack today.

title: FROM A POLISH CELL
description: The message got out through Polish underground sources. It protested Chile's arrest of union members and students for demonstrating against the Pinochet dictatorship. ''I express to the political prisoners,'' it said, ''my admiration and solidarity.'' It was signed: Adam Michnik, Investigation Prison, Rakowiecka Street, 37, Warsaw.

title: Sambo's Plan
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc. of Carpinteria, Calif., said a United States Bankruptcy Court judge approved a plan that would convert up to 206 of its Season's Restaurants into two franchises of the Grace Restaurant Company, a division of W. R. Grace & Company.

title: LET MEN AND WOMEN BE EQUALS BEFORE THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

description: b-After a $23,000 reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income including a tax credit of $28,000. The company is listed on the Philadelphia and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gullickson's 2 Hits Help Defeat Mets;  Expos 5 Mets 3
description: Al Oliver, the National League batting champion last season, got the 2,499th and 2,500th hits of his major league career tonight. Bill Gullickson, a pitcher with no known batting skills, got the 25th and 26th hits of his major league career. Gullickson's hits, both doubles, proved more instrumental in helping the Montreal Expos beat the Mets, 5-3.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday on the RCA Corporation's decision against selling its Hertz car rental subsidiary was incomplete in some editions. A supplementary article appears today on page D1.

title: 11 KILLED IN CRASH IN BORDER PURSUIT
description: Eleven men, all but two believed to be Mexican nationals, were killed this morning when their automobile was struck broadside by a tractor-trailer carrying 25 tons of hay.

description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in February.

title: OIL GLUT LEADS TO FISH GLUT
description: The rest of the world is awash in oil these days, and there's an awful lot of dried fish here to prove it.

CHECKER MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest 6 months reflect a gain of $2,365,800 from the sale of subsidiary assets. Year-ago results reflect a gain of $4,946,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of subsidiary stock.

description: Results were translated at the rate of 43.2 Israeli shekels per $1 for the latest first quarter and 29 Israeli shekels per $1 for the year-ago first quarter.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
KITCHEN SPACE SAVERS
description: NUMEROUS new products are designed to make the most efficient use of counter space in small kitchens. Two cutting boards could be useful in preparing food; one is plastic, the other wood, and both have handles that extend to make them fit firmly on the sink.

title: Polish Cleric Undergoes Gall Bladder Surgery
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, underwent surgery today for an ''acute inflammation'' of the gall bladder, according to the official Polish press agency.

title: A Lottery Winner Hopes to Teach History
description: Accompanied by her husband and their four sons, aged 12 to 33, Anne Watkins of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, went to claim her $3 million Lotto prize yesterday. The 50- year-old real-estate agent hopes to use the money to become a history teacher.

title: PERU CULTIVATES AMAZON, HOPING FOR A CORNUCOPIA
description: Peruvians call it the eyebrow of the jungle, a 1,000-mile arc of foothills cloaked by Amazon jungle in the shadow of the Andes.

title: SPONGE CONTRACEPTIVE IS SELLING WELL IN WEST
description: A new sponge contraceptive is selling briskly throughout the Western United States five weeks after it appeared on pharmacy shelves.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results include the operations of Diamond Tool & Horseshoe Co. since its acquisition on March 18, 1982.

title: Co-Founder Will Share Gartner Head's Duties
description: The Gartner Group Inc., a Stamford, Conn., research company known on Wall Street as perhaps the closest follower of the International Business Machines Corporation, announced yesterday that it had split the responsibilities of its president and chief executive officer, Gideon Gartner. It said that David L. R. Stein, executive vice president, would be brought in to share Mr. Gartner's duties in the office of the president.

title: Eligibility Woes
description: St. John's University officials have learned that Walter Berry, a 6-foot- 8-inch forward whose basketball eligibility has been denied by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, is caught in a bureaucratic maze in his quest to become eligible.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANK OF (WASHINGTON, D.C.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $201,077 for the quarter and $487,359 for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a discontinued operation and adjustement made principally to tax-benefit 1982 operating losses.

title: POWER SYSTEM COULD NOT COPE WITH STATION LOSS
description: The Consolidated Edison Company's power distribution system is designed to compensate automatically, and almost instantly, for a variety of failures. But the system cannot cope with the loss of an entire distribution substation, according to Bowin Lindgren, a utility spokesman - and that is exactly what happened yesterday.

title: AUTHORITY ON THE MILKY WAY
description: Bart J. Bok, former director of two major observatories who was a leading authority on the Milky Way, died Friday while working at his desk in Tucson, Ariz. He was 77 years old.

title: AUSTRALIA II IS BACKED ON KEEL
description: An international measurement committee today reaffirmed the legality of Australia II's unusual winged keel, but the United States Yacht Racing Union still asked worldwide sailing authorities to eliminate the top foreign contender in the America's Cup competition.

title: I.M.F. Emergency Plan
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd. proposed today that the International Monetary Fund introduce an emergency special drawing rights system to help high- debt nations solve their liquidity problems. The facility would be used when a nation faces default, the bank said.

title: Blast at Embassy in Iran
description: A bomb attached to a diplomat's car exploded today in the compound of the French Embassy in Teheran, but there were no injuries, according to Jean Perrin, the French charge d'affaires. He said that an Armenian guerrilla organization had telephoned a French news agency in Teheran to take responsiblity for the blast.

title: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORKERS MAKE ORDER OUT OF CHAOS AS BUSY SECTION OF CITY GOES DARK
description: Guests in the New York Statler Hotel waved fluorescent-green flashlights in the darkened lobby. On wet streets packed with fire trucks, police chased away cars and their rubbernecking drivers.

title: OFFICIALS SEE LESS FRICTION WITH MEXICO
description: Differences between Mexico and the United States over President Reagan's Central American program are narrowing, Administration officials said today as they prepared for Mr. Reagan's visit Sunday with President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado.

title: U.N. in China Project
description: The United Nations will provide part of the financing for an oil exploration project in China's southwestern Guizhou province, a U.N. spokesman said. He said the U.N. would provide at least $4 million for the project, while industry sources said the full cost could be about three times that. The United Nations Department of Technical Cooperation for Development will control the project.

title: JUDGE RULES HOME MUST BE BARN
description: Lee and Grace Prince, happy in their $200,000 home, say they have no intention of turning it into a barn as ordered by a judge.

title: Mullin's Foot Broken
description: Chris Mullin , the St. John's basketball star, suffered a broken foot in a practice game in Puerto Rico and will miss next week's Pan American Games. According to a St. John's spokesman, Mullin, a 6-foot-6-inch guard who averaged 19.1 points as a sophomore last season and was named Big East player of the year, broke a metatarsal bone in his left foot when he came down on another player's foot Tuesday night.

title: QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIONA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Note Rate Varies At Merrill Lynch
description: A $200 million issue of Merrill Lynch & Company floating-rate notes due in 1991 was offered yesterday at a price of 100, through underwriters led by the Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Group.

title: Jury Awards $10 Million In Killing by Robot
description: A jury has awarded $10 million to the family of a factory worker who was killed by a robot arm as he tried to do the machine's job himself.

title: CLOTHES TRADE CRIPPLED IN KEY WEEK
description: The largest garment manufacturing center in the world found itself in disorder and darkness yesterday, faced with millions of dollars in possible losses during one of its most critical sales weeks of the year.

title: GODFATHER'S PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
AGING CHURCHES: A GUIDE TO REPAIRS
description: A 40-page pamphlet on the maintenance and repair of churches has been published by the Preservation League of New York State, a nonprofit organization concerned with the protection of historic buildings.

title: U.S. Charges Floridian With War Crimes
description: The Justice Department said today that it was attempting to revoke the American citizenship of a Florida man accused of taking part in Nazi war crimes in World War II.

title: CUOMO IS OPEN TO INCREASE TO 21 IN DRINKING AGE
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he was ''well disposed'' toward raising the state's drinking age from 19 to 21 as part of an effort to establish a uniform age in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURNCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IU to Spin Off Stake In Echo Bay Mines
description: The IU International Corporation said today that it planned to spin off its controlling interest in the Canadian gold mining concern, Echo Bay Mines Ltd., to IU shareholders.

title: Tony Peters Indicted
description: Tony Peters, the star safety who helped the Washington Redskins win the Super Bowl last winter, was indicted along with seven other men today by a Federal grand jury that charged them with conspiring to distribute cocaine.

title: Advertising; New TV Tactics for Broadway
description: WHO'S more likely to squeeze the most promotion potential out of television advertising on behalf of a Broadway show than a showman who is also a former adman.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Champion Products Inc., Rochester, N.Y., has elected J. Jay Cassen to the new position of executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: DATAMARINE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINDSOR LIFE INSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Year-ago results, which were prepared by prior management, are not available.

title: What's Good for S.I. Must Be Good for Brooklyn
description: If Staten Island secedes, can Flatlands be far behind? And Gravesend and New Utrecht? Not if Joe Gentili has his way. Mr. Gentili, a Republican state committeeman and Brooklyn district leader, would like to lead half of his borough into a new and more perfect - or at least more Republican - union with Staten Island.

title: ADAMS DRUG CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONCERT: SUPERTRAMP AT THE MEADOWLANDS
description: AMONG the many 1970 bands, most of them English, who bent rock to fit classical models, none fused the two influences more ingeniously than the British-American quintet Supertramp. Led by the songwriting and keyboard team of Rick Davies and Roger Hodgson, the group expanded the melodic idiom of the late Beatles into a highly chromatic orchestral style of almost Wagnerian density.

title: Cavanaugh to 49ers
description: The search by the San Francisco 49ers for a new backup quarterback to Joe Montana ended yesterday with a trade for Matt Cavanaugh from the New England Patriots. The 49ers will give up a medium-round draft choice with the possibility of up to two more choices going to the Patriots if Cavanaugh stays with San Francisco beyond the expiration of his contract after the 1984 season, Coach Bill Walsh of the 49ers said.

title: SUNDANCE OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For several weeks it will be written by Letty Cottin Pogrebin, a writer and editor of Ms. magazine and the author of the soon-to- be-published ''Family Politics.''

title: MAYNARD ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Atlanta Transit Bonds To Yield Up to 10.43%
description: A $175 million bond issue of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, known as Marta, was offered yesterday with a maximum yield of about 10.43 percent for 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 2004. Underwriters led by Salomon Brothers offered other bonds with yields ranging from 7 percent in 1986 to 10.25 percent in 2003, with a 7 percent issue due in 2011 offered at a price of 71 1/4 to yield 10.10 percent.

title: Illinois Constituents Greet Crane Warmly
description: Representative Daniel B. Crane, the Illinois Republican who was censured last month by his House colleagues for an affair with a female teen-age page, was nervous about facing his constituents today, but he was asked only once about his morals.

title: Swift Sets Closing
description: The Swift Independent Corporation announced it would close its pork-processing plant in Sioux City, Iowa, in February 1984.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNDER WRAPS

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $377,000 for the quarter and $968,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $198,000 for the quarter and $2,441,000 for the 9 months and a special gain of $51,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations of Etco Photo.

title: 7 NEW YORK STORES REPORT SALES GAINS
description: Sales at seven of New York City's major department stores rose an average 2.6 percent in July from a year ago, a spot check of the retailers showed this week. With suburban branch stores included, the increase was 3.9 percent.

description: b-Net income.

title: Tight-End Problem
description: With 5 tight ends still among his 72 players, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said today that the 3 rookies - Jamie Williams, Malcolm Scott and Zeke Mowatt - might be given all the playing time in the Giants' second exhibition game, Friday night in Pittsburgh against the Steelers.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Red Army's Clay Feet
description: With one limited exception, all the Soviet Union's strategic missiles are liquid-fueled, a technology 20 years behind the solid-fuel systems of American missiles. The reason, according to ''The Threat,'' a new analysis of the Soviet military machine, is largely bureaucratic. Developing solid-fueled rockets is the exclusive preserve of the Nadiradize design bureau, which, without penalty, has failed for two decades to master the technology.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $928,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Death Toll in Ethnic Violence In Sri Lanka Revised to 362
description: At least 362 people died in the violence that erupted in Sri Lanka after Tamil separatist guerrillas killed 13 Government soldiers in an ambush last month, a Government spokesman said today.

title: PIZZA VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
PARIS IS SENDING 500 SOLDIERS TO CHAD
description: France is sending as many as 500 well-armed paratroopers into Chad to train the forces of President Hissen Habre for their fight against Libyan-backed rebels, Defense Ministry sources said today.

title: TRADE SANCTIONS: PROPOSALS SHORT OF A SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS SCORE EARLY AND GAIN PLAYOFFS
description: The Cosmos scored goals in the first half by Ricky Davis and Roberto Cabanas but had to defend desperately in the second to beat Team America, 2-1, tonight at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: Upset in Sanford
description: The bettors had made Aggressive Bid a cinch to win the $57,100 Sanford Stakes today at odds of 1 to 2, but at post time the 2-year-old colt seemed to be telling them to save their money. He refused to enter the starting gate six times, finally was shoved in, then never raised a gallop and beat only one horse while an 11-1 shot named Big Walt romped to victory.

title: Environmentalists Sue Watt Over Alaska Wilderness Swap
description: The Interior Department completed a land swap with three Alaskan Native corporations today. The National Audubon Society and five other environmental groups immediately sued Interior Secretary James Watt, contending that the exchange would allow development that would threaten seabird nests.

title: DESIGNERS ARE CREATING ETCHED GLASS RENAISSANCE
description: ''I'D like to do a whole skyscraper of sandblasted glass,'' says the New York architect Steven Hall. ''It has enormous potential.''

title: Chrysler Plea Said to Fail
description: The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board does not plan to reconsider selling warrants for Chrysler Corporation stock and will tell the company that in a letter, probably late this week, a Government source said yesterday.

title: DOW ADVANCES BY 7.71, TO 1,175.98
description: Stock prices rebounded moderately yesterday following their recent sharp declines, buoyed mainly by bargain-hunting in many of the recently depressed issues.

title: U.S. 'INDULGENCE' RESERVED FOR APARTHEID
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Per Class A common share. c-Per Class B common share.

title: ICE SHOW: 'MAGIC KINGDOM' AT GARDEN
description: ''WALT DISNEY'S Magic Kingdom on Ice,'' which is making the kids jump with joy in Madison Square Garden these days, is spectacularly numbing - in a stunning way - and almost never spectacularly dull. This new ice extravaganza bursts with color and invention, and it also tells a story.

title: Rome Said to Suspect K.G.B. Role in Abduction
description: Italian magistrates are investigating the possibility that the K.G.B., the Soviet security agency, took part in the kidnapping of Emanuela Orlandi in order to discredit Pope John Paul II, a top police official said today.

title: ELDERLY GET THEIR TURN AS CAMPERS
description: At Camp Isabella Freedman, the campers swim, row boats and make potholders. They whisper in their cabins after ''lights out'' and they start summer romances. And sometimes they write letters to their grandchildren.

title: AWOL Cub Fined
description: Mel Hall , the Chicago Cubs' rookie outfielder, failed to show up for Tuesday's game against the St. Louis Cardinals, and when he appeared for yesterday's game, he was fined an undisclosed amount for the unauthorized absence.

description: The Economy

title: ONE CONSERVATIVE FAULTS TWO PARTIES
description: There were times, in the last few weeks, when the House of Representatives looked like the Newt Gingrich Show.

title: GYPSY MOTH CARRIES HARM TO NEW AREAS
description: The gypsy moth munched through far fewer acres of forestland this year than last year, but the pest has expanded its frontiers from the Northeast into Ohio, Michigan and Virginia, forestry officials say.

description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $33,000 for the quarter and $21,000 for the 6 months.

title: HOW TO FEND OFF A MOSQUITO
description: THE months of July and August are the peak of the mosquito season and while mosquitoes can be wily and persistent in their search for a meal, the range of repellents available attests that humans can be just as wily and persistent in warding them off.

description: Dan S. Blumenthal, public-relations consultant and secretary-treasurer of the Professional Basketball Writers Association, died of a heart attack Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

description: The Government announced today tighter state controls on the economy aimed at damping inflation and bringing relief to the country's debt-ridden industry.

description: The electrical fire that blacked out part of midtown Manhattan yesterday effectively shut down one of the city's busiest retail districts, closing major stores and small shops alike and costing retailers lost sales estimated in millions of dollars.

description: b-After an exchange loss of $3,859,960. c-Net income. Sinclair Venezuelan Oil is a 97 percent-owned subsidiary of Atlantic Richfield Co.

title: YANKS TOP JAYS ON 6 IN 5TH,8-3
description: Jerry Mumphrey got his wish yesterday and was traded to the Houston Astros. But before he departed, he left his former Yankee teammates with something to remember him by with a triple and a sacrifice fly during a six-run fifth inning that enabled the Yankees to beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 8-3, before a crowd of 40,377 at the Stadium.

title: MERITS OF HARRIS TIE TO LANIER DEBATED
description: Can the Harris Corporation, marketer of sophisticated computers for the professional, find happiness with Lanier Business Products Inc., purveyor of copiers and a catalogue of relatively unsophisticated office equipment?

description: b-Including a tax credit of $61,640 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: REPORT SAYS HOSPITAL CHAINS RELY ON HIGH FEES FOR PROFITS
description: Profit- seeking hospital chains are more expensive than their nonprofit competitors but do not take care of sick people any more efficiently, researchers say.
