title: People
description: * Peter H. Reader has joined Herman & Rosner Inc., as senior vice president/director of client services.

title: POP: EDDY GRANT SINGS
description: EDDY GRANT is not one of pop's most subtle singers or trenchant lyricists. At the Ritz on Monday, he was serviceable on both counts, shouting his way through both conventional love songs and uncontroversial protest songs in a rough, hearty baritone.

title: VISUAL GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
BEHIND THE SCENE, EMERGENCY BOARD STEMS CRISIS
description: About 2 A.M. yesterday, awakened by the special police telephone in his Scarsdale home, Robert F. Littlejohn was told that there had been a water- main break in the heart of the Manhattan retail section and that the trouble might spread.

title: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $75,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of tax attributes.

title: Rates End Mostly Unchanged; Rally Erases Early Rise
description: Short- and long-term interest rates ended yesterday mostly unchanged, as securities dealers continued to gradually reduce their holdings of $15.75 billion of Treasury notes and bonds that were auctioned last week.

title: WAYS TO GIVE THE FIREPLACE A SUMMER FACE
description: LOOKING at an empty fireplace can be like looking at a television set that is turned off: empty and boring. Yet the fireplace is often the architectural highlight of a room and remains a presence even when not functioning. Whether it is a nonworking fireplace, it was closed off long ago or it is a working one cleared out for the summer months, the decorating problem has several imaginative solutions.

title: Technology; When Public Structures Fall
description: WHEN the ceiling of a public building collapses, as happened Monday in a Jersey City railroad station, or when part of a highway bridge suddenly falls into the river below, as happened on June 28 in Connecticut, the safety of all technologies, and the the competence of those who develop and administer them, are called into question.

title: Resorts' Net Climbs Sharply
description: Resorts International Inc. reported a net income of $9.4 million, or 93 cents a share, for the second quarter ended June 30, up from $321,000, or 3 cents a share, in the same period last year. Revenues for the Miami-based casino-hotel operator rose 18.5 percent, to $122.8 million, from $103.6 million.

title: Navy Attributes Misfire To a Computer Error
description: The Navy said today that one of its warships accidentally fired a shell in the wrong direction in exercises but denied the shot went near a Mexican freighter.

title: MOTHER KILLS 2 CHILDREN AND HERSELF
description: A 38-year-old woman and her two children were found dead this morning in their home in Mastic Beach, L.I., in what the police said was apparently a case of murder and suicide.

title: CHANGING TASTE: A HOUSE 25 YEARS LATER
description: IN 1958, Ladislav Rado and his wife, Donna Emilie, moved into a streamlined International-style house that Mr. Rado, an architect, had designed for a site high on a hill in Westchester County. ''I saw the interior as open and adaptable and felt the house was a forward-looking and interesting design that would not date,'' Mr. Rado said. The solar house, situated to take advantage of the sun's light and heat, also boasted one of the first microwave ovens ever installed in a residence.

title: Soviet Pipeline Test Near End
description: Tests on the pipeline that will supply Western Europe with natural gas from Siberia are almost complete, and the system will go into operation on schedule early next year, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.

title: Profit for Eagle Is Turnaround
description: Eagle Computer Inc., whose president died in a car accident the day his company went public, ended its latest quarter with a profit and a sharp increase in sales.

title: MR STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $57,000. c-Net loss.

title: Evidence to Be Allowed In New Jonestown Trial
description: Three pieces of crucial Government evidence that were excluded from the trial of Larry Layton for conspiracy to kill a Congressman near the Jonestown Peoples Temple in Guyana can be used in Mr. Layton's retrial, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: 'Is She a Mutt?'
description: In 1980, a Dallas consulting firm suggested that Kansas City's KMBC-TV look for a woman co-anchor to bring ''warmth and comfort'' to the news. The search turned up Christine Craft, an anchorwoman in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: SEAWAY MULTI-CORP LIMITED reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
GUATEMALA'S COUP II
description: The significance of the coup d'etat in Guatemala is its insignificance.

title: UNDERSTANDING LIBEL
description: It was in the 17th century that the law recognized words as weapons. Until then, honor had been vindicated by duels. With the birth of libel law, individuals were provided a judicial means of salvaging their reputations. Today, however, the law has veered so as to limit individuals' rights to protection.

title: NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Chairman of Trans-Lux To Head Film Institute
description: Richard Brandt has been elected chairman of the board of the American Film Institute, it was announced Tuesday.

title: Chilean Shuffles Cabinet On Eve of Protest
description: President Augusto Pinochet, reacting to growing protests against his rule, ordered 18,000 soldiers into the streets of the capital today and replaced several members of his Cabinet.

title: Nigerian Gas Loan
description: Partners in Nigeria's planned $7 billion Bonny liquefied natural gas complex plan to seek about about $5 billion in commercial credits late next year, with a quarter of that amount in syndicated Eurocredits, industry sources said today.

title: KISSINGER PANEL MEETS FOR FIRST TIME
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the members of President Reagan's commission on Central America today that he hoped they could find ''some common ground'' for American policy in the region.

title: Glory in Bronze
description: Three years ago at the Moscow Olympics, Yuri Sedykh of the Soviet Union won a gold medal in the hammer throw on his opening toss, although television replays at the time showed it was a foul.

title: Reagan Denies Forces Are Stretched Too Thin
description: President Reagan does not believe that United States military forces are being stretched too thin as a result of commitments in Central America, Chad and the Persian Gulf, a spokesman said today.

title: BRINK'S WITNESS IDENTIFIES DEFENDANT IN SHOOTOUT
description: A witness to a shootout in which two police officers were killed testified at the Brink's murder and robbery trial today that she saw one of the three defendants, Kuwasi Balagoon, ''shooting at the police.''

title: U.S. DENIES ATTACHE WAS IN COUP
description: The State Department said today that a deputy military attache from the United States Embassy in Guatemala was inside the national palace with a walkie-talkie during Monday's coup, but was not involved.

title: Protest Over Pollock
description: Summer time is rerun time, even in the art world. Mike Bidlo, a Manhattan artist, plans to reproduce one of Jackson Pollock's most famous pictures, ''Blue Poles,'' at 1 P.M. today, in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: NEWHALL INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-No year-ago results were provided because the partnership was formed on March 10.

title: CAMBRDIGE UNIVERSITY ECONOMIST
description: Joan Robinson, a Cambridge University economist with Socialist views who was a collaborator of John Maynard Keynes, died Friday at the age of 79 in Britain. She had been ill for several years, and in a coma for some months.

title: SEX EDUCATION MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Booking Rule Sought
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today took its first step toward regulating airline computer reservation systems.

title: Medicare's Race Against Time
description: Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund is headed for a disastrous crash. By next year the mammoth Federal health program's income could start falling below expenses. Cash reserves and income from loan repayments will fend off complete bankruptcy for a few years, but then the crash would be resounding.

title: BADEN QUITTING SUFFOLK TO RETURN TO CITY POSITION
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden said yesterday that he had submitted his resignation as the chief deputy medical examiner in Suffolk County and would return to the staff of the Chief Medical Examiner in New York City, where Mayor Koch removed him as Acting Chief Medical Examiner four years ago.

title: Frank Gregg Kear, Engineer; A Consultant on Electronics
description: Frank Gregg Kear, an electrical engineer who served as a consultant on electronics development, died of Alzheimer's disease July 21 in a Sunnyvale, Calif., nursing home. He was 79 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md., most of his adult life.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Larry W. McCurdy, who served for 25 years at Tenneco Inc. until early this year, was appointed yesterday as president and chief operating officer of Echlin Inc. after only five months at the company.

title: BANK RATES UP AGAIN
description: For the 12th consecutive week, interest rates for bank money market deposit accounts have risen in major cities in the nation. New York area rates also showed a marked increase in the seven-day period ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $177,400. c-Includes a tax credit of $151,000.

title: AGENCY SELLS DRUG KITS, THEN ARRESTS BUYERS
description: Federal drug agents seeking to draw out potential producers of hallucinogens and other illicit drugs have been operating bogus chemical companies that sell materials and instructions for the manufacture of such dangerous drugs. Then they arrest their customers.

title: Toshiba Pact
description: The Toshiba Corporation said it would sign a formal agreement to license Taiwan's Tatung Company to manufacture videotape recorders in Taiwan. The Taiwan Government has already approved the agreement, the Japanese company said without disclosing further details. Tatung, a Taipei-based electrical appliance manufacturer, is 5 percent owned by Toshiba, which has licensed it to produce color televisions and refrigerators.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
UNION WEIGHS PINE-TAR CASE
description: A representative of the Major League Baseball Players Association met yesterday with Lee MacPhail, the American League's president, and said later that the leadership of the union would now determine whether MacPhail was violating the basic agreement by insisting that the ''pine tar'' game be resumed next Thursday.

title: SIDNEY HOMER, 80, FINANCE EXPERT AND WRITER
description: Sidney Homer, economist, author, bond trader and raconteur of finance, died Tuesday of heart disease at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Homer, long known as the Bard of Wall Street for his colorful and humorous treatment of complex economic subjects, was 80 years old. He lived on Gramercy Park.

title: Italian Bank Figure Gone
description: Licio Gelli, a key figure in the Ambrosiano bank scandal that is rocking Italian political and financial circles, disappeared mysteriously during the night from a local prison here.

title: 200 U.S. MILITARY DUMPS MAY POSE WASTE PERIL
description: Up to 200 Defense Department installations worldwide may include hazardous waste dumps that threaten the environment, but only 18 are now being cleaned up, the Pentagon's director of environmental policy said today.

title: CARL LEWIS WINS 2D AND 3D GOLD MEDALS AT HELSINKI
description: Carl Lewis won the long jump and anchored the 400-meter relay team to a world record, and Mary Decker led from the start and survived a thrilling stretch duel in the 3,000-meter run at the world track and field championships today.

title: PROBLEMS IN TRAFFIC TODAY
description: Getting around the West Side of midtown Manhattan will continue to be a problem today as repair work continues at the fire-damaged Consolidated Edison substation at 38th Street and Seventh Avenue. City officials offered this advice: Traffic

title: Conference Set On Latin Debt
description: Latin American countries have scheduled a five-day meeting for next month to seek permanent solutions to their staggering debt problems and insure that funds continue to flow into the troubled region.

title: Market Place; Index Options' Various Roles
description: FOR many investors, stock index options are a means of insuring their portfolios against market declines. Others view them as a limited-risk speculation. And some investors use these options to create ''paper,'' or ''synthetic,'' portfolios as an economical alternative to buying actual stocks.

title: A RULING AGAINST SEABROOK 2
description: Utility regulators in Connecticut yesterday reached a preliminary decision to order the two major electric companies in that state to seek cancellation of the Seabrook 2 nuclear power project in New Hampshire.

title: HOME BEAT
description: WHILE Neil Schwartzberg, near left, designed what he called ''his monument,'' his brother Fred, far left, worried about how they were going to pay the bills for the new 10,000- square-foot Dallek retail showroom of office furniture.

title: LEBANESE DRUSE ASSAULT ARMY, SEIZE MINISTERS
description: Druse militiamen and Lebanese soldiers fought an artillery duel Wednesday in the hills south of here, with shells spilling over into the airport area and the headquarters of the United States Marine peacekeeping force.

title: RULE TO LET ATOMIC HAULERS PASS THROUGH CITY IS UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld regulations that would permit trucks carrying radioactive materials to travel through New York City.

title: UNITED WESTBURNE INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PACIFIC GAS TRANSMISSION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RETAIL SALES FELL IN JULY BY 0.003%
description: Retail sales cooled a little more in July, falling a tiny three one-hundredths of 1 percent from June after four months of gains, Government figures indicated today. The July figures still were 10.3 percent above those of a year ago, however.

title: Israel Devalues Shekel by 7.5%
description: Israel today devalued its shekel by 7.5 percent to approximate its real value against the United States dollar and to halt a run on banks for foreign currency at bargain prices.

title: U.S.-Soviet Trade Down
description: Trade between the United States and the Soviet Union fell to its lowest level in a decade in the first half of 1983, and was down 42.2 percent from the 1982 period, according to preliminary figures published today.

title: TALK OF PERCEPTION, REALITY, FINE-TUNING AND 1984
description: Like a gently grinning mirage in the capital's broiling August heat, the ghost of Dwight D. Eisenhower is being hailed lately by President Reagan's strategists as they squint at the political horizon.

title: Hudson Oil Cheating Fine
description: The 70-year-old chairman of the board of the Hudson Oil Company has been fined $5,000 and ordered to perform 200 hours of public service work for ordering gasoline pumps rigged to cheat customers at company stations.

title: Delta Terminal's $95 Million Issue
description: A $95 million bond issue to finance Delta Air Lines' new terminal at La Guardia Airport in New York City was offered by a Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company group with 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 2008 at a price of 99 to yield 10.61 percent.

title: Henning in Line To Coach Blues
description: Lorne Henning, the Islanders' assistant coach, is a leading candidate for the vacant job as head coach of the St. Louis Blues.

title: ORIOLES LOSE 5TH STRAIGHT
description: Lary Sorensen allowed six hits and struck out a career-high nine batters as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4-3, tonight to sweep a three-game series.

A Golf Ball Is Banned
description: A ball used by winners of the major United States golf championships this year has been banned by the United States Golf Association.

title: FED TO LET BANKS SERVE AS DISCOUNT BROKERS
description: In yet another crack in the barriers separating the banking and securities industries, the Federal Reserve Board today added brokerage services to the list of activities that bank holding companies may engage in.

title: AMERICA, JAPAN HAS COME OF AGE
description: Monday marks the 38th anniversary of Japan's unconditional surrender to the Allies. Although almost four decades have elapsed since Japan's surrender, there is continued reluctance on the part of Americans to treat Japan as a mature equal. This attitude ignores the fact that Japan has rapidly come of age.

title: Western Union Joins NPR Paging Project
description: National Public Radio and the Mobile Communications Corporation of America said today they had revised plans for a national satellite paging system to bring in the Western Union Telegraph Company as a 40 percent partner.

title: Reagan Asks Increase In Arms Office Budget
description: President Reagan asked Congress today to increase the budget for the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency by $2 million, about 10 percent more than the $21.4 million previously approved.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After charges representing equity in Chromalloy American Corp's continuing operations of $1,839,000 for the quarter and $3,935,000 for the 6 months. c-After a charge representing equity in net loss of Chromalloy American Corp's discontinued operations of $3,272,000 for the quarter and 6 months, a charge of $119,000 for the quarter representing equity in Chromalloy's continuing operations, and a credit of $1,265,000 for the 6 months representing equity in net income of Chromalloy's continuing operations.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Protesters Heckle Koch At College in Brooklyn
description: A small but noisy group of protesters followed Mayor Koch yesterday through the hallways and stairways of a Brooklyn college, calling for him to get out of the building and the borough.

title: A CITY HOSPITAL IN FORT GREENE WILL BE CLOSED
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that it would close Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn on Aug. 24 and shift its staff and patients to the newly opened Woodhull Hospital.

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: FOR RUINED CHAD'S SURVIVORS: STEAK FILET AND COTES DU RHONE
description: As countries go, Chad has claims to fame that hold no joy. It vies, for instance, with Bhutan for the title of the wold's poorest country. It challenges Eritrea, almost, as the theater for Africa's longest-running chronicled battle and war. Somehow, in this battered and potholed capital, where the wind sighs gently from the river and admits defeat to the desert's heat, it survives. And with style, too.

title: P.&.G NET UP BY 9.7% IN QUARTER
description: The Procter & Gamble Company announced that earnings in its fourth fiscal quarter, ended June 30, rose 9.7 percent, while sales increased 3.7 percent.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kermit Washington , who retired from the Portland Trail Blazers last season after suffering from leg and back injuries, has been having second thoughts, and hopes to rejoin the team. . . . Rob Palmer , a defenseman, has agreed to terms with the New Jersey Devils on a multiyear contract.

title: FROM SUPER BOWL BACK TO IVY LEAGUE
description: The left fielder wore aqua. The number 33 on his chest and back was not blue, and not green, exactly. The numbers were aqua. Unlike last year, when Rich Diana wore the jersey for the first time, there was no need to get up and adjust the color television.

title: Marine Officer Joins Iowa Senator's Staff To Aid Constituents
description: A Marine officer, in an unusual assignment, has been detailed to the staff of Senator Roger Jepsen to help the Iowa Republican respond to constituents' inquiries about military contracts.

title: WHEN ARCHITECTS DESIGN DOLL HOUSES
description: ''I couldn't find a dolls' house for my daughter, Alexandra, that wasn't mundane and traditional,'' said Dr. Andreas Papadakis as he explained the origins of an exhibition of architect-designed doll houses that has just opened at Sotheby's in London. He funneled his frustration into organizing a competition that fired the imagination of architects around the world.

title: CLAUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Results for the latest periods include operations of Northeast Petroleum Industries Inc., from February on.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This couldn't have happened on a worse day. This is the day in the week.

title: A.T.& T. Spinoff
description: The California Public Utilities Commission appealed the reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, charging that the divestiture of local phone companies violates antitrust laws and forces higher rates. In the suit, filed in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, the commission said United States District Judge Harold H. Greene's approval of the reorganization plan left Pacific Telephone with more debts than any local company in the Bell System. The commission said a plan it had developed would have cut the cost of local service by several hundred million dollars a year.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
News Analysis
description: The case of Christine Craft, the anchor newscaster who this week won a discrimination suit against a Kansas City television station, raises important questions about unequal standards for female newscasters in television. But at the same time, the two weeks of testimony in her trial also served as a powerful reminder of how overwhelmingly local television news is influenced by show business values.

title: Viacom Joins Japanese Venture
description: Viacom World Wide Ltd. said it had joined a group of Japanese companies that includes the Mitsui Group, the Toshiba Corporation, the Odakyu Railways Company and Fujita Industry Ltd. to develop and operate the first two-way addressable cable television system in Japan.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: GYPSUM-BOARD panels, which are almost always used now in finishing interior walls and ceilings, enable any do-it-yourselfer to do a smooth professional job in installing new partitions or in resurfacing old plaster.

title: Charterhouse
description: Charterhouse Petroleum P.L.C. said it had agreed to terms for the disposal of its interest in two North Sea licenses, and part of another license interest held by an associated company, the Jubilee Oil Company, to Santa Fe Minerals Inc., a unit of the Santa Fe International Corporation. Financial details were not disclosed.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Harry Peck on Tuesday misidentified the advertising and marketing company he founded. The company, in Garden City, L.I., is Advertising Distributors of America.

title: THE ALLEN AIDES BEHIND NORTHWEST ENERGY DEAL
description: Enrique F. Senior and Paul Gould both started their college careers with far different goals than putting together leveraged buyout packages for multimillion-dollar corporate takeovers. But the two Allen & Company Inc. executives, who are credited by the company with engineering the $575 million takeover of the Northwest Energy Corporation this week, say they don't miss their old goals a bit.

title: LIFE IN LOS ANGELES: WAITING FOR THE SEA TO RETURN THE SAND
description: Californians are pursuing a new diversion this summer: watching for their beaches to come back.

title: CHAD REBELS OPEN A MAJOR OFFENSIVE ON TOWN IN NORTH
description: Libyan-backed rebels launched a major assault today on the northern oasis town of Faya-Largeau, and Western intelligence sources here said the town might fall soon.

title: Little Change For Eurobonds
description: Bonds denominated in dollars made some scattered gains in early European trading but retreated after the weak opening of credit markets in the United States, dealers said today. At the close of trading in Europe, the dollar bonds were at about the same levels as a day before.

title: Bristol-Myers Plans Big Coupon Campaign
description: Bristol-Myers is going to dump 43 million cents-off coupons into the homes of America on behalf of Extra Strength Datril which, if cashed, would cost it $64.5 million.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: HISPANIC LEADERS SEEK TO MOLD A VOTING BLOC FOR 1984
description: Both the Republican and Democratic parties are making major efforts to woo votes of Hispanic Americans, whose growing numbers and new political sophistication are giving them political power on a scale they have not known in two centuries of American democracy.

title: MUSIC CONFEREES TRACE THE SOUNDS OF CULTURES
description: There was talk of moon-shaped lutes and sacred serpents, of shamans and missionaries, of panpipes, Shinto temples and Polynesian dance. Terms like ''acculturation'' and ''epistemology'' were bandied about, and one could hear sotto-voce discussions of tenure and grant applications as well as music from Japan, Puerto Rico and the Bolivian Andes.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. SAYS SOVIET SUB, 90 ABOARD, SANK IN JUNE ACCIDENT IN PACIFIC
description: A nuclear-powered Soviet submarine sank in the North Pacific in June, American intelligence officials said today.

SWAZILAND QUEEN LOSES POWER FIGHT
description: A power struggle in the royal household of the independent kingdom of Swaziland led today to the deposing of the Queen Regent, known as the Ndlovukazi or ''She Elephant,'' who had ruled since the 61-year reign of King Sobhuza II ended with his death a year ago.

title: Texas Bank Reports Loss
description: The First National Bank of Midland had a $109.3 million net operating loss in the second quarter, reflecting a slump in the oil and gas industry in West Texas. Bank officials cited problem loans and an increase in the reserve set aside for loan losses.

title: ASSAULTS ON ASIAN IMMIGRANTS INCREASE IN BOSTON
description: Sometimes when Keo Sopheap walks home from work, a group of young men with a dog waits in the street for him. ''They just try to make a lot of quarrel,'' Mr. Keo said with a shrug.

description: b-Net income.

title: Harvester Nissan Kits
description: The International Harvester Company has said it will start assembling truck kits imported from Australia for midsize Nissan trucks and reselling them under the Harvester name beginning in the fall.

title: Habib Visits Taiwan
description: Philip C. Habib, the former special American envoy to the Middle East, arrived today for a three-day visit to study Taiwan's economic development, officials said.

title: Ogilvy Reaches Accord On a Japanese Venture
description: Ogilvy & Mather International, with offices in 37 countries, has had to operate in Japan through an affiliated agency, Tokyu, part of a Japanese conglomerate.

title: BEHIND THE PRESIDENT'S 'CAVE MAN' JOKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Season for Hayes
description: He has spent more time playing basketball than anyone else in the history of the National Basketball Association, and now, after 15 seasons, Elvin Hayes of the Houston Rockets says it's about time to do something else. ''One more year and that's it,'' he said.

title: NIGERIAN PRESIDENT ELECTED TO A SECOND TERM
description: President Shehu Shagari has won a second four-year term, according to election results announced early today.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. EXPECTS DEREGULATION TO SAVE OVER $150 BILLION
description: The Reagan Administration said today that its actions to reduce the number and cost of Federal regulations would save consumers and businesses more than $150 billion over the next decade.

title: CHESSCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $679,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income including income of $29,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A PECULIAR FAITH
description: The faith of Jose Napoleon Duarte in Salvadoran elections all but passes understanding. Yet in a recent interview at his villa in San Salvador, the leader of Salvadoran Christian Democrats appeared firm in the conviction that he can convert victory in the forthcoming presidential election into a solution to the civil war racking his country.

title: HARVEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LITTLE RHODY THINKS BIG TO SET ECONOMIC POLICY
description: For perhaps half a century, since its textile mills began to fail, Rhode Island has been in a state of economic drift. Now, convinced that smallness is an advantage and that applied research will show the way, ''Little Rhody'' is embarked on an ambitious attempt to design an economy for the years of technological change ahead.

title: Fairs and a Parade This Weekend
description: Street fair, 115th Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Today, 7 to 11 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday, 3:30 to 11 P.M. Games, food and entertainment.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: The latest results reflect the operations of Dixie-Northern acquired from the American Can Co. in July 1982.

title: 'XICA' AND AFRICAN FILMS
description: ''We are neither black nor white, but our navel is Africa,'' the Brazilian author Jorge Amado once said of his country. The influence of African culture in Brazil can be seen in New York this weekend, at Film Forum 2's Brazilian-African film festival - 45 films that will be shown through Sept. 13.

title: P & O Gets Leader To Avert Takeover
description: In a move to shore up its defense against the takeover attempt by Trafalgar House P.L.C., the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company has named Jeffrey Sterling, the 48-year-old chairman of Town and City Properties, as chairman, effective Nov. 1.

title: JUDGE AID CHICAGO INQUIRY AS A SPY
description: A judge who put a tape recorder in his cowboy boots and acted as an informer in Chicago for the Federal Bureau of Investigation asserts that ''maybe one judge in eight is crooked'' in Cook County's court system.

title: ILC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Continental to Cut 89 Flights If Mechanics Strike Tonight
description: Continental Airlines plans to cancel 89 flights and suspend service to 19 cities in the event of a mechanics' strike Friday, the company said today.

title: Sebastian at Town Hall
description: John Sebastian, who wrote hits for the Lovin' Spoonful, will join NRBQ (the New Rhythm and Blues Quartet) in concert at Town Hall tonight at 8 o'clock as part of the New York Folk Festival, 308-7695. Tickets are $9.50 and $12.50, available at the box office, 123 West 43d Street, or through Chargit, 944-9300.

title: WILLIAM W. BODINE Jr.
description: William W. Bodine Jr., an educator and chairman of the World Affairs Council of Philadelphia, died of cancer yesterday at the Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 65 years old and lived in Villanova, Pa.

title: M*A*S*H Again a Hit - At the Smithsonian
description: After reigning gloriously over the television world for years, M*A*S*H has become a smash hit in the stately halls of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Richardson Gets More Aid
description: After recently undergoing a three-week drug rehabilitation program for cocaine abuse at a New Jersey hospital, Michael Ray Richardson of the New Jersey Nets has voluntarily entered another program, a team official said last night.

title: Carobeth Laird, Author, Dies; First Published at Age of 80
description: Carobeth Laird, a writer who didn't publish her first book until she was ''discovered'' by student researchers when she was 80 years old, has died at age 87.

title: Harvard to Offer Loans To Draft Nonregistrants
description: Following the lead of other major universities, Harvard will offer loans to students who lose Federal aid because they fail to register for the draft, but the loans will be made only at prevailing interest rates, according to the university's president, Derek Bok.

description: b-Net income.

title: Duback Left Out
description: When many of the American athletes departed yesterday for the Pan American Games, which begin Sunday in Caracas, Venezuela, there was a surprising omission from the soccer squad.

title: Paradyne Plea Is Rejected
description: A Federal judge has turned down a request from the Paradyne Corporation that a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit against it be dismissed. He said that a possible violation of securities laws was indeed at issue in the agency's complaint.

title: Injured Nureyev Leaves Boston Ballet 'Quixote'
description: Rudolf Nureyev withdrew from the Boston Ballet production of ''Don Quixote'' just before opening night tonight due to a leg injury suffered during a preview performance.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two Bronx men, Nathaniel Becton, 22 years old, and Robert Bell, 17, were charged yesterday with the assault and robbery of as many as 100 elderly men in Manhattan office buildings. . . . Police officers disguised as ambulance attendants seized $400,000 worth of cocaine and arrested four men at 5 P.M. Wednesday in a raid on suspected drug dealers operating out of an apartment at 1035 Grand Concourse in the Bronx. Those arrested were Steven Diaz, 22; Jose Carlos Diaz, 18, and Jose Rivera, 19, all of the Bronx, and Juan Fermin, 18, of Manhattan. . . . Garnet Wilson, 36, of 501 West 156th Street was arrested as a suspect in the robbery of $15,000 from as many as 10 banks by passing a note to tellers saying that he had a gun and was suffering from AIDS. The police said he did not have acquired immune deficiency syndrome, but apparently thought the note would panic anyone who read it and facilitate his robberies.

title: No Headline
description: THE ROSENBERG FILE. A Search for the Truth. By Ronald Radosh and Joyce Milton. 608 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $22.50.

title: No Headline
description: No longer does a typical evening here in Rockdale County consist of sitting on the front porch after the sun has gone down, sipping iced tea, watching lightning bugs, swatting flies and mosquitoes and trading gossip or, if you are young, sweet talk.

title: GIVE QADDAFI ROPE
description: Before pursuing confrontation over the wastelands of Chad, the United States should stop and consider some basic questions about Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. What American interests, if any, does the Libyan leader threaten? What is his standing at home, in the Arab world, in Africa? Will high- profile American military responses such as dispatching carrier battle groups and Awacs aircraft to patrol Libya's shores and borders curb Colonel Qaddafi's aggression?

title: Ford Unit's Shelf Filing
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company said today that it had filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering up to $500 million of medium-term notes.

title: Dogout Doctor
description: Every major league baseball club has a team physician, but Ron Taylor's involvement with the Toronto Blue Jays goes deeper than making house calls at the ball park. Dr. Taylor, as some fans will recall, was a relief pitcher for the Mets when they became world champions in 1969.

title: Rise in OPEC Output Seen
description: There is a ''high probability'' that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which agreed to limit its oil output in March because of declining worldwide demand, will raise its production ceiling by the end of the year, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, said yesterday.

title: SOVIET PROTESTS SHIP INCIDENT
description: The Soviet Union, in a protest note to the United States, today described as ''overt lawlessness and dangerous arbitrariness'' the actions of an American destroyer in approaching a Soviet freighter off Nicaragua on July 30.

title: VICTORY 83, AUSTRALIA II TRIUMPH
description: Under cloudy skies with scattered rain, the semifinal series began today to select the foreign challenger for the America's Cup. In both matches, the victories were by default because yachts withdrew after the races started.

description: Mary Decker and Grete Waitz, each of whom has won a gold medal at the current world track and field championships in Helsinki, joined about 50 other leading female runners from 20 countries today in a sex-discrimination suit against international track authorities, the International Olympic Committee and the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee.

description: West Germany today was declared the winner of the Admiral's Cup, the unofficial world championship of yachting, after two of its boats had finished in the first six at the end of the 605-mile Fastnet Race, the final event in the Cup series.

title: S.E.C.'s Rules On Bank Data
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday voted to require more information from bank holding companies about their foreign lending and their potentially risky domestic loans.

description: The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: Wolf Back in New York
description: Robert Wolf, former senior vice president, general manager of Kenyon & Eckhardt West in Los Angeles, is due in New York on Monday to take over the office of Chiat/Day as executive vice president, general manager. That agency has its headquarters in Los Angeles, headed by Jay Chiat, who like Bob Wolf is a local New York-area product. Before going West, Mr. Wolf, who is 41, worked here for Wells, Rich, Greene and first moved West in its employ.

FOR BUYER AND SELLER ALIKE, A DAY FOR MAKING DO IN THE GARMENT DISTRICT
description: Diane Ferro, of Warren, Ohio, has been traveling to New York's garment center several times a year for 15 years now, and had come to believe that during those many buying trips, she had seen it all.

title: 2-INCH RAIN FALL IN 4 HOURS CAUSES PARTIAL SHUTDOWN OF THE SUBWAYS
description: Thunderstorms dropped more than two inches of rain on New York City in four hours last night, knocking out service on almost half the subway system and causing scattered power failures and widespread flooding.

title: 3 LEBANESE CABINET MEMBERS FREED BY DRUSE
description: Druse militiamen freed three Lebanese Cabinet ministers today after detaining them for a day, and continued to bombard Lebanese Army positions around Beirut International Airport and in the mountains southeast of the capital.

title: U.S. Blocking Telecast Of Olympics to Cuba
description: The State Department is blocking plans by an American company to transmit television coverage of the 1984 Olympics to Cuba, insisting the Cubans book time on an international satellite instead of an American one.

title: Pipelayers For Soviet
description: A senior interagency group has accepted a recommendation by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige to lift export controls on pipelayers to the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today. The action, which is expected to be approved by President Reagan, would help the Caterpillar Tractor Company, which is the principal maker of the equipment and which is competing with the Komatsu Company of Japan. At today's meeting Mr. Shultz and Mr. Baldrige won out against opposition from the national security adviser, William P. Clark, and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, the officials reported.

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 1 and a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 30, 1982. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling of interests basis in the latest quarter.

description: Amateur Athletics

title: Brooklyn Man Is Slain on Street
description: A Brooklyn man was killed and four other men were wounded yesterday in what the police described as a gangland-style shooting in front of a coffee shop in the Bensonhurst section at 2:15 A.M. There were no arrests.

title: REATAURANTS
description: ALTHOUGH it is not necessary to say that Joe, or even Jose, sent you, you do have to ring a bell and be buzzed into Jose Sent Me, a new and engaging Tex-Mex restaurant on the second floor of a building on 55th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. The slightly seedy staircase hardly prepares you for the inviting and casual but smartly decorated dining rooms. The front room is done as an airy rustic cafe, and the inner room, with booths and with carpet on the wall, has a more formal look. In hot weather, the front room is preferable because the air-conditioning is more effective. The background music is more forgivable than in most places because country music seems to be an essential seasoning for the Southwestern food.

title: Count Basie's Birthday
description: Count Basie will celebrate his 80th birthday, which takes place Aug. 21, a week early with a rare club engagement this weekend at First City Cabaret (505-0090), 76 East 13th Street. With the singer Joe Williams as special guest, Mr. Basie will lead his band in two shows tonight and tomorrow at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. Admission is $25; there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Title Bouts Approved
description: Larry Holmes , the heavyweight boxing champion, has reached an agreement with the World Boxing Council that will allow him to fight two other opponents before facing the W.B.C.'s top-ranked contender, Greg Page , in a bout that has been tentatively set for next January or February. The W.B.C. had threatened to strip Holmes of his title if he did not carry out a mandatory defense against Page, but Holmes and the W.B.C.'s president, Jose Sulaiman , resolved their differences at a meeting in San Juan, P.R., last weekend, according to Holmes. As a result, the W.B.C. will sanction two fights that Holmes has scheduled for later this year, a bout against Scott Frank on Sept. 10 and one against Marvis Frazier on Nov. 25.

title: CORN CROP PROJECTION CUT BY U.S.
description: The Agriculture Department today lowered its projection for the 1983 corn harvest by more than one-third, an indication that the prices of meat and other foods could rise next year.

title: A ROMAN HOLIDAY UPSTATE: 'OSCULAME!' T-SHIRTS URGE
description: The Romans invaded Rochester today.

title: ALZADO HAS PROTEGE AT DEFENSIVE END
description: The old defensive end peeled off his uniform slowly last Saturday night and mentioned how tired his legs were, even though he had played only the first quarter. ''We've been working real hard in training camp,'' he said. ''Usually, it takes me a quarter just to get warmed up.''

title: Stocks Mixed; Metromedia Up by 30
description: Stock prices ended with mostly minor changes yesterday in slower trading. The main exception was Metromedia, which rebounded 30 points, to 425, after plunging 110 points earlier in the week.

title: AIR FARE WAR BREWING IN BUSY COAST CORRIDOR
description: The nation's busiest air corridor, the 350 miles between metropolitan Los Angeles and the San Francisco Bay area, is going to get even more crowded after Labor Day.

title: EG&G Founder Argues Views in Nuclear Book
description: Bernard J. O'Keefe, chairman of EG&G Inc. and head of the National Association of Manufacturers, calls himself a ''card-carrying member of the military-industrial complex.'' Some of his colleagues in the defense industry were surprised by the recent publication of his book ''Nuclear Hostages,'' which decries the arms race. It urges, among other things, that the United States not deploy Pershing II missiles in Europe.

title: Petrobras in Talks With Oil Concerns
description: Petrobras, the Brazilian state oil company, has opened talks with three multinational oil companies aimed at importing part of the country's oil needs under favorable terms, officials said.

title: HOME HEALTH CARE OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $70,000.

title: ART: A SHOW OF COMICS AT DOWNTOWN WHITNEY
description: THERE are two good reasons to go and see ''The Comic Art Show'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Downtown, which is housed in the Federal Hall National Monument at 26 Wall Street.

title: DECOM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Kaneb Mines Deal
description: Kaneb Services Inc. said it had acquired the major assets of three coal companies in eastern Kentucky known collectively as the Kentucky Gem Coal Company for $8 million in cash and the assumption of liabilities of about $500,000. The assets acquired include a coal supply contract, coal mining equipment, coal reserves and a unit-train loading facility. The coal contract, with the South Carolina Public Service Authority, has a base value of some $120 million, the company said.

title: Advertising; Chrysler's New Fall Campaign
description: Come mid-September, we'll be seeing some of the first visible results of the huge restructuring of the Chrysler Corporation's marketing operations. That's when the first of some $200 million worth of advertising begins to appear.

WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: Earnings for 1983 include the company's equity in the earnings of Welmoore Industries, an unconsolidated affiliate. Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split on Aug. 8, 1983.

title: Woolworth Income Up
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday that it had a net income in the second quarter of this year of $16 million, or 50 cents a share, contrasted to a loss of $9 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues edged up 4.1 percent, to $1.28 billion, from $1.23 bnillion. Results for the 1982 quarter have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the company's United States Woolco operations and the sale of its 52.6 percent interest in its British subsidiary, F. W. Woolworth, P.L.C. Results for the 1982 second quarter also included a $5 million, or 17 cent-a-share gain from the repurchase of debentures for sinking fund requirements.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.
