title: F.B.I. WEIGHS ACTION IN 'RAIDS' BY YOUTHS ON COMPUTERS DATA
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it might act against a group of young people who used home computers to get access to college files, a Los Angeles bank and a computer at a nuclear weapons laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M.

title: RELIANCE FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Reliance Financial Services is a subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

title: Madison Would Be Proud
description: It says something about American priorities that a blur called Chad has eclipsed the marvelous news from Nigeria. But it remains marvelous news nonetheless: Millions of people, of widely different tribe and region, have again ratified a democracy modeled on America's, freely choosing a President at the polls. Impoverished Chad's turbulent inability to agree on any government at all warrants barely a footnote by comparison.

title: MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Sales for 1983 include $1,500,000 under manufacturing agreements with Telcon Industries. Modular Computer acquired all the assets of Telcon on June 30.

title: U.S. Judge Voids Hauptmann Suit
description: A judge today dismissed a suit in which the 84-year-old widow of Bruno Richard Hauptmann charged that New Jersey had executed the wrong man for the kidnapping and murder of the infant son of Charles A. Lindbergh.

title: Firefighters Test Inventiveness as Cooks
description: The five cooks working intently in the back of the McDonald's at 58th Street and Third Avenue yesterday were not dishing up fast food. They were firefighters, one from each borough, competing for the honor of best firehouse chef.

title: 'TRIINGUALISM'-AN AMERICAN PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflects 3-for-2 stock split in April.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: WHO says opposites attract? Not the people who booked Summerpier's jazz series, which this weekend features three groups that are each dedicated to one kind of instrument. Tonight at 8 o'clock, Howard Johnson and Gravity - six tuba players and a rhythm section - will perform. Slide Hampton and the World of Trombones, with nine trombones and a rhythm section, will appear tomorrow. Sunday at 5:30 P.M., the tenor saxophonist Odean Pope will lead his Saxophone Choir: eight saxophonists and rhythm section. Both Gravity and the World of Trombones got started to revive interest - among musicians as well as listeners - in their instruments. Gravity, which features virtuoso playing from Mr. Johnson and Dave Bargeron among others, has been overturning the notion of the tuba as an ungainly behemoth since 1968, when Mr. Johnson first started putting together a book of arrangements for a tubas-and-rhythm group he called Substructure. The group became Gravity in 1977.

title: Town Above Mine Fire Votes for a Buy-Out
description: Residents of this central Pennsylvania hamlet voted today to accept a Federal buy-out and abandon their homes rather than go on enduring life above an underground mine fire that has burned for 21 years.

title: SATELLITE SYNDICATED SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Peete, Weibring Share Lead at 66
description: A pair of players with Michigan backgrounds, Calvin Peete and D. A. Weibring, shot six-under-par 66's today and shared the first-round lead in the $350,000 Buick Open at the Warwick Hills Golf and Country Club.

title: Market Place; Wary Outlook On Bond Rates
description: IF recent history is any guide, stock market investors might benefit in the period ahead by

title: Seaboard System To Lay Off 1,200
description: The Seaboard System Railroad, a unit of the giant CSX Corporation, is laying off up to 1,200 employees in its 13-state territory because of declining commodities traffic.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My experiences are so different, having come up as a litigator in a male-dominated profession and a male-dominated specialty.

title: Soybeans Up on Buying By Nervous Europeans
description: Prices of soybean futures shot upward again yesterday, largely on nervous buying by European bean oil and meal processors who sought to cover needs before the Agriculture Department issued its crop report.

title: CARDILLO TRAVEL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3,000 for the quarter and a gain of $122,000 from discontinued operations for the 6 months. c-Net income including a gain of $1,045,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $78,000. d-Including a gain of $1,393,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $556,000. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations of the former footwear products division which was spunoff as Biltrite Corp.

title: Brewers Beat Blue Jays by 6-4
description: Cecil Cooper hit a bases-empty home run and drove in two runs as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 6-4, tonight and moved into sole possession of first place in the American League East.

title: 'Arts by the Bridge' Has Balloon Sculpture
description: ''Arts by the Bridge,'' a free program of music, dance and other events, continues this weekend at Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park, New Dock Street, Brooklyn.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Loan Accord for Argentina
description: Argentina's Economy Minister, Jorge Wehbe, will leave for New York tonight to sign a $1.5 billion loan agreement that will help Argentina reschedule its $39 billion foreign debt.

title: ...A BANDWAGON FOR ALL POLITICIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: UGLY SEA CREATURES MAKE GOOD SEAFOOD
description: Receiving little of the attention lavished on more exciting marine provender, sea robins, the northern puffer and certain crabs provide excellent table fare and may be captured with unsophisticated and inexpensive equipment.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After loss on investments of $2,566 and extraordinary charge of $758,000. c-After investment gains of $1,241,960 for the quarter and $1,289,231 for the 6 months. d-After investment gain of $2,463,359.

title: Architectural Photos
description: ''Photography and Architecture: 1839-1939,'' a collection of photographs from the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal, is on view through Oct. 16 at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue at 91st Street. The exhibition includes early architectural photographs and work by photographers from around the world. The museum is open today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. Admission is $2; information: 860-6868.

title: Satsuo Yamamoto, Director; Made Antiwar Films in Japan
description: Satsuo Yamamoto, a noted movie director whose films depicted the brutality of war, died of cancer of the pancreas in a Tokyo hospital today, his family reported.

title: Rhythm and Blues Bill
description: Two veterans of 1960's rhythm-and- blues, Lee Dorsey of New Orleans and Carla Thomas of Memphis, are sharing a bill this weekend at the Bottom Line (228-7880), 14 West Fourth Street. Shows begin tonight and tomorrow at 9 P.M. and midnight; admission is $8.50.

title: FILM: 'GOLDEN SEAL,' FLIPPERS AND MAGIC
description: PETS are hard to come by on the Aleutian Island of Unak, where a boy named Eric lives with nary a squirrel to play with in ''The Golden Seal,'' which opens today at the Eastside Cinema. Alone with his parents on the rocky isle, Eric - whose father calls him Boy - longs for a puppy, which he is planning to name Girl.

title: South Korean Leader Plans Clemency for 2,000
description: President Chun Doo Hwan announced today that he will grant clemency to about 2,000 political prisoners and criminals.

title: Interest Rates Turn Lower Prices Rise Nearly a Point
description: Short- and long-term rates fell yesterday as demand from investors and speculators became strong enough to raise prices in all maturities.

title: MAURICE SPEAR OF HELMSLEY-SPEAR
description: Maurice R. Spear, retired president of Spear & Company, the real-estate concern that merged in 1955 with Dwight-Helmsley Inc. to form Helmsley-Spear Inc., died Monday at his home in Hallandale, Fla. He was 93 years old.

title: POVERTY'S WIDENING SPECTRUM
description: To the Editor:

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Share earnings reflect the stock split and the 1-for-2 capitalization plan approved by shareholders at the annual meeting on July 29.

title: Kotar Visited by Giants
description: The linebacker Harry Carson led a contingent of 45 Giant players and officials today to visit the ailing Doug Kotar. Kotar, 32 years old, the Giants' fourth-leading career rusher with 3,380 yards, was stricken with an inoperable brain tumor last summer.

title: ALTAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: They re-created Gower Champion's dances onstage and they reminisced about him offstage at a party Wednesday at the Red Parrot. It was a benefit to aid the Gower Champion Dance Fund, which will preserve on tape the shows shaped by the legendary director-choreographer who died on the day his show ''42d Street'' opened. The tribute, which exuded sentiment without melancholy, was the inspiration of Danny Carroll, who plays the choreographer in the show. ''When you do somebody's work eight times a week for three years,'' Mr. Carroll explained, ''you feel that some old-fashioned love for that person should be spread around.''

title: Bretton Woods Study
description: A study prepared for Commonwealth finance ministers has proposed that an international group be set up to prepare for a Bretton Woods-type conference, financial sources said today. The conference would be designed to review the world financial and trading system. The study will be considered at a meeting of finance ministers in Trinidad next month.

title: BROADWAY
description: AFTER a gestation of five years, Richard Maltby Jr. and David Shire, who have written lots of songs together, have given birth to a Broadway musical called ''Baby.''

title: News Analysis
description: In purely military terms, the fortunes of the Salvadoran Government in its war with leftist guerrillas seem to have improved in recent weeks, according to a variety of foreign experts. This improvement may be especially significant because, unlike several previous upswings in the war, it seems to stem less from mistakes by the rebels and more from improved performance by the Salvadoran Army and Government.

title: Sydney Sher, Mall Developer And a Lawyer, Is Dead at 75
description: Sydney Sher, a retired lawyer and real-estate executive who was active in the development of shopping centers in southern California in the 1950's and 60's, died Wednesday at the Cedars- Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: MISGUIDED PLANS TO AID LOCAL PHONE SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire in Synagogue Laid to Arsonists
description: Arsonists broke into a locked synagogue early today and set fires in several parts of the building, causing heavy damage to sections of the brick and wood structure, authorities said.

title: 7 Colts Ready to Weather the Travers
description: As an unrelenting downpour soaked Saratoga this morning, seven trainers entered their colts for the 114th Travers Stakes, which will be run Saturday. The trainers of the three favorites had no reason to fear the rain or the possibility of an off track on Saturday. Bill Boniface's Deputed Testamony won the Preakness on a sloppy track; Sid Watters's Slew o' Gold had just worked a flashy half-mile in 47 1/5 in the Saratoga slop, and Harvey Vanier's Play Fellow won the Blue Grass Stakes on a sloppy track.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After unrealized losses on marketable securities of $56,664 for the quarter and $363,574 for the 6 months.

title: 11 Shot in Gang Warfare At Chicago Project
description: Eleven young men were shot in a resurgence of gang warfare at the housing project where Mayor Jane Byrne briefly took up residence two years ago, the authorities said today.

title: CON EDISON BEGINS EFFORT TO RESTORE POWER IN MIDTOWN
description: Consolidated Edison crews began efforts to restore power to midtown Manhattan's blacked-out garment district yesterday as hundreds of businesses remained closed and economic losses mounted into the millions of dollars.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. LANDS EYED FOR TOXIC WASTE
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was studying a proposal to locate toxic waste disposal sites for private industry on ''contaminated'' or surplus Federal land.

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP OF COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a foreign currency translation gain of $60,000,000 for the quarter and a foreign currency translation loss of $79,000,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes foreign currency translation gains of $59,000,000 for the quarter and $100,000,000 for the 6 months. d-Per Royal Dutch Petroleum share. e-Per Shell Transport share. Royal Dutch Petroleum has a 60 percent interest in Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies. Shell Transport has a 40 percent interest in the Group.

title: Redbirds Break Attendance Mark
description: The Louisville Redbirds of the American Association, the top farm club of the St. Louis Cardinals, shattered the minor-league season attendance record again Tuesday night when 20,629 fans turned out.

title: Gault's Decision
description: Today is shaping up as a big day for Willie Gault.First he will compete in the 110-meter hurdles at the world track and field championships in Helsinki, Finland.

title: WILL SHE REACH 51?
description: One morning recently, I was at home reading a newspaper argument about the uses to which the MX missile can be put in arms control maneuvering and the proper way to interpret Andrei D. Sakharov's most recent writing on nuclear arms, the Soviet Union and the United States. I was also trying to rock my 10-day-old daughter to sleep. As I wondered whether a super weapon based in vulnerable silos could ever be considered useful for any purpose other than a first strike, the thought crossed my mind that it was obscene to read and think about such things while holding a person who is one foot, nine inches long and weighs about seven pounds.

title: Quinn unable to resist Valentina.'
description: ''VALENTINA,'' playing at the Coronet, is the first movie directed by Antonio Jose Betancor and produced by Javier Moro and Carlos Escobedo to be distributed in the United States. It is based on a novel by Ramon Sender, whose wife and daughters were killed in the Spanish Civil War and who spent his last years as a political exile in the United States.

title: Exhibition on Explorer At Botanical Garden
description: ''Adventure to Those Faire Plantations,'' an exhibit on the life of the 17th-century English explorer Capt. John Smith, will be on view through Sept. 10 at the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and Fordham Road in the Bronx. The display of portraits, journals, drawings, facsimiles of documents and other items was commissioned by England's Tradescant Trust.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SESSION HELD BY PRESIDENT;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of CNN: OPENING STATEMENT

title: CASABLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $178,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the year and extraordinary credits of $946,000 for the quarter and $1,636,000 for the year. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $2,262,000 for the quarter and $5,055,000 for the year.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MUSICAL IN THE PARK

title: JUPITER HAS SHOW, TOO
description: One winter night in 1610, Galileo trained his newly invented telescope at the planet Jupiter. What he found there was a miniature solar system: four tiny moons orbited the Jovian globe.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robert Irsay , the owner of the Baltimore Colts, has filed a grievance against the Denver Broncos for what he considers the premature disclosure of the deal that sent his first- round draft choice, the quarterback John Elway , to Denver in exchange for a backup quarterback, Mark Hermann, and an offensive lineman, Chris Hinton , who had been Denver's top choice. Irsay is seeking a second- round 1984 draft choice as compensation. . . . The New Jersey Devils have signed John MacLean , an 18-year-old right wing who was their first-round selection in the National Hockey League draft.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Columbia Chase Corp., Braintree, Mass., said it signed an agreement with Fuel Tech Inc. to provide commercial and industrial fuel suppliers a system for making their fuel more economical and less polluting.

title: SIMMS TO FACE STEELERS
description: Four years ago tonight, Phil Simms made his professional debut with the Giants in Pittsburgh and nearly guided them to an exhibition victory over the Steelers, who were then the defending Super Bowl champions.

title: DELTA EXECUTIVES ACCEPT SALARY CUTS
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that its senior executives had agreed to take a cut in compensation for the remainder of the company's fiscal year, which ends June 30, 1984. Neither the size nor the terms of the reductions were disclosed, however.

title: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $62,500,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $20,600,000 for the quarter and $20,400,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated. Results for 1983 include a write-off of $5,600,000 relating to the Mexican toy operations.

title: 2 Common Drugs Found To Shrink Mice Cancers
description: A Boston medical team reported today that two common drugs administered together shrank cancers in mice by halting blood vessel growth to the tumors. The team's study has possible implications for treatment of human cancers.

title: S.E.C Proposes a Curb On Stock Index Options
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday proposed a slowdown in the introduction of narrow- based stock index options so that brokerage houses would have more time to train their sales staffs to handle the proliferation of products.

title: BLACK RESISTANCE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: ''GENERATIONS OF RESISTANCE'' traces the history of black resistance to white rule in South Africa. It is a powerful documentary, drawing its strength not necessarily from the justice of the cause it is advocating, but from the authenticity of its presentation. It blends old film clips, newsreel footage and interviews into a montage, showing that the resistance has been sanctified by a past older than the headlines from this week or this year. The one-hour documentary, produced by the National Black Programming Consortium, will be shown on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: VALIUM WITHDRAWAL A PROBLEM FOR 43% AFTER PROLONGED USE
description: A major study issued today depicts Valium and similar tranquilizers as relatively benign, effective drugs that have nevertheless caused ''moderately to severely uncomfortable'' withdrawal symptoms in a surprising number of people after prolonged use at relatively low doses.

title: WARTIME INTERNMENT: A PERSONAL ISSUE AT THE FORE
description: In the spring of 1942, when memories of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor were still fresh, Norman Y. Mineta and Robert T. Matsui were among thousands of Japanese-Americans sent by the United States Government to relocation centers in the mountains of the West.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: CUOMO SELECTS FIRST WOMAN FOR HIGH COURT
description: Judith S. Kaye, a partner in a Manhattan law firm and vice president of the Legal Aid Society, was nominated by Governor Cuomo yesterday to be the first woman to serve as a judge on the state's highest court.

title: THE VIEW FROM THE TOP IS OF 'POSITIVE THINGS'
description: In his sprawling office, Charles Z. Wick examines the twinkling lights of a wall map like a four-star general watching a battle plan. His aide, John W. Shirley, sits beside him.

title: HOTEL GUESTS HEAD FOR BRIGHTER SPOTS
description: At 9 A.M. yesterday, M. C. Seamon of Philadelphia stationed himself in a chair smack in the middle of the steaming lobby of the New York Statler Hotel on Seventh Avenue. Only the first three floors, the lobby and the stairwells had light, supplied by an emergency generator on loan from Consolidated Edison.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS RISE
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose for the second time since December in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. And for the first time, the seven-day yield on the mutual funds, 8.57 percent, exceeded the interest rate paid on bank money market accounts, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report.

title: State Dept. Takes Over 3 Vacant Embassies
description: The State Department has taken over the vacant embassies of Iran, Cambodia and Vietnam and will rent them out after making renovations, officials said today.

title: POLES TO FREE 476, BUT STILL HOLD 60 LABOR ACTIVISTS
description: The Justice Ministry said today that it was releasing 476 political prisoners under the limited amnesty, but that 60 Solidarity figures would remain in prison.

title: Bridge Reopened Following Repairs
description: City officials here have reopened a bridge that they closed to traffic two weeks ago after inspectors said it was in danger of collapsing.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $841,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the early extinguishment of $4.5 million of industrial revenue bonds.

title: ISS INTERNATIONLAL SERVICE SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and reflects the net of tax effect charge of additional reserves of about $3 million for insurance and income taxes.

title: Times Driver Dies in Crash
description: The driver of a New York Times delivery truck, Seymour Blaustein of New Milford, N.J., lost control of the tractor trailer at 7:45 A.M. Wednesday, according to the police, and was killed when the truck rolled into an Amtrak embankment here. Mr. Blaustein, who was 64 years old, had been an employee of The Times for 36 years. Amtrak trains were delayed up to 30 minutes by the accident.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOVIET RUNAWAY TEEN-AGER CREATES WASHINGTON MYSTERY
description: The 16- year-old son of a Soviet diplomat here took his parents' car and ran away from home Wednesday because, according to a letter signed with the boy's name, ''I hate my country and it's rules and I love your country.''

title: BRINK'S SUSPECT LINKED TO SCENE OF TWO KILLINGS
description: A witness at the Brink's murder and robbery trial today placed a second defendant at the scene of a shooting in which two police officers were killed after the 1981 armored car holdup in Nanuet.

title: ST. LOUIS INTEGRATION
description: School desegregation, always difficult and controversial, is even harder when the schools to be desegregated are in a predominantly black city surrounded by predominantly white suburbs. Until recently, inner-city schools have been desegregated infrequently and then only after years of litigation resulting in court-ordered busing. Last month, however, a Federal district court judge approved a plan that will use incentives to achieve desegregation voluntarily in the St. Louis metropolitan area.

title: AFGHANISTAN'S PARALLEL TO CENTRAL AMERICA
description: No analogies are exact but the Soviet Union's problems in Afghanistan may provide a more instructive parallel than Vietnam to United States policy in Central America.

title: PUBLISHING: HOUSES WITHIN HOUSES
description: IMPRINTS - those small personal labels within large publishing houses that have been around for more than 20 years - appear to be prospering. Yet editors and publishers are still divided about their value.

title: JESS FERRAZZA
description: Jess Ferrazza, a retired official of the United Automobile Workers union, died Sunday of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital in Detroit. He was 66 years old.

title: Test for Vermeil
description: Dick Vermeil, smiling and at ease, turned up at the Jets' practice field yesterday as he prepared for his first football test since his tearful resignation last January as coach of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINFIELD HOMER WINS IN THE 10TH
description: Dave Winfield fouled the ball straight down against his left instep tonight and began hobbling around. ''Sometimes you do a little character acting,'' Winfield said later, ''but that one hurt.''

title: EXTRA SPECTACULAR METEOR SHOWER IS EXPECTED
description: Leave it to the heavens to come up with fireworks that promise to rival the Gruccis of Bellport, L.I., whose most dazzling recent pyrotechnic display lighted up the Brooklyn Bridge Centennial. Shooting stars by the hundreds, well beyond the range of the Gruccis, should be seen streaking through the skies tonight, tomorrow night and for several nights to follow.

title: Gerulaitis Eliminated
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, the defending champion, squandered a 4-1 lead in the third set and dropped a 6-3, 5-7, 6-4 decision to unheralded Anders Jarryd of Sweden today in the third round of the $450,000 Players' International tennis tournament.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MAN OF THE HOUR IN SOCIAL NEWPORT
description: Everything is spotless in the British compound nestled at the end of the Commercial Wharf here: the little white fence, the gay umbrellas that provide protection from the sun, the boats. The men and women, most of them young and bronzed, can't always be equally spotless but they have a lot of esprit. They run around in striped blue and yellow jerseys or white polo shirts adorned with a rather endearing bulldog named Winston, their waists encircled with belts repetitively emblazoned with the word ''Victory.''

title: Economic Scene; Confrontations Over Deficits
description: THE Reagan Administration presides over the threat of large budget deficits into the indefinite future. Such deficits are not consistent with classical governmental financial policy and in themselves must be viewed as undesirable by sophisticated supporters of the Administration. Yet, the Administration is willing to tolerate these deficits as a weapon in a struggle to reduce the size of the Government.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP Qtr to June 30 reports earnings for 1983
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,000 from the sale of assets. Share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid in March 1983.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $17,900,000 from the sale of Sabine's Canadian operations in January and an after-tax gain of $4,600,000 from the sale of certain non-oil and gas assets.

title: IN HEAT AND DIRT, CREWS FIX CABLES
description: All over the 12-block area of midtown affected by the Consolidated Edison blackout, workmen poked their heads out of manholes, coated with grime and grease.

title: LINCOLN CENTER PRESENTS DECADE OF FESTIVAL FILMS
description: It's the movie fan's movie festival.

title: THEATER: 'DOGS,' A MUSICAL, AT THE PERRY STEET THEATER
description: IN the dog days of summer, along comes ''Dogs,'' at the Perry Street Theater, yapping its way into theatrical limbo.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 12, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Talks Postponed
description: He's a leading pitcher on the verge of becoming a free agent, and the Texas Rangers had hoped to sign him to a new contract before the end of the season, but Rick Honeycutt , who has a 14-7 record, has broken off negotiations. ''Rick needs to concentrate on pitching,'' said his agent, George Kalafatis , who reported that he would wait until after the season to resume negotiations with Ranger officials.

title: Foote, Cone's Income Rises 29.4% in Quarter
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications came up with their second-quarter figures Wednesday, and showed that their net income was up 29.4 percent, to $4.4 million, or $1.28 a share, from $3.4 million, or $1.22 a share.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Sports of The Times; Looking for Something Big
description: They have prayed among themselves, pumped up to the spectators, waved tiny American flags and used words like ''spirit, commitment and confidence'' to describe their attitude. And when they weren't winning medals, Edwin Moses, Carl Lewis, Mary Decker, Willie Banks and others were winning friends with their smiles. Could this really be a United States track and field team?

title: Brooklyn Celebrates With Jazz in the Park
description: The Celebrate Brooklyn '83 festival will present Latin jazz this weekend at the Ninth Street band shell in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, in a series co-sponsored by Latin American Music in Alternate Spaces. Tonight, the flutist Dave Valentin and his quintet, who play salsa and jazz, will share a bill with the Brazilian percussionist Nana Vasconcelos and his quartet.

title: S.E.C. UNIT CRITICIZES SCHWAB
description: The continuing rapid growth of the nation's biggest discount broker, Charles Schwab & Company, is under challenge by the enforcement unit of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: KAPOK TREE INNS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Saudi Loan for India
description: Saudi Arabia signed an agreement today to provide a $30 million loan to India for the construction of a freight railway line in the state of Orissa.

title: PASQUALE FOOD reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
FERRON IS PART OF FOLK FESTIVAL FINALE
description: WHEN the third New York Folk Festival winds up tomorrow night at Folk City, 130 West Third Street, the grand finale will pair the great folk traditionalist Odetta with the compelling young Canadian singer-songwriter Ferron. At 52 years old, Odetta remains a supreme roots- music singer and guitarist whose repertory encompasses spirituals, work songs, blues and folk music. Ferron, the 31-year-old folk-pop singer who performed in New York for the first time only last November, has received some of the most glowing notices of any young up-and-coming folk performer in recent years.

title: LAWYER FOR THE CITY ASSESSES ITS LIABILITY IN POWER FAILURE
description: A lawyer for New York City said yesterday that the city might be legally liable for damages resulting from the power failure because it was a ruptured city water main that triggered the problem. But he added that the city could escape liability if it could show that the rupture could not be foreseen or was the fault of another party.

title: How galleries put on Shows
description: DURING the summer, when so many of the art galleries that remain open mount group or theme shows, visitors may ask, where did the idea come from? How did the show evolve? What is its purpose?

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Product Introductions Up 30.3% Through July
description: This year is turning out to be a boom year for new product introductions, according to Martin Friedman, editor of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample News. Through July alone the increase was 30.3 percent over the same period last year, to a total of 1,075 from 825.

title: 'ADVOCATING FREEDOM IS OUR BUSINESS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Journalist From India Killed in Gulf War
description: An Indian correspondent of Reuters, the British news agency, was killed today when a land mine exploded during a tour of the Iran-Iraq battlefront, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said. The agency said an Iranian official was also killed.

title: TRAVEL AGENTS FACING AIRLINE COMMISSION RIFT
description: The airline industry is in turmoil over how much to pay travel agents and corporate travel departments. More than $2 billion a year in commissions are at stake.

title: LEGG MASON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Tourism Comes to Harlem With an Eye to the Future
description: How can Harlem get its share of the

title: CHARITIES THE ADMINISTRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe-U.S. Farm Fight
description: Proposals by the European Economic Community to curb imports of soybeans, corn gluten feed and other American farm products will draw a formal written protest from the United States next week in Brussels, trade officials said today.

title: KEY TOWN IN CHAD REPORTED TO FALL TO LIBYAN ASSAULT
description: Libyan troops and rebels backed by planes, armored vehicles and artillery were reported today to have overrun Chad's northern oasis of Faya-Largeau, forcing Government forces to retreat into the desert.

title: NIGERIAN REJECTS ELECTION CHARGES
description: President Shehu Shagari, who in the early hours of the morning was named the winner of Saturday's presidential elections, today rejected charges of electoral irregularities and malpractices.

title: AN OLD FOE KEEPS MARCOS OFF GUARD AND GUESSING
description: Two months ago the best-known political opponent of President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced in Washington that he planned to return home soon from three years of self-sought exile in the United States.

title: COME JAN. 20, 1985
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTS REPLACE SAILORS AT SNUG HARBOR
description: In 1833, visitors to the Sailor's Snug Harbor, a home for retired or disabled sailors on Staten Island, might have strolled through the tree-lined grounds admiring the Greek-Revival buildings or watching old salts carve objects from wood and whalebone.

title: Con Ed's Thin Line
description: For almost eight weeks, it was an invisible strike. Some 16,500 Consolidated Edison workers were on the street, striking over wages, benefits and job security. But until Wednesday, Con Ed's 3.7 million customers in New York City and Westchester felt few effects. The utility's power system is so automated that 6,000 supervisors can keep it going almost indefinitely. Unless there is a big accident or emergency - which is exactly what happened Wednesday.

title: INVENTORIES FELL BY 0.1% DURING JUNE
description: Inventories held by American businesses fell one-tenth of 1 percent in June as sales rose 2.1 percent, to a record $371.59 billion, the Government said today. This put the ratio between inventories and sales at a record low, a welcome development for manufacturers.

title: THE FARM MACHINERY UPTURN
description: Slowly and quietly the precipitous four-year decline of the $9.6 billion farm equipment industry appears to be reversing itself, retail dealers say.

title: Northwest Buyout Draws Challenge
description: The Northwest Energy Company said a complaint has been filed against it, certain of its directors and Allen & Company Inc. which seeks to block the recently announced leveraged buyout of Northwest.

title: U.S. TO SELL ITS CHRYSLER WARRANTS
description: The Treasury Department said yesterday that it would proceed with the sale of its warrants for 14.4 million shares of Chrysler Corporation stock, rejecting a company request that the Government reconsider the move.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AUCTIONS
description: Celebrity bidders.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LINCOLN CENTER GOES OUT OF DOORS
description: THE sounds of bluegrass and Bach, mariachi bands and jazz will fill Lincoln Center's plazas and park this weekend and for days beyond. Somebody may imitate a chair. Dancers will present everything from classical ballet to ''The Black Cockroach Pas de Deux.'' Theater companies will perform. And so will the inventor of something called a zoomoozophone.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS LIBYA OVER CHAD
description: President Reagan today denounced Libya's military activity in Chad but said the United States was ''not in any way in line for participating militarily'' in defending the Chadian Government from being overthrown.

title: NOMINEE TO NEW YORK'S TOP COURT
description: ''I don't think of myself as a crusader,'' Judith S. Kaye said yesterday, standing at Governor Cuomo's side. But, she added, ''My gender travels with me. Being the first woman, I don't lay that aside. That enhances the excitement.'' Mrs. Kaye is the first woman to be nominated for the State Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Backpedaling on Peddling
description: In May, we awarded our very first apple to Mayor Koch for his ''responsive and reasonable action to regulate street vendors.'' In the process, we quoted a city official who warned that ''peddling is the Vietnam of municipal issues.'' Now the allusion seems painfully apt. By plunging ahead with the best of intentions, Mr. Koch has made the situation worse.

title: Honig Returning To Doyle Dane Post
description: Marvin Honig, who is 47 years old and had been creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach for the five years ended in 1979, is stepping back into that advertising hot spot to relieve Roy Grace, 46, of some of the pressure.

title: MUSIC: SOME ZITHERS FROM EAST ASIA PLAYED
description: ASIDE from the human voice, the zither must be the universal instrument. Vibrating strings are simply attached to a resonating object and are then struck, plucked or bowed. But like the universal phonemes of human speech that are selected and combined in dramatically different ways in different languages, what is done with the zither's strings and resonators varies greatly from culture to culture.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million of variable-rate notes due in 1993 at a price of 99 3/4 through various securities firms.

title: City Team Upset In Empire Games
description: New York City, the gold medal winner here the last two years, was defeated today by the Adirondack Region, 95-87, in the first round of men's open basketball at the sixth annual Empire State Games. In another upset, Susan Liers Westerfield of Smithtown, L.I., the only woman to win the race-walking here in its first five years, was defeated at 5,000 meters.

title: Puerto Rican Chamber
description: In an effort to revitalize Puerto Rico's troubled economy, the commonwealth's Chamber of Commerce will open local offices in Washington, Los Angeles and Chicago this year, the chamber's president, Robert Leith, said here today. The chamber now has one mainland office, in Miami.

title: AGENCY SAYS KOCH'S ACTION WILL KILL TWO PORT PROJECTS
description: The Koch administration's effort to change the terms on two multimillion- dollar waterfront developments - one in Queens, one in Hoboken, N.J. - will kill them both, the chairman of the Port Authority said yesterday.

title: Gordon Liddy Won't Be In 'Salesman' Revival
description: The Watergate burglar G. Gordon Liddy was rejected for a part alongside Dustin Hoffman in the Broadway revival of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman,'' but Mr. Liddy said he didn't want the part anyway.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 12, 1983
description: Blackout in Midtown

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bridge: Marv Rosenblatt Merited A Prize He Failed to Win
description: If there were a prize for the best- played hand of the recent Summer Nationals in New Orleans, the diagramed deal from the Spingold knockout tourney would be a strong candidate.

title: U.S. WON'T CHARGE EX-E.P.A. OFFICIALS
description: The Justice Department said today that it had not found sufficient evidence to warrant criminal prosecution of Anne McGill Burford, former Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, or five other former top E.P.A. officials it had investigated.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OFFICIALS ASSAIL ESTIMATE OF COST OF MEETING HALL
description: Three key Democrats in the State Assembly said yesterday that they believed that the head of the state's Urban Development Corporation had overestimated the cost of finishing New York City's Convention Center.

title: Brazil Loan Accord I.M.F.
description: A team of International Monetary Fund officials has worked out the basic outline of a deal that would permit Brazil to begin drawing down a $4.9 billion credit, Thomas Reichmann, the team leader, said here today. Mr. Reichmann, who left for Washington after the announcement, gave no details of the proposed deal but said the blocked financing should be freed by October.

title: Dollar Bonds Show Firmness
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were firmer today in late trading after a morning during which price levels were little changed, dealers said.

title: 9 Children Injured In 3-Van Accident
description: Nine children riding in two day-camp vans were slightly injured today when the vehicles were struck from behind by a third van, the Westchester County police said.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 10 OF THE CITY'S BEST SIDEWALK CAFES
description: NEW YORK CITY, particularly Manhattan, is not the most fertile terrain for outdoor cafes to take root in. Our city does not have the wide avenues and expansive sidewalks of Paris or Madrid or the ubiquitous piazzas of Rome. Even the weather, which shuns moderation, encourages indoor socializing. But inconvenience has never deterred New Yorkers from doing anything, and a survey of outdoor cafes around town shows that not only are they surviving during this searing summer of '83, but they are even flourishing.

title: Spectra-Physics
description: Spectra-Physics Inc. said its loss from previously reported unauthorized foreign exchange transactions would be $9.4 million for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

title: Computer Maker Net Up 63.8%
description: Commodore International Ltd., the home computer maker, said yesterday that it earned $26.7 million in its fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30, an increase of 63.8 percent from the $16.3 million earned in the 1982 period. Quarterly sales were $212 million, up from $98.1 million a year ago.

title: 2 SIDES IN OPERA STRIKE REVEAL THEIR POSITIONS
description: The New York City Opera and its striking orchestra yesterday revealed details of their latest proposals, and Beverly Sills, general director of the company, said, ''For the first time, I am seriously concerned about the future existence of the New York City Opera.''

title: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $88,200 for the quarter and $214,600 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $85,700.

title: JET SCOUT STALKS CHARGERS
description: In a departure from usual practice in the National Football League, the Jets, who have won only one season opener since 1972, are not bothering to scout their exhibition opponents this year. Instead, Coach Joe Walton said today, he has decided to send his advance scout, Jim Royer, to all four exhibition games of the Chargers, whom the Jets will oppose at San Diego when the regular season begins Sept. 4.

title: MEDAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Navy Halts Goat Hunt On San Clemente Island
description: The Navy's planned slaughter of more than 400 wild goats on San Clemente Island off the California Coast was called off today, and a Navy spokesman said it would not be conducted ''anytime in the foreseeable future.''

title: RCA to Purchase New Audio Disks
description: The Nippon Columbia Company, Japan's leading maker of phonographic records, signed a contract to supply the RCA Corporation with digital audio disks, a Nippon Columbia spokesman said.

title: CHIEF CONSOLIDATED MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Intermountain stock exchanges.

title: Parents Liable For Vandalism
description: Governor Kean today signed a bill making the parents of a minor liable for the child's vandalism to public and private schools in the state. The measure allows the school to require the parents or guardians to make restitution for the damage.

title: Esmark Shares
description: Esmark Inc. said it would file with the Securities and Exchange Commission next week for an offering of 3.5 million common shares. Esmark said it expects the sales to be made within the next two weeks. The company currently has about 14.9 million shares outstanding. The conglomerate said the proceeds would be used to reduce short-term debt incurred in its recent acquision of Norton Simon Inc.

title: CURFEW IS ORDERED IN CHILE AS PROTESTS GROW
description: Hundreds of people were arrested throughout Chile today in the fourth nationwide protest called by the opposition in as many months to demand the resignation of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: THE HARD-OF-HEARING LIKE THE THEATER, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Trade Walker For Kelvin Ransey
description: In a trade aimed at strengthening their backcourt, the New Jersey Nets last night traded an experienced playmaker, Foots Walker, to the Dallas Mavericks for a younger playmaker, Kelvin Ransey. The Nets also included a second choice in next year's draft and a No. 1 pick in 1985 in the deal.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: LINEAR INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: DOG DAYS SILENCE THE WHITE HOUSE
description: As President Reagan's helicopter rose noisily from the South Grounds this morning, silence descended on the rest of the White House. The silence is expected to continue through Labor Day as Presidential aides get away for their long-awaited vacations.

title: HAMILTON BROTHERS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of assets of $14.2 million for the quarter and $14.3 million for the 6 months and a writeoff of $8.9 million for the quarter and 6 months of primarily unproved oil and gas properties. c-Net loss including a gain of $506,000 on the sale of assets. d-Including a gain of $8.6 million on the sale of assets.

title: 5 RCA Products
description: The RCA Corporation said it had introduced five new video products, including its first small video monitor that also serves as a precision color television receiver capable of receiving up to 127 broadcast and cable TV channels. The company said the other products are a slimmer two- piece portable video cassette recorder, a deluxe color camera with time lapse recording capability and 19- inch and 25-inch color television models.

title: UTAH IS GIVEN TITLE TO 93,083 ACRES OF U.S. LAND
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt today presented Gov. Scott M. Matheson of Utah with title to 93,803 acres of Federal land, much of it in rural areas containing mineral resources.

title: PETROX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After nonrecurring gains of $377,000 for the quarter and $538,000 for the 6 months. c-After nonrecurring gains of $1,867,000 for the quarter and $3,213,000 for the 6 months.

title: MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $268,000 from the reversal of a tax credit.

title: Chain of Events On Keel Disputed
description: In the continuing controversy over the top- seeded America's Cup challenger, Australia II, the United States Yacht Racing Union today said it had learned that the Australian authorities who first measured the 12-Meter yacht had doubts about its radical winged keel.

title: Mascot Evicted
description: The teepee used by the mascot of the Atlanta Braves has fallen to the economy again.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 13, 1983
description: International

title: CANADA DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After a loss of $848,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PUBLISHERS EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue figures for 1983 exclude approximately $12,000,000 in the quarter and $18,000,000 in the 6 months from the construction of two incinerator ships. Because of an accounting change, the contracts are being treated as capitalized leases rather than as contracts which generate revenues. Year-ago results were restated.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT SMALL BUSINESS INVESTMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $71,905 for the latest first quarter and $56,330 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: CON ED HOPING IT CAN RESTORE ALL POWER TODAY
description: As most of midtown Manhattan's garment district remained blacked out for a third day yesterday, the Consolidated Edison Company held out the hope that full power might be restored as early as this morning.

title: BOONTON ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Metromedia Plans 3 Acquisitions
description: Metromedia Inc. said it had signed definitive agreements to acquire Ram Broadcasting of Texas Inc., Network I Inc. and Teltec Saving Communications Company Inc. Ram is a Dallas-based radio common carrier company with a participation in a group that has applied for a cellular mobile radio telephone license in Dallas. Network and Teltec are two Miami-based long-distance telephone resale companies.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT IN BIGGEST RISE
description: Consumers took on $4.41 billion more in installment debt than they paid off during June, the biggest monthly increase since the Government began keeping track in 1943, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: TRIMAC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: POWER-HUNGRY ON L.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBYA SAID TO RAID 2D CHAD TOWN, RAISING FEAR OF ALL-OUT ADVANCE
description: Libyan planes were reported today to have attacked the remote outpost of Oum Chalouba in what seemed to be a prelude to further advances into Chad.

title: ALIENS' FARM WAGE DIVIDES U.S. AIDES
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block and Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan are in sharp disagreement over the wage rates to be paid to aliens who come legally to this country to harvest fruit, vegetables and other crops.

title: NEW FEARS RAISED ON ATOMICPLANTS
description: A committee of expert advisers to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that the technique commonly used to measure the depth of cracks in reactor piping was unreliable. The panel said that by using the system the commission was accepting a higher level of risk of a major reactor accident than it usually considers acceptable.

title: STEELER TURNOVERS HELP GIANTS WIN
description: The Giants, playing aggressively if not artistically, converted four of the Pittsburgh Steelers' nine turnovers into points tonight, as they won their second straight exhibition game, 22-13.

title: OPERA: 'SIEGFRIED'
description: The Boston Lyric Opera's performance of Wagner's ''Siegfried'' at the Beacon Theater began simultaneously with the downpour that afflicted the city early Thursday evening. The storm was so ferocious that it could have been the one depicted at the outset of ''Die Walkure,'' but unfortunately, that opera had already been given on Tuesday.

title: Lawyer Wins a Point For Rights of Her Sex
description: The California Supreme Court has decided that if men do not have to tell a judge they are married, neither do women.

title: Spatial Relations
description: A new satellite-borne telescope recently fixed on the bright star Vega and made a startling discovery: The star is encircled by a cloud of matter that may be a solar system.

title: GREAT AMERICAN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,843 for the quarter and $5,543 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: PANEL SEEKS FILES OF REAGAN AIDES
description: The private campaign files of five officials of Ronald Reagan's 1980 campaign organization are being sought by the House subcommittee investigating the transfer of Carter Administration briefing papers to the Reagan camp.

title: Prices Steady For Eurobonds
description: Trading in the Eurobond market was thin today, with prices little changed from closing levels late Thursday, dealers said.

title: SENTRY DATA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Between Two Teams
description: Gary Anderson , who is under contract to two professional football teams, told a Federal court in Houston yesterday that he believed his former agent did not get him the best possible contract when he had him sign with the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League early this year. Anderson, a running back, later signed with the San Diego Chargers of the National Football League and is trying to have the court void the contract arranged with Tampa Bay by the former agent, Jerry Argovitz .

title: Reagan to Announce Aid for Border States
description: President Reagan plans to offer a relief program today to aid border-state businessmen hard hit by the devaluation of the peso, his chief spokesman, Larry Speakes, said today.

title: Some Fans Stuck
description: Some fans had the foresight to save their ticket stubs from the ''pine-tar game'' between the Yankees and the Kansas City Royals, hoping for admission if the game had to be continued at a later date. They are out of luck.

title: MISS LAVELLE SAYS SHE IS NOT GUILTY
description: Rita M. Lavelle, a former official of the Environmental Protection Agency, pleaded not guilty today to charges of perjury and obstructing a Congressional investigation. She was allowed to remain free without bond.

title: RITZY'S, G D, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KENNEDYS HELP SCHOOL FOR RETARDED
description: The St. Coletta School, an educational, training and retirement center for the mentally retarded, is getting a million dollars from the Kennedy family, and school officials say they know exactly what they will do with the money.

title: News Analysis
description: In only five days in office, Guatemala's new chief of state, Brig. Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, has moved the country's foreign policy decidedly closer to Washington's view of the causes and cures of the region's problems. General Mejia Victores, who took power in a coup on Monday, has abandoned the inward-looking and relatively neutral stance of his predecessor, Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 13.

title: Trudeau Shuffles Cabinet For 3d Time in a Year
description: With public opinion polls showing his party to be less popular than it has ever been, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau replaced five of his Cabinet members today with backbenchers as he shuffled his Cabinet for the third time in a year.

title: RATES DROP ON MONEY SUPPLY FIGURE
description: The basic money supply rose by only $400 million for the week ended Aug. 3, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: ISRAELIS AND LEBANESE FIND TRADE HAS NO BORDER
description: One look at this border crossing between Israel and Lebanon reveals the ways that Israel is trying to create a normal relationship with Lebanon in the aftermath of the June 1982 invasion.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results for the latest periods include equity in income from unconsolidated affiliate of $143,000 for the quarter and $320,000 for the year.

title: CLASSIC CHILDREN'S WEAR, FROM CATALOGUES
description: Rosette Arons is a fur designer who lives on the West Side and has two children, aged 13 and 15. Lois Perschetz is a writer who lives on the East Side and has two children, aged 1 1/2 and 4. The women met and became friends while summering on Fire Island. One day they discovered a minor matter they had in common that led them to take a major step: starting a joint business venture.

title: STATE CITES CITY FOR SEXUAL BIAS IN TRADE SCHOOLS
description: New York City's vocational schools operate in an ''environment of discrimination based on sex'' and school officials have done little to remedy the situation, according to the State Education Department.

title: 'THE CURSE OF THE PINK PANTHER'
description: To say that Blake Edwards's ''Curse of the Pink Panther'' is aimed at easy-to-please audiences is to understate the case considerably. It's aimed at those who'll be satisifed with another snappy credit sequence, a few of the old familiar faces, and very little more.

title: Small Change
description: Some of the British athletes at the world track and field championships in Helsinki, Finland, are mildly upset about their per diem spending allowance, which is $:1, or about $1.50 in American money, in contrast to the more typical American allowance of $10 per day.

title: WESTERN PREFERRED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $565,487 for the quarter and $1,156,067 for the 6 months, and gains on investments of $601,336 for the quarter and $617,092 for the 6 months. c-Includes a gain on investments of $78,147 for the quarter and a loss on investments of $325,059 for the 6 months.

title: Suspect Pleads Insanity In Vicki Morgan Slaying
description: The man accused of killing the model Vicki Morgan with a baseball bat pleaded not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity today, and a judge ordered psychiatrists to examine him.

title: BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BOARD ALLOWS POWER SYSTEM TO SUE CONTRACTORS
description: The executive board of the Washington Public Power Supply System voted today to allow the utility to file civil suits against electrical contractors and thus try to recover damages from possible antitrust violations.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAX LAW'S HELP IN REDUCING CRIME STATISTICS
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 LATIN DEBTOR NATIONS IN TALKS WITH CREDITORS
description: Three of Latin America's largest debtor nations, Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela, were involved in negotiations with various creditor groups this week.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,992,000 for the quarter and $11,282,000 for the 9 months and estimated losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $22,982,000 for the quarter and $25.3 million for the 9 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $524,000. d-Net income including income of $2,907,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BUCKEYE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
High Dioxin Level At Ironbound Site
description: New tests in Newark, disclosed today, show hazardous levels of dioxin on the approaches to a plant that formerly made Agent Orange.

title: RAIN AND FALLS HURT U.S. PERFORMANCES
description: After four days of dazzling sunshine and equally brilliant victories, the weather and the American team's performances both turned today at the world track and field championships here.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TORONTO SUN reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOW WATER MAIN BREAK BROUGHT POWER FAILURE
description: The accident last Wednesday in which a broken water main flooded an electrical substation and left a large section of the garment district without power has raised questions about actions taken by New York City's Bureau of Water Supply and by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. Here are some questions and answers about the incident. Q. Why did the water main break?

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
CUOMO SIGNS PENSION BILLS OPPOSED BY KOCH AS COSTLY
description: Despite the objections of Mayor Koch, Governor Cuomo signed bills today that offer pension benefits to 10,000 part-time New York City workers and permit thousands of workers laid off during the fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's to ''buy back'' pension rights for time they did not work.

title: Kuwait Stock Accord Is Set
description: Kuwait's National Assembly has approved a Government bill aimed at settling billions of dollars of debts from last year's stock market crash.

title: FLORIDA PRESSES U.S. ON ANTI-HIJACKING EFFORT
description: Gov. Bob Graham asked the Federal Aviation Admimistration today to increase the number of sky marshals and to tighten airport security checks after the diversion of nine south Florida flights to Cuba since May 1. Just three such hijackings occurred in all of last year.

title: BOY, 9, CAN PLAY THE ANGLES
description: When Chan Whitt was just a few months old, his father sat him atop the family pool table, a sheet of plastic beneath him to guard against leaky diapers, and let him roll the glossy balls into the pockets.

title: News Analysis
description: In February, besieged by allegations of political manipulation of financing of toxic waste cleanups and other possible wrongdoing at the Environmental Protection Agency, President Reagan announced, ''I have ordered a complete investigation by the Justice Department into every charge that is made.'' On Thursday the Justice Department made public a 53-page report on its investigation that left some important issues unresolved and others unmentioned. The chief unresolved issue was whether the agency's officials had slowed one toxic waste cleanup project and expedited others last year to help Republican candidates and whether White House officials knew of or authorized such actions.

title: Aoki's 66-134 Leads By 2 in Buick Open;  6 Players Tied for 2d
description: Isao Aoki of Japan shot a six- under-par 66 today and took a two- stroke lead after the second round of the $350,000 Buick Open.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Montefiore, Then and Now
description: Sarah Katzman Jaeger, a secretary at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center since 1921, turned over a shovelful of very wet mud yesterday, signaling the start of the costliest facelift ever for the complex in the northern Bronx.

title: Couple Charged In Killing of Boy, 6
description: The mother of a 6-year-old boy and the boy's stepfather were arrested early yesterday on charges of murdering the child, the police said.

title: KAYAKERS CHALLENGE FAST RIVERS IN WILD WEST
description: The North Fork of the Payette River drops more than 1,700 feet as it crashes through a steep canyon north of here, a 15-mile stretch of boiling rapids that provides what kayakers call one of the best rides in America.

title: Chinaglia Still Ailing
description: Giorgio Chinaglia trained yesterday after 10 days of inactivity with the Cosmos and said afterward he would not be ready to play for at least another week. He said he had been treating his hamstring himself and had practiced twice a day while he was in Rome the last few days.

title: Kanon Adds Dutton Title
description: Joseph A. Kanon has been appointed president of E. P. Dutton, replacing Ivor A. Whitson, who resigned after heading the 130-year-old publishing house for three years. Mr. Kanon, currently Dutton's editor in chief and publisher, will continue in those positions.

title: Three Challenges in Chad
description: What poignant pangs President Habre of Chad must have felt when he urgently requested French troops to return to this former French colony to help in his fight against Libyan-backed rebels. Hissen Habre is himself a proud and successful former guerrilla foe of the legionnaires who aided another Chad President a decade ago.

title: BRUNSWICK STOCK SOLD BY G.&W.
description: Gulf and Western Inc. announced yesterday that it had sold a block of 2,490,200 shares of the Brunswick Corporation at $39 a share. At $97.1 million, it was the seventh-largest block in dollar value ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: One Dies as Rescue Rig Fails
description: A cable on a device designed to rescue people from burning high-rise buildings snapped in a demonstration Thursday, killing a man and injuring a woman who were riding it down from a height of 100 feet.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: PAY-TV LINK ACCEPTED BY U.S. AFTER CHANGES
description: The Justice Department said today that it would permit a merger of Showtime and The Movie Channel, the second- and third-ranking pay television companies, because the proposal no longer includes two major movie distributors as co-owners.

title: MEXICO PRESSING NICARAGUA ON OIL
description: The Mexican Government has told Nicaragua that its oil supplies will be contingent upon Managua's commitment to pay, according to American diplomats and Mexican officials.

title: COMPUTER SECURITY RAISES QUESTIONS
description: The apparent electronic penetration of an unclassified computer in a nuclear weapons laboratory by a group of young people was not a threat to national security, telecommunication experts said today. But they said the incident illustrated the extraordinary difficulty of guaranteeing the security of any information stored in a data base accessible by telephone.

description: President Reagan today signed a bill he said would assure the solvency of the railroad pension plan through the 1980's. He said the measure was not perfect but was acceptable because of the need to save the plan for one million retired people.

title: Violence Continues In Northern Ireland
description: Roman Catholic youths hijacked cars and threw firebombs at policemen today on the 14th anniversary of the renewal of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland. Meanwhile, an American was convicted of rioting and ordered to leave the British province.

title: FOOD-STAMP APPLICANTS SEEK JOBS IN A TEST ON L.I.
description: For two months, the Goodens had been looking for work with no luck.

title: FOR 1984, DARING ONE-PIECE SWIMSUITS

The emphasis is still on the one-piece maillot cut high on the thighs and, occasionally, plunging to the waist in front. Bikinis appear for inveterate sun-worshippers, but the maillot is the first choice.

title: THE WATERMELON QUANDARIES
description: One of summer's cooler and sweeter delights, watermelon, can also raise some of the season's more diverting issues. For though this cold and cheerful member of the cucumber family is thirst-quenching and restorative, it presents almost as many problems as it does pleasures.

title: Jets' Ramsey and Leahy Safe
description: Chuck Ramsey, the Jets' veteran punter, and Pat Leahy, their place- kicker, have disposed of the competition at training camp once again, this time after only one game of the exhibition season.

title: City-U.D.C. Pact Is Formally Ended
description: Following up on an announcement he made Wednesday, Mayor Koch yesterday canceled an agreement to rebuild Times Square with the state's Urban Development Corporation and said the city would carry out the $1 billion project on its own.

title: Discovering America

title: News Analysis
description: Theoretically, the seven contenders selected three weeks ago for a seat on the New York Court of Appeals were the most highly qualified candidates in the state. Yet, as subsequent events showed, there were dissenting voices. Three panels of lawyers, more than ever before, passed on the merits of each of the candidates. And although their procedures had much in common - reviews of writings, personal interviews - the results were inconsistent. Indeed, with respect to Judith S. Kaye, the person chosen by Governor Cuomo, there were three verdicts.

title: GIT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
I.B.M. Charges On Secret Data
description: Hitachi Ltd. and a National Semiconductor Corporation subsidiary worked together to gather secret information on International Business Machines Corporation computers, court documents filed by I.B.M. charge. The assertions were made in an Aug. 1 affidavit filed in the United States District Court here by an I.B.M. attorney, Thomas D. Barr.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boxer Convicted
description: The heavyweight boxer Larry Frazier was convicted by a jury here Thursday of battery on a peace officer and of being under the influence of the drug Phencyclidine (PCP). The conviction stemmed from an incident at a motel here in April. The sentencing of the 33-year- old Frazier, of Bakersfield, is set for Sept. 8.

title: Summer Skiers
description: In the middle of August - today and tomorrow - championship ski races are scheduled to be held at the Catamount Ski Area on the Massachusetts-New York border near Hillsdale, N.Y.

description: Among the often-confusing collections of initials used to describe the various benefit and retirement programs available to employees, perhaps one of the least known is VEBA, which stands for Voluntary Employees' Beneficiary Association.

description: The start-up of one of the Salem nuclear generating station's twin reactors - shut down Thursday after debris clogged a water-cooling system - was delayed today because of an equipment problem, officials said.

title: PAKISTANI CHIEF PLEDGES VOTE AND END OF ARMY RULE BY '85
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq announced today that national and provincial elections would be held, constitutional democracy restored, martial law lifted and his military Government disbanded by March 23, 1985.

title: American Priest Honored
description: An American priest who ran a home for orphans in South Korea after the Korean War 30 years ago was named winner today of the 1983 Magsaysay Award for International Understanding. The board of trustees said the priest, the Rev. Aloysius Schwartz, 53 years old, would get $20,000 and a medallion from the foundation, which is named after Ramon Magsaysay, the Filipino President who died in a plane crash in 1957.

title: PACKAGERS SUCCEED IN BICYCLE TOURISM
description: It was 11 years ago, on a weekend bicycle trip with three colleagues from Middlebury College, that John S. Freidin came up with the notion that vacationers might enjoy bicycling from country inn to country inn in Vermont.

description: An integrated system for heart resuscitation and circulation support has been invented for the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

title: TV: FRANKIE LYMON STORY IS PART OF CHANNEL 13 SERIES
description: Frankie Lymon and the Teenagers was one of the first black rhythm and blues groups to make it off a street corner, become famous and use its music to shape the reveries of a generation. Frankie was 13 years old and undeniably a talent - energy, innocence and falsetto combining for hit records, appearances on the Ed Sullivan show and a date at the London Palladium. Fame left, however, almost as quickly as it came. Frankie Lymon died of a drug overdose in 1968, age 26. His career is recalled in ''I Promise to Remember: The Story of Frankie Lymon and the Teenagers'' on Channel 13 at 11 tomorrow night.

FILM: 'MAN WHO WASN'T THERE,' 3-D
description: Anyone who cherishes the sensation of having his eyes sucked out of his head like the pimentos from a pair of olives will probably lose no time beating a path to any of the myriad local theaters that yesterday accepted the tenancy of the summer's latest 3-D movie, ''The Man Who Wasn't There.''

description: As a woman, particularly a woman in television, I know what I'm supposed to be feeling about the Christine Craft verdict, but I don't feel it. It's not that I'm sorry Miss Craft was awarded $500,000 in damages. (How could any female be sorry after hearing the ''Is she a mutt?'' line used by the researcher trying to test audience reaction?)

title: SALVADORAN ANMESTY PROGRAM TO EXPIRE MONDAY

title: TO MICHELLE, IN NEWFOUNDLAND: I'D LIKE TO SHOW YOU NEW YORK, BUT I FEEL UNEASY ABOUT THE IDEA
description: My wife and I, although Manhattan residents, spend our vacations in a tiny fishing village in the Canadian province of Newfoundland. Eighteen miles from the nearest road, the village's only regular links to the outside world are a daily (weather permitting) passenger boat and a weekly (weather permitting) freight boat. The 78 residents take care of each other's needs as best they can, and all pitch in when the community needs a big job done. The township has no mayor, no police force, no taxes, no doctors, no nurses, no undertakers and no crime.

title: 623 at Eastern To Be Dropped
description: A total of 623 temporary and part-time employees of Eastern Airlines will be furloughed as the Miami-based carrier slims down to handle an 8.7 percent autumn drop in traffic, officials announced today. The 623 employees work in 50 locations served by Eastern, with 133 of them in Atlanta, 130 at the three airports in the New York-New Jersey area and 100 in Miami.

title: Statue of Pontius Pilate Is Blown Up in Lourdes
description: A group that is opposed to the commercialization of Lourdes blew up a religious statue here today and threatened to disrupt Pope John Paul II's pilgrimage to the Roman Catholic holy city in the Pyrenees this weekend.

description: About 3,000 tourists, mostly French, were scheduled to begin leaving Ouagadougou, the capital of Upper Volta, today. A French airline official said clearance had been received for flights for the tourists, who have been stranded there since the coup Aug. 4.

title: Bendix Net Off 53.5%
description: The Bendix Corporation, a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation, reported yesterday that its net income in the second quarter dropped 53.5 percent, to $18.2 million, from $39.1 million, in the similar quarter a year earlier. Revenues slipped nine- tenths of 1 percent, to $1.05 billion, from $1.06 billion. Allied said that while profits of Bendix's aerospace- electronics and automotive businesses were well ahead of those of the 1982 second quarter, the increases were more than offset by the effects of $61.3 million in pretax provisions.

title: FILM: 'CUJO,' GOOD DOG GONE WRONG
description: Not since the Baskervilles has there been a hound as horrible as Cujo, the film version of whose story opened yesterday at the National and other theaters. Based on a novel by Stephen King, ''Cujo'' tells of a lovable St. Bernard who, after being bitten by a rabid bat, becomes a good deal less lovable. He is soon covered in blood and slime, ready to attack anyone he sees. And his principal targets are a mother and her terrified little boy.

title: HARLEM STUDENTS CREATE AND PERFORM AN OPERA
description: Few 10-year-olds have much interest in modern opera; even fewer have produced their own contribution to the repertory. But yesterday, at the Harlem School for the Arts, a gifted team of youngsters, aged 7 to 17, presented the world premiere of ''A Bit of Me Died Today,'' an original opera composed, produced, arranged, designed, choreographed and performed by students.

description: Two unsuspecting motorists drove into a water-filled sinkhole that appeared in a farm road overnight, but the three people in the two vehicles managed to swim to safety.

title: MRS. THATCHER'S OPPORTUNITY TO PACIFY NORTHERN IRELAND
description: In Ireland, waves of feudal wars and foreign conquests, and centuries of oppression, economic depression and mass emigration have come to this: a conflict concentrated in the six counties of Northern Ireland, 14 years of horrific violence, thousands of lost lives and livelihoods, and no end in sight. Most of the 43 million Irish-Americans are mute on the subject - confused and tired of trying to decipher what is going on. People who live in Northern Ireland feel anger, horror and confusion. A visitor to America, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Mairead Corrigan-Maguire, told a delegation of Senators and Congressman that the dominant emotion in her country is anger - anger directed at both chief antagonists, the British Government and the self-ordained freedom-fighters.

title: Central Park Shelter
description: On a rocky promontory overlooking a gentle valley in Central Park, park workers, summer interns in blue Central Park Conservancy T-shirts and park officials gathered Thursday to dedicate the Dene Rustic Shelter, and the occasion turned into a bubbly surprise farewell party for David A. Rosen, the park's restoration coordinator.

description: Dr. Robert Greenhalgh Albion, a leading authority on American maritime history, a former professor at Princeton and Harvard and a Government adviser, died Tuesday at the Groton Regency Convalescent Home in Groton, Conn., where he had lived for four years. He was 86 years old.

Conclusion: There's a big new hyphen in national politics and Senor Reagan wants to turn it to his own advantage.

The phone company did not appear on the appointed hour, or day.

description: NORTH TARRYTOWN IT is near midnight at The Strand

title: ; THE CLOISTERED LIFE --
description: Julia Lieblich's article only serves to underscore what many feel: namely, that these cloisters are indeed ''archaic institutions'' and that ''the nuns inside are people with an unhealthy attraction to solitude.'' What a tragic misperception of life and of the discipline of contemplation to consider for a moment cutting oneself off from family and friends, behind grilles, self-flagellation with knotted rope scourges, walking barefoot throughout the year as ''reparation for our sins and the sins of the world,'' depending on charity and handouts to survive, or praying for the large part of each day as a means of salvation.

''I felt much better compared to Sunday,'' said Palmer, speaking of his first, five-inning appearance with the Suns.
