title: Man Held in French Slayings
description: A second man was arrested here today in connection with the slaying of seven people during a bungled burglary at a luxury hotel in Avignon a week ago. The arrested man was reported to have denied involvement in the killings.

description: Donell Nixon, a 21-year-old infielder for the Bakersfield Mariners of the Class A California League, set a minor league record Friday night when he stole his 124th base of the season. That broke the record of 123 set in 1981 by Jeff Stone of Spartanburg in the South Atlantic League.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, A TALE OF TWO COUNTIES
description: A few blocks from Interstate Route 91, past shopping centers and suburban homes, there is a lush grove of trees that each spring scents the air with the sweet fragrance of orange blossoms. The aroma is reminiscent of a time, not long ago, when citrus groves covered the land.

title: METS DEFEAT CUBS, 5-1
description: No pine tar was involved, but the Mets still got embroiled in an odd brush with the rules last night in Shea Stadium while they were defeating the Chicago Cubs, 5-1, for the 10th victory in their last 13 games.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Stellar CloudHints at BirthOf Solar SystemWhile calibrating an orbiting infrared telescope, astronomers last week happened on a cloud of solid material surrounding the star Vega - a possible solar system in formation. The evidence is not conclusive. But ''the cloud's expanse is the right order of magnitude and, more important, the solid objects in it are of substantial size,'' said Dr. Conway W. Snyder, an assistant project manager for the Infrared Astronomy Satellite at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Catherine Pollard, who has 10 grandchildren, was acting scoutmaster of Boy Scout Troop 13 in Milford, Conn., for four years and getting on fine with the two dozen boys who were members, she said. But when she wrote to the Boy Scouts of America in 1974 for formal recognition as the scoutmaster, ''they told me they wanted a male to build character, and that burned me up,'' Mrs. Pollard said.

title: IS 'PERFORMANCE' A NEW FORM OF ART?
description: The terms ''performance art'' and, more generally, ''performance'' crop up everywhere these days. Galleries, museums and concert-exhibition spaces like Franklin Furnace, the Kitchen and the Brooklyn Academy of Music present performance events, and will if anything augment their offerings this coming season. Summer series like Art on the Beach on the Battery Park landfill and Art in the Anchorage in Brooklyn are devoted to collaborations that involve performance, and this year their presentations extend through September. Books and journals have been devoted to the subject.

title: Miss Torres, Law Student, Has Nuptials
description: Analisa Nadine Torres, daughter of Family Court Judge Frank Torres and Mrs. Torres of New York, was married yesterday to Constantino Ramon Argimon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantino Antonio Argimon of Caracas, Venezuela. Bishop Eugene Marino and the Rev. Charles Beirne performed the ceremony at SS.

title: Hillary Clayson to Wed P. K. Loeb Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. George P. Clayson 3d of Providence and Newport, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hillary Davis Clayson, to Peter Kenneth Loeb Jr., son of Nancy F. Loeb and Mr. Loeb, both of New York. The wedding is to be Oct. 1.

title: FREIGHT RAIL LINE IS REPAIRED
description: THEY'VE been working on the railroad between Torrington and Waterbury and after one year, 11,500 railroad ties have been replaced, five bridges repaired and strengthened, eight road crossings improved and a new freight-loading dock built in Torrington.

title: Nigerians Elect Governors
description: Nigerian voters, who gave President Shehu Shagari a landslide re-election victory last Saturday, turned out again today to choose governors for the country's 19 states. Early voting appeared lighter than in the presidential contest, when 25 million of Nigeria's 65 million registered voters cast ballots.

At the same time that newspaper articles appeared on the trial of Patricia Freaney, accused of promoting prostitution at the Salem Social Club, there appeared a column by Wayne McMorrow, president of the Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, headlined ''Nassau's Shortage of Police Officers Brings Service Down.''

title: FOR REAGAN AND MEXICAN, A QUICK TOUR OF THE ISSUES
description: Behind the friendliness enveloping today's meeting between President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado of Mexico lie substantial differences over Central America and trade and economic policy that five hours of conversation are unlikely to resolve. Those looking for concrete achievements, both sides say, are likely to be disappointed.

description: The ''real'' India of dusty poverty and mud-hut villages, of swarming bazaars, bullock carts and naked children, of barefoot men in turbans and loincloths and women draped in bright saris of every hue, displays itself everywhere, as always.

description: Ann Elizabeth Loar, daughter of Mrs. Robert W. Ellis of Stow, Ohio, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Mark Alan Simon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Simon of Hallandale Beach, Fla. Where many journalists could not resist the temptation to hold a Freudian inquest, Miss Lieblich wrote about the nuns with pronounced respect.

description: ''Marine Tiger'' is a tale of two idioms, entirely appropriate to the story of Puerto Ricans who come to New York and find themselves fighting a losing battle with government bureaucracy. It is a short, hearty musical produced by the admirable Puerto Rican Traveling Theater in its 16th annual outdoor summer tour.

title: CUT-RATE REVIVAL
description: Ever since the bankrupt King's Department Store pulled out of the Putnam Square shopping mall in 1981, the mall, at the intersection of Routes 6 and 118 in Mahopac, N.Y., has seen a steady loss of both shoppers and tenants. But in October it will take on a new name and character as a retail center devoted to discount or off-price shopping.

title: PLAY GETS NEW LIFE IN A NEW LANGUAGE
description: ANEW project at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford has tackled the problems of translating foreign-language plays for the American theater in an innovative way.

title: THE FINEST BUBBLY AT A BARGAIN
description: Deluxe champagnes such as Dom Perignon, Perrier-Jou"et Fleur de Champagne, Roederer Cristal, Taittinger Comtes de Champagne and Mumm's Rene Lalou are some exceptional and prestigious examples of France's most famous product. These elegant and delicious cuvees speciales, as they are called, are made with the finest grapes in the Champagne region, are aged longer than other champagnes, are usually produced on a very limited basis and often come in highly distinctive bottles such as the elaborate Art Nouveau design of Perrier-Jou"et's Fleur de Champagne. Needless to say, such special effects are expensive.

title: On Expediency And the Yankees

title: A $1 MILLION GIFT FOR CANCER RESEARCH
description: FOUR years ago, Harry D. Williams 2d, a builder of low-cost homes in southern Connecticut, set out to raise money from corporations and foundations to support research into the causes of cancer. Recently the foundation he set up in Southport received a $1 million grant, the largest single gift received by the American Business Cancer Research Foundation, which he heads.

title: SUMMER CONTINUES WITH MUCH MUSIC
description: THE Silvermine Guild, South Shore Music Club and Merryall Community Center among them have racked up the astonishing total of 107 summers of musical service to their respective constituencies, and all three organizations have their welcome mats out for programs this week.

description: Jeanne Robineau McCulloch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Irvin Beggs McCulloch of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Dean Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger C. Taylor of Camden, Me. The Rev. Frederick Creamer of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton performed the ceremony at the McCulloch home.

title: Yvonne Draper Weds T. Charles Taylor in Jersey
description: Yvonne T. Draper, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar D. Draper of Dix Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to T. Charles Taylor, son of Goldie Mae Taylor of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Sgt. Robert Taylor of the Army. Capt. Martin Johnson, U.S.A. Chaplains Corps and a Church of God in Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the post chapel at Fort Monmouth, N.J.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: AS WELCOME as summer postcards arriving to surprise us and to ask that the writers be remembered by those who know them best, the following selection of books by former New Jersey residents are our links to a variety of experiences, both personal and strong. ''Read All About It! The Collected Adventures of a Maverick Reporter'' by Sidney Zion (Summit Books, New York, $16.50) opens with an explanation of how a ''kid lawyer'' from ''good old Passaic,'' which Mr. Zion was in 1962, came to be a journalist.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: If you think the Mostly Mozart Festival is running out of interesting ways to justify its title, consider its two concerts Friday and Saturday nights at Avery Fisher Hall. On both evenings, the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and the New York Choral Artists, conducted by the series' music adviser Gerard Schwarz, will perform Handel's familiar oratorio, ''Messiah,'' but with a notable twist.

title: Back at Work
description: Terry Cummings, the star rookie who had to leave the San Diego Clippers last April when he was found to have an irregular heartbeat, says he is on his way to full recovery and has begun training for the season. ''I feel pretty good,'' said Cummings, who has joined the Clippers for the final week of play in the California Summer Pro Basketball League.

title: ALCOHOLICS TO GET WORK COUNSELING
description: With a grant from a private foundation, an outpatient treatment service that focuses on helping rehabilitated alcoholics maintain employment will be opened in Manhattan.

title: TIPS ON THE PROPER USE OF THE NEW, IMPROVED GLUES
description: THERE are many new and improved glues and adhesives available to today's do-it-yourselfers that not only make previously ''impossible'' repair jobs possible, but also are actually easier to use than the older forms they replaced. However, even though most come with detailed directions for use, many people never really read these directions - and that is one of the main reasons people are often disappointed in the results. It's not that the product won't perform as advertised; it's simply because it is improperly used in many cases.

title: G.O.P. SPLIT AS EAST HAMPTON VOTE NEARS
description: AS primaries and elections approach in the Town of East Hampton, the Republicans, the majority party in the town, find themselves in disarray.

title: UNION SQUARE ON VERGE OF REDEVELOPMENT
description: THE former S. Klein store, boarded up

title: THERE'S NO MARGIN FOR ERROR FOR PRO KICKERS
description: PRO football kickers go from team to team like circuses go from town to town. Set up your tee, kick a few, and move on to another field. Except there are no clowns and no laughs for the kicker. Most coaches know very little about the art of kicking and, what's worse, couldn't care less. They only know if the ball goes through the uprights or not.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section today and a listing in The Guide, section 2A, give an incorrect date for the opening of themovie ''La Passante.'' It opens today.

title: Two Physicians Dispute Idea Of 'Herpes Dating Services'
description: Two Chicago doctors have warned that the ''herpes dating services'' that have emerged in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and other large cities might do medical and psychological harm.

LEISURE;
IT'S TIME TO REMEMBER THE MORE UNCOMMON IRISES ;
description: Bee Warburton is a plant breeder who specializes in irises.

title: CONCERT: KENNY ROGERS
description: The reasons why some pop singers become folk heroes are often mysterious. In the case of Kenny Rogers, the country-pop crooner who appeared at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Thursday, one explanation might be the reassurance some people feel when confronted with sheer, numbing mediocrity masquerading as cultural heroism.

title: THE RIGHT CHAIRMAN FOR A PANEL ON CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ROSENBERG CAUSE
description: In this issue of The Book Review, Alan M. Dershowitz puts the cap of ''definitive'' on ''The Rosenberg File,'' the new book by Ronald Radosh and Joyce Milton about a case that has called forth scores of books and articles in the 30 years since the execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for conspiracy to commit espionage. Mr. Radosh and Miss Milton conclude that Julius Rosenberg was a spy, that Ethel Rosenberg knew it and may have assisted him and that the prosecution took liberties with the facts and with legal procedures in its drive for conviction and execution. Definitive though their work may be, it is too much to hope that it will satisfy those who have invested faith and reputation either in the innocence of the Rosenbergs or in the justice of their execution. The case confirms yet again a grim axiom of history: The flames of ideology cannot be subdued by facts.

title: FAST SHUFFLES Cashdance
description: Most of the time there is little to do while cashing a check besides wonder why the bank doesn't hire more tellers. But not at 1:45 P.M. last Friday in a bank at Times Square.

title: Plane Hits House, Pilot Dies
description: A man in his basement emerged unharmed after a twin-engine plane sheared off the front of his house and crashed, killing the pilot, officials said. The plane, a Cessna 310, struck the front of Joseph Haberek's house Friday afternoon, damaging the roof and porch and tearing off the chimney. The pilot was identified as J. R. Moravek.

title: DEMOCRATS WANT SUPPORT OF BUSINESS IN 1984
description: BRUCE A. MORRISON won the Third Congressional District seat last fall without the help of local business leaders. They generally supported Mr. Morrison's Republican opponent.

title: BRAVES TOP DODGERS IN 9TH, 8-7
description: Bob Watson belted a two-run pinch-homer in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight to lift the Atlanta Braves to an 8-7 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: GENETIC SCIENTISTS HAIL GAINS IN FIELD
description: The ability to analyze and manipulate human genetic material is beginning to transform the whole field of diagnosis and treatment of hereditary diseases, scientists have told at a gathering here.

title: A Wedding Next June For Jill Berkelhammer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Berkelhammer of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Berkelhammer, to Jonathan S. Zorn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Zorn of Brooklyn and Danbury, Conn. The wedding is to be in June.

title: No Headline
description: DOUGLAS MILLS

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHY THE EXPERIMENTS HAVEN'T WORKED
description: THE trading systems of the future

title: Aircraft Carriers Named
description: The Navy's two newest aircraft carriers will be named for Abraham Lincoln and George Washington, according to the White House. The names were recommended by Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. The White House said the Lincoln would be commissioned in 1989 and the Washington in 1991.

title: OUTBREAK OF PLAGUE IN WEST LAID TO MOIST, COOL WEATHER
description: The unusually cool, moist weather in the West last spring is partly responsible for this country's worst outbreak of bubonic plague in human beings since 1925, health officials say.

title: BESTSELLERS FICTION 118
description: THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 2110 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 3 1 AUGUST, by Judith Rossner. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) The five-year relationship of two women, a teen-age patient and her analyst. 446

title: LATCHKEY CHILDREN CAN DIAL A FRIEND
description: The first week that an 8-year-old boy was alone after school because his mother was at work, he picked up the phone every day to talk to a friend. He talked about the notes his mother had left for him, he chatted about school, and he admitted that he was afraid that someone might come to the door.

title: THESE DUO-PIANISTS PUT BRAHAMS NEXT TO RAGTIME
description: When Katia and Marielle Labeque finished their second year at the Paris Conservatoire in 1968, they made a pair of decisions that would set their careers on course. First, they decided that they'd had enough of the Conservatoire's rigidity, and that they would not return for another term: We learned more by spending two hours playing Schubert with Alfred Brendel than we learned in two years at the Conservatoire, they would later explain. Second, they decided to pool their talents and work as a duo.

title: FOES OF PAKISTANI CHIEF REJECT ELECTION PLAN
description: Opposition politicians say that a civil disobedience campaign of protest against the military Government will start on Sunday as planned and that they reject President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq's pledge to restore democratic rule by March 1985.

title: Ann E. Mickum Will Wed in Fall
description: The engagement of Ann Elizabeth Mickum to Peter Edward Greene has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George B. Mickum of Chevy Chase, Md. A fall wedding is planned.

title: ARREST RATE FOR DRIVERS REVIVES ISSUE OF BAR HOURS
description: WHITE PLAINS IN the wake of a steep increase in arrests for

title: 2 Engines Ram Halted Train
description: Two runway engines struck a halted freight train near a highway overpass Friday, derailing three cars and injuring a conductor, the authorities said. Jerry Howell, 47 years old, who was in the train's caboose when it was struck by the engines, was in critical condition at Charlotte Memorial Hospital today. The police and fire authorities said they did not know why the engines were unoccupied when they rammed the Seaboard System train.

title: Governor Signs a Bill Raising Farm Wages
description: The minimum wage for workers on New York State's smaller farms will increase from the current $2 an hour to $3.35 by next summer under legislation signed into law by Governor Cuomo.

title: Headlines Transposed
description: On page 2 last week, the headline on the music article appeared over the theater article and vice versa.

title: Cordelia Gould Wed To John L. Kelly
description: Cordelia Eleanor Gould, daughter of Mrs. George Higginson Barker Gould of Englewood, Colo., and the late Mr. Gould, was married at St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Denver yesterday to John Lawson Kelly, son of James A. Kelly Jr. of Huntington, L.I., and the late Joan Lawson Kelly. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert O'Neill, assisted by the Rev. John Anderson, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TRAVELS OF A LOVESICK BEAST
description: SLOUCHING TOWARDS KALAMAZOO

title: CUSTOMS SERVICE WEIGHS CURBING DUTY-FREE SHOPS
description: In an effort to reduce organized and individual smuggling, the Customs Service is considering ways to tighten control over 125 tax-free and duty-free shops at American airports and border crossings.

title: REFORMS ORDERED FOR MENTAL CARE
description: A Federal judge has ordered a number of improvements at a large state- run institution for the mentally retarded on Long Island. He said he had found serious deficiencies in the care of its residents.

title: NIGERIAN ELECTION IS PEACEFULLY CHAOTIC
description: Aides to Nigerian President Shehu Shagari like to recall his colloquy at the last Organization of African Unity meeting, with the Kenyan leader, Daniel arap Moi. ''How can you have six candidates all running for President?'' Mr. Moi asked with evident exasperation. ''It must be pandemonium.''

title: SURRENDERING TO THE RAPIDS IN CANADA
description: The Ottawa River rolled gently through thick woodland and at least one of the 11 people on the rubber raft Wanton Willy was feeling somewhat silly about the life jacket and hockey helmet that had been issued each member of the paying crew. A murmuring current propelled the raft downstream off Calumet Island, at a point some 60 miles west of Ottawa. Blue herons waded in the wide river. The sun shone brightly. The Wanton Willy was the only boat in sight and the greatest danger at that point had come from the mosquitoes and the black flies that had been left behind when the river widened.

title: SCHOLARS OF ISLAMIC LAW PONDER ITS ANCIENT GATES
description: According to Islamic tradition, the Prophet Mohammed once told a man named Muaz to collect alms and distribute them to the poor. Mohammed then asked: ''Oh Muaz, by what rule will you act?''

title: PROGRAM NOTES SHOULD BE INVITATIONS TO THE DANCE
description: Some dancegoers boast that they never read program notes. Others claim to read notes only after a performance is over. Still others contend that dances should have no program notes whatsoever.

title: FOR A GOOD CATCH, PLAN AHEAD
description: The open season for salmon fishing in Scotland varies slightly from district to district but it generally runs from mid or late February to late October. Information on dates for individual rivers can be obtained from the Scottish Tourist Board, Ravelston Terrace, Edinburgh 4, Scotland (031-332-2433). Among helpful books on the subject is the Automobile Association's ''Guide to Angling in Great Britain,'' available from the British Travel Bookshop, 680 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019 ($7.95 plus $1.50 postage).

title: AT LAST, THE CORRECTION
description: WALL STREET concluded months ago that the current bull market could not continue without first experiencing a temporary setback. No major market rally since World War II had been able to escape a brief cooling-off period, and analysts did not see this one as any different. So, last Monday, when the Dow Jones industrial average was plunging 20 points after a 60- point drop during the previous two weeks, market strategists were finally able to announce that the long-awaited correction had finally arrived. The correction pre-empted, by a mere four days, the first birthday of one of the strongest bull markets in history.

title: FILM: ROMY SCHNEIDER PEFORMS IN TWO ROLES
description: In Romy Schneider's last film before her death, Jacques Rouffio's ''Passante,'' she plays two women, remarkably similar although 50 years apart. The modern-day Lina (Miss Schneider in black leather) is the devoted wife of Max Baumstein, a Swiss political activist, and in the 1930's, Elsa (the actress wearing softer colors, and with a sweeter expression) was the equally loving wife of Michel Weiner, an anti-Fascist newspaper editor in Berlin.

title: NO FAULT: A FAILED EXPERIMENT
description: THE effectiveness of a law should be measured by its ability to achieve its stated purpose. Once the law ceases to be effective or, more significantly, does the opposite of what it is meant to do, it should be altered, even if such a move involves a radical departure that amounts to an admission that the purpose of the law - however noble its intent - was a failure.

title: Agnes Pall, a Director Of Y.M.C.A. Division
description: Agnes Pall, the director of the Young Men's Christian Association's Center for International Management Studies and an associate director of the Y.M.C.A. International Division, died of cancer Friday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 50 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: Mary P. Ettari Is Wed

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: What JusticeFound at E.P.A.

title: BOOKSELLERS ACTIVE IN PUBLISHING
description: Booksellers Active in Publishing

title: NO GENERALIZATION APPLIES TO QUALITY OF SCHOOLS IN U.S.
description: THE spate of criticisms recently made against the public schools has brought about widespread public discussion, but complete information is needed so that citizens and leaders can make decisions that are truly in the best interest of our children.

title: Color Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION
description: State OpensBrink's Trial

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: ''Abraham Lincoln wrote the Gettysburg Address while traveling from Washington on the back of an envelope.''

title: WHEN STYLE OVERRIDES THE CONTENT
description: Acertain method of filmmaking reached its zenith in 1972, when Bob Rafelson put his actors on elephants in ''The King of Marvin Gardens.'' Since the scene took place on the beach in Atlantic City, why elephants? was a good question; however, why

title: SUNDAY, AUGUST 14, 1983 International
description: France deployed paratroops in the eastern Chad town of Abeche. The French forces were backed by helicopters and had orders to return fire if attacked. The move came as the Government forces they support pulled back to a new defense line under continued Libyan air strikes. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: Puerto Rican Immigrants
description: The assertion by Alan Pifer, president emeritus of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, that the newly displaced Puerto Rican professional can be a model of assimilation and success for the rest of us already here is rather ingenuous, to say the least (''The New Wave of Puerto Rican Immigrants,'' by Howard Bray, July 3). Besides encouraging our community to avoid coming to terms with what is an increasingly untenable economic and social situation on the island, it belittles the attempts of us here on the mainland to overcome very real obstacles to our equality as a people.

title: CHORAL WORKS OFFER A RICH LEGACY
description: Karl Richter's late 50's, early 60's Archiv recordings of the great Bach choral works taught an entire generation how to think about this music. Richter's work represented a happy compromise between the weighty, Teutonic Bach playing espoused by such conductors as Willem Mengelberg and Otto Klemperer and the leaner, more self-consciously scholarly interpretations of Gustav Leonhardt and Nikolaus Harnoncourt. By the time of Richter's early death in 1981, however, many younger Baroque enthusiasts considered him something of an antiquated reactionary for his continuing use of women altos and 20th-century instruments.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Slippage in Housing Starts?

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THEIR FAILURE WAS ALL BUT GUARANTEED
description: WITH the recent decisions of Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs to abandon over-the- counter trading in New York Stock Exchange listed equities, it would appear that the floor of the exchange has virtually eliminated competition from O-T-C market makers. If this development reflected nothing more - nor less - than a triumph based on some technical or economic advantages inherent in the specialist system of market making, it would be a highly laudable outcome.

title: TWO DIE IN GUNFIGHT IN IRELAND
description: Gunmen opened fire on police posts at two points near the border with the Irish republic today. Two officers were wounded and two attackers were killed, the police said.

title: GARMENT INDUSTRY IS BRACING FOR A 'MADHOUSE' TOMORROW
description: With power restored throughout the garment industry area early yesterday, apparel manufacturers said they were bracing for one of their busiest days ever tomorrow.

title: Federal Stewardship Of Sandy Hook Decried
description: Linda Mulhausen's lamentation on the possible expansion of Sandy Hook's facilities (Opinion Page, July 10) was very apropos but perhaps not carried far enough. What has taken place since the Federal Government has taken over the beach facilities is nothing short of disaster.

title: Remodeling a Wright House
description: Living in a Wright house is certainly not for the faint at heart, and the present owners are to be congratulated for the preservation of the architectural shell of the house (''Retouching a Master's Work,'' by Veronica McNiff, June 26). As the curator in charge of the Wright collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and of the recent installation of the living room from the second Francis W. Little residence in the American Wing, I cannot, however, join Veronica McNiff in her praise of Linda Holtzschue's remodeling of the interiors.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BRITISH BUSINESS
description: Britain may be having trouble selling its goods abroad, but when it comes to its nonmerchandise or service sector, business is strong. Early indications are that trade in this so- called invisible sector in 1983 will be even better than last year. One key reason: the continued prosperity in the City of London, a significant element in Britain's performance in invisible trade.

title: AOKI'S 204 LEADS BY SHOT IN BUICK OPEN
description: Isao Aoki stayed a stroke ahead of Jack Renner and three other players today after three rounds of the $350,000 Buick Open.

title: FORMER STAR IN CIRCUS WAS 92
description: Victoria Codona Adolph, a trapeze artist with the Mexican Flying Codona family who later became a featured wire-walker billed as Princess Victoria in a number of American circuses, died Tuesday in Palm Springs, Calif. Mrs. Adolph, who lived in Palm Springs, was 92 years old.

title: THE NATION
description: The Corn Factor

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: FESTIVAL REFLECTS THE POLISH SPIRIT
description: A SHOPKEEPER is repairing one of the colorful hand-painted shutters above his store on Pulaski Street. Below, workers are sweeping the sand from the recently laid brick edging along the sidewalk. Volunteers at the Polish Town Civic Association are repairing the kielbasa and beer booths in preparation for one and a half tons of kielbasa, 160 barrels of beer and 175 cases of imported Polish beer.

title: ACCUSATIONS OF AN EX-ADVISER
description: AUTUMN OF FURY

title:
HOME DESIGN;
RENEGADE DECOR
description: HOUSE WITHOUT A PAST'' IS KARL Lagerfeld's description of his apartment on the 21st floor of one of the many new buildings that have turned Monte Carlo's skyline into a Lilliputian Manhattan. Lagerfeld, whose considerable powers of invention permit him to regularly and successfully design the Chloe and the Chanel collections in Paris, as well as the Fendi fur collection in Rome, was at first stumped by the banality of high-rise architecture. He was at a loss as to what to do with the space. Until he remembered Memphis.

title: BOCCIE PLAYERS GAIN IN NUMBERS
description: NORWALK FOR about 20 seconds, Angelo Mattera peered down the narrow clay court, studying the lie of the balls that had already been thrown and their proximity to the ''pallino.'' Then he fired his hard plastic green ball down the court.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: AGAINST THE STREAM. By James Hanley. (Avon/Bard, $4.95.) A gripping novel that covers 10 days in the life of a fierce, desperate little boy who has suddenly been orphaned, ''Against the Stream'' is the work of ''a most remarkable writer.'' Our reviewer, Anne Tyler, called James Hanley ''a creator of small but extraordinarily immediate, dense, sharply defined worlds'' and said the ''dead-on precision'' of his language ''makes the most humdrum domestic event seem brand-new and curiously arcane.''

title:
STAMPS;
PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION IN THE 19TH CENTURY STYLE
description: Aone-cent coil stamp picturing a four-wheeled horse-drawn omnibus continues the ongoing Transportation Series. It is being issued Friday in Arlington, Va. to coincide with the opening session of the American First Day Cover Society convention in Arlington, Va.

title: NEW STATE LAW GIVES ARTISTS RIGHT TO SUE TO PROTECT WORK
description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation yesterday giving artists the right to sue when they believe that alterations made in their works have damaged their reputations.

title:
DINING OUT;
JAPANESE VARIETY UNDER ONE ROOF
description: THE remodeled premises of the old Gissha Steakhouse now holds an emporium of Japanese cooking establishments. Whereas in Japan most eating places specialize - in noodles, sushi, steak, blowfish or grilled things, for example - Karuta has gathered several restaurants under one roof, like boutiques in a department store.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: After being sentenced in April 1982 to 15 years to life in prison for killing a waiter in Manhattan, Jack Henry Abbott was found liable for monetary damages sought by the victim's widow. A State Supreme Court justice ordered a civil trial to determine how much money the widow, Ricci Adan, should get.

title: THE ANA IN SAN DIEGO
description: The 92nd anniversary convention of the American Numismatic Association opens Tuesday in San Diego. This will be the year's biggest coin show with attendance expected to exceed 10,000.

title: QUICK RULING HELD NECESSARY IN WINGED KELL CONTROVERSY
description: The summerlong controversy surrounding Australia II in the America's Cup trials stems from the uniqueness of the yacht's keel. It is a brilliant concept, revolutionary in sailboat design. And that is the problem.

title: UP TO A FIFTH OF U.S. WORKERS NOW RELY ON PART-TIME JOB
description: Bill and Ginny Passafiume are part of a growing phenomenon in the American work force, one that does not show up in unemployment figures: a dramatic increase in part-time work.

title: NO MORE NUKES, OR MUCH ELSE, TO BE NEEDED SOON
description: ALBANY PERHAPS the best thing that can be said about the argument over the Shoreham nuclear plant is that it isn't likely to be repeated soon. According to a draft of the state's new energy master plan released last week, no new reactors will be needed before 1999. Indeed, the plan scrubs coal-burning plants proposed for the Arthur Kill on Staten Island, Jamesport, L.I., and the shore of Lake Erie.

title: HARD-HIT SONY GIRDS FOR A FIGHT IN THE AMERICAN ELECTRONICS MARKET
description: TOKYO NOT long ago, the Sony Corporation seemed the ultimate consumer electronics company and the darling of Wall Street, and its pioneering Betamax video cassette recorder promised to lead the industry's glamorous new video sector.

title: OKLAHOMA SPEAKER TRIED IN VOTE FRAUD CASE
description: Testimony in the trial of Dan Draper, Speaker of the Oklahoma House, on Federal vote fraud charges has indicated that illegal registration and the casting of bogus ballots was so commonplace that some Government witnesses appeared perplexed at any suggestion they did anything wrong in a 1982 legislative race.

title: Poll Says Mondale Is Favorite
description: Democrats around the country continue to prefer former Vice President Walter F. Mondale by a comfortable margin over Senator John Glenn of Ohio for their 1984 Presidential nomination, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: ;  Hidden Treasure
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Sri Lanka Accuses the Left Of Promoting Ethnic Tension
description: The Government, which is trying to restore order after riots last month, accused leftists today of promoting ethnic tension to unleash more violence.

title: The Soviet Union
description: To the Editor:

title: Midge De Vries and Joseph Kravitz Are Married
description: Marjorie Yvonne De Vries and Joseph R. Kravitz, members of the class of '84 at the Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine in Hershey, were married yesterday. Acting State Supreme Court Justice William J. Deeley performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Marie Hanache De Vries, mother of the bride, in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: HOTEL-RENT RULES START TOMORROW
description: NEW restrictions effective tomorrow will limit the amount by which hotel operators may increase the rent for long-term tenants in rent-stabilized hotel rooms after they become vacant.

title: FEAR AND EUPHORIA
description: THE day was calm, and as I loaded up main and reserve chutes and waited to make my first jump, a pair of red- tailed hawks circled effortlessly overhead - an inspiration in the face of my apprehensions.

title: Kristi Frank Wed to Arnim S. Holzer
description: At the Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, N.J., yesterday, Kristi Frank and Arnim Sanchez Holzer were married by the Rev. Kenneth Smith.

title: Elizabeth Hayes Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Hayes Jr. of Marshfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Wentworth Hayes, to Addison Ridgely Mauck, son of Dr. and Mrs. F. Taylor Mauck of Farmington, Conn. A spring wedding is planned. Miss Hayes and her fiance graduated from the University of New Hampshire.

title: ALEXANDER C. MILLS
description: Alexander C. Mills, a retired superintendent of the photoengraving department at The New York Times, died Friday morning at the Holmdel (N.J.) Convalescent Center of kidney failure. He was 89 years old and lived in Middletown, N.J.

title: Charboneau Will Sign With Class A San Jose
description: Joe Charboneau, the American League rookie of the year with the Cleveland Indians in 1980, will sign a contract Monday to play with the San Jose Bees of the Class A California League, the club said today.

title: CONCERT: STEPHEN BURNS AND ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: Friday's Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall featured two very different soloists. Each played familiar pieces - Alicia de Larrocha Mozart's Concerto in A (K. 488) and Stephen Burns the Haydn Trumpet Concerto. Gerard Schwarz conducted the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra.

title: NEW LIGHT ON END END'S PAST
description: MAIN STREET, in the Village of East Hampton, was filled with thundering noises and neck-to- neck congestion as far back as the Colonial period. Back then, however, there was more livestock on the street than there were people.

title: DANCE: AMY OSGOOD AND COMPANY
description: Dance Theater Workshop's summer Out-of-Towners series brought a group of healthy, attractive young performers from Chicago to town on Thursday at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater.

title: GOODBYE ECONOMIC GAINS
description: Two decades after the historic civil rights march on Washington, America's own march toward economic and social justice is not only stalled but pivoting backward.

title: Ellen M. Waznik Wed To Francis Coughlin Jr.
description: Ellen Marie Waznik, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Waznik of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., was married yesterday to Francis J. Coughlin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coughlin of Manhasset, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. John J. Wiest at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Dixon, by 2 Seconds, Wins Asbury Park Run
description: Rod Dixon, a 34-year-old runner from Auckland, N.Z., outsprinted 26-year- old Andy Robertson of Sterling, Scotland, in the last 20 yards to win the third annual Asbury Park 10-Kilometer Classic today.

title: FILLING A LEXINGTON CORNER
description: When the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York erected its headquarters building at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street in the 1950's, it had to settle for an L-shaped design that wrapped around a small structure on the corner whose owner refused to sell.

title: REGGAE AND REVOLUTION
description: The Life of Bob Marley. By Timothy White. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Teams Seek Survivors Of Mexican Landslide
description: Rescue squads continued to search through tons of mud and boulders today for 38 people who were missing after a landslide late Thursday.

title: Lucia Whittelsey Weds a Publisher
description: Lucia Winifred Whittelsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Whittelsey Jr. of Newtown Square, Pa., was married yesterday to Winfield Scott Smyth, son of Ethelyn Holmes Smyth of Los Gatos, Calif., and the late John Scott Smyth of Brattleboro, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Douglas Theurner performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Burkehaven, N.H.

title: PAN AM GAMES OPEN TODAY IN CARACAS
description: Ready or not, the ninth quadrennial Pan American Games will begin Sunday.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: GREENWICH VILLAGE
description: IN 1948, a young woman arrived in

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER ; SPEEDING THE WAY THROUGH CUSTOMS
description: Europe was great. The plane trip was fine; even the in- flight movie was one you hadn't seen and rather enjoyed. Now comes Customs.

title: Browns Praised On Commitment
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HEADLINERS Cleveland Comeback
description: Dennis J. Kucinich , who alienated many in Cleveland as that city's feisty young Mayor in the late 1970's, found 4,118 Clevelanders who were willing to forgive and forget last week.

title: CHRYSLER RESCUE: A WELL-DISGUISED BLESSING
description: To the Editor:

title:
CAMERA;
HOW TO CAPTURE THE SUBTLETIES OF NATURE'S BLOOMS
description: Fred W. Rosen and George Schaub are amateur photographers.

title: SHARKS: FEW FACTS, MANY FANTASIES
description: BRIELLE ON a recent trip aboard the Paramount II, a party fishing boat that sails from here, a fisherman hoping for fluke was surprised instead to reel in an 18-inch shark.

title: FOSTER WINS 110 HURDLES: PEACOCK 2D IN HIGH JUMP
description: Greg Foster hit the last three hurdles but held on for a gold medal, and Tyke Peacock took the silver as he equaled the American record in the high jump by clearing 7 feet 7 1/4 inches on his last attempt at the World Track and Field championships tonight.

title: WHAT PRICE SPEAKER WIRE?
description: Almost everyone admired the emperor's new clothes. Given our tendency to be guided by our expectations, this happens all the time - even in audio. The latest outbreak of this kind of gullibility has to do with loudspeaker wires. Just why a simple connecting cord rates all this fuss and argument is not easy to see at first glance. But then, one should never understimate the capacity - nay, the eagerness - of the more maniacal devotees of any cause to inflate minor issues. That's why audio fans are buying special wires at up to $5 per foot to connect their loudspeakers.

title: IN GREENWICH, A BIT OF RELIEF
description: GREENWICH AT 9:45 on a recent weekday morning, Rebecca S. Breed, the First Selectman of Greenwich, left her Town Hall office, got into her gray station wagon and headed eastward along Putnam Avenue for Cos Cob, just a few miles away. Stopping only for an occasional red light, she made the journey in less than 10 minutes.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE FUR FLIES ON THE BRIDGE OVER GENERATION GAP
description: MY 16-YEAR-OLD kid is always telling me what to do. ''Here's something interesting in the 'Help Wanted' pages,'' she said to me. ''Become a stringer for The News Tribune.''

title: Jill Ellen Aber Will Marry Mark H. Hudesman in 1984
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Aber of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Ellen Aber, to Mark Harlan Hudesman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hudesman of Woodmere, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: BIRD rehabilitators last week were evaluating whether to operate on a peregrine falcon that was blasted by a shotgun in the Burlington County community of Runnemede earlier this month, but ''the prognosis really isn't that good,'' a spokesman said.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MOST school plays are performed in the school's auditorium, to an audience of doting parents and grandparents. But one Newark school group that started out in the usual way recently ended up onstage at Symphony Hall.

title: CARL LEWIS EMERGES: THE BEST AT ALL HE DOES
description: HELSINKI, Finland

title: GREENWICH OFFICIAL ASSAYS BORDER ROLE
description: GREENWICH AT 9:45 on a recent weekday morning, Rebecca S. Breed, the First Selectman of Greenwich, Conn., left her Town Hall office, got into her gray family station wagon, and headed for Cos Cob, just a few miles away. Stopping only for an occasional red light, she made the journey in less than 10 minutes.

title: THE SHIFT FROM RENTING TO OWNING IN WHITE PLAINS
description: ABROAD and pleasant boulevard called

title: 'DEMOCRACY' IS NO CURE-ALL FOR CENTRAL AMERICANS
description: A Government fell last week in Guatemala, and so quick and relatively bloodless was the fall that in another age and place few Americans would have noticed. But this is 1983, and so deeply involved is the United States in Central America that every shift and change - even the replacement of one general with another from within his own Government - seems laden with importance.

title: CLERC, ARIAS TO PLAY IN HEAD CUP IN RYE
description: PORT CHESTER TWO of the hottest players on the world tennis circuit, Jose- Luis Clerc and Jimmy Arias, are coming to the county.

title: ASTRONOMERS SAY STREET LIGHTS WILL BLIND PALOMAR
description: Ignoring pleas from astronomers, city officials have put out bids on a street lighting system that the astronomers say will ultimately blind the world-famous telescope at Mount Palomar, 60 miles to the north.

title: OPERA: 'ADVENTURES OF FRIAR TUCK'
description: We live in an age of revisionism, and many long-cherished myths have recently come up for re-evaluation. The latest to endure this contemporary acid test is the ever-green story of Robin Hood and his merry men.

title: ECHOES OF BASKETBALL SCANDAL
description: Perhaps the most disturbing thing for Andre Logan, beyond the embarrassment and feelings of betrayal, is that he never got the chance he had always hoped for.

title: PORT AGENCY IS FIGURING IN POLITICS
description: TRENTON THE Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is figuring prominently in political developments in New Jersey these days. The Republican state chairman is resigning because of increased business commitments and his recent appointment to the authority; a top aide in the Assembly Democratic majority office is quitting to take a job with the authority next month, and Mayor Koch wants to redraw authority plans for industrial development projects in Hoboken and New York, much to the surprise and annoyance of the Kean administration.

title: QADDAFI'S ASSAULT ON CHAD CAUSES FEAR OF MORE TO COME
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, is said to covet Chad, his southern neighbor, because it provides him with what he calls ''vital space.'' An earlier player on history's stage had the same notion in Europe and called it ''Lebensraum.''

title: Angela Haggerty, Pierce S. Sioussat To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Hunnewell of Locust Valley, L.I., and New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hunnewell's daughter, Angela Burdeau Haggerty, to Pierce Stewart Sioussat, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Stewart Sioussat of Cooperstown, N.Y. Miss Hagerty is the daughter also of Joseph J. Haggerty Jr. of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: WORLD CHURCHES SEE PROGRESS IN HEALING RIFTS
description: Against the backdrop of rising criticism of its policies, the World Council of Churches ended its Sixth Assembly this week after a vigorous effort to blend human-rights concerns with spiritual life.

title: FOR NOW, THE DEFICIT WILL JUST KEEP LOOMING
description: It is an axiom of the capital that a President faced with deep policy disagreements among his aides makes his decisions on the basis of what makes political sense. The axiom seems to apply in the case of President Reagan's willingness to live with the threat posed by Federal deficits rather than entertain the possibility of tax increases to help close them.

title: Kerouac's City

title: HOW MANY CRISES ARE TOO MANY TO HANDLE?
description: Libya threatening the Sudan, a Vietnamese incursion into Thailand, Lebanon in need of a peacekeeping force, Cubans reportedly contemplating a combat role in Nicaragua, the obscure oasis of Faya- Largeau in Chad under siege by Libyan-backed rebels - in each case, the Reagan Administration has not hesitated to make some kind of military response. And these responses seemed to have the desired effect: Whatever their military actions or plans, certain nations appeared to have second thoughts, although most of the situations are still unfolding.

title: BANKS FINALLY LIFT THEIR PRIME RATE
description: The nation's banks finally raised the prime rate to 11 percent from 10 1/2 percent, with Citibank leading the way. It was the first industry-wide increase since February 1982 in the rate banks use to set corporate loans. Though Wall Street had expected the move, the stock and bond markets took a pounding. The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 20 points, while bond prices plummeted. The higher prime rate only increased the attractiveness of the dollar to overseas investors, and despite reported intervention by central banks, the dollar continued to climb to new highs against major currencies. There is growing concern among economists that higher interest rates over the last two months will cut short the recovery. Already some Wall Street analysts have scaled back growth projections for the 1983 fourth quarter and 1984 first quarter. But stocks and bonds recovered sharply at week's end. Friday witnessed a strong rally in the bond market, and the Government's long-term bond closed with an 11.71 yield, almost half a percentage point below the highs of the week. The rally was helped by the Federal Reserve's report that the money supply rose $400 million, considerably less than expected. Stocks recovered almost all of their losses from early in the week, closing at 1,182.83.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
CLOTHES AND IDEAS BLOWING IN THE WIND

Someone before us had left the clothespins on the empty rope; that was the clincher, I think. Clothespins immediately put a laundry line into action and make it beckon to be used, like a palette with all the colors squeezed out in place, waiting for someone, even without talent, to come along and dip a brush in.

Nevertheless, last week's rise in the prime, to 11 percent from the 10 1/2 percent at which the key interest rate has rested for almost a year and a half, had the usual effect. The stock market tumbled more than 20 points the first day alone, and though at week's end the Dow Jones industrial average was still 50 percent above where it was 12 months ago, despondency persisted.

title: LA DOLCE VITE? HAH!
description: We lead an ordered life behind the wheel of an automobile in America. There are red and green lights, one-way streets and all kinds of signs telling us what (and more often, what not) to do. Streets are named. Police officers are generally available. We all more or less speak the same language and can ask for directions when we get lost. As Americans, we have all grown up behind the wheel. We are good drivers. Well, most of us are good drivers.

title: TODAY, MORE BUILDINGS ARE COMPETITIVE CREATIONS

The existing Opera was the result of an architectural competition held in the early 1860's; the weighty decision on the new one will once again be made through a competition staged by the French government.

title: REAGAN VETOES A MONEY BILL FOR CHICAGO'S DESEGREGATION
description: President Reagan vetoed legislation today that would have allocated $20 million to carry out a school desegregation program in Chicago mandated by a Federal court.

title: IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE CAN BAYREUTH BE HEADED AFTER THIS 'RING'?
description: Anew production of Wagner's ''Ring'' at Bayreuth comes as close to being a religious ritual as any secular ceremony known to cultural anthropology. Pilgrims and acolytes congregate each afternoon in somber garb (black tie is the only sanctioned uniform) for a service that can consume seven hours, including intermissions for fairly heavy dining. As with all religions, Wagnerism's official dogma is both sacrosanct and yet pliable according to the spirit of the times. Copies of the composer's canonical writings such as ''Mein Leben'' or of his widow's diaries are displayed in every bookstore window. The faithful can recite the librettos word for word, like believers mumbling over their beads. The ''Ring,'' you might think, is chiseled in stone by now. And yet, scribes and pharisees from all over the world regularly gather at the sacred Festspielhaus on Bayreuth's ''green hill'' to ponder the texts and to explicate new hermeneutical interpretations. Bayreuth is the holy city of a devout, vital sect, like Bethlehem or Mecca or Salt Lake City.

title: The Cloistered Life
description: In these times when most of us are dedicated to getting ''ours'' and ''doing our thing,'' it's good to know there are people who live for other reasons (''The Cloistered Life,'' by Julia Lieblich, July 10). While we are ''making a mark,'' ''beating the competition,'' ''fulfilling our potential,'' ''getting our share,'' these sisters do otherwise and, so doing, teach us that the aforementioned pursuits are not essential to happiness, and certainly not to peace. It is reassuring to know such people exist among us. PAULINE KERR New York City

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HE cultural heritage of Long Island's 600,000 Jews will be the focus of the first New York Jewish American Arts Festival, which is scheduled for Sept. 4 and 5 in Wheatley Heights.

title: Wendy K. Bowis Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Wendy Kahler Bowis to Charles Francis Malacaria has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hans Bowis of Chevy Chase, Md. A wedding in December is planned.

title: TWO CAMPS BATTLE OVER THE NATURE OF THE MEDIUM
description: The field of photography has never been one big happy family - to start with, it has never been that big - but, increasingly, it seems to consist of two families, and feuding ones at that. The issue that both divides and frames current photographic thinking is not (blessed relief) whether photography can be considered an art, but what kind of an art it is. Is it an art like painting or drawing, with the same esthetic claims and standards, or is it an art form unto itself, so inextricably interconnected with social and political values that to call it ''art'' in the conventional sense requires quotation marks?

title: Drugs Linked to Death Of Tennessee Williams
description: New York City's Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday that the playwright Tennessee Williams was apparently trying to ingest barbiturates when he choked to death on a plastic bottle cap last February.

title: Alison A. Winter Is Married in Britain
description: Alison Anne Winter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Alfred Winter of Worthing, England, was married yesterday to John Edward Oppenheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Oppenheim of Scranton, Pa., and New York. The Rev. Victor R. Sumner performed the ceremony at the Findon Valley Free Church in Worthing.

title: WOMEN TRY NEW PATHS ON RIGHTS
description: After months of concern about the effects of the ''gender gap'' on the 1984 Presidential election and after weeks of conscious effort to demonstrate its sensitivity to matters affecting women, the Reagan Administration's difficulties on the issue flared again last week. The United States Commission on Civil Rights joined 50 members of Congress - including some prominent Republicans - in accusing the Administration of abdicating its responsibilities in making a narrow interpretation of a law barring sex discrimination in educational institutions receiving Federal aid. Senator Bob Dole, for one, called the Administration's view ''legalistic.'' It could, the Kansas Republican said, be ''a substantial setback for women's rights.''

title: GEORGE W. HAIGHT
description: George Winthrop Haight, a specialist in international law, died Friday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan after a brief illness.

title: POLICING POLLUTION TRAFFIC ACROSS ARTHUR KILL
description: No matter which way the wind blows or the tides run, someone always seems to be going to court over the Arthur Kill, the 10-mile-long channel separating Staten Island from Middlesex and Union Counties. The reason is the two-way traffic in pollution - debris from a New York City landfill washes onto New Jersey while industrial fumes from New Jersey blow eastward.

title: EX-CHIEF FINDS THERE'S LIFE AFTER ROCKWELL
description: PITTSBURGH LIKE any angler, Willard F. Rockwell Jr. has found that sometimes the big ones get away. And for most of his post-retirement career, the former chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation has lost his share.

title: NOISE PLAN SEEKS ACCORD ON OPERATIONS AT REPUBLIC AIRPORT
description: -OF-WAR has been in progress over Republic Airport in Farmingdale for several years. Area residents have been seeking a reduction in aircraft noise, while members of the local industrial and aviation communities have been struggling to keep the facility free of air traffic restraints. Tomorrow, the Republic Airport Commission will consider adopting a noise abatement plan designed to alleviate pressure on both sides of the issue.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Kissinger PanelBegins SearchFor ConsensusIn 1933 Franklin D. Roosevelt launched a ''good neighbor'' policy in Latin America, whose cornerstones were nonintervention and mutual confidence. Last week, as an American naval task force completed maneuvers off Nicaragua and made way for another while thousands of American troops prepared for exercises in Honduras, President Reagan revived the term and asked his new commission on Central America to try to give it substance.

title: UTOPIA WITHOUT LAWYERS?
description: From the earliest days of the legal profession, lawyers have been maligned. ''No where so busy a man as he there was; And yet he seemed busier than he was,'' Chaucer said of the attorney in ''Canterbury Tales.'' Erasmus agreed: ''A most learned species of profoundly ignorant men.'' And Shakespeare said, in an often- quoted passage in ''Henry VI, Part II'': ''The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.''

title: TAKING UP THE CHALLENGE OF 'A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE
description: HOLLYWOOD From a crane holding him high in the air, cinematographer Bill Butler surveys the set. Smoky in color and gritty in tone, it is a graphic re-creation of the Vieux Carre, a squalid New Orleans neighborhood as it might have appeared during the 1940's. Today, the set is teeming with extras. Women in sundresses, some with children in tow, make their way down a shabby street past shore- leave sailors on their way to a noisy, corner honky-tonk. Across from it is the courtyard of a crumbling tenement.

title: TOWN HALL IS SCOUTING FOR DONORS
description: The endowment and naming of concert halls is usually a subtle behind-the-scenes affair. A large gift is given, and the generosity is remembered seemingly as an afterthought. Town Hall, that proud but battered old institution on West 43d Street, needs money to refurbish itself and to re-establish its 62-year-old reputation as an important performing arts center. It is not being coy about it.

title: MONTANA'S HUNTERS WARNED ON PESTICIDES IN FOWL
description: Wild ducks and geese in this state are tainted with high levels of dangerous pesticides, according to a two-year study, and a scientist for the state says the problem may be more widespread.

title: Marci Reisman to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Reisman of New York, Armonk, N.Y., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marci Carol Reisman, to Jeffrey James Hill, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Hill of White Plains. The wedding is planned for Oct. 8. The future bride's father is a senior partner in the New York law firm of Reisman, Schwartz & Goldberg. Mr. Hill's father is a dentist.

title: Nancy D. Sturgis To Become Bride
description: Nancy D. Sturgis and Henry S. Sturgis Jr., both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Sprague Sturgis, to Wilson Stuart Neely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Neely of Dallas.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE FINGER LAKES
description: European countries take pride in their distinctive regions of scenic lakes (England's Lake District), of hillsides dotted with vines (Italy's Tuscany) or of grand country houses (France's Loire Valley). In New York State such varied charms are gathered in the same place - the Finger Lakes district.

title: Craxi Government Wins Confidence Debate
description: The new Government won an easy victory today in a confidence debate in Italy's Senate to gain final confirmation for Bettino Craxi as the country's first Socialist Prime Minister, a Senate spokesman said.

title: SAYING GOODBYE TO NEIGHBORS
description: OUR neighbors and closest friends moved away last winter. We miss them a lot. We have been lucky - we have had good neighbors all our lives. We miss even those we have not heard from in many months or years, and those we probably will never see again. It is sad to lose good neighbors. It is like losing a member of the family.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Amateur Athletics
description: Pan American Games, at Caracas, Venezuela. Opening ceremonies will be held for the competition in 25 sports. There are approximately 4,000 athletes representing 30 countries in the Western Hemisphere at the games, which run through Aug. 29. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.)

title: Air Canada Hires U.S. Team To Investigate Safety Lapses
description: Air Canada has called in a team of United States aviation safety experts to investigate the airline after two of its planes were involved in midair incidents.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: United Housewrecking Could Fix the Place Up Fifteen miles from White Plains and to either side of I-95 at Stamford's Exit 6 at Harvard Avenue there are similar fantasylands called United Housewrecking and United Housewrecking Annex for Architectural Treasures.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SHOW AIDS NEW LONDON MUSEUM
description: FOR just over 20 years, the New London Antiques Festival has raised funds each August for the benefit of the Lyman Allyn Museum. The museum, on Mohegan Avenue in New London, is situated on a hill that is part of the campus of Connecticut College, overlooking much of this 17th-century seaport.

title: THE CULT FIGURE'S WIDOWER
description: CLARK BLAISE prefaces ''Lusts'' with the familiar disclaimer that any resemblance between his characters and persons living or dead is purely coincidental. But when Mr. Blaise's protagonist, Richard Durgin, takes a writing course at the University of Iowa, the instructor bears more than a coincidental resemblance to a person very much alive: ''My teacher was Philip Roth, only twenty-eight that year, himself a presence.'' Since it has become fashionable for novelists to place real celebrities in imaginary gardens, one can easily suspend one's disbelief. Raymond Chandler and Hannah Arendt also make guest appearances.

title: A TASTE OF MEXICO
description: MORTON N. COHEN, who writes and lectures on Victorian literature, is working on a biography of Lewis Carroll.

title: AMERICA'S CUP SAILS AND SELLS TECHNOLOGY ON THE HIGH SEAS
description: Sailing has always been a seat- of-the-pants sport, the sailor attuned to the interplay of boat and elements. But in this year's America's Cup trials, technology has more than ever put the race, and to a degree sailing itself, on a new tack, for innovations here can become fashion throughout the racing community.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: What racing requires each competitor to spend millions just to get to the starting line? Yacht racing. And more specifically, the America's Cup races - an international competition among syndicates. Even Karim El Husseini Shah, the fourth Aga Khan and among the world's richest men, created a consortium consisting of one of his own businesses, plus Alitalia, Fiat, Cinzano wine and Valentino, the fashion designer, to underwrite Italy's representative yacht, Azzurra, in this year's race. The 1983 trials began in June with boats from 10 syndicates participating. The finals start Sept. 13. The prize: a $500 silver cup, a trophy that has been won by the United States in every competition since the first in 1851.

title: 150 FRENCH TROOPS DEPLOYED IN TOWN IN EASTERN CHAD
description: French paratroops, backed by helicopters and with orders to return fire if attacked, were deployed today in Chad's eastern town of Abeche.

title: Keith Browning, Pamela Oresman To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Oresman of Darien, Conn., and Captiva Island, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Jane Oresman, to Keith Nulton Browning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Browning of Fairfield, Conn., and Vail, Colo.

title: RUSSIAN SEES A FUNNY SIDE TO BUSINESS
description: Moscow's drive for greater productivity in industry has centered renewed interest on a persistent scourge of the Soviet economy - the daily business meetings called by executives that keep people away from their work for hours.

title: FRANK DUNLOP READIES FOR EDINBURGH
description: LONDON Frank Dunlop won't have a chance to put his stamp on this year's Edinburgh International Festival. But when he takes over on Oct. 1 as director of the world's biggest arts jamboree, his plans and movements will be watched with considerable curiosity. It is an appointment that has raised expectations and eyebrows. Expectations because Mr. Dunlop becomes the first theater man ever to have run this music-and-opera dominated festival. Eyebrows because Mr. Dunlop, who constantly commutes between the Young Vic Theater in London and the United States where he is supervising his perennially successful production of ''Camelot,'' is a born popularizer and showman with an appetite for novelty. ''Unless Edinburgh can produce a lot of unique things,'' he says defiantly, ''there'd be no reason for a troublemaker like me to be going there.''

title: THE WORLD
description: The distrustful nature of United States relations with the Soviet Union, which makes arms negotiations so difficult, was underlined by two developments that came to light last week. It was learned that Washington recently asked Moscow for an urgent meeting of a special consultative group to discuss possible Soviet violations of two strategic arms treaties, the 1972 SALT I agreement and the 1979 SALT II, which both sides have agreed to implement though it has not been ratified by the Senate. For lack of ''hard and fast evidence,'' the Reagan Administration made no formal accusations, confining itself to ''raising concerns'' with Soviet officials and receiving, it said, unsatisfactory replies.

title:
GARDENING;
ADVANTAGES IN SUMMER PRUNING
description: MOST of us have been conditioned through years of exposure to think that the winter is the correct time to prune trees. Actually there are several advantages to be realized from summer pruning.

title: U.S. INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON COLLAPSE OF CEILING
description: JERSEY CITY THE investigation by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey into the collapse of the 50- ton suspended ceiling at its Journal Square Transportation Center here is expected to take about six weeks, but efforts are under way to have Federal investigators join the inquiry.

title: CHURCH DENIES IT HAS POLITICAL GOALS IN GUATEMALA
description: Officials of a California church that counts among its followers the deposed President of Guatemala, Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, deny having political ambitions and disagree with those who say their sect and other Protestant churches are being manipulated by conservative forces in Latin America.

title: All in the Family
description: After 14 years in the National Basketball Association, it's hard to find the right substitute sport, but after one false start, Rick Barry has apparently found his. ''It used to be golf but that's too relaxing a game,'' said Barry, who switched to tennis and found his niche.

title: POCKETING A WATCH
description: ''To carry a fine Brequet watch is to feel that you have the brains of a genius in your pocket,'' wrote the late David Salomons, who is acknowledged as the greatest collector of such watches.

title: JERRY FORD AT 70
description: Former President Gerald Ford, who just turned 70, is a busy and, by all appearances, happy man. Unlike Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter, he seems to have no regrets and no longings for the past.

title: SALMON FISHING: SCOTLAND'S ROYAL SPORT
description: The reputation which Scotland has long enjoyed as the Eden of anglers for whom the Atlantic Salmon is the king of all gamefish is well deserved. Certainly, Iceland, with its heavy run of fish, has its champions, and so does Norway, with its reputation for big fish and fast-flowing rivers. But for sheer variety of accessible rivers, dramatic changing scenery and consistent sport, Scotland has long been the most highly esteemed.

title: ; THE CLOISTERED LIFE --
description: After reading Julia Lieblich's article, I came to the conclusion that the cloistered life represents either the peak of human spirituality and perfection or the pit of near-psychotic inanity, and there is no way of knowing which is which. Perhaps the beauty lies not in the cloistered life itself, but in the simple act of taking the risk, because the leitmotif of many an hour in the isolation of the convent must surely be ''What if . . . ?'' JOSEPH M. SEGARRA, M.D. Arlington, Mass.

title: Kicker Impresses Parcells
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants was highly impressed by the performance of Ali Haji-Sheikh, the rookie from the University of Michigan who kicked five field goals against the Pittsburgh Steelers after missing the last Sunday's game against the Jets because of a foot injury.

title: DARIO FO'S BARBED WIT IS AIMED AT MANY TARGETS
description: As playwright, monologist and public personality, Dario Fo is an impertinent iconoclast, provoking officialdom at the same time that he is tickling his audience. Among contemporary playwrights who are concerned with the theater of politics - writers as diverse as Fernando Arrabal, David Hare and Caryl Churchill - Fo has distinguished himself not only as an author but as a performer of his own work. Imagine a cross between Bertolt Brecht and Lenny Bruce and you may begin to have an idea of the scope of Fo's anarchic art. In common with Brecht, he is seeking social change; in common with Bruce, he is often scatalogical and blasphemous.

title: MUSIC: 'LAMENT OF KAMUELA'
description: There is so much wrong with Jon Appleton's ''Lament of Kamuela,'' a multimedia production currently at Dartmouth College's Hopkins Center, that it is difficult to know where to begin.

title: THE UNSUNG HEROES OF AMERICA'S LABOR MOVEMENT
description: FIFTY years ago, the hot summer

title: BLUEGRASS: THE WHITES AND FRIENDS
description: Curious are the fortunes of the music business. The Whites, in one configuration or another and under different group names, have been around for more than 20 years. But it is just now that they have released a record on a major label and begun to win the kind of attention within mainstream country music and from pop- music critics that their excellence might have seemed to deserve all along. Thursday night they were at the Lone Star Cafe, and although Buck White seemed slightly nonplused at the decorous nature of the smallish audience for the late show, the group still delivered a charming set.

title: PHONE STRIKE ASSESSED
description: HOW badly did the start of the nationwide telephone strike last week affect customers in Connecticut? It depended on whom you asked.

title: A LAW ON BIAS PROPERLY ENFORCED
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION'S 'BAD BOY' MAKES GOOD
description: ATLANTA HE is best known as ''Captain Courageous'' - the skipper of the yachts that won the 1977 America's Cup and the stormy 1979 Fastnet race, off the south of England, in which 15 other sailors drowned. At Fastnet last week, Ted Turner tried for another victory at sea. But the waters were calmer this year, and another boat came in first.

title: Somalis Report Their Troops Killed 40 Ethiopian Attackers
description: Somalia said today that Government troops killed 40 Ethiopian soldiers in beating back an attack on two villages in the disputed Ogaden region.

title: KOHL SAYS REAGAN SEEKS SOVIET TALK
description: President Reagan sent Chancellor Helmut Kohl a letter this week confirming interest in a meeting with the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, an Austrian newspaper said today in an interview with Mr. Kohl.

title: RELIEF, DELIGHT AND A HUGE CLEANUP AS LIGHTS GO ON AGAIN IN MIDTOWN
description: In the stores, relieved shopkeepers welcomed the thousands of customers who had heard the power was back. Restaurant owners cleaned out spoiled food from their freezers and talked of opening on Monday. Out on the street, utility workers tried to make sure the lights would stay on - and the police stood by in case they did not.

title: BILL MOYERS CONTINUES TO ASK HARD QUESTIONS
description: It has become a commonplace to praise Bill Moyers,

title: AWAITING THE VERDICT
description: In knockout team play the result of

title: YONKERS MAN AIDS 'COCKNEY' ROUNDUP
description: CARL J. TOTA is not from England. Born and reared in the Bronx, he has lived most of his adult life in the county. But Mr. Tota, a Yonkers resident, is unabashedly ''Cockney,'' part of a vanishing group whose history and heritage he is dedicated to preserving.

title: Miss Hough Is Married
description: Barbara Lord Hough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Lord Hough of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to William Arthur Flint 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Flint Jr. of Woodbridge, Conn., and Stuart, Fla. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: WITNESSES CAN'T IDENTIFY 6 AT U.S. BRINK'S TRIAL
description: A defense lawyer has presented testimony to show that witnesses who saw the Brink's robbery and shootout in Rockland County could not identify any defendants in the Federal trial of the case in Manhattan.

title: THE REGION
description: City Hall toGo It Alone onTimes SquareIn their collaboration to rebuild Times Square, City Hall and the State Urban Development Corporation seem to have developed more animosity than anything else. Things came to a head last week when Mayor Koch angrily pulled out of the partnership and said the city would carry out the $1 billion plan alone.

title: THE NATION
description: On the way to La Paz, Mexico and today's meeting on matters economic with Mexican President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, President Reagan whistle-stopped Florida and the American Southwest. His agenda was matters political; his target, Hispanic Americans - not only the country's second largest and fastest growing minority, but even more important for 1984, a potential voting bloc concentrated in such big electoral states as Texas, Florida, California and New York.

title: WOODCHUCKS' OPEN SEASON ON GARDEN
description: PLEASE come home, Woodrow, all is forgiven. You too, Wilson. Woodrow and Wilson are the two woodchucks who until recently inhabited our modest estate.

title: No Headline
Q AND A
description: Question:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Plugged-InGeneration

title: RYAN INJURED AS JETS STOP RAIDERS, 20-17
description: Because it pitted the Jets against the Los Angeles Raiders, their game tonight at Giants Stadium generated emotion and excitement rarely experienced in an exhibition.

title: Charlotte Barnes to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mary Ellis Lacey of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Nicholas C. Barnes of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Charlotte Chappell Barnes, to W. Brown Glenn Jr., son of Mr. Glenn and Betsy Evans Glenn, both of Greenville, N.C. The wedding is planned for Dec. 10. Miss Barnes is a representative for the women's division of Ralph Lauren in New York. Her fiance works for the Twin Oaks Real Estate Group, Hilton Head Island, S.C.

title: Julie Hope Kassalow Wed To Kevin Anthony Norris
description: Julie Hope Kassalow, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Kassalow of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in White Plains yesterday to Kevin Anthony Norris, son of Jean Norris of Moscow, Pa., and the late Richard A. Norris. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony in the garden of the Mansion at the Westchester Hotel.

title: UNEASY IN BROOKLYN
description: -STAR JEW

title: FAIRFIELD STUDENTS UNEARTHING ITS HISTORY
description: NOT only does Connecticut have a wealth of archeological heritage, says David Poirier, an archeologist with the state's Historical Commission, but ''there has been more archeological activity in Connecticut in the last five years than in the previous three decades.''

title: Hollings's Grandchild Dies
description: Erin Walker Reardon, the 3-month-old granddaughter of Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, died Friday, apparently of sudden infant death syndrome, and the Senator canceled an appearance in Iowa to fly home. Erin was the daughter of John and Helen Hollings Reardon, said Al Kamhi, a spokesman for Mr. Hollings's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: PROVOCATIVE VISIONS
description: IN years past, when photography

title: THE REGION
description: Search RulesApply in School

title: Dallas Transit System Shows Support in Voting
description: The creation of a regional mass transit system and a sales tax to pay for it got strong support in incomplete returns today from voters in Dallas and 20 suburbs.

title: THE WORLD
description: Northern Ireland last week reminded the world of one of its most tenacious trouble spots. First there were night-long street battles in the Catholic areas of Belfast.

title: RESPECT FOR LATINS
description: Why don't we hear about relations between Latin America and the United States until a tempest looms on the horizon? Why does the United States refuse to face its responsibility for what happens elsewhere in the hemisphere? Why does it treat us Latin Americans with such humiliating lack of respect? Stop-gap efforts to calm upheaval in Central America will be of little avail unless we face these questions together and break the demeaning, destructive patterns of the past.

title: McCrory Wins W.B.C. Title
description: Milton McCrory knocked down Colin Jones in the first round today and then stood off a furious attack in the late rounds to win a split 12-round decision and the vacant World Boxing Council welterweight championship.

title:
GARDENING;
ADVANTAGES IN SUMMER PRUNING
description: MOST of us have been conditioned through years of exposure to think that the winter is the correct time to prune trees. Actually there are several advantages to be realized from summer pruning.

title: LOVE AFFAIR WITH A CADILLAC
description: THERE was a time when, like

title: THE NATION
description: Mondale andLabor AgreeTo Big StakesIf time is of the essence in a political campaign, timing can be even more so. It appeared that Walter F. Mondale had scored a tidy coup against his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination when the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council last week agreed to his request to endorse a candidate in October instead of December.

title: Susan Z. Means Plans A November Wedding
