description: Mr. and Mrs. David Hammond Means of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Zimmerman Means, to Daniel Kenly Drake, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Daniel Drake of Villanova, Pa.

title: Katherine Scher To Marry Oct. 8
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Scher of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Elizabeth Scher, to William Lowell Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Stanley Brown of Chatham, N.J. An Oct. 8 wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions

title: ROADBLOCKS GET COURT CHALLENGE AS ARRESTS RISE
description: ARRESTS for drunken driving have risen 300 percent in 14 towns in eastern Connecticut since the state police began operating systematic spot- checks in April to detect drunken drivers.

title: TEEN-AGE ARTISTS BROADEN TALENTS
description: IT was critique week at the Center for Creative Youth on the

title: China-U.S. Coal Project Is Delayed for 90 Days
description: Construction on a huge Chinese-American coal-mining project has been delayed for a further 90 days while the two sides discuss pricing problems, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: WASHINGTON CALLS IN A KEY SOVIET ENVOY ON RUNAWAY YOUTH
description: A top Soviet diplomat was summoned to the State Department today and was told that the United States was firm in insisting that officials be allowed to interview a Russian diplomat's son, who apparently wants to remain in the United States.

title: Chiefs of Newspaper Unions Call for End to Merger Plan
description: The international presidents of both the International Typographical Union and the Newspaper Guild have called for cancellation of referendums on a proposed merger of the two unions.

title: THE WORLD
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet ordered 18,000 troops and police into the streets last week to suppress anti- Government protests in Chile's cities. There followed the worst violence of his 10 years in power. At least 24 civilians, three of them children, were killed in two nights of rioting. Witnesses said troops fired into the air and at houses in slum neighborhoods where protesters leaned from windows and beat out a ''down-with-Pinochet'' rhythm on pots and pans.

title: No Headline
description: Everywhere, Caps From Alaska a friend writes that he's seeing only caps, not hats, on the sourdough. Caps on everyone, emblazoned with logos, just like the T-shirts. Caps and shirts beam out mini-commercials, signaling that because many people have less time for each other lately, we want to broadcast a quick fix on ourselves, a three- or four-word insignia for strangers.

title: No Headline
description: Licio Gelli bought himself a lot of trouble as a leader of the outlawed Italian Masonic lodge, Propaganda 2, and a key figure in the collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, Italy's largest, last year.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: PHILHARMONIC ON S.I.

title: A FEAST FOR THE EYES
description: WITH its setting overlooking Three Mile Harbor in East Hampton, the Clubhouse at Wings Point is a stunning place. Until this year it had been called the Lighthouse, a restaurant whose design took advantage of the waterfront panorama and yet was splendid in its own right, with a soaring interior space that held a 5.5-meter racing sloop (the Jade) over the bar. Now, as the Clubhouse, part of a complex that has been planned to include cottages and recreation facilities and that operates in conjunction with another Wings Point resort on Lake Champlain upstate, it is more magnificent than ever.

title: PRUDENT HERO
description: WESTERING MAN

title: Big Night for Deyna
description: For Kaz Deyna, the 36-year-old veteran of Poland's World Cup soccer teams, the 1983 season with the San Diego Sockers of the North American Soccer League has been pretty much of a washout. He missed the first nine games with a knee injury, and when he finally joined the team he couldn't seem to get his rhythm back.

title: Taiwan Offers Haven To Pilot From China
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that a Chinese Air Force defector who flew a MIG-21 to South Korea last Sunday would be allowed to accept political asylum in Taiwan, where a reward of $4 million in gold awaits him.

title: NEW PROGRAM AIDS SELLERS OF USED CARS
description: THE consumer who does not want to worry about how he'll go about selling his old car can now stop worrying.

title: SKYDIVING FINDING NEW ENTHUSIASTS
description: LAKEWOOD AS THE spectators strain to see the tiny plane 7,000 feet above their heads, four figures soar free of it, then link hands in a kind of aerial ballet. They separate, and soon are dangling from billowing red and orange canopies.

title:
ART;
IN STAMFORD, PARADOXICAL PAINTINGS
description: NEW ENGLAND is the last bastion of color field painting, a style of abstraction that held sway in the 1960's and into the 1970's. One reason why it has thrived in New England over the last 15 years is its fierce advocacy by Kenworth Moffett, the curator of 20th-century art at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: EVERY garden is different, of course, but the two I visited recently are so very different that, in my mind's eye, my own third of an acre is displaying wildly divergent forms of flora.

title: Orioles' Skid Ends
description: Cal Ripken Jr.'s tie-breaking two-run homer in the eighth inning tonight powered Baltimore to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox, snapping the Orioles' seven-game losing streak.

title: Miss Saiki in Final
description: Kim Saiki, the Southern California junior champion, and Buffy Klein, winner of the Texas junior title, each won twice today and reached the final of the United States girls' junior golf championship at the Somerset Hills Country Club. They will meet in the 18-hole final Sunday.

title: Julie Soury, R. N. Kattan, SUNY Graduates, Marry
description: Julie Lynn Soury, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Soury of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert N. Kattan, son of Mrs. Joseph Kattan of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Kattan.

title: Breaking Up
description: To the Business Editor:

title: THE GAMES WHERE OLYMPIC SPIRIT IS ALL THAT COUNTS
description: AT a time when the ancient ideals of the Olympic Games have been obscured by politics and commercialism, many people have asked about the philosophy propelling the amazing progress of the Special Olympics.

title: Mark Director Weds Shari Mara Hanania
description: The marriage of Shari Mara Hanania, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. N. David Hanania of White Plains and Bridgehampton, L.I., to Mark Dean Director took place last night at the Pierre Hotel in New York. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony.

title: ; AMSTERDAM
description: To the Editor:

title: ORGANIZED LABOR UPDATES ITS LEGISLATIVE PRIORITIES
description: Among the first things the A.F.L.- C.I.O.'s executive council did during its annual summer meeting here last week was to call for the formation of a national industrial policy. Such a plan, council members said, should be designed to revitalize basic industries and develop technologically advanced industries that could absorb the thousands of workers who face permanent exclusion from the job market because of automation or stagnation.

title: Q&A Ventilation Standards Question:
description: My apartment does not have windows in the bathroom or kitchen, so I depend on the building system for air circulation. My landlord says he is complying with the law if a paper towel sticks to the grill. What are the standards? . . . M. L., Manhattan

title: 16 WIN STATE COUNCIL FELLOWSHIPS
description: TRENTON SIXTEEN winners of crafts fellowship awards for 1983-84 were recently named by the State Council on the Arts.

title: VIEWS OF THE WALLPACK VALLEY
description: WALLPACK CENTER THERE is a pleasant, bracing sensation - call it little shocks of recognition - to be had from viewing paintings that depict the very landscape in which you are standing.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: ODD WALTON'S third novel, ''Louie & Women,'' skims rapidly through its scenes and past its characters in a way that is technically straightforward and - appropriately for its California setting - quite sunny in tone when it isn't melodramatic. Although a comic novel, it is not fundamentally meant to make us laugh. It is sentimental comedy, dashing by its complications and disasters toward a happy ending. Which is not to say that there aren't some amusing lines along the way.

title: PROMOTERS OF POVERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: When the Ostrovskys - Vladimir, Helen and their two children, Ann and Bella - arrived in the United States from the Soviet Union in early 1982, they were almost penniless. But they had hope, Mr. Ostrovsky said in halting English, and they did not have this before.

title: FRICK'S SIDEWALKS
description: Once, most of New York's sidewalks were paved with bluestone slate, and kids on roller skates loved it because the slate gave them such a smooth ride compared to the concrete that began to replace it before World War II. There aren't many slate sidewalks left, and one of the last on Manhattan's East Side, at the Frick Collection on Fifth Avenue between 70th and 71st Streets, is going.

title: Red Carpet
description: To the Business Editor:

title: CON ED RESTORES ELECTRIC SERVICE IN MIDTOWN AREA
description: Power was restored to midtown Manhattan's garment district yesterday morning, and life began returning to normal in the 12-block area where a three-day blackout caused a major business disruption. The garment industry estimated that millions of dollars in sales had been lost.

title: BIOFEEDBACK DANCE ENTERING SPOTLIGHT
description: ELMER ALTHOUGH it is nestled on 175 acres of quiet rural countryside, the Appel Farm Art and Music Center here is a place where innovative work with high technology and the arts is done, as it will be Wednesday.

title: A NEW ANGLE ON KENYA, AMERICA'S CUP CRUISE
description: African Safari Focuses on Fish Instead of Game

title: THE REGION
description: Cuomo's ChoiceFor High Court

title: IRA BERKOWSports of The Times
description: A Sound of Campus Money

title: CONSUMER RATES
DRUSE AND CHRISTIANS KEEP UP THEIR BEIRUT BATTLES
description: Rival Christian and Druse militiamen fought artillery battles today in the mountains ringing eastern Beirut.

title: Man Drowns in Baptism
description: A 37-year-old man who could not swim drowned while he was being baptized in a lake by a minister who also could not swim, the police said. John Edward Blue of Boston apparently lost his footing when he leaned back to be baptized at a place where the lake drops off sharply.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we are attacked, we shall defend ourselves. We have the means to do so including antiaircraft weapons.'' - Col. Bernard Messana, the commander of a French force in Chad. (1:1.)

title: SUMMER JOBS: A LESSON IN ECONOMICS I
description: ACROSS the country now, youngsters are toiling in a variety of jobs. While most parents

title: THE CLOUD OVER HONG KONG
description: Steve Lohr is a New York Times correspondent based in Tokyo. By Steve Lohr HINKING ABOUT THE BIG WHATif question - what if China takes over Hong Kong? - has seldom been a preoccupation of the people of this British crown colony. They have been too busy making money. Every so often in the past, though, residents of this bastion of capitalism on the underbelly of China, the country with the world's largest population under Communist rule, have had to confront the precariousness of their situation.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Social issues have had their ups and downs as themes for dance, though each generation has had choreographers who look habitually to the world around them for inspiration. One such choreographer has been Eleo Pomare, who came into prominence as a choreographer in 1965 with ''Blues for the Jungle,'' a dance about the contemporary and historical oppression of American blacks.

title: HEADLINERS Sons and HeirsSwaziland may be the only nation in the world where a coup can be accomplished by simply dropping a name. Queen Dzeliwe, the senior wife of the late King Sobhuza II, ruled as Queen Regent of the southern African nation after his death last year. She was expected to stay in power for years until one of the king's many sons was named heir. But she pursued modernization too fast for the traditionalist national council, the Liqoqo. Last week, after months of dispute, the Liqoqo abruptly made it official that 15-year-old Prince Makhosetive would succeed his father. And with a new King formally named, his mother, in this case
description: Queen Ntombi , automatically assumed the powers of Queen Regent.

title: About Men; A Wardrobe For Starting Out
description: THERE ARE TWO MALE FASHION WORLDS

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY FACES OF VERSATILE PIZZA
description: THAT Southern Italian institution, the pizza, is a quick and cheap meal that can easily be made at home. The variety of fillings is immense, among them ham, mushrooms, anchovies, olives, even clams or mussels. A brief consultation with the interior of the refrigerator almost always yields something that will be at home on a pizza. And instead of the traditional mozzarella and tomato, a more esoteric filling can be made with goat's cheese and sun-dried tomatoes arranged on the dough, baked and sprinkled with fresh basil leaves. But the very simplest pizza consists of nothing more than the crusty dough sprinkled with coarse salt and a fruity green extra-virgin olive oil. Of course all pizzas should be eaten with copious draughts of chilled Beaujolais or a robust red wine.

title: CHEERING THE HERO, BOOING THE VILLAIN
description: THEATER THREE, in Port Jefferson, is winding down its summer season with a rousing melodrama, ''The Drunkard, or The Fallen Saved.'' This classic temperance play, which was first performed in 1844, has been adapted by William H. Smith and has been jazzed up a bit with the addition of incidental music by Tim Peierls and lyrics by Winston Clark.

title: THE KOZLOVS LAUNCH A TOUR
description: Broadway and Balanchine have made Americans out of Leonid Kozlov and Valentina Kozlova. Four summers after their dramatic Los Angeles stagedoor defection from the Bolshoi Ballet, the couple - partners onstage as well as off - are now finding a place in the American dance world.

title: TWO SHOWS NEAR EACH OTHER BUT INSTRUCTIVELY FAR APART
description: THIS week the exhibition schedule dictates a review with a surrealistic juxtaposition of shows: a pictorial account of 19th-century industry in the Hudson River Valley versus paintings and sculptures by modern Haitian naives. Called ''In Search of the Picturesque,'' the first display can be seen at the Hudson River Museum through Sept. 4 (511 Warburton Avenue); the second, ''Four Haitian Masters,'' is at the Katonah Gallery, in Katonah (28 Bedford Road).

title: Giants May Rotate Two Quarterbacks
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said today that ''it's not beyond the realm of possibility'' that he would use two quarterbacks during the regular season.

title: Reynard F. Milici, Mary D. Seymour Become Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thaddeus Seymour of Winter Park, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Duffie Seymour, to Reynard Francis Milici, son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Francis Milici of Agawam, Mass.

title: Police Parking
description: To the Editor:

title: AN EXCURSION TO BALTIMORE'S INNER HARBOR
description: Not so long ago ''Bawlamer,'' as it's known locally, was thought of as a place to drive through on the way to someplace else. Nowadays, Baltimore is so filled with interesting attractions that what are called ''torsts'' in the local dialect are flocking there to visit.

title: COURT IS ADVISED TO INTERVENE ON SEWAGE IN BOSTON HARBOR
description: A court-appointed investigator has reported that critical sewage problems in Boston Harbor have made judicial intervention ''both appropriate and necessary.''

title: HELPING ILL CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES
description: FIVE years ago, Sheila Petersen of Croton Falls founded Friends of Karen, for the specific purpose of helping Karen MacInnes, a terminally ill teen-ager, spend her remaining months at home with her family. Now a registered charitable trust, the organization is helping eight families in the Northeast who have children with serious illnesses.

title: BILLS BEATEN BY BROWNS, 27-10
description: Boyce Green, a rookie from Carson-Newman, scored two touchdowns, one untouched on a 71-yard run, and led the Cleveland Browns to a 27-10 victory over the Buffalo Bills tonight in a National Football League exhbition game.

title: THE HUDSON ENDOWMENT: RESEARCH ON THE RIVER
description: ''THE Hudson is the only river in the world with its own endowment fund, and it's a substantial endowment,'' said Jim Rod, the warden-biologist of Constitution Island Marsh, a 270-acre sanctuary in Garrison that is managed by the National Audubon Society.

title: REVISITING THE BAUHAUS
description: Judith Pearlman is producing on a documentary film on the Bauhaus. By Judith Pearlman

title: NAME THAT HILL-BUT FIRST...
description: IF YOU are a New Jerseyan and

title: THE TOURISTS ARE HERE
description: OUTSIDE the tourist information center on Interstate 84 in Danbury, George Hitchcock and his family, from Louisiana, sat in their car looking at brochures of Connecticut attractions.

title: ; THE CLOISTERED LIFE --
description: Zen Buddhists, the Eastern cousins of Western monastics, tell the story of soldiers quartered at a Zen temple.

title: SLAVERY TRIAL WITNESS SAYS HE WAS PAID $40
description: A man who said he was forced to dig potatoes against his will and was paid $40 for three months of work is one of the prosecution's key witnesses in the trial of four men charged with practicing slavery in two migrant labor camps.

title: Dr. Raymond L. Vande Wiele, Columbia Chief of Obstetrics
description: Dr. Raymond L. Vande Wiele, chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Alpine, N.J.

title: HOW CHURCH LEADERS TACKLE OPPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: Bow of Wrecked Supertanker Is Scuttled Off South Africa
description: The oil-laden bow section of the Spanish supertanker Castillo De Bellver sank in deep Atlantic waters today after experts blew two holes in its side.

title: WHEN 'BUY AMERICAN' HURTS NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: 'STRANGE YEAR' AT NATIONAL PARKS PUZZLES OFFICIALS
description: The nation's sprawling national park system is experiencing one of the most puzzling patterns of vacation travel in recent memory.

title: CITY TEAM RETAINS BASKETBALL CROWN
description: New York City defended its title in men's open basketball in a three-team round- robin playoff today, the last day of competition at the Empire State Games.

title: ACID FOG AND TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING
description: In California these days, there is a lot of talk about souring grapes and ripening avocados, not to mention the non-bruising, or ''processing,'' tomato.

title: TV: NBC'S ADAPTATION OF 'PUMP BOYS' TONIGHT
description: ''PUMP BOYS and Dinettes on Television'' is a pleasant enough, entirely harmless, mildly amusing one hour. It is not so much a re-creation as an adaptation of the pleasant enough, entirely harmless, mildly amusing Broadway show of almost the same name. When you add the words ''on Television'' to the title it means you are adding guest stars and a certain amount of fiddle-faddle, too. The program will be seen on NBC, Channel 4, at 10 tonight.

title: EASEMENTS: 'A FAIR DEAL FOR ALL CONCERNED'
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Opposition Group Sets Up Military Base
description: An Iraqi group opposed to the Baghdad Government has set up its first military base on territory in northern Iraq captured by Iranian forces, the Iranian national press agency has reported.

title: GASTINEAU IS HERO OF JETS' TRIUMPH
description: As the images flickered across the movie screen today, Mark Gastineau suddenly felt that this was an important moment in his Jet career.

title: U.S.-CHINA RAPPORT
description: It took the Reagan Adminstration some time to forge working relations with China, but cooperation seems finally to be getting off the ground.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: U.S. KEEPS BEAVERS BUSY RESTORING CREEKS
description: Like most ranchers, the people up Currant Creek would just as soon shoot a beaver as look at it. For years, the animals had dammed the stream, flooded their hay meadows and plugged their drainage culverts with mud and sticks.

title: CHINAGLIA RETURNS, COSMOS WIN, 3-0
description: It was a night of soccer and song at Giants Stadium tonight, with the Cosmos and their fans the winners. The Cosmos defeated Montreal, 3-0, and the 45,821 fans later watched a Beach Boys concert free.

title: 5 People Die in Copter Crash On Trip to Mount St. Helens
description: A sightseeing helicopter on a trip to the Mount St. Helens volcano crashed and burned Saturday, killing four tourists and the pilot, the authorities said today.

title: Ex-Officer of Cynamid Joins Germanine Monteil
description: The Germaine Monteil Cosmetiques Corporation has named Stewart F. Rohr president and chief operating officer.

title: A NOVELIST FINDS POLITICS 'THE OPPOSITE OF WRITING'
description: James Webb went to the Naval Academy, where men are made. He went to Vietnam, where men were broken. He was graduated from the Georgetown University Law Center, farm club to Capitol Hill. He worked in Congress, farm club to the executive branch.

title: Houdini Bust Stolen From Queens Grave
description: A bust of Harry Houdini has disappeared from the magician's grave in Queens, the police reported.

title: NEW POWER READY FOR GARMENT AREA
description: As Consolidated Edison crews put finishing touches yesterday on a new electrical network under the garment district in midtown Manhattan, utility officials said the system would provide enough power for all the businesses reopening today - many for the first time since a blackout last Wednesday stilled the usually chaotic area.

title: Report on Blood Disease In Carolina Was in Error
description: Articles published last year in The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution inaccurately reported the incidence of a rare blood disease near Aiken, S.C., the newspapers reported today.

title: Hot Pot
description: This is the kind of thing most people say to their plants. They say ''More water, sweetheart?'' and ''Just let me brush off those nasty aphids'' and ''Looks like you're feeling peaked today.'' But what do you say when the plant is a philodendron that's hot to trot?

title: 8 of 11 Challenged Ads Dropped or Modified
description: In July the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus closed cases involving 11 challenges to national advertising claims. In only three did it judge the claims supportable.

title: POP: LEE DORSEY
description: LEE DORSEY and Carla Thomas, two veteran 1960's rhythm-and-blues singers, shared a double bill last weekend at the Bottom Line.

title: IN A JAPAN TOWN, NOT ALL HAIL 'NO SMOKING' DAYS
description: By latest count, there are 7,370 people in this town, and while no one knows how many of them smoke, it can safely be said that a few are not happy these days.

title: DANCE: BALLET TODAY
description: THERE have been times when Ballet Today, a group founded in 1981, looked as if it were going to turn into one of those avocational little dance troupes that come and go so regularly in New York. But a program by the company on Saturday night in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park Bandshell, suggested that it has some serious thoughts in its young head.

title: SALES AT APPAREL MART IN ATLANTA SURGE IN WAKE OF NEW YORK'S LOSS
description: New York's loss during the three-day power failure in the garment district last week has, to some extent, been Atlanta's gain.

title: SEIZING THE INITIATIVE
description: Now's a good time for President Reagan to seize the initiative in Soviet-American relations - and the 1984 Presidential campaign - by declaring a six-month moratorium on nuclear testing and challenging Moscow to do the same.

title: CHILE MAY YIELD AND SPEED ELECTIONS
description: Interior Minister Sergio Onofre Jarpa said in an interview published here today that the Government would call a plebiscite on amending the Constitution to speed up the Congressional elections now scheduled for 1990.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch published Aug. 5, 1982, contained incorrect information on the incidence of a fatal blood disease near a plant in Aiken, S.C., where fuel for nuclear weapons is produced. A corrective article appears on page A12.

title: Tennessee Bank Failure
description: The First Commerce Bank of Hawkins County was declared insolvent on Friday and sold by Government regulators because of large loan losses, officials said. It was Tennessee's 10th bank failure this year, and the ninth failure of a bank linked to the two brothers, Jake and C. H. Butcher Jr.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TRIPLE PLAY

title: Angola Says It Crushed Attack by Guerrillas
description: Angolan Government troops have beaten back a guerrilla attack in eastern Angola, killing 1,100 rebels and capturing South African-made arms, the official Angolan press agency said today.

title: TRANSIT PLAN WINS IN DALLAS REGION
description: Voters have approved creation of a regional transportation authority to cover this city and 13 suburbs, setting in motion plans for a bus and rail program that would include the biggest public works program in the city's history.

title: Postal Quirks
description: They'll take Manhattan but, unlike

title: Lear Gets McRae Option
description: The Lear Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired an option to buy 36 percent of the stock in McRae Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. for $14 a share, or a total of $79 million.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Bargain Hunter

title: A ZONING DEAL FOR DEVELOPERS FINANCED STREET AND PARK AID
description: An arrangement that gave zoning variances to developers of real estate on Fifth Avenue and Park Avenue who contributed to a special fund has resulted in more than $1 million of sidewalk and park improvements in the area.

title: PERU'S RICH ANTIQUITIES CRUMBLING IN MUSEUMS
description: Pre-Columbian works of art and artifacts of major historical interest, some dating to 6,000 years before Christ, are rotting, crumbling or being stolen in museums here.

title: MUSIC: GOSPEL CONCERT
description: AS part of the 27th conference of the International Council of Traditional Music, held at Columbia University this past week, the Chancel Choir of the Greater Refuge Temple in New York was to have performed a gospel concert in the Altschul Auditorium on Saturday. But at the last minute, and without explanation, they were replaced by a group calling itself the Devotion and Praise Singers, some of whose members belonged to the Chancel Choir.

title: No Headline
description: Identity Crisis at Sea Some of the competition for the America's Cup actually takes place on the water, but historically, much has also occurred around tables and on paper while contenders debate the rules. As the selection of this year's competitors draws near, the design of Australia II's keel is under attack by the New York Yacht Club because it allegedly fails to meet design criteria.

title: Boggs Average Now .379
description: Going into a four-game series with the Kansas City Royals in Boston this weekend, Wade Boggs, the 25-year-old third baseman of the Red Sox, was batting .370. After Saturday's doubleheader and the first game of a doubleheader yesterday, he had gone 10 for 15 and was batting .381.

title: THE POPULATION CORNER IS NOT YET TURNED
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: GALA AT JACOB'S PILLOW FESTIVAL
description: Ballet galas and portmanteau programs tend to be alike: a little ''Corsaire'' here, a bit of Tchaikovsky and white feathers there. But ''Ballet '83: New Views and Debuts,'' seen on Friday at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, lived up - should it be down? - to those expectations with a pleasant lack of consistency.

title: News Analysis
description: A California railroad expert who studied the New York City subway system concluded last week that deterioration of the tracks was ''readily apparent'' - ''even from the front end of a moving train.'' The image was a vivid one for New Yorkers, who sometimes have gazed out the front window of a subway train and wondered how the swaying cars remained on the tracks.

title: STAGE: SHOW BY UJAMAA ON THE BLUES
description: QUITE a few black Broadway theatergoers are perturbed, or at least ambivalent, about Broadway's black musicals. Many say the black musical perpetuates the belief that the black performer's role in the American theater is to sing and dance. All recognize that it provides jobs.

title: SUPER DERBY SHOWDOWN SEEN
description: The battle for this year's 3-year- old championship, which has been fought through the usual classic races at the lush resorts and tony centers of American racing, now is likely to be settled seven miles down Highway 80, due east of Shreveport, La.

title: Pageantry Marks Pan Am Opening
description: The ninth Pan American Games began today with pageantry that for the moment made onlookers forget the problems of this quadrennial sports competition in getting this far.

title: Advertising; Newsweek President's Goals
description: A SHORT time ago Mark M. Edmiston, president of Newsweek, said during an interview that all ''the major personnel changes'' had been made at the news magazine. Then, on Aug. 5, Charles J. Kennedy, the publisher, announced that he would resign as of Sept. 1.

title: THOUSANDS CLASH DURING PROTESTS AGAINST GOVERNMENT IN PAKISTAN
description: Tens of thousands of opponents and supporters of the Pakistani Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq clashed in Karachi today during a protest march.

title: War Worrying Oil Experts
description: International oil experts have grown increasingly worried that the war between Iran and Iraq, a border dispute now in its third year, could escalate rapidly because of the introduction of advanced fighter planes capable of firing missiles at oil tankers and storage facilities. The aircraft, five French- built Super Entendard planes, are scheduled for delivery to Iraq before the end of summer.

title: FOSTER'S 'SLAM' SWEEPS CUBS
description: They were still in last place, and they were still 20 games below the .500 level, but the Mets sustained their August revival yesterday by defeating the Chicago Cubs, 5-2, for the 11th victory in their last 14 games and a sweep of the three-game weekend series.

title: Telephone Cables Cut In 3 New Jersey Cities
description: Telephone service was disrupted for hundreds of New Jersey Bell customers Saturday when cables were cut in Atlantic City, Livingston and Weehawken, according to the company.

title: Crash Kills Spectator At Speedway on L.I.
description: A spectator was killed and two others were injured after a race car went out of control and crashed through a fence into the stands at the Islip Speedway, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: EMPLOYEES ON LOAN IN BRITAIN
description: After 18 years in the Department of the Environment, Peter Brown, 35, felt trapped. So he persuaded the Government to lend him out for a couple of years to the London Enterprise Agency, a nonprofit advisory organization supported by 11 large companies that are seeking to create jobs in the city.

title: Claudia Van Essen Is Bride Of Dr. Matthew Eric Snow
description: Claudia Van Essen was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Dr. Matthew Eric Snow at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hans H. Van Essen. Rabbi Phillip Schecter performed the ceremony.

title: Dissidents Pick Bradford President
description: The Bradford National Corporation, a New York-based computer- services concern, has named a new president and chief executive officer aligned with a group of dissident stockholders who recently took control of the company.

title: DR. SAMUEL ZWERLING
description: Dr. Samuel Zwerling, an otolaryngologist who founded hearing clinics in Brooklyn, died Friday at Central General Hospital in Plainview, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Commodities; Inflation Omen Seen In Futures
description: THE Commodity Research Bureau's index of futures prices

title: U.S. PASTA PROBLEM: IT'S ITALIAN
description: Nobody complains about Canadian capellini or Mexican macaroni, but mention Italy to an American pasta maker and you are likely to get an al dente snarl.

title: TO COMBAT ACID RAIN
description: Acid rain is clearly a pressing environmental problem, as recent reports by the National Academy of Sciences and other groups have confirmed. What is not so clear, as the Academy's report also confirms, is how best to solve the problem. Neither science nor politics will support the now-popular approach of laying the burden for reducing emissions of sulfur and nitrogen oxides on the utilities of the Midwest. We must move toward a broad, national cost-sharing formula that involves all states responsible for the problem, while also encouraging research into cost-effective means of reducing oxide emissions.

title: Market Place; Recuperation For the Dow
description: THE stock market stuck its foot through a support level last Monday and then proceeded to repair the damage - at least for the time being. The Dow Jones industrial average was able to finish the week virtually without change. It closed at 1,182.83, down 0.46.

title: FRENCH HAIL POPE ON LOURDES VISIT
description: Pope John Paul II, on his first foreign visit since his highly political journey to Poland last June, came here today as a pilgrim to the grotto where 125 years ago a peasant child said she saw the Virgin Mary appear on 18 occasions.

title: Bridge: The Reid Team Won a Title Before the Lights Went Out
description: Winning an event may lose something of its savor if nobody else knows you have won. This happened last week to Dr. Clarice Reid of Washington, George Hudson of Teaneck, N.J., and Larry Berkley and Julius Field of New York , in the ill-fated Summer Nationals of the American Bridge Association at the New York Statler Hotel.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FINAL DRESS. By John Houseman. 559 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95. MIDWAY through this third volume of his memoirs, the producer and director John Houseman recounts how, in 1964, he began talking into a tape recorder in an effort to connect ''my childhood memories and the personal and professional events of my adult life.'' When the miles of tapes were transcribed, he says, he had a pile of 680 triple-spaced pages, much of which was ''repetitious, self-pitying and useless.''

title: FAMILY THAT GREW WITH THE U.S. HOLDS REUNION
description: One by one, looking out at rows of pews filled with their relatives, the Risleys stood and recited their lineage.

title: GIANTS WELCOME TAYLOR
description: Lawrence Taylor rejoined the Giants today after his three-week holdout and was greeted by a round of applause from a few hundred fans at the practice and a chorus of boos from his teammates as he trotted onto the field at Pace University.

title: Cathy Miller Becomes Bride of Jeremy Schlosberg
description: Cathy Susan Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Miller of Lexington, Mass., was married there yesterday to Jeremy David Schlosberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Morris Schlosberg of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Cary David Yales performed the ceremony at Temple Isaiah.

title: STANDOFF CONTINUES IN DIPLOMATIC FUROR OVER RUSSIAN YOUTH
description: As Federal agents continued a stakeout of the Soviet residential compound in Washington, there was no apparent progress today in efforts to end a standoff between Soviet and American officials over a 16-year-old Russian who apparently wants to remain in the United States.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The problem in Central America is not the show of force, it is the use of force.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (A1:6)

title: LEVI WINS BY A STROKE
description: Wayne Levi charged from three strokes off the pace to beat Isao Aoki and Calvin Peete by a shot in the $350,000 Buick Open today.

title: Ruth S. Stevens Is Married to Thomas M. Stellard
description: Ruth Shotwell Stevens, daughter of Mrs. George Cooke Stevens and the late Mr. Stevens of Greenwich and Sachem Head, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Mark Stellard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Stellard of Allendale, Mich. The Rev. Dr. John Wesley Bishop of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich performed the ceremony in the amphitheater at Castle Park in Holland, Mich.

title: Moscow Calls on Party To Tighten Discipline
description: The Central Committee published a resolution on Communist Party elections today calling for improved discipline from members.

title: MUSIC: TWO CONCERTS BY BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: Two concerts presented by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood this weekend gave glimpses of younger American composers attempting to find their voices. This afternoon, as part of the Fromm Festival of Contemporary Music, Seiji Ozawa conducted the orchestra in Peter Lieberson's Piano Concerto, a work by the 37-year-old composer which will be receiving its New York premiere later this season. And last night, Leonard Bernstein conducted another quite different early work as part of the Koussevitzky Memorial Concert - his own ''Jeremiah'' Symphony, which he completed in 1942 when he was 24 years old.

title: 4,000 Miles of Cycling
description: Spokes glinted in the morning sun as

title: The Skins Game
description: Legend has it that there is more money won on the nation's golf courses in ''friendly'' bets than in all the professional tournaments combined.

title: MORE BUFFA THAN OPERA FOR PARK 'NON PASQUALE'
description: The other evening, during a dress rehearsal of ''Non Pasquale,'' the New York Shakespeare Festival's takeoff on Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale,'' the musical was described in several different voices by its creators:

title: Prost Takes Prix
description: Alain Prost of France won the Austrian Grand Prix today for his fourth Formula One victory of the season, increasing his lead in the world championship standing to 14 points.

title: How to Join 'Em on Housing
description: Subsidizing mortgages for middle-income home-buyers is a questionable way to spend scarce Federal funds. Worse, financing the subsidy through the sale of tax-exempt bonds costs the Treasury three dollars in lost revenue for every dollar going to homeowners. But the subsidized mortgages are so popular (and interest rates remain so high) that a majority in Congress now wants to make the program permanent.

title: COMPUTERS DRAW 1,100 TO CLASSES
description: Somewhere children are playing this summer. Somewhere they are stealing bases, somewhere they are swimming cool laps.

title: G. & W. SHEDDING MAJOR UNITS
description: Gulf and Western Industries, in a widely expected streamlining move, said yesterday that it would take a $470 million write-off in its just-ended fiscal year to divest itself of several major lines of business, including its natural resources operations and two race tracks.

title: Dr. Brown Wed To Carl McCall
description: Dr. Joyce Frances Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brown of New York and Centerville, Mass., and H. Carl McCall, State Human Rights Commissioner, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman McCall of Boston, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Rev. James Parks Morton, dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

title: IOWANS BALANCE MORAL VALUES
description: Iowans think lying is more sinful than smoking marijuana or premarital sex, and that swearing is worse than skipping church on Sunday, according to a recent poll taken by The Des Moines Register and Tribune Company. A third of Iowans consider shopping on Sunday mildly sinful, the pollsters reported.

title: NEW PROMISE OF ELECTIONS FOR PAKISTAN
description: Just off Constitution Avenue, a sweeping boulevard that cuts across this capital city, is a Government building that is being built of white stone to house Pakistan's Parliament.

title: Bic Introducing Its Erasable Pen
description: Bic, a leading presence in disposable ballpoints, as well as shaving systems and lighters, today formally introduces to the public its Bic Erasable Ink Ball Pen.

title: Desegregating a Court
description: New York's Court of Appeals enjoys a good reputation among state high courts. But its lack of diversity has become an increasing source of embarrassment.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Amateur Athletics
description: Pan American Games , at Caracas, Venezuela. Opening day of competition in basketball, fencing, soccer, gymnastics, judo, weight lifting, softball, tennis and shooting.

title: Reunion in Rome
description: Borough Presidents Anthony R.

title: FRANCE AND ALIENS IN ITS MIDST: FEAR ON BOTH SIDES
description: ''Look at this place,'' said the young Algerian as he made a sweeping gesture toward the drab concrete blocks that house 4,000 families here. There were apartment towers as far as the eye could see, and to this young man who called himself Abdel, that was no accident.

title: POLISH POLICE BREAK UP MARCH IN GDANSK
description: The police broke up a march in the Baltic seaport of Gdansk today that was intended to commemorate the third anniversary of the start of the strike that led to the formation of the Solidarity free trade union movement.

title: NEW SKILLS FOR SOUTH KOREANS
description: The future of the South Korean economy, by most accounts, rests in the hands of people like Park Sung-Kyou.

title: TV-Cable Week
description: Time Inc.'s newest magazine entry, TV-Cable Week, announced that it is moving into San Diego, its 18th market, on Sept. 4.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 15, 1983
description: Companies

title: Indian Crowd Panics; 53 Worshipers Killed
description: At least 53 people, including 19 women and 11 children, were trampled to death when thousands of Hindu worshipers visiting a shrine in northern India stampeded in panic after a hillside market collapsed, local officials said today.

title: TEARFUL TIMES IN THE WORLD FOR SUFFERERS OF HAY FEVER
description: Take some advice from the experts, allergy sufferers. Stay inside. Close the windows. Turn on the air conditioner. Don't exercise much.

title: WORKING AT NIGHT: THE TOLL
description: ''I FELT isolated and depressed when I worked nights at NewarkAirport,'' said Louis M. Matuyza, a Pompton Plains, N.J., radar technician. ''Because I was on a different schedule than my family and friends, I missed out on activities and was so tired that I didn't even feel like doing things alone.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A golfer hits a ball that lands on a green adjacent to the correct one for the hole he is playing. Is it permissible for him to putt the ball off the green? Is there a penalty stroke involved?

title: Diane Duus Wed To H. G. Bisgaier
description: Diane Louise Duus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andreas Duus Jr. of Washington, Conn., was married yesterday to Henry George Bisgaier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Bisgaier of Rockville Centre, L.I. Justice of the Peace Edward Peckerman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: END OF A BELL RESEARCH ROLE
description: The breakup of the Bell System marks the end of an era in telecommunications. But it also brings to a close an unusual episode in a private company's use of economic research, an undertaking that extended to A.T.& T.'s establishment of an economics research group within Bell Laboratories, a highly respected research journal, the company's own council of prominent economic advisers and even the sponsorship of numerous academic conferences.

title: Aide Denies 'Bidding' To Win Hispanic Vote
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, said today the Administration was not engaged in a ''bidding war'' for the Hispanic vote in 1984, but that if President Reagan ran for re- election he would get a ''fair share'' of the ballots of Hispanic Americans.

title: AGENCY ASSAILED FOR DELAY ON RADIATION DRUG
description: Federal agencies in charge of emergency planning for nuclear accidents have not issued guidance to state and local governments about a drug that averts some effects of radiation, although they told a Congressional subcommittee they would develop a policy a year ago.

title: Gail B. Ruderman Marries Michael Nelson Feuer
description: Gail Beth Ruderman, daughter of Mrs. Isaac Benjamin of Flushing, Queens, and the late Arthur H. Ruderman, was married yesterday to Michael Nelson Feuer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Feuer of San Bernardino, Calif. The ceremony was performed at the Bay Terrace Jewish Center in San Bernardino by Rabbi Moshe Kwalbrun.

title: News Analysis
description: As Israel prepares to pull out of the Shuf mountains above Beirut, Lebanon is bracing for what could become a new chapter in the civil warfare that has torn it apart for the last eight years. At issue is whether the largely untested Lebanese Army can move into the military vacuum that will be left by the Israelis without setting off violent resistance from the newly rearmed Druse militiamen in the Shuf.

title: MEXICAN CAUTIONS REAGAN ON USING 'SHOWS OF FORCE'
description: President Reagan was welcomed to Mexico today with a word of caution from President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado. International problems are aggravated by ''shows of force,'' he said, and must instead be dealt with by constructive political dicussions.

title: Washington WatchKenneth B. Noble Proxy Rules For Activists
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to change its shareholder-voting rules this week, which may make it harder for small shareholders and social activists to advance their causes at corporate meetings.

title: ROCK MUSICIAN HURT IN BRAWL
description: Johnny Ramone, a 29-year-old punk-rock guitarist, was seriously injured early yesterday morning when he and another musician fought in front of the East Village apartment where Mr. Ramone lives, the police said.

title: U.S. Fails to Win Delay On Disability Pay
description: A Federal appeals court has ordered the Social Security Administration to notify 78,000 people that they may reapply for monthly disability pay lost in the last three years.

title: KEEL-COPY CHARGES ARE DENIED BY U.S.
description: The Australia II keel controversy took another tack yesterday with the Freedom Campaign's denial of charges that it had intended to enter a boat with a copy of the Australian keel in the trials to select the America's Cup defender.

title: WILLIAM H. SCHWARTZ
description: William H. Schwartz, an executive of Jewish philanthropic organizations and a university administrator, died of heart disease Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami.

title: DODGERS HOLD OFF RALLY BY BRAVES, 5-4
description: Dusty Baker hit a two-run homer and Steve Sax had four singles and scored twice today as the Los Angeles Dodgers held off a late surge by the Atlanta Braves for a 5-4 victory.

title: Summer Spruce-Ups
description: Armed with rakes, spades and big

title: Susan B. Doppelt Is Bride of Dr. Stephen La Poff
description: Susan B. Doppelt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Doppelt of Springfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen Ira La Poff, son of June La Poff of Clifton, N.J., and Marvin La Poff of Fair Lawn, N.J. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein performed the ceremony at the Short Hills, a catering establishment in Short Hills, N.J.

title: PICKING OF JUDGES ASSAILED BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo has called for major changes in the methods used to select judges for the New York State Court of Appeals, saying that the process under existing law limits his options unnecessarily and is unduly secretive.

title: Heavy Drug Use Cited
description: According to a published report, well-placed sources in the National Football League say that as many as 50 percent of the players in the league use cocaine and that more than 20 percent of the 1,372 players are ''hard-core'' users.

title: YANKS WIN ON 3 IN 8TH
description: Dave Winfield affected many people in Detroit this weekend. Ken Griffey, his teammate, was one, but he finally shrugged off the Winfield effect and hit a two-run homer that sealed a 4-1 victory for the Yankees today..

title: Continental Insurance Adds a Hong Kong Post
description: John H. Bretherick, a senior vice president at the Continental Insurance Company, has been named to the additional post of chairman of the Lombard Insurance Group in Hong Kong as Continental moves to strengthen its position in the Far East.

title: REAGAN VETO OF CHICAGO INTEGRATION AID CRITICIZED
description: Civil rights advocates and Chicago school officials today denounced President Reagan's veto of a bill that would have provided $20 million to help desegregate Chicago's public schools.

title: U.S. ATHLETES STAND OUT IN WORLD TRACK EVENTS
description: For the second time in five days, Mary Decker outkicked a rival runner from the Soviet Union and won a gold medal today at the world track and field championships.

title: Citibank Sued Over Pemex
description: The Michigan National Bank of Detroit is suing Citibank to recover its $5 million share of a $45 million syndicated loan to Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state oil company.

title: East Berlin Plea on Arms
description: A group of East Berlin pacifists fasting for world peace has called on the Communist Party to reject any new Soviet nuclear missiles in East Germany, even if NATO stations its new rockets in Western Europe. A letter containing the plea was delivered on Thursday to the office of Erich Honecker, the Communist Party chief, and shown to Western journalists today.

title: BENCH JOCKEYING: LOST ART IN BASEBALL
description: FRANK ROBINSON's greatest apprehension may not have been appearing before a judge but rather anticipating the reaction of opposing players, some of whom probably spent the final days before spring training in 1961 sharpening their wits like knives at his expense. Robinson was a 25-year-old outfielder with the Cincinnati Reds then, and in February of that year, he was arrested for carrying a concealed weapon, a gun that he drew during an argument with a cook in a Cincinnati sandwich shop. As Robinson headed to Tampa, Fla., less than a month later, he understood the incident would provide baseball's all- star agitators with a fresh supply of material.

title: A SECOND APPEAL PUSHED IN BERRY CASE
description: EARLIER this summer, as part of a remedial reading program at St. John's University, a student named Walter Berry brought a newspaper clipping to read and discuss. Berry had not been graduated from Benjamin Franklin High School in Manhattan when he left there in the spring of 1982, but he received his high school equivalency diploma and completed 24 credits of college work through a New York state program offered by St. John's that served the same purpose as the General Equivalency Examination.

title: IN COLD PRINT
description: To the Editor:

title: PARAGUAY PRESIDENT ROLLS ON
description: Today, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner will become President of Paraguay for a sixth consecutive term, making him the longest-ruling dictator in the world today. Like his ''election'' in February, this inauguration ceremony makes a mockery of democracy and of the United States, which continues to pretend that the Stroessner regime is an example of pluralism and free political expression.

title: Rioters Battle Police In Northern Ireland
description: Young rioters hurling firebombs battled the police on the streets of two Northern Ireland cities early today.

title: Gunman Disarms Policeman And Rapes His Companion
description: A 17-year-old woman was raped by a gunman last night after he surprised her and a companion, an off-duty New York City probationary police officer, at the edge of High Bridge Park in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: BRAKES DISPUTE TOUCHES MANY LIVES
description: Kathryn Tapp, chosen as the salutatorian of the class of '83 at Jackson Hole High School in Wyoming, was driving slowly toward town in a 1980 Chevrolet Citation on Dec. 15. A witness said her brake lights suddenly went on, the car spun in crazy circles across State Highway 22 and was struck by a car headed in the other direction. She was killed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., has appointed Malcolm R. Lloyd group vice president responsible for the company's domestic consumer products divisions and Canadian operations.

title: BICYCLE RIDERS VIE FOR SPACE ON STREETS
description: As Edward Grover rode his bicycle down Seventh Avenue in midtown the other day, a taxicab pulled in front of him and stopped. A passenger opened a door on the street side. There was no time to swerve, and Mr. Grover slammed into the door.

title: 2 DEAD AND 2 HURT IN CRASH OF COPTER OFF JERSEY SHORE
description: At least two people were killed and two critically injured yesterday when a commercial helicopter taking passengers on sightseeing tours of the New Jersey Shore crashed into the Atlantic Ocean surf a few miles south of Point Pleasant, local authorities said.

title: Rocket-Ship Goodies
description: There are only five of them, but they

title: U.S. Scientists List Dangerous Volcanoes
description: Government scientists have identified 20 volcanoes that could endanger the West, including eight ''capable of extremely destructive eruptions.''

title: STABILITY IS FORECAST FOR OIL PRICES
description: Oil demand has been rising steadily in the five months since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to cut prices for the first time in its 23-year history.

title: CRACK IN A GENERATOR MAY DELAY SHOREHAM ATOM PLANT'S OPENING
description: A diesel generator that would supply power in the event of a breakdown at the Shoreham nuclear power plant developed a crack during a test, and an official of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that the problem could delay the plant's opening.

title: FEW ARE FINDING PROFICIENCY TEST BAR TO DIPLOMA
description: The Regents Competency Test, introduced five years ago to tighten standards for a high school diploma in New York State, is preventing fewer than 2 percent of the students in the state from graduating each year, according to the State Education Department.

title: Konica Films at Levine
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, in the midst of launching Konica video and audio tapes for Konishiroku Photo USA, has gotten another assignment from the subsidiary of the Japanese manufacturer.

title: JEWISH WORLD WAR II REFUGEES' ITALIAN HEROES
description: To the Editor:

title: McGovern Gets Ready
description: In a cabin outside Sevierville,

title: Dr. Janice Gabrilove Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Janice Lynn Gabrilove, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Lester Gabrilove of New York and Montague, N.J., was married yesterday to Barnard Michael Dirzulaitis, son of Mrs. William B. Peterson of Ridge, Md., and the late Dr. Barnard Mark Dirzulaitis of Arlington, Va. Rabbi Emeritus David J. Seligson of the Central Synagogue in New York performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: GERMAN-AMERICANS MARK TRICENTENNIAL
description: This year marks the 300th anniversary of German settlement in America. It was on Oct. 6, 1683 that 13 Mennonite families, 33 people in all, from the city of Krefeld arrived in Philadelphia and founded Germantown, Pa. And thanks to the German- American Tricentennial Commission the event is not about to go unnoticed.

title: Diplomats Report Nicaragua Seeks U.S. Deal on Arms Aid
description: Nicaragua is prepared to send home its Cuban military advisers and halt the import of Soviet arms if the United States reduces its military presence in neighboring Honduras, diplomats here said today.

title: DOLLAR RISE, U.S. RATES IRK BONN
description: The dollar's rise last week to its highest level in nine years against the mark reinforced a deep-seated belief here that the Reagan Administration and its economic policies continue to undercut West German efforts to revive the economy.

title: Stephen Michael Banker Weds Judith C. Kohlberg
description: Judith Claire Kohlberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Eugene Kohlberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Port- au-Prince, Haiti, was married yesterday to Stephen Michael Banker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel I. Banker, also of Mamaroneck. Rabbi Jacob Shankman performed the ceremony at the Kohlberg home.

title: Port Authority Picks Ogilvy for Airports
description: Having gone through 33 agency proposals and screened five finalists, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has chosen Ogilvy & Mather Partners to handle the promotion of its three airports.

title: CAMPERS IN CITY'S SHADOW SAY THEY HAVE BEST OF TWO WORLDS
description: During the day, the Dubmans explored New York City, with its crowds, skyscrapers and noise. At night, they cooked a spaghetti dinner outdoors over their Coleman stove, played cards with their two children, and slept in a tent.

title: Draft Regulation Is Extended By Education Dept. to Oct. 1
description: College students receiving financial aid will be given an extra month to comply with the Federal law that requires them to register for the draft, the Education Department has announced.

title: Voting Drive Marchers Pause in Cincinnati
description: Civil rights leaders paused here today on their 360-mile voter registration march to encourage black parishioners at several city churches to register to vote.

title: CONCERT: FROMM WEEK
description: Grander-scaled, higher-budgeted new-music festivals like the New York Philharmonic's Horizons '83 come and go. Experimental-music gatherings like the annual New Music America Festivals may be hipper. But as the yearly summer showcase for serious new music, Tanglewood's Festival of Contemporary Music - otherwise known in honor of its longtime patron, Paul Fromm, as the Fromm Week - still commands a unique position.

title: Sri Lanka Toll Put at 2,000
description: The head of the main political party of Sri Lanka's Tamil minority said today that 2,000 people probably died in the two months of ethnic unrest that included July's riots in the island nation.

title: Israeli General Resigns From Army
description: Maj. Gen. Yehoshua Saguy, who was dismissed as Director of Military Intelligence in the wake of the Phalangist massacre of Palestinian refugees in Beirut last year, has resigned from the Israeli Army, it was learned today.

title: CUOMO SIGNS LAW GIVING AID TO PATIENTS IN HOSPICE CARE
description: Governor Cuomo has signed legislation that recognizes hospice aid for the dying as a state-sanctioned form of health care, making it eligible for reimbursement under Medicare and Medicaid, the Governor's office announced.

title: Nkomo Says He Plans A Return to Zimbabwe
description: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwe opposition leader, said today that he would fly home Monday, ending five months of self-imposed exile in Britain.

title: FRANCE TO DEPLOY TROOPS IN VILLAGE ON CHADIAN FRONT
description: French paratroops were ordered today to positions on what has become the Chad Government's front line in its war against Libyan-backed rebels.

title: Race Still Young to Anderson
description: Sparky Anderson, the veteran manager, appreciates his team's place in the standing, but he is delaying his excitement for a few more weeks.

title: Division Street Wins Monticello
description: Division Street, the odds-on favorite, scored a 3 1/4-length victory today in the $201,000 Monticello Classic for New York-bred 3-year-old pacers at Monticello Raceway.

title: 49ers' Rally Tops Patriots by 17-15
description: A seldom-used second-year quarterback, Bryan Clark, passed for 54 yards in two plays with a little more than a minute to go today, then Ray Wersching kicked a 33-yard field to give the San Francisco 49ers a 17-15 exhibition victory over the New England Patriots.

title: FEW CORPORATE ISSUES SCHEDULED
description: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are the regular weekly auctions of new three- and six-month bills. By late Friday, outstanding three-month bills were bid at 9.4 percent, while the six-month issue was at 9.56 percent.

title: ORIOLES GAIN FIRST, BEATING WHITE SOX
description: The fortunes of the Baltimore Orioles seem finally to be changing. The Orioles, losers of seven straight games going into their weekend series against Chicago, yesterday handed the White Sox their second straight loss, 2-1.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE TEXT OF REMARKS BY REAGAN
description: Following are excerpts from the official text of President Reagan's remarks after his meeting today with President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado:

title: SALVADOR IN PACT WITH GUATEMALA
description: Guatemala and El Salvador have agreed on closer military cooperation, including a plan for Guatemala to provide counterinsurgency training in exchange for arms and ammunition from El Salvador, according to diplomats and officials in both countries.

title: PRICES RISE AMID UNCERTAINTY
description: Interest rates fell sharply late last week, bringing profits to traders but no definitive answers to investors who still face conflicting advice about the direction of interest rates.

title: MEETING A TEST
description: In 1974, at a track meet in Moscow, 15- year-old Mary Decker became so enraged when a Soviet relay runner elbowed her off the track during a race that she threw the relay baton at her opponent. Today, at the world track and field championships, Miss Decker showed she has found a better way to deal with Soviet runners who try to push her around on the track. She outruns them.

title: ETIQUETTE CAMP: TACKLING A LOST ART
description: Sherry O'Neill said she had already noticed a few changes in her 11-year-old son, Christopher, although, she acknowledged, ''Kids try to gross out their parents as much as they can and I'd be the last one to know what he really learned here.''

title: Turk Makes Unkindest Cut
description: THE news came across in the fine print of the sports transactions the other day that a young football player named Jeff Turk had been cut by the Atlanta Falcons. No doubt young Mr. Turk did not think his release was either poetic or justice, but generations of football players may have smiled at the concept of a Turk being cut by a football team.

title: Miss Navratilova Routs Mrs. Lloyd
description: Martina Navratilova trounced Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-1, 6-3, and won the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Los Angeles tennis tournament today.

title: Strange Doings on Chicago's South Side
description: THERE are people, normal, law-abiding, apple-pie eating people who truly believe a hex was put on the White Sox. They wonder now if the worst is over.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week. Monday

title: Debt Issues
description: * Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates filed to offer up to $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures in amounts and prices to be determined at the time of the sale, through First Boston Corp. Common Stock

title: Filipino Assails Corruption
description: The Archbishop of Manila, Jaime Cardinal Sin, said today that an atmosphere of fear and anguish prevailed in the Philippines because of social injustice and rampant violation of human rights. ''Poverty and suffering stalk the countryside and corruption maintains its terrible stranglehold on government,'' he said during mass at Manila Cathedral.

title: THE ANTI-SANDINISTAS FEAR ROLE IN U.S. POLICY IS BEING ERODED
description: As the Reagan Administration has begun highly visible military exercises in Central America over the last month and started to pay more attention to negotiating efforts in the region, anti-Sandinista guerrillas based in Honduras seem concerned that they have lost their pivotal role in American policy toward Nicaragua.

title: It's Not Brooklyn
description: When he was drafted by the Chicago Cubs in June of 1982, Shawon Dunston, a hard-hitting infielder who had starred for Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn for four years, was acclaimed as the most promising baseball prospect the New York area had produced in decades.

title: 2 Die as Tanker Truck Explodes in New Orleans
description: A gasoline tanker truck overturned and exploded into flames on the ramp of the Pontchartrain Expressway today, killing two people.

title: PLAN LACKING A MARSHALL
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL WOULD PERMIT MEDICAL USE OF MARIJUANA
description: An effort is under way in Congress to ease Federal restrictions on the use of marijuana as a treatment for glaucoma and the side effects of chemotherapy.

title: NICARAGUA OUTLOOK WORRIES EXECUTIVES
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to destabilize the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua through a variety of economic and military measures is being viewed cautiously by United States businesses and banks that operate in the war-torn country.

title: TEXACO REFINERY
description: -The Trinidad and Tobago government will decide soon whether to take over the 350,000 barrel-a-day Texaco Inc. refinery at Pointe-a Pierre, Patrick Manning, energy and natural resources minister, said Friday. Texaco Trinidad Inc. has offered a 75 percent share in the refinery for $200 million, following a plunge in output to 65,000 barrels a day caused by declining demand.

title: OUTDOORS: ADVANTAGES OF LIGHT TACKLE
description: THOSE accustomed to angling for striped bass and bluefish with 20- or 30-pound-test line sometimes have difficulty resorting to lighter gear.

title: 'FEET PEOPLE' JOIN CAPITAL VOCABULARY
description: Here come the ''feet people.'' They might not be pouring across the border yet, but they are rapidly entering the political language of the capital.

title: SWISS SEIZE PAPERS SOUGHT IN U.S. CASE
description: The Swiss Government, citing its laws on corporate disclosure, has seized documents belonging to a Swiss-based multinational company that is under investigation in the United States for possible income-tax evasion. And it said yesterday that it would not release the documents without negotiations with Washington.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 15, 1983 International
description: Mexico welcomed President Reagan with a word of caution. President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado told Mr. Reagan that international problems were aggravated by ''shows of force'' and must instead be dealt with by constructive political discussions. Mr. de la Madrid's comment, which he made in a speech welcoming President Reagan, was widely viewed as an allusion to Mr. Reagan's Central American policy. (Page A1, Column 6.) French paratroops in Chad were ordered to positions on what has become the Chadian Goverment's front line in its war against Libyan-backed rebels. There were also indications that France was matching its military show of force with a new diplomatic initiative. Guy Penne, President Francois Mitterrand's African adviser, met with President Hissen Habre and, according to a French spokesman, conveyed France's agreement to send troops to Salal, the northernmost outpost still in Government hands. (A1:4.)

title: PSYCHOLOGISTS DETERMINE BEST WAYS TO TALK TO ASSAILANTS
description: IT is a bad dream shared by many

title: NICARAGUA: A CORRESPONDENT'S PORTRAIT
description: This is a tropical revolution, sprawling in the heat and wild rain, not quite contained by ideology or plan.

title: PUERTO RICANS PUNISHED BY PROSECUTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: ENERGY RESOURCES OF NORTH DAKOTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a reverse stock slit in August 1982.

title: A KNACK FOR AWE
description: The caves at Altamira are neither the oldest nor largest prehistoric sites in southwestern Europe. But they have a special fascination because of their extraordinary paintings.

title: Free Financing By Alfa Romeo
description: Alfa Romeo Inc. said it had begun offering ''zero percent'' financing on its 1983 GTV-6 model luxury sports car. The Italian auto manufacturer said it would offer the financing to qualified customers on up to $13,000 for a maximum of 36 months, until Sept. 30.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Telephone Cuts 15% of Force
description: U.S. Telephone Inc., which provides long-distance services, has laid off 170 staff workers, about 15 percent of its work force, a company official said.

title: SYM-TEK SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: C. Nicholas Miller Jr.
description: C. Nicholas Miller Jr., a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died of cancer Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 57 years old and lived in Jupiter Hills Village, Fla.

title: TEXAS MAYOR TELLS AGENCY TO RETURN FROM NEW MEXICO
description: The local housing authority, continuing a symbolic four-month standoff with the Mayor, refused to come home from New Mexico today and said it had no plans to do so.

title: THE CONFUSING HAITIAN CONNECTION TO AIDS
description: THE link between Haitians and acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the terrifying disease known as AIDS, is baffling and will probably remain so for some time. For Haitians, the association is especially damaging. The nation's income from tourism has fallen and many Haitians regard the AIDS connection as a personal affront.

title: NATIONAL PARAGON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $237,468. c-Net loss.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' It seems to me that in looking for ways to resolve new tasks we were not vigorous enough, that not infrequently we resorted to half-measures and could not overcome the accumulated inertia fast enough.

title: PHOTO-CONTROL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Con Ed Workers To Vote on Pact
description: Striking Consolidated Edison workers will have an opportunity on Thursday to vote on a tentative contract that could end the two-month-old walkout, the chairman of the State Mediation Board said yesterday.

title: Rise in Jobs Off the Books
description: Workers in undeclared jobs are increasing in most Western countries and now represent about 10 percent of the total workforce, the International Labor Organization said today.

title: THOUSANDS OF NIGERIAN STUDENTS IN U.S. STRANDED BY AID CUTOFF
description: At least 10,000 Nigerian students at colleges and universities nationwide are not getting financial support from their homeland and may be forced to leave school, officials say.

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the quarter and $129,000 for the 6 months.

title: Soybean, Corn Futures Advance by Daily Limit
description: Soybean and corn futures prices soared by their daily permissible limits yesterday as the six-week drought continued to cut crop yields in the main producing areas of the Middle West.

title: Toulouse Police Arrest 2 Men As They Set Fire in Cathedral
description: The police in this city in southern France have arrested two members of an anarchist group as they were trying to set fire to St. Etienne Cathedral, the authorities said today.

title: Sellers and Buyers Differ on Media Time
description: The sellers and buyers of media time seem to be looking at entirely different pictures, according to a recent survey of 900 spot television advertisers and 100 sellers of broadcast time by Vitt Media International, a media planning and buying service.

title: YOUNG DOCTORS' PROBLEM: TOO MANY DOCTORS
description: After four years of medical school, five years of graduate training and months of all- night rounds, Dr. Michael Kressner, at the age of 32, was finally ready to open a practice in gastroenterology. The problem: No hospital would take his patients.

title: HURTFUL EXPORT CONTROLS
description: Do export controls work as a foreign policy tool? Experience suggests that they do not but that they do harm American exporters. Nevertheless, the Administration and Congress seem determined to pass legislation that preserves the President's privilege to impose export controls on any goods - consumer or military - whenever and wherever he sees fit.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomn Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Reactivated Dane Iorg, outfielder-first baseman. BASKETBALL

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RATES MIXED; DATA AWAITED
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as market participants waited for new developments that might point toward higher or lower interest rates.

title: TSI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RATIO OF MALE KANGAROOS TO FEMALE OFFSPRING TIED TO SURVIVAL
description: FOR more than half a century scientists have debated why ratios of male to female offspring vary at different times in populations of humans and other animals. For example, it has been reported that women in lower socioeconomic groups, presumably under greater stress, bear more girls than boys.

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Teletime's Fashion Videotapes
description: EVERY cloud has its silver lining, and Harold Klein thinks he has found his in the garment district's blackout last week.

title: New Futures In 5 Currencies
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission staff has recommended approval of a proposal from the Midamerica Commodity Exchange to trade futures in five foreign currencies. A staff document, prepared for a meeting Tuesday at which the trading commission will vote on the contracts, saidMidamerica's contracts would be one-half the size of but otherwise identical to those traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The units to be traded are 19,500 pounds, 50,000 Canadian dollars, 62,500 West German marks, 6.250 million yen and 62,500 Swiss francs.

title: Judge to >TO>
description: Citing substantial progress in removing homeless New York City families from hotels and motels in New Jersey, Essex County officials have asked a Federal judge to postpone a hearing on a suit to force their removal.

title: Slide Shuts Yosemite Road
description: A slab of granite fell from a mountainside to a road Sunday, blocking an entrance to Yosemite National Park. Eileen Berrey, a National Parks Service spokesman, said no one was injured by the slide, which came during a light shower. She said the road would be closed indefintely.

title: QUINTERO DIRECTS 'CAT' AS TRIBUTE TO WILLIAMS
description: His home here in the Los Feliz district, is on a hilltop, very far off Broadway, seemingly engulfed by trees and lush greenery. Not far from the hill is the college where he enrolled as a Panamanian immigrant almost 40 years ago, beyond that the theater where Ethel Barrymore had first stirred in him a love for the stage. In a way, Jose Quintero says, he has come back to his roots.

title: Workers Suing Atari
description: A $13.6 million lawsuit was filed today against Atari Inc. on behalf of 600 laid-off workers who asserted that they were not given advance notice of the layoffs.

title: Swingline Promotion
description: Swingline Inc. will spend $2 million in 1983 and 1984 to promote its Electronic 5000, an electronic stapler. The campaign, by Al Paul Lefton Inc., will include full-page insertions in business publications and regional television.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Computer Consortium
description: Computer technology in the 1990's could be worth $500 billion a year and create 7.5 million jobs in the United States - but ''only if we lead,'' Bobby R. Inman, the head of a research consortium, said.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Headline
description: THE HEARTS OF MEN American yreuth Dreams and the Flight from Commitment. By Barbara Ehrenreich. 206 pages. Anchor Press/Doubleday.

title: MACHINISTS SET STRIKE DEADLINE ON METRO-NORTH
description: Machinists threatened yesterday to go on strike tomorrow against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, which was shut down for seven weeks last spring by a walkout of the line's trainmen.

title: Top 3-Year-Olds Will Run in 1984
description: Thoroughbred racing fans have had to resign themselves to avoiding emotional attachments with good 3-year- olds. Time and again in the last few years, the colts who thrive in the Triple Crown races become so valuable as stallion prospects that they are prematurely retired and whisked off to the breeding shed.

title: U.S. EASES SECURITY AROUND COMPOUND SHELTERING RUNAWAY
description: A senior State Department official said today that the Administration had reduced the ring of security agents around the Soviet residential compound at Mount Alto here where a diplomat's teen-age son, whose name was signed to a letter saying he wanted to remain in this country, is said to be.

title: RIDGEWAY OIL EXPLORATION & DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $26,964 from discontinued operations.

title: ATLANTIC CITY ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DR. MICHAEL NEWMAN
description: Dr. Michael Newman, a psychologist and professor emeritus in the student development department at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, died Sunday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: EFFORT TO LOWER COST OF AID FOR FARMERS THWARTED BY NATURE
description: The persistent heat wave and drought is not only shriveling the 1983 corn crop but also upsetting predictions about the effect of the nation's farm policy. And once again experts both in and out of the Administration are despairing of bringing the unwieldy and expensive farm program under control.

title: IS U.S. TAX CREDIT FITTING FOR PRIVATE-SCHOOL BILLS?
description: The idea of providing Federal tax relief for families paying to send children to nonpublic schools has been considered repeatedly over the last 10 years, but each proposal has become mired in controversy and has failed to pass Congress.

title: TEACHERS WHO ARE MEMORABLE
description: EDUCATION has been defined as what you remember after you've forgotten what you've learned. A companion definition might be that education is the teachers you remember after you've forgotten the others.

title: REVERSE RACISM
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wrong Source
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:

title: A's 5, Angels 0
