description: Gorman Heimueller, an Oakland rookie, pitched a four-hitter for his first major league shutout and complete game. The 27-year-old left-hander, who spent six and a half years in the minors before joining the A's on July 12, struck out seven, did not walk a batter.

title: THE NEW RESORT COLLECTIONS ARE LOOSE, LONG, RELAXED
description: There's something about warm weather clothes that brings out the best in designers. The resort openings, which touched off a salvo of lighthearted, imaginative fashion designs when they began earlier this month, have continued to impress viewers. The showings were not affected by the power failure that caused upheaval on other parts of Seventh Avenue.

title: MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Altman's 'Streamers' Set for Film Festival
description: ''Streamers,'' Robert Altman's film based on David Rabe's award- winning play, will be shown on the closing night of the New York Film Festival, Oct. 9, at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $42,190,000 for the quarter and $66,074,000 for the 6 months. c-Including realized investment gains of $1,217,000 for the quarter and $2,326,000 for the 6 months.

title: White's Ankle Broken
description: There was discouraging news yesterday for one former Heisman Trophy winner from the University of Southern California, and good news for another.

title: MARINES IN LEBANON FIND THE ENEMY IS BOREDOM
description: ''Welcome to Sand Bag City, Population 89,'' proclaims the handpainted sign at the fringes of Beirut's silent and abandoned-looking airport.

title: SONOMA VINEYARDS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PREPARATION KEY TO U.S. TRACK SUCCESS
description: The impressive performances of American long and high jumpers at the first world track and field championships were more than coincidence. In the weeks leading to the meet, which ended Sunday, American team coaches drilled daily with the jumpers and even imported a psychologist to the team's Swedish training camp to help them adjust to the different tempo, pressures and procedures of jumping with prescribed time limits.

title: Unitary Tax Is Criticized
description: Canada has added to the growing international pressure on the Reagan Administration to sponsor legislation in Congress to outlaw a growing move by individual states to adopt the practice of unitary corporate taxation.

title: DEAN R. GIDNEY
description: Dean R. Gidney, president of the Potash Company of America in Manhattan, died of cancer yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated for a 7 percent stock dividend paid December 1982.

title: JOURNALISTS DISPUTE CRITICISM BY THE PRESIDENT OF CENTRAL AMERICA COVERAGE
description: Several representatives of news organizations took issue yesterday with President Reagan's assertions that the news media have not adequately reported programs of economic assistance to Central America. They said the attention given to military developments in the region had been spurred by White House actions.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POPE, AT LOURDES, SEEKS TO CONSOLE THE SUFFERING
description: Pope John Paul II concluded his two-day pilgrimage to this shrine today by celebrating an open-air Assumption Day mass and offering consolation to those who are suffering from illness and infirmity.

title: MARINE TRANSPORT LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $171,000 for the quarter and $253,000 for the 6 months, and a gain of $2,400,000, or $1.00 a share, for the quarter from insurance claims. c-Net loss including an extraordinary gain of $59,000. d-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $120,000. Results for the latest 6 months reflect a restatement of the previously reported first quarter 1983 net income, the effects of vessel disposals, and insurance claims.

title: ARMS CURB DEBATE SETS GLENN APART FROM RIVALS
description: The debate on nuclear arms control has been one of this year's longest-playing records here but, because it has been stuck mostly in the groove of exchanges between Congress and the Reagan Administration, the differences between the leading candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination have never clearly emerged.

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SOCIAL INSECURITY
description: I'll soon be 65 years old and can't bring myself to even think of applying for Social Security. As a father and grandfather, I am guilt-ridden to realize that young people would be paying for benefits I never expected to receive and never actually earned.

title: DEFENSE DEPT. HELD CARELESS ON DISPOSAL OF TOXIC WASTE
description: A House subcommittee chairman charged today that the Defense Department's system of disposing of hazardous military waste invited fraud and could threaten public health.

title: Beach Changes Blamed For Broken Necks
description: Winter storms and heavy summer surf have so changed the southern California coast that more surfers are suffering broken necks, according to lifeguards.

title: Topics; Murky Ideas; Correction
description: An editorial on Sunday incorrectly said that Solicitor General Rex Lee had defended tax exemptions for racist schools. Mr. Lee disqualified himself in the recent Bob Jones University case, which raised that issue.

title: NBC FINDS 'FAME' NOT SO FLEETING
description: Despite a fresh title, set and format, NBC's weekly news magazine, ''First Camera,'' may not be offered by almost 10 percent of NBC's 210 affiliate stations during the program's new time slot at 7 P.M. on Sundays this fall.

title: ROBINSON NUGENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid January 28 and a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid August 29.

title: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $802,017 for the quarter and $1,291,148 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $465,940 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss after a loss of $3,350,457 from discontinued operations.

title: INVESTORS' SUIT ACCUSES SON OF ASHLAND EX-CHIEF
description: John J. McMullen, the owner of the Houston Astros baseball team, has filed a lawsuit charging that Charles A. Atkins, the son of the former chairman of Ashland Oil Inc., was the central figure in a $25 million fraudulent scheme to loot the assets of several partnerships.

title: A SURVEY OF BOOKS SPAWNED BY ELECTRONIC AGE
description: COMPUTERS, many of their advocates used to say, would eliminate books, magazines and newspapers. Instead of slumping in the easy chair with an ugly lump of wood pulp, tomorrow's readers would sit erect, alert and jut- jawed, before a video screen, scanning all the news of all the world, or plugged in to the entire contents of the British Museum Reading Room, including all the world's works-in- progress as of five minutes ago.

title: 'HOMER' RULED A DOUBLE
description: Roland Hemond walked the six short blocks and four long blocks from the Sheraton Centre to the American League headquarters at 280 Park Avenue yesterday morning with a videotape tucked under his arm. The tape, the general manager of the Chicago White Sox felt, would prove that the home-plate umpire erred when he reversed another umpire and took away a home run from the White Sox in their 2-1 loss to the Baltimore Orioles at Comiskey Park on Sunday.

title: An Educational Debt
description: Even school-board candidates have to worry about campaign debts long after the votes are counted, particularly when they lack the support of the education unions.

title: Talking Business with Britain's Sir Michael Havers; Legal Discord With an Ally
description: The normally cordial relationship between the United States and Britain has been strained by two legal events: the sanctions President Reagan imposed in June 1982 on foreign companies aiding the construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline, and the Federal grand jury investigation of the role of British Airways and British Caledonian Airways in the collapse of Laker Airways.

title: U.S. PLANS MORE SPRAYING TO KILL MARIJUANA
description: *The herbicide paraquat could be sprayed on marijuana fields on Federal lands in 40 states after what the Reagan Administration considered a successful trial run in northern Georgia last week, officials said today.

title: Paraguay's President Takes Oath for 7th Term
description: Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, who has ruled this country under a state of siege since he took power in a 1954 coup, was sworn in today for a seventh term as President of Paraguay.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A DISILLUSIONED ATHLETE
description: From Danny Callandrillo's wood- frame house on 80th Street inNorth Bergen, N.J., it is just a walk of a block, past a row of similar houses, to Kennedy Boulevard. There, at the top of the hill, one may see, about six miles in the distance, the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, large and imposing, and having been constructed on a marshland, nearly desolate.

title: Grand Trunk Hearings Open
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission began hearings today on a proposal by the Grand Trunk Corporation to acquire the Milwaukee Road, which has been undergoing reorganization as part of bankruptcy proceedings for six years.

title: Washington State Offers 6 1/2% Notes
description: The State of Washington is offering $200 million of notes due in one year, yielding 6 1/2 percent, through underwriters led by the Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Group.

title: OMINOUS DECLINE IN PUBLIC SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: FACING THE 'GENDER GAP' WITH CONFLICTING ADVICE
description: At the White House, a fierce debate surrounds President Reagan's recent steps to address feminist issues. The debate is under way because there is no agreement over why Mr. Reagan continues to fare so poorly among female voters.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Includes income from a 30 percent interest in Monogram of $608,000 for the quarter and $217,000 for the 6 months.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 16, 1983
description: Markets

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: People
description: Theodore A. Bell, Daniel S. Reid, and Robert J. Taylor elected senior vice presidents at Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DONORS WARMING TO HARLEM TROUPE
description: The gift of an empty factory building on West 152d was cause for rejoicing at Dance Theater of Harlem back in 1971, when the black ballet company was only slightly more than a dream for its founders, Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook. Dance Theater has come a long way since then, though that first big gift is still its home.

title: AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: News Analysis
description: All night and most of the day, the thunder of French military transport planes reverberates over this city, and the symbolism is evident. This is the bridgehead of Western support for President Hissen Habre's 13- month-old Government, it is the emblem of a reluctant commitment by the Socialists in Paris that has frozen the advance of Liyba's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, into Chad, for the time being at least. But the triumph may turn out to be Pyrrhic.

title: ARGENTINA GETS I.M.F. BACKING
description: The International Monetary Fund gave formal approval today to changes in Argentina's economic policies, an action that releases $1.8 billion in loans from commercial banks and a third $300 million installment of a standby credit from the I.M.F.

title: Murky Ideas; Western Thought
description: New York habits of thought run deep, as a lifelong New Yorker found on a recent fishing trip in Montana. With a friend and a fishing guide, he floated down a river until, at the end of a long afternoon, their rubber raft reached the take-out ramp.

title: GENEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DIOXIN SPREADER IN MISSOURI SEEKS A NEW HAULING PERMIT
description: Russell M. Bliss, the waste hauler who spread road oil contaminated by toxic dioxin throughout Missouri, says he is considering a move to seek a permit to haul waste in another state.

title: Ford Will Offer A Plastic Bumper
description: The Ford Motor Company will put an all- plastic bumper that needs no metal reinforcement or backing bar on some 1984 subcompacts, the company said.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
An Offer to Mauch
description: After meeting last Sunday with the Montreal Expos' owner, Charles Bronfman , and the club's chief executive officer, John McHale , Gene Mauch left Canada with an offer to return as an executive in the Expos' front office. Mauch, who was the team's manager when Montreal joined the National League in 1969, would reportedly be made a vice president, primarily handling the duties of general manager.

title: 3-HITTER STOPS YANKS, RIGHETTI
description: Britt Burns, emerging from the Chicago bullpen, won a stirring pitching duel last night with Dave Righetti, the Yankees' most effective starter this season. Burns allowed three hits and Righetti allowed five, but it was the balk that Righetti committed that represented the difference in the 1-0 White Sox victory.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,700,000 from tax deferred sales.

title: PILGRIMS AT POLISH SHRINE HAIL SOLIDARITY
description: Solidarity banners formed a solid wall across the ramparts of the fortress- monastery of Jasna Gora today as hundreds of thousands of Roman Catholic pilgrims gathered to pay homage to the Black Madonna, Poland's most revered icon.

title: MOVING TO LIMIT THE IMPACT OF PAC'S
description: Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., a Republican from upstate New York, will accept no more than $50 as a campaign contribution, regardless of whether it comes from an individual or from a political action committee, or PAC.

title: A King 4,000 Times Over
description: Rodgers and Hammerstein had lunch at Quo Vadis the other day, but not together.

title: UNWISE GRINS AT ISRAEL
description: Lots of birds - some happy, some grudging - lately have been singing, from the treetops, a sweet song about renewed American-Israeli understanding. What's troubling is that no one has bothered to ask if Israel's best interests are served by the new cordiality or if the Reagan Administration is doing the right thing by being so indiscriminately nice.

title: Major Infiltration Seen
description: The group of local computer hobbyists under scrutiny by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for infiltrating computers penetrated dozens of systems, the lawyer for one of them said today.

title: Market Place; A Report Card On Technology
description: UNITED STATES and Canadian investors who placed $550 million of their money in the original offering of Sci/Tech Holdings - the largest single mutual fund ever marketed - show a small loss so far on their purchases. Currently, the fund's 107,331 shareholders are receiving their first quarterly report, whose release also has been awaited with intense interest by the investment community.

title: BARTER BROADCASTS: OFTEN MURKY AREA
description: William B. Tanner of Memphis has become well known in Southern broadcasting circles in the past 25 years for driving fast cars and hard deals.

title: OPERA: THE BOSTON RING
description: NEW YORK'S mini-Bayreuth festival - borrowed from Boston - ended Saturday night with the fourth of Wagner's ''Ring'' operas, ''Die Gotterdammerung.'' This weeklong cycle has been virtually a tale of two cities - the theater, the audience and the enthusiastic response coming from us, but the courage, energy and musical acumen of the Boston Lyric Opera Company making it possible.

title: Repression in Chile: Lesson Two
description: Repression cannot forever substitute for politics in a sophisticated society, especially not when times are tough. It's an old lesson for which Chile provides the newest blackboard - and yet, as the bloody disorders there demonstrate, it's a lesson the Chilean Government still doesn't understand.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about the New York Jets in Sports Pages last Friday attributed a quotation incorrectly. The man who spoke of being asked by Oakland to scout an opponent's defensive backfield was Charley Winner.

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30

title: Burt Lancaster Plans To Undergo Surgery
description: The actor Burt Lancaster said today that he would enter Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in about two and a half weeks for heart by-pass surgery and that he expected to be back at work by mid-October.

title: XEBEC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $133,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $145,000 for the quarter and $306,000 for the 6 months.

title: Reynolds Filing
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries of Winston-Salem, N.C. reported in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is considering selling its Sealand Trucking and Transportation unit, which it purchased for $500 million in cash and stock in 1969. It made the disclosure in a filing for the sale of up to 650,000 Reynolds common shares that it expects to be swapped with a cash payment for certain debt securities held by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Crash Kills Tunisia Diplomat
description: Hamda Kbaier, 38 years old, first secretary of the Tunisian mission to the United Nations, and his 6-year-old daughter Karima were killed after he parked his car on a highway and it was struck from behind by a car driven by Paul Williams, the authorities said. His wife, Hayet, 27, their 8-year-old daughter, Narda, and Mr. Williams, 58, were injured. The Tunisians were on a vacation here.

title: MONOGRAM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Results for the latest year include a loss of $387,000 from the settlement of certain deferred compensation agreements in the March 1983 quarter.

HOW TESTERS SEEK OUT CHEATERS
description: FOR three weeks recently, in the unlikely setting of a small courtroom in New Brunswick, N.J., little-known and even less understood practices of the largest testing organization in the country came under rare scrutiny.

description: b-Net income.

title: WIGGER PUTS SIGHTS AGAIN ON THE GOLD
description: Lones Wigger is hardly a typical-looking athlete. At age 45, standing 5 feet 7 inches and weighing 180 pounds, he looks more like an Army lieutenant colonel with a healthy appetite. Which he is.

title: DINOSAURS: CATASTROPHIC THEORY IS CONTESTED AT HELL HOLLOW
description: STANDING in one geologic time zone and reaching up toward another, Bill Clemens addressed the side of a bluff in Hell Hollow. He drove a small hand pick into the face just below the traces of lignite. Out fell a crumbling of clay, pieces of what is called the boundary layer. This layer, just a few inches thick, is the zone of contention in a rattling debate among geologists and paleontologists.

title: BRANCH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3 million, or $1.20 a share. c-Net loss.

title: SPENDING ORDERED FOR JOB TRAINING
description: Over the Labor Department's objections, Federal District Judge June L. Green today ordered that $123 million in job training funds be made available for back payments to thousands of laid- off workers.

title: A. & P. to Acquire Kohl's From Batus
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company said today that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Kohl's Food Stores chain in Wisconsin from Batus Inc.

description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

description: Nassau County police are patrolling Coney Island, the Albee Square Mall and the First African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church in Brooklyn, the Grand Concourse in the Bronx and all of Harlem.

description: International

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lackawanna Bid Said to Fail
description: Kenneth E. Lipke said he had failed in his bid to buy the specialty products portion of Bethlehem Steel Corporation's giant Lackawanna works.

title: News Analysis
description: In vetoing a bill to provide $20 million of desegregation assistance to Chicago schools, President Reagan said Saturday that the measure had been passed under pressure from a Federal judge who exceeded his powers. Mr. Reagan said that a recent order by Federal District Judge Milton I. Shadur in Chicago ''raises problems of profound constitutional significance.'' The basic constitutional question is the extent of a judge's power to set spending priorities for the President and Congress. Setting those priorities, Mr. Reagan said, is ''exclusively the function of the legislative and executive branches'' of Government.

title: Murky Ideas; Press Problem
description: Faith Ryan Whittlesey, the White House director of public liaison, has a ready explanation for lack of public support for her boss's Central American policies. She blames it on ''deliberate distortion'' by the press, which she says has portrayed Communist guerrillas as Robin Hoods and has so framed polling questions as to show public ignorance and indifference.

title: TALKS IN TELEPHONE STRIKE TO RESUME TODAY
description: As more workers joined the nationwide telephone strike today, representatives of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the three striking unions said they would reopen negotiations Tuesday.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A caption Saturday in the Metropolitan Report incorrectly identified a woman giving a test for a job at the Norstar Bank in Hempstead, L.I. She is Helen Summit.

Nkomo Flies Home After 5 Months in Britain
description: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwe opposition leader, arrived here early today, ending five months of self-imposed exile in Britain where he fled to escape what he said were Government plots to kill him.

title: Computerland Names President of U.S. Unit
description: The Computerland Corporation, the fast-growing franchiser of computer stores, has restructured its management and named Michael Shabazian president of its operations in the United States.

title: Lee Head, Novelist, Is Dead; Won Western Writers' Award
description: Lee Head, novelist and mystery writer, died of cancer Saturday at her home in Santa Fe, N. M. She was 52 years old.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: William B. Stokely 3d, having accomplished his mission, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of Stokely-Van Camp Inc.

title: REVIVED LAROCHE RETURNS TO YANKEES
description: Through the spring and most of the summer, Dave LaRoche put on his pinstriped uniform every few days, took his cuts in batting practice and headed to the outfield at game time.

title: THE DUTCH DESIGN A NEW DIKE
description: A MONOLITHIC pier 12 stories high was successfully planted on the bottom of the Scheldt River estuary in the Netherlands last week, allowing the long-suffering Dutch to see ahead to the day when a completed line of defenses will permanently protect their land from the North Sea.

title: CHICAGO COMPANY AND EXECUTIVE GUILTY OF SHIPPING PARTS TO LIBYA
description: A Chicago area company and its vice president have been convicted in Federal district court of illegally selling $16 million in aircraft parts to Libya.

title: TACO VIVA reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
No Headline
description: Three leading retail store chains yesterday reported sharp earnings increases for their latest three-month periods.

title: F.B.I. CONDUCTS 2D INTERVIEWS IN INQUIRY ON DEBATE PAPERS
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are beginning to reinterview some officials of President Reagan's 1980 campaign to clear up conflicts and inconsistencies that have developed in the investigation of how the campaign obtained debate briefing material prepared for President Carter, Federal law-enforcement sources said tonight.

title: Herman and Rosner Get Express Telecom
description: Herman and Rosner Enterprises Inc., has been named the agency for Express Telecom, a company founded last year that provides low- cost, long-distance telephone service. Billings are estimated at $1 million for the first year.

description: New Jersey Bell today applied for an $89.6 million rate increase, the second part of a $157 million increase sought by the telephone company.

The Mountains of Venus
description: No other body of the solar system has so far been shown to have long mountain ranges like those produced on earth by constantly shifting crustal plates. Now, however, radar scanning of Venus, whose surface is constantly hidden by clouds, has revealed a number of parallel ranges comparable to those on earth.

title: ORIOLES WIN BY 6-4 FOR THIRD IN ROW
description: John Lowenstein's three-run homer was the key hit for Baltimore in a five-run sixth inning as the Orioles defeated the Texas Rangers, 6-4, tonight for their third consecutive victory.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide yesterday incorrectly reported the cover price for the nightclub show this week at the Village Gate. It is $10.

description: The Phoenix Steel Corporation, which filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code last week, cut workers' wages and benefits, while company officials began working with creditors under court supervision to develop a reorganization plan.

title: Rand Gold Mining Area
description: The General Mining Union Corporation appears likely to develop a new gold mining area in the East Rand, Davis Borkum Hare, a brokerage firm, said here today. But Ted Pavitt, the mining concern's chairman, said that a feasibility study had not yet been completed and that no decision had been made to proceed with the project. Davis Borkum Hare said the area in question probably contains some 60 million metric tons of mineable ore with a gold content of about 6.5 grams a ton.

title: ANDROPOV URGES TOP PARTY AIDES TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: Yuri V. Andropov pressed his campaign to overhaul the economy today by summoning senior Communist Party officials to a meeting and telling them that the ''half-measures'' adopted in the past were not enough.

description: The city's five Borough Coalitions of Emergency Food Pantries have five more tons of food to distribute as a result of the Impact on Hunger Day held at Shea Stadium on Sunday, sponsored by the New York Mets.

title: NELSON L B, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings are restated for a 5 percent stock dividend in April.

description: When she was only 15 years old, Cynthia Woodhead was a record- breaking swimmer, the star of the 1979 Pan American Games in Puerto Rico, where she won five gold medals for the United States. Miss Woodhead rarely encountered adversity then, in or out of an Olympic-size pool.

title: U.S. MEN WIN IN BASKETBALL

description: b-Net income.

description: An Australian entrepreneur announced in Perth yesterday that he was making an unconditional takeover offer valued at nearly $3.5 billion at current exchange rates for Australia's largest company, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd.

description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition in February 1983 of Compu-Psych Inc. on a pooling-of- interests basis.

description: Msgr. Clement Kern, known as the ''labor priest,'' because of his aid to blue-collar workers, died today at Henry Ford Hospital after emergency abdominal surgery.

description: A $40 million offering of pollution control revenue bonds due in 2008, issued for the Eastern Edison Company, has been tentatively priced to yield 10 1/8 percent.

description: The syndicated bridge columns written by B. Jay Becker, one of the world's all-time great players, have often contained references to Sylvia, a lady whose play is technically inadequate but whose results are spectacularly good, thanks to the operations of the fates.

title: Koch Nominates 5 For Judgeships
description: Five nominees for judgeships were announced yesterday by Mayor Koch. His Committee on the Judiciary will hold public hearings on them next Monday.

title: Gene-Splicing Patent

The procedures are intended to replace those now widely used in gene splicing, in which genes (in the form of long molecules of DNA or deoxyribonucleic acid) are inserted into bacteria.

title: The Weakness of a Strong Dollar
description: The dollar is strong, the strongest it's been in a decade. Sounds good, but it isn't. It's another sign of economic policies gone askew, and a caution against further wrong steps. Any country would rather have a strong currency than a weak one. The problem now is that the dollar has become too strong - ''overvalued'' - making trouble at home and abroad.

title: BRAVOS GREET GALANOS'S SWEATERS
description: FIRST there were only gasps and a few squeals. Then came the bravos. How many times in the annals of fashion have bravos been heard for sweaters? Probably not too often, but these were not ordinary sweaters. They were the first knitted styles designed by James Galanos. A mixture of Angora and cashmere with a pile as deep as fur, they were almost floor-length, accompanied by jackets deeply encrusted with pearls and other jewels. They are one of the first fresh ideas in evening clothes any contemporary designer has had in a long time.

COVER LETTER AND EXCERPTS FROM JUSTICE DEPT. REPORT OF KLAUS BARBIE
description: Following is the cover letter and excerpts from a report issued today by the Justice Department's Criminal Division on its investigation of Klaus Barbie's relationship with United States Government officials, as submitted to the Attorney General by Allan A. Ryan Jr., special assistant to the Assistant Attorney General: As the investigation of Klaus Barbie has shown, officers of the United States Government were directly responsible for protecting a person wanted by the Government of France on criminal charges and in arranging his escape from the law. As a direct result of that action, Klaus Barbie did not stand trial in France in 1950; he spent 33 years as a free man and a fugitive from justice, and the fact that he is awaiting trial today in France is due entirely to the persistence of the Government of France and the cooperation of the present Government of Bolivia.

title: WITH AN EAR TO 'MAIN STREET AMERICA'

Since then the agency has made 461,900 business loans totaling $35.7 billion, plus 905,000 disaster loans totaling $12.2 billion to individuals and businesses hurt by natural disasters.

title: Occidental-China Mining Venture
description: China and the Occidental Petroleum Corpporation have agreed to proceed with preliminary work on a giant coal mine while they negotiate possible changes in financial terms of the project, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEY GAVE THEIR REGARDS TO OLD BROADWAY
description: THEY began some 50 strong, song sheets in hand - by belting out all four choruses of ''There's No Business Like Show Business'' in front of Mays department store on 14th Street at Broadway. Mays was once the site of the Union Square Theater and this was, officially, a sing-along salute to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the New York stage. Unofficially, it was an opportunity for would-be warblers to come out of the shower. Or, as Felix Cuervo announced over his bullhorn, ''This is a chance to be happy and have a good time.''

title: U.S. BASKETBALL TEAM OVERTAKES BRAZIL
description: The men's basketball team representing the United States here in the Pan American Games won its second game tonight in 24 hours. But the 72-69 hair-raising victory over Brazil, following Monday night's 74-63 struggle against Mexico, provided few bright spots.

title: Harry V. Anderson, 81, Ex-Magazine Publisher
description: Harry V. Anderson, founder and former publisher and editor of Interior Design magazine, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 81 years old and had lived in Manhattan and Woodbury, Conn.

title: Investing in Marilyn
description: Men in seersucker, carrying briefcases, swarmed over the stage at the Minskoff Theater yesterday during the first rehearsal for ''Marilyn: An American Fable.'' They were only some of the 97 investors for the $3 million musical about Marilyn Monroe.

title: Team America Demands
description: Robert Lifton, the principal owner of Team America, has told the North American Soccer League that he will cease to operate the team after Sept. 5 unless a series of demands are met.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Allstate Insurance Co., Northbrook, Ill., has elected Wayne E. Hedien executive vice president, treasurer and chief financial officer.

title: FORMER SCHOOL OPENED BY CITY AS 16TH SHELTER
description: Twenty-two women were taken last night to New York City's newest shelter for the homeless, the former United Nations School on First Avenue, where as many as 200 women will be housed until next spring.

Taiwan's TV Exports
description: Taiwan's exports of color televison sets almost doubled in the first half of this year, to 579,500, from 301,300 a year earlier, according to customs figures. In value terms, exports in the first have came to $100 million, about the same as for all of last year. Most of the exports went to the United States, which imported 364,200 sets in the first five months of 1983, compared with 400,000 for all of 1982.

title: RETIRED JUDGES TO HELP CLEAR COURT BACKLOG
description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation today setting up a new judicial post for retired judges to help deal with the backlog of criminal and civil cases in the state.

title: I.D.A. Funds May Decline
description: United States Deputy Treasury Secretary Timothy McNamar said today that there was no hope of getting the American Congress to approve an increase in the United States contribution to the World Bank's International Development Agency.

title: Bridge: Crocodile Snapped in Time To >TO>
description: Crocodiles are very rare on Long Island, but one opened its jaws wide in Patchogue Sunday during the Suffolk Championships.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to July 16
Raid on Afghan Tea Shop By Russians Reported
description: The crew of a Soviet tank opened fire on a tea shop in an Afghanistan town near the Soviet border where they thought a sniper was hiding, killing or wounding 50 civilians, Western diplomatic reports said today.

title: CHEAP MEXICAN PESO LURES U.S. FILM MAKERS
description: The hotels in Mexico City's Zona Rosa are crammed with American movie makers this summer. Directors and producers who usually ply their trade north of the border have, instead, flocked south this year.

title: New Chrysler Newport
description: The Newport, dropped from the Chrysler Corporation's car model line after 1981, will return in the 1984 model year, the company says. Chrysler plans to produce the larger-sized auto at a Fenton, Mo., plant. Sales will begin in early 1984, according to a company spokesman, Thomas Houston.

title: U.S. Jury Weighs F.A.L.N. Case
description: A Federal jury deliberated for four hours yesterday, but was unable to reach a verdict immediately in the case of two men accused of refusing to cooperate with an investigation of activities of the F.A.L.N., the group seeking Puerto Rican independence.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.* The Gloves e. $40. Bonwit Teller. [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ]

title: Banks Is Winner In Triple Jump
description: Willie Banks of the United States turned a lackluster international track and field meet into a one- man show today as he won the triple jump before a rain-soaked crowd.

title: Tech Penalized
description: New York Institute of Technology has been placed on one- year probation, retroactive to last Dec. 10, for violations in its men's basketball program, the National Collegiate Athletic Association said today. The penalty does not affect the school's eligibility for postseason competition.

title: PREMIER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DENELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Utility Faces $100,000 Fine For Nuclear Plant Violation
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission recommended Monday that the Florida Power and Light Company pay a $100,000 fine for ''a serious violation'' at its Turkey Point nuclear power plant.

title: Citibank Ends Bid For Grindlays Ltd.
description: Citibank said it has abandoned plans to take over an Australian investment bank, Grindlays Australia Ltd., following an Australian Government ruling that Grindlays must be 50 percent domestically owned within four years.

title: THOUSANDS ON THE GULF COAST FLEE HURRICANE
description: Alicia, the first hurricane of the season, bore down on the Gulf Coast with 80-mile-an-hour winds tonight, sending thousands of residents of Texas and Louisiana fleeing to higher ground. The officials said the storm could flood some escape routes by daybreak Wednesday.

title: JUDGE AND PRESIDENT
description: Judge William Clark is being cast these days as the villain in the basement of the White House - the President's national security adviser who, like Henry Kissinger and Zbigniew Brzezinski, is wielding power at the expense of the Secretary of State.

title: WHEN NATIONS' LAWS CLASH
description: Marc Rich & Company A.G., the Swiss-based commodity trading firm under investigation for possible United States tax evasion, is in a classic double bind.

title: Blues Deny Report
description: Jacques Demers , who coaches the Fredericton Express of the American Hockey League, has become a leading candidate to take over as coach of the St. Louis Blues, but Blues officials, contradicting a report in The Montreal Journal, denied that a decision had been made or that a news conference had been scheduled to announce a decision today. Another candidate for the post is Lorne Henning, an assistant coach with the Islanders.

title: Victor Layoffs
description: Victor Technologies Inc., a maker of small business computers, calculators and cash registers, said it has laid off 600 employees. The company on Monday reported a second-quarter loss of $11.1 million despite a sharp rise in sales, to $66.6 million, from $10.1 million a year earlier. Victor blamed its loss and layoffs on high marketing costs, bad debts and a shortage of floppy discs that prevented the company from filling orders on its microcomputer.

title: Indonesia's 5-Year Plan
description: The Indonesian economy will be projected to grow at 5 percent a year in the new five-year plan that begins next April, President Suharto said in a speech at the state opening of Parliament.

description: b-Net income.

title: ANTI-SEMITIC MOTIVE FEARED IN 3 FIRES IN WEST HARTFORD
description: Last Thursday, arsonists destroyed the sanctuary of a synagogue here. On Monday, several fires were set in the chapel and sanctuary of a second synagogue. Today, another fire destroyed the library of a rabbi's home.

title: KEAN IN ACCORD ON MOVE TO CUT AUTO INSURANCE
description: An agreement on a new automobile insurance system designed to enable New Jersey motorists to save an average of $150 a year was announced today by Governor Kean and legislative leaders.

title: SIMPSON QUITS TRANSIT POST, CITING 'INTRACTABLE' PROBLEMS
description: John D. Simpson, saying he had given ''everything I've got'' to the city's ailing subway and bus system, resigned unexpectedly yesterday as president of the New York City Transit Authority.

title: JAPAN STEPS UP TALK OF ARMS AND WORLD ROLE
description: In yet another August that marks the anniversary of its defeat in World War II, Japan is caught in an intense debate over whether it is time to assert itself actively once again in world affairs.

title: South African Mine Deaths
description: Six miners were killed during an underground accident 6,000 feet underground at the world's deepest gold mine, Western Deep Levels, southwest of Johannesburg, a mine spokesman said today. The mine has workings down to 10,500 feet.

title: NCNB, Ellis In Merger Pact
description: The Ellis Banking Corporation, one of the few remaining large family-controlled banks in Florida, said it had agreed to merge with the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C. NCNB said it would exchange 4 million of its shares for 4.1 million shares of Ellis stock owned by A.L. Ellis, the bank's 77-year-old chairman, and members of his family. Based on NCNB's current price of $26.50 a share, Mr. Ellis will receive stock worth an indicated $106 million.

description: b-Net income.

description: For all the opinions about Christine Craft, the ex-anchor who sued KMBC- TV in Kansas City for personal damages, there's a question of broader damage: Is the public being injured when a television station insists that women news readers exude ''warmth and comfort''?

title: Texas Air Order
description: The Texas Air Corporation, the holding company for New York Air and Continental Airlines, said it would purchase 11 new DC-9/Super 80 aircraft from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in a $250 million deal. The planes, which have a range of up to 2,300 miles and carry between 135 and 170 passengers, are to be delivered in 1984 and 1985, a spokesman said.

title: President Is Named By Executone Inc.
description: John R. Jester has been named president of Executone Inc., designers and marketers of business telephone systems, the company announced yesterday.

title: Caveat Retired For Syndication
description: Caveat, who won the Belmont Stakes on June 11 but in the process strained a foreleg ligament, has been retired from racing and is being syndicated to begin a new career as a stallion.

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IRAN-IRAQ DRAGS ON
description: Next month, the Iran-Iraq war will be three years old, and after more than 100,000 deaths it has settled into a grim military stalemate that costs each side about $1 billion a month. The rest of the world is largely unconcerned, in some cases even pleased to see the struggle continue as long as it does not spin out of control.

title: TV: 'TO DANCE FOR GOLD,' A 2-HOUR DOCUMENTARY
description: WE'RE not watching dance on ''To Dance for Gold,'' a two-hour public-television documentary; we're watching a program about dance. And don't think this is a fine distinction, because it's not. ''To Dance for Gold'' is afflicted by a severe case of Wide World of Sportsitis. The documentary, which will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is supposed to be about ballet, but it's really about gold medals, the rules of the game and what the guys say in the locker room. Phooey on all that.

title: MCCRORY WINNER IN GAMES
description: Steve McCrory of Detroit survived a last-round flurry by Panama's Jorge Arcia and won a 4-1 decision tonight in a 112-pound bout, the opening fight for the American boxing team at the Pan American Games.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IF I were to give a basic lesson for novice cooks in flavor composition - how to achieve harmony with various kinds of foods - I might well begin with foods cooked on skewers. The two basic elements of this kind of cooking are a little fat, such as olive oil, corn oil or melted butter, and an acid, which might be red or white vinegar, lime or lemon juice.

title: SAN FRANCISCO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW LISBON MUSEUM A HOME FOR MODERNISTS
description: After 21 years of acquisitions, more than three years of construction and a lively controversy generated by conservationists, Portugal's first museum of modern art has opened in Lisbon. It has been greeted with raves - and some 4,000 visitors in its first three days of operation.

title: Gault Signs With Bears
description: Passing up a chance to compete in next summer's Olympics, Willie Gault signed a contract with the Chicago Bears yesterday and joined the team at its training camp in Lake Forest, Ill. Gault, an acclaimed wide receiver from the University of Tennessee who had helped set a world record in the 400-meter relay at last week's world track and field championships, ended speculation about his future when he signed the contract that will reportedly make him the highest-paid rookie receiver in the history of the National Football League.

title: BENJAMIN COHEN, NEW DEALER, DIES
description: Benjamin V. Cohen, one of the key architects of President Roosevelt's New Deal, died Monday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: VW Plant Sale
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said its German parent had approved terms for the sale of its assembly plant in Sterling Heights, Mich. to the Chrysler Corporation.

description: b-Net loss.

title: COURAGEOUS SPLITS 2 WITH DEFENDER
description: At the opening of the final trials to select the America's Cup defender, Courageous rallied with an improved upwind performance and split two races today with Defender.

title: PERILING MINERS
description: The explosion of methane gas that ripped through a southwestern Virginia coal mine last June, killing seven miners and injuring three others, should have surprised nobody. The mine, McClure Coal Mine No. 1, had been cited 163 times in the previous nine months for violating health and safety rules; included in the citations were more than 30 for faulty ventilation of methane gas. And then, two weeks later, during the July 4 weekend, another methane-induced blast took the life of a Homer City, Pa., mine inspector.

title: NATURE'S SUNSHINE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Mellon-CCB Merger
description: The Mellon National Corporation said that it and CCB Bancorp had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board for their previously announced merger. Terms call for Mellon to issue one-half common share and one share of Series A preferred stock for each share of CCB.

title: Film Festival to Open With 'Big Chill'
description: ''The Big Chill,'' a film directed by Lawrence Kasdan, about the reunion of a group of friends from the 1960's, will open the 21st New York Film Festival Sept. 23 at Lincoln Center. Mr. Kasdan also directed ''Body Heat'' and was the screenwriter for ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' ''The Empire Strikes Back'' and ''Return of the Jedi.''

title: Salvadorans Say Israel Will Reopen Embassy
description: Israel will reopen its embassy in El Salvador in October and closer ties between the two countries could lead to weapons and training agreements, Salvadoran diplomats said today.

title: Pilot'sBodyFound In Jersey Crash
description: The body of a helicopter pilot was found off Chadwick Beach early today, more than 13 hours after his craft crashed, killing a 14-year-old boy and his father and critically injuring two other people.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am curious to know how to substitute agar-agar for gelatin in recipes. A member of my family is a vegetarian and will not eat gelatin.

title: HOUSE CONSTRUCTION DOWN 0.6% IN JULY

title: OFFERS ITS 'REGRETS' TO THE FRENCH
description: The United States said today for the first time that the Army had hidden Klaus Barbie, a former Gestapo officer wanted by the French for war crimes, employed him as a spy in Germany and then helped him escape to Bolivia.

Mr. Dederick was the first person to hold the post of Under Secretary for Economics, which he was named to in 1981.

title: HOME LOANS DRAW CROWDS TO BANKS
description: The chaise longues were lined up with little space between them as people jockeyed for position on the narrow strip of land. There were the usual accoutrements: Thermos bottles, bags of potato chips, paperback novels and earphones plugged into radios. It was all very typical for the summer, except this ''beach'' was the concrete sidewalk outside the Boston Five Cent Savings Bank and the only light above was from streetlamps and the moon.

description: Ross Roy, an advertising executive who was a pioneer in selling techniques, died today after a brief illness, company officials said. He was 85 years old.

MACARTHUR TRUST, A PHILANTHROPIC MAVERICK, FACES DIVESTITURE AND DISCORD
description: In philanthropy, a field pervaded by tradition and caution, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation stands out as a big spender with an unconventional style. It is perhaps best known for its annual series of fellowships to ''exceptionally talented individuals'' and for spending $5.4 million to rescue the 130-year-old Harper's magazine.

description: His given Russian name is Andrei, but the nickname he gives himself is Andy. ''I'm a Russian kid,'' he wrote in a letter to The Times, but he hates his country, loves this one and ''I want to stay here.'' Assuming he still wants to, can he stay? Is there a humane solution to the tormenting question raised by Andy Berezhkov, the 16-year-old son of the Soviet First Secretary in Washington?

Spicer Lung, who lost his job in Houston as a Pan Am catering manager, started work Monday as a supervisor of ramp and operations in San Francisco, an airline spokesman said here.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jimmy Connors and his wife, Patti, have reconciled their differences and are once again traveling together as a family with their 3-year-old son, Brett, according to their lawyers. . . . Ray Grebey , the former director of the Major League Players Association, has joined the faculty of Washington University in St. Louis and will serve as executive in residence at the university's School of Business and Public Administration for the coming year, the school announced. . . . Mike Weaver , former World Boxing Association champion, will fight Stan Ward at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif. Sept. 14, and Dwight Braxton, former World Boxing Council light- heavyweight champion, will meet John Davis Sept, 17 at a site to be announced. . . . Joe Charboneau, the American League's top rookie in 1980, has changed his mind and will not return to baseball this season by playing for San Jose of the Class A California League, something he announced last weekend that he would do.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DOES sleep really knit up ''the ravell'd sleave of care,'' as Shakespeare said? Does it relieve body and mind of the wear and tear of the day's labors and restore them so they are ready to face the demands of yet another day? If so, just how much sleep - and what kind - is needed to achieve this restitution?

title: Crash at Czech Border
description: An Austrian-Czechoslovak border crossing was closed for four hours today after a truck reportedly hit a barrier in what seemed to be an attempted escape to Austria.

title: INSTRUMENT FAILURE IS BLAMED FOR JET CRASH THAT KILLED 213
description: An expert on cockpit instruments testified today that a malfunctioning indicator confused the crew of an Air India 747 jumbo jet and caused it to plunge into the sea, killing 213 people seconds after taking off from Bombay.

title: American Airlines Cancels Fee Plan
description: American Airlines, apparently bowing to the pressure of other major carriers, said it had decided to withdraw plans to reduce travel agents' commissions to 9 percent from 10 percent.

title: MOUSSE: VERSATILE, ELEGANT AND EASY TO MAKE
description: CERTAIN foods, like certain people, are intimidating merely because of their appearance - even before you know the first thing about them. A galantine of chicken or an airy mille- feuilles pastry, for example, look as if they require painstaking work; they do. Elegantly presented cold mousses of fish, fowl or seafood, which are so delightful this time of year, also look arduous; they are not.

title: BALK PROVES COSTLY
description: When a batter hits a home run, everyone in the ball park sees it. When an infielder makes a diving stop of a wicked ground ball, everyone sees it. But when a pitcher commits a balk, virtually no one sees it.

title: Mayor May Lay Off 2,000 in Chicago Dispute
description: In another showdown with the City Council, Mayor Harold Washington is threatening to lay off 2,000 city employees if the Council rejects his plan for cutting back a year-end deficit estimated at $59 milllion.

title: Ex-Head of Ramada Moves to Carlson Cos.
description: Juergen Bartels, former president of the Ramada Hotel Group, has joined the Carlson Companies to head its 36 hotels and 349 restaurants.

title: BEARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW RULES ON HOLDERS' PROPOSALS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a hotly debated proposal that will make it more difficult for activist shareholders to put social and other issues to a vote at corporate annual meetings.

CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including gains of $2,450,000 for the quarter and $5,150,000 for the 6 months on the early retirement of debentures.

title: Market Place; Wall Street's Other Animals
description: IT'S common knowledge that bulls and bears prowl about Wall Street. But there are other creatures, large and small, populating the securities markets and some of them can be dangerous to the investor's financial health. Alligators, for example.

NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: No standing in line for a visa for Keith Elliott. The 42-year-old Briton doesn't bother to get one when he sets sail for the United States.

description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: RIGHTS CHARADE IN MADRID
description: Why does the West persist in playing the fool to the so-called ''peoples' democracies'' of the Eastern bloc? That is exactly what they have done in Madrid, at the negotiations known formally as the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and, more familiarly, as an extension of the Helsinki conference. In fact, these talks are a sad charade that do a disservice to the goals - human rights and international cooperation - they are meant to advance.

title: Article 106037 -- No Title
description: After a monthlong study of Investors Diversified Services Inc., the American Express Company said yesterday that it was dropping its plan to purchase the operation from the Alleghany Corporation unless it could negotiate a lower price.

EDUCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: SCREEN: 'THE MIRROR,' IN RUSSIAN
description: AMONG artistic creations, there are those that speak to a universal audience and those that speak mainly to their creator.

title: Media General Officer Quits
description: Citing ''possible conflict of interest,'' Media General Inc. announced yesterday the resignation of Louis R. Lucas as vice president, secretary and legal counsel of the William B. Tanner Company of Memphis, Tenn.

title: EAST GERMAN BREAKS THE ICE, GOES TO POLAND
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, arrived here today for a state visit, the first by a Soviet-bloc leader since 1980, when Solidarity was formed.

title: HI-G INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After a charge of $168,000 for the writedown of an investment in a subsidiary.

title: SPANISH CONSUL HELD HOSTAGE IN LOS ANGELES
description: An armed man who apparently wants members of his family flown to Puerto Rico took four people hostage at the Spanish consulate this afternoon, the authorities said. The consul was among the captives, officials confirmed.

title: SHIPMATES RECALL FLAMES OF WAR
description: They stood in the shade of the gray steel bridge yesterday, four not-so-young men. They were on the flight deck of the Intrepid, the aircraft carrier turned museum, at 46th Street and the Hudson River, but in each other's eyes they saw again the South Pacific, the flames, the fear - and the enemy.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $11,581,000 from the sale of interest in Consumers Distributing Company LTD. of Canada.

title: Big Bank In Austria Seeks Aid
description: The Government- controlled Creditanstalt-Bankverein, Austria's largest bank, has asked the Government to provide financial aid for companies controlled by the bank, saying that their mounting losses are dangerously diminishing the bank's profits.

title: 1 OF 2 BIDS IS REJECTED FOR BUS SHELTERS
description: One of two bids to build bus-stop shelters in New York City's five boroughs was rejected yesterday because it did not meet the city's bidding terms. This cleared the way for a start on 2,523 new shelters.

title: Resolving the 42d Street Spat
description: Governor Cuomo loves nothing more than displaying his considerable skill as a mediator; and he put that skill to excellent use over the weekend to settle the spat among directors of the state and city corporation that plans to reconstruct 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Equally, Mayor Koch deserves credit for his willingness to negotiate.

title: RANGERS 1-HITTER STOPS ORIOLES
description: John Butcher allowed only one Baltimore hit, Al Bumbry's third-inning single, and Buddy Bell hit a home run as the Texas Rangers defeated the Orioles, 2-0, tonight. Baltimore had won three straight.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BEETHOVEN IN THE PARK
description: THE New York Philharmonic had to share the center of attention with its agreeable setting Monday night. There was music by Corigliano, Beethoven and Sibelius for its concert on the Great Lawn of Central Park, but equally attractive were the people, predominantly young, who by the thousands sipped wine, ate sandwiches and watched the sun fade, then give way altogether to the lights of New York's skyline.

title: WHAT A BOOK CAN DO THAT A COMPUTER CAN'T
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest Rates Down Slightly; Notes, Bonds Sell Well
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday as dealers reported good investor demand for Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Foote, Cone Is Opening Tokyo Office With Daiko
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, with offices in 22 countries, is opening an office in Tokyo with Daiko Advertising, the third-largest agency in Japan.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STAGE: RICHARD PRYOR LIVE AT RADIO CITY
description: IF there is one thing funnier than Richard Pryor's concert films, such as ''Richard Pryor Live on the Sunset Strip,'' it is Mr. Pryor live in performance. This week he is offering a series of midnight shows at Radio City Music Hall, and his peerless talent as a comic, mimic and commentator makes this a comedy evening of the first magnitude.

title: A LAWYER'S CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: MOYERS GOAL WINS IN SECOND OVERTIME
description: The Cosmos have had success here against the Toronto Blizzard, like tonight's 1-0 sudden-death victory in two overtimes on a goal by Steve Moyers. But they have never played an attractive soccer game here since the Blizzard moved into Exhibition Stadium five years ago.

title: Cuomo Shifts Site For State Police
description: Governor Cuomo has instructed the state police to build the headquarters for its Long Island troop at Republic Airport in Farmingdale instead of the preferred site at nearby Bethpage State Park, a spokesman for the Governor, Joseph Slacus, said today.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Airline to Restore Flights to 11 Cities
description: Continental Airlines is restoring service to 11 of 17 cities where flights were dropped when union machinists went on strike last weekend, a spokesman said today.

description: b-Sales figures for the 6 month periods are in billions of dollars.

title: WINE TALK
description: ONE might expect that most of the mail coming across this desk would be contentious, taking issue with comments on vintages and such. While there is quite a bit of that, the single theme repeated most often goes something like this:

title: U.S. Carrier Coral Sea Off Coast of Nicaragua
description: The aircraft carrier Coral Sea and four other United States warships arrived off the Caribbean coast of Nicaragua today to start the second phase of United States exercises in the region.

title: WHITE SOX TOP YANKEES AGAIN
description: When Ron Kittle stepped to the plate to bat against Rich Gossage with the bases loaded and two out in the seventh inning last night, he brought with him a .251 batting average and a .283 strikeout average. That is, he had hit safely 96 times in 382 at-bats, but he had struck out even more - 108 times.

title: Jockey Rides 7 Winners
description: - Earlie Fires tied a Chicago thoroughbred racing record today when he brought home seven winners from eight mounts at Arlington Park.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: No man is an island, except Manhattan. BOB LAPIDES

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Big-Time Crowds
description: When Syracuse University moved its basketball team from Manley Fieldhouse to the Carrier Dome in 1980, the program not only entered a bigger arena but broke into the big time as well. Attendance jumped from an average 8,900 per game to 16,000 in 1980 and increased to 18,000 in 1981.

title: Water
description: A 36-inch water main burst today, sending two million gallons an hour of water into streets in the eastern and northern sections of this city.

title: U.S. IS CONCERNED OVER PALESTINIANS
description: State Department officials, in a classified memorandum, have expressed concern about ''a dramatic increase'' in threats to the lives of Palestinian refugees in Lebanon.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: JOHN I.B. MCCULLOCH, PRESIDENT OF U.S. ENGLISH-SPEAKING UNION
description: John I. B. McCulloch, president of the English-Speaking Union of the United States, died Monday of a stroke at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: CORRECTION
description: The money table in Business Day Tuesday misstated the 180-day London interbank offered rate. The correct figure was 10.75 percent.

title: REAGAN IS NOT EXPECTED TO OPPOSE LIE TEST FOR AIDES ON CARTER DATA
description: The White House indicated today that President Reagan would have no objection if senior Administration officials agreed to take polygraph, or lie detector, tests to resolve conflicts in their accounts of how the Reagan campaign obtained President Carter's debate strategy papers in 1980.

title: TRIES TO PROD QADDAFI TO NEGOTIATE
description: President Francois Mitterrand has expressed irritation at United States pressure on France to intervene in the war in Chad, and says he does not agree with what he sees as an American campaign against Libya.

title: U.S. AGENCY BACKS ATOMIC DATA CURB
description: The Energy Department today defended its proposal to further restrict the distribution of nuclear information. But, responding to criticism from an array of Government and private organizations, the department said it would be willing to modify the plan.

title: LIFE HUMS IN TOWN THAT LIVES ON TREES
description: Tourism is going up. Silver is going out. Trees are coming down. Seedlings are going in. And life is starting to hum again here in the isolated, tree-covered northwest corner of this rugged state. Orval Bothman is working night and day to perfect production of his new invention, a chemical-free fire-starter for campers, outdoor cooks and fireplace fanatics. Jim Merry's job at the plywood plant seems secure for now. And Wade Nixon is back in the woods falling fir behemoths and resuming payments on his truck.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
METHOD TO DELAY TAXES MAY COST U.S. MILLIONS
description: The Federal Government apparently is losing several million dollars a year because the Internal Revenue Service is not enforcing laws that prohibit corporations from making late deposits of weekly payroll taxes.

title: Economic Scene; Production, Modern Style
description: THE past decade has been marked by uncertainity in interest rates, prices of materials, exchange rates, technology and consumer tastes. In the last several years, business leaders have come to see the new uncertain environment as permanent and have tried to restructure their organizations by becoming more flexible and more adaptable.

description: WHEN Ellsworth Statler and the Pennsylvania Railroad built the Hotel Pennsylvania in 1919, on Seventh Avenue between 32d and 33d Streets, their aim was to serve travelers arriving at the recently opened Pennsylvania Station across the street.

title: Two Bullion Dealers Indicted
description: William and James Alderdice, the two brothers who founded the now-closed International Gold Bullion Exchange, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on 18 counts of conspiracy, mail fraud and wire fraud, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

Satellite for Communicating With Shuttle Flights Is Tested
description: A communications satellite that will be used in space shuttle flights has successfully completed its first operational test, a spokesman for the company that designed and made the satellite said Monday.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ARE RESUMED IN TELEPHONE STRIKE
description: Negotiations to end a nine-day nationwide telephone strike resumed today.

title: New York Led Astray
description: Does the Department of Sanitation encourage New Yorkers to violate the law? Helene MacLean of Brooklyn Heights thinks so. For years she has been trying to get the department to leash the pup on its ''Clean Up After Your Dog'' sign.

CORIANDER: PUNGENT HERB GROWS POPULAR
description: LESS than 10 years ago the author of an herb cookbook saw nothing peculiar about describing fresh coriander as ''an odd-smelling foliage.'' The only people who really liked it, she wrote, were Orientals, Mexicans and South Americans. She neglected to mention Indians and Moroccans.

title: Major Problems Surround Bengals
description: The Bengals, who take an 0-2 exhibition record into tomorrow night's nationally televised game against the Jets at Cincinnati, are trying to steady themselves after some recent unsettling developments.

description: Democratic Party officials have rejected a delegate-selection plan that would have given Senator John Glenn an added advantage in his home state's Presidential primary next May.

description: THE University of Vermont has begun a program aimed at luring people from business into the public schools to become mathematics and science teachers.

title: COMPANY NEWSA.& P. Will Close 25 No-Frills Outlets
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company said today that it had decided to close its 25 Plus discount grocery stores and concentrate on running conventional supermarkets.

description: A United States soldier taking part in joint military exercises with Egyptian forces was killed when the jeep he was driving overturned on a road near Cairo, the Army said today.

description: Flanked by armed soldiers, President Hissen Habre of Chad indicated today that there was little chance of a peaceful solution to his country's problems because of what he termed Libyan expansionism.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHEN one first sees Graham Parker come strutting out onto a stage, looking tense and wiry and always, it seems, at least a head shorter than any of the musicians in his backing band, one experiences a moment of doubt. Can the huge, raging voice on Mr. Parker's records possibly belong to such a frail-looking bantam?

title: Grand Jury Clears Woman With Gun
description: A Manhattan grand jury declined yesterday to indict a 67-year-old Alabama woman who used an unloaded pistol to frighten off eight people who she said she thought were going to rob her near the Port Authority Bus Terminal early Monday soon after she arrived in New York.

Detective Accused Of Taking Bribes
description: A detective in the Newark Police Department was indicted today on charges of offering to use his influence to have liquor licenses of bars renewed in return for bribes.

title: Tampa Bank Indictments
description: Two executives have been indicted on charges that they tried to gain control of the Metropolitan Bank and Trust Company by secretly using loans from it to buy up its own stock shortly before it collapsed last year.

title: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Marmon Group Inc. is owned by Marmon Group, a private concern.

title: TRADITIONAL DISHES STILL FLOURISH IN NORTHERN ITALY
description: Considering the hundreds of Italian restaurants in New York and the wide variety of dishes on their menus, it is surprising to realize that the selection represents only a small percentage of intriguing regional dishes of Italy. While I found on a recent six-week tour that it is more difficult to find excellent meals than it was 15 or 20 years ago, Italy still abounds in traditional specialties rarely if ever seen on menus in the United States. This is especially true of northern Italy, even though we consider that region well represented here. Many of these dishes fit the contemporary preference for lightness and freshness, for natural herb seasonings, for high-carbohydrate foods such as pasta and rice with vegetables and for main courses of fish and veal.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: From Delices to Queens Guy Pascal has picked up his pastry tube, his madeleine molds, his apron and his toque and left the kitchens of Delices La C^ote Basque on Lexington Avenue. He has opened new kitchens in Queens under a new name, Delices Guy Pascal.

title: ISRAELI BIDS BEIRUT RECONCILE WITH DRUSE
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, urged the Lebanese Government today to come to an understanding with the Druse in order to assure a peaceful transfer of authority when Israeli forces pull out of the Shuf mountains.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pennsylvania Notes Are Offered At 6.75%
description: The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania sold $600 million of tax anticipation notes due June 15, 1984, which were offered at a yield of 6.75 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Pittsburg National Bank. By late in the day, underwriters said, the issue was more than 95 percent sold.

title: Nigeria Auto Pact
description: Anammco, a joint venture between the Nigerian Government, the Anambra state Government and Daimler- Benz A.G., the West German car manufacturer, said it would begin production of Mercedes Benz automobiles in Nigeria within three years. Peugot and Volkswagen also assemble cars in the country.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: Bird Still Unsigned
description: His deadline is less than two months away, he and his agent are about to leave for a two-week tour of Israel, and negotiations on a contract that would keep Larry Bird with the Boston Celtics beyond next season haven't even begun. That was the word yesterday from Bird's agent, Bob Woolf, who said he had not spoken with the Celtic general manager, Red Auerbach, in two months and was still waiting for the call that would get the negotiations going in earnest.

title: Griffith's 2d Thoughts
description: Calvin Griffith, the owner of the Minnesota Twins, has been having second thoughts about his first-round draft choice, Tim Belcher, a pitcher from Mount Vernon Nazarene College in Ohio. Belcher was good enough to be the first player chosen in the draft last June, but, according to Griffith, he is not good enough to justify the $160,000 signing bonus he has been asking for.

Pay Proposal Backed
description: Two college football coaches, Hayden Fry of Iowa and Jim Criner of Iowa State, have spoken out in support of a proposal put forward by Coach Tom Osborne of Nebraska that would allow colleges to pay their football players a monthly stipend. ''I've always agreed with that,'' said Fry, who said that Osborne's proposal of $50 a month in spending money would be ''a good starting point,'' but that a $500 stipend proposed by a Nebraska legislator would make the players real professionals. ''We ask kids to meet all these entrance requirements and deny them an opportunity to work while they're playing,'' said Fry.

description: The pilot of the burning Air Canada jetliner in which 23 people died testified today that all compasses and direction indicators in the smoke-filled cabin failed as he attempted to land the DC-9.

description: United States industry operated at 75.8 percent of capacity last month as manufacturers - particularly auto makers - put more of their long-idled production lines into action, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

description: Foreign currency futures prices continued to advance yesterday. But currency traders cautioned that the relative decline in the dollar's value against these currencies this week might be more technical than fundamental.

title: DANCE: UTAH REPERTORY COMPANY AT DAMROSCH PARK
description: ONE of the best dance bargains in town was to be found on Tuesday at the Damrosch Park Bandshell, when the Repertory Dance Theater of Utah performed works by four American modern-dance pioneers. It was the kind of program - well-chosen, informative and vibrantly performed - that would have been a bargain at normal dance-theater prices, though it was free as part of the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival.

title: STATE DEPT. AIDE IS SUED BY OILMAN
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt, the oilman, filed a lawsuit last month charging Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam with an apparent conflict of interest for holding two other jobs last summer at the same time he was charging $24,000 for arbitrating an oil case involving Mr. Hunt.

title: HERS
description: WHEN four of the Democratic Presidential candidates appeared before the National Women's Political Caucus convention last month to seek its endorsement, a paragraph in a report in The New York Times said: ''Mr. Glenn flirted with trouble when he spoke of 'man and wife' rather than using the preferred language of 'husband and wife.' Mr. Hollings got a forgiving laugh when he apologized for a brochure that called him 'the thinking man's candidate.' ''

description: The Journal Square Transportation Center here will open Thursday for the first time since a 50-ton ceiling above its main concourse fell, killing 2 people and injuring 10 others on Aug. 8, officials said today.

title: TIME TO ADD TO A LIBEL PLAINTIFF'S BURDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: WAYS OF ATTACKING JAPANESSE BEETLES
description: ROSES, marigolds, zinnias, corn silks, hollyhocks, Boston ivy. You name it; Japanese beetles eat it. These insects use their voracious appetites to gulp succulent rose petals in big bites or skeletonize leaves into lacy patterns. Their feeding has few limits. Nearly 300 ornamentals - trees, shrubs, flowers - can be chewed by these beetles.

title: WELCH AND HOWE BEAT METS
description: Ron Hodges, the Mets' catcher, had his choice of three bases to throw to for an out in the second inning tonight against the Los Angeles Dodgers. Instead, he held the ball and the Dodgers went on to score three runs in the inning and beat the Mets, 4-1.

title: Berry Will Get A Second Appeal
description: The Division I steering committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association voted today, 11-10, to consider a second appeal by St. John's to have Walter Berry ruled eligible to play basketball.

title: DON'T DRINK THE WATER IN AKRON, OHIO
description: Thousands of residents in the southwestern part of Akron have not been able to draw potable water from their faucets for a week, and the end is not in sight. The water has been contaminated with harmful bacteria, and city officials have been unable to find the source of the problem.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AT THE MOVIES

title: SOVIET ASTRONAUT RECORDS HARDSHIPS OF LONG FLIGHT
description: Excerpts from a diary kept by a Soviet astronaut during a seven-month flight last year have given an unusually candid glimpse into the fatigue and anxieties experienced by crewmen living for long periods in space.

title: LET THE MOVIE AUDIENCE BE THE FINAL JUDGE
description: MOVIE viewers have to make snap judgments all the time. They size up characters on first impression, often with very little time to do so - and few current movies invite and utilize snap judgments as deliberately as ''The Star Chamber.'' This may be a film about the inequities of our judicial system, but its own tactics are not entirely fair. When it comes to deciding which of the story's characters are to be regarded as honorable and which ones are not, the jury is seldom out. Peter Hyams, the director of this exciting if overly manipulative drama, establishes the film's sympathies with such persuasive strokes that ''The Star Chamber'' could stand as a virtual text on how to shape and dictate an audience's opinions - or how not to.

title: A LEGACY OF TALENT AT THE STANFORD WHITE ESTATE
description: BESSIE SMITH, wife of the turn-of-the-century architect Stanford White, used to be fond of watching the Long Island Sound from a favorite hilltop on the North Shore. It was there the architect built for his wife Box Hill, an Italianate mansion with Italian gardens. ''It's really Bessie Smith's land,'' said Claire Nicolas White, a member of the extended White family that lives on the now-lapsed estate. ''That she loved it is why the whole place came to exist.''

description: The world's leading tanker owners said today that the international oil tanker market remained depressed despite a drop in the number of idle ships.
