description: * American Health Products Co., Orangeburg, N.Y., has named Reynald M. Swift president.

title: Addendum
description: * Grey Direct International, direct marketing subsidiary of Grey Advertising, has opened a Chicago office.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 19, 1983
description: Markets

title: BANKER INVEST IN ELEGANT OFFICE LUNCHES
description: While there may be no free lunch in the world at large, there is if you work for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. And if you are high enough on the ladder at such other New York financial institutions as Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the lunch is not only free but also downright opulent.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HORMEL, GEORGE A, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
A CARAVAN OF AFRICAN TEXTILES ROLLS INTO MUSEUM
description: In the mountains of Morocco, the men of the Berber tribe wear voluminous black cloaks. On the back of these is woven an enormous red oval, to represent - and, they hope, to protect against - a jealous ''evil eye.''

title: BRIEFING
description: The Sound of Anvils

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a gain of $39,087,000 from an accounting change.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEATER: 'PREPPIES,' A MUSICAL SATIRE
description: ''PREPPIES,'' the new musical that opened last night at the Promenade Theater, might have an appeal for past and promising preppies, but for others the interest should be largely academic. In keeping with the subject matter, the show is intentionally traditional, upholding the J. Press dress code of button-down shirts, khakis and loafers.

title: 4 ARE CONVICTED OF ENSLAVING MIGRANT WORKERS IN THE SOUTH
description: A farm labor crew chief, his two sons and another man were convicted today of holding migrant workers in slavery.

title: TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSTON'S GLASS CASTLES SHATTER AS THE HURRICANE SWEEPS INLAND
description: The city of Houston, the dazzling and futuristic metropolis of glass, became the city of flying glass today.

title: AGNICO EAGLE MINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Braves Lose Fourth in Row
description: Ferguson Jenkins, with last-out help from Lee Smith, pitched a seven-hitter, and Jody Davis hit a three-run homer in the fourth inning today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 3-0 victory from the Atlanta Braves.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 19, 1983
description: International

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOSPITAL IN CITY REPORTS COMPUTER TAMPERING
description: One or more young men, using a home computer, gained access to and reprogrammed a computer containing the radiation- therapy records of patients at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, according to hospital officials and Federal documents. .

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $2,682,000 for the quarter and $4,830,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,404,000 for the quarter and $1,977,000 for the 9 months.

title: SHRINKING JOB MARKET GENERATES VIOLENCE ON CALIFORNIA FARMS
description: More than 300 striking union workers stormed a cantaloupe-packing shed in this town more than 120 miles south of San Francisco last week, hurling stones, bottles, bricks and steel spears made from fence posts. In the battle that followed, 10 police officers and several strikers were injured, some seriously.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Vivian Beaumont Theater yesterday incorrectly described the marital status of Adele Block, vice president of the Beaumont board. She is married to Leonard N. Block, the treasurer of Lincoln Center.

title: EX-NEW YORK SCHOOL OFFICIAL
description: Andrew G. Clauson Jr., who served 16 years on New York City's Board of Education under four Mayors, died Wednesday at Staten Island Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: INSTACOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: HENZE IS PERFORMED AT TANGLEWOOD FESTIVAL
description: The climax of Tanglewood's Festival of Contemporary Music is traditionally the full-orchestra concert of Berkshire Music Center fellows conducted by Gunther Schuller. This year's installment of that concert took place Wednesday night in the Theater-Concert Hall, and it was a loud, rattling success, thanks largely to the two big-name composers on the bill.

title: Lower Blood Pressure Trend Linked to Less Heart Disease
description: Trends toward lower blood pressure may have contributed to the recent decline in deaths from cardiovascular disease in the United States, doctors said today.

title: WORKERS APPROVE A NEW CON ED PACT ENDING A WALKOUT
description: Striking employees of the Consolidated Edison Company voted overwhelmingly last night to accept the terms of a new contract and end their nine-week walkout against the utility.

title: COMPTEK RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
A McEnroe Loss
description: Brad Pearce of Provo, Utah, upset top-seeded Patrick McEnroe of Douglaston, Queens, 7-6, 6-3 in the quarterfinal round of the United States Tennis Association international boys' grass- court tennis championship today.

title: Journal Sq. Station Is Back in Service
description: The Port Authority's Journal Square commuter station here, which had been closed since a suspended ceiling collapsed Aug. 8 and killed two people, was reopened this morning. Scaffolding covered areas with ceilings similar to the one that fell.

title: INTERNATIONAL MOBILE MAHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALIFORNIA BANKS CLOSING BRANCHES
description: As part of a nationwide trend, officials of the Wells Fargo Bank and the Bank of America said today that they plan to close dozens of full-service branches in California this year, relying on automatic teller machines to maintain levels of customer service.

title: CHAD SAYS RUSSIANS ACCOMPANY LIBYAN INVADERS
description: Authorities here said today that Soviet military advisers had been present in the north of Chad for several years and had probably visited the Libyan troops supporting rebels in the captured northern oasis of Faya-Largeau.

title: THOUSANDS DELAYED AS L.I.R.R. CUTS POWER BECAUSE OF GAS-MAIN PUNCTURE
description: A gas-main break in Maspeth, Queens, forced the Long Island Rail Road to shut off power on its main line at the peak of the evening rush hour yesterday, delaying thousands of commuters. Service was restored more than two and a half hours later, shortly after 6 P.M.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest quarter include a pre-tax write-down of $6,000,000 due to continuing depressed energy markets.

title: DOW FALLS BY 14.02, TO 1,192.48
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday after Wednesday's upsurge as investors cashed in some of their profits because of concern over interest rates.

title: Free Blakey Concert
description: The Long Island Jazz Festival at Heckscher State Park in Islip is presenting a free concert by Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers tomorrow night at 8. The number for directions and information is (516) 246-6126.

title: OUR ENDANGERED CHILDREN
description: Growing Up in a Changing World. By Vance Packard. 385 pages. Little, Brown. $18.95. IT is the fate of 20th-century children to suffer fads. Right now, the fad is to apostrophize them.

title: China Holds Truck Talks
description: China is holding talks with West German and Austrian companies on importing equipment to build heavy trucks to help its automotive industry, a senior official said today.

title: APPELLATE JUSTICE ORDERS 'PLAY BALL'
description: Joseph P. Sullivan, an associate justice in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, ended two days of legal wrangling yesterday by permitting the conclusion of the suspended pine-tar game.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: Penthouse Seeks Casino Financing
description: Penthouse International is holding talks with several New Jersey banks for $100 million in financing, and with a few foreign governments for up to $35 million in export credits to resuscitate its ailing casino project, David Myerson, executive vice president for Penthouse International, said. He declined to name the banks or countries.

title: Samuel Derecktor, 86; Had Owned the Exodus
description: Samuel Derecktor, who supplied the ship that became known as the Exodus for use in trying to transport Jews to Palestine, died Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN POLICY: 3 THEORIES
description: The Reagan Administration's management of Central American policy these days is in a state of partial limbo, transition or confusion, depending on the view of the official describing the situation.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was the last in a two-month-long series of birthday parties for Milton Goldman, who was born Aug. 12, 1914. Since Mr. Goldman, a theatrical agent, is known as a great partygoer, all his friends seem to have decided to give one for him. They started when he was in London in June and ended Tuesday - for this year, anyway - at the Park Avenue apartment of Jerry Silverman and Shannon Rodgers.

title: IRVINE SENSORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $42,400 for the quarter and $133,200 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: Columbia Savings Sells 2 C.D. Issues
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, Beverly Hills, Calif., is selling adjustable-rate and fixed-rate certificates of deposit due in 1989 through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: ST. LOUIS REPORTS 3 ATTACKS, AND NOBODY 'GETS INVOLVED'
description: In three incidents in less than three weeks, large groups of onlookers were reported to have stood by and done nothing as victims of crime pleaded for help on the streets of St. Louis.

title: Governor's Cup Race Is Set for Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow at noon, about 125 boats will set sail from the Battery Park City Esplanade for the 10th New York Governor's Cup Race, a 16-mile race to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and back. The vessels have been grouped according to size and handicap.

title: Coast Jet Aborts Landing
description: The pilot of a United Airlines jetliner aborted a landing Wednesday at the San Francisco International Airport to avoid a collision with another plane on the runway, a passenger said. ''We couldn't have been more than 100 feet off the ground when he aborted the landing,'' Chris Williams, an editor for the Prentice-Hall Publishing Company who was a passenger on the plane, said after the incident. Federal Aviation Administration officials in the airport tower said the plane, arriving from Los Angeles, aborted the first landing and the pilot gave no reason for the action.

title: New York Phone Asks For Delay in Rate Rise
description: The nationwide telephone strike has forced the New York Telephone Company to seek a delay of a scheduled $160 million rate increase, the State Public Service Commission said today.

title: U.S. SEES CHAD AS A PORTENT OF QADDAFI'S AMBITION
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they regarded the conflict in Chad as a major test of wills with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. They assert that Colonel Qaddafi had made no effort to disguise his plan of controlling Chad and of eventually unifying all African Moslems under the Libyan banner.

title: Vanderbilt Play Contained Rare Deal For 2 Top Teams
description: In head-to-head team play, it is rare to play successfully two bidding zones above the opposition. To bid and make a grand slam when the opponents are in game, or to bid and make a small slam when the opponents are in a part-score, is a source of considerable satisfaction and no little profit.

title: No Bonn Shipyard Aid
description: West Germany's Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, said today that his Government would give no financial aid now in a planned merger of three Bremen shipyards. In a radio interview, he said such money should go to help industries with prospects of growth rather than to save ''no longer competitive'' jobs.

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERVICES SCAN DRUG TEST ERROR
description: The Army and Navy are tracking down more than 3,500 personnel who may have been disciplined by mistake for drug abuse as a result of faulty testing procedures at two Navy laboratories in California.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $268,151 for the quarter and $275,851 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $98,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: New Computer By Convergent
description: Convergent Technologies Inc. will introduce a new briefcase-sized computer today that promises to heat up the already competitive market for portable computers. The battery-powered unit will be 8 1/2 inches by 11 inches by one inch thick and will sell for $900.

title: SALVADOR ARMY: ITS ADAPTABILITY IS A KEY TO WAR
description: The army, the key national institution in El Salvador for more than 50 years, is now the Reagan Administration's proxy in a struggle to contain a leftist insurgency. The chance of success depends greatly on that institution's potential for change.

title: COMBAT FOR SURGEONS
description: To the Editor:

title: DIET INSTITUTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHROEDER RESIGNS FUEL POST
description: Victor A. Schroeder resigned today as president of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation following attacks on his performance by fellow directors and critics in Congress. He has been the corporation's second-ranking official, earning $135,000 a year, since May 1981.

title: Tandy Net Up 20% in Quarter
description: The Tandy Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended June 30, rose 20 percent, to $74.5 million, or 71 cents a share, from $62 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Tour of Little Greece
description: The Queens community of Astoria, which has the largest number of Greek residents outside of Greece, will be explored on a tour tomorrow sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring.

title: Joyce Group Buys Arlington Park
description: The sale of Arlington Park, the Middle West's premier horse-racing track, by Gulf and Western Industries was formally announced today. Tom Rivera, the track's director of public relations, said the price was between $19 million and $21 million.

title: TINY CROWD AFTER BIG DISPUTE
description: The most talked about baseball game of the summer ended last night before only 1,245 fans at Yankee Stadium. Many of them said they had spent the afternoon tuned to the radio to follow the developments in two New York State courtrooms that allowed the suspended game to be completed.

title: SIBONEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Lendl Denies Defection Report
description: Ivan Lendl, the Czechoslovak tennis star, tonight denied a report that he was planning to defect to the United States.

title: Queens Museum Shows Art of 20th Century
description: ''Twentieth-Century Art From the Metropolitan Museum of Art: Selected Recent Aquisitions,'' an exhibition of 24 paintings and sculptures, is on view at the Queens Museum until Oct. 16.

title: THE GIANT AND ITS NEW PEANUT
description: The Peanut is coming, and the home computer industry is preparing for yet another shock.

title: DR. JOEL ROBBINS
description: Dr. Joel Robbins, chairman of the department of obstetrics at Nassau County Medical Center, died Monday after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: TRANSDUCER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
YANKS' ROBERTSON HURT IN CAR CRASH
description: Andre Robertson, the Yankee shortstop, suffered a series of injuries, and his companion, a 23-year- old University of Texas law student, was critically injured early yesterday morning when their car bounced off one retaining wall, smashed into another and flipped over on the West Side Highway at 72d Street.

title: COMPUTER INVESTORS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WOMETCO IN TALKS ON SALE
description: Wometco Enterprises Inc. of Miami, a target of takeover rumors since the company's founder died in January, said today that it was holding talks with an unidentified potential buyer.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about social change in Mississippi gave the incorrect date of the upcoming anniversary march on Washington. The march will take place Aug. 27.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 19, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: LIFE ON AND OFF ICE AT 'DISNEY'S MAGIC KINGDOM'
description: On the ice, Bruno Jerry is every inch the pirate. He looks tall and muscular in his skimpy satin costume, flashing his sword and baring a skull and cross bones on his chest. But off the ice, Bruno Jerry is almost petite. He seems quieter and calmer, not at all like his persona when wearing skates.

title: JETS BEAT BENGALS IN OVERTIME, 20-17
description: Joe Klecko, returned to the defensive line and said he ''felt great,'' but Coach Joe Walton of the Jets was somber tonight after his team defeated the Cincinnati Bengals, 20-17, on an overtime field goal by Pat Leahy.

title: Garment Center Blast Kills Man and Burns 2
description: One man was killed and two others were seriously burned early yesterday in an explosion in a 10th-floor bathroom of a building in the garment district.

title: STATEMENT ON RUSSIAN YOUTH
description: Following is the text of a State Department statement on Andrei V. Berezhkov issued tonight at Dulles International Airport:

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: AUTODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BERKLINE CORP reports earnings for Year to July 2
WORLD FEDERAL GOVERNMENT TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: STRATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; MTV Cites Its Young Audience
description: MTV is becoming positively respectable. Music Television, home of new wave music and even newer wave commercials, is getting the kind of youthful audience that in recent years has been confined largely to radio and the video arcades. And this month it has been calling advertisers' attention to that fact, with a campaign - addressed to personal computer manufacturers, fast-food franchisers, foreign auto makers and other likely candidates - that asserts: ''Now's the time to face the Music.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; Bargaining Over Murder
description: Two murders for the price of one - that's what the courts seemed to allow Ivan Mendoza.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Rain Date for Ballet
description: The Bowyer and Bruggeman- American Ballet Comedie will demolish dance styles in a free performance - at 8:15 tonight in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park - that will include the Black Cockroach duet and a Spanish number, ''La Stampa de Feeta.'' Rain last night canceled the company's performance as part of Lincoln Center's 13th Out-of-Doors Festival, in progress through Aug. 29.

title: Kennedy Son Surrenders Alaskan Walrus Tusk
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 16-year- old son violated state law by taking a 24-inch walrus tusk from an island preserve that is home to thousands of walruses, officials said. The youth returned the tusk.

title: LOUGANIS IS FIRST IN 3-METER DIVING
description: For years, Greg Louganis of El Cajon, Calif., has been the world's best male diver. A year ago, he certified that position by winning both titles - the 3-meter springboard and 10-meter platform - in the world aquatic championships in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

title: WORLD FEDERAL GOVERNMENT TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Imperial Knife Chooses Successor to President
description: The Imperial Knife Associated Companies, a big privately held cutlery manufacturer, has named Martin F. Zorn president.

title: PHONE UNIONS EXPECT NO QUICK SETTLEMENT
description: Negotiators for the three unions in the nationwide telephone strike, responding to the latest proposals from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, were pessimistic today about prospects for a settlement in the next few days.

title: JAMESBURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $440,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $1,735,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ABORTION: A FORUM LEAST APPROPRIATE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: American States Insurance Co., Indianapolis, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lincoln National Corp., said it proposed to buy all the outstanding shares of American States Life Insurance Co.; American States Insurance currently owns 68.5 percent of American States Life.

title: FOR WEEKEND WARRIORS NEW PRIDE AND GROWTH
description: In 1979, having been expelled from high school and having lost his job as an assistant manager at the Fish 'n' Chips in Somerset, N.J., 19-year-old Howard Alford joined the National Guard.

title: ART: A SHOW OF SHAPES IN PAINTING AND DRAWING
description: ''THE SHAPES OF THINGS,'' at the 22 Wooster Gallery, 22 Wooster Street, is a group painting and drawing show that suggests how the shapes of faces, furniture, buildings - everything in the world around us - can be experienced and known through paint. There is a long tradition of this kind of patient exploration, which, at best, reveals something both about painting and seeing.

title: FRANK J. SCHAFFELD
description: Frank J. Schaffeld, vice president for service of the World Wide Volkswagen Corporation in Orangeburg, N.Y., died July 12 in a boating accident while on a fishing trip in Alaska. He was 67 years old and lived in Oradell, N.J.

title: DRUG ABUSE FOUND IN MEDICAL TRAINING
description: The problem of drug abuse in the medical professions was dramatically underlined yesterday with the first published national survey of drug use within a single specialty.

title: KEEL HEARING AUG. 20
description: On a fog-shrouded Rhode Island Sound, Liberty defeated Defender in the two races sailed today in the final trials to select the America's Cup defender, including a dramatic 1-second victory after a close duel over a 16-mile course. Defender, though, was flying a protest flag at the end of both races.

title: MICHAELS, J, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fighting Mad
description: Jim Harrington says that he's mad enough to fight, but the California State Athletic Commission says that he may not be fit enough. Harrington, an amateur boxer, says he is a victim of discrimination, but the state commission says it is keeping him from being victimized in the ring.

title: PUBLISHING: TRADE WITH THE RUSSSIANS
description: ONLY a handful of American publishers will be at the Moscow International Book Fair from Sept. 6 to 12. Many have chosen to boycott the fair as a way of expressing opposition to Soviet persecution of writers and artists, but there is actually little reason for trade-book publishers - that is, publishers of books sold to the public through bookstores - to attend.

title: Chicago Cleared by Jury On Park Allocations
description: A Federal jury found on Wednesday the Chicago Park District not guilty of racial discrimination in allocating park resources.

title: Required Reading; Handshake With Cal
description: Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of upstate New York, in remarks to the House before passage of a resolution designating Aug. 1-7 as the ''First Annual President Calvin Coolidge Week'':

title: 'ON THE JOB TRAINING' AT THE PENTAGON
description: Ronald S. Lauder is the first to concede that he did not win appointment as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense because of his expertise in military affairs.

title: AUCTIONS
description: COUNTRY auctions are different from big-city sales. True, the aims and the state and local regulations under which auctioneers must work are similar everywhere - whether the sale is at a prestigious New York gallery or in a small-town Grange hall, a converted barn or on the lawn beside a house that is being cleaned out.

title: LEVY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including special gains of $1,985,000 for the latest first quarter and $28,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: PRECISION FILM & VIDEO reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $28,000 for the quarter and $51,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $430,000 from tax benefits and an extraordinary gain of $5,752,000 from the sale of land. c-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: BRAZILIAN PIANIST ON EXPATRIATE ROAD TO STARDOM
description: SOMETIMES the only way a musician can develop artistic wings is to become an expatriate. That's what Tania Maria, the Brazilian-born jazz pianist and singer had to do. She had to leave a country that didn't care much about jazz for foreign cities that were more hospitable to a female musician with a stubbornly independent musical point of view.

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Theft of Time Clock
description: When a time clock was installed last May in the Health Department's electronic data-processing center, just punching it apparently wasn't enough for resentful employees, who had previously signed in and out.

title: TIME SHARING RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RESUMED GAME ENDS IN 5-4 YANKEE LOSS TO ROYALS
description: Twenty-five days, one upheld protest and two court decisions later, the Yankees and the Kansas City Royals completed a baseball game last night. The finish was anticlimactic.

title: ANDROPOV ISSUES A PROMISE ON ANTISATELLITE WEAPONS
description: Yuri V. Andropov proposed today that the Soviet Union and the United States agree to a complete ban on antisatellite weapons, and he pledged that the Soviet Union would not place any such weapons in space as long as other countries refrain from doing so.

title: Harold P. Seligson, 82; Founded Law Institute
description: Harold P. Seligson, a lawyer and founder of the Practising Law Institute in Manhattan, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Seaview on Fire Island.

title: I.M.F. Ponders Change
description: The International Monetary Fund is talking about modifying the amount countries may borrow, monetary sources said today. Countries may draw 450 percent of their quota over three years, but some members want this reduced because of the heavy demand for I.M.F. loans.

title: POVERTY'S BOTTOM LINE
description: The Administration, reacting to statistics showing that 15 percent of Americans live in poverty, again asserts that the poverty line does not take into account noncash benefits and thus is inaccurate. Even critics who believe poverty has gotten worse now seem to take this argument at face value. Many concede that the index could be improved by including benefits such as Medicaid, food stamps and public- housing subsidies. In isolation, this idea makes sense - but only in isolation.

title: Lebanese Prime Minister Decides Not to Resign
description: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan rescinded a threat to resign today and led a Cabinet meeting at President Amin Gemayel's palace.

title: SEAWAY MULTI-CORP LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $1,773,000. c-Includes a special gain of $28,000.

title: ABNORMALIZATION OF THE EAST BLOC
description: Fifteen years ago this week, on Aug. 20-21, Soviet tanks rolled into Czechoslovakia. The Warsaw Pact invasion was part of a pattern of military intervention in Central Europe that is unlikely to change in the foreseeable future.

title: S SUSHI SALUTE TO FIRST NEW IRT CAR
description: With sushi and Japanese beer as refreshments, New York's newest subway car was unveiled yesterday at a ceremony on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Poisoning Pot - and People
description: It would be astonishing to deter illegal parking by planting land mines in ''no parking'' zones. Yet what the Reagan Administration is doing to deter marijuana smoking is nearly as extreme. When Federal enforcers found pot in Georgia, they sprayed it with paraquat, an herbicide that can be lethal when inhaled.

title: No Joke in Zimbabwe
description: It took courage for Joshua Nkomo to return to Zimbabwe - and none whatever to jeer him for doing so. In reclaiming his seat in Parliament after five months of self-exile, Mr. Nkomo shamed his detractors.

title: THRILLS AND CHILLS FOR A SUMMER DAY
description: HOW'RE you gonna keep 'em back at the old amusement park after they've seen Disney World? Can the parks in our area possibly hold their own against Mickey, Minnie and Unca Donald? Well for one thing, Disney World is 1,098 miles away. You can't just hop in the family wagon with Rover and the kids and zip down to Orlando, Fla., for the afternoon. For another thing, Disney World, is, well, Disney World - and an amusement park can be all that and something more.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WHITE CHICKS' IN NYACK

title: VIOLENCE FEARED IN STRIKE-TORN MINING TOWN
description: Law-enforcement officers are preparing for possible renewed violence in this strike-torn mining town when a 10-day moratorium on production and hiring of nonunion workers at the mine and smelter of the Phelps Dodge Corporation expires at noon Friday.

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Shepp Sextet Plays
description: The tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp is leading a sextet tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South, near Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.. There is a $7.50 cover and a $5 minumum.

title: U.S. DESIGNATES SITE OF BLACKOUT A DISASTER AREA
description: The Federal Government yesterday designated the area of Manhattan affected by last week's blackout an ''economic injury disaster area'' and agreed to make low-interest loans available to businesses badly hurt by the three-day power failure.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I guess I can express my determination best in two words: Play ball.'' - Justice Joseph P. Sullivan. (A15:5.)

title: THERE IS JUST ONE WAY TO CUT MEDICARE COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Plenty of Room at Fort Wadsworth
description: Though once vital to New York City's coastal defense, Fort Wadsworth today serves mainly to house the Navy Resale Service Department. But the old fort, on a picturesque piece of Staten Island, has been in the news because of a lawsuit brought by supporters of Gateway National Park. They want the fort included in the park, an idea approved by Congress but resisted by the Interior Department.

title: SOVIET TEEN-AGE BOY FLIES HOME AFTER HE DISAVOWS BITTER LETTERS
description: A Soviet diplomat's 16-year-old son, who touched off an international incident last week by disappearing from his home near here, left the United States for Moscow tonight with his parents, saying, ''I wanted to go home and not stay here.''

title: GRAND CANYON TOURIST PLANE CRASHES IN STORM, KILLING 10
description: A sightseeing airplane dodging thunderstorms on a flight to the Grand Canyon slammed into the face of a mountain overlooking the chasm, killing all 10 people aboard, the authorities said today.

title: THE PLATINUM ROLLER COASTER
description: After a three-year period of rapidly fluctuating prices spurred by inflation, most of the world's metals markets have settled back into something like their normal cycles of ups and downs. But not platinum.

title: A CONDOMINIUM OF GLASS TO BE ERECTED NEAR U.N.
description: For nearly three decades the Albanese brothers, Anthony and Vincent, have been building apartment buildings, town houses and office buildings throughout New York City and Long Island.

title: NEW 'KING AND I' PRINT WITH VIVID OLD COLORS
description: A newly struck Cinemascope print of the 1956 movie version of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''The King and I,'' with the original color restored, is one of the highlights of this weekend's summer film revivals.

title: DISPOSABLE INCOME SOARS
description: The personal income of Americans rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July, but their disposable income jumped by more than twice that, in part because of the July 1 tax cut, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DICKEY-JOHN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $17,989 for the quarter and $1,455,009 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $57,060 for the quarter and $676,922 for the year.

title: AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WORLD FEDERAL GOVERNMENT TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Debit Card System
description: Bank of America and four other West Coast banks said they had agreed to form a shared point-of-sale system to be called Interlink Network.

title: TROUBLES PLAGUE CONVENTION HALL
description: The head of the New York State Urban Development Corporation said yesterday that he had a new ''reason for concern'' about a key structural element that has already caused months of delay in the construction of New York City's Convention Center.

title: 6 CHINESE HIJACKERS RECEIVE LIGHT PRISON TERMS IN SEOUL
description: Six Chinese who hijacked a Shanghai-bound domestic airliner to South Korea in May were sentenced today to prison terms of four to six years by a criminal court judge in Seoul.

title: Plea to Forgive Chinese Debt
description: The Reagan Administration today asked a Federal court to set aside a judgment ordering China to pay more than $40 million for defaulting on a loan to build a railroad from Peking to Canton.

title: Start of Transition At Florida National
description: George C. Whitner, the president and chief executive of the Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., was named vice chairman yesterday, but he disclosed plans to retire by Jan. 1, 1985.

title: Jersey Banks
description: Three New Jersey bank holding companies announced the formation of a joint export holding company.

title: A long line forms in Chinatown
description: ONE reliable clue to good food in Chinatown is the length of the line outside a restaurant at mealtimes. At Siu Lam Kung, a trim, modern year-old restaurant on Elizabeth Street, between Canal and Bayard, the lines, primarily of Chinese customers, form every night from 7 to 9:30. The seven superb meals we had there make this phenomenon understandable.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Estimate Board Votes Study Of a New Phone Area Code
description: The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to study a proposal by the telephone company to assign a separate area code to Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: HARVESTER, POSTING LOSS, RESHUFFLES
description: The International Harvester Company, which today reported a quarterly loss of $131 million, announced the third realignment of its top management in 16 months.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WESTERN ENERGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Bucs Sign McCall
description: Faced with the possible loss of Jimmie Giles if contract negotiations with him should fail, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers bought some insurance at tight end by obtaining Reese McCall, who had been having contract problems with the Baltimore Colts after being a starter for most of his five seasons before 1982. McCall had not reported to Baltimore's training camp.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORATOMIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A JUDGE ENDS THE AGONY
description: Forests of trees were felled to produce the yellow pads of the lawyers, veins of coal were depleted to light the offices of baseball executives plotting late into the night, and underground seas of fossil fuel were diminished to transport the Kansas City Royals, the New York Yankees, a herd of journalists and a few fans back into Yankee Stadium last evening for a short and peaceful coda to the fabled pine-tar incident.

title: J. Aron & Co.  Reduces Staff
description: J. Aron & Company, the commodity subsidiary of Goldman, Sachs & Company, has made staff reductions that include the layoff of four vice presidents, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: BASEBALL

title: WAGNERIAN LOG CABINS
description: In America, the log cabin that sheltered early settlers eventually became a symbol of their hard work, sound values and modest circumstances. But in turn-of-the-century Finland, the architect Lars Sonck took the simple Scandinavian log cabin and elevated it into a symbol of Finnish nationalism: Majestically sited, mounted on heroic stone podiums and surmounted by expressive, oversize roofs, these were Wagnerian buildings that could have housed the Valkyries.

title: Derelicts Are Targets In Coast Cleanup Plan
description: A City Councilman thinks Skid Row bums should be shipped out of town to ''grow vegetables'' on a farm during the 1984 Olympics, but skeptics said today that the plan was unworkable and the police said it was probably illegal.

title: SCREEN: 'EASY MONEY'
description: ''EASY MONEY'' is strictly for the easy laughers, or at least for those who find Rodney Dangerfield an irresistible card. Mr. Dangerfield has some funny moments here, but he also has a screen presence that's decidedly strange. He won't stand still, being given to constant jerking motions, and neither will he refrain from eye rolling and mugging at the slightest opportunity. Almost never, during the course of a very long 95 minutes, do these tics have anything to do with what is ostensibly going on.

title: COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $199,500 for the quarter and $516,500 for the 6 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $311,499 for the quarter and $375,048 for the 6 months.

title: George Chacharis, Ex-Mayor Of Gary Who Was Jailed, Dies
description: George Chacharis, who was Mayor of Gary for four years and was sentenced to prison in a kickback scandal, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After minority interest losses of $21,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the year. c-After minority interest losses of $35,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the year.

title: BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 19, 1983.

title: WILLIAM B. GOULD 3D
description: William Benjamin Gould 3d, an electrical engineer who had principal responsibility for installing early-warning radar on the West Coast in World War II, died of cancer Monday at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Elberon, N.J.

title: THE GOVERNMENT AS A FOR-PROFIT LENDER
description: To the Editor:

title: WEINBERGER TO VISIT 3 LATIN NATIONS NEXT MONTH
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he would visit Central America soon, and he defended the dispatch of Awacs radar planes to help Chad.

title: I.B.M. Japan
description: I.B.M. Japan Ltd. said it had acquired 35 percent of the outstanding shares of the Japan Business Computer Company. Terms were not disclosed. Through the tie-up, I.B.M. Japan, a unit of the United States-based International Business Machines Corporation, plans to develop small computers using Japan Business Computer's technical knowledge.

title: GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
James Warwick Is Dead at 89; Playwright and Screen Writer
description: James Warwick, a Hollywood writer and a playwright whose 1935 melodrama, ''Blind Alley,'' was a success on the Broadway stage, died on Monday at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Role Is Proposed For Northern Ireland
description: Representatives of 150 Irish-American organizations have called for the designation of a special United States envoy to try to mediate the differences between the British and those seeking the reunification of Ireland.

title: BANKS RESCHEDULE DEBT DUE FROM POLAND IN '83
description: Western bankers and Polish officials agreed today to reschedule $2.6 billion in Polish debts that are due in 1983. Of the $2.6 billion, $1.5 billion represents principal and $1.1 billion represents interest.

title: Market Place; Energy Issues In a Comeback
description: FOR a brief period in August 1982, shares of the

title: Bank Asks Debt Payoff
description: Chemical Bank of New York demanded immediate payment today of the entire $2.25 billion debt for two terminated Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear power plants.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRISTOPHER TURKEL
description: Christopher Turkel, director of press and information for the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, died of cancer Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Money Fund Assets Grow
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose for the second consecutive week in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Third-degree assault charges against Angel Cordero Jr. , filed by a woman who said he threw a bat and a glove at her during a softball game, were adjourned yesterday for six months by a city judge in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The jockey's lawyer, Arthur N. Spellman, said that the ruling meant that if Cordero stayed out of trouble for six months, the charges would be dismissed. . . . The Rangers have signed Nick Fotiu, a left wing, to a new contract. Fotiu, a native of Staten Island and an eight-year veteran, was entering the option year of his contract. . . . Larry Bird, who could become a free agent at the end of the next National Basketball Association season, was represented at talks with the Boston Celtics by his agent, Bob Woolf. It was the first talks in six weeks because the team was in the process of being sold.

title: DR. PAUL EDWARD WARD
description: Dr. Paul Edward Ward, associate superintendent of schools for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died Monday at St. John's Hospital in Yonkers after a brief illness.

title: WORDS AND MEANINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICA'S COSTLY TRADE BARRIERS
description: It is popular to decry other nations' trade policies, particularly ''unfair'' subsidies that enable these nations' declining industries to ''dump'' cheap products into the American market. What Americans too often fail to recognize is the high cost - which may exceed $70 billion this year - of our own Government's policies to protect various industries from foreign competition. This largely hidden cost takes the form of higher prices for consumer goods.

title: Court Seeks Data About DeLorean
description: A judge has ordered the Central Intelligence Agency and other Government organizations to hand over any documents they have on John Z. DeLorean, the car maker, for the court's private inspection, sources at the court said.

title: MINORITY CONCERN TO BUY 2 CITY BUILDINGS ON PARK
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it would sell two vacant city-owned buildings that border Central Park on 110th Street to a minority development group. The group, officials said, will turn them into 60 condominium apartments that will cost from $68,800 to $112,584.

title: Impasse in Phoenix
description: The owner of the Arizona Wranglers said that a decision would be made within the next few days on whether he would sell the United States Football League club to a Phoenix heart surgeon.

title: DAMAGE EXTENSIVE IN GALVESTON
description: Hurricane Alicia sent waves and flotsam cascading over Galveston's 15-foot sea wall all night, and this morning city residents emerged to find windows broken, signs toppled and roofs vanished.

title: BROADWAY
description: A PRODIGAL New York actor is returning to the stage. Dustin Hoffman, who honed his acting skills in little Off Broadway theaters before becoming a Hollywood star, will open on Broadway this winter in Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman.'' Playing the role of Willy Loman, the all-American loser, Mr. Hoffman will be making his first New York stage appearance since ''Jimmy Shine,'' which opened on Broadway in 1968. ''Death of a Salesman'' will be directed by Michael Rudman, an American-born director who staged the play at the National Theater in London, and it will be produced by Robert Whitehead and Roger L. Stevens.

title: IT'S WRONG TO DEPORT SALVADORANS RIGHT NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rich Hearing
description: Government prosecutors have postponed from Monday until Sept. 19 a special court hearing in the case of Marc Rich & Company A.G., the commodity trading firm under investigation for possible tax evasion that has been resisting prosecutors' requests for subpoenaed documents. The postponement is apparently aimed at giving Marc Rich additional time to produce the subpoenaed documents without forcing the Government to take further action against the firm. It would also give the Governments of the United States and Switzerland time to work out an agreement under which the Swiss would hand over Marc Rich papers they seized from the firm's Zug, Switzerland, headquarters.

title: Fairs and Festivals This Weekend
description: Chinatown Bazaar, Bayard Street, between Mulberry and Mott Streets (indoors at Chinatown Planning Council, sponsoring organization, in case of rain). Tomorrow, 9:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. Games and food

title: TAXES HELD LESS PROGESSIVE THAN LAW IMPLIES
description: A Census Bureau report issued today said the nation's tax system did less to equalize the distribution of income than the tax code would indicate.

title: In the Money
description: During the recent world track and field championships in Helsinki, Finland, Bob Bright, the executive director of America's Marathon in Chicago, distributed a 4-by-6-inch card to athletes and reporters listing the prize money for the Oct. 16 race.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $30 million. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $24,364,000 for the quarter and $65,040,000 for the 9 months. d-After an unusual charge of $69 million relating to certain restructuring costs, an unusual charge of $30 million from litigation, a loss of $6 million from discontinued operations and extraordinary income of $54,136,000.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mets-Dodgers Postponed
description: The Mets' game against the Dodgers tonight was postponed after a 2-hour-55-minute rain delay. It was only the Dodgers' 11th rainout in Los Angeles since the team moved to Dodger Stadium in 1962 and only the 2d rainout since Sept. 1978.

title: TECFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $29,900. c-Net loss.

title: Brazil Debt Talks
description: Brazil's Planning Minister, Antonio Delfim Netto, arrived here to discuss possibly rescheduling the country's $14.3 billion debt to Western governments, banking sources said today. He is not expected to hold talks here on Brazil's $59.3 billion in commercial debts.

title: GALVESTON REDIDENTS CLEAN UP AFTER A COSTLY VISITOR
description: R. SHIPP

title: Sports of The Time; The Long Race Toward Equality
description: The discrimination against women in running is older than the Modern Olympics. As early as the 12th century, the memoirs of an Arab-Syrian warrior recount a women's race in Tiberias during the era of the Frankish crusaders.

title: NBC PUTS NEW BITE IN PROMOTIONS FOR FALL SHOWS
description: In bold letters, the legend on the television screen reads: ''A warning to the people of Dallas.'' The camera cuts to J. R. Ewing, the villain of the CBS hit ''Dallas,'' floating in a swimming pool. ''Mama,'' he says into his portable telephone, ''it looks like we got Friday night wrapped up this year.''

title: WHAT THIS COUNTRY NEEDS IS A MELTDOWN
description: What's happening in the nuclear industry is being called a disaster. Default and bankruptcy in the Pacific Northwest. Default and bankruptcy perhaps looming for Seabrook, in New England. Unbuilt plants all over

title: SWINDLER WALK FINE LINE AT PARKING BUREAU
description: It was taking as long as a day for a motorist to make his way through the lines at the New York Parking Violations Bureau. For those who wanted to pay parking fines so they could register their cars, the bureau office was a confusing and frustrating place.

title: HOUSTON BEGINS DRIVE TO RESTORE POWER AND WATER AFTER HURRICANE
description: Brought to its knees by the first hurricane to strike directly at the downtown of a major American city in more than a decade, the city of Houston struggled today to regain its footing.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST OFF 6.8 MILLION
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 4.1 percent, or 6.8 million shares, in the month ended Aug. 15, to 159.4 million shares.

title: Louisiana Land
description: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, which was engaged in a bitter proxy fight earlier this year, said it had acquired from the Second Crescent Investment Company and the American Financial Corporation all shares of Louisiana Land held by each of them, totaling 6,592,500 shares. The company said the aggregate price paid for the shares was $98.9 million in cash and a like principal amount of eight-year notes of Louisiana Land.

title: Books of The Times Domesticated Violence
description: CAL. By Bernard MacLaverty. 170 pages. George Braziller. $12.95. How strange it is to read about a religious war in an English-speaking country in our time. Yet that's essentially what Bernard MacLaverty's ''Cal'' is about - the undeclared war between Irish Catholics and Protestants in Ulster.

title: Strange Takes One-Stroke Lead
description: Curtis Strange shot a nine-under- par 62 today to take the lead in the second round of the Sammy Davis Jr.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Appeal on Berry Denied
description: An appeal by St. John's University seeking the eligibility of Walter Berry, the basketball player, was denied today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council. In a secret vote taken Thursday and announced today, the Council's Division I steering committee determined that Berry, who was never graduated from Benjamin Franklin High School in Manhattan when he left in June 1982, would remain ineligible because he did not earn a high school equivalency diploma by taking the tests of General Educational Development.

title: COUPLE CAPTURED IN FLORIDA ARE RETURNED TO TENNESSEE
description: A Tennessee prison fugitive and the lawyer accused of helping him escape four and and a half months ago were locked in a Tennessee jail today as agents described their life as fugitives as ''bouncing around'' Florida motels using names taken from tombstones.

title: ZONING: AN OLD RULE WITH A NEW PURPOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: SMITH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $933,000 for the quarter and $3,831,000 for the 9 months. c-Comparable year-ago results aren't available because the company was in the development stage until November 1982 and hadn't begun its principal operations.

title: 107 Immigrants Arrested As Illegal in Jersey Raid
description: The Immigration and Nationalization Service has arrested 107 suspected illegal aliens and is holding them in custody awaiting deportation hearings as a result of a raid on a South Plainfield handbag factory, authorities reported today.

title: Blind Man Sails Pacific To Make Port in Hawaii
description: Hank Dekker sailed into Honolulu on schedule today, becoming the first blind person to successfully sail alone from San Francisco to Hawaii. Mr. Dekker and his 25-foot sloop Dark Star were escorted into the Ala Wai Yacht Harbor just before 3 P.M. to a welcome of leis and music and cold beer. He had been joined by fans from the Waikiki Yacht Club for the last mile of the journey that began July 27. Mr. Dekker used Braille charts, a Braille compass, a ''talking'' clock and a navigational system that reads his position aloud.

title: Released from Contract
description: Dave Cowens , on the disabled list for nearly a month last season because of a torn knee tendon, has been granted his request to be released from the final year of his two-year contract with the Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association. However, the Bucks hope that the former star of the Boston Celtics will rejoin them when he is ready to play again.

title: Jersey Eases Its Restrictions On Market Near a Dioxin Site
description: The New Jersey Health Department announced today that the Newark Farmers Market would be permitted to display food outdoors for the first time since dioxin contamination was discovered more than two months ago at a former Diamond Alkali plant nearby.

title: Hot Air on a Hot Day
description: Neighbors on West 77th Street hadn't seen anything like it since Thanksgiving, when the giant parade balloons are inflated on their block between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

title: Quintuplets Are Born To New Jersey Woman
description: A 27-year-old woman expecting quadruplets has given birth to quintuplets at Jersey Shore Medical Center, hospital officials said.

title: YELLOW CAR SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SCOUTING;Vassallo on Deck
description: Though other athletes might have won more medals in the 1979 Pan American Games in San Juan, Puerto Rico, there was no greater hero than Jesse Vassallo. The Puerto Rican native, swimming for the United States, won two gold medals and one silver, and every time he swam, hundreds of relatives and friends, all wearing similar T-shirts, cheered him on.

title: An Angry Client in Louisiana Kills His Lawyer and Himself
description: Nolan Edwards, a lawyer who is a brother of former Gov. Edwin Edwards, was shot to death Thursday by a disgruntled client who then killed himself, the police said today.

title: RAIDERS SAID TO TAP 2 COMPANY COMPUTERS
description: The same group suspected of intruding into a computer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York is also being investigated by Federal authorities in connection with numerous unauthorized entries of computers operated by at least two companies, according to officials of those companies and a Federal affidavit.

title: JOHN SVAHN PICKED FOR DOMESTIC POST
description: President Reagan today appointed John A. Svahn, an Administration executive who now holds two Federal post, to be his new assistant for domestic policy development.

title: Portugal Seeks to Speed Talks on Market Entry
description: Prime Minister Mario Soares of Portugal today asked the Greek Government, the current head of the European Economic Community, to help speed up talks over the entry of Spain and Portugal to the 10-nation organizaton.

title: CONTINENTAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $7,183,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $2,452,000 on pre-petitioned settlements after reorganization.

title: 70 REPORTED KILLED AFTER NIGERIAN STATE ELECTIONS
description: At least 70 people have died in outbreaks of violence after last weekend's elections for state governors.

title: JETS LOSE 2 PLAYERS FOR SEASON
description: Kurt Sohn, hobbling with his right knee in a cast, assured well-wishers, ''I'll be back.'' Johnny (Lam) Jones supported himself on a pair of crutches. Mickey Shuler's fingers were immobilized. Jim Luscinski winced as he stared straight ahead, a prisoner of his neck brace.

title: LEGISLATURE TO RECONVENE IN ALBANY SEPT. 15
description: The State Legislature will reconvene Sept. 15 to consider minor changes in legislative and Congressional district lines and to try to identify spending projects for the proposed $1.25 billion public works bond issue, legislative leaders said today.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Letter: On I.M.F. Loans Stretch Time for Foreign Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Over 1,300 Pounds of Cocaine Seized Aboard Ship in Tampa
description: Drug enforcement agents reported finding 1,391 pounds of cocaine in a shipload of fungicide from South America in what was called the second-largest seizure of the drug in this country.

title: FEDERATED DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: Cal Ramsey , a former basketball star at New York University, will return there as an assistant coach of the men's varsity team. . . . Wim Rijsbergen will be lost to the Cosmos for 10 days after arthroscopic surgery on his knee. . . . The owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, Leonard Tose , has dropped a countersuit he filed against a group of investors who charged him with reneging on a promise to sell the football club. . . . Dave Casper , a tight end for the Houston Oilers, was arrested in San Angelo, Tex., and charged with driving while intoxicated. . . . The Boston Bruins have signed another free agent to their defensive corps, adding the veteran Jim Schoenfeld to the roster on a one-year contract. On Monday, the team signed a free-agent defenseman, Guy Lapointe .

title: 25,000 IN ARGENTINA PROTEST MILITARY'S PLAN FOR AMNESTY
description: More than 25,000 Argentines marched here today to protest a proposed amnesty that would protect the military against prosecution for the disappearances, deaths and tortures that occurred in the antiterrorist campaign in the 1970's.

title: Pine-Tar Game Gets a Last Look
description: The pine-tar game might finally be over, but there could be some unfinished business. According to a source close to Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner was not particularly pleased with the Yankees' reaction to Lee MacPhail's ruling and their public comments and stance in trying to resist finishing the game Thursday against Kansas City.

title: WELCOME AND REJECTION FOR THE CITY'S HOMELESS
description: When the city opened two new shelters for the homeless this week, the welcome each shelter received from neighbors was as different as the neighborhoods they moved into.

title: Andy and the Fig Leaf
description: The Reagan Administration is not famous for its sensitivity concerning the Russians. We have it on Highest Authority, for example, that the Soviet Union is an ''evil empire.''

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN QUARTET
description: The American String Quartet's performance at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday night, in conjunction with the oboist Heinz Holliger and the flutist Aur ele Nicolet, was a worthy occasion, but it was hardly Mostly Mozart.

title: PURCELL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Harness Heritage
description: Harness racing has always been a family affair, and the record books are filled with the exploits of the Dancers, the Filions, the Gilmours and the Simpsons. Now the Merrimans are making their impact on the sport.

title: Paramax Contract
description: Paramax Electronics Inc., a Sperry Inc. unit, said it had received a $1.25 billion (Canadian) subcontract for work on Canada's patrol frigate project from the Saint John Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, the contractor for the $3 billion, six-ship project. Paramax said it intends to ''develop into a leading high-technology company,'' adding that the frigate subcontract is a ''major first step toward that goal.'' The first frigate is to be delivered in 1988, with the rest to be completed by 1992.

title: Statue of Liberty Posters
description: Early posters of the Statue of Liberty, some never before on display, are on view through October in a show called ''The Popular Imagination: Statue of Liberty in Posters, 1883-1983,'' at the American Museum of Immigration at the Statue of Liberty on Liberty Island.

title: THE G. & W. METAMORPHOSIS
description: From his 42d-floor office on 61st Street, Martin S. Davis, head of Gulf and Western Industries, has a clear view of upper Manhattan. From that vantage point, Central Park seems to neatly divide the crowded island into three distinct pieces.

title: Hands Off Dupree
description: Chet Simmons , the commissioner of the United States Football League, has assured University of Oklahoma officials that the league has no plans to recruit its star sophomore tailback, Marcus Dupree . Simmons wrote a letter in response to concerns expressed by the Sooner coach, Barry Switzer , that the U.S.F.L. would try to sign Dupree as it had signed Herschel Walker of Georgia. . . .Two former Pro Bowl selections, Rod Perry , an eight-year cornerback with the Los Angeles Rams, and David Hill , a seven-year tight end with the Detroit Lions, have been swapped. The Lions also received an undisclosed future draft choice in the deal, which Coach John Robinson of the Rams said gave him the opportunity of a two tight-end offense, with Mike Barber as the other one.

title: 'Smear' Seen On I.M.F. Bill
description: Democrats in the House of Representatives told President Reagan today that a ''smear campaign'' by a Republican committee might jeopardize his chances for gaining final approval of increased support for the International Monetary Fund.

title: JAEGER OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dow Ahead by 1.73; Trading Is Slower
description: Stock prices ended with minor changes yesterday in much slower trading as many investors remained on the sidelines awaiting the latest Federal Reserve report on the nation's money supply.

title:
PATENTS;
Columbia Stresses Genetic Patent's Value
description: The commercial importance of the patent on genetic engineering announced last Monday by Columbia University has been emphasized by a university spokesman. Nonexclusive licenses are available under patent 4,399,216, granted to Dr. Richard Axel and two co-inventors.

title: BLUEPRINT FOR TACKLING LATIN NATIONS' DEBTS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
New Fuel Pellets For Commercial Use
description: A Brooklyn man has invented a process for the production of fuel pellets to be burned in commercial plants. Charles J. Reilly was granted patent 4,398,917 this week for a method of using enzymes to break down wood, municipal waste and other materials so they will flow more easily into the pelleting equipment.

title: HGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Figure represents both operating loss and net loss.

title: PARTIES IN A MANSION: ELEGANCE FOR RENT
description: When 21-year-old Ann Clancy thinks back upon the setting she chose for her wedding ceremony, she remembers it as suffused with a special magic.

title: SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SATURDAY, AUGUST 20, 1983
description: The Economy

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results reflect a pretax charge of $5.7 million for the quarter and 9 months for a loss on the reacquisition of property. Year-ago revenues have been restated.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $181,000 from discontinued operations. Qtr to June 30 1983 1982 Sales 2,774,000 3,550,000 Net inc 337,000 b264,000 Share earns .32 .26 6mo sales 6,310,000 6,321,000 Net inc 584,000 b424,000 Share earns .56 .42 b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $49,000 for the quarter and $45,000 for the 6 months.

title: Parcells Deliberates on Roster;  4 Key Roles Unsettled
description: Decisions, decisions, decisions.

title: British Steel Negotiations
description: MacGregor will act for the British Steel Corporation in negotiations with the United States Steel Corporation in September, even though he is stepping down as British Steel's chairman Aug. 31. Mr. MacGregor and David Roderick, the chairman of U.S. Steel, have spent several months attempting to piece together a plan that would send slab steel from the modern but money-losing British Steel plant at Ravenscraig, Scotland, to be finished into steel products at U.S. Steel's Fairless Works near Philadelphia. The agreement would allow both companies to close part of their facilities.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SOME EXPERTS FAULT HOUSTON CODE FOR GLASS BUILDINGS
description: The glass damage in Houston caused by Hurricane Alicia on Thursday, incurred largely by high-rise, glass- sheathed office buildings erected in the last 10 years, was ''rather extensive and could have been a lot worse,'' said Horace Cude, deputy building official for the City of Houston.

title: GLOOM AT CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera labor dispute, which for a while seemed rather well-mannered, has turned into a bitter stalemate, with little hope of settlement for at least another month. Earlier this week, the company answered the musicians' six-week-long strike with a de facto lockout, canceling all performances until Sept. 15. How did things reach this sorry pass, and what are the hopes for a settlement?

title: SINGER STORY FILMED CAFETERIA STYLE
description: It was a hot, brightly lit summer day of 1966 early last week at midnight on a hot, darkly dank summer night of 1983 in Dubrow's Cafeteria, and the intrusion of a long-gone New York dog-day afternoon into the muggy night radiated an eerie sensation, not unlike those juxtapositions of fantasy you find in a story by Isaac Bashevis Singer.

title: YANKEES POUND ANGELS
description: The subject matter at Yankee Stadium for the past month had been pine tar.

title: ON A WORLDWIDE ALERT FOR PROBLEMS ON RISE
description: Lester R. Brown, the 49-year-old president of Worldwatch Institute, is not by nature a pessimist. But he has taken a kind of grim satisfaction from some of the newspaper headlines that have resulted from his work, including these:

title: Van Stolen From Family Of Boy Facing Surgery
description: The van of a Virginia couple who brought their teen-age son to Boston for surgery was stolen and vandalized while they were waiting for the operation.

title: Stay of Execution Denied Georgia Killer
description: Describing John Eldon Smith's crime as ''an affront to humanity,'' a Federal district judge today refused to halt the convicted murderer's execution, set for Thursday.

title: AN OLD NICARAGUAN TOWN ADJUSTS TO A REVOLUTION
description: When the volcano called Black Mountain erupted eight years ago, spewing ash over roofs of this city and covering the cotton bolls with gray dust, the people of Leon, as they often do when they are afraid, prayed.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. BRIEF BACKS MEMPHIS ON BALCK LAYOFFS
description: The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that the Fire Department in Memphis should be allowed to dismiss and demote black employees with less seniority than white employees, even though the blacks had been hired under a court order in settlement of a race discrimination case.

title: AMERICAN PLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $143,000 for the quarter and $90,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect adjustments to reserves for losses and loss adjustment expenses, bad debts and reinsurance, together with related income tax effects.

title: U.S. DONATING FOOD TO HURRICANE VICTIMS
description: The Department of Agriculture has donated 48,000 pounds of food for an estimated 20,000 victims of Hurricane Alicia along the Texas Gulf Coast, officials said today.

title: PRIORITIES REVISED IN CITY'S HOSPITALS
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation has approved a series of broad changes designed to restore basic clinic and emergency-room care as the major priority in municipal hospitals, city officials said yesterday.

title: DATATRAK reports earnings for Year to May 31
SATURDAY, AUGUST 20, 1983
description: International

title: The Beach Barge
description: From the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, it looks like a giant sandbox. Up close, it's a barge loaded with 200 tons of sand from Port Washington, L.I. Pine trees, flowers, umbrellas and bathing beauties embellished it yesterday, but no one's sure how long the beach barge, complete with a bar, will last.

title: 2 JESSE JACKSON GROUPS MISUSED $1.7 MILLION, U.S. AUDITORS SAY
description: Federal auditors contended today that Operation PUSH and a subsidiary misused more than $1.7 million in Government grants and contracts and suggested that the organization, headed by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, return the money.

title: WEAK CASE FOR CURBING BANKRUPTCY RELIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE CITY'S CASUALTIES OF CAPITALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Honeycutt to Dodgers
description: Rick Honeycutt , one of the American League's leading pitchers this season, moved to the National League yesterday when the Texas Rangers traded him to the Los Angeles Dodgers. In return for the 29-year-old left- hander, the Rangers received Dave Stewart , a right-handed pitcher, and a player to be named, believed to be Ricky Wright , a minor league pitcher.

title: Bridge: Club Just for Smokers Rises
description: Smoking has become a burning issue in club and tournament play in recent years. The Washington Bridge League recently took an extreme step by barring all smoking unless there are enough smokers to form a separate section of play.

title: I.M.F. Delay In Venezuela
description: The leader of an International Monetary Fund mission to Venezuela put off his scheduled talks with Government officials on an austerity program for the country, financial sources said today.

title: GIFTS THAT COME TO DINNER
description: Beware of guests bearing gifts is a lesson learned the hard way by almost anyone who has been a host or hostess. Despite repeated advice from etiquette experts, who say that such gifts are not necessary, some people are uncomfortable unless they are bearing flowers, cakes, candy or wine when they go to someone's home for dinner.

title:
PATENTS;
2 Systems for Handling Spent Nuclear Fuel
description: A method for reprocessing and separating spent nuclear fuel has been invented for the Department of Energy at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. The inventors are Oscar H. Krikorian, John Z. Grens and William H. Parrish Sr., staff members.

title: FOR A SOVIET ENVOY AND SON, 'WHAT A WEEK' FINALLY ENDS
description: After the Berezhkovs arrived in Moscow, the Government issued a protest over the incident. Page 3.

title: Court Refuses to CurbParaquat in Kentucky
description: While Federal drug agents sprayed paraquat on marijuana patches today in the rugged hills of southeastern Kentucky, a judge refused to grant a temporary order against further use of the weed-killer but delayed his ruling on a permanent injunction.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HEAD OF OPERA STUDY NAMED
description: Msgr. James A. Healy, chairman of the New York State Mediation Board, announced yesterday the appointment of James J. McFadden as secretary of a board of inquiry to examine the New York City Opera labor dispute and to make recommendations for its resolution.

title: First Boston Client Shifts
description: The United States League of Savings Institutions said yesterday that it had moved $750 million from the management of the First Boston Corporation after objecting to the investment bank's involvement with a program called Shelternet that publicizes the availability and price of mortgage money around the country.

title: FRANCE IS SENDING A COMABT GENERAL FOR DUTY IN CHAD
description: In a sign of its deepening military involvement in Chad, France announced today that it had appointed a brigadier general with experience in colonial wars and African trouble spots to command its troops in Chad.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BLUEPRINT FOR TACKLING LATIN NATIONS' DEBTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LET THE PEOPLE BENEFIT FROM CHEAPER POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SOUND OF BALONEY
description: More and more, Americans want to hear the right sounds. Smart politicians have already sensed this change in public appetite. No longer do they tell apprentice politicians, ''If you want to get elected, tell people what they want to hear.'' Now they say, ''Make the sounds that make people happy.''

title: Bandits Rob Cannes Cartier
description: Two armed men stole jewelry valued at $3.75 million from a Cartier store in this seaside resort today, the police said.

title: China-U.S. Accord
description: The United States and China, formally ending a trade dispute, signed an agreement today that limits the growth of Chinese textile shipments to the American market to 3.5 percent annually over five years.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Year to May 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $12,500,000 from the disposal of Domestic Flour Mills.

title: Officer Is Suspended For Coney I. Incident
description: A 25-year-old rookie police officer was suspended without pay yesterday in connection with an incident in which a group of off-duty officers roughed up patrons at a Coney Island amusement area and menaced others with a revolver, the Police Department said.

title: MASSACHUSETTS LEGISLATURE DELAYS BOSTON ELECTION
description: The Legislature has ended three weeks of uncertainty over Boston's mayoral election by moving back the dates for the primary and general election.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $927,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $43,006 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $2,856,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. BARS NEW SALVADOR ADVISERS
description: President Reagan has decided not to send more United States military advisers to El Salvador, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Trials Put Off
description: The trials to select the defender and the challenger for the America's Cup were postponed today because of no wind and heavy fog on Rhode Island Sound.

title: Advice From the Top
description: The United States-Japan Foundation, founded in 1981 and based in Rockefeller Center, has rounded out a foursome of former heads of government to be honorary advisers in its grant-making.

title: Schroeder Inquiry Ends
description: The Justice Department dropped its investigation into accusations of wrongdoing by Victor A. Schroeder, the president of the Government's Synthetic Fuels Corporation, today - a day after he resigned from the $135,000-a-year job.

title: PRESSURE IS GROWING IN BRAZIL TO PUT OFF PAYING FOREIGN DEBT
description: The Brazilian Government is coming under pressure from increasingly diverse elements of the nation to declare a moratorium on the repayment of its $90 billion of foreign debt.

title: Singapore Air Loan Aid Set
description: The United States Export-Import Bank said today that it was prepared to provide credits and loan guarantees totaling almost $680 million to allow Singapore Airlines to buy jet aircraft from the Boeing Company. In a letter to Congress, which must approve the transaction since it exceeds $100 million, the bank estimated the total United States export value of the transaction for United States business at $941 million.

title: Zimbabwe Soldiers Said to Kill Kidnapper
description: Government soldiers have killed the leader of the band that kidnapped six tourists just over a year ago, Zimbabwe's leading newspaper reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In general, I am sorry for the fact that many of our friends have spent so much time on this instead of on so many problems that really exist in the world. As if there was nothing more important than this silly thing.'' - Valentin M. Berezhkov, a Soviet diplomat. (3:1.)

title: NEW OIL FEVER GRIPS IRELAND
description: An obsession with geology, visions of bounty, and a certain looniness - these and other unmistakable symptoms of oil fever are sweeping Ireland again.

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
2D QUARTER G.N.P. IS REVISED UPWARD TO A RATE OF 9.2%
description: The economy grew even faster in the second quarter of the year than originally reported, and inflation was even lower, the Government said today.

title: Fan Hurt in Fall At Yankees' Park
description: A Yankee Stadium spectator was critically injured last night when he fell or jumped 40 feet from the ball park's mezzanine level as a game there was ending, the police said.

title: POLAND OUTLAWS WRITERS' UNION FOR ITS DEFIANCE
description: The authorities tonight dissolved the Union of Writers, one of Poland's most important intellectual organizations.

title: CANCELED ACQUISITIONS: NOT ALL THAT UNUSUAL

A NONCONFORMIST, EVEN IN HIS EXIT
