Some reporters and the school's sports information personnel hovered by the field speculating about Smith's whereabouts when the errant player appeared through the branches of the gnarled oak trees that border the campus.

title: Your Money, Data on Stocks Going to I.R.S.
description: ALL the attention given to the battle over tax withholding on dividend and interest payments, a revenue-building plan that failed in Congress despite the backing of the Reagan Administration, has tended to obscure an important new income-reporting measure affecting securities and commodities owners.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 12.

title:
PATENTS,
A Method To Save Energy
description: A PROFESSOR at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark was granted a patent this week for a method of conserving energy by improving the operation of refrigerators, air-conditioners and heat pumps. He estimates that the new method will save 15 percent to 20 percent of the energy expended.

title: Durables Orders Off 3.6% in July
description: New orders for durable goods fell 3.6 percent in July, the first decline since February, the Government reported today.

title: Kidnapped American Released in Colombia
description: A United States woman who was kidnapped from her ranch four months ago has been released, the Colombian authorities said today.

title: INCINERATE NEW YORK GARBAGE
description: New York City, which disposes of about 22,000 tons of solid waste a day, is facing a waste disposal crisis of frightening proportions. The only reasonable long-term solution is large- scale incineration, which has already raised understandable fears about adverse environmental effects. Yet, we believe the technology exists that will allow us to burn all our garbage without violating Federal air quality standards or further fouling the city's air.

title: THE COURT 'VETO' AND AIRBAGS
description: In two cases decided at the end of its recently completed term, the Supreme Court reshuffled the constitutional balance of power among the executive branch, Congress and the judiciary. The first case, which invalidated the legislative veto, has been credited with transferring enormous political power to the executive branch. But, closer study reveals that much of the freedom of action the Court gave the executive in the ''veto case'' it took back shortly thereafter in an opinion concerning airbags.

title: GAINES PUTS OFF QUITTING IN SWIM
description: Rowdy Gaines says he har made an important decision on whether to retire from swimming nnw or continue training for the 1984 Olympic Games. His decision is that he will maje no decision for mnnths, though he indi= cates that he will keep svimming.

title: Congress's Budget Office Still Sees Big Deficits
description: The Congressional Budget Office, in its revised economic and budget outlook, predicts stronger economic growth this year and next. But it still projects large Federal budget deficits in the years ahead, even if proposed spending reductions and tax increases are approved.

title: Westinghouse Fined $6,000
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has been fined $6,000 for shipping violations blamed for a fire last week at the Chem-Nuclear waste dump near Barnwell, S.C., state officials said.

title: Client Stabs Welfare Worker
description: A receptionist at a city welfare center in East Harlem was stabbed in the back with an ice pick by a client yesterday after she told him his social worker was not there, the police said. The receptionist, Gloria Tapper, 30 years old, was reported in stable condition at Metropolitan Hospital with a punctured lung. The assailant fled the center, at Third Avenue and 126th Street. The stabbing occurred at 8:45 A.M.

title: F.D.A. Committee Acts on Drug
description: A special advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended approving the painkiller ibuprofen for over-the-counter sales, an F.D.A. spokesman said.

title: TAX THEORY AND REALITY
description: The findings of a new Census Bureau study confirm what many economists suspected: the nation's tax system, in practice, is less progressive than the tax code would imply. In 1980, households with incomes of $75,000 or more paid, on the average, one- third of that income in Federal income taxes. The tax rate on income above $75,000 was at least 54 percent at that time, and the rate rose to a maximum of 70 percent on income of more than $215,400. In 1981 Congress reduced the maximum rate to 50 percent.

The airline, citing deregulation and competition from new domestic carriers, also said it was postponing indefinitely benefit increases that were scheduled to go into effect this fall, including merit pay increases and insurance improvements.

title: Oil-Drilling Rise Seen
description: An average of 2,425 rigs will be drilling for oil and gas in the United States in 1984, up 6.1 percent from the estimated average of 2,285 this year, I. C. Kerridge, a vice president of the Hughes Tool Company and an economist, predicted today. He said the company also expected 67,300 wells to be drilled next year, 6.8 percent more than the estimated 63,000 in 1983. United States drilling expenditures are expected to increase to $21.5 billion in 1984, from $19.2 billion this year, he added.

The group topped the Shea Stadium attendance figures for the Beatles and everyone else on Thursday night because a way was found to pack in 70,000 people for a sold-out performance.

description: WHEN we had scraped together enough money to make a down payment on a waterfront summer cottage, my husband told the lawyer who handled the purchase for us: ''Make sure there are no easements across the property. We don't want to find ourselves singing the 'back cottage blues.' ''

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Chad ChallengePuts the FrenchIn a Testy MoodDispatching French troops to prop up a former African colony was bound to be awkward for Fran,cois Mitterrand, a Socialist President who had castigated his predecessors for doing just that. So last week, as several thousand French paratroops flew into Chad and the neighboring Central African Republic, Mr. Mitterrand loudly changed the subject. He authorized the newspaper Le Monde to portray him as staunchly resisting purported pressure from Washington. Mr. Mitterrand was acting only to rescue Africans from heavy-handed American tactics that threatened to create a dangerous new East-West battlefront, the paper said. President Reagan had sent so many messages, added Le Monde, that Mr. Mitterrand hadn't bothered to answer them all.

title: Mary C. Mars Weds Rev. F.A. Mahlau
description: The marriage of Mary C. Mars to the Rev. Franklin A. Mahlau took place yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Hyde Park, N.Y., where the bridegroom is rector. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carlos J. Caguiat, assisted by the Rev. Francis T. Bryant, the Rev. Leslie F. Prutton and the Rev. Dr. G. Frederick Stoerker.

title: YONKERS WOOS JOBS BUT ENDS UP JILTED
description: Like many older cities fearful of decline, Yonkers has been willing to spend generously to retain industry. When the city's largest employer, the Otis Elevator Company, considered moving out in 1972, Yonkers rushed to the rescue. Using $16 million in state, Federal and city money, it helped the company buy nine acres on which a $10 million factory, employing 1,400 workers, was built.

title: The Education Consumer;  Guide to Some Computers Now Leading the Market
description: FOLLOWING are some of the more popular microcomputer systems and their suggested retail prices, which may be subject to considerable discounts in some stores. Moreover, list prices in the microcomputer market have been declining rapidly, and they are likely to fall even more in the near future as new models are introduced and competition stiffens.

title: U.S. TELLS COMPANY TO REPAIR SCANNERS THAT REPEAT X-RAYS
description: The Federal Government has approved a plan to correct what it says is a defect in up to 238 sophisticated X-ray scanners that could expose patients to ''unnecessary and possibly hazardous amounts of radiation.''

title: Joan Baldwin Weds Geoffrey Rossano
description: Joan Hope Baldwin, daughter of Dr. Hel ene L'Esperance Baldwin of Cumberland, Md., and the late Dr. Maitland Baldwin, was married yesterday to Geoffrey L. Rossano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rossano of Woodbury, L.I. The Rev. Peter Sipple, headmaster of the Salisbury (Conn.) School, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the chapel of the school, where the bridegroom is a history and investment teacher.

title: NEW UNDER THE SUN: HATS
description: Practicality in the crushing heat of August in the city can mean hats - for men, women and children. More than ever this year, big hats with wide brims - those that deflect the glare of a searing sun - have been seen around town.

title: The Schools;  Science and Math: New Recruiting Formulas
description: IN 1980, armed with a Bachelor of Science degree from the Rochester Institute of Technology, Virginia Flook readily found a niche for herself as a research assistant in the field of optics, and eventually moved up to a position with the Eye Institute in Boston. However, she soon started having second thoughts. "I was working with computers all day," she said, "when I realized I was really a people person. I had done some volunteer teaching and I loved it." So when she heard that this fall the Harvard Graduate School of Education would be starting an intensive one-year mid-career math and science teacher training program, she quickly applied.

title: BUS PROBLEM: NARROW STREETS
description: PEOPLE in Point Lookout have mixed feelings about their bus service. ''Everybody wants the service,'' said Jo Robertson, manager of public services for the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority, ''but they don't want it on their street.''

title: 61 Jailed in Pakistan
description: Military courts have sentenced 61 political opponents of President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq's martial-law Government. An official news release on Friday said 52 political activists in southern Pakistan were sentenced to at least one year's imprisonment, fines equivalent to $1,500 and 10 to 15 lashes. In Islamabad on Friday, a military court sentenced nine people to 10 lashes and one year in prison.

title: Mary C. Griffith Weds A.H. Platt
description: Mary Carroll Griffith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd Tayloe Griffith of Mount Holly, Va., was married yesterday to Alexander Hartley Platt, son of Dr., and Mrs. Adrian T. Platt of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Treadwell Davison performed the ceremony at Yeocomico Episcopal Church in Tucker Hill, Va.

title: JERSEY MOPED OWNERS FAILING TO MEET NEW LICENSING LAW
description: Officials of the State Motor Vehicles Division are hoping to hear from thousands of moped owners who are facing a Sept. 9 deadline under a new state law requiring that they provide ownership papers, registration certificates and a license tag for the motorized bicycles.

Power performed the ceremony.

title: REVAMP 'FROMM WEEK'?
description: Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, which ended on Thursday, has long counted as the East Coast's most prestigious summer showcase for serious new music. But in recent years, numerous commentators have complained that the festival has fallen into a programming rut - that it has become a dogged defender of conservative contemporary music - ''conservative'' meaning traditionally modernist, dissonant, complex, academic music. Not all the scores in this or any recent festival conformed to that description, of course. But many did, and large areas of new-music activity were steadfastly ignored.

But then the Comedie is not at all a normal kind of dance experience.

title: FIRES IN SPACE
description: 100 BILLION SUNS, The Birth, Life, and Death of the Stars. By Rudolf Kippenhahn. Translated by Jean Steinberg. Illustrated. 264 pp. New York: Basic Books. $25. FOUNDATIONS OF SPACE-TIME THEORIES Relativistic Physics and Philosophy of Science. By Michael Friedman. Illustrated. 385 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $35.

title: EXPLORING THE LABYRINTH OF THE MIND
description: James Gleick is an assistant metropolitan editor of The Times. By James Gleick OU'RE LOOKING AT A NEWSPAper comic page and your eye falls on today's jumble. It's an anagram puzzle. You have to turn a few scrambled letters into a word. LOONDERK. A tough one. KRONDOLE. KNOODLER. Close. Patterns form and re- form in your mind. Actually, in this case there isn't even a word there, but at least the patterns look like words. Implausible combinations like EOKDNLRO and NRDOEOKL never leap to mind. This isn't like doing arithmetic - there are no rules to tell you how to make these patterns. No conscious logic decides how to tear the letters apart and put them back together. It just happens, with a delicacy that belies the power of the decision making. The regrouping is fast, subtle and fluid.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES ART
description: One of the more successful outdoor sculptures this summer season is Tom Butter's ''W.H.-M.M.D.,'' at the Hammarskjold Plaza Sculpture Garden, 866 Second Avenue, through September. The scale of the work is right, and the interaction between the organic and architectural shapes and vertical and horizontal movements make the work a forceful point of orientation for the trees and buildings around it.

title: SITE OF EXECUTIONS READY IN TRENTON
description: After providing details about last meals, last rites and lethal drugs, a New Jersey corrections official said today that the state was ready to carry out the death penalty ''scientifically, with precision.''

title: NOT IN ENGLISH, PLEASE
description: ''COMMENT dit?'' ''Como se dice?'' and ''Come si dice?'' At Caumsett State Park these days, these phrases are bouncing back and forth as 56 Long Island high school students immerse themselves in French, Italian and Spanish. During the 17-day program, which concludes next Sunday, English is forbidden.

title: No Headline
A SMALL BUT SWEET SUCCESS
description: DOWN a dirt alley, behind a cluster of stores on Bethel's main street, Robert Allison stood in the back room of his tiny shop one recent morning, a white apron covering his shirt and jeans. Around him, blenders whirred, freezers hummed and a cylindrical stainless-steel machine rumbled as it produced a creamy white substance that fell into a red plastic bucket.

title: STUNTS ALOFT
description: Fifteen stunt pilots - most in biplanes, but one in a jet and another in a glider - will take to the skies in Sussex Airport's annual airshow next Friday, Saturday and Sunday. The pilots will be joined by the Army's Special Forces (Green Berets) sky- diving team from Fort Bragg, N.C.

title: Jaeann Titus Marries Burton Carnot Coit 3d
description: Jaeann Whitmore Titus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Titus of Old Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Burton Carnot Coit 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coit Jr. of Washington, Pa. The Rev. Jack Hascup performed the ceremony at the Brookville Reformed Church, assisted by the Rev. Mario Costa of St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church, also in Brookville.

title: Miss Dominguez Wed In Harvard Ceremony
description: Kathryn Mary Elizabeth Dominguez, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Dominguez of Westchester, Calif., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to John Andrew Christian Pound, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pound of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. John Vannersdall, a Lutheran minister who is chaplain of Yale University, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Appleton Chapel at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: NEW HOSPITAL PROGRAM AIDS ALCOHOLICS
description: ALTHOUGH alcoholism has become more accepted as an illness, with ballplayers, actors and other public figures acknowledging their addiction, there still is often a stigma attached to those who admit that they are alcoholics.

title: DRUSE OF SHUF HOLD ONE OF HIGHER CARDS IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT,Lebanon ROBERT C. McFarlane, the President's special envoy in the Middle East, was caught last week in a diplomatic tangle - trying to assuage the fears while meeting some of the demands of one of Lebanon's religious minorities, the Druse sect. The agenda may seem esoteric, but there is concern here that if Mr. McFarlane's mission fails, Lebanon may be plunged into a new catastrophe.

title: EMIGRE MATHEMATICIAN OFFERS VIEWS
description: LEONIA BORIS MOISHEZON, a leading Soviet mathematician now living in this Bergen County community, says Federal laws should require public schools to teach more mathematics and science.

title: ROCK-AND-ROLL: TALKING HEADS IN FOREST HILLS
description: The audience walking toward the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium Friday night for the first of Talking Heads's two shows there - the second is tonight - was predominantly white and almost demonstrably affluent. The band itself, or at least its four core members, boasts similar attributes, and almost makes a signature of its uptightness. And yet by the end of the two-and-one-half-hour show, the entire sold-out stadium seemed to be a mass of rock-and-roll celebrants, dancing on their seats and in the aisles. Preppy funk triumphant, you might say.

title: THE WORLD
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, greeted nine Democratic United States Senators last week and offered a catchy-sounding ban on antisatellite weapons. But Washington, fearful of a possible Catch-22, reacted cautiously.

title: PARIS WITHOUT A CLIPBOARD
description: We were not going to Paris. We were going somewhere else by way of Paris, which would become merely that place where we transferred from plane to train. We were glum about that, and about the busyness of our lives that made it impossible to arrive sooner or leave later; what was the point to being in Paris for a mere 26 hours?

title: No Headline
description: 'Givebacks' and the Comeback The recession produced a new buzzword in labor-management relations - ''givebacks'' by labor to management. Headlines focused on unions accepting wage cuts, but there was more to it than that. This was no temporary phenomenon that would end when business got better. It was a fundamental change, a grim but necessary recognition that labor costs have to be reduced if American businesses are to remain competitive and jobs preserved.

description: AS classes change at George Washington High School in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, the halls erupt with the boisterous chatter that is the familier background sound of all schools. Individual words or sentences are not distinguishable by themselves but are cemented into a mosaic of sound. But there is something a little different in the lilt and rhythm of those noises. The pieces of the mosaic are not English, but Spanish.

The Justice Department has also been working hard, seeking as it has throughout the Reagan tenure to modify legal remedies established under previous Administrations for violations of civil rights.

Her parents, who left their native Poland for Austria two days before martial law was declared, ultimately immigrated to Chicago to live in the world's largest Polish community outside of Warsaw.

In refocusing their attention on safety and workmanship at Shoreham, many Long Islanders were reminded last week that the Shoreham debate involves questions of technology as well as economics and that some of the plant's biggest technological headaches are nonnuclear.

title: Pryor Is Hospitalized
description: The World Boxing Association junior welterweight champion, Aaron Pryor, was listed in ''very stable'' condition today after being admitted to a hospital suffering from a severe headache. Booker Griffin, a spokesman for Pryor, said the boxer had finished a workout Friday at Caesars Tahoe hotel when he complained of pain over his left temple. Griffin said Pryor would remain in the hospital overnight ''as a precaution.''

title: DASHERS AND DAWDLERS
description: Samuel Johnson used to contend that ''a man may write at any time if he will set himself doggedly to it,'' and he made a point of living up to those words. It is estimated that he wrote the ''Parliamentary Debates'' at the astonishing rate of 1,800 words an hour, and he claimed to have completed his life of the poet Richard Savage in 36 hours. Urging a young friend to try to write as quickly as possible, he argued that ''if a man is accustomed to compose slowly and with difficulty upon all occasions, there is danger that he may not compose at all, as we do not like to do that which is not done easily.''

title: Leona Rienow, Writer O
description: Leona Train Rienow, who wrote books for children and works on government and the environment, died of a stroke Thursday at Child's Hospital in Albany. She was 80 years old and lived in Selkirk, N.Y.

title: HEADLINERS Chief's IndictmentFor some, the arrest of
description: William Darden , Florida's first black police chief, was a cause cel ebre last week, but for black leaders, his indictment on racketeering charges was a cause for concern. Many in the Florida black community said they detected a pattern, in which a series of notable black men have been prosecuted, but Federal attorneys denied any racial motives. Mr. Darden has been police chief in Riviera Beach, in Palm Beach County, for 12 years.

title: CUOMO SEEKS TIGHTER CONTROLS FOR GRANT PROGRAM
description: Following a formal report saying that a former State Senator had been guilty of ''systematic larceny'' and ''looting'' of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Urban Development Corporation, Governor Cuomo has ordered two top aides to recommend action that might be taken to tighten state monitoring of neighborhood preservation programs.

title: ...FROM DOWN UNDER
description: This is an open letter to the New York Yacht Club from a sporting Australian citizen.

title: CHINATOWN
description: Daniel Liu peered through the glass door of his Chinese restaurant late last Thursday night and squinted to make out the figure knocking on the door. After a moment, he searched for the new alarm system button that would electronically unlock the front door of the Mandarin Garden restaurant.

title: IN THE NEW ABC'S, C IS FOR COMPUTERS
description: WHEN 3-year-old Sarah Hall of Danbury gets ready for a bedtime story, she sits in her mother's lap and reaches her tiny fingers across a big screen. With little prompting, she removes the ''Sammy the Sea Serpent'' cartridge from its jacket and places it into a computer cassette deck.

title: SHOPPING AROUND FOR AIR FARE BARGAINS
description: The current New York-Florida fare war provides an excellent illustration of the seemingly zany price structure that pervades much of the air travel market. It illustrates the strong advantage of shopping around in highly competitive markets and examining the fares not just on the fastest routes, but also on indirect routings that might take a little longer but save you a lot of cash.

title: ; PLAYWRIGHTS ON THE HORIZON --
description: As a longtime theatergoer in New York and a chronic nonrenewer of theater subscriptions - until my second year at Playwrights Horizons - I found John Lombardi's report incomplete.

title: UNION SIGNALS PROGRESS IN PHONE STRIKE TALKS
description: The Communications Workers of America, in a signal of major progress in negotiations to end the two-week-old strike against the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, has called the union's top policy-making body together to review a new contract offer from management, the union announced tonight.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE county has long had an association with the women's suffrage movement. One of the movement's leaders, Susan B. Anthony, once taught in New Rochelle. Another, Carrie Chapman Catt, made her home in that same city. Their efforts led to the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, which granted women the right to vote.

title: International
description: The President lifted export controls on pipeline equipment to the Soviet Union, the Commerce Department said. It was another in a recent series of moves taken to reduce East-West economic tensions. The decision resolves an intense struggle within the Administration in favor of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldridge. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger was the leading opponent of the action, Administration officials said. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: A LAW CENTER
description: The quest was successful, and earlier this month Cadwalader acquired two adjoining and interconnecting buildings, a 10-story structure at 100 Maiden Lane and the 16-story building next door at 102 Maiden Lane. The price was $20 million.

title: ALL QUIET ON THE POTOMAC
description: The capital of the United States is very quiet now, relaxing in the summer heat. The President is at his ranch, and the members of Congress are in their districts. It's a pause for rest and reflection, long overdue.

title: Erin Wolf Is Married
description: The marriage of Erin Linda Wolf, a member of the class of '84 at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, to Richard Vaughn Spencer, a municipal finance consultant for the Bank of Boston, took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nicholson B. White, rector of the church.

title: THE GHOST OF ROBERT MOSES MAY STILL HAUNT CITY HALL
description: In June 1980, when New York City was still a little shaky financially, Mayor Koch invited the state's Urban Development Corporation to participate in the most serious attempt yet to rebuild Times Square. Ten days ago, the Mayor terminated that agreement, charging that the corporation was trying to usurp the city's role. With more than a little help from Governor Cuomo, the conflict was resolved last week, and Mr. Koch was again speaking of a ''unanimity of interest'' between City Hall and the U.D.C.

title: RALPH HANOVER CAPTURES CANE PACE
description: Ralph Hanover swept to a six-length victory tonight in the $599,230 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway and kept alive his hope to become the seventh pacer to win the triple crown.

title: PARTS FOR BRAKES OF X-CARS FAULTED
description: While the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is seeking a court-ordered recall of 1.1 million General Motors 1980 X-cars because of alleged brake system defects, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday that it was not formally investigating additional charges by a consumer group that replacement brake linings worsen problems with the cars.

title: A Correction
description: An article on midwifery in The Week in Review of Aug. 7 incorrectly compared the fees of nurse-midwives and obstetricians. The professional fee collected by hospitals is about the same for both. A midwife- attended birth in a birthing center is about half the cost of a hospital birth, which averages nationally about $2,000.

RESCUING A RARE BREED

description: Brazil's program of political liberalization is being put to its sternest test by the austerity measures being adopted to curb the country's foreign indebtedess.

title: Kate McMahon Is Wed in Darien
description: Katherine Mara McMahon, daughter of Mrs. Horace McMahon of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Mr. McMahon, was married yesterday to Stuart Barnard Upson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Upson of Darien, Conn. The Rev. William Millea of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in South Norwalk and the Rev. Donald Emig performed the ceremony at the United Church of Rowayton.

title: L"UBECK: RICH GATEWAY TO THE BALTIC
description: Thomas Mann spent the four most productive decades of his life in Munich, where he arrived as an 18-year-old in 1893. But of all his novels, none has made as indelible a mark as his first, ''Buddenbrooks,'' the scandalously gossipy tale of the rise and fall of a merchant family in his native city, L"ubeck. He was only 25 when it was published in Germany in 1901, but it became an instant best seller - even in L"ubeck where, however, the book was sold under the counter like pornography or subversive literature. It established Mann's fame as much as it did L"ubeck's, but to this day L"ubeckers, especially the leading families whose bourgeois decadence Mann described so trenchantly, have not forgiven him.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ABOUT PIPELAYERS
description: Following is a statement issued today by the Department of Commerce on its removal of export-license requirements for the sale of heavy-duty pipelaying equipment to the Soviet Union: The Department of Commerce announced today that it will no longer require a validated export license for the export of pipelaying tractors to the Soviet Union. This action is a technical adjustment in the application of export controls and is effective immediately.

title: Miss Grant Is Married
description: Pamela Faith Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Delano Grant of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to Mark Chapman Wheeler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wheeler, also of Wellesley Hills and of Christmas Cove, Me. The Rev. Philip J. Mayher Jr. performed the ceremony at the Wellesley Congregational Church.

title: THE CITY'S SUBWAY CHIEF DECIDES TO TAKE A WALK
description: A new Japanese subway car arrived in New York last week, the precursor of an order of 325 and the first addition to the ailing city fleet in six years. But the promise it held for improved service was offset by the abrupt decision two days earlier by John D. Simpson to step down as president of the Transit Authority, a job he said was too demanding and maybe even impossible. ''I've already given it everything I've got,'' he wrote in his letter of resignation.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
ANOTHER HANDOUT FOR BIG BUSINESS
description: DESPITE his call for budget austerity, President Reagan has proposed to expand the authority of the Export-Import Bank - increasing its ability both to lend and to guarantee loans by $4.7 billion. And many in Congress want even more subsidized financing for foreign purchasers of American goods.

title: ISLAND OF NATIONS ON THE SOUND
description: WITH Ireland, Italy, Israel and India, with Japan and Jamaica and with Tanzania and Namibia all aboard - not to mention at least a dozen other represented countries, New Rochelle will turn into a miniature United Nations next Sunday, at least for a day.

title: 15 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments last week for health code violations.

title: AGENCIES DIFFER IN IDEAS FOR RENEWAL SITE
description: TWO sites in the Washington Street

title: BROWN ON BROWN
description: Jim Brown's National Football League record of 12,312 career yards rushing in 118 regular-season games has stood for 18 years. But its impressiveness is built not only upon the total but also upon the number of games in which it was accomplished.

title: STRUCK MINE OPENS UNDER TIGHT GUARD
description: About 500 law-enforcement officers stood in formations today as nonstriking miners went to work at the struck Phelps Dodge Corporation facility.

title:
ART;
AMERICAN WORKS OF THE 30'S IN STAMFORD
description: AMERICAN art of the 1930's covers the waterfront, from trenchant social realism to blithely experimental abstraction. The Whitney Museum, which began its life in the 30's, has organized a traveling exhibition of work in its collection from that decade. The final stop will be at the Fairfield County branch of the Whitney in Stamford through Aug. 31.

title: FIGHTING THE CHARGE OF THE BLIGHT BRIGADE;
description: Sally Huxley is a freelance writer.

title: RESEARCH AIMS AT RELIEVING PAIN
description: MORE and more these days, people who suffer chronic pain are relying for relief not on drugs, but on tiny electrodes taped to their skin and connected to a wallet-sized, battery-operated device.

title: AMATEUR TITLE TO MISS PACILLO
description: Joanne Pacillo, who was graduated from Stanford University last June and turned 21 years old last Tuesday, had reason for another big celebration today when she won the 83d United States women's amateur championship at Canoe Brook Country Club.

title: BROADCAST NEWS: A TRADITIONAL PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: ; THE TROUBLE WITH POLICE WHO AREN'T
description: To the Editor:

title: A POET OF LACONIC POWER
description: ANTONIO MACHADO, Selected Poems. Translated and introduced by Alan S. Trueblood. 316 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25. TIMES ALONE Selected Poems of Antonio Machado. Edited and translated by Robert Bly. 173 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $9.95. ANTONIO MACHADO Y RUIZ (1875-1939) was a poet of quiet epiphanies and solemn enunciation whose stature in the Spanish-speaking world is akin to Yeats's and Rilke's in their worlds. These two anthologies draw from Machado's three books and give us most of his major poems. Machado's poetry is made up of intertwining dream, memory and landscape done in language of a subliminal power very difficult to translate.

title: An Old Pro's Opinion
description: Venezuela's Commissioner of Amateur Sports has taken a look at the baseball talent at the Pan American Games and concluded that the United States is outclassed by the Cubans. ''The Cubans are not amateurs, they play like professionals,'' said the official, whose pronouncements on baseball carry more than routine interest in Venezuela.

title: RENOVATION LAGS IN HISTORIC DISTRICT
description: NEWARK DONALD T. DUST, a former journalist, sat in the newly renovated sitting room of his 19th-century town house in the James Street Commons historic district here and threw up his hands.

title: NEW CONVERTIBLE MORTGAGE OFFERED
description: -year mortgages that will allow home buyers to switch from an adjustable to a fixed rate without cost or penalty will soon be available for the first time under Federal auspices in a special program to stimulate home purchases during the current uncertainty over high interest rates.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE RIVER'S IN MY BLOOD, Riverboat Pilots Tell Their Stories. By Jane Curry. Illustrated. 288 pp. Lincoln, Neb.: University of Nebraska Press. $17.50.

title:
ART;
OUTSIDE THE GALLERY SYSTEM
description: ACKNOWLEDGING one's status as an ''unaffiliated artist'' - someone who is currently not represented by a dealer - carries with it no shame. Many artists are proud of their ability to survive and even flourish outside the commercial gallery system. The 12 who are so labeled in the exhibition at the Hillwood Art Gallery of Long Island University's C. W. Post Center in Brookville amply demonstrate that artistic success should not be measured in terms of commercial representation.

title:
CONTINUING EDUCATION; 
Take Two Generations and Mix Well
description: WHEN 16-year-old Mark Bigelow, who is from Pelham, Mass., arrived at George School two years ago, he was matched on the basis of interests with a 73-year-old resident of a retirement community situated at the edge of campus of the private Quaker secondary school here. The woman to whom he is matched, Bertha Greenebaum, shares Mark's passion for politics, and they discuss current events during the occasional chess games they play.

title: FAIR ATTRACTS 'FARMERS' FROM ALL OVER THE CITY
description: Beekeepers from Staten Island, quilters from midtown Manhattan, fiddle players from Brooklyn and urban gardeners from every borough converged on a corner of Floyd Bennett Field yesterday for the Seventh Annual City Gardeners Harvest Fair.

title: CATHOLICISM EMBRACES MANY KINDS OF MIRACLES
description: THE very name Lourdes, the French shrine visited last week by Pope John Paul II, can evoke vivid images of miraculous cures marked by discarded crutches and abandoned body braces. It can also elicit jeers and derision as an obsolete remnant of a past plagued by superstition. Neither rendering of miracles and healing accords with Roman Catholic thought today.

title: HOW THE SUMMERFARE MUSICALS FARED
description: GIVEN the mounting costs of mounting musicials, traditional out-of-town tryouts have dwindled. To a large extent, regional theater productions, small-scale workshops, extensive pre-Broadway tours and extended periods of previews in New York City have replaced them.

title: Miss Richmond, Teacher, Weds Salvatore Sparacino
description: Karen Rose Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Richmond of Bayside, Queens, was married in Flushing, Queens, yesterday to Salvatore C. Sparacino, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Sparacino of Nutley, N.J. The Rev. Robert A. Perless performed the ceremony at the Church on the Hill (Reformed Church in America).

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: BLUEFISH BASH

title: Miss Wiatrowski To Wed Sept. 10
description: Elaine Diane Wiatrowski and Richard D. Vorisek plan to be married in Williamsburg, Va., Sept. 10.

title: The Changing Chesapeake
description: Unfortunately, the problems of Maryland's Eastern Shore are universal (''The Changing Chesapeake,'' by Michael Wright, July 10). Over the past 25 years, I have watched the farms and woodlands of central New Jersey give way to development and industrialization, with no planning and even less consideration for the natives.

title: CANADIANS ANNOY LEGISLATORS IN U.S.
description: A major lobbying effort by Canadians to convince the United States to clean up the pollution that produces acid rain has drawn complaints by some Congressmen of foreign interference in American politics.

title: Kathryn Angell Engaged to Wed Herman Leonard
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Angell of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and West Dover, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Anne Angell, to Herman Beukema Leonard, son of Maj. Gen. Charles F. Leonard, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Leonard of Bellevue, Wash.

title: DANCE: CALCK HOOK AND JOYCE TRISLER COMPANIES
description: The name was hard to pronounce, or even fathom. But what happened when the Calck Hook Dance Theater took to the stage at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival tonight had the logic of the maddest dream. ''Six at the Top'' may have been the name its choreographers, Wendy Shankin and Doris Seiden, gave the piece the Paris- based theater-dance company performed at the Pillow, but it was Dr. Caligari's cabinet pried open by an adroit female hand.

title: Britain Supports Australia On Keel
description: In a show of support for Alan Bond and his top-seeded America's cup challenger Australia II with the radical winged keel, the British this evening said they had received permission more than a year ago to put little wings, or ''winglets'', on the keel of a 12-Meter yacht.

title: FILM SCHOOL-A REPORT CARD
description: A film class is preparing to watch a sample of the professor's work. As the lights dim, the students settle into hushed reverence; a hand fills the screen as the soundtrack belches thunderous organ music. After a minute, the film is over and the pupils gush, ''A masterpiece!'' as the proud professor beams.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Bird Invasion

title: Mrs. Lehner Takes 100-Meter Butterfly
description: In the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, Wendy Lansbach Boglioli, then 22 years old, was the self-styled old lady of the United States swimming team. Here, at the Pan American Games, that distinction belongs to 25-year-old Laurie Lansbach Lehner, and today the youngest of the five Lansbach sisters and two brothers showed why she appears ready to become one of the two or three best in the world in her specialty.

title: Reins on the Fed
description: To the Business Editor:

title: RECALLED AUTO WORKERS REFLECT ON DISRUPTED LIVES AND SIDETRACKED DREAMS
description: The telephone call James Stoscup had been waiting to receive for almost a year came early this month. He was recalled to his job as a grinder at the General Motors Corporation's HydraMatic automatic transmission plant in nearby Ypsilanti. He was laid off last Sept. 9.

title: No Headline
description: Andrei V. Berezhkov acknowledged a fondness for Mick Jagger and a desire to become a comic actor, but he denied last week the claim that had created an international tug-of-war: that he had written to President Reagan, asking to remain in the United States. American officials allowed the 16-year-old Russian diplomat's son to depart after he told a press conference that he wished to go home. ''It was all a misunderstanding,'' the youth said upon arriving in Moscow.

title: AS THE CITY BAKES, COMMERCE WILTS UNDER HOT AUGUST SUN
description: At a little past 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon on a sweltering Canal Street sidewalk, Joel Kaufmann pulled up a lawn chair and squirted himself in the face with water from a spray bottle.

title: No Headline
description: Mrs. Carner Leads by a Shot

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF A SPY, By Mary Bancroft. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.95.

title: MEDICARE FINANCING WILL NEED AN RX
description: If you thought Social Security's retirement programs were in trouble before the recently enacted Congressional rescue package, wait until you see the condition of Medicare.

title: TV MAILBAG
description: OPINIONS DIFFER ON EFFECT OF TV VIOLENCE

title: SOAP OPERA STAR AT IVORYTON
description: THE status of celebrity has changed since Helen Gallagher became a musical comedy mainstay over three decades ago.

title: Melissa C. Mueller and Philip Allen to Wed Oct. 8
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Frederick W. Mueller of Miami Shores, Fla., of the engagement of her daughter, Melissa Chloris Mueller of New York, to James Philip Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Allen Jr. of Burlington, N.C. An Oct. 8 wedding is planned in Cambridge, Mass.

title: POLL FINDS BUSINESS PLANS NEW PRODUCTS
description: DESPITE the recent shakiness of the economy and despite New Jersey's ongoing transition from manufacturing to high technology, a survey has found that almost 90 percent of 1,200 businesses in the state will be introducing a new product or service within the next three years.

title: Higher Education;  Budget-KO'd Scholars Come Back Fighting
description: "THEY talk in academe about the lost generation of scholars in the humanities," said Georgia Wright, a historian of medieval art. "Well, consider us found! We're not waiting around for new professional jobs to begin opening up again in the 1990's. We're forging our own future, right now."

title: No Headline
description: On LanguageBy Ronald R. Butters MICHAEL WITTE Can I Ax You About That Arruh?

title: ACCOUNTS DEBATABLE
description: WHEN Ronald Reagan took office in January 1981, the American economy was a shambles. It got messier by the month, sliding into the worst downturn since the Great Depression. Now it is on the mend, and there are two questions: how much credit Reaganomics can claim, and how much real improvement there has been.

title: EL SALVADOR'S VEHICLE FOR DEMOCRACY IS LOW GEAR
description: One morning last week, as the Constituent Assembly began its article-by-article review of a proposed Constitution, 3,000 peasants from all over El Salvador milled around outside on the blazing hot blacktop parking lot. On cue from their organizers, they shouted against provisions they saw as threatening the fledgling land-redistribution program. Officials refused to let spokesmen for a campesino's union present their views orally to the Assembly. Yet later that day, the Assembly adopted language spelling out in ringing terms the rights of Salvadorans to freedom of expression.

title: Now, 'Why Robots Should Buy Cars'
description: Bad jokes about car salespeople are as redeeming as ethnic jokes. You get your expected laugh, but at whose expense? If Bernard Sloan had had a pleasant experience shopping for a car, he wouldn't write an article on it; who would laugh (''Why Robots Should Sell a Car,'' Opinion Page, Aug. 7)?

title: AROUND THE CARD TABLES, AN OLD WORLD DISCUSSION IS REVIVED
description: SITTING in a large gymnasium in Woodmere, gathered around dozens of card tables, some 100 ordinary men - accountants and salesmen, jewelers and brokers - are spending another Tuesday night with their rabbis, worrying over subtleties in Jewish law.

title: Auburn Fullback Dies After Sprint in Practice
description: The first-team fullback for Auburn, 20-year-old Greg Pratt, died today at an Opelika hospital after collapsing on the practice field, officials said.

title: THE MENU REFLECTS SIMPLICITY
description: DAVID LIN, who was the chef at Shun Lee Palace in Manhattan, recently opened his own restaurant, Hunan Palace, in Patchogue. When it comes to devising names for Chinese restaurants, the term ''palace'' is frequently chosen. Here it suggests an atmosphere far more elaborate than the small, somewhat austere storefront dining room.

title: Omaha Beach
description: To the Editor: I would like to add a comment to the query in the Q & A column (Travel, July 21) on the American Military Cemetery at Omaha Beach, Normandy, France. Two years ago my wife and I motored to St. L^o from Mont-Saint-Michel.

title: Elizabeth Moss to Become the Bride Of Jonathan Bradley of London Oct. 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Moss of Garrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth McAlpine Moss, to Jonathan P. Bradley of London, son of Daphne Renshaw Goodley of Woodlands, Hampshire, England, and Maj. Gen. Peter Bradley of Haydon Bridge, Northumberland, England.

title: No Headline
description: City Opera Ticket Refunds

title: Rising Immigration Tide Strains Nation's Schools
description: AMERICA'S classrooms, confronted by the biggest influx of immigrant students since early in the century are once again feeling the heat that turned them into melting pots for previous generations of newcomers. The nation's face is hanged by waves of fresh arrivals from Latin a, the Caribbean and Southeast Asia, as well as a more traditional European sources. The impact is especially apparent in elementary and secondary which are struggling to absorb immigrant young- the hundreds of thousands each year.

title: No Headline
description: Mrs. Carner Leads by a Shot

title: HEADLINERS Counsel in Custody
description: Mary P. Evans , a Tennessee lawyer, has discovered that there are limits to the attorney-client privilege. Miss Evans and her client, convicted murderer William T. Kirk, were arrested last week by F.B.I. agents in Daytona Beach, Fla., after a four- month odyssey. Miss Evans is accused of abetting Mr. Kirk's prison escape by providing him with a gun and by holding it on three guards while Mr. Kirk tied them up.

title:
CAMERA;
FILTERS MAKE A BIG DIFFERENCE IN THE FINAL RESULTS
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. is a freelance writer and photographer.

title: RAINS AIDED CROPS
description: CONNECTICUT farmers were given a reprieve from the summer drought with the soaking two-day rains in the middle of the month. But while the rain was a godsend for many, an untold number of stunted stalks and scrawny ears remain on the state's 52,000 acres of feed corn.

title: Omaha Beach
description: To the Editor: I would like to add a comment to the query in the Q & A column (Travel, July 21) on the American Military Cemetery at Omaha Beach, Normandy, France. Two years ago my wife and I motored to St. L^o from Mont-Saint-Michel.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE recent decision by an Essex County jury not to recommend the death penalty for a 20-year-old Irvington woman convicted of beating to death her 3-year-old son still leaves almost 60 people across the state facing possible death sentences.

title: A Home-State Catch
description: The Memphis Showboats may have to go far afield in their search for a coach, but the new United States Football League franchise has found its first player without crossing the Mississippi. He's Eddie Payton, a 32- year-old kick-return specialist and longtime Memphis resident whose professional career includes stints in both the Canadian and the National Football Leagues.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT PERENNIALS EARLY FOR BEST RESULTS
description: FALL is an excellent time to plant herbaceous perennials. There is usually an abundance of rain and, although air temperatures may become quite nippy at times, the soil remains warm and root growth takes place well into November.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: Nina Routh Plans Wedding
description: Mrs. Eugene F. O'Neil of Greenwich, Conn., and Carlos J. Routh of Boynton Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Routh, to David John Szaltzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius A. Szaltzer of Denver.

title: NON-PARALLEL
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTION, NOT TALK, IS NEEDED ON TOXIC WASTE
description: IMAGINE: You just bought your

title: GUATEMALA'S PATH TO THE PRESIDENCY
description: To the Editor:

title: VACATION HABITS SURVEYED
description: Most Americans take vacations and think they matter a lot. But certain categories - divorced, widowed and separated adults, residents of small towns and rural areas, and those with family incomes under $25,000 - are least likely to take a vacation of a week or longer this year.

title: PIANO ECLECTICISM IS HIS STYLE
description: LEONARD ZELIG, the fictional subject of Woody Allen's current film, inspired awe and front-page headlines with his virtually limitless ability to assume the characteristics - mannerisms, style, even appearance - of those around him at any given moment. Dick Hyman, a real-life musical eclectic who composed all the original songs in ''Zelig,'' possesses similarly impressive characteristics.

title: No Headline
description: Music School Dean Named

title: No Headline
description: City Opera Ticket Refunds

title: IN CALIFORNIA POLITICS ANY INTEREST CAN BE SPECIAL
description: Democrats in California last week brought out one of their old war horses, Jesse M. Unruh, to manage what they regard as a battle for political survival. It seemed appropriate that they turned to a man whose most famous utterance was ''Money is the mother's milk of politics,'' for the campaign he will head is likely to be financed largely by contributions from special interest groups seeking favors in the State Legislature.

title: ON YOGURT DAIRY FARM, TIMES ARE HARD
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON once said, ''Let the farmer forever be honored . . . for they who labor in the earth are the chosen people.''

title: THE LITTLE JEWISH GIRL AND THE SISTERS
description: AN AWESOME half century has passed since, like the biblical Ruth, I stood in tears amid the alien corn.

title: BRANFORD TAKES UP TEACHER PAY ISSUE
description: THE national debate over merit pay for teachers has come to Branford, where the Board of Education has voted to try to institute a system of basing salaries on performance.

title: INAUGURATION AND THE SUPER BOWL, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Retiree at Slot Machine Wins $1.7 Million Payoff
description: A retired San Francisco warehouseman who won $1,701,938 on a slot machine says he played the only machine he could find open.

title: Elizabeth Cornell Marries Teacher
description: Elizabeth Plummer Cornell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Cornell of West Hartford, Conn., was married at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford yesterday to Joseph Wilkin, son of Judge and Mrs. William J. Wilkin of Orchard Park, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. James Kidd, the senior pastor, assisted by the Rev. Richard Russell, Roman Catholic chaplain at Yale University.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: John Best owned a marina in Egg Harbor Township, N.J., and began to build in it in 1980 what he described as ''customized boats.'' Township officials, observing that the boats were two stories high, with kitchens, baths, bedrooms and cedar siding, said they were housing.

title: 'IL PASTOR FIDO' COMES IN A TRULY BAROQUE TREATMENT
description: Nicholas Kenyon is a music critic for The Times of London.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Texas FeelsThe Fury

title: 'METALSTORM' IN 3-D
description: As though to give meaning to the expression ''snail's pace'' and to confute the premise that imitation is a form of flattery, a 3-D movie called ''Metalstorm: The Destruction of Jared-Syn'' opened Friday at local theaters.

title: FOR RUSSIANS, BREZHNEV IS A FADING MEMORY
description: The bronze plaque on the wall above the sidewalk at 26 Kutuzovsky Prospekt is of a size and style that the Soviet system reserves for its most honored citizens.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: SINCE his Boy Scout days in Newark, Lester Pilkington, an embalmer from Union, has been all wrapped up in snakes.

title: THE NATION
description: AdministrationArgues Right toDismiss BlacksWhether to soften his image or in fact because he wishes to declare a change of course, in recent weeks President Reagan has been tireless in vowing to commit the powers of his office to the advancement of minorities. The Justice Department has also been working hard, seeking as it has throughout the Reagan tenure to modify legal remedies established under previous Administrations for violations of civil rights.

title: CITY FOCUSING ITS AIM IN APPLYING FOR FEDERAL GRANTS
description: NEW YORK CITY is rewriting the rules under which it uses Federal money for the redevelopment of real-estate properties - moving from a scattershot approach to standards that will narrow the number of projects in which the city gets involved.

title: No Headline
description: GUILT AND PENANCE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, By Bernard Mac Laverty. 170 pp. New York: George Braziller. $12.95.

title: WBGO SWINGS INTO SUCCESS WITH JAZZ
description: When the second annual Greenwich Village Jazz Festival begins this Friday afternoon at 5:30 in Washington Square Park, the opening concert featuring Joe Williams and the Wynton Marsalis Quintet will be broadcast nationally by a radio station headquartered in Newark, N. J. The two- and-a-half-hour live program, to be distributed via satellite, is another coup for WBGO-FM, the public-radio station that in four years has attracted a devoted and supportive audience to its 24-hour-a-day mix of jazz and news.

title: YANKS AND METS WIN, 6-2 AND 7-2
description: Backed by a seven-run fifth inning, highlighted by George Foster's second grand slam in six games, Ed Lynch pitched his first complete game in the major leagues today for a 7-2 victory from the Giants at Candlestick Park.

title:
Higher Education; 
For Minority Engineers, A GEM of a Program
description: THE blue industrial robot that Lisa Washington came to know so well this summer repeatedly thumped its arm onto a device called a position sensor. Columns of red lights flashed on a monitor before her, measuring the accuracy of the robot's aim within five ten-thousandths of an inch, the degree of precision required for the intricate tasks such industrial machines perform. Miss Washington, from Park Forest, Ill, a first-year graduate student in mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, designed this system during a 10-week summer internship at Western Electric's Engineering Research Center, near Princeton.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Critics BombardPlan to RestrictNuclear DataIn yet another move by the Reagan Administration to limit the availability of Government information, the Energy Department announced plans in April to restrict public access to a broad range of unclassified data on nuclear power and weapons. In written comments filed since then and in public hearings held last week, the plan attracted an equally broad range of criticism.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Belgian Aide Arrested As an Economic Spy

title: AMY OPENGART IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Opengart of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Amy Robin Opengart, to Christopher Pappas, son of Marigo Pappas of Irvington, N.Y., and the late Thomas Pappas.

title: POLISH PARTY LOSES MEMBERS BUT NOT CONTROL
description: One day this summer, paunchy, graying men in stiff black suits, the leaders of the Communist Party in the city of Poznan, laid wreaths at the huge monument in the central square. It was an awkward moment, for the monument honors some 70 workers shot down on orders of their predecessors in the rioting for ''bread and freedom'' in 1956. Like virtually every symbol of Polish patriotism and nationalism, the monument, quickly thrown up during the brief period of the trade union Solidarity, belongs to the political opposition. The striking work consists of two crosses, roped together by a single bar, suggesting bound hands, and the stump of the third cross. The dates of Polish uprisings are emblazoned on one of the crosses: 1956, 1968, 1970, 1976, 1980.

title: ; PLAYWRIGHTS ON THE HORIZON --
description: The success of Playwrights Horizons is attributable in large part to Andre Bishop's emphasis on the quality of the play rather than on the quality of the playhouse. If the play is stimulating and provocative, theatergoers will attend, regardless of the physical deficiencies of the theater itself. Richmond Crinkley and his associates at the Vivian Beaumont could learn a lesson from this. DAVID M. KAPLAN New York City

title: Doctors, Lawyers And Malpractice Suits
description: This is in connection with the article ''Malpractice Suits Increase Care Costs'' (July 24). No doubt about it: Increases in doctor and hospital and other provider charges often result from suits for malpractice.

title: ; NUCLEAR HALT
description: To the Business Editor:

title: BEAUTY
description: FACING THE CAMERA The lens is a legendary adversary for most people, but the experts say that it can be wooed. Attention to the proper lighting, makeup and dress helps - and so does cultivating the proper mood.

title: MERGERS RESHAPING BANKNIG INDUSTRY
description: CONNECTICUT'S banks are embarking on what bankers and analysts see as a new round of mergers that will drastically reshape the state's commercial banking structure within a few years.

title: Stoudt and Steelers Beat Cowboys, 24-7
description: Cliff Stoudt passed for a touchdown and ran for two more tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 24-7 exhibition victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

title: THE REGION
description: Economy-ModelCar InsuranceFor New JerseySaddled with the highest auto insurance bills in the nation - $600 a year is average, $2,000 is not unheard of - it is little wonder that many New Jersey drivers have come to believe they're being taken for a ride. Last week, Governor Kean and legislative leaders agreed on a package of changes designed to make the going a little less bumpy.

title: EXCLUSIVE TRACT GETS A SECOND CHANCE
description: PAST the puddingstone marker and through the sentry gates on Route 23 in Kinnelon lies Smoke Rise - cool, quiet and exclusive.

title: Kimball Reis Plans to Wed Josh Howell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Howard Reis of Houston and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimball Reis, to Joseph Maughan Howell 3d of New York, son of Capt. Willard Young Howell, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Howell of Arlington, Va. An Oct. 1 wedding is planned.

title: CONVENTION PLANS RUN AFOUL OF PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN
description: TRENTON THE dynamics of the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination are interfering with attempts by New Jersey Democratic leaders to get some of the leading candidates to come to Atlantic City next month and woo the 1,500 delegates to the party's state convention.

title: Perspectives;  Dear Students: Come Back, Come Back Wherever You Are
description: AS part of my regular teaching routine at the Long Island school where I work, I called six parents one day during the spring to discuss their children's poor attitude toward school. Unfortunately, the families were in Florida. During the winter, I had tried contacting a mother about her son's similar problem. She had taken him Christmas shopping.

title: ACT FAST IN MIDEAST
description: Unless the United States acts fast to create conditions for negotiations between Arabs and Israelis, it may soon see the end of 10 years of predominance in the Middle East. We have reached the end of the era in which land can be exchanged for peace, and soon an American-brokered agreement will no longer be possible.

title: RIVER FOR MODERN-DAY VOYAGEURS
description: The air is crisp, the sky a clear blue above Ontario's French River. A breeze rides over the pines on a nearby ridge, and two hawks spiral upwards. A merganser and her dozen ducklings noisily fish along the shoreline, and a pike slaps back into the water after snapping up an insect.

Wasley of New York and Niantic, Conn., and the late Mr. Wasley, was married in Niantic yesterday to Robert Gray Atkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Atkins of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Wilfred Thibodeau performed the ceremony at St. Francis Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: A Sentimental Journey
description: Can we assume that a sitting room is where one sits and relaxes, or is it merely a stage set (''A Sentimental Journey,'' by Marilyn Bethany, July 10)? How can one sit on a chaise longue covered with two delicate antique tablecloths? How can one sit on a love seat already occupied by three oversized pillows? What is the point of a tablecloth elaborately pulled out from the round table? Why block access to the out- of-doors in a country cottage with a tea service for 10? (Tea? Ten?)

title: CONSUMER RATES
REAGAN PRAISES CHECKS ON DEFENSE DEPT. SPENDING
description: President Reagan said today that his crackdown on waste and fraud had saved the taxpayers billions of dollars, and he praised Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger for checking what the President termed irresponsible military spending.

Raives of New York and Cornwall, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Robert B. Essex of Hicksville, L.I., and the late Shirley Essex.

title: NECESSARY AMENITY
description: It will come as no surprise to prospective buyers of houses in the new Windemere subdivision in Woodbury, L.I., that the 12 ''lakefront'' properties being offered are among the most expensive. They start at $435,000, while off-lake houses begin at $375,000.

title: BROOKLYN OVERHAUL
description: This week, workmen are putting the finishing touches on a $20 million rehabilitation project started at Vandeveer Estates in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn more than two years ago. Residents in the complex of 2,500 units in 59 buildings have benefited from new windows, roofs, oil burners, boilers, electrical and plumbing lines as well as new cabinets in kitchens and bathrooms.

title: DROUGHT AND FARM AID SLASH SURPLUS OF CORN
description: With a swiftness that has shocked both farmers and economists, a severe drought and a costly Government program have greatly reduced the nation's corn surplus.

description: IN Windham the ''Battle of the Frogs'' has been celebrated for more than a century, and is commemorated on the metal and china figurines that adorn the Windham Center Library and on the banner displayed during a visit by President Theodore Roosevelt in 1902.

title: WHAT GIVES 'JEDI' MASS APPEAL?
description: OF the 4,000 or so science-fiction motion pictures produced in the last 85 years - from the man shot out of a cannon and sent on ''A Trip to the Moon'' (1902) to the stranded space child in ''E. T.'' - ''The Return of the Jedi'' may be seen by more people and make more money than all its predecessors combined.

title: SPINNING MINIS AND NEW SALES
description: Back in the days when Elvis was king, records were sold as either singles or albums. But with rising costs sending the list price of singles up to $1.98 and albums as high as $9.98, the industry has come up with an intermediate-sized entity that is priced accordingly. Enter the mini-LP.

title: Cynthia L. Hohn Bride Of Denis J. O'Leary Jr.

title: FILM: 'YOR, THE HUNTER,' WITH A CAVE MAN HERO
description: ''Yor, the Hunter From the Future'' is based on an illustrated, comic-strip novel, a work that is undoubtedly a lot more literate than the film itself. The movie, which opened Friday at the Criterion Center and other local theaters, follows a muscle-bound cave man hero and his adventures across a dreary, sun-baked landscape remarkable chiefly for its phallic rock formations.

title: Ex-Player to Replace Kuhn
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES CULLS AN ALBUM OF AMERICAN LIFE
description: The National Archives in Washington, D.C., might not seem at first glance the most likely source of photographs for a truly fascinating exhibition. Most of the more than five-million photographs housed there were made and kept as official records of various departments and agencies of the Federal Government, and even the ones that came into the archives from outside the Government - for instance, the photographs of the Civil War from the Matthew Brady studio, which were bought in 1973 by the war department - were originally made and later acquired as records.

title: THE SCRAMBLE TO REWIRE AMERICA FOR LONG DISTANCE
description: CHARLES D. LEDDON, vice president of the Seaboard Railroad in Jacksonville, Fla., has other things on his mind these days besides coal, paper, chemicals and the other products that the railroad system carries. At a press conference on Tuesday, Seaboard's parent company, the CSX Corporation, will officially announce that it is going into the long-distance telephone business.

title: No Headline
description: Break Up New York City? When New York City faced bankruptcy, its plight conveyed a warning to other cities and moved the national government to give unprecedented help. Now New York City faces another danger that has lessons for other cities: secession.

title: PITTSBURGH'S LAW CURBING PLANT CLOSINGS IS UPSET
description: This city's new law requiring companies that go out of business to notify the city was declared invalid Friday.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE OXFORD BOOK OF AMERICAN LITERARY ANECDOTES. Edited by Donald Hall. (Oxford University Press, $8.95.) Yarns about 142 American writers and literary figures from Anne Bradstreet and Michael Wigglesworth in the 17th century to Anne Sexton and Sylvia Plath in the 20th. The stories, like their subjects, are of uneven quality, but as a whole Donald Hall's collection makes delightful, even addictive reading. GOEBBELS. By Helmut Heiber. (Da Capo, $9.95.) A biography of Paul Joseph Goebbels (1897-1945), the poet-playwright manque who became a great master of propaganda and second most powerful man in the Third Reich. Helmut Heiber, a journalist-researcher at the Institute of Contemporary History in Munich, based this biography on Goebbels's writings, speeches and diaries. When it was first published in 1972, our reviewer, Richard Grunberger, said it was ''both informative and readable'' and had ''a strong claim to be called definitive.''

title: ; PLAYWRIGHTS ON THE HORIZON --
description: As a longtime theatergoer in New York and a chronic nonrenewer of theater subscriptions - until my second year at Playwrights Horizons - I found John Lombardi's report incomplete.

In written comments filed since then and in public hearings held last week, the plan attracted an equally broad range of criticism.

title: 300 Tamils to Be Repatriated To Escape Sri Lanka Violence
description: About 300 people from Sri Lanka of Indian origin, descendants of people who came to the island more than a hundred years ago, are to be repatriated to India because of recent ethnic violence, an Indian diplomat said today.

description: COMPETENCE in the kitchen is a key element but certainly not the only one - in the success of a restaurant. In the case of La Villa, a tiny eatery in two miniscule and rather characterless rooms of a small frame house in Salisbury, there is no question about the chef's skills. Any number of interesting dishes seem to be within the reach of the French chef, Raynald Saunier.

title: ISRAELIS WILL PULL BACK WITH DREAMS ON THE CASUALTY LIST
description: JERUSALEM ABOUT a year ago, as the Israeli Army had West Beirut under siege, a young Israeli reserve officer looked down on the city from his hilltop base and began to dream aloud. Someday soon, he said, when the war was over and peace had come to Lebanon, he and other Israelis, back in civilian life, would sail their yachts from Tel Aviv to Junieh, the Christian harbor town north of Beirut. He had met the head of the Junieh Yacht Club, he said, and had already made the plans.

title: WELL, WHOSE FAULT IS IT?
description: ACCORDING to statistics, alcohol is the major factor in approximately half of all traffic accidents. More shocking is the statistical revelation that nearly 100 percent of people involved in automotive mishaps were clothed.

title: 'MOON IS BLUE': COMEDY IN ECLIPSE
description: TIME has not been kind to F. Hugh Herbert's 1950's romantic comedy, ''The Moon Is Blue,'' now playing at the Arena Players Repertory Theater of East Farmingdale. It is remembered chiefly, if at all, for trivia highlights.

title: ON GOSSIP, GLITZ AND OTHER REAL STUFF
description: ''Personal & Confidential,'' a new magazine show that has just had a one-week trial run on NBC, was right up front with what it was all about. ''We're bringing you everything that's personal and confidential,'' Steve Edwards, the amiable host, said, although this was really a contradiction because when you spread that kind of stuff around it's no longer personal and confidential. It's gossip and glitz. It may have had meaning once, but expose it on the tube and it has no meaning at all. It is not so much that the sacred becomes the profane; it is more that the profane becomes trivia.

title: Janis Ellen Koopersmith Plans an Oct. 8 Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Kenneth Koopersmith of Glen Cove, L.I., of the engagement of his daughter, Janis Ellen Koopersmith, to Andrew Arno, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Arno of New York. The wedding is planned for Oct. 8.

title: GEMS OF THE PRINTMAKER'S ART
description: PRINCETON THE art of printmaking goes back many centuries, the earliest prints extant being woodblock prints of Buddhist figures that date from A.D. 868. While the original prints from steel and copper plates and woodblocks at The Eye for Art on Spring Street here do not go back that far, there are hundreds of rare prints that date from the 1600's to the 1890's.

title: Building Collapse Kills 17 in Cairo
description: A four- story apartment building that was being illegally expanded to house a newlywed couple collapsed at dawn today, killing 17 people and injuring 11, the police said.

title: Cars and Self-Image
description: -Image'' (About Men, July 10) emphasizes automobiles for the wealthy and successful male and promotes a continuing emphasis on image rather than substance. No critical remark is made about the male fascination with ''souped-up'' cars, a practice that continues today at the expense of our environment, peace and quiet, gasoline supply and safe roads.

title: CHEAP G.M. POWER: INTEREST REVIVING
description: GOVERNOR Cuomo's plan for selling inexpensive New York Power Authority energy to the Grumman Corporation on Long Island appears to have stirred new interest in the question of obtaining cheaper power from the agency for General Motors in Westchester.

title: BERRY OF ST. JOHN'S CAUGHT IN ADMINISTRATIVE MAZE
description: Walter Berry's escape to Spain ended unexpectedly Friday. He had looked forward to his trip with a National Sports Festival all-star basketball team as an opportunity to see another part of the world, and more importantly, as a chance to try to forget his role as the central figure in a complex and increasingly emotional dispute between St. John's University and the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: RENNER, ON 64-198, LEADS HARTFORD BY 1
description: The third round of the Greater Hartford Open ended this afternoon with six players clustered at the top, within four strokes of one another. That promised a free-for-all in Sunday's finale, with more than a dozen other players close behind the leaders.

title: The Olympic Equestrian Team
description: I assume that P. S. Wood lists the United States Equestrian Team among the elitist interests of the former Olympic Committee president Avery Brundage, and that is why it gets no mention in his article ''Olympics '84: America Gets Set'' (July 3). The fact is that there will be some 350 horses and riders competing in the 1984 Olympics just 14 miles north of the Coliseum.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS; Grasso Memorial
description: After the death of Ella T. Grasso in February 1981, Connecticut legislative leaders moved to honor their former Governor. An Ella Grasso Memorial Statue Committee was set up, and in September 1981 the chairman said the goal was to raise up to $100,000 for a seven-foot white marble statue.

title: The Schools;  QR: A Way to Rid Children of Tension
description: HE is 8 years old, squirming at his desk, waiting for his turn to read out loud. He is scared. His face is hot and his heart is starting to pound. His stomach feels upset. Twenty pairs of eyes will be on him in a minute, and he is frozen in place. Then he remembers QR, his imaginary "body friend" who can help calm him down. Inside, he thinks of a smile on his face. He takes an easy, deep breath and lets it out. He breathes in again, lets his jaw go ever so slightly slack, and lets the breath out. That's all. In six seconds the panic has ebbed. Calmly, clearly, he starts to read.

title: Finding an Outdoor Program
description: INFORMATION on organizations that offer scientifically oriented summer outdoor programs is most readily available in university libraries, which tend to receive and retain more literature in this area than do public libraries. Following is a sampling of such programs:

title: CRBBSWBRD FBNS FBLL IN BLBNKS
description: After the second round of crossword competition, Stanley Newman jumped up and said: ''The Wicked Wasp of Twickenham! That's Alexander Pope! With a mathematics background, I'm not supposed to know such things, but I do. I picked them up from doing puzzles.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS

title: HOW SHOULD CONDUCTORS BE JUDGED?
description: It used to look so simple. The board of trustees of a symphony orchestra or opera house engaged a music director and put him in full charge of artistic matters. Actually, this was sheer pretense: Most music directors, understanding that they are high-level employees, have always done pretty much what the trustees wanted, even down to the programming (or more likely, the nonprogramming) of specific works by specific composers. Some important conductors, to be sure, have been powerful enough to resist trustee pressures and operate more freely. A few still are, perhaps.

title: MUSIC VIDEO TURNS ON THE INDUSTRY
description: For the first time in four years, the record business is sounding more upbeat and some say that's because it's looking more upbeat. In fact, music video, the three-to-five-minute visualizations of pop songs that first surfaced on television about two years ago, is being given much of the credit for the record industry's recovery.

title: No Headline
description: Andrei V. Berezhkov acknowledged a fondness for Mick Jagger and a desire to become a comic actor, but he denied last week the claim that had created an international tug-of-war: that he had written to President Reagan, asking to remain in the United States. American officials allowed the 16-year-old Russian diplomat's son to depart after he told a press conference that he wished to go home. ''It was all a misunderstanding,'' the youth said upon arriving in Moscow.

title: Lynn M. Kroeger Weds R. W. Daly
description: Lynn Marsh Kroeger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hal A. Kroeger of Scarborough, N.Y., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert W. Daly, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard T. Daly of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Paul Zahl performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough.

title: A TASTER'S GUIDE TO DINING AND SNACKING AT TIVOLI
description: Carefree, innocent and forthrightly old-fashioned, the flower-bedecked restaurants that trail through the Tivoli Gardens provide one of the calmer, more placid dining spots in the world.

title: REVISING OUR NOTIONS OF DOCUMENTARY PAINTING
description: Not so long ago, people didn't want to hear about documentary painting, let alone look at it. Documentary painting had been all very well when the painter was John Trumbull and the subject was the signing of the Declaration of Independence. It had been big business in Victorian times, when a painted record of a historic occasion could command a high price. (The painter could then go on to make a fortune out of the engraving that would be made from it. The English academician W. P. Frith, a past master in such matters, received the equivalent of $250,000 in today's money for one such engraving).

title: RENOVATION LAGS IN HISTORIC DISTRICT
description: NEWARK DONALD T. DUST, a former journalist, sat in the newly renovated sitting room of his 19th-century town house in the James Street Commons historic district here and threw up his hands.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE recent decision by an Essex County jury not to recommend the death penalty for a 20-year-old Irvington woman convicted of beating to death her 3-year-old son still leaves almost 60 people across the state facing possible death sentences.

title: THE REGION
description: Economy-ModelCar InsuranceFor New JerseySaddled with the highest auto insurance bills in the nation - $600 a year is average, $2,000 is not unheard of - it is little wonder that many New Jersey drivers have come to believe they're being taken for a ride. Last week, Governor Kean and legislative leaders agreed on a package of changes designed to make the going a little less bumpy.

title: 3 Hondurans Say That Cuba Instructed Them in Warfare
description: The army here has presented three Hondurans who said they spent more than a year in Cuba for training in guerrilla warfare and that other Cuban-trained guerrillas were operating in Honduras.

title: ; PLAYWRIGHTS ON THE HORIZON --
description: The success of Playwrights Horizons is attributable in large part to Andre Bishop's emphasis on the quality of the play rather than on the quality of the playhouse. If the play is stimulating and provocative, theatergoers will attend, regardless of the physical deficiencies of the theater itself. Richmond Crinkley and his associates at the Vivian Beaumont could learn a lesson from this. DAVID M. KAPLAN New York City
