description: VINCE VAN PATTEN may look as if he has just stepped off a California beach, but his roots remain in Bellerose Village.

title: No Headline
description: FOR 30 years, the two-story, gray-shingled house at 689 Dune Road in Westhampton was comfortably nestled behind a grass-covered dune that protected it from the ocean's rage. But after a series of storms last winter, the dune was completely eroded and in April, in an effort to save his home, William Yankus had the house moved 48 feet back from the ocean and placed on seven-foot pilings.

title: SUMMER'S TWILIGHT, AND MUSICAL DAWN
description: JUST when you thought that the summer's concert activity was winding down, there is encouraging word about two new music societies, one giving an opening gala this Saturday night, the other ushering in an annual chamber music festival.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY HANDEL'S 'MESSIAH,' REVISED BY MOZART
description: ''Messiah,'' that quintessential December favorite, in midsummer? Christmas came early this year, when Gerard Schwarz led the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra through a stirring rendition of Handel's justly beloved oratorio Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: PAPANDREOU RENEWING GREECE'S TIES TO WEST
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialist Government, which took office in October 1981, is approaching midterm with a reputation of independence but with a record of having renewed Greece's traditional ties with the West.

title: THE SPIRIT NEEDS A HIGHER CAUSE
description: ''There are only two forces in the world - the sword and the spirit. In the end, the sword is always conquered by the spirit.'' - NAPOLEON

title: Reds Honor Bench
description: He's retiring at the end of the season and the honors and the appreciations are already coming in, but the Cincinnati Reds have found a new way to honor their star catcher. They are establishing a Johnny Bench Scholarship Fund that will be designed to help athletes with good grades and special needs. Bench will be chairman of the committee that will select the annual recipients.

title: The Changing Chesapeake
description: Unfortunately, the problems of Maryland's Eastern Shore are universal (''The Changing Chesapeake,'' by Michael Wright, July 10). Over the past 25 years, I have watched the farms and woodlands of central New Jersey give way to development and industrialization, with no planning and even less consideration for the natives.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AUCTIONS EMPHASIZE STRENGTHS IN THE MARKET
description: The rare coin market is on the march again. Any lingering doubts have been laid to rest by the success of two recent auctions in New York. Prices were not close to the astronomical highs of 1979 and 1980, but bidding and prices reflected strong new activity.

title: Cars and Self-Image
description: -Image'' (About Men, July 10) emphasizes automobiles for the wealthy and successful male and promotes a continuing emphasis on image rather than substance. No critical remark is made about the male fascination with ''souped-up'' cars, a practice that continues today at the expense of our environment, peace and quiet, gasoline supply and safe roads.

title: Susan E. Houser to Wed W. W. Winant 2d in Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. L. Murray Houser 2d of Bala-Cwynwd, Pa., and Avalon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ellen Houser, to William Wesley Winant 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Winant 3d of New York. The wedding is to be Oct. 22 at the Presbyterian Church of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: The New Pluralism;  In Miami, Bilingual Means Progress
description: "SIX or seven years ago," said Ralph E. Robinette, director of bilingual and foreign-language programs for the Dade County, public schools. "if I had a call from a parent it was 'Why is my kid in Spanish?' Now if I get one, it's 'Why isn't my kid in Spanish?"

title: WHEN A WINDOW NEEDS A HAND
description: IN older homes that have double-hung

title: 'FOUNDING FATHER' INSPIRES A SEARCH
description: EACH weekday morning they drive through the mosquito-infested, poison ivy-laced area and resume shoveling and sifting. Considering their perseverance, one might think these Islip residents were digging for gold.

title: THE REGION
description: Flames of FearIn West Hartford

title: WBGO SWINGS INTO SUCCESS WITH JAZZ
description: When the second annual Greenwich Village Jazz Festival begins this Friday afternoon at 5:30 in Washington Square Park, the opening concert featuring Joe Williams and the Wynton Marsalis Quintet will be broadcast nationally by a radio station headquartered in Newark, N. J. The two- and-a-half-hour live program, to be distributed via satellite, is another coup for WBGO-FM, the public-radio station that in four years has attracted a devoted and supportive audience to its 24-hour-a-day mix of jazz and news.

title: Nicaragua Panel Ends Work On Law for Political Parties
description: The Council of State has completed work on a law for political parties as a step toward elections promised for 1985.

title: The New Pluralism;  In Texas, Troubles Spread Northward
description: FOR Carmen Rosas, teaching fourth grade to a group of Hispanic children here has become a game of musical chairs. Each school year, she is forced to divide her class into different rows; those students who speak English well separated by rows from those who don't. She teaches the class one row at a time. When she changes subjects, the students whose English is better in that subject switch rows.

title: UNITES STATES GAINS BIG LEAD AT GAMES
description: The domination of the Pan American Games by the United States continued today as its medal count topped the 100 mark, with more than a week of competition left.

title: Reins on the Fed
description: To the Business Editor:

title: 2 IN VERMONT TO BE WED BY GOVERNOR
description: As captain of Vermont's ship of state, Gov. Richard A. Snelling has a variety of duties and powers. Unlike some other ship captains, he cannot legally preside over a marriage ceremony.

title: FIGHTING THE CHARGE OF THE BLIGHT BRIGADE;
description: Sally Huxley is a freelance writer.

title: HURRICANE COULD BE COSTLIEST EVER TO HIT U.S.
description: Hurricane Alicia, which began as an uneasy current in semitropical air over the Gulf of Mexico and grew over three days into a surprise disaster, could be the costliest storm in United States history.

title: SOME APPLIED HISTORY FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
description: PRESIDENT

title: LIBRARY BRANCH TRADES STUDIO SPACE FOR ARTISTS' HELP
description: When Matthew Calhoun, a playwright, walks into the Tompkins Square Branch of the New York Public Library once a week, he is not planning to read or do research. He is at the library to direct a group of children and adults who are rehearsing a play he wrote.

title: Truck's Spill Kills Fish
description: A tanker truck accident Friday spewed 3,500 gallons of diesel fuel into the Little Salmon River, killing all the fish as far as seven miles downstream, Jerry Conley, the state fish and game director, reported. The truck ran off U.S. 95, state police dispatchers said.

title: CARS AND SELF-IMAGE --
description: I read with curious interest ''Cars and Self-Image.'' After 41 years, four sons and some steady employment, I, a woman, finally triumphed with a purchase of a TR-6, 1974 vintage.

title: NEW EVIDENCE LEADS THE POLICE TO SUSPECT AUTHOR WAS SLAIN
description: When the author Jacqueline deSieyes Bernard was found dead in her fourth- floor cooperative apartment on Riverside Drive earlier this month, the authorities thought she had died by accident or of natural causes.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: The Victim as Hero

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Rejected Rocket

title: A Link to Life
description: The article on the organ- procurement program at the University of Pittsburgh appeared on the day my husband sustained a fatal injury to the brain stem as a result of a bicycle accident (''A Link to Life,'' by Sally Kalson, June 19).

title:
The Education Consumer; 
Paths to a College Transfer
description: EACH year thousands of high school seniors denied admission to their first-choice colleges enroll at other institutions. Most adapt successfully, but others are dissatisfied. Many of the the latter group try to transfer to colleges typically more prestigious than their own. Nearly a million of them -- about 7 percent of the nation's total college enrollees -- yearly succeed in making the switch. Many others do not.

title: Higher Education;  Endowments Try Getting Rich Quicker
description: FOR the city of Boulder, Colo., the grand opening of the expanded and renovated Crossroads Shopping Mall was a proud day of ribbons, balloons and speeches. For Anthony D. Fox, a vice president of Property Capital Trust of Boston, it was a triumph of investment strategy. Through an arrangement pioneered by Mr. Fox's concern, 30 percent of the mortgage funds for the $25 million development, which was completed this month, had been provided by the endowments of Columbia and Harvard Universities.

title: GEMS OF THE PRINTMAKER'S ART
description: PRINCETON THE art of printmaking goes back many centuries, the earliest prints extant being woodblock prints of Buddhist figures that date from A.D. 868. While the original prints from steel and copper plates and woodblocks at The Eye for Art on Spring Street here do not go back that far, there are hundreds of rare prints that date from the 1600's to the 1890's.

title: THE RUSH TO DEREGULATE
description: Martin Tolchin reports on Congress for The New York Times. Susan J. Tolchin, his wife, is Professor of Public Administration, George Washington University. This article is adapted from ''Dismantling America - The Rush to Deregulate,'' to be published this fall by Houghton Mifflin. By Martin Tolchin and Susan J. Tolchin HE EVIDENCE WAS CLEAR. Thousands of infants had suffered convulsions and brain damage when they were fed commercial formulas lacking essential nutrients. Congress reacted by adopting the Infant Formula Act of 1980, and the Food and Drug Administration promptly proposed stringent rules to enforce the law. In 1981, however, the newly installed Reagan Administration delayed those regulations, studied the matter for 18 months (during which time three million cans of flawed formula were sold) and finally produced a new set of rules. According to Jim Greene, a spokesman for the F.D.A., the new standards meet ''all the requirements needed to protect the consumer.'' According to a staff report prepared for the Oversight Subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, the new rules ''adopted, virtually in every respect, the suggestions of the infant-formula industry to relax the proposed rules and add 'flexibility.' ''

title: G.O.P. CONVENTION PLANS WIDER COMPUTER USE
description: Republicans are preparing to nudge their national political convention into the computer age in 1984.

title: Playwrights on the Horizon
description: John Lombardi's article ''Playwrights on the Horizon'' (July 17) was inspirational to a young playwright.

title: PEAK SEASON
description: The visitor to western Washington State periodically sees, in fuzzy skies to the east, a flicker of perhaps a Japanese painting, some mirage of cloudy radiance. It resolves itself into mountaintops, frequently catching westering light while the earth darkens, and then evaporates like a stage set painted on scrim. It is only on the third or fourth such hallucination that the Easterner grasps that it is the Cascade Range towering up there.

title: WHAT GIVES 'JEDI' MASS APPEAL?
description: OF the 4,000 or so science-fiction motion pictures produced in the last 85 years - from the man shot out of a cannon and sent on ''A Trip to the Moon'' (1902) to the stranded space child in ''E. T.'' - ''The Return of the Jedi'' may be seen by more people and make more money than all its predecessors combined.

title: WAR BY OTHER MEANS
description: THE SHADOW WARRIORS, O.S.S. and the Origins of the C.I.A. By Bradley F. Smith. 507 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.75.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Accent on Variety And on Price Cuts

title: WHEN AMERICA'S CUP WAS FIRST RAISED
description: To the Editor:

title: RETIRED VIOLINIST AND TEACHER
description: George Zazofsky, a retired assistant concertmaster and first violinist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, died Friday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 69 years old and had homes in Stockbridge, Mass., and Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Fathers, Child Custody And the Courts
description: I read with interest Ed Sussman's recent letter to the editor and the earlier article, ''Men Seek Aid on Family Problems,'' to which he was responding. I agree with Mr. Sussman: what is done to men in the State of New York by the courts is wrong.

title: IN COURT, POLLUTION CASES SELDOM PROVE CLEAR CUT
description: As the litany of toxic substances grows - asbestos, benzene, chlordane, dioxin, formaldehyde - so, too, does the number of people who discover they are being exposed to serious health hazards in their own homes.

title: A Sentimental Journey
description: Can we assume that a sitting room is where one sits and relaxes, or is it merely a stage set (''A Sentimental Journey,'' by Marilyn Bethany, July 10)? How can one sit on a chaise longue covered with two delicate antique tablecloths? How can one sit on a love seat already occupied by three oversized pillows? What is the point of a tablecloth elaborately pulled out from the round table? Why block access to the out- of-doors in a country cottage with a tea service for 10? (Tea? Ten?)

title: THE NATION
description: It was on the whole an elevated week in the slide toward Campaign 84. But while contenders for the main event stuck to policy and positioning, from the secondary arenas came reminders that politics in practice is not all on the high road.

title: TV MAILBAG
description: OPINIONS DIFFER ON EFFECT OF TV VIOLENCE

title: A Call for Fair Play . . .
description: To the Sports Editor:

description: In Africa the wine is cheap, and it is on St. Mark's Place too, beneath a white moon. I'll go there tomorrow, dark bulk hooded Against what is hurled down at me in my no hat which is weather: the tall pretty girl in the print dress under the fur collar of her cloth coat will be standing by the wire fence where the wild flowers grow not too

title: Striped Bass And the Westway
description: Fishermen, who have been lobbying for and against the bill increasing the size limit of striped bass to 24 inches - which was signed recently by Governor Cuomo - should also be lobbying the Governor to trade in the Westway.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Amateur Athletics
description: Pan American Games, at Caracas, Venezuela. Competition begins in cycling and table tennis, and ends in diving, synchronized swimming and shooting. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Reggie Jackson and Rod Carew make their final visit to Yankee Stadium this season, but the Yankees will play against them again in Anaheim next weekend. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.)

title: THE WORLD
description: Chile GoesFrom ProtestsTo PromisesThe Chilean military regime's resolve to delay the return of democracy as long as possible seems to weaken with each wave of protest. Last week, after demonstrations that caused the death of at least 24 people, the new Interior Minister, Sergio Onofre Jarpa, promised Congressional elections before 1990, the date set by the Constitution.

title: Prespectives;  Myths in the Anti-Liberal-Arts Kingdom
description: LATELY I've been made to feel like a snake-oil salesman.I haven't committed any crime to speak of. But I can see the disapproval in the headshaking, the doubting looks and the skeptical questions I am asked. You see, I am in the suspect profession of being a liberal-arts college president.

title: THE WORLD
description: Chile GoesFrom ProtestsTo PromisesThe Chilean military regime's resolve to delay the return of democracy as long as possible seems to weaken with each wave of protest. Last week, after demonstrations that caused the death of at least 24 people, the new Interior Minister, Sergio Onofre Jarpa, promised Congressional elections before 1990, the date set by the Constitution.

title: STATUS WEIGHED FOR 35 STATIONS
description: THIRTY-FIVE railroad stations in the county, some of which have been termed obsolete or neglected, have been informally approved by the state's Board for Historic Preservation for listing on the state and national registers of historic places.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES DANCE
description: Dance will take to the sky and shoreline this week. Theater of the Riverside Church will forego its intimate little dance auditorium and offer dance Sunday on the rooftop of the church, right under the bell tower, in a tiled open space that should be a natural for performance. The festival will feature new and familiar performers of modern dance, for the most part, in a marathon that begins at noon and runs to dusk. Admission is free, but a hat will be passed for each company. Some New York dance presenters are likely to be on hand, too, to talk about their theaters and philosophies.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: The PentagonAs Polluter

title: THE RABBLEMENT'S DESIGNS FOR 'ALL THE LAWYERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: SEES LITTLE IMMEDIATE EFFECT
description: A spokesman for the Caterpillar Tractor Company welcomed the Commerce Department's announcement today that it was lifting special licensing requirements for the sale to the Soviet Union of heavy equipment for laying oil and gas pipelines.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES CULLS AN ALBUM OF AMERICAN LIFE
description: The National Archives in Washington, D.C., might not seem at first glance the most likely source of photographs for a truly fascinating exhibition. Most of the more than five-million photographs housed there were made and kept as official records of various departments and agencies of the Federal Government, and even the ones that came into the archives from outside the Government - for instance, the photographs of the Civil War from the Matthew Brady studio, which were bought in 1973 by the war department - were originally made and later acquired as records.

title: Noncompetitive Higher Education
description: In the July 17 issue I read another in what seems to be an unending series of articles on ''the bitter contest for students'' between private and public universities in Connecticut (''Colleges in Bitter Contest for Students''). It is true that as the number of college-age students diminishes, schools are searching for new programs, state assistance and ways in which they can meet the needs of the nontraditional adult student. These changing needs do not always pit university against university.

title: CRIME
description: This year marks the 10th anniversary of the Mario Balzic series by K. C. Constantine. ''The Rocksburg Railroad Murders,'' published in 1973, was one of the best first crime novels of the decade. Mr. Constantine knows small towns, police procedure and local speech - a speech that is gritty and gamy, not for the squeamish, but nevertheless the way lower- middle-class America really talks. For five novels Mr. Constantine has maintained his steady pace, and now comes ALWAYS A BODY TO TRADE (David R. Godine, $12.95), every bit as good as its predecessors.

title: THE REGION
description: Fraud Charged inPoverty Program

title: Stephanie Field Spoor Wed to Peter Jennings
description: At Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday, Stephanie Field Spoor and Peter Narvesen Jennings, graduates of the Berkshire School and New England College, class of '83, were married by the Rev. Hugh F. McManus.

title: Palestinian Shot Dead By Gunmen in Athens
description: Two young men on a motorbicycle, their faces covered by crash helmets, today shot and killed a businessman identified by the Palestinian press service as a top lieutenant in Yasir Arafat's Al Fatah guerrilla group.

title: HEADLINERS Is It Over?The American League president and Kansas City Royals pitcher Dan Quisenberry teamed up last week to silence the rhetoric of Yankee manager
description: Billy Martin and the bats of his players. In the completion of the celebrated ''pine tar'' game, Quisenberry dispatched the Yankees in 10 minutes. New York had originally been declared winner of last month's game when a Royals home run was disallowed because of too much pine tar on the hitter's bat, but the league president overturned the ruling.

title: THREADS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: MACUMBA
description: Warren Hoge is The New York Times's bureau chief in Rio de Janeiro. By Warren Hoge MAJOR BUSINESS decision was at hand so the Sao Paulo bank president gathered six associates, flew them to the Amazon and ritually sank blessed bowls of white and yellow manioc flour in the river's roiling waters.

title: G.I.'S DIG IN FOR HONDURAS MANEUVERS
description: American G.I.'s are digging ditches and stringing communications lines under the bright sun at this dusty military post as American C-130's land and take off.

title: REBELS UNDERCUT PLAN FOR NAMIBIA
description: Military gains by Angolan rebels this week are seen by South African officials as undercutting the refusal of South Africa's black neighbors to agree that an internal settlement in Angola is the key to independence for South-West Africa.

title: Nuclear Halt
description: To the Business Editor:

title: ARMONK CHILI WIZARD ONCE AGAIN TO SEEK INTERNATIONAL TITLE
description: FOR the second year in a row, Robert Kitchener's tangy mixture of beef, tomato sauce, capsicum peppers, onions, garlic, red wine and other choice ingredients lived up to its name of ''The Right Stuff,'' capturing first place in the Chili Appreciation Society International's New York State cookoff held Aug. 13 at Playland in Rye. And, according to the chief judge, John A. Hryncewich Jr., of Hawthorne, N.J., it was ''the winner by a nice margin,'' besting 14 other entries.

title:
The Education Consumer; 
Computers: The Needs Of a Collegian
description: MELANIE HOAG, a graduate student in biology at Drexel University in Philadelphia, wrote her 200-page master's thesis the old-fashioned way, on a typewriter. That, she decided later, was a mistake.

title: SOLARZ PRESSES MARCOS TO HOLD FREE ELECTION
description: The opposition political leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. returned to the Philippines today after three years of self-exile and was immediately arrested by armed police who boarded his Nationalist Chinese airliner when it arrived from Taiwan.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon.

title: SERVICE PLACES UNWANTED PETS IN NEW HOMES
description: AN Essex family that had bought a pig for slaughter but had treated it as a pet encountered a problem when the red sow grew to the size of a refrigerator. They could not bear killing it, but they also could no longer keep it.

title: Hotels
description: To the Editor: In reference to the ar

title: Tebbetts Mugged
description: Birdie Tebbetts , a former major- league catcher and manager who is now head scout of the Cleveland Indians, was mugged last Wednesday while entering his hotel room in St. Louis.

title: NON-PARALLEL
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP DISPUTED IN SUFFOLK
description: FOUR years after Peter F. Cohalan and two allies, Anthony Pace and Anthony Prudenti, captured control of the Suffolk Republican Party in the County Executive primary, the party leadership is again at stake in the September primaries.

title: WHEN ROLE AND ACTOR ARE PERFECTLY MATCHED
description: Among the many reasons for the longevity of ''The Return of Martin Guerre,'' a beautiful and moving film that after nearly three months' run at the 68th Street Playhouse is still generating attendance figures described by Variety as ''amazing,'' is the exceptionally good use it makes of France's most talented and ubiquitous screen star. He is, of course, Gerard Depardieu, who plays what is apparently the title role in this medieval mystery, and who has by now proven himself to be enormously prolific and changeable. He has played everything from a petty hoodlum (''Loulou'') to a leader of the French Revolution (in Andrzej Wajda's forthcoming ''Danton''), and his screen accomplishments include acts of both heroism and masochism (most notably his self-emasculation in Marco Ferreri's ''Last Woman''). He has by now worked for many of Europe's most renowned directors, as well as some of its most eccentric. Yet few of his earlier roles have suited him as fully as this one does.

title: A WINNING SPONSOR
description: The past two decades have seen two major changes in the two most prestigious events in the annual tournament calendar, the Vanderbilt Knockout and the Spingold Knockout. Both changes were decidedly in evidence in last month's Spingold in New Orleans.

title: L"UBECK: RICH GATEWAY TO THE BALTIC
description: Thomas Mann spent the four most productive decades of his life in Munich, where he arrived as an 18-year-old in 1893. But of all his novels, none has made as indelible a mark as his first, ''Buddenbrooks,'' the scandalously gossipy tale of the rise and fall of a merchant family in his native city, L"ubeck. He was only 25 when it was published in Germany in 1901, but it became an instant best seller - even in L"ubeck where, however, the book was sold under the counter like pornography or subversive literature. It established Mann's fame as much as it did L"ubeck's, but to this day L"ubeckers, especially the leading families whose bourgeois decadence Mann described so trenchantly, have not forgiven him.

title: LOUIS TOBIN
description: Louis Tobin, for 57 years president and chief executive officer of Tobin, Sporn & Glaser Inc., manufacturers of tablecloths and art needlework, died of pneumonia Friday at New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Carte Vermeil
description: To the Editor: In connection with the letter from A. M. Fraade (Travel, July 31) regarding the carte vermeil, or rail pass for elderly persons in France, I would like to find out where the card can be purchased in France and whether it is available in the United States.

title: THE REGION
description: CompetencyComes Easy

title: 5 Swimmers Share Sprint-Relays Honors
description: Five swimmers in four different age groups - Barbara Radef, James Fabbricatore, Tommy Peters, Frank Stonitch and Jennifer Kilbride - scored a meet-high 24 points to take the outstanding swimmer awards yesterday in the Sprint Relays at Astoria Park Pool in Queens.

title: ...AND PLEASURES (OF A KIND)
description: THE weeds are magnificent this year. The mild winter and heavy spring rains have favored every growing thing, but the weeds especially. I remember last year, in the fall, my husband pointed out some weeds that seemed to be encroaching on our grass. ''Well,'' I replied at the time, ''at least they match the grass.'' This season, I've noticed, the grass matches the weeds.

title: H. B. Levering Jr. Wed To Elizabeth A. Tryon
description: Elizabeth Anne Tryon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lane Tryon Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Herbert Brune Levering Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Levering of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Peter B. Grandy performed the ceremony at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford.

title:
The Education Consumer; 
Computer Learning, From the Cradle On
description: LAURA WHEATER first sat in front of a microcomputers when she was three months old. Her home in Bergenfield, N.J., contains three such machines. Laura's mother, Carolyn Wheater, a computer consultant with the public schools there, views the desktop computers as powerful teaching tools and, with Laura's development in mind, she has begun to examine educational computer programming, or software, for preschool age children.

title: NEW BACK-TO-SCHOOL STEREO
description: The midsummer doldrums are the traditional time for thinking of nothing in particular, an occupation also popular in other seasons. But by late August, a young segment of the population usually concentrates its mind on things to take back to school. Among these, sound equipment holds a position of priority.

title: JAVITS LEAVES CALIFORNIA HOSPITAL AFTER TREATMENT FOR NERVE DISEASE
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits checked out of a hospital here today after undergoing experimental therapy for the degenerative neurological disease that has kept him in a wheelchair for two years.

title: Nancy Evans Engaged To John Rand Lloyd
description: The engagement of Nancy Hunt Evans to John Rand Lloyd has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Evans of New York, Fishers Island, N.Y., and Essex, Conn. The wedding will take place Oct. 15 at St. John's Episcopal Church, Fishers Island.

title: Criticism of Doctors Decried and Praised
description: I hesitate to be as hard on Jacqueline Shaheen (''Doctor, Discover Your Humanity,'' Opinion page, June 19) as she was on the

title: Carte Vermeil
description: To the Editor: In connection with the letter from A. M. Fraade (Travel, July 31) regarding the carte vermeil, or rail pass for elderly persons in France, I would like to find out where the card can be purchased in France and whether it is available in the United States.

title: WHAT JOB SPECIFICATIONS CALL FOR A WAR CRIMINAL?
description: United States intelligence agencies, like many others, have long operated outside the boundaries of ordinary law, pursuing national security by means ranging from deception to attempted assassination (now formally forbidden), in alliances with foreign dictators and on occasion with Mafia leaders and alleged war criminals. The scheme by which Army intelligence officers helped Klaus Barbie escape prosecution for war crimes in France, copiously documented by the Justice Department in a 218- page report last week, shows the extremes that have been resorted to in the fight against Soviet Communism, and the fine lines that must be drawn in passing judgment on them.

title:
The New Pluralism; 
Immigrant Adults: The Forgotten
description: IN the wake of the Communist takeover of South Vietnam in 1975, Letam Bui, a student, and nine of her young friends posing as peasants fled the country in a small boat. After having lived in refugee camps in Indonesia and, eventually, Florida for several months, Miss Bui moved to New York City in anticipation that there would be many jobs for her in business here. She found, however, that she could not qualify for most positions because she needed more education in English and American culture than she had learned in school in Saigon and the refugee camps. To help her overcome these problems, she enrolled in the Y.M.C.A.'s English Language and Employment Services Project for Adult Refugees.

title: THE NATION
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation waded into its second round of questioning of former Reagan campaign aides last week, trying to determine how President Carter's debate strategy papers fell into the hands of the Reagan camp. The bureau sought to clear up conflicts and inconsistencies from earlier inquiries and there were hints that investigators might use polygraph machines to aid in detecting lies.

title: RIDING HIGH IN THE ANDES, AUTUMN RIVER CRUISES

title: IN KEARNY, THE FUTURE IS A QUESTION MARK
description: KEARNY NINE days ago, when a study filed with a Federal court in Newark recommended that the Western Electric plant here be allowed to follow through with a phase-out announced last January, maybe, Eddie Stevens thought, the waiting and uncertainty were finally over.

title: THE NATION
description: Neither Congress nor the President let recess interfere with the state of play on Federal spending last week.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOR State Senator Norman J. Levy, Republican of Merrick, the solution became obvious. After a monthlong effort to find an alternative site for the proposed state police headquarters at Bethpage State Park, Mr. Levy invited representatives of the state police, the Governor's office, local Bethpage officials and other Long Island legislators for a final parley at Republic Airport in Suffolk County.

title: COPENHAGEN'S SMALL WONDER
description: The good news is that very little has changed at Tivoli. It's nice to think that's the result of a master plan. It works, it's charming, so don't touch it. Let people come back year after year, generation after generation, and rediscover Tivoli, a gem of a place set in the center of a gem of a city.

title: GOSPEL SINGER GOES 'LEGITIMATE' AT 49
description: WHEN Cissy Houston, one of the eight cast members of ''Taking My Turn,'' off Broadway's musical ode to aging, and Barry Levitt, the show's musical director, met on the first day of rehearsals, Miss Houston asked, ''What's going on here?'' and Mr. Levitt answered: ''I don't know. I'm new at this, too.''

title: THE PLEASURES OF COLLECTING EARLY MPS
description: Some people want a map to find the way to where they're going. Others, especially collectors of early maps, care not a whit about a map's practical applications - in fact, they appreciate a map's often touchingly ill- conceived portrait of the earth as viewed from another age. An especially disarming example is a map of Britain by the 13th-century cartographer Matthew Paris which includes a short note stating that ''the whole island should have been longer, but the page was not big enough.''

description: I assume that P. S. Wood lists the United States Equestrian Team among the elitist interests of the former Olympic Committee president Avery Brundage, and that is why it gets no mention in his article ''Olympics '84: America Gets Set'' (July 3). The fact is that there will be some 350 horses and riders competing in the 1984 Olympics just 14 miles north of the Coliseum.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: ''Firing Line,'' William Buckley's weekly discussion series, will offer ''Was Gandhi for Real?'' Sunday at 5:30 P.M. on Channel 13. And a ''Firing Line'' is just what it is this week. One participant, Richard Grenier, author of ''The Gandhi Nobody Knows,'' can be counted on to blast away at Mohandas K. Gandhi, the Indian leader who was assassinated in 1948. Mr. Grenier says Gandhi was a person of ''autocratic temperament but compared to the other autocrats of the period, Stalin and Hitler, he was a pretty nice guy.'' Mr. Grenier considers ''Gandhi,'' David Attenborough's Academy Award- winning film, an agitprop, pacifism-promoting movie. And, he adds, ''People who like Gandhi seem to be highly emotional.''

title: CHINESE FIND WAYS TO BEAT BUREAUCRACY
description: A British diplomat newly arrived in Peking went to the hospital for the physical examination needed to obtain a Chinese driver's license. All went well until the diplomat put on his glasses to complete the eye examination.

title: ACT FAST IN MIDEAST
description: Unless the United States acts fast to create conditions for negotiations between Arabs and Israelis, it may soon see the end of 10 years of predominance in the Middle East. We have reached the end of the era in which land can be exchanged for peace, and soon an American-brokered agreement will no longer be possible.

title: Nuclear Halt
description: To the Business Editor:

title: EL SALVADOR'S VEHICLE FOR DEMOCRACY IS LOW GEAR
description: One morning last week, as the Constituent Assembly began its article-by-article review of a proposed Constitution, 3,000 peasants from all over El Salvador milled around outside on the blazing hot blacktop parking lot. On cue from their organizers, they shouted against provisions they saw as threatening the fledgling land-redistribution program. Officials refused to let spokesmen for a campesino's union present their views orally to the Assembly. Yet later that day, the Assembly adopted language spelling out in ringing terms the rights of Salvadorans to freedom of expression.

title: Argentine Nobel Winner Is Barred by Uruguay
description: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the Argentine Nobel Peace Prize winner, was denied entry to Uruguay by the military Government today, police sources said.

title: AMERICA'S TRADE DEFICIT IN BOOKS
description: Almost 40,000 books are published in the United States each year, a number that even some publishers think is too high for the industry's own good. But some Americans worry that too few of these books are finding their way overseas. Since the mid-1960's, ''there has been a significant decline in concern about U.S. books abroad on the part of both American publishers and the American Government,'' said John Y. Cole, executive director of the Center for the Book at the Library of Congress.

title: FOR WOMEN, HIT SINGLES ARE ALL-IMPORTANT
description: To be trendy or not to be trendy is a question that presents itself every time a pop star decides to make a new album. For the generation of singers who became big stars during the 1970's when the record industry was fat and confident, that question is particularly vexing these days. In the leaner 80's, a commercially ''off'' album can augur the end of a big-time recording career.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AUCTIONS EMPHASIZE STRENGTHS IN THE MARKET
description: The rare coin market is on the march again. Any lingering doubts have been laid to rest by the success of two recent auctions in New York. Prices were not close to the astronomical highs of 1979 and 1980, but bidding and prices reflected strong new activity.

title: CIRCUMPECTION AND ALERTNESS
description: The right stuff for winning the 1983 United States Invitational Championship in Greenville, Pa., turned out to be the avoidance of anything rash and alertness to seize upon the opponent's error, no matter how subtle.

title: RIVER FOR MODERN-DAY VOYAGEURS
description: The air is crisp, the sky a clear blue above Ontario's French River. A breeze rides over the pines on a nearby ridge, and two hawks spiral upwards. A merganser and her dozen ducklings noisily fish along the shoreline, and a pike slaps back into the water after snapping up an insect.

title: Salary Level Averaged 6.8% More This Year
description: American companies gave their salaried employees average pay increases of 6.8 percent in 1983 and plan increases averaging 6.6 percent in 1984, according to a national survey.
