title: THE STATE PRESENTS ITS CASE SWIFTLY AS DEFENDANTS SIT OUT BRINK'S TRIAL
description: The state's Brink's trial, once expected to last as long as three months, is rapidly winding up after testimony this week that palm prints and bullet-shattered glass linked three defendants to the $1.6 million robbery and the murders of a guard and two policemen.

title: JEWELERS LEAP FIFTH
description: Despite an increase in their ranks, for more than 30 years wholesale traders of precious stones and metals have chosen to squeeze themselves into the Diamond District, a maze of booths and arcades in a single block of 47th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. If a 1980 plan to turn the old Korvette's building at 47th and Fifth Avenue into a jewelers' center had not failed, it would have been the first move by the diamond dealers to the east side of Fifth Avenue.

title: U.S. MOVES AGAINST ITS WORKERS ON STUDENT LOANS
description: The Reagan Administration has stepped up its campaign to recover unpaid Federal student loans, saying it may withhold part of the salaries of 41,000 Government employees who have defaulted on loans.

title: Mary R. Clifford and J. P. Wood Marry
description: Mary R. Clifford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Clifford Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jonathan P. Wood, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Myric Wood Jr. of Lebanon, N.H. The Rev. Donald Cutler performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Elmsford, N.Y.

title: Ex-Player to Replace Kuhn
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The New Pluralism;  In New York City, 2 Bilingual Colleges
description: ON a recent balmy afternoon, students at Boricua College's Manhattan center at 156th Street and Broadway sat outside the school's main building and discussed the upcoming semester.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY A Helping HandFor Two Debtors
description: Brazil and Mexico, which are staggering under estimated foreign debt burdens of $90 billion and $80 billion respectively, got the promise of some relief from the United States Government's Export-Import Bank last week. By approving loan guarantees of up to $1.5 billion to Brazil and up to $500 million to Mexico, subject to review by Congress, the bank sought to encourage reluctant private banks to follow suit and to stimulate American exports. The loans are tied, as usual, to purchases in the United States, which is running record trade deficits.

title: THE NATION
description: Chicago ShowdownThe Constitution was cited in a different context last weekend, when Mr. Reagan vetoed a bill providing $20 million to help integrate schools the Carter Administration had charged were illegally segregated.

title: Judge Grants Divorces To 54 Couples at Once
description: Judge Linda Thomas of Family Court said a few words, right hands were raised, and seconds later 108 people were divorced.

title: Burden of Proof
description: To the Editor:

title: HERE COMES THE MUSICAL 'LA CAGE'
description: Recently a friend of Arthur Laurents went to see ''La Cage Aux Folles,'' which Mr. Laurents directed. After the first act he asked Mr. Laurents archly, ''Are there any tricks you

title: Sonics Deal Canceled
description: A six-player deal that would have sent the Seattle SuperSonics 7-foot- 2-inch backup center, James Donaldson , to the San Diego Clippers has been canceled because Donaldson is a free agent and doesn't want to go. ''We obviously can't trade a free agent,'' said Seattle's general manager, Les Habegger , as other Seattle officials said San Diego had disclosed the deal prematurely. As announced, Seattle would have got two San Diego forwards, Tom Chambers and Al Wood , in exchange for Donaldson, two other reserves, a forward, Gregory Kelser , and a guard, Mark Radford , and Seattle's first-round draft choice next year.

title: 'YOR, THE HUNTER,' WITH A CAVE MAN HERO
description: ''Yor, the Hunter From the Future'' is based on an illustrated, comic-strip novel, a work that is undoubtedly a lot more literate than the film itself. The movie, which opened Friday at the Criterion Center and other local theaters, follows a muscle-bound cave man hero and his adventures across a dreary, sun-baked landscape remarkable chiefly for its phallic rock formations.

title: WHERE SOVIET RIGHTS ABUSES GET GLOBAL EXPOSURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Last of Con Ed Strikers Approve New Contract
description: Utility workers on Staten Island approved a new contract with the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday, ending the second of two strikes that had kept more than 17,000 workers off the job for most of the summer.

title: CAPITOL SOUTH RALLIES TO WIN THE HOPEFUL
description: Capitol South, who scored an impressive victory in a maiden race here July 30, came right back to win the $121,200 Hopeful Stakes for 2-year- olds today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have returned on my free will to join the ranks of those struggling to restore our rights and freedoms through nonviolence.'' - Benigno S. Aquino Jr., in a statement prepared for his return to the Philippines. (A8:1.)

title: HARLEM WEEK ENDS ON A FESTIVE NOTE
description: Normally quiet on a Sunday afternoon, 125th Street came alive yesterday in a blaze of colors, sounds and aromas as thousands went to the block between Lenox Avenue and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard for the finale of a 12-day celebration of Harlem.

title: VATICAN SHOW VISITORS SPENT $101 MILLION IN CITY
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's exhibition of treasures from the Vatican this year attracted 426,700 out-of- town visitors, who poured approximately $101 million into the city's economy, according to estimates by the research firm of Yankelovich, Skelly and White.

title: Barbara Goodman Marries
description: The marriage of Barbara Lynne Goodman, a reference librarian at DePaul University, to Seth Jay Weinberger, an associate with the Chicago law firm of Mayer, Brown & Platt, took place yesterday. Rabbi Neil Brief performed the ceremony at the Ambassador West Hotel in Chicago. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Carol C. Goodman of Skokie, Ill., and Mr. and Mrs. Martin I. Weinberger of Passaic, N.J.

title: RECALLING THE SACK EXCHANGEHEMPSTEAD, L.I.
description: IN its time, the New York Sack Exchange was worth

title: Cathy S. Pollack Weds Stephen M. Yesenosky
description: Cathy Susan Pollack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman G. Gelfand of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Stephen M. Yesenosky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven J. Yesenosky of Wayne, N.J. Rabbi Albert Sturmer performed the ceremony at the New Knoll Country Club in Parsippany, N.J.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH ON 2 IN 9TH
description: Most of the afternoon was a contrast, power pitching against finesse pitching. Dave Righetti, on the mound for the Yankees, was cutting his way through the California order with fastballs. Geoff Zahn, for the Angels, was flirting with the Yankees, skipping out of jams with off-speed pitches and breaking balls.

title: No Headline
description: DEAR BESS: The Letters From Harry to Bess Truman, 1910-59. Edited by Robert H. Ferrell. 593 pages. Norton. $19.95.

title: L.I. WOMAN FOUND SLAIN IN HOME
description: A 21- year-old woman who neighbors described as shy and afraid to stay alone was found slain Saturday night in her parents' home in Great Neck Estates, the police said today.

title: Jamaica Dance Theater
description: The National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica will make its first Manhattan appearance Sept. 14 at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: Stamford Gains World Series Spot
description: A two-hitter by Greg Padilla led Stamford, Conn., to a 5-1 victory over Woonsocket, R.I., Saturday to capture the Eastern regional in the Little League Tournament of Champions.

title: Margery Neale Marries on L.I.
description: Margery Karen Neale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Neale of Woodsburgh, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Howard Goorin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Goorin of Union, N.J. Rabbi Mark N. Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: THE DANCE: MINNEAPOLIS ENSEMBLE
description: A FRESH breeze from Minneapolis blew into the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater on Saturday, when Linda Shapiro and the New Dance Ensemble appeared as part of Dance Theater Workshop's summer Out-of-Towners series. Nothing that happened on stage was all that new. But the three dances by Miss Shapiro, a Merce Cunningham- trained dancer who has been choreographing in Minneapolis since 1973, had an unmistakably personal stamp.

title: Very Rev. N.R.H. Moor Of Episcopal Cathedral
description: The Very Rev. Nathanial Rue High Moor, Dean of Trinity Cathedral of the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh from 1931 to 1962, died Saturday night at the Royal Megansett Nursing Home in North Falmouth, Mass. He was 91 years old.

title: U.S. KEEPS WINNING
description: Cuba completed a stunning performance in Greco-Roman wrestling at the Pan American Games today, but the United States stretched its gold-medal lead, with 18 championships for the day, to 12 for Cuba.

title: Hope M. Schuyler Is Bride Of Lieut. Henry D. Hacker
description: Hope Melanie Schuyler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Schuyler of New York, was married yesterday to Lieut. Henry David Hacker, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood Hacker of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

title: Calling All Miss Subways
description: In 1959, Ellen Hart Sturm had a moment of glory as Miss Subways for March-April. The beauty contest, begun in 1941, was discontinued in 1974.

title: HOW CICELY TYSON GOT TO TEACH IN WALES
description: HER predecessors in the role are enough to make even the most stalwart actress blanch: Ethel Barrymore, Bette Davis and Katharine Hepburn are among those who have portrayed Miss Moffat in the past.

title: Preserving History
description: As a writer who specializes in baseball, especially its shadowy early history, Dick Thorn has been a familiar figure at the New York Public Library. That's because the library has what Thorn and others consider one of the most important resources for baseball research, the Albert G. Spalding collection of early baseball diaries and scrapbooks.

title: ROCK: ASIA PLAYS FOREST HILLS
description: ASIA, the band that performed Saturday night at the Forest Hills Stadium, stems from Britain's first crop of classically trained rock bands.

title: 2 Set High-Jump Record
description: Ulrike Meyfarth of West Germany, despite an injured foot, and Tamara Bykova of the Soviet Union each set a world record of 6 feet 8 inches in the high jump at the European Cup track and field championships today. The previous record, 6-7 1/2, was set by Miss Meyfarth last summer at the European championships in Athens.

title: Rollins in 'Soldier's Play'
description: Howard E. Rollins Jr., who won an Academy Award nomination for his portrayal of Coalhouse Walker in the film ''Ragtime,'' will have the leading role in the film ''A Soldier's Play.'' The drama, written by Charles Fuller, won the 1982 Pulitzer Prize and the New York Drama Critics Circle Award. Norman Jewison will direct the story of the murder of an Army sergeant, which was produced on stage by the Negro Ensemble Company.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Is there a goaltending equivalent in professional football that bars a player from extending his arm above the goal post to block an attempted field goal or a point after touchdown?

title: Greg Rosenzweig Marries Nadine Hertz in Stamford
description: Nadine Clair Hertz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Hertz of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Greg Rosenzweig, son of Jacqueline Rosenzweig of Ozone Park, Queens, and Allen Rosenzweig of Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz performed the ceremony at the Agudath Shalom Synagogue.

title: AN ONSHORE SALUTE TO THE AMERICA'S CUP
description: For all but one of the 2,680 guests at the America's Cup Ball here, arrival at the Breakers, the carved granite Italianate palazzo built in 1895 by Cornelius Vanderbilt as his summer ''cottage,'' was really quite grand.

title: Hooked on Success
description: He has lived the life of a boxing champion, complete with limousines, room service and luxury hotel accommodations, and now, after years of comparative deprivation, Roger Stafford is looking to regain the championship life by doing something he's never done before - becoming a champion.

title: THREE SHOT AND ONE BEATEN AT HOME IN HARTFORD SUBURB
description: Three members of a family were shot and seriously injured and a fourth, an 11-year-old boy, was severely beaten with a pistol last night in their home in the Hartford suburb of Newington, the local police said early today.

title: STRANGE WINS BY 1 IN HARTFORD OPEN
description: Curtis Strange got ''a big weight off my shoulders'' today by winning the Greater Hartford Open, his first victory on the PGA Tour since 1980.

title: STIFFER PENALTIES AGAINST DRIVERS SIGNED INTO LAW
description: Governor Cuomo today announced his approval of legislation that will impose stiffer penalties on motorists who run red lights and who drive while intoxicated.

title: ANGLERS ON PARTY BOATS HAPPY TO GET THE BLUES
description: They had been fishing for two hours off Sandy Hook, N.J., yesterday, and the hardest thing hitting the deck of the 110-foot Palace II was the sun's rays.

title: News Analysis
description: New York City's Convention Center was envisioned at its start three years ago as a model public development, but the project, now delayed and over its projected budget, may soon embark on a far more private course. Under a plan offered by William J. Stern, head of the state's Urban Development Corporation, the state would sell the center to investors who would then lease it back to the state. In addition, the center would be operated privately rather than by the public corporation set up by the State Legislature.

title: Bridge: Lynn Deas Takes 2 Events In First District 3 Regional
description: Players from many parts of the Eastern Seaboard crowded into the Meadowlands Hilton Hotel here in the past four days to take part in the first District 3 Regional Championships.

title: ACTING TRANSIT CHIEF
description: The topic was transportation, but a sports metaphor seemed to suit both the man and his situation. ''The M.T.A. calls me its designated hitter,'' Daniel T. Scannell was saying, ''but I think of myself as the utility infielder.'' The 70-year-old Mr. Scannell had just come back to his summer home in Breezy Point, Queens, after jogging to the beach, where he swam three- quarters of a mile.

title: JETS HAVING TROUBLE AT CENTER
description: No one hit the centers today as the battered Jets began practicing for their final exhibition game Saturday night against the Saints in the Superdome at New Orleans.

title: Caroline Tonetti Is Wed
description: Caroline Susan Tonetti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Tonetti Jr. of Great Neck, L.I., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Steven Mark Schatz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Z. Schatz of Royal Palm Beach, Fla., and Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel. The bride is vice president of sales for the National Flag and Display Company, of which the bridegroom's father is president. Mr. Schatz is a partner in the New York law firm of Gelberg & Abrams. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: STAGE: 'KNACK' RETURNS
description: ''THE KNACK'' by Ann Jellicoe, revived at the Roundabout Theater Company's Stage One, is a lark of a play from the early 1960's, when both London and the London theater were swinging. A long-running Off Broadway success under the direction of Mike Nichols, and a popular Richard Lester movie, ''The Knack'' is the opposite of a kitchen-sink drama. It is a bachelor-pad comedy, high-spirited rather than overemotional.

title: Wilander Topples McEnroe
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden achieved his second major upset in two days today, defeating John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-3, in the final of the $375,000 Association of Tennis Professionals championship.

title: Mrs. Carner Wins
description: The defending champion, JoAnne Carner, shot a three-under- par 69 and survived a hole-in-one by Ayako Okamoto for a two-stroke victory today in the Chevrolet World Championship of Women's Golf.

title: 131 Stolen Bases
description: Donnell Nixon, third baseman for the Bakersfield Mariners, stole three bases in the opening game of a doubleheader against San Jose today in California League Class A action to tie Vince Coleman, a center fielder for the Macon (Ga.) Redbirds, for the professional baseball career stolen- base record with 131. Coleman had surpassed the mark of 130 stolen bases set last season by Rickey Henderson of the Oakland A's earlier in the day with two steals in his team's loss to the Charleston Royals.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 22, 1983
description: International

title: TIMES SQ. AREA SWEEPS HAVE TRIPLED ARRESTS
description: At 1:20 yesterday morning, a boisterous crowd had gathered around a three-card monte game at the corner of Broadway and 44th Street. A young woman who looked to be an out-of- towner - her eyes wandering up and down the Times Square neon, her tailored suit like that of a theatergoer - noticed the excitement and stepped over to watch.

title: OUTDOORS: THE TINY ISLAND OF CUTTYHUNK BECKONS
description: CUTTYHUNK hovers in my mind like a half-forgotten line of poetry that when revisited evokes the unspoiled wonder of the first encounter.

title: Positive Thinking
description: It was a modest beginning, but the former University of North Carolina punter and defensive back Steve Streater made his head coaching debut a successful one, directing the semi-pro Carolina Pirates to a 23-10 victory over the Washington Stonewalls of the Mason-Dixon League in Durham Saturday night.

title: CABARET: A FORCE IN MEMPHIS
description: TRAMPS, the blues club on 15th Street, has found yet another vital rock veteran - Rosco Gordon. Mr. Gordon was a major force in Memphis rhythm-and-blues circles, who recorded hits throughout the 1950's. Three decades later, he still plays two-fisted piano and sings with gutsy finesse.

title: A Good Time Was Had By All but the Planner
description: ''It is rather funny, isn't it?'' Ann

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRESSMAKERS New York has almost always been the national fashion center, the city where clothes were designed and made, sometimes under labor conditions that stood in stark contrast to the attractive garments that were produced. The International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union was organized about the turn of the century to improve life in the shops where so many newcomers to the city got their start, in the early days Jews and Italians, in later days, Chinese, Hispanic people and blacks.

title: Strolling Through Harlem
description: Two roosters crowed at dawn yesterday in a community vegetable garden on East 117th Street, welcoming 250 people on a six-mile, five-hour tour of Harlem.

title: BENIGNO AQUINO, BITTER FOE OF MARCOS
description: From the courtroom, his jail cell and exile 8,000 miles from the Philippines in Newton, Mass., the 50-year-old Benigno S. Aquino Jr. remained an outspoken and implacable foe of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Victory 83 Gains Challenger Final
description: Victory 83 of Britain secured a berth in the America's Cup challenger final series by defeating Canada 1 today by a resounding 2 minutes 26 seconds.

title: Auburn Testing Players for Drugs
description: Auburn football players who returned to campus in Alabama on Saturday were required to take blood and urine tests for drugs, Pat Dye, the university's football coach, confirmed.

title: MACDOWELL MEDAL TO ELLIOTT CARTER
description: It seemed appropriate this morning, at the MacDowell Colony in the Monadnock region of New England, that the composer Elliott Carter received the Edward MacDowell Medal for a lifetime of achievement. Mr. Carter, in his musical career, has unswervingly dedicated himself to a personal vision rather than to public acclaim. Thirty years ago he even urged a struggle ''to preserve that liveliness of the individual mind so important to our civilizaton''

title: Wendy H. Oehlert Weds in Tennessee
description: Wendy Howe Oehlert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hilborn Oehlert Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of New York, was married in Beersheba Springs, Tenn., yesterday to David Porterfield Adams Jr., son of Mrs. Adams of Nashville and the late Mr. Adams. The Rev. David Moss, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bridegroom's family.

title: Nzau Triumphs In Falmouth Race
description: Joseph Nzau of Kenya covered 7.1 miles in 32 minutes 20 seconds and led an international field of 4,500 runners to victory in the 11th annual Falmouth road race today.

title: COLLEGE HEADS SEEK VETO OVER N.C.A.A. COUNCIL
description: IN a move that could eventually

title: PACEMAKER FIGHTER
description: HE said that when he first put his foot into the boxing ring that night he was already soaked with sweat. He said he could ''hear everybody and see everybody'' but that it was all a blur, and he wasn't ''comprehending'' it. For the first time, the realization hit that he might get hurt.

title: Honeycutt Stops Phils in Dodger Debut
description: Rick Honeycutt, in his National League debut, combined with Tom Niedenfuer on a seven-hitter as the Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-0, today for their fifth straight victory.

title: Miss Feldmann Bride Of James Barry Cowen
description: Leslie Anne Feldmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Feldmann of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Barry Cowen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cowen of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Feldmann home.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: JEWISH LEADERS STRIVE TO ROUSE THE UNCOMMITTED
description: Putting aside a longstanding aversion to winning adherents, Jewish leaders across the spectrum of Judaism have been working to kindle an active interest in the religion among uncommitted Jews.

title: ROYALS WIN BY 8-3, DEFEATING PALMER
description: Jim Palmer made his first major league appearance in more than eight weeks yesterday. After one pitch he had an indication of things to come. U. L. Washington singled. Then he stole second, moved to third on an infield out and scored on Hal McRae's double to right field.

title: RUTLEDGE IN QUARTERBACK BID
description: Sounding more like a man pleased with the cards he was holding than one who was troubled over which one to play first, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants again today answered the questions about his quarterback situation with straightforwardly noncommittal answers.

title: Allyn Fincher Married to Steven Richard Winnett
description: Allyn Fincher, daughter of the late Roy Fincher of Kingsport, Tenn., and the late Linda Fincher of New York, was married yesterday to Steven Richard Winnett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Winnett of Montreal. The Rev. Reid Isaac performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: JACKSON GETS A GRIP ON A TROUBLED YEAR
description: HIS manner was casual and his mood upbeat, a departure from the days when Reggie Jackson reigned in the Bronx and storms of controversy often swirled about him like hot-dog wrappers and empty soft drink cups caught in a Yankee Stadium whirlwind. Perhaps it is an indication that Jackson has come to terms with what has been his most disappointing season. Perhaps he does not want to betray his emotions in a city where the memories are so bittersweet.

title: METS SWEEP GIANTS SERIES
description: The Mets continued their surge today when Jesse Orosco stopped a rally in the ninth inning to lift New York to a 4-3 victory over the Giants at Candlestick Park and a sweep of their three- game series.

title: STAGE: THE MUSICAL 'CAGE AUX FOLLES'
description: ''LA CAGE AUX FOLLES'' is the first Broadway musical ever to give center stage to a homosexual love affair - but don't go expecting an earthquake. The show at the Palace is the schmaltziest, most old-fashioned major musical Broadway has seen since ''Annie,'' and it's likely to be just as popular with children of all ages. Were you hoping for a little more? I must confess that I was. The glitz, showmanship, good cheer and almost unflagging tunefulness of ''La Cage aux Folles'' are all highly enjoyable and welcome, but, in its eagerness to please all comers, this musical is sometimes as shamelessly calculating as a candidate for public office.

title: Saga of a Sign of the Time (And Temperature)
description: They didn't need the sign to tell

title: Sine Nomine to Give Handel's 'Hercules'
description: Two performances of Handel's ''Hercules,'' a musical drama based on Sophocles' ''Trachiniae'' and Ovid's ''Metamorphoses,'' will open the 16th season of the Sine Nomine Singers on Oct. 29 at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. The work, which has a libretto by Thomas Broughton, will be performed Oct. 29 at 7:30 P.M. and Oct. 30 at 2 P.M.

title: Army Center Damaged By Explosions in Bronx
description: Two explosions, believed to have been caused by bombs, blew a large hole through the side of a Bronx armory last night and destroyed a truck in a rear yard, the police said. The blasts also shattered windows and caused other damage.

title: CHARLES H. LOCKTON
description: Charles H. Lockton, a retired executive of several chemical and pharmaceutical companies, died Saturday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.

title: TV: 'THE BODY WORKS,' 5-PART PHYSIOLOGY SERIES
description: ''THE BODY WORKS'' is a nice piece of programming for young people that has the inestimable value of being informative for grown-up people, too. Dr. Timothy Johnson, or Dr. Tim as he is called here, teaches three young assistants about human physiology. This could be dull stuff, of course, but on ''The Body Works'' it's done painlessly, with good-natured flair. The five-part, half-hour series begins on Channel 5 at today at 4 P.M.

title: NEW GURU: THE PERSONAL NUTRITIONIST
description: The psychiatrist and the hairdresser have been listening to America's secrets for years. More recently, people have sought out astrologers, chiropractors and gym trainers as their personal gurus. Now, it seems, Americans are turning to the personal nutritionist for health and happiness.

title: PAUL HEFFERNAN
description: Paul Heffernan, a former editor of The Bond Buyer and The Money Manager, died Saturday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., after suffering a heart attack two weeks ago. He was 78 years old and lived in Harrington Park, N.J.

title: CAREY SETS MARK IN SWIM
description: World swimming records often look easy. Few have looked as easy as the one set today in the rain in the Pan American Games by Rick Carey, a 20-year-old Texas junior from Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: LEANING ON DIVORCE LAWYERS
description: ON a hot Sunday afternoon in July, the telephone rings in Cecile Weich's house in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She picks up the receiver to hear a woman's voice saying, ''He didn't clean the pool.''

title: BOCCIE TEAMS COMPETE IN HAVING A GOOD TIME
description: The players danced, swayed, squatted, leaned, cursed at their luck and smiled for the family camera. Sometimes they tossed a colored wooden ball and watched it roll toward a smaller white one. They were competing in a boccie tournament, but to many of them, it was more a picnic than a contest.

title: HEALTH CRISIS FOUND BY NEW YORK STATE AT 2 HOTELS IN CITY
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that surprise state inspections of two New York City hotels housing displaced people had found ''mind boggling'' health conditions. He said he had ordered the State Health Department to provide emergency food and medical care for families there.

title: The Longest Jump
description: He's the Candy Man now, helping to promote a contest to guess how many chocolate pellets there are in a giant jar. But although 15 years have passed and although a new wave of track and field stars have emerged to obscure the exploits and foibles of his generation, the Candy Man still remembers those dark days of 1968.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT STING, 5-3
description: The Cosmos clinched their sixth consecutive Eastern Division title in the North American Soccer League tonight with a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Sting but not without some controversy.

title: Nastase Gets Suspension
description: Ilie Nastase was fined $8,500 today and suspended from tournament play for 42 days following a dispute with a line judge.

title: Yarborough Wins 400 in Michigan
description: Cale Yarborough dominated the last 200 miles of the Champion Spark Plug 400 today for an easy victory and completed a sweep of the two Grand National stock car races at Michigan International Speedway this season.

title: A'S BEAT YANKS IN 14TH BY 3-2
description: The Yankees learned last night that Andre Robertson would miss the rest of the season with a broken neck. Then they lost to the Oakland A's, 3-2, in 14 innings after Rich Gossage let another game get away.

title: AQUINO WAS WARNED 3 TIMES OF DEATH PLOT
description: Philippine Government officials warned Benigno S. Aquino Jr. three times that there would be plots to kill him if he returned to Manila, according to friends and relatives. But Mr. Aquino believed that the threats were only an effort to keep him from coming back after three years of self-exile in the United States.

title: BRITISH YACHT ADDS 'WINGLETS'
description: The America's Cup keel controversy widened today to include Victory 83. Peter de Savary, chairman of the Victory syndicate, revealed that the British challenger had raced with ''winglets'' on its keel for the first time, losing to Australia II by 1 minute 21 seconds in the trials to select the Cup challenger.

title: CLOTHES FOR 2 SEASONS IN THE SUN
description: ''I don't make a summer collection,'' observed Bill Blass. ''The clothes my customers buy from the resort collection constitute their summer wardrobes as well.''

title: MESSAGE FROM SPAIN
description: It's not quite a year since Felipe Gonzalez's Socialists won a smashing election victory, not yet a decade since Generalissimo Francisco Franco died.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: EVERY fall sees a new invasion of

title: DWARF TREES MAY MAKE A MAJOR IMPACT ON APPLE INDUSTRY
description: GENEVA, N.Y.

title: CAMACHO'S PROFILE HIGH AS HIS GOALS
description: It was not until he turned at 106th Street and Madison Avenue and cut through a red light at Park that Hector (Macho) Camacho slowed to a cruising speed. He had hurried from the midtown television studio in his black Cadillac Eldorado, weaving around trucks and speeding past cabs.

title: Perry Back With Rams
description: The former all-pro Rod Perry , a defensive back obtained by the Detroit Lions in a trade with the Los Angeles Rams last Friday, has failed his physical examination and been sent back to the Rams. Although Perry underwent knee surgery four years ago, he has started every regular-season game for the Rams the last three seasons.

title: HIGH TECH: STRONG SUIT OF NORTHEASTERN STATES
description: To the Editor:

title: MORTGAGE RATE CUT BY U.S.
description: The Government today lowered the maximum interest rate on federally backed home mortgages to 13 percent, from 13.5 percent.

title: PHONE PACT TO BRING RATE INCREASES
description: The tentative agreement to end the nationwide strike against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is likely to lead to slightly higher phone rates because wage increases will be passed on to consumers, company and union officials and analysts said yesterday.

title: Nigerian Checkpoint Guards Arrest and Expel Immigrants
description: Nigerian immigration officials arrested more than 500 illegal aliens, most of them from Ghana and Togo, last week, Nigeria's official press agency reported today.

title: BENEATH THE BEACH BLANKETS, A MICROSCOPIC FURY
description: VACATIONERS often lie down on the beach, close their eyes and are grateful for the peace and quiet that surrounds them. But if they knew what was going on an inch or two below their beach towels, they would realize that for many other creatures life was not so peaceful.

title: Soviet Citizen Is Sentenced On Charge of Spying for U.S.
description: A Soviet citizen has been sentenced to a long prison term for spying for the United States, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Argentine Rail Workers Strike for Better Pay
description: Some 100,000 union railroad workers halted passenger and freight traffic throughout Argentina today when they started a 24-hour nationwide strike to demand wage increases.

title: BLACK VOTE SEEN AS KEY TO RUNOFF IN MISSISSIPPI
description: R. SHIPP

title: DINKINS NAMED TO STATE BOARD
description: Governor Cuomo has nominated City Clerk David N. Dinkins to be one of the directors of the State Urban Development Corporation, William Stern, the chairman of the agency, said last night.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Feeding the Algae

title: SPIT AND POLISH IN EAST ORANGE
description: Informed that he was engaging in unlawful activity and could get a summons, Antoine Williams moved on. Antoine explained that receiving a ticket would be no small matter. He would be in trouble with his mom.

title: Richard Nixon's Wife Home After Treatment for a Stroke
description: Pat Nixon, the wife of former President Richard M. Nixon, suffered a mild stroke last week.

title: JUSTICE AIDE RESIGNS, DENOUNCING REAGAN VIEWS ON WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: A Reagan appointee who had been working on the Administration's project to eliminate sex discrimination from Federal and state laws resigned today after assailing the project as ''a sham.''

title: HOW NOT TO STOP A NUCLEAR TERRORIST
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE PHILIPPINE SAGA HAS YET TO END'
description: The following article is adapted from an introduction to ''The Philippines: Democracy or Dictatorship?'', a book that Benigno S. Aquino Jr., President Ferdinand E. Marcos's strongest political opponent, was writing before he returned to Manila on Monday and was assassinated.

title: AGAIN, CHARGES OF LAX SECURITY AND MISSING MONEY
description: All is not well at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, where for a century the printing presses have cranked out the nation's money supply - 4.1 billion individual notes worth more than $35 billion last year alone.

title: A JOB ABUNDANCE FOR YOUNG DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: C. JAMES FLEMING JR.C. James Fleming Jr., a retired advertising executive, died of cancer Thursday at Nantucket (Mass.) Cottage Hospital.

title: 4 LIFTERS LOSE MEDALS FOR USE OF STEROIDS
description: Four weight lifters from Canada and Cuba, including the world-record holder Daniel Nunez, were stripped of their medals at the Pan American Games today on grounds they used anabolic steroids.

title: INVESTIGATIVE JOURNALISM IS FOUND SHIFTING GOALS
description: The activity loosely defined as investigative journalism is changing some of its targets and its tone.

title: SIX SEEKING DEMOCRATIC NOD FOR PRESIDENT PLAN DEBATES
description: The six declared candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination have agreed to a series of debates this fall sponsored by a group of House Democrats and Dartmouth College, a New York Congressman announced today.

title: CleaningWomanFoundSlain
description: A 41-year-old cleaning woman from Brooklyn was stabbed to death while working in a building in midtown Manhattan last night, the police said. The victim, who was not immediately identified, was found by a co-worker at 11 P.M. in room 505 at 1407 Broadway, at 38th Street, according to Sgt. Ed Burns, a police spokesman.

title: No Headline
description: Quotation of the Day

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: TV and the Museum Add Up to a Creative Job

title: A 2d Generator at Shoreham Said to Have 'Possible Fault'
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday that it might be facing major problems with a second of the three emergency diesel generators at its nearly completed Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: JET ROOKIE ON RECEIVING END
description: A week ago, Mike Harmon was a running back with not much hope of running anywhere for the New York Jets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, AUGUST 23, 1983
description: International A new trade-policy dispute has erupted within the Administration. The subject is an export license sought by a British-owned Houston-based company to ship a $40 million offshore marine mooring system to Libya. The Commerce Department is in favor of the sale, officials said, while the State Department opposes it. The dispute comes just days after the resolution of one dealing with sales of pipeline-laying equipment to the Soviet Union. (Page A1.) Mexico, after a year of financial crisis, has overcome an early sense of panic and is now resigned to a combination of economic difficulties and the social hardships they have created. Along with austerity, however, there is cautious hope for the future. (A1.) Mexico announced compensation terms for 11 of the 57 private banks and credit institutions that were nationalized last year. (D15.)

title: Family Says Salary Rise Blocks Aid for Child, 2
description: The father of a 2-year-old girl is looking for a lower-paying job so the family can get Federal aid for medical bills for the child, whose brain disorder may limit her height to 32 inches.

title: CHAD, CALLING AID INADEQUATE, URGES FRANCE TO 'WAGE WAR'
description: The Chadian Government urged France today to ''wage war'' against Libyan regulars and rebel forces who have occupied the northern third of the country and who were reported today to be continuing a buildup of heavy arms in the oasis of Faya-Largeau.

title: A ROMAN SOCIALIST UPHOLDS AUGUST TRADITION
description: ''The Government will resume its activity next week,'' Ansa, the Italian news agency, informed its readers in a dispatch sent over its teleprinters Friday.

title: PINCUS ISESON
description: Pincus Iseson, president of Pincus Iseson & Company, certified public accountants, died Sunday.

title: No Headline
description: Lilco Is Selling Preferred Issue The Long Island Lighting

title: DOCTOR URGING U.S. TO REVEAL PILLS' CONTENT
description: A New York State physician is waging a quiet battle to get the Food and Drug Administration to inform the public about what ingredients go into pills besides drugs.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PRESIDENT STILL PLANS TO VISIT PHILIPPINES
description: The White House carefully emphasized today that ''right now'' President Reagan intends to go ahead with his planned visit to the Philippines despite the assassination of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's chief opposition critic.

title: 32 U.S. Ships Will Take Part In Exercise in West Atlantic
description: Thirty-two United States ships, plus three vessels from Britain and the Netherlands, will take part in a major training exercise in the western Atlantic and Caribbean Aug. 23-Sept. 17, the Pentagon announced today.

title: AN OPULENT OPENING PARTY FOR 'LA CAGE'
description: ''If you're going to have an opening night party you either do your Sardi's roast beef-and-peas number or you go all out with an extravagant, gala evening,'' Allan Carr was saying Sunday night as 1,190 formally attired guests streamed into the lobby of the Pan Am Building.

title: EARLY BOOK-FILM TIE-IN FOR 'THE RIGHT STUFF'
description: The Ladd Company's movie version of ''The Right Stuff'' will reach theaters late in October. Bantam's movie tie- in edition of Tom Wolfe's book about the original astronauts is being shipped to bookstores this week, an extremely unusual two months early.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: DENG'S BAIT TO TAIWAN
description: Peking's proposals for unity with Taiwan spelled out in Deng Xiaoping's recent interview with Professor Winston Yang of Seton Hall University constitute the most detailed and generous terms offered to date. Indeed, they probably are the best basis for negotiations that Taiwan is likely to get.

title: BICYCLES CAN CLEAR THE AIR...
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE IN PAKISTAN FIRE ON PROTESTERS, KILLING ONE
description: The police fired on a crowd of anti-Government demonstrators in Sind Province in southern Pakistan today, and official sources said one protester was killed and another was wounded.

title: LED UNITED CHURCH MISSIONS
description: The Rev. Dr. Alford Carleton, a force for ecumenism as head of the United Church of Christ's missionary work, died in Riverside Hospital today. He was 80 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Trutone Lobell Wins Sheppard

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: More Help for Bryant Park

title: P.L.O. STUDIES THE REFUGEES' LOT
description: The executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization has decided to set up a commission to investigate the living conditions of Palestinian civilians in Arab nations, particularly in Lebanon, the Algerian press agency reported today.

title: No Headline
description: CHEKHOV. The Early Stories. 1883-1888. By Anton Pavlovich Chekhov. Chosen and Translated by Patrick Miles and Harvey Pitcher. 203 pages. Macmillan Publishing Company. $14.95.

title: 5TH SPACE SHUTTLE MAY BE IN WORKS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and Rockwell International Corporation are preparing for possible construction of a disputed fifth space shuttle by building spare parts, it was reported today.

title: COLLEGE 'STARS' GO TO BAT FOR THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: PAJARO DUNES, CALIF. STATUS and prestige are the currency of progress in American society. Let a lowly principal or an assistant professor come up with the most sensible proposal, and you get a polite shrug. But get a star to speak up, and the country listens.

title: Tamco Option
description: Tamco Enterprises Inc. said it had been granted an option by Reliance Group Holdings Inc. to buy at $15 a share the 3,541,100 shares of Imperial Corporation of America owned by a Reliance subsidiary.

title: No Headline
description: Murder, Not Suicide, in Manila Who's responsible for the assassination of Benigno Aquino? To hear President Marcos of the Philippines, the brave Mr. Aquino caused his own death. Amid expressions of ''shock, humility and tears,'' Mr. Marcos insists that his Government tried its hardest to prevent the victim's return from American exile. But Mr. Aquino ignored those appeals, Mr. Marcos says, and besides, protecting a public official from a determined killer is difficult.

title: No Headline
description: International Ferdinand E. Marcos appeared on television to try to dispel what he called ''an orchestrated attempt to spread panic'' across the Philippines after the assassination Sunday of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., his leading opponent. President Marcos said the assassin had fired from a distance of ''16 to 18 inches.'' Opposition leaders said they were determined to fight dictatorship. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan's planned visit to the Phillipines in November is still scheduled despite the assassination of Mr. Aquino, according to the chief White House spokesman. (A8:1-2.)

title: CLOTHING COMPANY SUES CON EDISON ON BLACKOUT
description: A dress manufacturer filed a $10 million suit yesterday against Consolidated Edison over the three-day power failure that blacked out most of the garment district this month.

title: TV: 'TWO MARRIGES'
description: THINGS are better in Iowa. Old values persist. Life is upscale and more comfortable, too. Certainly there are problems, but nothing that a good-hearted scriptwriter and camera crew can't fix. ABC-TV's ''Two Marriages'' is meant to celebrate traditionalism, and if it could be beamed to Moscow the Russians would want to emigrate in droves. The 90-minute premiere of the new series will be seen tonight at 9:30. On Aug. 31, the series will move into its regular prime-time period of Wednesday nights from 9 to 10.

title: SCOUTING
description: Expendable Bear

title: SCOUTING
description: Clash on Gloves

title: Topics Looking Backward
description: Hello, Central

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHORT-CHANGED LATIN ARMY
description: El Salvador is impoverished, and so is its army. Some of the army's problems in the war with leftist guerrillas stem from mundane military shortages.

title: Safeguard Seeks Lewellyn Shares
description: Safeguard Scientific Inc. said its shareholders had approved certain steps for the eventual purchase of 1.6 million of its shares that had been acquired by Swiss American Securities, the broker for Gary Lewellyn, who was convicted on charges of fraud and embezzlement of funds in connection with his purchase of Safeguard shares. Safeguard, based in King of Prussia, Pa., makes power transmission products.

title: Ohio Physician's Lawyer Concedes Series of Rapes
description: Dr. Edward Franklin Jackson Jr., a physician who is charged with a series of sexual attacks over several years, pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity Monday, and his attorney acknowledged that his client had committed the rapes.

title: Playboy Narrows Its Loss
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today that it had narrowed its loss in the April- June quarter to $6.2 million, from $21.3 million in the same period last year.

title: U.N. CHIEF STARTS TALKS ON NAMIBIA
description: The United Nations Secretary General arrived here tonight for talks aimed at easing a deadlock on independence for South- West Africa that has now lasted more than five years.

title: Some Parts of Boston Still Without Electricity
description: Boston Edison Company officials said about 100 customers were still in the dark tonight, 24 hours after a water main ruptured and plunged a 20-block area into darkness.

title: WILLIAM H. JOHNSTONE
description: William H. Johnstone, formerly a vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and chairman of its finance committee, died after a long illness yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ; ...BUT HAVE THEM SPORT THUMB BELLS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Obscure Weiden Foursome Wins Regional Swiss Event

title: Malaria Drug Test
description: An experimental drug appears to be effective in controlling malaria, which kills up to 1 million children a year, says the head of a Federal Government team that tested the new substance on volunteers. Dr. Thomas Cosgriff headed the research team at the Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases at Fort Detrick, Md. The drug, so far listed only as WR 180,409, was tested on 22 volunteers.

title: BUZZ MY BELL WINS SPINAWAY STAKES
description: The 116th season of racing at Saratoga ended in slop and drizzle today. Buzz My Bell won the Spinaway Stakes for 2-year-old fillies, and thousands of horses and their followers started to leave town.

title: No Headline
description: Southern Stage Groups

title: No Headline
description: Heat Stroke Cited In Player's Death

title: ON THIRD-WORLD AID
description: The free world banking system has set up the means to cope with the first major international debt crisis we have experienced in a long time. Yet if we are to meet the challenge of fostering worldwide economic growth and preventing future crises, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development must take a further creative step under the leadership of the United States. Such a step might entail providing less-developed countries with long-term loans at subsidized interest rates, to assist them not only in economic development but in easing their more pressing social problems as well.

title: Perkins Keeping Busy
description: Ray Perkins gained a reputation for intensity during his years as the Giants' head coach, and things apparently haven't changed much since he left for the University of Alabama after last season.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Discharged Manager Lee Elia and replaced him with Charlie Fox, a former manager of the San Francisco Giants and now an assistant in the Cubs' front office. Elia was in the second year of a three-year contract. Recalled Carmelo Martinez, first baseman, from Class AAA farm club in Des Moines. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Put Willie Wilson, outfielder, on 15-day disabled list with a cracked bone in his left hand. To replace Wilson on the roster, club purchased contract of Butch Davis, outfielder, from Triple A affiliate in Omaha. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Reactivated Pete Vukovich, right-handed pitcher and 1982 Cy Young Award winner. He had been out all of this season with a rotator cuff injury. Placed Bob McClure, left-handed pitcher, on 21-day disabled list with strained back muscle. YANKEES (AL) - Announced that Andre Robertson, the shortstop, would be out the rest of the season because of a fractured vertebra he sustained in a car accident. BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES (NBA) - Waived Dwight Jones, center-forward. PORTLAND (NBA) - Asked waivers on Don Buse, guard. BOXING TOP RANK INC. - Announced shift in site of middleweight championship fight Nov. 10 between Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Roberto Duran from the Dunes Hotel to Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev. COLLEGE Five colleges in the Carolinas and Georgia have formed the Big South Atlantic Conference and hope to obtain N.C.A.A. Division I status in basketball for the 1985- 86 season. The five are Baptist, Campbell, Winthrop, Coastal Carolina and Augusta.

title: STORM CLEANUP WORKERS IN TEXAS SAY THEIR JOB MAY TAKE 2 WEEKS
description: Another week or two of cleaning up is still necessary before life along the Texas Gulf Coast can return to normal in the wake of Hurricane Alicia, officials said today.

title: 11 DIE, 7 LIVE AS SKYDIVERPLANE CRASHES ON COAST
description: Eight skydivers clawed their way out of a spinning plane after it stalled and dived toward the ground with engines roaring, but 10 people were killed as the plane hit a highway embankment and exploded and one of those who jumped free died later.

title: STRAWBERRY HITS 2
description: Darryl Strawberry hit his 18th and 19th home runs of the season tonight, but they weren't enough as the Padres scored a 4-3 victory to snap the Mets' three- game winning streak.

title: U.S. Plans To Resume Pershing Missile Tests
description: The Army is planning to conduct the final two test flights of its new Pershing 2 ballistic missile in September after X-ray checks to make sure its engines are clear of a problem that caused a test missile to blow up in July.

title: No Headline
description: Cubs Replace Elia With Fox CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UPI) -

title: Royals Lose Wilson
description: The Kansas City Royals placed Willie Wilson , their star outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list yesterday. Wilson, the American League's batting champion last year, was injured last Friday night at Baltimore when he swung at a pitch from Sammy Stewart and the ball hit his left hand, cracking the knuckle of his index finger.

title: MEDICAL EXAMS SET FOR 7,000 CHILDREN ON KOCH'S ORDERS
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he had ordered medical examinations of 7,000 children in 50 welfare hotels in New York City and that the examinations would begin today.

title: THEATER: 'THE CORN IS GREEN'
description: CICELY TYSON'S considerable reputation as an actress on television and in movies is primarily based on her ability to personify conviction under siege, as exemplified by her performances as such pioneering women as Miss Jane Pittman, Harriet Tubman and Marva Collins. For this reason, the character of Miss Moffat in Emlyn Williams's ''Corn Is Green'' would seem to be a role within her emotional range. Unfortunately this is not the case in the revival of the play that opened last night at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: No Headline
description: Educators Seek N.C.A.A. Clout

title: Deposed Afghan King Offers to Help Rebels
description: King Mohammad Zahir Shah of Afghanistan announced today that he had decided to resume political activity ''to give an official voice to the Afghan resistance'' at the United Nations-sponsored talks on the conflict.

title: 6 REPORTED DEAD IN BEIRUT SHELLING DUELS
description: A sharp outbreak of shelling today burst out of the mountains above Beirut and into the eastern and western suburbs of the city.

title: SCOUTING
description: Football Weather

title: A BUNDLE OF DISKS FOR THOSE BEWILDERED NOVICES
description: ANYONE confronting the idea of a personal computer for the first time is usually overwhelmed by a feeling that nothing about these culture-invasive machines is comprehensible, much less simple.

title: POWER, AND YOUTH, TO BURN
description: They will probably remember it

title: WEAPON AGAINST SATELLITES READY OR TEST
description: ON a mission cloaked in secrecy, an F-15 jet fighter is now set to soar to the fringe of the earth's atmosphere and unleash an 18-foot missile that is designed to speed into space at the blistering pace of more than eight miles per second.

title: Six Now Expelled In Belgian Espionage
description: Belgium has expelled at least six Russians and Rumanians for economic espionage and uncovered an electronics company in the capital that was a front for Soviet technology spies, a senior official said today.

title: HERSHEY AND NESTLE ENTER MILK MARKET
description: The brown carton looks like a giant Hershey bar stood on its end and exploded into a full three dimensions. Sitting on the cooler shelf among the unassuming quarts of milk, it assaults the eye like an Andy Warhol painting.

title: Reagan's Ear Checkup Finds Hearing's Worse
description: President Reagan said today he had suffered a further loss of hearing in his right ear, which was damaged years ago in the filming of a Hollywood movie.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Incumbent Wins Vote On Indian Ocean Isle

title: O'NEILL'S OBSERVATIONS ON SEVEN PRESIDENTS
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was a 20-year-old Boston College student when he met his first President of the United States. The year was 1933. The President was Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: GAS GUZZLERS RETURNING FROM IGNOMINY
description: The time was 1980 and the facts were plain: Gasoline had hit $1.45 in some places, and in others it was hard to get at any price. With a drive to Florida coming up, William Cunningham decided the time had come to do what everyone was doing: buy a small car.

title: DANCE: A COLLABORATION IN THE SAND
description: THERE was an attractive tidiness about ''Economy of Means,'' performed Sunday in Creative Time's ''Art on the Beach'' series. A collaboration between Daniel McCusker, choreographer; Tom Hatch, artist, and Geraldine Pontius, architect, the 45- minute piece made use of the extravagantly beautiful site of the Battery Park City Landfill in a quietly provocative way. There was the sand, and the sky, and the strangeness of the whole landscape, but all seemed woven inextricably into the fabric of the work.

title: 2 NEW KILLINGS IN CHICAGO SUBURBS BRING TOLL TO 16
description: Two people were found Sunday with their throats slashed, raising the murder toll this summer in this suburban county to 16. The authorities are not sure if they are seeking one or several killers.

title: SCOUTING
description: Little Sympathy For a Jet in Pain

title: EDWARD ARNOLD
description: Edward Arnold, president of the Arnold Furniture Manufacturing Company of Irvington, N.J., died of cancer Sunday at his home in Mountainside, N.J. He was 53 years old.

title: Argentine Party Invites Mrs. Peron to Congress
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron's political party has invited her to return from self-exile in Spain to preside over the party's congress next month.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Letter From Lincoln

title: MISS HU WINS FIRST AS A PRO
description: Hu Na, the Chinese tennis player who defected to the United States 13 months ago, posted her first victory as a professional in the United States tonight.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Seventh Graders' View

title: Article 116895 -- No Title
description: Nine people have been arrested and $3.5 million in fake money has been seized in a raid on a counterfeiting ring, the Secret Service said today. The money, in $10, $20, $50 and $100 bills, was confiscated Saturday night at a graphics company as agents concluded an undercover investigation, according to a Secret Service agent, Barney Boyett.

title: BETTER IDEAS ARE SOUGHT FOR TWO-YEAR COLLEGES
description: FOR many students, especially members of minority groups, the community college, with its policies of open admissions and low tuition, has been a vehicle for upward mobility, a point of entry into a higher education system in which black and Hispanic enrollment was only about 5 percent less than 20 years ago.

title: Turkish Journalists Charged
description: The editor in chief and a columnist for the newspaper Turcuman were charged today with insulting the military Government and a prosecutor urged that they be jailed for up to eight years, officials said.

title: DERBY RULES TIGHTENED
description: The directors of Churchill Downs agreed today to drop the also-eligible list for the Kentucky Derby. Lynn Stone, the track's president, said the also-eligible list, which the Derby has had for the last eight years, had only offered ''false encouragement'' to horsemen hoping to make the Derby field through a late scratch of one or more of the horses listed as starters.

title: No Headline
description: $200 Billion and Counting

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Amateur Athletics
description: Pan American Games , at Caracas, Venezuela. Track and field events begin today, with the United States expected to dominate the competition.

title: 2 REPORTERS REVEAL THE EASE OF GETTING PRIVATE INFORMATION
description: Two newspaper reporters in Madison, Wis., used a home computer and a telephone last week to demonstrate the vulnerability of a state computer center.

title: 4 GOLDS IN SWIM FOR U.S.
description: The six days of swimming in the Pan American Games ended tonight the way they began - with almost unblemished success for the United States. Its strong team won three of the night's four individual titles, and its men's 400-meter medley relay team broke its year-old world record.

title: No Headline
description: What Homeless Families Need After a surprise state inspection found several poor families in two city hotels suffering from ''Dickensian'' malnutrition and disease, Governor Cuomo ordered state officials to weigh in with emergency food and health care. His intervention is welcome - especially as it indicates a commitment to a long-term solution.

title: OF DUES WE PAY AND REWARDS WE REAP
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Cuts Power in Toronto
description: A huge underground electrical cable short-circuited and caught fire today, sending clouds of acrid smoke billowing into the air. Power was cut to buildings in a 10- block downtown area near the fire at King and Yonge Streets, but there were no reports of injuries.

title: PANEL NAMED TO STUDY OPERA STRIKE
description: Msgr. James A. Healy, chairman of the State Mediation Board, yesterday announced the complete membership of the panel of special mediators that he has established to examine the New York City Opera labor dispute.

title: THE YANKEES' QUIET VOICE
description: Cast with colleagues who blatantly root for the home team, engage in banter that often becomes sophomoric and spend half the game wishing ''Happy Birthday'' to just about everyone living in the New York metropolitan area, Bill White emerges as the most professional of the Yankee broadcasters. He is the one who can convey a feeling of sympathy for the Yankee cause while at the same time retaining an air of objectivity in the face of the constant turmoil and controversy that surround the team.

title: PEKING DEPLOYS A MISSILE-FIRING NUCLEAR SUB
description: China has developed a nuclear-powered submarine, the Xia, that can fire 16 nuclear missiles at targets 1,800 miles away while submerged, according to the latest edition of Jane's Fighting Ships.

title: BRIEFING
description: On Japan, Off the Record

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pete Vuckovich, the Milwaukee right-hander who won the American League's Cy Young Award last year, has been reactivated by the Brewers. Vuckovich has not played at all this season because of a torn rotator cuff. . . . Aaron Pryor has been permitted to resume training for his defense of the World Boxing Association's junior-welterweight championship against Alexis Arg"uello in Las Vegas on Sept. 9. He had entered a hospital on Friday after complaining of headaches and blurred vision.

title: THE FLOWER MATTERS HERE may well be virtue in
description: helping an endangered species. But this time there's money in it as well.

title: 3 MIDAIR JETLINER INCIDENTS ARE INVESTIGATED
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it was investigating three separate midair incidents involving malfunctioning equipment on scheduled airliners in recent days.

title: PSYCHOLOGISTS AIM TO PLEASE ANIMALS
description: When hogs are added to an existing herd, boars fight and stare each other down to establish social rank within the herd.

title: CUOMO AS EXECUTIVE: TIGHT REIN CRITICIZED
description: Governor Cuomo's staff was nearly unanimous. Michael J. Del Giudice, the secretary, told Mr. Cuomo he should go. Timothy J. Russert, the counselor, told him to go. Lawrence T. Kurlander, the criminal-justice coordinator, told him to go.

title: No Headline
description: Chess:Five Finish in a Tie for First In World Open Tournament

title: Elway Gets No. 1 Job
description: A lot of football fans may have considered the decision foregone, but now Coach Dan Reeves has made it official: John Elway , the superstar from Stanford, is the Denver Broncos' No. 1 quarterback for the season that begins Sept. 4. In making the announcement yesterday, Reeves acknowledged that the veteran Steve DeBerg had been Elway's equal in training camp but added that ''for a guy to be equal as a rookie, he gives you the chance to get better.''

title: LIBERIAN VISITS ISRAEL AMID CONCERN OVER LIBYA
description: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia arrived in Israel today to begin the first state visit here by a black African leader in 12 years.

title: INJURIES OF MURDERED L.I. WOMAN INDICATE SHE STRUGGLED, POLICE SAY
description: A 21- year-old woman whose body was found in her family's home here Saturday had struggled with her assailant before she was bludgeoned to death, the Nassau County Police said today.

description: The U.N. Today Aug. 23, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; THOUGHTS IN SUMMER
description: Favorite Recent Headline: ''Strange Wins.'' Well, that's life sometimes. That was also Curtis Northrup Strange, Sunday at the Sammy Davis Jr.-Greater Hartford Open.

description: When Emile Tubiana visited New York as a tourist 10 years ago, he was struck by the fact that although New York was a great fashion center, it did not have its own big fashion show.

title: John McKiernan, 78, Ex-Commerce Official
description: John F. McKiernan, former New York regional director of the United States Department of Commerce, died Sunday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TEACHERS GET 5-YEAR-OLD'S VIEW OF SCHOOL
description: Everything in Room 638 was just as it would be on the first day of school. Everything, that is, but the students. They sat cramped in the knee-high chairs yesterday, trying to fit their adult frames into seats designed for 5-year-olds while flipping through books with such titles as ''Need a House? Call Ms. Mouse!''

description: Debt Issues

title: AT 2 BRINK'S TRIALS, ACCUSATIONS AND NEW MOTIONS
description: As the prosecution in the state's Brink's trial rested its case today, the three defendants briefly ended their two-week boycott of the courtroom and asked that three men be called to testify for them.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Machismo Flunks Marriage

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: RERUNS So, you're tired of sitting home and watching summer reruns on television. Why not go out to watch the best of reruns that are always available at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street (752-7684). Here are reruns, often spun into new formats, of great shows and performers, some of which you may have missed because they were around before your time.

title: No Headline
description: DR. SEYMOUR M. KATZDr. Seymour M. Katz, associate attending obstetrician and gynecologist at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Weinberger Meets Japanese
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met today with the head of the Japanese Defense Agency, Kazuo Tanikawa. Spokesmen said their talks would focus on security issues, including the increased Soviet presence in Asia.

title: TOWNER PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. Offers Look at Base For Chemical Weapons
description: The United States today invited the delegates to the 40-nation disarmament conference here to visit a United States Army base in Utah where chemical weapons are destroyed.

title: BYERS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $63,000.

title: Abdul-Jabbar May Stay
description: The agent for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar said last night there was a good that the 36-year-old free-agent center would re-sign with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Ira Gershwin Tribute Planned With Broadway Dignitaries
description: A tribute to the lyricist Ira Gershwin, who died last Wednesday, will take place at noon tomorrow in the Gershwin Theater, at 222 West 51st Street.

title: A $100,000 AWARD IS CREATED TO HONOR THOSE AIDING JEWS
description: An annual international prize of $100,000 has been created to honor the man or woman, Jew or non-Jew, who is judged to have done the most in the previous two years ''for the defense of the rights of the Jewish people.''

title: U.S. Said to Protest To Greece on Missiles
description: Western diplomats said today that the United States had protested to Greece over its proposal that the Common Market support a six-month postponement in the scheduled deployment of American missiles in Europe.

title: Search for Thompson
description: The police in Denver say they want to ask David Thompson, the former Nugget basketball player, about his contacts among the city's drug dealers.

title: POP: MADNESS, 'NUTTY BOYS'
description: THERE'S more to Madness than the band let on in Monday's concert at Pier 84. Its seven members wore baggy suits and bopped around the stage like characters in a Mack Sennett movie, and the songs oom-pahed along in British music-hall style with a hint of Jamaican ska and reggae.

title: A RADIO STATION MAY BE UP FOR GRABS
description: In addition to the contest among six contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination, there is another scramble under way in Washington this summer involving high stakes and prominent people, and it has the added dimension of classical music.

title: U.S. Investing Abroad Dips
description: Direct investment abroad by American corporations and individuals fell by 2.2 percent last year, the first decline since 1946, the Commerce Department said today.

title: OHIO RAPE DEFENDANT WAS ESTEEMED AS PHYSICAN
description: A year ago, Dr. Edward Franklin Jackson Jr. was a Columbus internist and hospital board member who had the respect of his peers and a successful practice.

title: Market Place; Stock Choices For Long Haul
description: THE stock market lately has shown a confusing pattern of rising one day and falling the next day. But let us assume that an investor, taking a patient, longer view, is willing to consider stocks that might be bought now and sold just before Labor Day 1984 in hopes of a long-term capital gain. To qualify for such a gain, a security must be held at least one year plus one day.

title: BRIEFING
description: Letting Diplomacy Proceed

title: MISSISSIPPI ATTORNEY GENERAL CLAIMS NOMINATION
description: Bill Allain, the State Attorney General, claimed victory over Evelyn Gandy today as the Democratic nominee for Governor.

title: HOUSTON STORM TOLL: GLASS AND PRIDE
description: When Hurricane Alicia bruised its way through downtown here last Thursday, it inflicted both physical and psychological wounds in a proud, boisterous city.

title: Scott Paper to Sell Unit to General Felt
description: The Scott Paper Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its foam division to General Felt Industries. In addition, it will put up for sale its Brown Jordan division and 240,000 acres of timberland in Washington.

title: C.I.T.'S FACTORING UNIT SUES EX-CHIEF, OTHERS
description: One of the oldest financial services companies for the garment trade, the William Iselin Company, yesterday said that it had sued its former chief executive and two former employees, charging them with conspiring with a large apparel group to defraud Iselin of more than $15 million from 1978 through 1982.

title: Kansas City Bank Plans Takeover
description: Commerce Bancshares said it had agreed to acquire the County Tower Corporation's common shares that it does not already own for $61.50 a share, or a total of about $97.1 million. Commerce Bancshares and its chairman, James M. Kemper, already own 9.4 percent of County Tower's 1,680,000 shares outstanding.

title: South Korean President Says He Will Serve Only One Term
description: President Chun Doo Hwan said today that he would step down in February 1988, as required by law, but he does not plan to call direct presidential elections or abolish a political blacklist for the time being.

title: TOWER PROPOSED FOR CENTRAL PARK WEST
description: An obelisk-shaped apartment tower would rise more than 425 feet on West 70th Street if the Landmarks Preservation Commission approves a plan offered yesterday in a stormy meeting.

title: AN APPEAL FOR A FACE FROM THE DEPRESSION
description: Decades after her careworn, resolute face became a symbol of the grinding poverty of the Depression, Florence Thompson's children are asking for help to save their mother's ebbing life.

title: U.S. Wins In Basketball
description: Wayman Tisdale and Cheryl Miller led the unbeaten United States men's and women's basketball teams to easy victories today at the Pan American Games.

title: Down to Earth
description: Geoffrey Geer, the coach of the cross-country ski team at the University of Colorado, does not agree with the theory that athletes who train at high altitudes have an advantage over those who train at sea level.

title: CABLE TV CONCERN FILES PIRACY SUIT
description: The cable television company that serves the lower half of Manhattan yesterday took its first major legal action to combat the growing problem of cable piracy.

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Careers; New Focus On Job Security
description: THE late Charles E. Merrill, founder of Merrill Lynch & Company, had a strategy for surviving the ups and downs of the business cycle. Companies like his, he said, should increase advertising and other promotional efforts during a recession and then cut back proportionately when the upturn came. If many companies did this, he reasoned, they would keep more customers, stabilize employment and speed the recovery.

title: SONGS EXTOLLING NEW YORK ENJOYING NEW GOLDEN AGE
description: With attitudes ranging from ''New York Is So Exciting'' and ''All the Critics Love U in New York'' to ''I'm Never Going Back to New York City,'' songwriters have been producing a bumper crop of songs about New York.

title: Debt Repaid by Mexico
description: Mexico repaid a $1.85 billion debt to the Bank for International Settlements today, three days before the scheduled signing of a $20 billion debt- restructuring agreement with 500 foreign private banks. The Banco de Mexico said Mexico had repaid in full its debt to the B.I.S., based in Basel, Switzerland. The loan was extended a year ago by central banks of Western nations.

title: PERILIN
description: Panama, once the centerpiece of President Jimmy Carter's Latin American policy, has quietly slipped from view as the United States focuses on the bitter violence elsewhere in Central America. Panama's surface tranquility, however, is threatened by Reagan Administration policies that are likely to undermine the basis for Panama's fragile stability, particularly now during an uneasy period of transition to democracy after 15 years of military rule.

THE CRISIS IN MEDICARE
description: RECENT reports highlight the financial crisis and the need for action in the Medicare program. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the Medicare Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is expected to be bankrupt by 1988 and to accumulate a deficit of more than $300 billion by 1995. Thirty million elderly and disabled Americans rely on the $50 billion Medicare program for assistance in paying their medical bills.

In a statement on Monday from its sales headquarters in Torrance, Calif., the Japanese auto maker said its Van Wagon would carry seven people or more than 1,500 pounds, would be aerodynamically styled and would get at least 24 miles a gallon.

title: FROM START TO FINISH, ZUCCHINI MEAL
description: ONE of the time-honored rules of menu planning is that you should avoid duplicating a particular flavor, texture or ingredient during a given meal. If you serve pasta with tomato sauce, for example, you should not use tomatoes in any other form during the meal, be it in appetizer, soup, salad or main course. Brooke Swenson is an inventive cook with a lively sense of humor who not only has defied that basic tenet but has done so with highly satisfactory results. Not long ago, I heard, she served a meal at her home in Weston, Conn., each course of which consisted of one primary ingredient: zucchini. The interesting thing was that the guests were unaware that every dish they ate was based on it. Only in the salad - made with thin, cold, briefly cooked slices - and in the rice, cooked with grated zucchini, did they detect its presence.

title: PRICES EASE IN PROFIT TAKING
description: Prices fell slightly yesterday for most notes and bonds. Securities dealers said investor demand was weak at the same time as some participants were selling Treasury issues to lock in profits earned when prices rose sharply earlier this month.

description: Rebels killed 2 Soviet mining technicians and took another 24 hostage in an attack on a gem mine in central Mozambique on Sunday, the Portuguese radio reported today.

title: Weather Delays Raising Of Monitor's Anchor
description: Rough seas and thunderstorms forced researchers today to postpone efforts to raise the anchor of the Monitor, the Civil War ironcald that sank in the Atlantic 120 years ago.

title: FARMING THE SEA BOTTOM TO FILL MUSSEL DEMAND
description: THE wind whipped up sheets of rain as the Northern Star II made its way somewhat unsteadily from the small coastal village of Stonington en route south to the Camp Island mussel- lease farm. As Bobby Burgess wrestled the 40-foot fishing boat through a series of choppy channels among the tiny, fir-covered rocky islands of Jericho Bay he wondered about the weather and the beginning of the mussel season.

title: RABBI AARON SHATZKES
description: Rabbi Aaron Shatzkes, a Talmudic scholar on the faculty of Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, an affiliate of Yeshiva University, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Columbia- Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The chief Philippine opposition leader asked today in Parliament how an assassin had been able to approach Benigno S. Aquino Jr. on a heavily guarded airport runway, and why the Government had issued practically no information on Sunday's killing.

title: CONSUMER PRICES INCREASED IN JULY BY MODERATE 0.4%
description: Consumer prices rose a moderate four- tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today. Economists predicted that inflation would continue at about this rate, almost 5 percent a year, for the near future.

title: COMPUTER DISASTER: BUSINESS SEEKS ANTIDOTE
description: Secluded in the countryside near this Catskills town is an office-and-warehouse complex built inside a mountain. Trucks with barely any identifying marks come and go each day, entering the mountain through an opening guarded by a seven-ton steel door and unloading their cargo into one of 12 buildings inside the huge underground cavern.

title: Record Deficit For Australia
description: The Australian Government expects a record budget deficit of $8.36 billion (Australian) for the fiscal year 1984, which began July 1, compared with a deficit of $4.47 billion in the year before, the Treasurer, Paul Keating, told Parliament today.

title: ARGENTINE LEADERS IN WAR WERE INEPT, MILITARY PANEL SAYS
description: The Argentine junta that ordered the invasion of the Falkland Islands demonstrated incompetence in virtually every aspect of the war and should be court-martialed, according to a military investigative commission report that was disclosed to the press today.

title: SRI LANKA'S ABUSE OF HUMAN RIGHTS
description: While world attention has focused on violent conflict in Sri Lanka between the mainly Buddhist Sinhalese majority and largely Hindu Tamil minority, insufficient attention has been paid to the Sri Lanka Government's civil rights record. Yet is it precisely at a time when the Government has been seeking a return to the rule of law and to reduce ethnic conflict, in a country often cited as a model of third-world democratic development, that a demonstration of its respect for rights takes on heightened importance.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HOW hot has it been in the subways this summer? So hot, says Betty Russell, that a bare-chested man in tennis shorts boarded the shuttle at Grand Central the other afternoon carrying a rattan peacock chair. Planting the chair in the middle of the aisle, the man sat down and proceeded to cool himself with a paper fun.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THELONIOUS MONK and Jerry Lee Lewis are not often mentioned in the same breath. But perhaps they should be, and not just because their most important recordings have recently been collected in two compendious reissue albums. Both of them developed innovative, intensely rhythmic, distinctly personal piano styles. Both have been widely imitated by several generations of musicians, yet their music is essentially inimitable. Even a casual listener will recognize Mr. Monk or Mr. Lewis after hearing the first few seconds of one of their records; disks by their imitators sound like imitations.

title: USE OF STEROIDS HAS INCREASED
description: Anabolic steroids, the hormonal compounds that have led to disqualification of athletes at the Pan American Games, are believed to have first been used by sports participants decades ago.
