His days as the head of Great Eastern Mussel Farms' programs in quality control and research and development are spent analyzing the bivalve mollusks to develop criteria to insure that they are uniformly plump, sweet and tender.

title: Iowa Revenue Bonds To Yield Up to 10 5/8%

description: West German crude oil imports fell 9.6 percent, to 38 million tons, in the first seven months of this year compared with the period a year earlier, the Office of Trade and Industry said today. Imports rose 5 percent in July, however, to 5.6 million tons from the level in July 1982.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the Style page yesterday misidentified the designer and the outfit. The flowered silk jacket and pullover with white linen skirt was designed by Bill Blass.

title: EIGHT OPERA UNIONS CALL FOR BINDING ARBITRATION
description: Eight labor unions that have been affected by the New York City Opera orchestra's strike have urged Beverly Sills, the general director of the opera, and John Glasel, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, to accept binding arbitration and to permit an immediate return to work.

title: NEBRASKA BACKFIELD GLITTERS
description: Mike Rozier was not complaining, not at all. He would be among the first to admit that when compared to the existence of most college football players in America, his place as the I-back at the University of Nebraska is rare.

title: Canadian Inflation Dips
description: Canada's annual inflation rate fell to 5.5 percent in July from 5.6 percent in June, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

title: GLADYS FRIES HARRIMAN
description: Gladys Fries Harriman, an American Red Cross volunteer and official for more than 40 years and a noted driver of pacing and trotting horses in the 1920's and 1930's, died yesterday at her home in Arden, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 87 years old.

title: ANAREN MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHAD SAYS REBELS ARE 50 MILES CLOSER TO CAPITAL
description: The Chadian Information Minister said today that Libyan regulars and rebel forces of former President Goukouni Oueddei had moved 50 miles south of Faya-Largeau and ''are preparing new aggression which is intended to lead to the total annexation of Chad.''

title: Charleson Is Acquired
description: U.S. Business Press Inc., a new company backed by the investment banker Dillon, Read & Company and the Keeley Management Company of Radnor, Pa., acquired Charleson Publishing Company, which publishes several trade magazines including Toy & Hobby World, Leisure Time Electronics and Product Marketing. The terms were not disclosed.

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 10 percent stock dividend in May 1983.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
Freddie Mac's New Debentures
description: A $300 million issue of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation 11.85 percent debentures due in 1991 is offered at a price of 100 by the corporation and various securities firms.

title: Miss Hilsenrath Weds Azriel Heuman
description: Chaya Hilsenrath, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Yakov R. Hilsenrath of Highland Park, N.J., was married at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens, yesterday to Azriel Heuman, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Fred Heuman of Brooklyn.

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHAT THE NAVY SHOULD SPEND: A CLASSIC WASHINGTON CLASH
description: Paul Thayer, a captain of industry until he became Deputy Secretary of Defense last January, has found that taking command of the Pentagon apparatus may be more difficult than running a corporation.

title: DEERE NET UP 21.4% IN 3D QUARTER
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment, reported yesterday that net income for the third quarter ended July 31 rose 21.4 percent as a result of a reduction in inventories, but that sales fell. The company also predicted that production will continue low for the rest of the fiscal year.

title: Sale Accord At Weirton
description: The National Steel Corporation has reached a ''definitive agreement'' to sell its Weirton division to employees, which would create the largest employee-owned company in the nation, officials said.

title: A'S BATTER YANK PITCHERS
description: Matt Keough, an insecure Yankee pitcher, indulged himself in some wishful thinking before the game with Oakland last night. ''Maybe if I throw a shutout,'' he said, ''there won't be any more trade talk.''

title: WEDGESTONE REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $176,900 resulting from a change in accounting method.

title: On the Foreign Front
description: The City Council was about to vote yesterday on a resolution urging the United States to ''cease providing military aid to the government of El Salvador and cease all efforts to destabilize the legitimate government of Nicaragua.'' It had been introduced by Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger, a Manhattan Democrat.

title: AMOSKEAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S very likely true that we never see ourselves as others see us, and all in all maybe it's a good thing. But even the characteristics

title: CITY AIDES INSPECT WELFARE HOTELS
description: New York City Health Department officials spent yesterday checking conditions at about 50 welfare hotels and city shelters. They set up medical examinations for about 7,000 children living in the hotels and shelters, and arranged to have food sent to the displaced people who live there.

title: KOCH ASSAILS CUOMO ON HOTEL ISSUE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that statements by Governor Cuomo over the weekend about malnourished children in two city welfare hotels were an ''unfair attack'' on the city and were based on misinformation.

title: SEVEN DECADES ON THE TRAIL OF THE TRUFFLE
description: HE is an old man and he works alone, except for his little dog. ''This is a very secret business,'' Edmond Lauvinerie explained through an interpreter. ''That is why I have no neighbors.''

title: TV BARGAIN ON OLYMPICS FOR SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union's broadcasting authorities have bought television rights to the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics for a fraction of what the American Broadcasting Companies will spend to bring fewer hours of the Summer Games to the American public, according to a report in the forthcoming issue of TV Guide.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
SEN. TOWER SAYS HE WON'T RUN FOR SEAT IN '84
description: Senator John Tower of Texas, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and one of President Reagan's strongest allies on military matters, announced today that he would not seek re-election in 1984.

title: FRENCH VIEWS OF CHAD: PRIDE, ANGER, DOUBT
description: ''Some things are more important than Chad - like food.''

title: CSX, Phone Unit In Joint Venture
description: The CSX Corporation and the Southern New England Telephone Company announced they would build a long-distance communications network that would extend up to 5,000 miles and whose lines will run mainly along the track corridors used by CSX's railroads.

title: Carlton Sues Agent
description: For 10 years David Landfield handled the business and financial affairs of Steve Carlton, Philadelphia's star pitcher, and in spring training negotiated a contract with the Phillies that made his client the highest-paid pitcher in baseball. Now Carlton feels that Landfield, of Oldsmar, Fla., has rewarded himself too generously over the years, and he has filed a suit in United States District Court in Philadelphia accusing the agent of embezzling more than $100,000 since 1973.

title: SANDINISTA FOES MAY MERGE
description: Representatives from two anti-Sandinista organizations are expected to announce a merger on Sept. 15, according to an official from one of the groups.

title: U.S. IS WITHDRAWING AIRCRAFT IT SENT TO HELP CHAD
description: The United States announced today that the two Awacs electronic surveillance planes and eight F-15 fighter escorts sent to buttress Chad against Libyan- backed rebels were being withdrawn from the area because they were no longer needed.

title: Required Reading Proxmire's Reverie
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, in a Senate speech denouncing a Treasury Department study that, according to the Senator, contended that continuing large deficits might help increase economic growth, Aug. 4, 1983:

title: ACS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARK
description: THE Great Lawn in Central Park begins to look like the Great Sandbox toward the end of every August. After hundreds of thousands of pairs of feet have found their way close to the concert stage, for a multitude of summer events, it is no surprise that the lawn's natural green is ultimately trampled into a sandy brown.

title: BLUE JAYS' 5-RUN 4TH ROUTS ORIOLES BY 9-3
description: A two-run single by Barry Bonnell in the fourth inning capped a five-run Toronto rally as the Blue Jays routed the Orioles tonight, 9-3. Baltimore aided the rally by making three errors.

title: MASSACHUSETS CLAIMS TINY, UNCHARTED ISLAND
description: A tiny strip of sand between Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Island was invaded by a group of claimants Sunday and unofficially named Hauser Island as a maneuver in a jurisdictional dispute between Massachusetts and the Federal Government.

title: MUSIC: SLATKIN CONDUCTS
description: WHEN Leonard Slatkin conducted one of Haydn's minor symphonies as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night, the performance was so tasteful, intelligent and insightful that even the most insignificant of moments became a demonstration of the composer's genius and influence.

title: L.I.R.R. AND UNION CONFER IN MOVE TO AVERT STRIKE
description: In an attempt to avert a new strike by the carmen's union threatened for 12:01 A.M. Friday, officials of the Long Island Rail Road and the union met yesterday to try to put into writing the terms of a new contract they thought they had agreed upon three weeks ago.

title: GIANTS RELEASE SHIRK
description: The Giants today released four players, including the veteran Gary Shirk, and placed three more on injured reserve as the team ended one of its most competitive training camps in recent seasons.

title: Ramsey and Nets Seem Compatible
description: Kelvin Ransey, the 6-foot-2-inch guard who was acquired by the Nets from the Dallas Mavericks on Aug. 12, says that he has finally arrived with a National Basketball Association team on which his many skills will be employed and appreciated.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a charge of $57 million for the quarter for plant closings, early retirements and other costs, partly offset by credits of $20 million from nonoperating items and a tax credit of $2 million for the 9 months.

title: SCOUTING
description: Sharing Lockers

title: There's More Than One String to a Fiddle
description: Looking deceptively demure in pastel blouses, the String Fever band ripped into a selection of blues and rock music Monday night in Lincoln Center's north plaza. Nearly all the band members are women, and all but one are string players.

title: Goldilocks Finds A Home in Brooklyn
description: This summer's hottest performers? Arguably, the Three Bears, in bear suits, doing ''Goldilocks'' at the Penny Bridge Players, the Brooklyn Heights theater for children at 59 Cranberry Street.

title: Threshold Plan
description: Threshold Technology Inc. said it had filed a reorganization plan with the United States Bankruptcy Court that provides for its unsecured creditors to receive 25 percent of the allowed claims against the company in cash. The plan also provides for funding of about $3 million to support continued technology research and product development, the company said. Threshold, which makes automatic speech recognition equipment, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act in November 1982.

title: Accounts
description: * Club Med to Ogilvy & Mather Direct.

title: WINE TALK
description: A cabernet sauvignon wine made in 1979 by a winery called Quilceda Creek Vintners won a gold medal here Sunday at the annual wine competition sponsored by the Enological Society of the Pacific Northwest. More than that, it won a grand prize, only the second time any wine has been so honored in the seven years this judging has been held.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Unforgivable in Argentina
description: In the late 1970's thousands of Argentines, perhaps as many as 30,000, disappeared. Most are presumed to have been kidnapped and killed by the military. Thousands more were tortured and much personal and business property was seized.

title: DURABLE COOKWARE
description: SEVERAL qualities must be looked for when buying pots and pans for home or commercial use. First is the thickness, or gauge, of the utensil, whatever it is made of. I never buy a saucepan or skillet that is light and thin, no matter how inexpensive it may be, because in the long run it invariably buckles over high heat.

title: ARTEL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BLOCK SEES NO '84 PLAN TO CUT FEED GRAIN CROP
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, citing extensive drought damage to this year's corn and sorghum crops, expressed further doubts today that there would be another payment-in- kind program next year for corn and other feed grains.

title: LOW TEACHER PAY AND STATUS FAULTED
description: A study on the condition of American school teaching released today concludes that it is in a crisis, primarily because of low professional status and low teacher salaries.

title: REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TERRELL WINS, HITS 3D HOMER
description: Walt Terrell hit a single, double and his third home run of the season tonight, tying a Met record for home runs by a pitcher in a season, as he stopped the Padres, 8-3.

title: Coast Jury Gets Case In Slaying of 13 at Club
description: The case of Benjamin Ng, accused in the slaying of 13 people last February at a Chinatown gambling club, went to the jury today after a prosecutor described Mr. Ng as the main killer.

title: U.S. AND CANADA IN ACID-RAIN ACCORD
description: The United States and Canada agreed today to conduct a joint project to trace the flow of pollutants that cause acid rain.

title: G.M. DIVISION VOTES ON TWO-LEVEL PAY
description: Workers at the General Motors Packard Electric division were voting today on a contract proposal that would drastically cut wages for new employees.

title: YOUTH OFFICIAL IS FATALLY SHOT NEAR HIS CAR
description: A director of Children's Village, the 132-year-old social-service agency for troubled children in Westchester County and New York City, was fatally shot Monday evening as he was parking his car in front of one of the agency's facilities in Queens.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell Group Ltd., Sydney, Australia, which last week announced a $3.5 billion takeover offer for Broken Hill, Australia's largest company and only steel manufacturer, said that the formal documents for the bid should be filed this week.

title: IRAN REPAYS EXPORT-IMPORT BANK $419.5 MILLION TO SATISFY CLAIMS
description: Iran has paid the Export-Import Bank $419.5 million to settle claims arising from the seizure of American hostages in 1979, according to a joint announcement today by the lending agency and the Treasury.

title: PEGASUS GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RADIATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in August.

title: DANCE: LERMAN COMPANY AT WORKSHOP
description: WHAT is political satire to some may be just social commentary or sophomoric nose-thumbing to others. Liz Lerman, a popular modern-dance choreographer from Washington, touched all bases in a performance with her Dance Exchange company Monday in the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater, where they appeared as part of Dance Theater Workshop's Out-of-Towners series.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOOD DISTRIBUORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $81,000. c-Includes tax credits of $32,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the 6 months, and a real estate gain of $529,000 for the 6 months.

title: RESORT & URBAN TIMESHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue in the year-ago quarter consists of interest income. Resort & Urban Timeshares acquired its operating unit, Sweetwater, in July 1982. It said results for the latest quarter are not comparable to year-ago quarter results.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
France-Japan Venture
description: Rh^one- Poulenc, the state chemical enterprise, today announced an agreement with the Mitsui Petrochemical Company of Japan to produce polyamide resins. A joint subsidiary will make a special resin called PABM, which is useful at high temperatures.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, Ill., has named Jack W. Schuler group vice president.

title: INJURY FELLS A FAVORITE IN TENNIS
description: Andrea Temesvari of Hungary, ranked 10th in the world in women's tennis and one of the favorites to win here, retired in the second set with an injury tonight in a match against Camille Benjamin and was eliminated from the Virginia Slims New Jersey tournament at Ramapo College.

title: I.M.F. Help For Morocco
description: The International Monetary Fund agreed tentatively to provide about $300 million of assistance to Morocco, monetary sources said today.

title: SOME U.S. ATHLETES LEAVE GAMES AT CARACAS AMID STIFF DRUG TESTS
description: Thirteen male track and field athletes from the United States voluntarily flew home from the Pan American Games today, only hours before the start of competition in their sport.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday on news that inflation increased in July. Trading was slower.

title: WARNING ISSUED ON ANESTHETIC FOR CHILDBIRTH
description: The Government, citing the cases of 20 pregnant women whose hearts stopped during labor, recommended today that a widely used local anesthetic no longer be used at its highest concentration for obstetrical procedures.

title: By Donald Westlake;
description: KINGS IN THE COUNTING HOUSE. By

title: No Headline
description: Quotation of the Day

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
SFN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Free Philharmonic Concert
description: The New York Philharmonic will give a free outdoor concert at 12:30 P.M. today at Castle Clinton in Battery Park. The concert will mark the first midday performance in the orchestra's 19-year history of parks concerts, as well as its first Battery Park performance since 1846. James Conlon, music director of the Rotterdam Philharmonic and a native New Yorker, will conduct a program of Liszt and Dvorak, including Dvorak's ''New World'' Symphony.

title: People
description: * David J. Farenholt has joined the Bachman Company, Reading, Pa., as vice president, marketing.

title: AT MOSCOW'S TACKY TRACK, MARX IS LONG SHOT
description: It is not Belmont Park or Hialeah. But where it matters - out on the track and among bettors jostling each other at the rail - Moscow's Hippodrome offers all the fun, the stable intrigue, the triumph and despair that make horse racing a popular sport wherever it is held.

title: Pioneer Texas
description: The Pioneer Texas Corporation said it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws as a result of liquidity problems and its inability to pay interest on its subordinated debt outstanding.

title: CHILD CUSTODY TRIAL FOCUSES ON SECT BEATINGS
description: Whether 66 children should be returned to their parents, members of the Black Hebrew Israelite Jews, will be determined at a trial in Allegan, Mich., where jury selection is set to begin Wednesday.

title: California Offers $150 Million Issue
description: A $150 million issue of Aa-rated California bonds is offered at yields ranging from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.2 percent in 1993, 9.1 percent in 2003 and 9.2 percent in 2009, through underwriters led by the First Interstate Bank of California.

title: FLYING FRISBEES ATTRACT COMPETITORS
description: IT was a cross between a no-budget Woody Allen movie and a ballet in tennis shoes.

title: 13 ARE CHARGED WITH OPERATING BIG HEROIN RING
description: Eight men, one of them a lawyer, were arrested yesterday at their homes in Queens and Long Island and charged with being part of what the Federal Bureau of Investigation described as ''a massive narcotics importation and distribution ring'' that brought heroin from Southeast Asia to Florida and New York.

title: Schoolboy Dies After a Tryout
description: A 16-year-old student at Glen Head (L.I.) High School collapsed and died yesterday shortly after trying out for the school's football team, the Nassau County police said.

title: Miss Reagan Is Hired As Adviser on Women
description: President Reagan's spokesman confirmed today that Maureen Reagan, the President's daughter, had been hired by the Republican National Committee as a consultant to improve her father's image among women.

title: Bridge: Lightnerrong Side in the Regionals
description: The late Theodore Lightner often gets the blame for disasters associated with his famous slam double - a request for an unexpected opening lead. He was unpopular once again on the diagramed deal, played Sunday in the District 3 Regional Swiss Team Championship in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Betty Ann Colhoun, 57, Dies; Headed a Community Center
description: Betty Ann Colhoun, former president of the Goddard-Riverside Community Center in Manhattan, died of cancer Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. She was 57 years old and lived in Tarpon Springs, Fla., and Boothbay, Me.

title: BEACH BARGE IS GROUNDED BY THE CITY
description: The idea was to put a bit of the Bahamas - a beach and beautiful people and pina coladas - on the bank of the East River.

title: MCI Off 4 7/8 on F.C.C. Ruling
description: A decision by the Federal Communications Commission on telephone company access charges sent the stock of the MCI Communications Corporation plummeting 4 7/8 yesterday to 15 1/4, bid, in over-the-counter trading.

title: CHINA SIGNS OIL PACTS
description: China signed oil exploration contracts today with the Exxon Corporation and the Shell Oil Company, the third series of oil pacts China has signed since May.

title: HOW STARS OF 'LA CAGE' GREW INTO THEIR ROLES
description: For some time after he had agreed to take on the part of Albin in the musical ''La Cage aux Folles,'' George Hearn used to wake up suddenly in the middle of the night. ''I'd bolt upright and think, 'I'm going to do what ?' '' Mr. Hearn said, clapping his hands to his head and doubling over in mock anguish. ''I couldn't believe I was going to do that in front of God and everyone - in Times Square, no less.''

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Reduced by $3,000,000 due to the reduction of excess manufacturing capacity at the Process Machinery and Railway Equipment divisions.

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 24, 1983 International
description: President Reagan ascribed ''hype and theatrics'' to what he called the peace movement and contended that its backers ''would wage peace by weakening the free.'' Addressing the American Legion, Mr. Reagan said that ''the members of the real peace movement - the real peacemakers - are people like you.'' He exhorted the veterans to press Congress for continued financing of the MX missile. (Page A1, Column 4.) A Philippine opposition leader asked in Parliament how an assassin had been able to approach Benigno S. Aquino Jr. on a heavily guarded airport runway, and why the Government has made public practically no information about Sunday's murder. Salvador H. Laurel, one of the few opposition members of Parliament, also expressed other doubts and questions about the slaying of the country's best-known opposition leader. (A1:1.)

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ACID RAIN'S CAUSES AND EFFECTS: THE ANSWERS ARE IN
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Chrysler Warrants Up For Bid Soon

title: President's Party Wins Nigerian Senate Races
description: President Shehu Shagari's National Party of Nigeria scored a sweeping victory in Senate elections today and anticipated another big win in House of Representatives races this weekend.

title: No Headline
description: Crutchfield to Face Saints

title: AT JEWISH HOME, MAKING THE GOLDEN YEARS GOLDEN
description: ''Nothing gets me down except the elevator,'' said James Hodge, who at the age of 85 retains the bright alertness he showed for the 30 years he served as a dining-car waiter on the New Haven Railroad.

title: WINN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,999,000 from the sale of headquarters property.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock splits paid Dec. 7, 1982 and June 8, 1983.

title: LAND OF LINCOLN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
African Students Protest
description: A noisy protest by 200 black students at University of the Witwatersrand ended today after officials said they were violating the law. The students, in support of guerrillas fighting South African control of South-West Africa, disrupted a talk by a former fighter for the South-West Africa People's Organization.

title: DeLorean And a Broker Sued by Investors
description: In a Federal lawsuit filed here today, a group of investors charged that the auto maker John Z. DeLorean and the brokerage firm of Oppenheimer & Company had conspired to misappropriate $18.7 million in research and development funds.

title: ST. LOUIS STUDENTS BUSED TO SUBURBS
description: After 11 years of courtroom maneuvering, Federal intervention and legal appeals, 300 black students rode buses from the city to the suburbs today on the first day of St. Louis's voluntary desegregation plan.

title: METS DEFEATED, 3-2, BY LOLLAR
description: Tim Lollar outpitched Tom Seaver and hit a run- scoring triple tonight to lead the San Diego Padres to a 3-2 victory over the Mets.

title: WATER MAIN BREAK ON EAST SIDE STOPS SUBWAY FOR HOURS
description: An aging water main burst on the East Side at 6:15 A.M. yesterday, flooding streets, knocking out major subway lines and snarling traffic during the morning rush.

title: Study Finds Caffeine Spurs Breast Cancer in Female Rats
description: A two-year study on female rats indicates that caffeine promotes the growth of breast cancer cells, a group of researchers from Michigan State University has reported.

title: Tulane Apologizes
description: A Tulane graduate assistant who was caught spying on a Mississippi State football practice was acting on his own, university officials said in apologizing for the incident.

title: ORIGIN OF PAPERS IN REAGAN CASE ELUDING PANEL
description: The special counsel to a House subcommittee said today that the panel had yet to decide how to resolve conflicting accounts by two senior Administration officials over how Ronald Reagan's campaign obtained President Carter's political strategy papers in 1980.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES UP 19.8%
description: New-car sales continued to show year-to-year gains in the mid-August period, with the Big Three auto makers today reporting a 19.8 percent improvement from the same period in 1982. But the rate of recovery from depressed levels a year ago has slowed because of low dealer inventories and the elimination of incentives for buyers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: AT THE CASTLE In its years of summer touring in city parks, the New York Philharmonic has always performed after dark. Today, however, the 95 musicians, led by James Conlon, will break precedent with a free concert at 12:30 P.M. at that most historical of local sites, Battery Park, in front of Castle Clinton, the old fort at Manhattan's southern tip.

title: MUSICIANS' TIES TO NAZIS STILL A SUBJECT OF DEBATE
description: FIFTY years after Hitler came to power, tales about musicians during the Nazi period still have the capacity to shock. In the 1930's, for example, the late conductor Karl B"ohm would offer the Hitler salute at his concerts. Following Hitler's victory in the elections of 1936, B"ohm even paid homage to his F"uhrer with a written message: ''Nazism has set the musician a goal and a task to which it is worthwhile to apply all our talent and our strength, namely, the service of the German people and its cultural heritage.''

title: Stocks Decline; Dow at 1,184.25, off 8.64
description: Stock prices declined moderately yesterday in continued slow trading, with some of the technology and retailing issues posting the largest losses.

title: ADVERTISING ; USA Today Announces Expansion, Reshuffling
description: USA Today said it will begin distribution of the newspaper to the Boston- New England and Cleveland markets on Sept. 12 and to the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Oct. 3.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SCREENS THAT ROLL UP
description: IF you have a window of odd

title: No Headline
description: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan A Comeback For Aluminum

title: Dutch Volvo Unit Gains
description: Volvo Car BV's president, A. Deleye, said today that the company expected to produce more than 100,000 cars this year, up from slightly more than 90,000 last year.

title: EUROPE'S GYPSIES HEAR THE CALL OF THE EVANGELICALS
description: The beautiful young woman, dressed all in white, with a white ribbon that cut through her black hair like a quarter- moon on a night sky, walked onto center stage. She stepped into a two-foot- tall, plastic child's wading pool. It was blue and white and decorated with clouds, colored flowers and Walt Disney caricatures of birds, fish and happy cocker spaniels.

title: Sex-Tapes Lawyer Charged in False Report
description: Robert K. Steinberg, the lawyer who told a story of having videotapes showing Government officials at sex parties, has been indicted for filing a false police report saying the tapes were stolen, officials said today.

title: LOCAL PRESIDENT ASSIALS CITY OPERA AND UNIONS
description: John Glasel, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, yesterday accused the leaders of eight New York City Opera unions of ''betrayal,'' and attacked the opera's administration, under the direction of Beverly Sills, for ''mismanagement.''

title: HMW Files To Block Offer
description: HMW Industries Inc. said it had filed in Federal District Court in New York for an injunction to block a partial tender offer begun last Friday by the Clabir Corporation. HMW also urged its shareholders to reject the offer for about 44 percent of HMW shares at $38 a share.

title: Rough Seas Prevent Raising Of Civil War Vessel's Anchor
description: A ship trying to recover the anchor of the Civil War vessel Monitor headed for calmer seas today when a tropical storm caused rough waters.

title: SMUCKER, J M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRIEFS
description: Bell & Howell Co., Chicago, and its education subsidiary, Devry Inc., said they had settled with the Department of Education a lawsuit relating to the federally insured student loan program.

title: BLOCK, H & R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
20-YEAR-OLD IS CONVICTED IN DEATHS OF 13 IN SEATTLE
description: Benjamin Ng, a 20-year-old immigrant from Hong Kong, was found guilty today of taking part in the murder of 13 Chinese- Americans in a Chinatown gambling den. He could face the death penalty.

title: 16 SUMMER SLAYINGS HAVE CITY GROPING FOR REASON
description: County investigators today released a composite sketch of a possible suspect in four of the 16 unsolved killings this summer that have shaken this Chicago suburb.

title: Cyanamid License
description: The American Cyanamid Company said it had signed an agreement with Technical Developments and Investments, a Swiss corporation, that gives Cyanamid an exclusive license in the United States, Canada and Mexico for a new anticancer agent.

title: GROWING JAPANESE ROLE IN CALIFORNIA BANKING
description: Mitsubishi Bank's $282 million bid for the Bancal Tristate Corporation underscores the growing presence of the Japanese in California banking.

title: 5 G.E. REACTORS TO SHUT FOR CHECKS FOR CRACKS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered temporary closings before the end of the year of five General Electric nuclear reactors to check for cracks in cooling pipes.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Saturday misidentified the manufacturer of Bubblicious gum. It is made by the Warner-Lambert Company.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF DISCERNS CALL TO UPGRADE NATION'S SCHOOLS
description: Secretary of Education T.

title: ELECTRONIC THEATRE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: MOZART CHAMBER QUINTET
description: ONLY rarely does a listener sit in a concert hall and hope that microphones are also present to document a performance. But that was the case at the Mostly Mozart festival concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night. Mozart's Quintet for Piano and Winds in E flat (K. 452) - which Mozart, even as late as 1784, felt was ''the best work I have written so far'' - was so supplely and subtly played, that the performance was, in the best sense, delightful.

title: HANDCRAFTED DESKS IN HAMPTONS SHOW
description: ''THE DESK'' is the theme for an exhibition of new handcrafted furniture at the Pritam & Eames gallery in East Hampton, L.I. Sixteen craftsmen are showing their desks, and that term covers a variety of forms, ranging from the flat-top writing table to closed secretaries.

title: U.S. WEARS 2 HATS AMID CHILE UNREST
description: In the face of rising civil unrest in Chile, the Reagan Administration has tried to distance itself somewhat from the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, according to senior American officials.

title: U.S. WINS USE OF HONDURAS LAND
description: A Federal District judge here today dismissed a lawsuit by an American citizen asking that United States soldiers who are training soldiers from El Salvador on his Honduran ranch limit the range of their activities.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $407,500. c-Includes tax credits of $214,300 for the quarter and $1,264,300 for the year.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: For years, the Kemper family has dominated banking in Kansas City, Mo. No foreign entanglements for them. Commerce Bancshares - with James M. Kemper Jr. as chairman and his son, David W. Kemper, as president - has a total overseas exposure of just $3 million.

title: No Headline
description: Bargaining With an Assassin Has Michael Townley, who built and planted the car bomb that killed the Chilean exile Orlando Letelier and his American assistant, gotten away with murder? That's what it looks like in the wake of a court ruling that after serving a light sentence in this country he need not be extradited to Argentina to face a similar assassination charge. Instead he is headed for freedom and a new identity under the Federal witness protection program.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. Watt Takes Gleeful Refuge Interior Secretary James Watt recently discovered that the National Audubon Society allows oil and gas drilling on its Rainey wildlife sanctuary in Louisiana. Bubbling with glee at what he perceived as his critics' inconsistency, Mr. Watt wrote the chairman to congratulate him and ask a sardonic favor: ''I will appreciate your efforts to keep the National Audubon Society from criticizing the Reagan Administration for policies it obviously so thoroughly embraces for itself.''

title: SCOUTING
description: Love of Baseball Inspires Bill Lee

title: Japanese Sale in Turkey
description: A Japanese consortium has won a $75.7 million order for hydroelectric power plant equipment from Turkey, the Nissho Iwai Corporation said today. Its partners are Hitachi Ltd., the Toshiba Corporation, the Fuji Electric Company and the NPC Engineering Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: Toyota Profit $829 Million TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP) - The

title: George T. Chew Wed To Marilynn K. Yee
description: Marilynn K. Yee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kee Wing Yee of Sacramento, Calif., was married in Manhattan yesterday to George Theng Chew, son of Mr. and Mrs. Siow J. Chew of Brooklyn. City Clerk David N. Dinkins performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Municipal Building.

title: MINERAL RESOURCES INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ANNE FRANK HOUSE FOR PHILADELPHIA
description: A group of Philadelphia residents is turning a 200-year-old house into a memorial to Anne Frank, the young Jewish girl whose diary spoke of faith in mankind despite the horrors of Nazi persecution.

title: Police Said to Beat 60 Zairian Dissidents
description: About 60 opponents of President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire were kicked and beaten by the police in Zaire after four of them met with members of the United States Congress, the newspaper De Morgen said today.

title: Assurance by China on Oil
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang assured foreign oil contractors today that China would not nationalize any oil discoveries, and that China would not abandon its policy of seeking foreign skills in developing oil resources.

title: SOONER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $645,000 for the quarter and year for a valuation reserve because of anticipated losses on certain real estate holdings, and pre-tax gains from the sale of securities, property, real estate, and loans of $1,577,000 for the quarter and $4,310,000 for the year. c-Net loss after gains from the sale of securities, property, real estate, and loans of $969,000 for the quarter and $5,286,000 for the year.

title: ANOTHER NO. 1 RATING TO JAPAN
description: There has been no lack of studies showing that Japanese automobiles and electronic equipment are generally higher in quality than their American competitors.

title: TIME ENERGY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, AUGUST 25, 1983
description: The Economy New-car sales by the Big Three auto makers rose 19.8 percent during the mid-August selling period, a slower pace than earlier. Ford's sales were up 23.6 percent, while Chrysler reported a 19.2 percent rise and G.M. one of 18.5 percent. The annual selling rate for all domestic companies dropped to 6.2 million units from 7.9 million units in early August. Analysts cited a shortage of cars and the elimination of most incentive programs. (Page D1.) The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said some homeowners have been overcharged by lenders when the homeowners assumed mortgages. The corporation, which owns about 1.6 million mortgages, wasn't sure how many overcharges had occurred. It asked homeowners who felt they might deserve a refund to call its Washington headquarters. (D1.)

title: AUSTRON INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
NO-HIT BID BY RAINEY HALTED WITH 2 OUT IN 9TH
description: Chuck Rainey of the Chicago Cubs pitched hitless ball for eight and two-thirds innings today before Eddie Milner singled to center field for Cincinnati's only hit as the Cubs defeated the Reds, 3-0.

title: No Headline
description: Semifinals For Stamford WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug.

title: LIBERIAN ATTACKS LIBYAN AMBITION
description: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia said today that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, was sending bribes, terrorists and ammunition throughout Africa in an effort to overthrow governments and take over the continent.

title: Beatrice Unit Sold
description: The Beatrice Food Company said it had completed the sale of its animal byproduct processing operations and is also considering the divestiture of its confections business. The sale was part of the company's announced plan to realign by selling about 50 companies that do not conform with its new strategic direction. Beatrice also said that it expected to close the sale of eight more companies within the next 30 days.

title: Mesa Selling Unit
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it had agreed in principle to sell its Mesa Australia Ltd. unit to Western Mining Corporation Holdings Ltd., an Australian concern, for $35.4 million. Mesa, based in Amarillo, Tex., said the sale is expected to be completed before the end of next month. It said it would retain a 5 percent overriding royalty in the approximately 3.7 million net acres held by Mesa Australia in exploration permits in Australia.

title: Transactions
description: Activated Chris Chambliss, first baseman, from disabled list, and Donnie Moore, pitcher; optioned Larry Owen, catcher, and Tony Brizzolara, to Richmond of the International League. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Buzzie Bavasi announced he will give up his duties as general manager but retain his title as general manager and financial manager. DETROIT (AL) - Acquired Glenn Abbott, pitcher, from Seattle on waivers; sent Mike Laga, first baseman-outfielder, to Evansville of the American Association. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Recalled Porfi Altamirano, pitcher, Len Matuszek, first baseman, and Alejandro Sanchez, outfielder, all from Portland of the Pacific Coast League, and Don Carman and Tony Ghelfi, pitchers, Darren Daulton, catcher, and Jeff Stone, outfielder, from Reading of the Eastern League. TORONTO (AL) - Reactivated Mike Morgan, pitcher; optioned Matt Williams, pitcher, to Syracuse of the International League. BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Waived Derrick Hord of Kentucky and Dwight Jones of Cincinnati; released Mel McClaughlin of Central Michigan. FOOTBALL BALTIMORE (AFC) - Placed Elmer Bailey, wide receiver, Paul Columbia, tight end, and Carlton Finister, fullback, on waivers; acquired Marcus Gilbert. running back, from Washington, Victor Oatis, wide receiver, from Philadelphia, and Preston Brown, wide receiver, from New England, all on waivers. CHICAGO (NFC) - Jim Finks resigned as general manager and executive vice president. Placed Dan Plater and Oliver Williams, wide receivers, on the injured reserve list. CINCINNATI (AFC) - Acquired Andy Gibler, tight end, on waivers from Cleveland. DALLAS (NFC) - Cut Stephen Johnson, tackle, and Darrell Songy, defensive back. HOUSTON (AFC) - Waived Ken Burrough, wide receiver.

title: 26 TEEN-AGERS KILLED, 6 MISSING AS ROOF FALLS AT A TAIWAN SCHOOL
description: The roof of a high school collapsed on hundreds of students during heavy rains today, killing 26 and burying 6 other teen-agers under tons of concrete and steel rubble.

title: SOUTH AFRICA CALLS CUBANS SOLE SNAG ON NAMIBIA
description: South Africa said today that ''all outstanding issues'' blocking independence for South-West Africa had now been settled except for the presence of 23,000 Cuban troops in Angola.

title: Youth Kills Himself Over Broken Romance
description: An 18- year-old who ''couldn't stand the pain'' of breaking up with his girl friend became the sixth teen-ager this year and the third in a week to commit suicide in this Dallas suburb, the authorities said.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Finance/New Issues report in Business Day Tuesday misstated the number of shares in a proposed stock offering by Medmaster Systems Inc. It is 700,000.

title: SIMMS MAY START IN SEASON OPENER
description: Bill Parcells picked up a third- down pass-catching halfback today and then dropped more hints that the player who might be passing for the Giants this season was the same as the one in 1981 before his career was interrupted by injuries.

title: VITAMIN IS LINKED TO NERVE DAMAGE
description: People who take too much vitamin B6, popular among health faddists and women with menstrual swelling, risk numbness, loss of sensation and even crippling themselves, doctors warned today.

title: TV NETWORKS VYING FOR A JUMP ON FALL SEASON
description: ''This year was going along quite nicely,'' said Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment. ''It seemed like nobody was going to be doing a lot of tricks, but all of a sudden it's as if we are slowly moving into all-out war before the fall season gets started.''

title: U.S. STOPS SALE OF AM STEREO ITEM
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday ordered the Harris Corporation to halt production of a device that permits monaural AM radio stations to broadcast in stereo and to notify its customers to shut their units down.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Chargers Acquire Carr
description: The San Diego Chargers, concerned about injuries to their all-pro wide receiver Wes Chandler , obtained Roger Carr from the Seattle Seahawks for undisclosed draft choices. The 31-year-old Carr, who made his reputation in Baltimore when he caught most of his 269 National Football League passes, wanted a guaranteed contract.

title: SUCCESSFUL DESIGN SOLUTIONS FOR BROWNSTONE GARDENS
description: MANY brownstone gardens are both an asset and a problem: they promise to bring outdoor space into the lives of nature-starved New Yorkers, but the spaces themselves are usually small and sometimes damp, and they often lack light and privacy. The high canopies of the aspiring ailanthus and other city trees compound both the promise and the problem of a back garden by providing greenery that obscures the sun.

title: Swiss Choose German Tank
description: The General Dynamics Corporation lost a sales battle today when Switzerland announced it would equip its army with a West German tank rather than a General Dynamics model.

title: Low-Power TV Sites
description: The Federal Communications Commission, which is to hold an auction Sept. 29 to allot the first licenses for low-power television stations, today identified seven locations for allotment.

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shares outstanding figures include incremental shares for employee stock options.

title: STORMS IN SOUTH EASE HEAT WAVE
description: Thunderstorms broke nearly a week of oppressive heat in the Southeast yesterday, starting dozens of fires, cutting off power in some areas and causing at least one death.

title: HARDEE FARMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Year-ago results are not available because of a change in the fiscal year- end to March 31.

title: JAZZ: ROSCOE MITCHELL
description: -garde, Roscoe Mitchell qualifies as an iconoclast. He uses ideas from Western and non-Western classical music, as well as the jazz tradition, to write music that swings like mad or, deliberately, doesn't swing at all.

title: ARGENTINE WHO FILED SCANDAL SUITS IS SEIZED
description: A right- wing nationalist who has filed a number of court cases charging political and military scandals was kidnapped here this morning as he left his home, the police said.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A SOUND APPROACH ON INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: Does the United States need a Department of International Trade and Industry (modeled after Japan's MITI) or a new Reconstruction Finance Corporation (fashioned from our own experience in the Depression)? While Congress and the academic community debate that question, the Administration is demonstrating that the President already has substantial power to shape industrial policy. The Administration's actions, while tentative, are a step in the right direction and should be pursued.

description: THE next thing to be computerized might be

title: Hawaii Housing
description: An issue of Hawaii Housing Authority mortgage revenue bonds was reduced to $30 million from $50 million and offered with a maximum yield of 10.33 percent for 10 1/4 percent bonds due in 2014. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.75 percent in 1995, with 10 percent bonds due in 2001 offered with a 10.06 percent yield. The issue had been tentatively priced through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets to yield a maximum 10.2 percent.

title: CASE FOR ASYLUM
description: Two cases, two human situations: consider what they say about official United States attitudes toward people seeking refuge from tyranny.

title: Lawyer to Join Safety Board
description: President Reagan today announced the nomination of Sandra Brown Armstrong, a Justice Department trial attorney, to a seven-year term as a member of the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Mrs. Armstrong, who is 36 years old, would succeed Edith Barksdale Sloan.

title: MANVILLE THRIVING IN BANKRUPTCY, SHIELDED FROM ASBESTOS LAWSUITS
description: A year after the Manville Corporation said it was ''completely overwhelmed'' by asbestos-related lawsuits and obtained protection under the Federal bankruptcy laws, its business has surged and it has acquired a huge portfolio of cash and marketable securities.

title: Allied Bancshares
description: Allied Bancshares Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Texas United Bancorp Inc. through an exchange of stock valued at about $46 million.

title: Iraq Says It Destroyed Four Iranian Vessels
description: Iraq said today that its ships and aircraft destroyed four large Iranian naval targets north of Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal in the Persian Gulf.

title: VIDEO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $39,000. c-Net loss after losses and costs amounting to $1,161,000 from the Direct Mail business which was discontinued in January 1982.

title: SCOTT NEARING, ENVIRONMENTALIST, PACIFIST AND RADICAL, DIES AT 100
description: Scott Nearing, a prominent pacifist and radical in the early part of the century who later became an ardent environmentalist, died yesterday at the farm overlooking Penobscot Bay in Harborside, Me., where he lived with his wife, Helen. He was 100 years old.

title: WINDOW GUARDS, PLAIN AND ORNATE
description: ANDREW WINSLOW is an infant with two particular baby traits: he likes to crawl and he loves to climb. This worried his mother, who feared that her 1-year-old might get hurt.

title: HANDICAPPING THE BRZEZINSKI WAY
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski is willing to give everyone a fighting chance. At least on the tennis court.

title: No Headline
description: Crash Victims Were Aliens

title: CORDERO INJURED IN SPILL AT BELMONT
description: Belmont Park reopened amid some confusion yesterday as Bold Style was deprived of a track record in winning the $60,600 Brighton Beach Handicap after track officials found that the race timer was started after the horses had already run 52 feet.

title: No Headline
description: BLUEBEARD. Life and Crimes of Gilles de Rais. By Leonard Wolf. Illustrated. 259 pages. Clarkson N. Potter. $12.95.WE have novel ways of judging fame these days and to be regarded as the wickedest man of the 15th century is certainly a distinction of some kind. Gilles de Rais, popularly called Bluebeard, was known in his time as a beast of extermination, the ogre who roasted and ate stolen children. He has fascinated biographers and historians for centuries and now Leonard Wolf, a professor of English, has written what professes to be the first unexpurgated account of Gilles's crimes.

title: RUPTURED PIPES AN INEVITABILITY AS SYSTEM AGES
description: The Manhattan water-main break yesterday was the second major one in two weeks in a vast, aging system of pipes in a violent underground environment of subway and street traffic vibrations.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kevin Williams , a former guard for St. John's basketball team, was so impressive in last month's camp for free agents and rookies that the San Antonio Spurs have signed him to a contract.

title: DUAL-PAY PROPOSAL IS REJECTED BY UNION AT A G.M. DIVISION
description: Workers at the General Motors Corporation's Packard Electric Division in Warren, Ohio, have rejected a tentative contract that would have sought to preserve existing jobs by drastically cutting the wages of newly hired employees. The vote in Local 717 of the International Union of Electric Workers was 5,301 to 2,084 against the plan.

title: B.P. Resources
description: B.P. Resources Canada Ltd., which is 64.4 percent owned by the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., said it planned to acquire British Petroleum's Selco Inc. subsidiary for $50 million. The price is based on Selco's being free of debt before its acquisition and is subject to adjustment for metal price variations over the next five years, B.P. Resources said. Selco operates a copper, gold and silver mine in Quebec and a lime and limestone plant in British Columbia.

description: Iraq to Seek Oil in Jordan BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 24

title: ODD AUGUST FOR PORK BELLIES
description: The August pork bellies futures contract expired yesterday, with commodities traders still debating whether they had witnessed a rare attempt at a squeeze.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $90,000 for the quarter and $530,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 1.

title: Salvadoran Court Jails Soldier in Killing
description: A criminal court sentenced the commander of a civil defense squad to 30 years in prison today for murdering a seminary student. It was the first time a military man had been convicted of a human rights violation since the civil war began in October 1979.

title: WHO PULLED THE TRIGGER ON AQUINO?
description: ''I have returned,'' said Benigno ''Ninoy'' Aquino Jr. in his last formal statement before he was assassinated at the Manila airport on Sunday, ''to join the ranks of those struggling to restore our rights and freedom through nonviolence. I seek no confrontation.''

description: Luggage Can Get Mixed Up, And So Can Siberian Tigers

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1983.

title: THINKING OF BUYING A HOME COMPUTER?
description: NEW computer equipment designed for home use is coming on the market every day and more and more people are beginning to think about using home computers to get organized, play space and adventure games, write novels or run businesses out of their homes. The September issue of Consumer Reports devotes a 28-page section to an evaluation of computer equipment for the home market, including a comparison of the features of 17 business and general purpose computers currently available for home buyers.

title: LINCOLN CENTER MOVES AGAINST THE BEAUMONT
description: In a highly unusual action, the board of directors of Lincoln Center yesterday took strong measures against one of its constituents - the board of the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: Six Are Arrested In Usury Case
description: Six men, including an official of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, were arrested yesterday in connection with loan-shark activities in recent years in Manhattan's garment district, the police said.

description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he would end a 22-month ban on night flying at Westchester County Airport in Purchase, N.Y.

title: ATHLETE WHO LEFT CITES FEAR OF TESTS
description: The shot-putter Ian Pyka said yesterday that he and several other United States athletes had withdrawn from the Pan American Games out of fear that the drug-testing procedures being used there might have detected a variety of banned substances at levels that had previously escaped discovery.

title: A. Starker Leopold, 69, Naturalist at Berkeley
description: The naturalist A. Starker Leopold, who headed a commission that led to widespread changes in National Park policies, died of heart disease Tuesday at his home here. He was 69 years old.

AMNESTY FOR SOLIDARITY FIGURE WHO GAVE UP
description: The Polish Government granted an unconditional amnesty today to Wladyslaw Hardek, a senior leader of the Solidarity union who surrendered to the police and who urged other fugitives to do the same.

title: Sweden Hunting Submarine
description: The Swedish Navy dropped depth charges after spotting what was believed to be a foreign submarine stalking naval maneuvers near the Karlskrona naval base Tuesday night, the Defense Staff said today.

title: Alcan Potline
description: Alcan Australia Ltd. said it would go ahead with the construction of a third potline with a capacity of 45,000 tons a year at its Kurri Kurri, New South Wales, aluminium smelter. Work on the $200 million potline is expected to start by the end of this year and production should begin toward the end of 1984, it said. Alcan is 70 percent owned by Alcan Aluminium Ltd. of Canada.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
U.S. Is Said to Thwart Plot Against Embassy
description: Within weeks of the bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut last April 18, intelligence agents uncovered a similar plan to blow up the American Embassy in Kuwait, CBS News reported tonight.

title: MUSTANG DRILLING & EXPLORAION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Judge Approves Moving of Unruh
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that Howard B. Unruh can be moved to a wing of Trenton Psychiatric Hospital that is less restrictive than the jail- like section in which he has been held since killing 13 people in a 1949 shooting spree.

title: Issue by Xerox To Yield 11.33%
description: A $100 million issue of Xerox Corporation extendable notes with a final maturity in 1998 was offered at a price of 99.8 with an 11 1/4 percent coupon to yield 11.33 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: REAGAN AIDE BELITTLES WOMAN WHO RESIGNED
description: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, today ridiculed a Justice Department official who resigned after assailing the Administration's record on women's rights. He said she had ''played an important role'' by dressing up as the Easter Bunny in the White House Easter egg roll.

title: Angolan President Rules Out Negotiations With Guerrillas
description: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola has rejected any talks with the rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, the official Angolan press agency, Angop, said today.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. The Yankees, trying to avoid the loss of more ground in the five-team struggle for the divisional title, send Shane Rawley, a former Mariner, against Jim Beattie, a former Yankee. (Television - SportsChannel, 2 P.M., live, and 8 P.M., tape. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.)

title: TOYOTA APPOINTS HEAD OF U.S. SALES
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. announced yesterday that it had named a new president.

title: FILIPINOS PAY TRIBUTE TO A SYMBOL OF OPPOSITION
description: All day long and well into the sultry night, the lines have glided past the open coffin in the ample foyer of the house on Times Street.

title: POP: ORIGINAL 1960'S HOLLIES
description: PSYCHODRAMA loomed when the original 1960's members of the Hollies - Allan Clarke, Graham Nash, Tony Hicks and Bobby Elliott - performed Tuesday at the Bottom Line. The group has made a reunion album and is touring the United States with four backup musicians; its New York show was moved from Radio City Music Hall to the 400-seat Bottom Line.

description: The surprise announcement by Senator John Tower that he will not seek re-election to the seat he has held for 22 years has generated political turmoil here and dealt a severe blow to the Republican Party.

title: Anti-Klan Group Starts Vigil
description: An anti-Ku Klux Klan group today began a 24-hour vigil outside the Justice Department to call attention to what it said was Government inaction against spreading racial violence by the Klan. Lynn Wells, coordinator for the Atlanta-based National Anti-Klan Network, said the organization handed the Justice Department a petition signed by 15,000 people across the country urging it to act against an upsurge of racial violence by the Klan. The department had no comment on the vigil.

description: The head of the nation's largest Hispanic organization said today that President Reagan's performance on Mexican-American issues had been dismal.

description: Preliminary results from an autopsy indicate that a youth who collapsed at a North Shore High School football practice Tuesday evening died of an abnormally enlarged heart.

description: Business Computing International announces that Robert B. Dixon has joined the company as senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: WESTMORELAND SUIT DATA RELEASED
description: The libel suit brought against CBS by Gen. William C. Westmoreland has entered a new phase, centering on previously undisclosed documents from the Central Intelligence Agency. Lawyers for CBS said that one of them was ''the smoking gun'' that would uphold a CBS program that charged General Westmoreland with conspiring to suppress information on enemy troop strength in Vietnam.

description: A Brooklyn jury deliberated only 3 hours and 15 minutes yesterday before finding a white youth guilty of taking part in an attack on three black transit workers that left one dead.

title: MEDICARE EXPERTS REJECT EXCISE TAX
description: A Federal advisory committee studying the future of Medicare today rejected proposals to help finance the health insurance program by increasing taxes on alcohol and tobacco products.

title: EVACUATION PLAN TESTED IN ROCKLAND
description: New York State today began its second attempt to demonstrate that it could respond to an accident at the Indian Point nuclear power station despite a boycott of emergency drills by Rockland County.

title: CITY RUNS A SUPER-SUPERMARKET
description: Storage racks soar way beyond reach. Almost as high are piles of boxes, looking as much like mountains as cardboard could. Around every blind turn might lurk an approaching forklift truck loaded with hundreds of pounds of goods.

description: AT times in recent years I have been uncomfortable both as a Jew in the women's movement and as a feminist in Judaism. title: PHOENIX AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend.

title: FRANCE, FORCES IN PLACE IN CHAD, TRIES DIPLOMACY
description: With its military forces in position to defend the Chadian Government against Libyan-backed rebels, France called today for a peaceful settlement of the conflict and began a diplomatic search for a solution.

title: Neighbors Flee North Bergen Fire
description: Residents of a 26-story tower here were forced from their apartments for more than four hours today as firefighters fought a blaze at a condominium complex being built nearby, officials said.

title: U.S. FALTERS IN TRACK, BOXING
description: United States athletes, who had been dominating the Pan American Games, had their worst day today.

title: MOST OF 116 CHILDREN PASS HEALTH TESTS AT SHELTER
description: More than a hundred children, most of them clutching their mothers' hands, lined up outside the Amboy Street Shelter in Brooklyn yesterday, waiting to be weighed, measured and given blood tests.

title: No Headline
description: Meenan Oil Takeover The Meenan Oil Company

title: Tremor Shakes Coast
description: A moderate earthquake centered in an undersea fault rolled gently along a 120-mile stretch of the northern California coastline for 10 seconds today. The tremor registered a magnitude of 5.5 on the Richter Scale and was situated 45 miles southwest of Eureka in Humbolt County, 230 miles north of San Francisco. No damage was reported.

title: SLOSHING TO THE RESCUE: 'IT LOOKED LIKE A RIVER'
description: Waves of water broke over the prow of Richard Gainer's car as he pushed westward toward Madison Square Park yesterday morning. ''It looked like a river,'' he said later.

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,381,000 from the exchange of 102,742 common shares for $4,700,000 principal amount of outstanding 7 3/8 percent sinking fund debentures.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Last Patient Gone From Cumberland
description: Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn moved out its last patient yesterday, completing the long-awaited transfer of its services to Woodhull Hospital.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH ON MORENO HOMER
description: Omar Moreno was traded to the Yankees two weeks ago because his inability to hit left-handed pitchers got him in trouble in Houston. Last night, the left-handed hitting Moreno hit a three-run home run against a left-handed pitcher that powered the Yankees to a 6-3 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: SHANNON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Shannon Group Inc. was previously called Shannon Oil & Gas Inc.

title: ERNEST A. CLOTHIER
description: Ernest A. Clothier, a steamship captain and an authority on steamship piloting, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: INTEREST RATES DROP SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as credit market participants remained uncertain about the longevity of recent declines in overnight interest rates.

title: Tamils in Sri Lanka Strike Over Killings
description: Sri Lanka's Tamil minority staged a strike in their northern stronghold of Jaffna today to protest the killing of 52 Tamils in a Colombo jail nearly a month ago when ethnic riots swept the island.

title: IN MYSTERY FICTION, ROOMS FURNISHED ONE CLUE AT A TIME
description: P. D. James is a retired British civil servant who has written nine novels, the latest of which is ''The Skull Beneath the Skin.''

title: Bush to Visit North Africa
description: Vice President Bush will make a 10-day trip to several countries in North Africa and Europe, beginning Sept. 11, it was announced today.

title: Paula H. Wolfert Becomes a Bride
description: Paula Harris Wolfert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam R. Harris of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to William Bayer of New York and West Tisbury, Mass., son of Leo G. Bayer of Duxbury, Mass., and the late Eleanor Perry of New York. Justice of the Peace Nelle K. Vincent performed the ceremony at the West Tisbury home of the bridegroom.

title: OIL LEASING BIDS IN GULF NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24 (AP) - Oil companies looking for offshore drilling space offered the Government top bids totaling $1.55 billion today on 475 tracts in the Gulf of Mexico off the Texas coast.
description: ''It far exceeded our expectations,'' said Perry Pendley, the Department of Interior's assistant secretary for minerals.

description: Chile Gives Arts Prize To Opponent of Regime

title: ADVERTISING ;  People
description: * Emmett H. Sellars has been appointed vice president of tire sales and marketing for the Goodyear International Corporation, Akron, Ohio.

title: U.S. WOULD COOL TIES WITH MARCOS IF GUILT IS FOUND
description: As Filipinos continued to pay their respects to Benigno Aquino, his widow, Corazon, returned to Manila from the United States. Page A4.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the New York Philharmonic's free outdoor concert at Castle Clinton in Battery Park gave the incorrect date. The concert is today at 12:30 P.M.

title: Bethlehem to Shut Plant by Oct. 15
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has announced Oct. 15 as the date by which all basic steel-making will end at its giant works here.

title: No Headline
description: H. Bell said today that while the quality of American education had declined and the teaching profession was at ''its lowest ebb,'' a public drive to upgrade standards had taken hold.

title: No Headline
description: Accounts

title: Finks Quits Bears
description: Jim Finks , the vice president and general manager of the Chicago Bears, resigned, even though the regular season is less than two weeks away.

title: ABOUT THE WEST BANK AND THE EMPEROR'S CLOTHES
description: It happens so often in Washington that it could be called ''The Emperor's New Clothes Syndrome.'' A President makes a statement that his aides know is questionable, at best, or wrong, at worst. But because the remark is made by the President, his aides devote their energies not to correcting it, but to trying to find some way of substantiating it or glossing it over.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include the operations of Poppin Fresh Pies, Inc., which was acquired on May 2, 1982.

title: U.S. Credit for Mexico
description: The United States said today that it will provide Mexico an extra $100 million in credits to help finance immediate purchases of American grain. The Agriculture Department said the credit guarantee are for the current financial year ending Sept. 30.

title: Arsonist Sentenced To 10 Years in Prison
description: A firefighter, burned as a child in a fire that killed his brother, has been sentenced to 10 years in prison for hiring a man to set fire to a building occupied by a family of seven.

title: ESTATE OF THE ORIGINAL 'BILL' HIT WITH CLAIM FOR $9,863
description: The estate of Bill Sackter, a retarded man portrayed by Mickey Rooney in the television movie ''Bill,'' will not pay a $9,863 claim filed by Minnesota, the man's former guardian says.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
CORRECTION
description: Information with a map in the Metropolitan Report yesterday gave an incorrect date when new bus stops would go into effect on Fifth Avenue. They have been in use since Monday.

title: DR. ANNA L. PHILBROOK
description: Dr. Anna L. Philbrook, a pioneer in child psychiatry in New Hampshire and director of the state's Child Guidance Clinics from 1945 to 1966, died last Thursday at Concord Hospital in Concord, N.H. She was 79 years old.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including extraordinary income of $367,000 for the quarter and $746,000 for the 9 months.

title: Egypt Lifts New Blackout On Joint Maneuvers with U.S.
description: The Egyptian Government lifted its news blackout today on the joint Egyptian-American maneuvers code-named Bright Star '83 to allow reporters to watch a final phase of the exercises in the desert north of Cairo.

title: CHAD DENIES REPORTS OF BATTLE AT OASIS
description: The Chadian Information Minister today denied reports that there had been fighting in the area of Oum Chalouba, a northeastern oasis that has been a battleground several times this summer.

title: ALGONQUIN MERCANTILE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Year-ago results were not provided because of a change in the fiscal year-end from June 30 to March 31.

title: CONCERT: JAZZ AT GATE
description: TWO trumpeters reached for the sky, and a third held his ground, at Monday's ''Salsa Meets Jazz'' concert at the Village Gate. As the weekly series usually works, a jazz soloist steps bravely into the middle of sets by two Latin bands while a good part of the audience dances.

title: A BOUNTIFUL CROP FOR CITY 'FARMERS'
description: AS the steamy days of summer subside, increasing numbers of city gardeners are enjoying their harvest on rooftops, balconies and windowsills as well as in backyards and community gardens.

Lawrence, 164 E. 116th St., Queens. Lincoln, 430 Broad St., Newark.

title: Outlook for Malaysia
description: Malaysia's gross domestic product is expected to grow 5.5 or 6 percent this year, compared with a rise of 4.8 percent last year, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said today in a speech.

title: MISSISSIPPI VICTOR IS BACKED BY RIVAL
description: After stopping Evelyn Gandy's bid to become the first woman in this state to win the Democratic nomination for Governor, Bill Allain said today that merit, not gender, had been the deciding factor.

title: PACER KEEPS FAMILY TOGETHER
description: Bob Farrington isn't your typical, bigtime man in sports. He's 54 years old, lives on a farm in Mokena, Ill., and starts every day by hiking to the horse barn to say good morning to his 13-year-old pacer.
