title: Dim Outlook In Britain
description: Higher inflation, continuing unemployment, a slim 1 percent growth in output and low domestic demand lie ahead for Britain, the National Insitute of Economic and Social Research said today.

title: CUT-RATE MURDER PENALTY
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE GOES ON
description: The nationwide strike by the Communications Workers of America against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will continue because some of the 34 striking C.W.A. locals have not been able to reach local contracts, the union said early today.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: AdvertisingPamela G. Hollie Renault's Encore Campaign
description: RENAULT, better known in France as Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, celebrated its minority ownership of the faltering American Motors Corporation last fall with the introduction of an American-made sedan called Alliance.

title: CARLING BASSETT LOSES, 6-3, 6-4
description: Carling Bassett of Canada, a 15-year-old rising star in women's tennis, experienced a setback today when she was eliminated in the second round of the Virginia Slims of New Jersey tournament by Christiane Jolissaint of Switzerland.

title: Judge Cale J. Holder, U.S. Jurist for 29 Years
description: Federal District Judge Cale J. Holder, who served on the bench for 29 years, died Tuesday at St. Francis Hospital, where he was taken Saturday after suffering a stroke at his home. He was 71 years old.

title: Italy Freezes Rizzoli Stock
description: A judge here ordered today that 50.2 percent of the stock in the Rizzoli publishing empire be attached to safeguard claims by shareholders of the bankrupt Banco Ambrosiano.

title: BALLET: TAMARA HADLEY
description: Gala-style pas de deux programs have been proliferating this summer like a ballerina's bunions. ''All That Glitters,'' presented tonight by the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, was one with an air of unusual intimacy and literateness as well as a high level of dancing.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THERE seems to be a widespread misapprehension that wrenches are needed only by the likes of auto mechanics and professional service personnel. While they are not used as often as other basic tools in ordinary home maintenance, when they are needed, nothing else will quite do in most cases. If, for example, you try to work on a bolt or nut with pliers, you will find that you may not be able to apply the needed pressure without slipping and causing damage. You may may also end up with skinned knuckles.

title: GUARDSMEN LEAVE STRIKE SITE
description: Despite tensions in this copper-mining community, several convoys of Arizona National Guardsmen today continued to vacate the tent city set up near the struck Phelps Dodge Corporation plant.

title: BRITISH FLAVOR MAKER PROMOTES AIDE IN U.S.
description: Roger G. Rich has taken over as president of Bush Boake Allen Inc., the American subsidiary of Bush Boake Allen, a large British-based supplier of flavors and fragrances. The parent company was purchased last fall by the Union Camp Corporation for $75 million.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Diamond International Corp. said it had offered to buy all of its 8.35 percent sinking fund debentures due Sept. 1, 2006, for $775 in cash for each $1,000 principal amount. The offer will expire Sept. 19 unless extended.

title: Rates Up At Banks
description: Interest rates for money market deposit accounts at banks continued to rise across the country in the latest seven-day period, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: U.S. ORDERS ATHLETES' DRUG TESTS
description: The United States Olympic Committee, responding to the drug controversy at the Pan American Games here, decreed today that there be mandatory random tests for banned substances at any event where athletes qualify to represent the United States internationally.

title: Nevada Issue To Yield 9%-10 1/2%
description: A $323 million issue of Clark County, Nev., airport revenue refunding bonds was priced by underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to yield a maximum 10 1/2 percent for bonds due 2007-2012.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to exclude Applied Solar Energy on a consolidated basis and to include only the company's equity in the earnings of Applied Solar.

title: KOCH CRITICIZES STATE'S CUTS IN MENTAL HEALTH AID
description: New York City is not getting its fair allotment of money for mental health because of ''a fiscal juggling scheme'' by the Cuomo administration, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: MORTGAGE OVERCHARGE REPORTED
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today that some lenders had overcharged homeowners who assumed mortgages owned by the corporation.

title: No Headline
description: Sputter and Flash in Poland It's been a demoralizing week for opponents of the Jaruzelski dictatorship in Poland. They attempted a slowdown at the Lenin Shipyard, Solidarity's birthplace.

title: Ford Denial
description: The British subsidiary of the Ford Motor company, responding to a decision to conduct an inquiry into its business, denied that it was acting in an anticompetitive manner.

title: GENESCO INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,001,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: FOES OF WESTWAY DROP CONTEMPT-OF-COURT CASE
description: Environmental and civic groups dropped their contempt-of-court case involving the Westway project yesterday to await a decision on a landfill permit needed for the huge highway project.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
TAX NOT LOWER, FED REPORT SAYS
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia has challenged the Reagan Administration's claim that taxes have been reduced significantly as a result of actions in the last two years.

title: CLAYTON HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ProgressReported In L.I.R.R. Talks
description: A Federal mediator said yesterday that negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and four shop craft unions had made ''good progress'' in clarifying disputed language in a proposed draft agreement.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Ex-Hospital Chief
description: A former director of Gouverneur Hospital was indicted yesterday on charges of accepting about $100,000 in kickbacks from a supplier to the hospital's federally financed food program for low-income mothers and children.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 25, 1983 International
description: Policy toward the Philippines was outlined by Reagan Administration officials. They said the Administration was prepared to dissociate itself from the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the event that he or his top associates were found responsible for the assassination of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr. But they stressed that American-Philippines ties go beyond the Marcos regime and have strategic importance. (Page A1, Column 6.) The drug dispute at the Pan Am Games prompted the United States Olympic Committee to order mandatory random tests for prohibited drugs at all events where athletes qualify to represent the United States internationally. (B11:3-6.) National

title: UNITED STATES SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
THE HARM SOME TRANQUILIZERS CAN DO
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Invisible City, Visible Paralysis If New York's heavy trucks could sense the layers of conduits below them they would tiptoe through the streets, and pneumatic drills would have their points sheathed in powder puffs. Underfoot a serpentine maze of pipes, conduits, mains and tracks carry water, gas, electricity, steam, sewage, rain water and people - until a brittle or worn or weak spot gives way. The result, as it was yesterday, is paralysis in the visible city.

title: U.S. SUING TO FORCE GLEN COVE TO ALLOW RUSSIANS ON BEACHES
description: After months of detente, the cold war between Glen Cove, L.I., and the Soviet Union heated up again yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Esmark Profit Rises Sharply Esmark Inc. said yesterday

title: 3 LEADING STEELMAKERS INCREASE SHEET PRICE 7%
description: Three of the nation's leading steelmakers yesterday announced increases of about 7 percent in the price of sheet and strip steel products that are used by the automobile industry and in consumer goods.

title: OPERA TALKS RESUME
description: The management of the New York City Opera resumed negotiations yesterday with representatives of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians in an attempt to settle the opera orchestra's seven-week-old strike.

title: Marketing and Media Sees Cost Increases
description: Marketing and Media Decisions, a monthly industry magazine, is predicting a 9.4 percent increase in overall media costs for the year from September 1983 to September 1984. The magazine's annual survey will appear in next month's issue.

title: RAWLEY BEATS MARINERS
description: The Yankees' 7-4 victory over the Seattle Mariners yesterday produced two positive results: Shane Rawley indicated he is prepared to join Ron Guidry and Dave Righetti in bringing a semblance of consistency to the pitching staff in the final weeks of the division race, and Manager Billy Martin indicated he is prepared to accept the Omar Moreno trade.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $24,353,000 on a loss from Japanese distribution operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations.

title: STATE SAVINGS BANKS HEALTHIER
description: Savings banks in New York State showed considerable improvement in the second quarter, although more than half of them continued to report operating losses, according to the state banking department.

title: Insider Given U.S. Sentence
description: A lobbyist was sentenced to perform 300 hours of community service and was fined $10,000 for telling a friend about a corporate takeover plan.

title: ORDER ON DELOREAN TO STAND
description: A Federal district judge today refused to rescind his order for 51 Government agencies to submit to the court their files on John Z. DeLorean, the automobile manufacturer charged with cocaine trafficking, a decision the prosecution warned could delay the trial for years.

title: N.C.A.A. SUED ON BERRY ISSUE
description: Walter Berry and St. John's University filed a Federal suit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday, asking that Berry be made eligible to play for the St. John's basketball team in the coming season.

description: News Analysis

title: Bucks Sign Breuer
description: The Milwaukee Bucks signed their top draft choice, Randy Breuer, a 7-foot-3-inch center from the University of Minnesota, to a multiyear contract.

title: Italy Sells Pipe to India
description: Italy's state-owned Siderexport has signed a $38 million contract to supply steel pipe for India's offshore gas pipeline, an Italian Embassy official said today.

title: Kodak Predicts 1984 Turnaround
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's earnings will improve, but not until 1984, its chairman, Colby H. Chandler, said in the company's quarterly magazine.

description: b-Net income. Gerber Systems is 80 percent owned by Gerber Scientific Inc.

title: BARBIE'S AMERICAN CONNECTION
description: The Department of Justice report on Klaus Barbie's American connection is unsatisfying and troubling. Mr. Barbie is the World War II Gestapo officer whom the French call ''the butcher of Lyons.'' The U.S. Army hired him as an agent in Germany after the war, protected him and enabled him to escape to Bolivia in 1951 when the French sought to try him for war crimes.

title: Michigan General Acquisition Plan
description: The Michigan General Corporation said today that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the retail lumber and building products division of Diamond International Inc. for $120 million in cash, stock and notes.

title: No Headline

title: U.S. REBOUNDS AT PAN AM
description: The United States returned to its winning ways today in the Pan American Games as its women's basketball team decisively clinched a gold medal, Joan Benoit scored a runaway victory in the women's 3,000- meter run, and four boxers advanced to championship bouts.

title: COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Telecom Contract
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said it had signed a five-year contract, valued at more than $300 million (Canadian) to supply Turkey's Post, Telegraph and Telephone Administration with digital telecommunications systems and parts. The contract is subject to financing by Canada's Export Development Corporation, the company said. Northern Telecom said it had also signed a license with Northern Electric Telekomunikasyon A.S., a Turkish concern in which it has a 31 percent interest, for switching systems.

title: Rose Takes a Seat
description: It was one of the longest streaks in the history of baseball and it came to an end on Wednesday when Pete Rose was kept on the bench for the first time since he joined the Philadelphia Phillies in 1979. As a result, his streak of consecutive games played ended at 745, leaving him 10th on the career list headed by Lou Gehrig's 2,130.

title: AID AUTO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $40,363 for the quarter and $37,664 for the 6 months. Corrected from the first edition.

title: SOVIET WRITER LOSES CIITIZENSHIP
description: Georgi N. Vladimov, the dissident writer who left under pressure for the West last spring, has been stripped of his citizenship by the Soviet Government for ''systematically engaging in activities hostile to the U.S.S.R.''

title: ISLAM FLOWERS IN SOVIET, BUT IT DOESN'T GROW WILD
description: Stop almost anybody in this sunbaked Central Asian town and they'll direct you to the Mosque of the Sacred Scroll - down the street named for the prewar German Communist leader, Ernst Thaelmann, past the V. I. Lenin secondary school and through a gateway opposite the No. 7 fruit and vegetable store of the Osh city cooperative society.

title: Stamford Eliminated
description: Stamford, Conn., the representative of the United States Eastern region, was eliminated from the Little League World Series today with a 9-8 loss to Marietta, Ga., in the semifinals.

title: Arms Stockpile Smallest Since Mid-60's, U.S. Says
description: The United States nuclear weapons stockpile is the smallest since the mid-1960's and would increase only moderately over the next 15 years if arms reduction talks fail, the Pentagon said today.

title: Hunter of Nazis Says France Used Gestapo Man as Agent
description: The French intelligence services used a former Gestapo chief as an agent in the months after World War II, the Nazi- hunter Serge Klarsfeld says.

description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that French troops had been sent to Chad to ''bring peace,'' but he warned that, if threatened by Libyan-backed rebels, they could go on the offensive.

title: No Headline
description: Israel Reconnects in Africa It makes political and economic sense for black Africa to renew a once-valued connection with Israel. Many Africans say as much in private, and more than 20 African states now benefit from unofficial Israeli development aid. But the dogmas of third-world diplomacy, coupled with hopes of Arab largesse, have kept black Africa's leaders from renewing a beneficial partnership.

title: UTILITIES RESTORE PUBLIC SERVICES IN FLOODED AREA
description: Although East Side traffic remained snarled because of a water-main break under Broadway near 23d Street, almost all public services were restored and private businesses were back to normal, city officials said yesterday.

title: Empty Seats in Jersey
description: When Jersey City's high school football teams kick off next month, there will be no fans in the stands at Roosevelt Stadium, because the seating where crowds watched Jackie Robinson make his professional baseball debut are unsafe. City officials said yesterday that the seats would be torn out and that fans won't even be permitted on the sidelines because of safety concerns at the stadium, which will be demolished later this year to make room for condominiums.

title: BURLINGTON SEEKS REST OF EL PASO
description: Burlington Northern Inc., which acquired 48 percent of the stock of the El Paso Company through a tender offer in January, yesterday offered to acquire the remaining 52 percent of the Houston-based energy concern in an exchange of cash and stock valued at $670 million.

description: A father who says he killed his infant daughter five years ago and is capable of killing his small son was set free when the police were unable to find a way to bring charges against him, the authorities said today.

description: After 20 years growing grapes, Cloyce Pineo put a ''For Sale'' sign on his vineyard.

title: ARRESTS IN HORSE KILLINGS
description: Four owners of race horses today were charged with killing 10 trotters, pacers and thoroughbreds and collecting thousands of dollars in fraudulent insurance claims.

title: THEATER: 'NON PASQUALE'
description: DELIVERING the Prologue in ''Non Pasquale,'' a pop version of the opera ''Don Pasquale,'' Joe Grifasi directly addresses Donizetti. Looking skyward, he says, ''Scusi.'' In the name of the composer, the apology is accepted. Prego.

title: ADHERING TO WORLD LAW
description: Cuba and Nicaragua hint that they would be willing to stop sending men and arms to promote the rebellion in El Salvador if the United States agreed not to help the Salvadoran Government put the rebellion down. The agreement they propose would abolish the distinction between aggression and self-defense in international law and treat both as politically and morally equivalent. For the United States to embrace that proposition should be unthinkable.

title: Aetna Claim Costs
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said its net claim costs from Hurricane Alicia would total about $35 million after reinsurance recoveries.

title: FOAM INSULATION IS CLEARED OF BAN
description: Urea formaldehyde foam insulation, which is suspected of causing cancer, respiratory distress and skin irritation, was allowed back on the market today by the Reagan Administration.

title: PARCELLS HOPES THE SUCCESS CONTINUES
description: The Giants play the Miami Dolphins here Friday night, seeking to cap a perfect preseason, and there is a history lesson here.

title: Israel Pledges to Help Liberia In Ships, Roads and Farming
description: Israel has promised to provide agricultural, technical, medical and economic aid to Liberia, according to an agreement reached by leaders of the two countries here today.

title: PUBLISHING: BOOKLETS FOR PROMOTING BOOKS
description: LAST spring, bookstores around the country offered a free illustrated booklet consisting of the first chapter of ''Make- Believe: The Story of Nancy and Ronald Reagan'' by Laurence Leamer. The booklets have proved so popular with booksellers and customers that the book's publisher, Harper & Row, is doing a similar giveaway for ''A Cold Mind,'' a psycho-thriller by David L. Lindsey scheduled for publication next month. The 43-page free booklet consists of the book's first four chapters.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: BROADWAY
description: Liza Minnelli may return to stage in roller-rink musical.

title: FILIPINOS IN U.S. WERE HARRASSED, EX-AIDES ASSERT
description: Filipino dissidents in the United States may have been spied on and harassed by Philippine Government agents, according to former State Department officials and a Pentagon intelligence document.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tribute to Aquino In the City Tonight

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JULIA: A Portrait of Julia Strachey. By herself and Frances Partridge. 308 pages. Little, Brown. $16.95.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Toronto-Dominion Bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: BRIEFING
description: Pressure on Hatfield

title: A 'FAN' SALUTES THE LIBEL LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bancal Holders Amend Lawsuit
description: In an amendment to a lawsuit, shareholders of the Bancal TriState Corporation have charged that key company directors withheld information to assure board approval of a takeover bid by Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.

title: BOB AND RAY, THE MEN IN THE STREET
description: (Music, the kind that is played at the beginning of news broadcasts. Fade in on an announcer sitting behind a desk.)

title: WHY WE'RE MARCHING
description: When Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his ''I have a dream'' speech on Aug. 28, 1963 on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, there was a very real sense in which he changed world history. That speech pricked the conscience of a nation that, within one year, moved to eliminate the infamous system of segregation by law that for a century had been a blot on our democracy.

title: ONE MAN WITH REVIVAL ON HIS MIND
description: The Rev. Dr. Joseph E. Lowery, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, came to the capital this week with revival on his mind.

title: No Headline
description: Guthrie at Bottom Line

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HICKSVILLE OKTOBERFEST

title: Hong Kong Gains Seen
description: Hong Kong's economic recovery, buttressed by rising exports, will continue through the second half of the year, the Government said today in its midyear economic report. Exports grew 9 percent in real terms in the first six months from the period a year earlier, and they should continue strong through the end of the year, the report said. The fastest growing sectors have been garments, electronics and food, the report said.

title: THE VILLAGE BECOMES A JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: a sleepy-looking bunch of musicians, record-business people, managers, disk jockeys, club owners, journalists, relatives and hangers-on - club-hopping in Greenwich Village is the only way to live. And club-hopping is the basis of the second Greenwich Village Jazz Festival, which begins tonight at 5:30 with a free concert.

title: WIDDERSHINS MOTION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Those left behind experience pleasures unknown to those on the beaches and in the woods. That night, while watching a movie it was impossible to get into earlier in the week, they thank heaven they are not in a traffic jam.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Getting Away From It All: Miss Bellamy's Route

title: SIDE IS RETIRED ON PICKOFFS
description: One summer when he was growing up in La Junta, Colo., Tippy Martinez was given the choice of having a motor scooter or going to a baseball camp. He chose the Big State Baseball Camp in Waco, Tex., and, as things turned out, it was fortunate for the Baltimore Orioles that he did.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to holders of record on March 18, 1983.

title: TEXT OF LETTER ON INSULATION
description: Following is the text of the letter from Solicitor General Rex E. Lee to Nancy H. Steorts, chairman of the Government's Consumer Products Safety Commission, on the decision not to appeal a decision overturning the commission's ban on the sale of urea formaldehyde:

title: U.S. AIDES GET NEW SECRECY PLEDGE
description: The Reagan Administration put into effect today a directive requiring Federal employees with top-secret security clearances to submit articles and speeches for approval before publication.

title: Home Resale Rate Drops
description: Resales of single-family homes fell 4.4 percent last month, a real estate trade group said today. It attributed the decline to higher interest rates.

title: Ute Geweniger Sets Swim Mark
description: Ute Geweniger of East Germany set a world record of 1 minute 8.51 seconds in the women's 100-meter breast-stroke today at the European Swimming Championships, breaking the record she set two years ago.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A First: Woman to Lead Labor Day Parade

title: Not in the Family
description: When Chris Evert Lloyd and her husband, John Lloyd, were eliminated in the second round of last year's world mixed-doubles championships, both players complained about the extreme pressures on spouses playing together for big money.

title: U.S. Motion On A.T.& T.
description: The Justice Department today asked that a legal challenge to the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company be brought directly to the Supreme Court.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS SAID TO STEP UP COMBAT ACTIVITY
description: Insurgents fighting the Nicaraguan Government have stepped up their activity in the last week, mounting at least eight attacks over a wide area of northern Nicaragua and inflicting scores of casualties, according to Government officials.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Battle of Taya Crique
description: A small stream called Taya Crique is only a tiny scratch on the map of Honduras. Until recently its existence was unknown to the lords of power in Washington, who cared as little about Taya Crique's owner, Temistocles Ramirez de Arellano. They may well care now.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $235 million in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, to $165.3 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: CANADIAN GENERAL ELECTRIC CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEWS SUMMARY FRIDAY, AUGUST 26, 1983
description: International

title: Cessna Aircraft Picks President From Deere
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company has reached into the farm-machine industry for a new president and chief operating officer.

title: Brazil Debt Talks Held
description: Brazil's major private creditors completed two days of meetings in New York yesterday, amid indications that by the middle of next week the International Monetary Fund might sign a letter of intent with the debt-ridden country agreeing to a new set of economic measures.

title: $123,000 Stolen In Brooklyn Ruse
description: Two men who threatened to dynamite a check-cashing agency in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday morning made off with $123,000 in cash and $1,000 in food stamps, the police said.

title: TWO NEW SHOPS OFFER ETHNIC CRAFTS
description: Two ethnic shops have opened in recent months with totally disparate looks and outlooks. But the idea behind both is similar: the celebration of a culture, its artists and artisans.

title: 'DANIEL,' A QUESTION OF JUSTICE
description: AS ''the story of two generations of a family whose ruling passion is not success or money or love, but social justice,'' Sidney Lumet's film ''Daniel'' -thus described by Mr. Lumet and by E. L. Doctorow, whose screenplay is based upon his own novel - is a work of noble and unusual ambitions. That these ambitions become the film's most admirable element is a sign of just how difficult it must have been to bring this material to the screen, as well as an indication of problems that are more mundane.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan When Brokers Make Insider Trading Profits
description: -BACHE SECURITIES, one of the nation's largest brokerage firms, has 4,100 stockbrokers, 280 offices, 800,000 customers and an advertising campaign tied to the theme ''Bring us your future.''

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ARGENTINA GADFLY FLEE BUT BATTERED AND CUT
description: Guillermo Patricio Kelly, a gadfly who was kidnapped Wednesday, showed up battered early this morning and said he had been abducted by union thugs.

title: ISRAELIS AGREE TO DELAY PULLBACK IN LEBANON
description: Israel was reported today to have agreed to an American request to delay, by a few days, the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon's Shuf Mountains. Although no firm date had been announced, it was understood to have been set for early next week.

title: COMPUTERIZED BILLBOARD BRIGHTENS UP TIMES SQ. WITH ART-OF-THE-MONTH
description: There would be no art if the artist and the computer man could not come to an understanding. The first time Howardina Pindell carted her sketches to Curtis King, the programmer of an electronic billboard in Times Square, nothing was resolved.

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $23,407 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $142,651 for the year. c-Year-ago results were not given because the company said they weren't comparable with the 1983 results.

title: Offer of Shares In Enserch Corp.
description: An offering of four million shares of the Enserch Corporation is under way at $23.25 each through securities dealers led by Salomon Brothers and Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FAVORABLE OPENING DRAW FOR 2 TOP PLAYERS
description: For tennis followers who equate a major tournament draw to a pro football draft, John McEnroe and Martina Navratilova may have emerged as winners yesterday for the United States Open championships that begin next Tuesday at the National Tennis Center.

title: ; WHAT LAWYERS MUST DO TO THE TRUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER DISPUTE ON KEEL
description: While the New York Yacht Club's original dispute with the Australia II syndicate appeared on its way to being resolved today, another one broke out, promising further controversy over the construction of the chief foreign challenger to the America's Cup.

title: HARVESTER AND LENDERS SET NEW TALKS ON DEBT
description: Executives of the International Harvester Company and its major lenders will begin several days of meetings in Chicago today in an attempt to work out what would be the company's third debt-restructuring plan in as many years.

title: HOUSTON ST.: DOWNTOWN BOULEVARD REVISITED
description: THE story is told of a Texas oil millionaire who went to New York's Houston Street in the hope of finding some good down-home cooking. But instead of barbecued ribs, he found knishes, pasta and quiche.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A MODERN CONDOMINIUM AMID WEST SIDE SOLIDARITY
description: A certain drab solidity prevails along 79th Street west of Columbus Avenue. Most of the boxlike brick buildings, 15 stories tall, date from the period of heavy construction between the two world wars. It is an environment unaccustomed in recent years to new construction.

title: LOCAL DISPUTE SNAG THE RETURN OF MOST TELEPHONE WORKERS
description: The Communications Workers of America, the largest of the three unions negotiating with 34 subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, failed today to reach agreement with several local telephone companies.Most of the union's 525,000 members continued their strike against the A.T.&T. affiliates.

title: U.S. TO BUS ILLEGAL ALIENS FAR BACK TO INSIDE MEXICO
description: In an attempt to impede some of the almost unbridled shuttle of illegal aliens across the Mexican-American border, the United States Border Patrol will start busing captured aliens who volunteer for the ride hundreds of miles into the interior of Mexico rather than simply dropping them off on the other side of the border.

title: Kochare Pass
description: Restrictions on half-fare passes for elderly and handicapped subway riders should be eased, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: U.S. APPEALS CHICAGO SCHOOL DESEGREGATION ORDER
description: The Reagan Administration, in what it calls a matter of ''profound constitutional significance,'' today formally appealed a Federal district judge's order that it pay the Chicago Board of Education $14.6 million to help finance school desegregation efforts, and set aside another $250 million for similar expenses later.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
MIANUS BRIDGE OPENS SUNDAY TO BIG TRUCKS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill announced today that the westbound lanes of the Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich would be reopened to heavy trucks and buses starting at noon Sunday.

title: DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
MANCINI AND BOSTON POPS IN JERSEY
description: HENRY MANCINI'S melodies get stuck in a person's head. Hear a strain of ''Moon River,'' and the piece is likely to play on in your mind for hours or days. ''The Pink Panther'' catches the same way, and so do ''Charade,'' ''Days of Wine and Roses'' and the music from the ''Peter Gunn'' television series.

title: RISING USE OF COMPUTER NETWORKS RAISES ISSUES OF SECURITY AND LAW
description: Computer experts say cracking a sophisticated computer network is far easier and has become far more common than has been generally believed. They say the recent intrusions by Milwaukee youths, for example, in no way represent an especially ingenious maneuver that could be achieved only by electronic wizards.

title: AdvertisingPamela G. Hollie One Woman Magazine
description: ONE WOMAN is a public relations representative's dream and perhaps the ultimate in personalized publications. The new quarterly men's magazine devotes 100 pages, 95 photographs and 16,000 words to just one woman. The first issue in October belongs to television's ''Flamingo Road'' actress, Morgan Fairchild, who tells all - but does not bare all - for the readers.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Small houses, large values.

title: 'STRANGE BREW,' MEN IN QUEST OF BEER
description: BEER is to the Canadian hopheads Bob and Doug (''Eh?'') McKenzie as marijuana is to Cheech and Chong, though Bob and Doug are by far the more infantile duo. (One of them, whenever he's in trouble, actually sucks his thumb.) The McKenzies are the creation of two Second City TV veterans, Rick Moranis and Dave Thomas, who wrote, directed and star in ''Strange Brew,'' a movie that's barely there. The McKenzies are genial enough, and once in a while they're vaguely funny. But their film is so ephemeral that you may hardly be aware of watching it, even while it's going on.

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
James Keoloha, No. 2 Official When Hawaii Became a State
description: James K. Kealoha, who was Hawaii's first lieutenant governor under statehood, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: AN ADMINISTRATION COMMITED TO SAFETY IN AMERICA'S MINES
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOUTING
description: Interim Status

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Pakistani May Have Made Best Opening Lead of 1983

title: Youth Killed by Motorboat
description: A 17-year-old English youth fell off a motorboat on a water- skiing ride in Moriches Bay Wednesday and was slashed to death by its propeller, authorities said. They said the youth, David Gill, had been staying with friends here and was to have entered the freshman class at Brown University next week.

title: QUESTIONS FOR MANILA
description: Who - including President Reagan - can really believe that the Government of Ferdinand Marcos will conduct a thoroughgoing investigation of the foul murder of his strongest political rival, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.? But at least Salvador H. Laurel, another opponent, boldly put the right questions to the Marcos-controlled Philippine National Assembly:

title: 'HONEYMOONERS' ISN'T OVER FOR ITS FANS
description: The black-and- white television screen flickers, and aw-a-a- a-a-y they go to the crazy cosmos of Ralph Kramden and ''The Honeymooners,'' the situation comedy that was a Saturday night ritual in millions of homes in the 1950's. For a 625-member club ''The Honeymooners'' is still a ritual, and the group is, to borrow a line from the show, ''a riot, a regular riot.''

title: French Output
description: France's gross domestic product rose a provisional two-tenths of 1 percent during the second quarter, the Statistics Institute said today. The agency revised the first-quarter figure to zero from an earlier estimate of a one-tenth of 1 percent increase

title: L.I. GASOLINE DEALER ACCUSED OF EVADING $600,000 IN TAXES
description: State tax agents arrested a Long Island service-station owner today and charged him with illegally importing and selling nearly three million gallons of gasoline and evading $600,000 in state taxes.

title: PHILIPPINES OPENS INQUIRY ON AQUINO
description: A Government commission formally began its inquiry today into the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., but its credibility was immediately challenged by supporters of the slain Philippine opposition leader.

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results from its 90 percent stake in Norton Simon Inc. are not included.

title: U.S. ASSURES SOVIET OF STEADY SUPPLY
description: The United States and the Soviet Union signed a new five-year grain agreement here today that gives the Russians a new guarantee that supplies from America will not be interrupted.

title: REPORT CITES EFFECT OF U.S. CUTBACKS ON POOR
description: The Congressional Budget Office reported today that 40 percent of the cutbacks in Federal benefit programs over the last two years affected households with annual incomes below $10,000.

title: TEXT OF AMERICAN-SOVIET AGREEMENT
description: Following is the text of the American-Soviet grain agreement signed today by Agriculture Secretary John R. Block of the United States and Foreign Trade Minister Nikolai S. Patolichev of the Soviet Union:

title: FRIEND ARRESTED FOR THE SLAYING OF L.I. WOMAN
description: A 24-year-old bookkeeper who the police say became enraged when his proposal of a date was rejected was charged yesterday with having murdered a young woman in her family's Great Neck, L.I., home last Saturday with repeated blows with a shillelagh.

title: OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $854,000 for the quarter and 6 months, and tax credits of $1,134,000 for the quarter and $2,500,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $3,680,000 for the quarter and $4,755,000 for the 6 months.

title: No Headline
description: Steroid Use Called Wide EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 25 (UPI) - John McArdle, one of the United

title: D
description: Dr. J. Herbert Dietz Jr., chief of rehabilitation services at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center until his retirement in 1980, died of a heart attack Aug. 16 at his home in Middle Haddam, Conn. He was 68 years old.

title: No Headline
description: On Giving Qaddafi the Business Will Colonel Qaddafi collapse if Washington refuses to let him buy an American system for mooring and loading tankers offshore? Hardly. But who could imagine authorizing this sale when Libya's reckless strongman has just launched another military adventure, this time against Chad? That's the dilemma of the economic sanctions game. Each case offers difficult choices and uncertain results.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: BankAmerica Ratings Are Lowered by S.& P.

title: Fluid in Lungs Killed Rock Star's 5th Wife
description: The fifth wife of Jerry Lee Lewis, the rock music star, died because her lungs were filled with fluid, the authorities said today.

title: Japan's Steel Exports
description: Japanese exports of steel products totaled 2.69 million tons last month, up 2.3 percent from a year earlier but down 4.3 percent from June, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.

title: DR. FRANCES PASCHER
description: Dr. Frances Pascher, professor emeritus of dermatology at the New York University Medical Center, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Raleigh, N.C. She was 78 years old.

title: Chilean Cyclist Is Disqualified
description: A Chilean cyclist, who was using a banned substance, became the latest athlete to be disqualified from the Pan American Games today.

title: A SEATTLE YOUTH, 20, GETS LIFE SENTENCE IN CHINATOWN CASE
description: Benjamin Ng was sentenced tonight to life in prison without possibility of parole for his role in the killings Feb. 18 of 13 people in a Chinatown gambling hall.

title: Riviera Chapter 11
description: Owners of the Riviera Hotel, unable to make payments on a $56 million loan, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws. Riviera's chairman, Meshulam Riklis, said he would keep the hotel operating normally. He added that he would infuse $1 million immediately and guarantee up to $10 million annually to pay some of the hotel's debts.

title: PRICE'S 66 LEADS WORLD SERIES
description: In humid conditions that made the 7,173-yard Firestone Country Club play easier than usual, 10 players in a field of 42 broke par 70 today in the opening round of the World Series of Golf. Seven others matched par.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SHARMAN DOUGLAS thought

title: Arizona City Files In Bankruptcy Court
description: The city of South Tucson, which has been ordered to pay more than $3.5 million to a disabled former policeman, filed in United States Bankruptcy Court today for protection from creditors.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Choosing Sides

title: AMERICAN WELL SERVICING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include a nonrecurring pretax gain of $483,000 from the increase in the equity value of the company's stake in Beta Engineering & Development Ltd.

title: FED ACTION PUTS RATES UP SHARPLY
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve signaled to the financial markets that it was not easing monetary policy or trying to bring down short-term interest rates. By late in the day, many short- and long-term interest rates were higher by a tenth of a percentage point.

title: 'CLEOPATRA' AND A DE MILLE PROFILE
description: CHANNEL 13 has a happy idea for programming tonight: at 9, show a one-hour documentary about Cecil B. De Mille; at 10, show ''Cleopatra,'' not the latter-day presentation with Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, of course, but the 1934 version, the one in which De Mille directed Claudette Colbert, a cast of thousands and an asp. Even on a television screen, it is still a spectacular.

title: Business Problem Seen In Executive Romances
description: Love in the board room is creating new problems for business as women climb the corporate ladder, says a Harvard Business Review editor who thinks companies should treat affairs of the heart between their executives as conflicts of interest.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
What's in a Name?
description: Edward J. DeBartolo needed a name for his new United States Football League franchise in Pittsburgh, but rather than turning to professional marketers to help with the choice, he held a contest. After reviewing 50,000 amateur entries, including such suggested names as Fortress, Vulcans, Pioneers and Renaissance, DeBartolo announced that the team would be known as the Maulers.

title: ISRAEL PLANS TO WITHHOLD SOME MONEY FROM U.N.
description: Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations said today that for the first time his Government would withhold a portion of its financial contribution to the orgnaization to protest what he called United Nations support of ''pernicious activities designed to vilify and defame Israel.''

title: BRINK'S DEFENSE DERIDES U.S. WITNESSES AT TRIAL
description: Defense lawyers ridiculed the prosecution's key witnesses as summations continued yesterday in the Brink's trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After a loss of $33,000,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $1,300,000 from discontinued operations.

description: Felt Forum Double Bill

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Caesars World Inc., Los Angeles, has elected Cornelius E. Smyth executive vice president for Latin American operations of Caesars World International, a subsidiary.

title: No Headline
description: I.B.M. Japan's Order in China TOKYO, Aug. 25 (Reuters)

title: I'M NOT MARCHING
description: It has been 20 years since Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told a packed Washington Mall about his dream for the poor and disadvantaged of this country, and on Saturday some of you will be marching again. I won't be with you.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: Photos of old rail days.

title: U.S. VOW ON GRAIN DELIVERY
description: The Reagan Administration has gone out of its way to persuade the Soviet Union that there will be no recurrence of a grain embargo under the new five-year agreement that the two countries signed today in Moscow.

title: Dr.WilliamBennett,79,Dies; InventorforBellLaboratories
description: Dr. William Ralph Bennett, an inventor in telecommunications, died of a heart attack Sunday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Colts Neck, N.J.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 26, 1983

title: TRIBUNE CO. PROSPECTUS CITES DAILY NEWS PROFIT
description: The Daily News posted an operating profit of $6.3 million during the first half of 1983, the newspaper's parent company disclosed yesterday in a prospectus for its first public stock offering.

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $106,000 for the quarter and $427,000 for the 6 months, and a provision of $592,000 for loss on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $337,000 for the quarter and $930,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results are restated from amounts previously reported to present King Musical Instruments, Inc. as a discontinued subsidiary.

title: 4 Teen-agers Die in Crash
description: Four teen-agers were killed Wednesday night when their car crashed through a highway rail and hit an embankment. A coroner's spokesman said today that the driver of the car was Kimberlie Ann Haynie, 14 years old. Bethann Cramer, about 15, Kenneth John Still, 17, and a boy, whose name was withheld pending notification of relatives, were also killed.

title: HUNGER PANELISTS ARE CRITICIZED
description: President Reagan's choices for his new Presidential study commission on hunger include some people who have been critical of past welfare and nutrition programs for the poor, a White House source said today.

title: 2,500 Farmers Rally Over Midwest Drought
description: More than 2,500 farmers rallied at a county fairground today to show their concern about the Middle West drought, which they said had caused more damage than Hurricane Alicia.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $16,000 for the quarter and $37,000 for the 9 months.

LIMIT ON SKYSCRAPERS URGED IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: San Francisco's planning department today unveiled a new master plan for the city's heavily built-up downtown that sharply limits the size and location of new skyscrapers.

description: The U.N. Today Aug. 26, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $1.9 million mainly from the close of the company's Ponca City, Oklahoma bicycle plant, less a profit on the sale of a previously closed bike plant in California. c-Net loss. d-Net income.

title: Pakistani Protesters Storm Police Station
description: A policeman and a protester died today as more than 1,000 demonstrators stormed a village police station near the hometown of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was hanged in 1979, officials said.

title: A PAC MAY BE A PAC, BUT YOU OFTEN CAN'T TELL BY THE NAME
description: What's in a name? As far as many political action committees are concerned, not much. Or, perhaps, too much.

title: NEW TOOL FOR PUBLIC AFFAIRS LOBBIES
description: Reluctantly but surely, Washington's public affairs lobbies are beginning to follow big business and big government into the computer age.

title: VALMAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Includes tax credits of $388,000 for the quarter and $1,423,000 for the year.

title: LINCOLN CENTER ACTIONS WIN CAUTIOUS SUPPORT
description: The action of the board of directors of Lincoln Center on Wednesday, imposing sanctions on one of its constituents, the board of the Vivian Beaumont Theater, is guardedly supported by most of those in the theater world who could be interviewed yesterday. Many theater people were out of town because of the summer, and a number of those who were available expressed only amazement at recent events.

title: WOODWARD & LOTHROP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30

title: MUSIC: 'IL PASTOR FIDO' BY HANDEL
description: RECONSTRUCTING a fairly recent theater tradition is difficult enough - just consider the stumbling efforts of the current Bayreuth ''Ring'' to be faithful to a 19th-century Wagnerian style. There is no solid consensus, for that matter, about how Verdi's operas actually were sung. But those are simple problems compared to reviving a Baroque pastoral opera. Here is territory so shadowy that only a few doughty performers who are steeped in the lore of the period dare to venture there. That's understandable, but also a pity, since there is a good deal of music in that genre that deserves to be rescued from the well- meaning hands of collegiate old- music groups.

title: NAMIBIA TALKS SNAGGED OVER U.N. ROLE
description: -West Africa, Aug. 25 - One of the longest-standing issues of the negotiations over independence for this disputed territory came up again today, only a day after South Africa told the Secretary General of the United Nations that it could be considered settled.

title: TROUBLES PLAGUE TRAIN TO NEW YORK
description: An Amtrak train bound for New York derailed in North Carolina yesterday, injuring 21 passengers, after two earlier accidents that left one person dead.

description: Acting on an anonymous tip, the police dug up trash bags bulging with most of the $1 million in gold and silver artifacts and jewels stolen two months ago from a Newport mansion.

description: The city will auction a $76,000 cabin cruiser seized from a landlord who failed to pay a $100,000 fine for neglecting court-ordered repairs on a Harlem apartment building he owns, officials said yesterday.

title: BIRD ART OF FUERTES AT NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM
description: AMERICANS love looking at birds. They bring to that activity a passion that is both perennial and ubiquitous. Irrespective of age, sex or station, and in a spirit of the most total and unaffected democracy, birdwatchers go about their business in big cities and small towns. They go about it in the countryside, in the high mountains and on the open sea. Separate a bird man from his binoculars, and he will bite you.

title: 'MR. MOM,' DOMESTIC COMEDY
description: ''MR. MOM'' is a very creaky comedy about a househusband, whose plight is presented as a terrible humiliation. Though Jack (Michael Keaton) proclaims himself ''a regular Phil Donahue'' when it comes to being enlightened about women in the workplace, the first half of the movie revolves around his annoyance about his wife's having a job.

description: Shipyard workers in Gdansk turned a visit by the Deputy Prime Minister into a pro- union rally today, greeting him with catcalls and chants of ''Solidarity!''

title: DAVID BOWIE IN 'MERRY CHRISTMAS'
description: DAVID BOWIE plays a born leader in Nagisa Oshima's ''Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence,'' and he plays him like a born film star. Mr. Bowie's screen presence here is mercurial and arresting, and he seems to arrive at this effortlessly, though he manages to do something slyly different in every scene. The demands of his role may sometimes be improbable and elaborate, but Mr. Bowie fills them in a remarkably plain and direct way. Little else in the film is so unaffected or clear.

title: BLAST IN LEBANON KILLS FRENCHMAN
description: A French soldier died in an accidental explosion today that destroyed a French ammunition truck in West Beirut. A short while later a bomb ripped through the Air France offices in East Beirut, wounding three Lebanese, the authorities said.

title: GAIN FOR U.S. CARS IN EUROPE
description: American car makers, long trailing in the European field, are finding themselves in the driver's seat. For the first time, Europe's leading seller is an American company - the Ford Motor Company - and General Motors is scoring sharp sales gains in the Continent's auto markets.

ECONOMIC SCENE;
HEALTH CARE'S SOARING COSTS
description: PROGRESS in combating inflation has been welcome news. The health sector, however, continues to experience soaring inflation. In 1979 the United States spent $215 billion on the health sector, or 8.9 percent of the gross national product. In 1982 the United States spent $322 billion, or 10.5 percent of the G.N.P. In just three short years, health spending increased by 50 percent - considerably faster than either inflation in the economy or growth in family incomes.

title: BRIEFS
description: Acacia Mutual Life Insurance Co., Washington, said it had agreed to purchase the Calvert Group Ltd.

title: BOAT REFUGEES' HORRORS
description: The flow of Vietnamese boat refugees has fallen sharply since 1979, yet there remains a steady leakage across the Gulf of Thailand and the South China Sea of those who have experienced or fear repression by Vietnamese authorities. Today's refugees face the same dangers as their predecessors: rough seas and unseaworthy boats; Vietnamese Navy patrols; and, in some cases, an inhospitable welcome on the receiving shores. But these dangers pale next to the horror of pirate attacks. The pirates are not of the swashbuckling variety, but rather

title: FED VOTED TIGHTER BANK RESERVES
description: The Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee voted July 12 to tighten bank reserves slightly , according to minutes of that meeting, which were released today.

description: Yuri V. Andropov said today that if negotiations with the United States on medium-range missiles succeeded, the Soviet missiles in Europe that Moscow is offering to eliminate would be, as he put it, ''liquidated.''

description: With Elie Nadelman's 19-foot-high sculpture of Two Circus Women serving as a backdrop, the architects of Mexico's financial balancing act took a bow yesterday on the promenade level of Lincoln Center's New York State Theater.

title: INQUIRY ON AQUINO UNCOVERS LITTLE
description: The chief police investigator assigned to the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. gave the first detailed account of his inquiry today. He acknowledged, however, that he had no firm answers for nearly every key question in the case.

title: No Headline
description: The March and the Dream Today's march in Washington commemorates history, progress and paralysis. The history, of course, arises from that tidal wave in 1963, the first of a generation of gigantic demonstrations. The progress, whether measured politically or economically, is remarkable. So is the paralysis. Many people will march today because many - minorities, women, the handicapped - sense that the nation's march toward Martin Luther King's eloquent dream has slowed dramatically.

description: John Robert Carroll was sentenced today to 13 years in prison for manslaughter in the death of his infant daughter, whose liver was donated in an unsuccessful effort to save a Mississippi boy, Brandon Hall.

description: A flash propane explosion on an Indian reservation today injured seven children and two adults and forced the evacuation of 200 people as flames shot as high as 60 feet in the air, the authorities said.

title: Seabrook Reactor
description: The United Illuminating Company said it would obey a State Department of Public Utility Control order that it seek cancellation of a second reactor at the Seabrook nuclear power plant. The utility is only one of 16 investors in the project, owning 17.5 percent of the $5.2 billion plant in New Hampshire. The state agency said continuation of construction on Seabrook 2, which is 25 percent complete, placed too much strain on the utility's finances.

title: Malta Still Blocks East-West Accord
description: Malta continued to refuse to endorse final agreement today at the 35-nation conference on European security as diplomats pressed ahead with plans for a major East-West gathering of foreign ministers here Sept. 7 to 9.

title: Stamford Beaten
description: Hidetoshi Yoshino pitched a three-hitter and scored four runs as Osaka, Japan, beat Stamford, Conn., 11-3, today in the game for third place at the Little League World Series. Yoshino, who pitched a perfect game Tuesday against Saudi Arabia, did not allow a hit today until the fourth inning, when Brian Mayglothling singled and Greg Padilla followed with a home run. Yoshino hit two doubles.

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones Classified Code Unit Disclosed

Captain Safford applied for the patent on May 23, 1962, but the Patent and Trademark Office delayed issuance under a secrecy order.

description: Developers of the Marriott Marquis Hotel now meet a requirement that more than 20 percent of their work force be made up of minority-group members, the state's Urban Development Corporation said.

title: G.M. Recalls Police Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling 19,000 Chevrolet and Buick police cars because the throttles might stick open, the automobile maker said today. General Motors said the cars involved included 1980 Impalas and Malibus sold in California and 1981 LeSabres and 1981, 1982 and 1983 Impalas and Malibus sold nationwide.

title: CHARGES FLY IN PRIMARY ON WEST SIDE
description: This is the story of a primary contest for Democratic district leader that has just about everything: a granddaughter of Nelson A. Rockefeller; allegations of forgery, non-existent addresses and residences in Fifth Avenue office buildings; a Board of Elections altercation that brought in the police; a candidate of Afghan background in what was once a classic Irish district, and, finally, the same candidate admitting he had served a sentence for passing bad checks.

As a result of the contract, the company said it could hire an additional 400 employees for the 4,500-member work force at its aerospace operations. The subsidiary said the contract covers 26 fuel tanks and raw materials for 21 additional tanks.

They were scheduled to come to the United States for the first time next month to perform at the New York Shakespeare Festival and to lecture at the New York University School of the Arts and the Yale Drama School.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 27, 1983 International
description: Moscow will ''liquidate'' missiles in Europe that it has offered to eliminate if negotiations with the United States are successful, Yuri V. Andropov said. The United States has said that previous Soviet statements left open the possibility that the medium- range missiles, including triple-warhead SS-20's, would simply be moved from Europe to Asia. However, the Soviet offer was coupled to a restatement of the basic Soviet negotiating position, an insistence that the United States abandon its plan to start deploying 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe in December. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moscow has accepted a U.S. proposal to renew negotiations on a new cultural and scientific exchange agreement and on establishing consulates in New York and Kiev, State Department officials said. The cultural and scientific exchange was suspended and plans to establish a Soviet consulate in New York and a United States consulate in Kiev were broken off by the United States in response to the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan in 1979. (1:5.)

title: Republic Airlines
description: Republic Airlines Inc. said leaders of the Airline Pilots Association had tentatively approved a 15 percent wage reduction for nine months, effective Sept. 1. The agreement also includes a freeze on scheduled pay increases for the 1,800 pilots during the nine months, it said.

description: Lister Hill, who served 45 years in Congress, was listed in fair condition today after his chauffeur-driven car struck the back of another auto Thursday, the police said. Mr. Hill's wife, Henrietta, was listed in stable condition.

title: A BIKER'S TALE
description: Winter in New York City brings not only snow and slush but drivers' curses as car wheels catch potholes and underbodies clang against the pavement. With each snowfall and thaw, the potholes and the curses multiply. All who drive understand the connection between ice and potholes. However, I have discovered (some might say, invented) a new method for revealing the true nature and frequency of potholes and their ultimate cause. I call my basic instrument the rumpmeter, for reasons that will become clear. It not only gauges the depth of the pothole but unequivocally identifies future cavities.

title: TWO WORKMEN PLUNGE TO DEATH FROM 25 STORIES

title: Ruling Against Drivers
description: A state appeals court in Trenton, N.J., has ruled that six harness racing drivers, including Herve Filion , who has the most career victories, should be suspended for actions in a race still under investigation. The 3-0 decision by the Appellate Division of Superior Court upheld suspensions imposed by the New Jersey Racing Commission on grounds that the drivers slowed horses in a mile pace at Freehold Raceway on Oct. 31, 1981 that showed betting irregularities. Filion, Larry Rathbone, Paul Ingrassia Jr., Harold Kelly and Donald Dancer received 30-day suspensions, and Thomas Luchento received a 10- day suspension.

Lagomarsino, Republican of California, said today that it was his Administration's ''sacred responsibility'' to guarantee that ''Central America does not become a string of anti- American Marxist dictatorships.''

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. CRITICISM OF REAGAN ON EDUCATION IS FAULTED BY BELL
description: Federal spending for educationally disadvantaged children and for adult and vocational training programs has dropped dramatically under the Reagan Administration. according to a report prepared by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Miss Lin, Financial Aide, Weds S. E. Blicharski Jr.
description: Meihwa Lin, daughter of A. Oscar Lin of Flushing, Queens, and Jane Lin of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Stephen E. Blicharski Jr., son of Wanda Blicharski of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Mr. Blicharski. The Rev. John Cullinane performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Quarter's Productivity Pace Fastest in 8 Years
description: Riding the national rebound from recession, United States business productivity surged upward at a 6.1 percent annual rate in the April-to-June quarter, the Government reported today. That was the fastest pace in nearly eight years.

title: U.N. Chief Offers Help At Talks on Angola
description: -West Africa, Aug. 26 - The Secretary General of the United Nations offered today to play a role in negotiations on Angola and the Cuban troops there, but insisted that the Angolan issue was separate from the independence of South-West Africa.

title: PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
KV-Upjohn Deal
description: The KV Pharmaceutical Company said that under an agreement with the Upjohn Company it is developing a nonsteroidal anti-inflmmatory product for treating arthritis and inflammatory diseases. It said the product uses KV's proprietary rate- controlled drug delivery technology and is designed for once-a-day dosing. Upjohn is based in Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: NORTH AMERICAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Space Shuttle Is on Schedule
description: With weather problems out of the way, the path was cleared today for the third launching of the shuttle Challenger, a nighttime blastoff that will carry the first American black into space.

title: SUSPECT IN 13 SEATTLE DEATHS TO GET LIFE SENTENCE
description: The sentence of life imprisonment without parole imposed by a Superior Court jury Thursday night on Benjamin Ng did not dispel the gloom that has hung over Seattle's Chinatown since Feb. 18, when 13 people were murdered in a robbery at the Wah Mee Club, an illegal gambling house.

title: SCOUTING
description: They're Shooting For Tough Image

title: DINNER BELL FOODS reports earnings for Year to July 2
Concepcion Penalized
description: Dave Concepcion has been suspended for three days and fined an undisclosed sum by the National League for allegedly spitting in the face of an umpire during a game last Tuesday with the Chicago Cubs.

title: U.S. SAYS STATE HAS FIXED FLAWS IN DISASTER PLAN
description: A Federal agency said today that drills this week in Westchester and Rockland Counties showed that officials had remedied the last two ''significant deficiencies'' in plans for coping with an accident at the Indian Point nuclear complex.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. CLINCHES GOLD IN MEN'S BASKETBALL
description: The United States clinched the men's basketball championship at the Pan American Games tonight with an 87-79 victory over Brazil.

title: Japanese Car Deal Possible
description: A high- level Japanese minister said today that the question of restraining auto exports to the United States ''is a completely clean slate,'' indicating that Japan may reconsider its decision not to renew the limits a fourth year.

title: METS TROUNCE BY GIANTS 12-1
description: Joel Youngblood came back to Shea Stadium last night to haunt the Mets for trading him away. Youngblood belted a first-inning three-run homer that sent the San Francisco Giants on their way to a 12-1 victory, and he caused some more damage along the way.

title: 13 Will Split Jackpot Totaling $9.9 Million
description: There were 13 winning tickets in Thursday's $9.9 million drawing in New Jersey's Pick Six lottery, it was announced today by Hazel F. Gluck, the State Lottery Director.

title: Venezuela's Fund Talks
description: Venezuela has put off until 1984 talks with the International Monetary Fund aimed at devising a new economic program, Finance Minister Arturo Sosa said today.

title: JOBLESS TEEN-AGERS A SOLUBLE PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: PHONE UNION CHIEF BARS CONCESSIONS
description: A few key bargaining units stuck on local disputes held up settlement of the 20- day-old telephone strike today, and workers vowed to press on with the nationwide walkout until the last contract is settled.

description: 'People Pieces'

title: NEW YORK CITY TRAFFIC IS UNFIT FOR BIKES

description: To the Editor:
