description: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to reopen negotiations on a new cultural and scientific exchange agreement, State Department officials said today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 43.

title: APARTMENTS: HARD CHOICE SPLITS DARIEN
description: Witnesses at public hearings talked of ghettos and leper colonies. Elderly residents chastised younger ones as disrespectful. Young homeowners spoke of the destruction of a dream.

title: Yacht Club Drops Dispute Over Keel
description: The New York Yacht Club announced today that it had resolved both of its objections to Australia II, the top- seeded America's Cup challenger, ending a monthlong controversy over the boat's winged keel.

title: DELOREAN PROPERTIES FROZEN
description: John Z. DeLorean, the automobile maker who faces drug trafficking charges in Los Angeles, cannot sell any of his three East Coast properties, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: No Headline
description: Alcoa Raises Price Of Ingot by 6.5%

title: DESPITE U.S. CUTBACKS, CITY FIGHTS LEAD POISON
description: The tests' results were positive. The 18-month-old boy from Bedford-Stuyvesant had lead poisoning, an illness that especially affects children of poverty, robbing them of energy, retarding their intellect and eventually, in the severest cases, taking their lives.

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $117,600. c-Includes tax credits of $271,250 for the quarter and $610,250 for the 9 months.

title: 6 COUNTRIES WEIGH A $6 BILLION LOAN TO MONETARY FUND
description: Mexico and bankers signed accords restructuring $11.4 billion of nation's public-sector debt. Page 33.

title: Letter: On Terrorism The Roots of Armenian Violence To the Editor:
description: No matter how strongly one may disagree with their methods (and our organization has condemned indiscriminate violence like that perpetrated by the Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia in July at Orly Airport), it serves no purpose to misrepresent the motives of Armenian terrorist organizations and to ignore the facts by suggesting, as your Aug. 9 editorial does, that they are motivated exclusively by events of 1915 and are simply killing Turks ''because of their ethnic identity'' in revenge for Turkish crimes of almost 70 years ago.

title: 2 Steelmakers Raise Prices
description: Two large steel companies, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and Armco Inc., said yesterday that they would raise their prices on sheet and strip steel by 7 percent, beginning Sept. 1.

title: MCRAE CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Filmex Principals Quit Ailing Festival
description: Gary Essert, director and co-founder of the Los Angeles International Film Exposition, and Tom Laughlin, president of the organization, known as Filmex, have resigned from the financially ailing festival, it was announced Thursday.

title: ENORMITY IN TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Crum & Forster To Buy Navco
description: Crum & Forster Inc., a unit of the Xerox Corporation, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Navco Corporation for $31 a share, or $34 million.

title: Chad Thanks France For Policy on Fighting
description: A Government spokesman said today that Chad was grateful that President Francois Mitterrand had not ruled out the possibility that French troops might play ''a more combative role'' in the country.

title: 16 EDENS-COUNT 'EM
description: According to my Zip Code book, the United States has 16 Edens. There is no Eden in California, which surprises me. There is one in Texas, which is not surprising.

title: BRANIFF-HYATT DEAL SEEN ADVANCING
description: A vote among various classes of Braniff creditors has been running about 90 percent in favor of a plan to start up the airline again with an investment of about $70 million by the Hyatt Corporation, sources close to the proceedings said yesterday.

title: IN EGYPT, A BUMPER CROP OF RUMORS AND MELONSThe Talk of Cairo
description: For weeks, mothers kept children, and their fears, locked indoors.

title: TERRANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNITOG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BAR GROUP'S PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Open Withdrawals
description: Kevin Curren and Evonne Goolagong Cawley withdrew yesterday from the United States Open. Curren, who was seeded seventh, told officials he had hurt his wrist, and Miss Goolagong, seeded 16th, was said to have a flareup of an injury she incurred in Europe. They will be replaced in their 128-player divisions by the higher- ranked losers in the last round of this week's qualifying tournaments.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Business Day article Aug. 19 incorrectly defined ''noble'' metals. They are chemically inactive, especially in not reacting with oxygen.

title: SIMPSONS-SEARS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Music and Art

title: Kaypro Stock
description: The Kaypro Corporation, the portable computer manufacturer that had its intial public offering on Thursday when four million shares were sold at $10 each, closed yesterday at 10 1/4 bid, up 1/8, in over-the-counter trading.. The company's profits and sales have been booming this year.

title: NEW JUNIOR HIGH TO LINK WORK EXPERIENCE WITH SCHOOL STYU
description: DY

title: GEOPHYSICAL SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since March.

title: RULING MADE ON METRO-NORTH CREW SIZES
description: A binding decision announced yesterday by an arbitration panel sets a procedure for determining train crew size on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, the issue that led to a six- week strike by trainmen last spring.

title: Japan Consumer Prices
description: Japanese consumer prices fell five-tenths of 1 percent in July from June, the Government said today. July prices were up 2.2 percent from a year earlier. The figures are not seasonally adjusted.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Maxim's Encore

title: Woman Arraigned As Brink's Suspect
description: A woman arrested Wednesday in Washington pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to a charge that she had helped suspects escape after the 1981 Brink's robbery in Rockland County.

title: SOVIET EMIGRE DOCTORS SUE MEDICAL SCHOOLS, CHARGING DENIAL OF RIGHT TO PRACTICE
description: Thirty-four Jewish physicians who live in New York and are political refugees from the Soviet Union filed a formal complaint with Federal civil rights officials here yesterday, charging that they had been prevented from practicing medicine because of discrimination by medical societies and hospitals.

title: DOLPHINS ROUT GIANTS
description: If the Giants' final exhibition game tonight was to decide the starting quarterback, then Mark Reed did as much to win the position as the other candidates. Mark Reed did not play.

title: Maine Kite Stops Air Traffic
description: Two young children, testing how high their kite could fly, stopped air traffic for about half an hour Thursday at Hancock County Airport. The airport manager, Robert Cossett, called the Hancock County Sheriff's Department to report that a Bar Harbor Airlines airplane had just missed hitting a kite at 700 feet. An officer tracked the kite to a backyard, where the mother of the two children was already reeling it in.

title: Man Fatally Shot On Bronx Street
description: A gunman killed a man, fired at a police officer and wounded a mailman in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx last evening, the police said.

title: Woman Injured Fatally As Jet Crashes in Yard
description: A Marine Corps jet exploded ''like an atomic bomb'' when it smashed into the front yard of a home here Thursday after the crew ejected, fatally burning an elderly woman, officials and witnesses said.

title: DR. MARTIN STEINBERG, 79, FORMER DIRECTOR OF MT. SINAI
description: Dr. Martin R. Steinberg, the director of Mount Sinai Hospital for 21 years, who helped establish the hospital's School of Medicine, died of heart disease Tuesday at Metropolitan Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 79 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: A LOWER-COST TRY AT HYDROPONICS
description: Under a one-acre plastic roof between the East River and the steel oil drums of the New York Power Authority generating station in Astoria, Queens, tons of plump tomatoes, 12- inch cucumbers and bushy heads of lettuce are growing.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago results include a charge of $12,200,000 from the writedown of certain assets.

title: 13 A-Plant Guards Ousted
description: Thirteen guards hired to protect the San Onofre nuclear plant have been dismissed for having ''significantly high levels'' of drugs in their bodies, officials said.

title: TULLY RETURNS AND WINS GOLD
description: Mike Tully of Los Angeles, one of the 12 American male track and field athletes who left here Tuesday amid a drug controversy, returned this morning and won the pole vault tonight in the Pan American Games.

title: No Headline
description: Marijuana as Medicine Smoking marijuana may be harmful to your health, doctors warn. But they also know that in the case of several illnesses, marijuana is the therapeutic drug of choice. It reduces nausea for patients undergoing cancer treatment, for instance, and arrests developing blindness in glaucoma victims.

title: MYSTERY OF SOLIDARITY FIGURE: PRESSURE TO RECANT REPORTED
description: Wlad yslaw Hardek, the former underground Solidarity leader who said Tuesday that he had surrendered to get amnesty, was in fact captured by the police several days before his announcement and pressed into his appearance on state television, a Roman Catholic Church source in the Nowa Huta steel-mill district said today.

title: STROH'S BIG-LEAGUE GAMBLE
description: The Stroh family quite literally bet its mortgage on last year's takeover of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, pledging the assets of the Stroh Brewery Company for the $336 million it borrowed to acquire the larger company.

title: NATIONAL ENERGY CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was ''spun-off'' in September 1982 as a stock dividend by Cogenic Energy Systems, Inc.

title: EALING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $31,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss. d-Inclucing a tax credit of $112,000.

title:
PATENTS ;
Helping Computers Understand Speech
description: Because of variations in sound combinations, it has been technologically difficult for a computer to understand human speech, particularly continuous speech.

title: MUSICIANS' DISABILITIES PROVOKE MEDICAL STUDY
description: The hand troubles of Leon Fleisher and Gary Graffman, two of America's best pianists, are perhaps the most publicized examples of the physical and motor control disabilities that can beset musicians. But those two pianists are not the only ones who have suffered.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW APPLIANCES: WHEN THE THRILL IS GONE
description: Marilyn Evins has a problem and it's almost no comfort at all to know that she has plenty of company. Mrs. Evins is what is known as a sucker for advertisements that virtually guarantee to make her life a breeze and her body beautiful; she can't wait to run out and buy a new product that her friends tell her she can't live without. So before the ink has dried on one check, she's busily scribbling another for something that she doesn't need and will probably rarely, if ever, use.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO AGREE ON AIDING CHILDREN IN WELFARE HOTELS
description: Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo agreed yesterday to work together to help children in the city's welfare hotels.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $200 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply declined by a meager $200 million in the financial week that ended Aug. 17.

title: Aide at Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that its directors had elected Peter A. Field president of its consumer group and vice president of the company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, AUGUST 27, 1983
description: International An emergency loan of $6 billion for the I.M.F. is being negotiated by several industrial countries and Saudi Arabia, officials reported. The money would help the agency offset a squeeze on its resources caused by its lending to developing countries hurt by the recession. Besides Saudi Arabia, the nations involved were said to be West Germany, Japan, Britain and Switzerland. (Page 1.) The I.M.F. approved a $14.1 million loan for the leftist Government of Grenada despite strong Administration objections. (36.) Agreements to restructure $11.4 billion in Mexican debt were signed in New York. The accords, with some 300 commercial banks, call for principal payments to be stretched out over eight years with a four-year grace period. (33.)

title: Octogenarian Record
description: The time of 5 minutes 47.09 seconds was not especially fast for a 200- meter backstroke event, but for Ella Peckham it was a world record. Her time in the 200-meter event at the United States Masters Long Course championships in Indianapolis on Thursday was a record for her age group. She is 84, the oldest competitor at the meet, and began swimming competitively only two years ago.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chairman Resigns At United Artists
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company said today that Donald Sipes, chairman and chief executive of its United Artists subsidiary, had resigned from those positions, as well as from his seat on the MGM/UA board of directors. The move was not unexpected.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $2,163,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $747,622 from discontinued operations and a gain of $86,044 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Sampson Signs
description: Ralph Sampson , the No. 1 pick in last June's college draft, signed a four-year contract yesterday with the Houston Rockets for between $5 million and $6 million, according to the Rockets' general manager, Ray Patterson . That will probably make Sampson the highest-paid rookie in National Basketball Association history.

title: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PACESETTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STALKING TAKEOUT SHOPS FOR GOOD CHICKEN SALAD
description: If three weeks ago someone had asked me what good chicken salad had in common with an honest man, I would have answered, ''Nothing.'' But after sampling 60 different chicken salads purchased from 31 local fancy-food shops, I would have to answer, sadly, that both are equally hard to find. Following the example of Diogenes, who went out with a lantern in broad daylight in search of an honest man, I went out in broad daylight in search of good chicken salad and wound up almost as much a Cynic as that Greek philosopher.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: ELECTROHOME LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: bNet income.

title: BUSES ROLL INTO CAPITAL WITH RALLY PARTICIPANTS
description: The first of the expected 4,200 buses rolled in this evening in preparation for a rally Saturday to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the nation's largest civil rights demonstration.

title: A Terrific Waterfront View
description: THE Bascule Bridge opens and a graceful sailboat glides past. Then another, and still another.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: ELIZABETH
description: WALKING the broad streets of Elizabeth's Westminster section, a visitor sees clapboard colonial houses enclosed by picket fences and senses the spirit of a gentler age. Westminster and the slightly less grand Elmora section conjure up an image that clashes with the view of Elizabeth that passing motorists get from the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: VIOLENCE IN BEIRUT
description: While much is reported on the goals of the Syrian and Israeli forces in Lebanon, confusion and mystery still surround the aims of the multitude of militias which battled before the intervention of those armies, and which will, in all likelihood, continue to do so long after they depart. Subsequent articles should clarify just who in Lebanon is shooting at whom, and why. MICHAEL OREN Princeton, N.J.

title: Tug McGraw Is Sued
description: Tug McGraw has been sued for $270,000 by a New Jersey promoter. The Philadelphia Phillies' relief pitcher was accused of failing to pay commissions on a contract with All- Star Productions of Willingboro, N.J. William H. Pettit , president of the company, accused McGraw of failing to honor a deal signed on Jan. 1, 1981, that guaranteed the promoter a 20 percent commission on all endorsements that he arranged for the pitcher.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
All the Ingredients Of a Health Co-op
description: Twelve years ago the nonprofit Way of Life Co-op opened in Pleasant-ville to provide natural and organically grown food to members anxious to avoid chemical fertilizers, pesticides, sprays, additives and preservatives.

title: TOPICS
description: WHAT do you do in a car during the highway rush hour? If, like me, you're the passenger, you stare out the window. One morning, while traffic was jammed up for miles, I stared out the window as we entered a brick underpass. The arch had a border with a pleasing design, and I found myself daydreaming of ancient viaducts, of Caesar and his legions.

title: A DAY OF CANDLES FOR THE CARDINAL
description: Hundreds of people visited St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to say prayers and light candles for Terence Cardinal Cooke. The Archdiocese of New York had disclosed Friday that the Cardinal was terminally ill with leukemia.

title: USE OF STEROIDS: DISCOVERY IN THE FACE OF DISBELIEF
description: The drug scandal that has rocked the Pan American Games here is a result of two intertwined occurrences. First, one arm of science caught up with another, and second, too many people refused to believe it.

title:
GARDENING;
AN IDEAL TIME FOR IMPROVING THE LAWN
description: AS the end of summer approaches, it is timely to evaluate the condition of the lawn with an eye toward the possible need for renovation. A sparse turf may not be sufficient reason to renovate, if there are few bare spots larger than four to five inches in diameter. Adequate water, lime and fertilizer and the use of herbicides as such a lawn to fill in by spring. But where a sufficient number of large, bare spots are present, renovation is the logical solution.

title: THE REGION
description: Decoys DescendOn Times Square

title: An Arm Around the Shoulder, that's All Joey Ever Needed
description: CURIOUS how a memory, instead of fading, can grab you and never let go. I have such a memory of a neighborhood boy named Joey. I spent many years waiting for Joey, waiting to hear he was finally okay.

title: Lisa McHugh and Mitchell Vaughn Massey Wed
description: Elizabeth Nevin McHugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nevin McHugh of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mitchell Vaughn Massey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lewis Massey of Ragland, W.Va. The Rev. William V. Reynolds performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont.

title: ONCE A WILDERNESS, NOW A WASTELAND
description: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP NOT far from where the headwaters of the Manasquan River begin with several small streams and a cranberry bog, it is hard to find the wild cherry trees, swamp dogwoods or Atlantic white cedars that once grew here.

title: THEATER: CONSTRUCTION OF BRIDGE SET TO MUSIC
description: Well, Verdi wrote a splashy musical, ''A"ida,'' for the opening of the Suez Canal, so why shouldn't Dorothy Chansky (book and lyrics) and Scott MacLarty (music) do a modest musical, ''The Brooklyn Bridge,'' for the 100th birthday of the local crossing which, like the canal, links different worlds, in this case, Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Kathryn Carson, Lawyer, Marries
description: Kathryn Louise Carson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David L. Carson of Troy, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Raymond Joseph Dorado, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ricardo Dorado of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Jane Brawley and the Rev. Thomas Phelan performed the ceremony at the First United Presbyterian Church.

title: A COLD SHOULDER FOR SOLAR WATER HEATING
description: AQUASOL is the name given by Public its $1 Service Electric and Gas, New Jersey's largest utility, to its residential solar water-heating program. While other utility companies in the state offer their customers loans and advice on installing solar water heaters, Public Service is the first to actually select two particular systems, train contractors to install them and back the systems with five-year warranties.

title: IN PAKISTAN, ISLAM LEAVES LITTLE ROOM FOR FREEDOM
description: The other day, the morning movie on closed-circuit television in one of Karachi's big Western-style hotels was about a military leader who seized power, disbanded Parliament and, as the agent of the Almighty, set about creating a puritan society.

title: THE NATION'S PRISONERS JOIN THE LABOR FORCE
description: LEAVENWORTH, Kan.

title: October Nuptials For Miss Conroy And R. D. Tyrer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gerard Conroy of New York and Key Largo, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberley Ann Conroy, to Robert David Tyrer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Tyrer of Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England.

title: Food;  What to Do With the Tomatoes When the Plants Get Heavy
description: DEEP red and bursting with flavor and juice, tomatoes, now at the height of their season, are plentiful and low priced. At this time of year, in fact, there is usually a glut. People growing their own are experiencing the familar yearly frustration of trying to figure out what to do with them all. And it won't be long before those plastic wrapped "slicing" tomatoes, hard as a rock or mushy as paper towels and unfit for any use in the kitchen are going to be back in the stores. When these tomatoes are the only choice it is better to stick to canned ones.

title: MRS. THATCHER TESTS THE MINERS
description: LONDON THERE is an old saying here that British politicians should not tangle with

title: Government Formed On Indian Ocean Isle
description: Prime Minister Aneerood Jugnauth, whose three-party alliance won last week's general election, formed a new government today with eight new faces and a surprise choice for Foreign Minister.

title: PANEL TO PROMOTE BOND ISSUE
description: A campaign committee has been established, at the urging of Governor Cuomo and key aides, to raise money for the promotion of the proposed $1.25 billion transportation bond issue that will appear on the November ballot.

description: A First StepOn Acid Rain

title: CARL C. FRANCIS
description: Carl C. Francis, a longtime officer of the Putnam Trust Company in Greenwich, Conn., and its chairman from 1959 to 1964, died last Monday in a nursing home in Seattle.

title: Nothing Can Be Taken for Granted
description: I TOOK Tylenol for years and used a drop or two of Gravy Master in my day, and I tried Rely tampons before the onset of toxic shock syndrome. Since the incidents involving these products occurred, I have curtailed my use of them considerably.

title: Susan Hertzberg Becomes Fiancee Of Stephen Brody
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Arthur Hertzberg of Englewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Riva Hertzberg, to Stephen Russell Brody, son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Brody of Devon, Pa. The wedding is to be in October.

title: KATHARINE FALK
description: Katharine Sonneborn Falk, a lecturer and private teacher of Jewish history and culture, died of cancer Wednesday while visiting San Diego.

title: ''The Golden Dawn''
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPSITES MAY GO TO PROTECT BEARS
description: The crowd booed when Barry Wohl, a pediatrician from Sheridan, Wyo., stood up and said, ''I favor removing Fishing Bridge Campground and not replacing it'' in order to protect the park's dwindling grizzly bear population.

title: Mary L. Camp Is Wed To George W. Vieth Jr.
description: Mary Lawrence Camp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Camp of Crestwood, Ky., was married yesterday to George W. Vieth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vieth of Davenport, Iowa. The Rev. Benjamin Sanders performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Louisville, Ky.

title: Corrections
description: A letter last Sunday from James H. Ray contained several typographical errors.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
RERUNS PAY PRODUCERS' BILLS
description: THIS month, the Federal Communications Commission issued

title: TEXANS ARE WARY AS NEW STORM NEARS COAST
description: A hurricane watch went into effect from Port O'Connor to Brownsville tonight as tropical storm Barry gathered strength over the Gulf of Mexico, and vacationers in one coastal town were evacuated.

title: HONDURANS DIVIDED ON U.S. MANEUVERS
description: Outside the village of Yojoa, Napoleon Velazquez brought his mule to a halt by the highway.

title: Bus Routes Tested In Evacuation Drill
description: IF practice makes perfect, then the people who would organize an evacuation in case of an accident at the Indian Point nuclear power plants may have taken a step toward perfection last Tuesday, when they made a third attempt to show the Federal Government that enough buses would be available to carry people without automobiles.

title: Woman in Joliet, Ill., Is 17th Slaying Victim
description: An elderly woman whose body was found in her living room chair became the 17th person slain in the Will County area in the last two months.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AWEEKLY Bergen County newspaper recently ceased publication, another victim, say its publishers and editor, of the economy and unstable advertising revenues.

title: THE NATION
description: Mississippi DecidesThough her opponent avoided the issues of gender and age, preferring to portray her as a member of the ''old guard'' that controlled Mississippi for 50 years without bringing progress, many voters clearly believed 62-year-old Evelyn Gandy's place was not the Governor's mansion. Or so they said last week after Miss Gandy, a former Lieutenant Governor trying for the second time to become the state's first woman chief executive, lost the runoff for Democratic nomination to Bill Allain, 52.3 percent to 47.7 percent.

title: GIANTS LIKELY TO START SIMMS
description: Whatever decisions the Giants were making, from starting quarterbacks to third-string tight ends, remained behind closed doors yesterday.

title: WON OBIE FOR ROLE IN 'BUFFALO'
description: Mike Kellin, a character actor whose career on the stage, screen and television spanned 35 years, died of lung cancer Friday in Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Nyack.

title: SMALLER NATIONS CRACK ARMS MARKET
description: There are Brazilian armored personnel carriers in Portugal, Israeli fighter-bombers in Argentina, South Korean field guns in Brazil and South African surface-to-air missiles in Chile, all examples of the entry into the international arms bazaar of new producers prepared to sell their weapons to almost any buyer.

title: GUATEMALAN COUP WITH A DIFFERNECE

title: CONDITIONING ATHLETES' MINDS
description: Emily Greenspan's book ''Little Winners'' was published this month by Little Brown. By Emily Greenspan AUL ANNACONE, NOW 20 YEARS old, was a talented but temperamental and easily distracted tennis prodigy. At 17, he was ranked No. 2 among boys 18 and under in the East. At the United States Tennis Association's Junior Clay Court Championships that year, he lost the third and last set to his former doubles partner, Ken Flach, 11 games to 9. Furious, he stomped off the court and slammed his fist into one of the lockers downstairs. ''I've got bad news, and I've got worse news,'' he told his father over the telephone. ''The bad news is that I lost to Ken. The worse news is that I broke my hand.''

title: CORDLESS PHONE: TROUBLE ON THE LINE IS A NEW PROBLEM
description: When Richard Barth got his cordless telephone as a birthday present last spring, he was delighted with it. ''It was something of a marvel to me that I could place a call without a wire,'' Mr. Barth, a writer and jewelry designer, recalled.

description: The defense scored first and Joe Theismann and Bob Holly each threw touchdown passes to give the Washington Redskins a 27-19 victory over the Buffalo Bills tonight in a National Football League exhibition.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Bier of Valley Stream, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Cathy Bier, to Dr. Bruce Levin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Levin of Rockville Centre, L.I. The future bride, a dentist, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine. Dr. Levin, who graduated from Hahnemann Medical College, is a resident at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. A June wedding is planned.

title: HEALTH INSURANCE AND THE OLDER WORKER
description: In the last few weeks, workers between the ages of 65 and 69 have been receiving a blizzard of paperwork from their employers notifying them of a major change in the way health insurance reimbursement programs will operate. The notices stem from legislation intended to cut the Government's Medicare bill. The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, in amendments to the Age Discrimination in Employment Act and the Social Security Act, stipulates that Medicare will no longer be the insurer of first resort for older employees. Instead, private insurance plans of employers will pick up medical bills first and then Medicare will pay whatever remaining expenses qualify for coverage. The change, which is retroactive to Jan. 1, is expected to save the Government $1.48 billion through fiscal year 1985 by transferring the primary insurance bill to the private sector. Overall benefits for older employees who continue all of their existing coverage ''generally will not be reduced,'' said Herbert M. Pollock, an official at the Health Care Financing Administration, which administers Medicare. But older workers are now faced with key decisions about what health insurance they should carry. For some, the cost of their premiums may rise. The new law requires that employers of 20 or more persons must give older workers, and their spouses age 65 through 69, the option to select several different forms of health coverage. They can choose their employer's private health plan, Medicare Part B (the voluntary part of Medicare) or both.

The Rev. Harry Chase performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church in Tenafly.

title: SOOTHING SIGHTS AND SOUNDS Natural Combos
description: Some of our favorite combos get their gigs together each year for the month of August. They're bands of wildflowers, and like most musicians, they're always on the road, or at least, in profusion, along the roadsides.

title: Q AND A Shelter From Tax on Sale Question:
description: I am selling a commercial property. I have been told that if I invest the proceeds from the sale in like real estate within five years, and in the interim place those proceeds in a blind trust, there would be no taxes due. Is this correct? . . . S.C.B., Westport, Conn.

title: JUSTICE BRANDEIS AND THE CASELOAD
description: They were confidential conversations between a United States Supreme Court Justice and an intimate friend. The subject was the Court's workload. The Justice felt that too many of the nation's problems were being brought to the Federal courts, and, more than that, he was concerned that his colleagues were too willing to rely on personal prejudice in resolving those problems, especially in cases involving minority rights under the 14th Amendment. The Justice acknowledged, though, that there was no way to prevent those pitfalls - except, perhaps, by repealing the 14th Amendment, and otherwise limiting the kinds of cases that could be filed in Federal court.

title: RESTORATION: SAVING IT FOR THE LOVABLE MOVIES
description: When the running time of ''A Star Is Born'' was reduced from 181 minutes to 154 during its opening engagements in 1954, the changes were made for commercial considerations. These couldn't be more different from the reasons for which the same film has now been lovingly and ambitiously restored. The current wave of film restoration is taking place far from the realm of the marketplace, where scholarship and appreciation may matter at least as much as entertainment value, if not more. Not until the novelty of restoration wears off will there be any need to measure how much any given film is really enhanced by adding material that has been refurbished or rediscovered.

title: John Gaffney Marries Karen Lee in Virginia
description: At St. Louis Roman Catholic Church in Alexandria, Va., yesterday, Karen A. Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gary A. Lee of Alexandria, formerly of Ithaca, N.Y., was married to John T. Gaffney, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Gaffney Jr. of Highland, N.Y. The Rev. Robert O'Connell performed the ceremony.

title: A Duffer's Glossary of Golf
description: GOLF has away of making things stand still. Since the invention of the electric cart, I haven't made a single great stride in my game. But this fact alone is not what gets me down. Unlike Ben Crenshaw, I'm not about to stick a five iron 20 feet from the flag and throw down my club in disgust. (I would, in fact, jump for joy as I have never stuck anything more than a wedge 20 feet from the flag.)

These consist of well over 100 black and white images hand-somely mounted and accompanied by a catalog that is as attractive as it is informative.

title: HOMELAND LEADER RECOUNTS A PLOT

title: Lines Forming on State Transit Bonds
description: ANDREW CUOMO, the Governor's son and adviser, crouched in front of a map of the state's counties last week, pointed to Suffolk and Nassau and declared, "The Island will be swing." The 25-year-old Mr. Cuomo has been assigned by his father to help sell the "Rebuild New York Bond Issue" to a voting public that has often resisted appeals to increase the state's indebtedness. If Andrew Cuomo and a cadre of other gubernatorial advisers assigned to the task convince enough New Yorkers to vote "yes" in November, the Cuomo administration will be authorized to spend $1.25 billion on improvements to the state's net-work of roads, bridges, rails, ports and mass transportation.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: BRONX PRIMITIVE: Portraits in a Childhood. By Kate Simon. (Harper/Colophon, $4.95.) In her splendid account of growing up female, a sophisticated and cosmopolitan writer now known for making glamorous places ''deliciously intimate to readers'' turns her ''powers of observation upon herself as a child and upon the sidewalks, the stoops, the public schools and the railroad flats of the Bronx she grew up in,'' according to our reviewer, Helen Yglesias, who commended ''Bronx Primitive'' for its remarkable rendering of the truth of a particular immigrant experience.

But his exhaustion did not shake a belief that he had ''touched a very sensitive nerve'' on his foray into national politics with the first of six speeches to try to guide the Democratic Party to what he calls the ''mainstream.''

title: THE WORLD
description: Wear and TearAnd a BoostFor SolidarityFor the tattered remnants of Solidarity, Poland's short-lived experiment with an independent trade union, it was a week of ups and downs. The authorities crowed as Wladyslaw Hardek, a Nowa Huta steelworker who was one of the union's five underground leaders, appeared on television and said he was giving up the battle.

title: No Headline
description: When a Church Becomes a Landmark In New York City, the owner of a building declared to be a landmark cannot change or demolish it without permission from the Landmarks Commission, and that raises a special problem for churches and synagogues. Often enough, affluent members move away, leaving behind a shrunken congregation to bear the costs of preserving a decaying building. The no-change provisions of the landmark law make it impossible for them to alter the building or sell it and move.

title: FOR U.S., GLOBAL NEEDS CAN OVERSHADOW HUMAN RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON FOR weeks, President McKinley had procrastinated over whether to annex the Philippines. In 1898 Washington was divided between those who saw the islands, one of the spoils of the Spanish- American War, as strategically vital to American political and commercial interests and those who were unhappy with the concept of colonization. Finally, as he later related, he chose humanitarian reasons to justify the strategic decision.

title: THIS PRESIDENT, TOO, CAN BEND IN POLITICAL WINDS
description: WASHINGTON HAS President Reagan had a change of heart or is he simply trying to reposition himself for the 1984 election, projecting an image of concern and compassion to rebut the ''Reagan Hood'' charge that he robs the poor to help the rich? The evidence that he has moderated his views is circumstantial, gleaned from his recent speeches. Reviewing it, many political observers consider the apparent shift tactical, not ideological. They also consider it characteristic of incumbents.

title: MARCH ON THE CAPITAL
description: President Reagan was out of town when close to a quarter of a million people came calling here today for ''jobs, peace and freedom.'' And maybe he was wise to be absent. For he referred earlier in this week to the demonstrators against his nuclear arms policies as ''the so-called peace movement,'' which they regarded as a slur comparable to calling him ''the so-called President.''

title: Seeking to Prevent Birth Defects
description: "WE have a vaccination for rubella, so that it is 90 percent under control, but there are hundreds of other infectious agents that may cause birth defects," said Dr. David A. Baker at his office near the research virology laboratory at the University Hospital at Stony Brook. "Some studies show that as many as one in 10 pregnant women have been exposed to these agents. Sometimes the mother may not be affected by them at all, but if the fetus or newborn is infected, a whole spectrum of illnesses may result, and sometimes the baby will die."

title:
Gardening; 
An Ideal Time for Improving the Lawn
description: AS the end of summer approaches, it is timely to evaluate the condition of the lawn with an eye toward the possible need for renovation. A sparse turf may not be sufficient reason to renovate, if there are few bare spots larger than four to five inches in diameter. Adequate water, lime and fertilizer and the use of herbicides as such a lawn to fill in by spring. But where a sufficient number of large, bare spots are present, renovation is the logical solution.

title: A RURAL SETTING FOR A SUBSIDARY
description: The breakup of the Bell System has created several new subsidiaries, among them A.T.& T. Information Systems. To house this new entity and give it a headquarters, the Sudler Companies of Newark will build and then lease to the company an 800,000-square-foot office and research facility in Middletown Township, Monmouth County N.J. The site is a 258-acre plot at Laurel Avenue and Holland Road.

title: WHAT'S HOLDING THE UNDERCLASS DOWN?
description: Just days after Mayor Koch entreated Democrats around the country to pay more attention to the middle class, he and other top city and state officials last week inadvertently rediscovered poverty. It began when Governor Cuomo disclosed that state inspections of two New York City hotels housing displaced families had found ''mind boggling'' conditions. Children, Mr. Cuomo said, were malnourished and living in ''Dickensian'' circumstances, with babies sleeping on floors amidst rats and bugs. The Governor ordered an immediate investigation of the 50 other hotels sheltering homeless city families.

title: TRADITION SPURS INVENTIVE JAZZ GROUPS
description: For a jazz musician, choosing an instrument means thinking about history. Pianists have the shades of Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk looking over their shoulders; tenor saxophonists have to consider Coleman Hawkins, Lester Young, John Coltrane and Sonny Rollins. For alto saxophonists, the tradition holds the ineffable ballad playing of Johnny Hodges as well as the harmonic and structural revolutions wrought by Charlie Parker and Ornette Coleman - a legacy of tautly balanced soul and intellect.

title: LATIN POLICY: BASIC ISSUES STILL UNCLEAR

Goldbergh of Suffern, N.Y. The future bride's father, a former United States Bankruptcy Judge for the Southern District of New York, is a partner in the New York law firm of Barst, Mukamal & Babitt. Mr. Goldbergh is an associate with the New York law firm of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine & Underberg.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;

title:
Dining out; 
Rusticity and Home-Style Cooking
description: DON'T expect liveried serving hierarchy; all dining-room staff remind one more of Mom. Nor expect luxuriously spaced tables, to which diners in the county have become accustomed; the two cramped rooms are tight with tables and antiques - samplers, baskets, prints, bread tins, dishes, pots, wood planes, quilts -- for decoration and for sale. Proverbial crisp linen gives way to functional ceramic tile-topped tables, and napkins are red bandanas from which diners unroll their place settings. But excepting a few leaves of sandy spinach, nothing bad left the kitchen, and much was superb.

description: Spending for education is expected to reach $230 billion in the new school year, as against $215 billion last year, while enrollment will drop 1 percent, Secretary of Education T. H. Bell said today.

Their task was to survive the most brutal weather of the century at a time when food, clothing and morale were lower than they had been at any other point in the Revolutionary War.

Javits received for a degenerative neurological disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. title: MY FRIEND, MALCOLM COWLEY
description: Last Wednesday Malcolm Cowley was 85. The Book Review wanted to mark the occasion and was fortunate enough to get permission from the estate of John Cheever to print a talk Cheever delivered at a dinner on Oct. 9, 1979. The dinner was given in Mr. Cowley's honor by the Newberry Library in Chicago, where his papers are kept, to celebrate the acquisition of more of Mr. Cowley's papers. Referring recently to the talk, Mr. Cowley said, ''Something unpublished by Cheever - and a good piece, too - would be a real coup for the NYTBR as well as for myself.'' Mr. Cowley's extraordinary career as a writer and a friend of writers has been full of coups. That the talk is a coup for The Book Review, we agree.

title: PROSECUTOR IS FACING A DILEMMA
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the Monmouth County Prosecutor, Alexander D. Lehrer, whose term expires at the end of this month, would like to stay on the job, the state's political system makes that all but impossible.

title: BARBIE AND THE U.S. 'SORRY' IS NOT ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: Such 'Concern'
description: To the Editor:

title: LONE PINE LANDFILL CALLED PERIL TO AQUIFERS
description: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP CONTAMINATION from the Lone Pine landfill - a toxic-waste dump closed by the state in 1979 - is now thought to be so extensive that it will take at least 20 years to pump out and purify the potable water that lies below it.

title: SINGAPOREAN STUDIES CITY DARE-CARE PROGRAM
description: The visitor from Singapore listened intently as two 7-year-old children at the Harbor School-Age Day Care Center demonstrated their knowledge of the human body.

title: CANADA RED-FACED ON NUCLEAR LEAK
description: Just as the Canadian Government announced this month that it had sold one of its heavy-water nuclear power plants to Rumania, one of its reactors in use developed an unprecedented leak.

title: DIDEROT MADE ART REVIEWS INTO AN ART
description: Jacques Barzun is professor emeritus of cultural history at Columbia University. The following essay is part of a lecture on ''Art and Criticism in 18th-Century France'' delivered at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth last spring.

title: 4 Gunmen Hijack Jet; Most Passengers Freed
description: Four Arabic-speaking hijackers commandeered an Air France plane on a flight from Vienna to Paris, landed in Geneva and Sicily Saturday night and then took off this morning, apparently bound for Damascus, Syria, with eight crew members and nine passengers still aboard.

title: TIME TO FIX THE ROOF IS WHEN THE SUN SHINES; HERE'S HOW
description: -type roofs are usually covered with roll-type roofing material that is applied in layers, rather than with shingles (shingles are practical only on roofs that have a definite slope to them). When properly applied, this kind of roofing will last for many years. But as a rule, roll roofing (sometimes referred to as built-up roofing) does require more frequent inspection than shingles if leaks are to be prevented from developing as the years go by.

title: In the Spirit of Volunteerism, A New 'Macho'
description: IN 1900, a small band of men volunteered to participate in a medical experiment. Offering their arms and their lives, they allowed themselves to be bitten by the Aedes Agypti mosquito. As a result of their courage, the great plague of yellow fever was soon eradicated.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Bluegrass music was one of the earliest pop fusions. It brought together old-time fiddle tunes and blues with the close-harmony singing of backwoods churches, tightened them up, and turned them into showcases for virtuoso pickers and singers.

title: PAKISTANI RIOTING POSES TEST FOR ZIA
description: Nearly two weeks of anti-Government agitation and rioting in the southern Pakistani province of Sind have posed the first major challenge to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq's military Government since General Zia seized power in a coup six years ago.

title: Patriots' Sims Hurt
description: Kenneth Sims , the New England defensive end and 1982 top draft choice, will miss about four weeks because of a hairline fracture in his left leg suffered during the Patriots' exhibition game loss to Tampa Bay Friday night, Tom Hoffman , a Patriots' spokesman said Saturday. Hoffman, said Sims suffered the injury when he was kicked below the knee during a pileup. Hoffman also said that the defensive back Paul Dombroski , who suffered a concussion during the game, would remain for a second night at a Tampa hospital.

title: IT TAKES MORE THAN SETTING STEPS TO MUSIC
description: Let's ponder three statements. First, there's George Balanchine's description of music as a ''floor for dancing.'' The second comes from an essay that the late Edwin Denby wrote in 1945 in which he foresaw a new dance Classicism that would stir audiences ''by the act of dancing and not, as the fashion was from 1910 to 1940, by opposing to that act obstacles of various kinds of mimicry.'' The third remark was made by Hugo Fiorato, one of the New York City Ballet's conductors, at this summer's meeting of the Dance Critics Association. Balanchine, said Mr. Fiorato, did not ''just put movements on top of a score, he added a new dimension to it.''

title: DEVELOPMENT IS TOUCHY IN MIDWEST VACATION SPOT
description: The mouth of the Mink River is hidden in a marshy corner of Rowley Bay, in the northwest reaches of Lake Michigan. Beyond the initial cluster of green stalks sprouting from the murky water, the lazy life of the river unfolds.

title: No Headline
description: Steinbrenner Is Named ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 27 (AP) - A former University of

title: DUXFORD REVISITED
description: DONAL HENAHAN is the chief music critic for The New York Times.

title: NICARAGUA: THE BELEAGUERED REVOLUTION
description: Stephen Kinzer reports for The New York Times from Central America. By Stephen Kinzer N THE DUSTY STREETS OF A MANAgua slum, several thousand people walked slowly toward the cemetery. At the head of the procession, covered with floral wreaths, were the coffins of two teen-age boys who had volunteered for the militia and been killed in a skirmish with the contras , the American-armed guerrillas at war with Nicaragua's Sandinista regime.

title: $400,000 Award
description: Alice Duffy, blinded by a golf ball while a spectator at the 1973 Western Golf Open in the Chicago suburb of Midlothian, has been awarded in excess of $400,000 by a Cook County jury. Judge Charles Freeman said after the verdict that the decision might force changes in the way spectator sports were presented.

title:
Gardening; 
An Ideal Time for Improving the Lawn
description: As the end of summer approaches, it is timely to evaluate the condition of the lawn with an eye toward the possible need for renovation. A sparse turf may not be sufficient reason to renovate, if there are few bare spots larger than four to five inches in diameter. Adequate water, lime and fertilizer and the use of herbicides as such a lawn to fill in by spring. But where a sufficient number of large, bare spots are present, renovation is the logical solution.

title: BARRY DILLER'S LATEST STARRING ROLE
description: ''IM learning new words,'' said Barry

title: Health Officials Warn Of New Malaria Strain
description: New reports of a drug-resistant malaria strain in parts of Africa have prompted United States health officials to issue a warning to travelers in those areas.

title: HEADLINERS All AshoreBeaches sometimes wash away, but they hardly ever get towed out of town. That happened last week to the one
description: Michael O'Keeffe had tied up next to his Water Club restaurant on the East River at 34th Street. Actually, it was a 126-foot barge filled with 200 tons of Long Island sand and, until Susan Frank, Commissioner of the City Ports and Terminals Department, ordered it out, swim-suited men and women sipping daiquiris and pina coladas at a thatched-roof bar or lolling under umbrellas.

title: HOW DESIGN WAS DECIDED FOR CENTRAL PARK'S LAMPS
description: Designing the lamp fixtures being installed in Central Park raised questions about historic preservation for the designers of the lamps and the three city agencies that had to approve the designs.

title: JAZZ: DAIVD EYGES
description: David Eyges is carving out not one but two roles for jazz cello. His trio, with James Emery on guitar and Sunny Murray on drums, played two kinds of pieces in its Mobil Summerpier concert Friday on Pier 16.

title: Soccer Fans Arrested In Rampage in London
description: Police battled with Birmingham City soccer fans in the London streets today as the new season opened.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY A GlimmerOf Detente
description: Moscow's empire may be no less ''evil'' now than it was when President Reagan delivered his militant ''Darth Vader'' speech in March. But last week, while Mr. Reagan toned down his anti-Soviet oratory and indicated his desire to do business, Soviet President Yuri V. Andropov made what looked to the State Department like a ''positive'' move on arms control.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE IN HARTFORD CURBS INSANITY DEFENSE
description: A Federal judge in Connecticut ruled today that the use of the insanity defense against Federal criminal charges should be limited but not abolished.

title: 'LA CAGE' HAS THAT OLD-TIME APPEAL
description: Broadway has been hungry for a popular hit for a long time, and, heaven knows, it finally has one in the new musical ''La Cage aux Folles.'' What's more, ''La Cage aux Folles'' is an even rarer phenomenon for our theatrical day - a show that had found its audience long before the critics came to call. From the moment this musical opened its box office in June, a line of ticket buyers was snaking out of the Palace Theater morning and evening, betting top dollar that ''La Cage aux Folles'' would deliver the goods. At a time when many audiences and producers have lost faith in Broadway, the lines at the Palace were enough to make one believe that the god who watches over the commercial theater had sprung back to life again.

title: FOR A BUYER, A HECTIC CITY PACE
description: It is, according to Joanna de Jesus, exciting, challenging and a little bit frightening.

title:
The Lively Arts; 
It'll Be a Weekend for Festivals
description: On Labor Day weekend, those who labor in the arts in and around Long Island won't be joining the rest of the population in a final summer fling. They will be toiling at two major festivals: the four-day Celebration of the Arts in Roslyn Harbor and the two-day Jewish Arts Festival of Long Island in Wheatley Heights. The only work demanded of audiences will be deciding which festival to attend; the two overlap on Sunday and Labor Day.

title: THE REGION
description: Stay-at-HomeEvacuation Drill

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants , at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. In a game that will mark the Giants' last visit to New York this season, Craig Swan (2-7) will attempt to prove that he is still capable of being the winning pitcher that the Mets once believed would make him the head of their starting staff. He will be opposed by Bill Laskey (13-10). (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.)

title: HEADLINERS
description: Birthday SuiteThey might not have been able to hum the first movement of his ''Jeremiah'' symphony, but the people of Lawrence, Mass., did sing an enthusiastic ''Happy Birthday'' last week to a celebrated native son, Leonard Bernstein . On his 65th birthday, the composer and conductor was treated to a parade through the old mill town's confetti- strewn streets.

title: NAVIGATING THE SHIPOWNERS' AEGEAN HAVEN
description: MARVINE HOWE is chief of the Athens bureau of The Times.

title: MOUNTING DEFICIT ENDANGERS CONNECTICUT PRISON INDUSTRY
description: The Connecticut Correction Department's prison industries fund is in a ''dangerous situation'' because of mounting deficits, including an $800,000 shortfall last year, state auditors have reported.

title: THE CLUBHOUSE
description: BY WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY JR. William F. Buckley Jr. is the author most recently of ''Overdrive'' (Doubleday). BEGIN WITH A REMINIS cence. The scene was an all- male private club. It was late in the afternoon, cocktail time, and I was talking with Bart Giamatti, the freshly elected president of Yale University who was at the Hillbillies Camp as guest of a classmate of mine who, the year before, had invited Giamatti's predecessor as president of Yale, Kingman Brewster. ''A difference between King and me,'' said Giamatti, ''is that if King had come into this enclosure, he'd have made a beeline'' - Giamatti pointed to the densest cluster of guests a few yards away - ''for over there. I come in and I look for the loneliest sector of the congregation.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PORTSMOUTH
description: ELEANOR CHARLES is a regular contributor to The New York Times.

title: SNAGS CITED IN NAMIBIA TALKS
description: The Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, arrived here today for the opening Monday of a 10-day conference on Palestinian rights. He was to spend the weekend drafting a report for the Security Council on his unsuccessful talks in southern Africa on the deadlock over independence for South-West Africa.

title: No Headline
description: Getting High on High-Tech Weapons The Pentagon is debating how far the next generation of armaments should depend on highly computerized systems, which are capable of scanning the battlefield and devastating the enemy with precisely targeted missiles. That the debate is taking place at all reflects the Pentagon's reluctance to learn from experience.

title: BAROQUE WORKS STILL CHALLENGE
description: From today's perspective, the original fate of Bach's Brandenburg Concertos seems ironic: Having constructed the set from previously composed material, Bach sent the six works to the Margrave of Brandenburg - partly in fulfillment of a request the Margrave had made a few years earlier, and partly in the hope that the Margrave would offer him a post. As it turned out, the Margrave not only failed to make Bach an attractive offer, but apparently had the concertos filed in his library without a playing - possibly because they presented technical demands that his orchestra could not meet.

title: SHCHUKIN'S MATISSES AND PICASSOS
description: ALL THE EMPTY PALACES

title: THE 'BIG ONE,' FOR SOME, IS 30
description: -1950's may be too involved in our careers, our marriages, our young families or all three to be rattled by the Big One when it comes.

title: SOOTHING SIGHTS AND SOUNDS
description: Supercouch

title: AMONG LIFE INSURERS, LITTLE ONES SHINE
description: WHILE many of the big, lumbering life insurance companies have been lackluster performers in the stock market over the last year, a number of the smaller life insurers have recently come into favor among investors.

title: Barbara B. Bates Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara Bonbright Bates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce B. Bates of Rochester, was married there yesterday to William Holland Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Davis of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Bay, assisted by the Rev. George Willis Jr., performed the ceremony at the Third Presbyterian Church.

title: Wedding Upstate For Dr. Creamer
description: At the United Presbyterian Church in Putnam Station. N.Y., yesterday, Dr. Winifred Creamer and Dr. Jonathan Haas, both archeologists, were married by the Rev. Howard R. Foye.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: ''Generally speaking,'' he says, ''people want to be able to do something for the grant they receive.''

title: Scottish Dirk
description: To the Editor: The photograph used to illustrate Douglas Sutherland's de

title: 'TOTALLY GROUNDLESS' REPORT ON POLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: A BARN FOR SOHO
description: ''I'll bet it's the first barn to be raised in Manhattan in at least a century,'' said Jason Carter as he gestured toward a miniature farm building and adjoining silo on the roof of 118 Wooster Street in the heart of SoHo. The barn and its dome-topped observation silo are atop a former manufacturing building that Mr. Carter is turning into 15 condominium apartments, and they are among three whimsical structures built to replace skylights.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE MAN YOU LOVED TO HATE

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: ORDERING SPECIAL MEALS ALOFT
description: The jetliner has begun its flight and the voice of a cabin attendant comes calmly over the public address system: ''Will the following passengers please identify themselves - Mr. Yates, Mrs. Longhi and Mr. Goldberg.'' Why are these people wanted? Are they on the run? On the wrong plane? Lost their tickets?

title: Van Townsend Jr. Weds Miss Howe
description: Robin Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Sawyer Howe of Farmington, Conn., and Sakonnet, R.I., was married yesterday to Kiliaen Van Rennselaer Townsend Jr., son of Mr. Townsend of Atlanta and the late Mary Campbell Everett Townsend. The Rev. David Powell performed the ceremony at St. Andrews-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Sakonnet Point.

title: Elizabeth Casey Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Francis Guy Casey Jr. of North Plainfield, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Frances Siobhan Casey, to Steven Samuel Eichberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Eichberg of Denver. The wedding is to be Nov. 12.

title: Eleanor Hoey Wed to Nicholas Bright
description: Eleanor Frances Hoey, daughter of James F. Hoey Jr. of Wellesley and Chathamport, Mass., and Jane F. Hoey of Dover, Mass., was married yesterday to Nicholas Bright, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright Jr. of Islesford, Me. The Rev. George G. Hogan performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Survey to Study Turnpike Dining
description: FOR about as long as Americans have been taking to the road in their cars, somewhere down the road has been a roadside restaurant with distinctive orange and aquamarine colors and familiar food and services.

title: FOR 75 YEARS, MACDOWELL HAS BEEN A COMPOSER'S HAVEN
description: PETERBOROUGH, New Hampshire

title: Rambling Willie Wins
description: Rambling Willie, who has won more races and more money than any other pacer in history, defeated six rivals in an invitation mile at Freehold Raceway today.

title: Mistakes of Our Mothers
description: IS there a woman among us who hasn't grown up vowing that she will never repeat the mistakes of her mother? I doubt it. But it takes a long time to reach the lofty heights of adult maturity, and by then most of us have discovered that we are more like our mothers -- mistakes and all -- then we care to admit.

title: ABOUT CARSMarshall Schuon A.M.C.'s Big Deal And Little Jeeps
description: PAUL TIPPETT was holding forth on the newly scrutable East, talking about the deal that American Motors has made to produce as many as 40,000 Jeeps a year in Peking. ''This thing took four years to put together,'' he said, ''and it was interesting to see the changes in China during that time. They are really serious about coming into the 20th century. They say it won't go as fast as we would like, maybe, but they are very serious about doing it.''

title: Catherine Donahue Weds Roy Fugazy
description: Catherine Mary Donahue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Patrick Donahue of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Roy Daniel Fugazy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Denis Fugazy of Harrison, N.Y. Bishop Edwin B. Broderick, assisted by the Rev. Michael Moynihan, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Three Arrested After Officer Is Shot and Wounded on L.I.
description: A police officer was shot and wounded Friday while questioning several suspects in a purse-snatching, and two men and a woman have been arrested and charged in the case, the police said today.

title: Postcard Is Clocked At 15 Years Per Mile
description: The good news is the message on the postcard Blanche Besecker received from her Aunt Emma and Uncle Bert was not terribly urgent. The bad news is it arrived 74 years late.

title: GUNTHARDT, MAYER ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: Heinz Gunthardt today withstood the 92-degree heat and the humidity to defeat Vince Van Patten, 6-3, 6-2, to advance to the Sunday final of The Hamlet Challenge Cup against Gene Mayer, a 6-2, 6-4 winner over Chris Lewis.

title: The Black Image In Centuries of Art
description: IT is rare to find a local exhibition with the kind of broad educational and iconographical content offered by "The Image of the Black in Western Art," currently on view at the Black History Museum in Hempstead. Centuries of artistic and social ideas are compressed into a survey that begins with the early sculpturing and drawing cultures of the Mediterranean and carries us into the Renaissance era of great commissions and collectors.

title: VIOLENCE IN BEIRUT
description: We need all we can get of Thomas Friedman's thorough, honest journalism. If any writer can help us sheltered Americans understand life in the Middle East, he will.

title: Hope Lefeber Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Hans Lefeber of New York and Morristown, N.J., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Hope Lefeber, to Dr. Howard B. Kessler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Kessler of Cleveland.

title: VIOLENCE IN BEIRUT
description: Thomas Friedman's article served to reinforce certain long-standing feelings I have had on the present state of our society and the resilience of man.

title: They Call It Progress
description: I HATE the fact that I can see that rock. It should be buried in the ground -- it belongs in the soil. Its home is with the roots of trees, not thrown on my lawn to be carted away with garbage. Progress, the future, they call it, building on every square inch of green. Making way for 44 large new quarter-million-dollar homes.

title: AT WHAT AGE DOES ONE BECOME 'OLD'?
description: ''O.K. POP.'' The young lady in a car next to me in a crowded supermarket parking lot was telling me to go ahead of her.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I KNEW there was big news in the offing the moment I picked up my telephone and heard Green Thumb on the other end. A hint of unusual doings virtually wafted over the line, and I wated for him to start divulging.

title: CONSUMERS' OIL CO-OPS
description: AT his law office, at cocktail parties and on the ski slopes last

title: MEN IN BLUE HAVE MOOD TO MATCH
description: ''This month we were all brutal racists, last month we were all drug addicts, the month before that we were drunks and sex fiends,'' Police Officer James Martin of the Midtown North Precinct was saying last week. ''A lot of times you get the feeling that the city doesn't care, the public doesn't care, that your partner and the other cops are the only ones you can count on. We're the most visible, the most vulnerable and the least vocal. Cops don't talk. They never know when it's going to be taken out of context, and people aren't going to understand it anyway. So you just read about it, you watch it, you put on the uniform and go out and do your job.''

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN TELEPHONE MARKETING;
A.T.&T.; COURTS THE BUYERS
description: The court-ordered reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has galvanized the retail phone industry, prompting A.T.& T. to push sales of the telephones it had leased for so long and creating a free-for-all in the race to convert Americans to the joys of phone ownership.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS ARE MAKING A COMEBACK
description: Something that is giving pleasure to a great many people is the renewed popularity of the illustrated book - or, as it is sometimes called, with a shift of emphasis, the artist's book. For evidence of its flourishing state we have only to go to the exemplary shop called Franklin Furnace, at 112 Franklin Street in Manhattan, where the representation of artists' books grows stronger every day.

title: AQUINO'S DREAM AND FOREBODING
description: To the Editor:

title: SOPHIA'S REBIRTH
description: Few passersby would guess that the striking 28-story Art Deco building at 43 West 61st Street was created as a garage, but that was its purpose when it was built in 1930. Later it became a storage facility known as the Sophia Warehouse.

title: A TRIO OF BULBS FOR NEXT SPRING'S BLOOM;
description: Patricia Hubbell is a writer and gardener.

title: Phone Strike Continues; Local Disputes Dwindle By United Press International
description: Negotiators worked yesterday to resolve the last local disputes stopping settlement of the 21-day-old national telephone strike.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a printing error, several sentences were garbled at the end of Michael Palmer's review of ''The Book of Questions'' by Edmond Jab es (Aug. 21). Mr. Palmer wrote: ''If one can speak of progression in such a work, it would seem to be toward some still point of concentration on the individual word. (This movement culminates in the seventh volume, 'El,' whose title is also a single dot standing for a Hebrew vowel.) . . . (The translator) has concentrated on an accurate transmission of the meaning but has also managed to adhere remarkably well to the rhythm of the work.''

title: THE WORLD
description: The United States is still the greatest of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's satans, but there is such a thing as giving the devil his due. Last week, Iran settled $419.5 million of American claims, transferring the money to the Export-Import Bank in Washington from the $1.42 billion escrow account set up when 52 American hostages in Teheran were released in January 1981.

title: Ambitious Menu in a Cafe Setting
description: GREENSTREET in Northport changed hands late last year. It was always a pleasantly informal country cafe done in green and white with an airy, light look. The new owners have not revised the decor, but they have created a rather ambitious menu that is French with Continental overtones. Despite a few commendable accomplishments, a number of flaws marred the cooking on recent visits, so that the restaurant cannot be recommended as highly now as it had been in the past.

title: KISSINGER PANEL TO HEAR FORD
description: Two former Presidents and three former Secretaries of State will appear next week in Washington before the Presidential Commission on Central American policy headed by Henry A. Kissinger.

title: RESEARCHERS SAY CELLS HAVE VIRUS DOORWAYS
description: Researchers have reported that viruses invade cells through entry points uniquely tailored to each variety of virus, and that blocking those points may be a new method of warding off infection.

title: V.A. JOB TELETHON PLANNED
description: THE Vietnam Veterans Civic Council and the Veterans Administration regional office in Newark are seizing the momentum generated by an improved economic climate to hold a $50,000 telethon aimed at finding jobs for 1,000 veterans. The statewide all- day event will be held Sept. 24.

title: How Couple Keep Home Center Stage
description: CAN a young married couple determined to succeed in the fabled world of Broadway adapt to the down-to-earth reality of raising a family and leading what they insist on calling a "normal life" in Mamaroneck?

title: Train-Station Gallery Viewed a Success
description: THOUGH the trails that arrive at Southport's railroad station may not always be on time, the members of Art/Place, a gallery housed in the westbound section of the station, are right on schedule with their plans for the nonprofit venture.

title: TEXT OF THE SPEECH DR. KING DELIVERED 20 YEARS AGO TODAY
description: Following is the text of the speech delivered at the Lincoln Memorial 20 years ago today by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.:

title: Miss Pease Is Married
description: Bonnie Lee Pease of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Thayer Pease Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Frank Janeway Keeler of New York, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Martyn Decker Keeler of Brookfield, Vt. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson of the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York performed the ceremony at the couple's country home in Keene, N.Y.

title: Captains Criticized For Killing Shark
description: TO Peter Benchley, the author of "Haws," it was a wanton slaughter. But to Gregory Dubrule of Mystic and Ernest W. Celotto of Ledyard, both charterboat captains, their harpooning of a great white shark off Block Island earlier this month was in the interests of science, even though they might have second thoughts about doing it again if the opportunity arose.

title: The Trials Of a Native-Born 'Foreigner'
description: AS a child growing up, I was usually the only kid of Chinese origin in the neighborhood. Indeed, in the whole school and even at college. At various times I was mistaken for a foreign exchange student from Korea, a Japanese war bride, an adopted Vietnamese and sometimes a Burmese; before Hawaii became a state, a Hawaiian visitor. I was never mistaken for an American.

title: THE NATION
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, facing divestiture at the end of the year, learned anew last week just how troublesome decentralization can be.

title: Joan M. Azrack and W.G. Ballaine, Lawyers, Wed
description: Joan Marie Azrack, a daughter of John J. Azrack of Spring Lake, N.J., and Sea Island, Ga., and the late Teresa Whelan Azrack, was married yesterday to William G. Ballaine, son of Alice S. Ballaine of Flushing, Queens, and the late Dr. Francis K. Ballaine. Chief Judge Arthur J. Blake of the Superior Court of Ocean County, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Azrack home in Spring Lake.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL CALLS SOVIET ARMS OFFER A DISAPPOINTMENT
description: A senior Administration official said today that the United States was disappointed by Yuri V. Andropov's latest arms control statement.

title:
Art; 
'Summertime' at Somerstown
description: AN exceptionally lively and varied exhibition of the work of 25 contemporary artists is on view through Sept. 5 at the Somerstown Studios and Gallery. Entitled "Summertime . . . and the Living Is Easy," the show, a large one filling the gallery's three floors and 10 or 12 rooms, includes the work of several fresh but as yet little-known talents.

title: Home Design; Interior Trends 1984
description: ONE CANNOT HELP BUT WONDER WHAT THE late ELsie de Wolfe would make of the house in good taste, circa 1984. Some 70 years after the height of her reign as this country's first professional interior designer, and the arbiter of decorating taste, she would certainly be buoyed by the news that the stenciled leopard prints she initiated are in style again. On the other hand, she no doubt would be crushed to learn that the very sort of 19th-century furniture she succeeded in exorcising from fashionable homes has become socially acceptable again.

title: THE WORLD
description: WithdrawalSymptoms

title: TURKEY'S GENERALS KEEP FOES OUT OF ELECTION
description: The military Government this week in effect barred conservative and social democratic parties from the parliamentary election Nov. 6, thereby excluding its opponents.

title: BEHIND EACH ASTRONAUT STAND THE 'OTHER' WOMEN OF NASA
description: HOUSTON SALLY RIDE broke a major sexual barrier with her space shuttle flight in June, entering a world once reserved for male test pilots and scientists. But some feel the hoopla over her achievement has obscured the need for more ground-level action at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: FRESH AIR FUND CHILDREN TELL FOND SUMMER TALES
description: Swimming, pitching hay, fishing, milking the cows. It had been a busy summer for the children who had Fresh Air Fund vacations, and now it was over.

title: A GARDEN STATE GARDEN?
description: -foot-high vantage point near the Bergen-Passaic border, the eye can take in most of the 115 acres of woodlands, wildflower gardens, meadows, bogs, ponds and formal gardens that make up Skylands Botanical Gardens in Ringwood.

title: FEED ETHIOPIA FAST
description: The Administration's reported steps to seek United Nations and private assistance to provide food to Ethiopia, where perhaps a million people are starving, is commendable. But if the Administration is serious, it can provide that relief more easily.

title: Blood Banks Fight Fear of AIDS
description: BLOOD donations in the county, which had dropped more steeply than expected earlier this summer because of public uncertainty over the transmission of AIDS, now appear to be on the increase. However, health officials caution that continual educational efforts will be needed to prevent repetition of what they view as a serious problem.

title: Peter White Wed To Susan Wilcox
description: Susan Sanborn Wilcox, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Sanborn Wilcox of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Robbins White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Austin White of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Dr. James Kidd performed the ceremony at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: WIL PERONIST PARTY DEAL A WILD CARD IN ELECTION?
description: -- A long-running political cliffhanger starring former President Isabel Martinez de Peron may come to a denouement this week.

title: MUSIC IS RECYCLED
description: Memory is an elusive thing, of course, but it seems that things were simpler in the ''old days'' - whenever they were. In the days of 78's you had a choice: RCA Victor or Columbia; except for really involved collectors, that was the classical scene in records. Then came the LP and the number of labels burgeoned, but even then it was simple: RCA, CBS, London, Angel, etc. Now, however, it's not that simple anymore.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: No longer would an enraged player need to charge a lineman or the umpire in a tennis tournament, insisting that the ball was inside, not outside, the court. If Henry Von Kohorn of Greenwich, Conn., prevailed, electricity would rule out all argument. Mr. Von Kohorn, who is an avid tennis player, received United States Patent 4,381,109 last April for a conductive tennis ball.

title: 15 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments last week for violations of the health code.

title: CORRECTION
description: In today's Arts and Leisure section, the photograph illustrating Gene Thornton's review of ''The American Image'' at the International Center of Photography is not in that exhibition. It is part of the show ''Ghost Trains: Railroad Photographs of the 1950's by O. Winston Link,'' which is also on view at the center.

title: AFTER 30 YEARS, THIS MEDIA WATCHDOG IS STILL VIGILANT
