description: Yolanda R. Turocy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steve Turocy of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was married yesterday to Robert M. Taub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Taub of Edison, N.J. The Rev. Stephen Szabo, pastor of the First Hungarian Reformed Church in Cleveland, performed the ceremony at the Shaker Heights Club,

title: THE REGION
description: Glen Cove SuedOver Russians

title: Optimism Voiced On Hay Fever Year
description: IT'S late August, the time when hay fever sufferers -- nearly 20 percent of the population -- brace for the attacks of incessant sneezing, itchy and watery eyes and general misery brought on by allergic reactions to ragweed pollen. On the worst days, tempers grow short, vacations are ruined and time is lost from school or work.

title: Art;  Bronze Show Suits Its Setting
description: WAVE HILL, at 657 West 252d Street in the Bronx, has staged seven outdoor sculpture shows in as many years. But its current "Bronze 1983" is the first to be devoted to contemporary works in that medium. Indeed, on this scale -- 20, mostly large pieces by 12 artists displayed outside and 19 smaller, related works in the museum itself -- it may be the first of its kind in two or three decades.

title: OXFORD AND CAMBRIDGE TO TAKE COLUMBIA STUDENTS
description: Thirty-three undergraduates from Columbia University will begin a year's study at Oxford and Cambridge Universities in England this fall through a new foreign-study program at Columbia.

title: Celia Smith Wed To Brian Carroll
description: Celia Ellan Smith, daughter of Mrs. Howard Haldeman Steel of Villanova, Pa., and Dr. Edward Cary Smith of Spokane, Wash., was married yesterday to Brian Winstanley Carroll, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Carroll Jr. of New York. The Rev. Charles R. Cowell performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Barnabas in Irvington, N.Y.

title: SENATOR JACKSON, IN PEKING, SAYS BETTER TIES ARE AHEAD
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that Chinese-American relations were improving at a pace that could soon bring an exchange of visits between President Reagan and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang.

title: OBSERVING THE FORMALITIES
description: I am puzzled, in Mr. DiGennaro's reference to single- breasted dinner jackets, that he emphasizes shawl collars but does not mention notched lapels.

title: POLICEMAN DOUBLES AS A BALLETMASTER
description: SMOKE comes out of his mouth and his voice thunders as he exhorts his troupe, and a stranger might take him for a drill sergeant, especially since he wears a military kind of uniform, complete with a marksman's badge.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN TELEPHONE MARKETING;
PROFITS IN CUTTING THE CORD
description: Cutting the phone cord is proving to be a successful marketing tactic this year. In fact, cordless telephones - hybrids of radio and telephone technology - are the fastest-growing segment of the telephone industry.

title: A BEGIN STATEMENT READY FOR ARAB TESTING
description: To the Editor:

title: PoliceOfficer,2Others Wo
description: Three Brooklyn residents, including an off-duty police officer, were shot last night in an altercation between the officer and three youths as the officer was leaving a Williamsburg church with his family, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: On LanguageBy Jack Rosenthal The Words of Summer

title: MUSIC: RAPPERS GATHER FOR A CONCERT AT PIER 84
description: Just about every rap group in the city seemed to show up at Dance Music New York, the concert at Pier 84 on Wednesday. The advertised acts were Afrika Bambaataa and the Soul Sonic Force, Kurtis Blow, the Crash Crew and the vocal groups New Edition and Rockers Revenge.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Westchester Guide
description: TRAINING TO BE DOCENT

title: Susan Elliot Billerbeck Wed to D. W. Whalen
description: Susan Elliot Billerbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Allen Billerbeck of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel William Whalen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Whalen of Shrewsbury, N.J. The Rev. David Muyskens performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Shrewsbury.

title: AN INDONESIAN TREAT
description: NO FOOD PREPARATION, to our knowledge, is better suited to warm weather and the summer season than the one known in Indonesia as sataysa. For those unfamiliar with them, they might best be described as less-than-elaborate shish kababs with a curried flavor. When we say less than elaborate, we mean that the meats, while threaded on skewers, are not alternated with layers of mushrooms, green pepers, onions and the like.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Easing the Squeeze on Jobs

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WHILE studying the effects of Lyme disease on the wildlife of the state, researchers at the Connecticut Agriculture Experiment Station in New Haven have found that 25 percent of the dog population in parts of southeastern Connecticut may be affected by the tick-borne disease, which can arthritis in humans.

title: More Drug Testing At Olympics Eyed
description: The success of the doping-control procedures at the Pan American Games may spur the expansion of testing plans for next summer's Los Angeles Olympics.

title: DEFENDER OUT OF YACHT TRIALS
description: Defender was eliminated today in the final trials to select an America's Cup defender. The elimination came on the heels earlier today of two devastating losses to Liberty.

title:
Gardening; 
An Ideal Time for Improving the Lawn
description: AS the end of summer approaches, it is timely to evaluate the condition of the lawn with an eye toward the possible need for renovation. A sparse turf may not be sufficient reason to renovate, if there are few bare spots larger than four to five inches in diameter. Adequate water, lime and fertilizer and the use of herbicides as such a lawn to fill in by spring. But where a sufficient number of large, bare spots are present, renovation is the logical solution.

title: TOWN BACKS PLAN TO REVIVE OLD THEATER
description: CLINTON FOR nearly 30 years, the Clinton Music Hall has been a white elephant on West Main Street here - a sad reminder to the 1,900 residents of this small Hunterdon County town of a time when it was a thriving community and its elegant playhouse the main attraction.

title: RIGHTS MARCHERS ASK NEW COALITION FOR SOCIAL CHANGE
description: Text of the ''I Have a Dream'' address by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther

title: Beriozkas
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed Gloria Levitas's article, ''Capitalist's Guide to Beriozkas,'' (Travel, July 3) since it rekindled warm memories of a trip we took from Irkutsk to Mos

title: Today, Prayers for a Ruined Temple
description: THE woman's eyes flooded with tears as she talked the other day about the fires set here at two synagogues and a rabbi's home within a six-day period.

title: LOVING ODETTE
description: BEAUTIFUL WOMEN; UGLY SCENES

title: Observing the Formalities
description: Tradition does indeed dictate that the pleats of the cummerbund be worn upward; however, this is not for the reason that Ralph DiGennaro cites (''Observing the Formalities,'' About Men, July 17). The cummerbund was not created to hold theater tickets, or anything else.

title: ENGINEERING'S FACE OF THE 80'S
description: -Gross earned her bachelor's degree in engineering from the University of Pittsburgh in 1974 she was one of 58 women in a class of 1,270, or 4.6 percent women engineering undergraduates. Today, 486 students, or 22.2 percent of the university's engineering enrollment, are women.

title: WILDLIFE SANCTUARY FULFILLS A DREAM
description: WEST MILFORD ALTHOUGH they were childless, Fred and Hedwig Ferber tended a close-knit, loving family. Birds, dogs, bear, opposums and other animals lived with them on their 212-acre property here for more than 20 years.

title: IS IT TIME FOR A FOURTH TV NETWORK?
description: It is an idea whose time has never quite come,

title: BOOKS
description: ''MOTHER, CAN YOU HEAR ME?'' by Elizabeth Cooper Allen (Dodd, Mead and Company, New York, $13.95), an autobiographical account of an adopted daughter's reunion with her natural mother, is a story to wrench the heart.

title: 5 COUNTRIES VYING OVER AN ASIAN ARCHIPELAGO
description: Specialists in Pacific and Asian affairs here are concerned by the potential for conflict in a five-way territorial dispute over the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.

title: IRISH SWEATERS TO LAST FOREVER
description: LISA de MAURO is a writer who lives in New York.

description: STONY POINT, N.Y. IN ''What I Did Last Summer,''

title: No Headline
description: Use in Schools Reported

title: Exercise: A Way to Tone the Ego
description: I KNOW it is a crime when I refuse to clip the Gloria Stevens coupon that offers me six weeks of weight loss at a discount. And I do feel a twinge of guilt during my midmorning coffee break, knowing that two friends are suffering palpitations in the name of good health at their weekly aerobics class.

title: Carol Donaldson Wed To Adam Scott Zais
description: Carol Donaldson, daughter of Marion Boyd Dietzgen of Cotuit, Mass., and Theodore Donaldson of Evanston, Ill., was married yesterday to Adam Scott Zais, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Monroe Zais of Pleasantville, N.Y. Justice of the Peace Royden C. Richardson performed the ceremony at the Beach Club in Centerville, Mass.

title: THE OBLIGATIONS OF KEEPING A PET
description: THE man who had just brought in a cardboard box full of kittens didn't understand why the woman on the other side of the counter wasn't more enthusiastic when he told her the good news. After all, she worked for the Bergen County Animal Shelter; she had to be an animal lover. Why didn't she smile when he told her this was the second litter his cat had delivered in three months?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SUDS

title: PIRATES TOP BRAVES ON TUNNELL'S 5-HITTER
description: Lee Tunnell pitched a five-hitter, allowing only one hit after the second inning, and Bill Madlock belted a two- run homer tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Atlanta Braves, 2-0.

title: DANCE: MUSIGN GROUP
description: The Musign Theater Company's name tells its story. Music and sign language are what this three-person group from Berkeley, Calif., performed on stage Friday at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater in the final week of Dance Theater Workshop's summer Out-of-Towner series. And that fluent mix made for a bright, inventive and warm evening in the theater.

title: Elizabeth Weisbecker to Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Van Tassel Weisbecker to David Townsend Claghorn has been announced by her parents, Elizabeth Dannehower Weisbecker and Burton Franklin Weisbecker of Princeton, N.J. An Oct. 29 wedding is planned.

title: GEORGE VECSEYSports of The Times Historian at First Base
description: AS soon as the baseball season ends, Keith and Sue Hernandez will drive south and west from New York toward the Civil War battlefields of Pennsylvania and Virginia. Hernandez has been given the name of a historian who may take him on a walking tour of Gettysburg, whose bloody fields he knows only from dozens of history books.

title: A STATEMENT BY THE PRESIDENT
description: Following is a statement by President Reagan on the 20th anniversary of the civil rights march on Washington:

title: Exploring Marital Twist
description: YOU could say she's obsessed with death. In her first novel, "Ending," and her third, "Hearts," a husband dies young. In her second novel, "In the Flesh," a character detects, even in the sunny suburbs, "alurking specter of death." And in her fourth novel, "In the Palomar Arms," published last spring to eritical accolades, an odor of mortality pervades the opening tryst between Daphne and her married lover, Kenny.

title: FAMILY PIETY
description: Johanna Kaplan is the author of a collection of stories, ''Other People's Lives,'' and a novel, ''O My America!'' REMEMBER THIS TIME

title: PRIDE OF SWISS IS DEALT BLOW BY A JAILBREAK
description: Switzerland's reputation for efficiency has suffered a blow with the escape from a Geneva prison this month of an Italian arrested here almost a year ago.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: ''They never got Al Capone on murder - they got him on tax fraud'' was the way a state senator summed up a new antinarcotics law in Arizona. The law, which went into effect last month, required illicit dealers to buy a $100 license and to pay ultrahigh taxes on their illegal sales.

title: Dr. Carla Rosenthal Marries Dr. Alan R. Schwartz
description: Dr. Carla Wolf Rosenthal, daughter of Mrs. R. Rex Rehfeld of Baltimore and the late Walter L. Rosenthal, was married yesterday to Dr. Alan Richard Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Schwartz of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Rabbi Sheila Russian and Rabbi Murray Saltzman of the Baltimore Hebrew Congregation performed the ceremony at the Engineering Society of Baltimore.

title: GAMBLING FLOWERS IN A COAST STATE
description: With bingo in church basements and grocery checkout lines, with half-million-dollar fish being pulled out of Puget Sound, with drugstore clerks selling lottery tickets and with two state commissions overseeing it all, games of chance have burst out of the shadows and into the limelight in Washington.

title: Sheila P. Casey Is Wed To Kevin R. McManus
description: Sheila Pinkham Casey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Paul Casey of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Marblehead, Mass., was married in Marblehead yesterday to Kevin Richard McManus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Francis McManus of Marblehead. Msgr. Joseph Bukay performed the ceremony at Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church.

title: OLD DEBATE RINGS ANEW WITH RAILROAD CENTENNIAL
description: There were no fireworks, no bands, and the brave speeches were 100 years old. Yet when Montanans got together to celebrate the centennial of the Northern Pacific Railroad's completion here this week, they were cheering the birthday of their Brooklyn Bridge, their monument to the westward course of an empire.

title: NEW INSIGHTS INTO WRIGHT'S DESIGN
description: What more can be learned about Frank Lloyd Wright's designs? A great deal, it appears, as can be seen in the ambitious exhibition ''Frank Lloyd Wright and the Prairie School,'' opening Tuesday and remaining through December at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, Fifth Avenue at 91st Street.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
IS IT JUST THE THING DEPICTED?
description: Real life. That is what seems to be present in the photographs included in the exhibition ''The American Image,'' that was reviewed last week in this space. However, precisely because it is so full of life, this exhibition raises in the most acute way the question of what it means for something to be ''in'' a photograph. When we respond to a photograph of say, a small child, is it the child himself we are responding to? Or does a photograph, like a painting, put a certain distance between us and its subject?

title: Air Curfew Ruling Spurs New Plans
description: WITHIN hours of a Federal judge's decision last week to end a 22-month ban on night flying at Westchester County Airport in Purchase, N.Y., Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, finished drafting a letter and an accompanying 15-page document to the County Board of Legislators setting forth a program for dealing with the "void" created by the judge's decision.

title: Weicker Gets G.O.P. to Ponder A New Diversity
description: CONNECTICUT Republicans took the first step last week toward a major overhaul of their election process.

title: U.S. WINS 400 RUN, SWEEPS BASKETBALL
description: Cliff Wiley of Baltimore ended a string of personal disappointments today by winning the 400 meters at the Pan American Games, where a little-known stimulant cost a Dominican sprinter, Juan Nunez, his silver medal.

title: TRANSLATING KLEIST
description: To the Editor:

title: More Surplus Food Available
description: THE hungry in Connecticut will receive more than 100,000 pounds a month of free cheese and other food from the Federal Government through the rest of the year, state officials have learned.

title: JERSEY ADDS $3 TO LICENSE FEE FOR UNSPAYED DOGS IN STATE
description: A $3 annual license surcharge for dogs that are not neutered began this month in New Jersey, but it will take several months before low-cost sterilizations financed by the surcharges can be offered, officials said.

title: WILLIAMSTOWN WEEKEND
description: LINDA CHARLTON is a writer who lives in Canaan, N.Y.

title: A TROUPE TRIES TO PLUMB THE HEART OF THE BARD'S WORDS
description: LENOX, Mass.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: As a Profession,Teaching Goes toThe Back RowSometime this spring, the nation seemed to awake from a long sleep during which the quality of how it educates its young people had seriously deteriorated. In April, a Government commission warned that a ''rising tide of mediocrity'' was threatening the schools. Last week, a new study by the Carnegie Foundation concluded that low status and low salaries had smitten the teaching profession.

title: Barbara Grace and Jonathan Fast Wed
description: Barbara Aileen Grace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Grace of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jonathan David Fast. The Rev. Albert Ciarcia performed the Unitarian-Universalist ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Fast of Redding Ridge, Conn.

title: Lynne Battle to Wed William Roesing
description: Lynne Davis Battle, general counsel and director of the Washington office of the College Placement Council, plans to be married Oct. 1 to William Pierce Roesing, president of Campaign Planning Inc., a political consulting concern in Washington.

title: THE NATION
description: For months now, diagnosticians reviewing the weekly collection of reports on the economy's health have seen signs of improvement and feared a relapse. The past seven days were no different.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE LURE OF A LUSH RURAL SETTING
description: PEOPLE travel to The Cascades Lodge as much for the setting as for the food. Perched on a hill in upper Bucks County about half a mile from the road that connects Reigelsville with Kintnersville (Route 611), the building overlooks lush rolling meadows, paddocks complete with horses, ponds, and a small manmade waterfall that cascades gently next to and beneath the building.

title: LAYOFFS OF POLICE BARRED IN CHICAGO
description: A circuit judge has issued a temporary restraining order to stop the city from laying off 332 probationary police officers. But another judge refused to issue a similar order for city firefighters.

title: MODERN BRITAIN'S CHIEF ARCHITECT
description: ATTLEE

title: CITY'S FESTIVALS CARRY THE ARTS TO THE STREETS
description: Disco music blared over the speakers in the courtyard of the Wise Towers apartment building on West 90th Street. Children, from toddlers to adolescents, danced along or perched expectantly on overturned milk crates, waiting for the show to begin.

title: LAWSUIT ON WATER DRAINS INDIAN HOPE
description: The talk on the Wind River Indian Reservation this spring was of big water-using projects, like irrigation dams and synthetic fuel plants, to put Indians to work after years of widespread unemployment.

title: THE RIGHT TO DIE IS STILL UNCLEAR
description: AN Appellate Court decision on July 8 in the case of Claire C. Conroy has generated much public discussion and debate. Unfortunately, much of this discussion is based on inaccurate or misleading descriptions of the facts.

title: At Horse Show; 'Instant City'
description: A CARAVAN of trailers transporting horses from all over the country will journey toward the corn and potato fields of Bridgehampton today and tomorrow. Their destination is the annual Hampton Classic Horse Show, where more than 1,100 equestrians will compete from Tuesday through Sept. 4.

title: ISRAEL CLEARS CAMP OF INMATES
description: The Ansar detention camp for suspected Palestinian terrorists in southern Lebanon was cleared this week of its 5,000 inmates after several escape tunnels were discovered underground.

title: 'BIRDERS' GATHER TO SEE 4,000-MILE WANDERER
description: Nantucket island's most unusual visitor this summer is a rare African Western Reef heron that has confounded ornithologists but has delighted bird watchers and the tourist industry.

title: Connecticut Joins Suit Against Watt
description: CONTENDING that its jurisdiction over coastal areas is threatened, the State of Connecticut this month joined 10 other states in a suit against Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: With lumber costs soaring and long stretches of Atlantic City's famous pine boardwalk rotting, the question arose: Why not use less expensive, more weather-resistant aluminum?

title: TEACHER SCHOOLS RAISE STANDARDS
description: Students interested in teaching careers are encountering stiffer admissions standards and curriculums at the nation's teaching colleges, a new Federal survey says.

title: IN KINDERDIJK, HOME IS A WINDMILL
description: STEVE SCHNEIDER contributes to The Times from Long Island.

title: STATE WEIGHS LEASING PARK FOR CONSTRUCTION OF A HOTEL
description: State park officials are considering an unusual proposal to lease the Ogden Mills and Ruth Livingston Mills State Park here for the construction of a resort hotel and conference center.

title: JOHN HENRY BACK ON HIS TURRF AND LOOKING AS GOOD AS EVER
description: THE story of John Henry makes ''The Black Stallion'' look tame and rivals the sagas of Santa Claus and the Easter Bunny for believability. It is the story of an ill-bred little gelding who was bought for $1,100 and traded and sold eight times before finding a permanent owner, but then became the richest horse who has ever lived, setting records every time he runs.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NEW GUYS AROUND THE BLOCK

CAMERA;

title: GUARINI CALLS FOR AN INQUIRY ON NAVY'S REJECTING BAYONNE
description: UNLESS the Defense Department can justify its decision to make Stapleton, S.I., instead of Bayonne, the home port for the Navy's Surface Action Group, Representative Frank J. Guarini said last week, he will ask the House Armed Services Committee to review the decision.

title: DEATH SPILLS INTO COSTA RICA FROM NICARAGUA
description: Recent killings have alerted the authorities to the threat posed by political violence spreading across the border from Nicaragua.

title: SECOND-HAND AUDIO MAY NOW BECOME A GOOD BUY
description: During the riotous Presidential campaign of 1968, opponents of the Republican candidate urged the voters to consider whether they would buy a used car from ''that man.'' They might as well have asked if the voters would buy a used stereo set from him. After all, the opportunities for mendacity are probably as tempting in the second-hand hi-fi trade as they are in the used car business. That is why, traditionally, most customers feel safer with brand-new equipment, and the market in second- hand components has remained spotty.

title: A GENERATION LATER, YOUTH JOIN IN MARCH
description: Etta Williams, an unemployed factory worker from Jamestown, N.Y., was back again.

description: GOD & HARVEY GROSBECK

title: IRA BERKOWSports of The Times; Steve Burtt: Of Harlem and Iona
description: STEVE BURTT and a companion entered the apartment building on West 118th Street in Harlem on a recent afternoon, took the elevator to the fifth floor, walked through the clean, well-lighted hallway and then, with a turn of the key, entered his apartment.

title:
ANTIQUES; 
Tiny Treasures of the Young
description: THE collector's fancy for antique dolls and the costumes and toys made to accompany them has increased markedly over the past several years. In recognition of this interest, a special exhibit now is on view at the Connecticut Historical Society, 1 Elizabeth Street in Hartford.

description: The angriest player in the United States Open tennis championships this week figures to be Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, who arrived with 20 racquets, 5 pairs of shoes, 3 warm-up suits, 200 sets of gut for strings and plans for a lawsuit against the officials of international tennis.

title: THE NOVELIST AND THE NATIONALIST
description: TOLSTOY AND GANDHI, MEN OF PEACE

title: Williams College Awards
description: Williams College has announced that it will give $1,000 in cash annually, starting this year, to four secondary school teachers for teaching excellence and $500 to their schools. Nominations will be made by seniors, the college said Wednesday, and a committee of faculty and students will make the selections. The money will come from a $102,000 fund established through the estate of the late George Olmsted Jr., a 1924 graduate of Williams and chairman of the S. D. Warren Company, a paper making concern, and gifts from his wife, Frances.

description: OUR ENDANGERED CHILDREN

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS HIS MIDEAST PLAN
description: President Reagan reaffirmed today that the establishment of Israeli settlements in the West Bank posed ''an obstacle to peace'' in the Middle East.

title: Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: The article ''What's Doing in Amsterdam'' (Travel, July 17) reawakened nostalgia for some happy hours I have spent there. I was particularly glad to note your refer

title: MAPPING
description: Where are the closest subway stops? Are there places nearby where employees can have either restaurant or deli meals? Do major banks have branches in the area? If I need a shirt in a hurry, is there a shop in the neighborhood? What about a hotel for our traveling sales reps?

title: Dolly Vincel, Alumni Aide, Has Nuptials
description: Carolyn Ann Vincel, daughter of Mrs. Andrew Fletcher Jr. of New York and Southampton, L.I., and Garrick Vincel of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Richard Kyle Samperton of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Samperton of Sumner, Md. The Rev. Malcolm Foster performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church in Southampton.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: This is the last week of the exhibition of paintings by John Constable at the Metropolitan Museum. It is not of course the last opportunity that we shall have to look at Constable's work - the Yale Center for British Art has just acquired another major painting by him, and quite a few of the paintings at the Met are lent from American collections - but this is nonetheless a very substantial show, and one that has the merit of being curated by Graham Reynolds, for many years a leading authority on the subject.

title: POLL FINDS SPLIT IN MOOD OF WHITES AND BLACKS
description: There is a sharp contrast between the number of whites and the number of blacks who express satisfaction with their personal lives and with the way things are going in the nation, according to a recent Gallup Poll.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN TELEPHONE MARKETING;
THE DAWNING OF DISPOSABLES
description: They are not quite use-once-and- throw-away products, but the forerunner of the disposable telephone may be here. Low-cost electronic phones are now one of the fastest- growing retail telephone product segments, selling almost as quickly as retailers put them on the shelves.

title: YOUNG SURVIVORS
description: CHILDREN OF WAR

title: Parlez-Vous Croissant?
description: NOW that the croissant has replaced the 99 Special, English muffins and corn-flakes as America's favorite breakfast, it is time we came to terms with its pronunciation.

title: RISE IN LOAN RATES ALSO LIFTS LEVEL OF UNCERTAINTY
description: HOME buyers, home sellers and the lenders who provide the financing that brings them together are keeping a worried watch on the interest markets these days, the way a traveler who has had a bad bout with malaria keeps a wary eye on a mild fever.

title: WASTE IN FUEL OIL IS CURBED BY STATE
description: New York State has restricted for the first time the amount of toxic lead, PCB's and solvents allowed in heating oil, officials have announced.

title: Walker Enters Mile
description: John Walker, the New Zealander who won the 1976 Olympic gold medal in the 1,500-meter run, has entered Saturday's third annual Fifth Avenue Mile. Walker, a former world-record holder in the mile, was the first person to break the 3-minute-50-second barrier in the mile, when he turned in a 3:49.4 in 1975, a mark that remained until 1979.

title: OVER 20 YEARS, THE MOOD HAS CHANGED MARKEDLY
description: In terms of numbers, the turnout at today's march for jobs, peace and freedom may have approached the one it was meant to commemorate, but the tone, the moods and the passions of today's marchers were markedly different from those of the men and women who marched the same route 20 years ago with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Music;  Connectricut Goes to Purchase
description: AN increasing number of Connecticut musical organizations, having either outgrown their local auditoriums or become dissatisfied with the acoustics there, have been crossing the state line to perform at the Center for the Arts at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Marcos Foe'sMurder ShakesTwo CountriesWhat to do with a strategic ally whose political practices are an embarrassment even to itself? The problem was dramatically thrust on the United States last week when the foremost rival of President E. Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines was gunned down at Manila airport within minutes of his return from three years of self-exile.

title: WOOING 'THE BEST AND THE BRIGHTEST'
description: UPSTAIRS in the private dining room of the Chelsea Lobster House in Howard Beach, Queens, seafood was on the table and real- estate management on the agenda. A group of managers consumed clam chowder, lobster, salad and white wine and discussed boiler repairs, rent subsidies and landlord-tenant relations.

title: CRIME
description: There is nothing unfamiliar in LISTEN FOR THE CLICK by Jon L. Breen (Walker, $12.95). In this first novel, Mr. Breen observes some of the modern conventions. Contemporary writers do not think along the lines of heroes a la Lord Peter Wimsey or James Bond. Thus the central character in ''Listen for the Click'' is an overweight race- track announcer. But everything else is standard, and the girls are still beautiful.

title: Correction
description: The Sports of The Times column last Sunday incorrectly identified Intrepid as the 1962 America's Cup defender. Weatherly successfully defended the Cup that year. Intrepid was the successful defender in 1967.

title: ORIOLES, PALMER TRIUMPH
description: Jim Palmer allowed three hits over seven innings to win his first game since returning from the disabled list as Baltimore topped the Minnesota Twins, 5-3, tonight and extended the Orioles' winning streak to five games.

title: Child-Killer's Execution Set
description: The Mississippi Supreme Court has ordered Jimmy Lee Gray, 34 years old, who narrowly avoided the gas chamber last month for kidnapping, assaulting and murdering 3-year-old Deressa Jean Scales, executed next Friday. The order was handed down late Friday by Chief Justice Neville Patterson in response to a request by the state Attorney General, Bill Allain.

title: SEASON OF ECONOMIC CONFUSION IS AT HAND
description: After an August calm, the Reagan Administration's international economic policymakers are girding for a barrage from the guns of September. The shooting will be over such issues as mounting third world debt, high interest rates, an overstretched dollar, thinning resources at the International Monetary Fund, the record $60 billion American trade deficit and strained trade relations almost everywhere.

title: NEW BOOSTER RULE'S EFFECT ON COLLEGE SPORTS
description: IT'S a familiar scene. Johnny, the No. 1

title: POLICE CHIEF NOTES A CONTRAST
description: Police Chief Maurice Turner, who was a patrolman during the March on Washington 20 years ago, said the air of confrontation at that event was absent from the anniversary march today.

title: Youth in Suit Over Test Accepted by University
description: One of the four Millburn High School graduates who lost a recent court challenge after the Educational Testing Service questioned their college entrance examination scores because of suspected cheating has been admitted to the University of Richmond.

title: The Master's Plans
description: In 1936, when leftist partisans in Barcelona turned the studio of Antonio Gaudly Cornet, near the Sagrada Familia church, most of his working papers were consumed. Now, after years of detective work and research, George R. Coilins and Juan Bassegoda Noneil have assembled THE DESIGNS AND DRAWINGS OF ANTONIO GUADI (Princeton University Press. 926; $128 after Dec. 31), including plans and drawings by the Cataian master that were rescued from private hands and institutions as well as drawings of Guadi buildings by his associates or students.

title: Courtney Callender,46, Dies; Fo
description: Courtney Callender, New York City's deputy commissioner of cultural affairs during the administration of John V. Lindsay, died of cancer Friday at his home on Roosevelt Island. He was 46 years old.

title: Translating Kleist
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: D. A. Pennebaker's ''Don't Look Back,'' one of the great rock artifacts of the 60's, is back in circulation for the first time in over a decade. This behind-the- scenes documentary follows Bob Dylan, at the height of his glory, on his concert tour of England in 1965.

title: WHY TODAY'S FILMS TURN TO HISTORY
description: In the middle of ''Zelig,'' Woody Allen's gleeful

title: TO BANGLADESH, FENCES MAKE BAD NEIGHBORS
description: An Indian proposal to stop a flow of illegal immigrants from Bangladesh by building a fence along the border between the two countries has drawn angry opposition from Bangladesh and has soured relations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe in the cause. I wasn't here, but I remember that it happened.

title: PHILHARMONIC: ON TOUR IN QUEENS
description: For those put off by the large crowds that descend on Central Park for the free New York Philharmonic concerts, there exists a happy alternative. After all, the Philharmonic does not belong exclusively to Manhattan. Every summer the orchestra tours various parks throughout the five boroughs, and for the price of a subway token, an interested listener can hear a concert in Brooklyn's Prospect Park or in one of the plethora of smaller patches of green throughout the city.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: In 1961, the same year that Benjamin Britten composed his ''War Requiem,'' the BBC and the German Democratic Republic's broadcasting system co-produced a recording of a performance of the work. The work was composed to commemorate the World War II bombings of Coventry by the Nazis and Dresden by the Allies. Poems by Wilfred Owen, who died in World War I, and the old Latin Mass for the Dead inspired Mr. Britten's text. ''War Requiem,'' which was filmed in the Dresden Cathedral in Germany with 300 musicians and singers, will be broadcast here for the first time on Tuesday at 10 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Home Clinic;  Time to Fix the Roof Is When the Sun Shines; Here's How
description: FLAT or shed-type roofs are usually covered with roll-type roofing material that is applied in layers, rather than with shingles (shingles are practical only on roofs that have a definite slope to them). When properly applied, this kind of roofing will last for many years. But as a rule, roll roofing (sometimes referred to as built-up roofing) does require more frequent inspection than shingles if leaks are to be prevented from developing as the years go by.

title: Isabelle Weare Is Married
description: Isabelle Weare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ashley Weare of New York and Watchung, N.J., was married in Edison, N.J., yesterday to Scott L. Winzeler, son of Mrs. Ray Wangrin of Napoleon, Ohio, and the late Dr. Edwin Winzeler. The Rev. Robbie Klauder, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Samek. The bride's father is a senior vice president of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.

title: For 2 Weeks; Boys and Girls Give Camp Their Best Shots
description: AT 6 feet 10, the former Iona College basetball star Jeff Ruland towers over Carol O'Keefe, a slender 15-year-old from Thornwood. She stares up at him attentively as he patiently instructs her in the art of making a foul shot.

title: CORRECTION
description: The announcement of the wedding of Carolyn Ann Vincel and Richard Kyle Samperton on page 66 is incorrect. After the article was printed early yesterday, Miss Vincel's stepfather said the wedding had been canceled by a mutual decision.

description: R. SHIPP

title: State Panel On Arts Gets Grant For Study
description: CONNECTICUT'S Commission on the Arts was recently chosen as the first recipient of a special Rockefeller Foundation grant for self-evaluation.

title: SEEING CHIOS THRROUGH GREEK EYES
description: DAVID PLANTE, an American writer, has lived in London for 20 years. His most recent book is ''Difficult Women'' (Atheneum).

title: Colt Dies After Finishing 3d
description: All Fired Up won the $577,425 Arlington-Washington Futurity for 2-year-olds today at Arlington Park after Smart n Slick, the favorite, who took the lead in midstretch, apparently suffered a ruptured artery and died on the track a few seconds after the finish.

title: TOWN OF 7 ON PRAIRIE GIVES UP 'BIG CITY' LIFE
description: This prairie town of seven people, weary of big-city paper work, bureaucratic infighting and having to scrounge around for people to serve on the Town Board, has voted to end its incorporated status.

description: FLAT or shed-type roofs are usually covered with roll-type roofing material that is applied in layers, rather than with shingles (shingles are practical only on roofs that have a definite slope to them). title: Lori Jill Nitzberg Marries Bruce Rothman, a Broker
description: Lori Jill Nitzberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Nitzberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bruce Michael Rothman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rothman of Borough Park, Brooklyn. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

title: H.A. DEBUTTS, EX-CHAIRMAN OF SOUTHERN RAILWAY SYSTEM
description: Harry Ashby deButts, who retired as chairman of the Southern Railway System in 1962 after more than 46 years with the company, died yesterday at his home in Upperville, Va., after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER; 
Night Lines
description: IT is 2 o'clock in the morning, and Midland Avenue is quiet. Stores and warehouses are shuttered; even the neon sign in front of the Turf Club Bar and Grill no longer glows green. Although it is hot and sultry, no one is hanging out.

title: SUNDAY, AUGUST 28, 1983;  International
description: The United States was disappointed by Yuri V. Andropov's latest arms control statement, a senior Administration official said, because it did not show any flexibility on two of the key issues delaying progress in negotiations on limiting medium-range missiles in Europe. The official said the Soviet leader's statement ignored two basic problems: Mr. Andropov's insistence that no new American missiles should be deployed by the Western alliance, and the renewed American insistence that any agreement on limits on the Soviet SS-20 mobile missile system be applied to Asia as well as Europe. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: PARTY MODERATES PLAN LIFE AFTER REAGAN
description: WASHINGTON BEFORE the end of the year, probably sometime in November, President Reagan is expected to make known whether he intends to seek a second term in office. Whatever decision he makes, it is likely to have important implications not only for Republican chances in the 1984 Presidential election, but for the party itself in this decade and beyond.

title: 'Busby!' Misuses Grand Old Songs
description: IF there is a real musical to be made from the high-kicking but hard-knock life of Busby Berkeley -- the legendary director who declared that three things were necessary to make a show a success: "Girls, girls, girls" -- the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport has not come up with it.

title: PERMANENT POVERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: Violence in Beirut
description: Thomas L. Friedman's article ''Living With the Violence of Beirut'' (July 17) would have been excellent were it not for some mild sensationalism and a certain condescending tone which marks the author as a definite outsider.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIA SIGN GRAIN ACCORD
description: The United States and Russia signed a five-year grain agreement worth some $10 billion to American farmers. It was the first major trade pact between the two countries since President Carter imposed a partial grain embargo in response to the Soviet Union's military intervention into Afghanistan in December 1979. The agreement, which takes effect Oct. 1, commits the Russians to buy between nine and 12 million tons of grain a year from the United States. And the Reagan Administration seemed downright apologetic. At a news conference following the signing ceremony in Moscow, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block (right) described the Carter embargo as ''a distasteful chapter,'' that had hurt American farmers and ''forced'' the Soviet Union into the arms of other suppliers. And he promised better conduct. ''We want not only to be a good supplier - we want to be the best supplier for the U.S.S.R.,'' the secretary said.

title: PLEASURES OF THE FAST PAYOFF
description: One day I began to write seriously; my writing had begun to impress me. Years of all sorts had gone by. The annunciation had long since tolled and the response was slow awakening. Much remained to do and become, if there was time. Some are born whole; others must seek this blessed state in a struggle to achieve order. That is no loss to speak of; ultimately such seeking becomes the subject matter of fiction. Observing, reading, thinking, one invents himself. A familiar voice asks, ''Who am I, and how can I say what I have to?'' The writer reads his sentences to see if the words answer the question. Thus he may tell his fortune. His imagination impels him to speak in several tongues, though one is sufficient. At this point he may begin to write a story, a daring endeavor.

title: COMPUTERS AREN'T THE LAST WORD
description: A software company in Norman, Okla., advertised a full college course for my Atari with 16 programs, 8 cassettes, 32 tests and ''a fancy binder'' for only $79. ''That's less than the books and tuition for most college classes. And we offer a 10-day, 100 percent exchange allowance. Does your alma mater?'' Considering that my university charges students more than $10,000 a year, this offer seemed a bargain. (We include meals and a bed, which are not part of the computer package.)

description: STEVEN V. ROBERTS is a reporter in The Times Washington bureau.

description: Mr. and Mrs. David K. Smith of Weston, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Carleton Smith, to David Yonkers Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Berry of New Vernon, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Bridge; Trigger-Happy Double
description: In bygone days, we are told, Dodge city was full of trigger-happy cowboys., Their spirtual descendants are to be found at bridge tournaments, especially in match-point play, letteng fly with a double at the slightest provocation.

title: FRANCE AND ZAIRE HOLD JOINT EXERCISE WITH CHAD
description: French, Chadian and Zairian troops and combat aircraft have taken part in a joint military exercise in eastern Chad, Defense Minister Charles Hernu of France said today.

description: On a winding stretch of the Montauk Highway from he Boardy Barn, a popular disco in Hampton Bays, to the equally popular Bay Club in East Quogue, a higher than average number of alcohol-related accidents occur. Extra patrol cars are now monitoring that section of the highway, using part of the $21,200 that was allocated to the Southampton Town police for the 1983 Stop D.W.I. (Driving While Intoxicated) program.

title: COST OF STATE BRINK'S CASE $2.5 MILLION SO FAR
description: Documented expenses for the prosecuting of state charges in the Brink's robbery and triple slaying have risen to about $2.5 million, and the expense is likely to continue growing, according to officials of Rockland and Orange Counties.

Dr. David Cousins of the United Methodist Church in Red Bank, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Blair home.
description: The bride, an administrative assistant at the Turkish Consulate General in New York, attended the Robert College Lycee in Istanbul and graduated from Harvard College.

title: State Is Investigating Druggings at Batavia
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board is investigating the apparent drugging of four harness race horses at Batavia Downs last week by someone whose motive has not been determined, state and track officials say.

title: ALISON JAMES IS BRIDE
description: Alison Mary James, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis James of Manchester, England, was married yesterday to John Voe, son of Clara Voe and the late John Voe of Chicago. The Rev. William D. Roberts performed the ceremony om the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: MISCAST OR NOT, OLIVIER RISES ABOVE THE ROLE
description: Any old actor can play against type, but only a great actor can turn type inside out and stand it on its head. In ''Mr. Halpern and Mr. Johnson,'' a one-hour drama that will be shown tonight on HBO, Laurence Olivier plays a newly widowed Jewish cardboard-box manufacturer in the Bronx. Forget your preconception of how such a man looks and sounds. Olivier believes he looks and sounds like a fussy hairdresser in one of the drearier suburbs of London. He is helped in this conceit by the script, which says that the character he plays did indeed arrive here from London some 40 years ago. On the other hand, Olivier is such a very great actor that it probably doesn't matter. ''Mr. Halpern and Mr. Johnson'' is an inspired piece of miscasting.

title: SPLITTING THE PRIZE
description: There is one way to avoid rancor, recriminations and hurt feelings in the awarding of a brilliancy prize split it up among several games. This is what was done in the United States Invitational Championship in Greenville, Pa.

title: Not at Your Service
description: Russell Baker has the right idea about full-service gas pumps (''Not at Your Service,'' Sunday Observer, July 17). I, too, am accused of being old-fashioned and extravagant because I refuse to pump gas.

title: HANA MANDLIKOVA, JO DURIE GAIN FINAL
description: Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia and Jo Durie of Britain captured their semifinal matches today and will meet Sunday in the final of the Virginia Slims of New Jersey tennis tournament.

title: THE REGION
description: Maybe ThereShould Be aCrosstown FerryBeneath the cracked, crumbling and broken-down streets of Manhattan lies a cracked, crumbling and broken-down water system, as anyone in the vicinity of Fifth Avenue and 23d Street Wednesday morning was all too aware. Pedestrians were ankle- and knee-deep, subways at a standstill and traffic not much better after the second serious water main break in as many weeks.

title: FREUD ON TASTELESSNESS
description: Sigmund Freud, who savored a jest, wrote that a joke, any joke, was a ''double-dealing rascal,'' a thoroughly untrustworthy character. So the good doctor would probably not have been too shocked by the less'' humor reported in The Times a few weeks ago. He might have listened first, silently, smoking his cigar, while the facts were presented.

description: AFTER 22 years of unchallenged rule, John J. Driscoll, president of the State A.F.L.-C.I.O., will face his first contested election next month at the age of 71.

description: "BARNUM," now playing at the Westbury Music Fair, is the musical biography of that quintessential showman, Phineas Taylor Barnum. That's Barnum as in P.T. Barnum, founder of the Greatest Show on Earth, and co-owner of the Barnum & Bailey traveling three-ring circus under the canvas big top. He was a man who embroidered his dreams with multicolored ribbons and turned his most elaborate fantasies into reality.

title: TCHAIKOVSKY WITHOUT MYTH
description: Biographies of famous people of our own time - the living or the recently alive - are certainly not useless. Rather often, in music at any rate, they can be wonderfully entertaining, like dipping into the Apochrypha. I particularly enjoy the life stories of opera singers and other virtuosos whom I have known, however slightly. These books, which flood out each season, usually make little pretense to objectivity or documentary truth but simply reflect the subject's idealized image of himself or herself. The writers go along, either out of genuine hero worship or out of the fear of being denied access to invaluable historical documents such as old programs and laudatory press clippings. And really, it makes little sense to expect more of these hard-pressed authors than that. Contemporary biography, no matter who practices it, is a hybrid art: part history, part fiction. It is mythology in action.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Marjorie Gamso has always been one of the more reflective post-modernist choreographers. And her ''Fugitive Furniture'' promises to continue in that vein.

description: Elizabeth Anne Higgins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lindley Roberts Higgins of Old Bridge, N.J., was married yesterday to William C. Coffin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coffin of Point Pleasant Beach, N.J. The Rev. J. Wesley Vanaman performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in Helmetta, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Elmer F. Francis, a cousin of the bride.

description: THE two artists currently exhibiting at the Louise Himelfarb gallery in Southampton are both concerned with illusion, but they express that concern in very different ways. While the sculptor Walter Channing creates three-dimensional trempe l'oeil effects with carved wood, Jorge Gentillini uses perspective and architectonic design to suggest a world of order and harmony.
