title: Miss Kegg, A Portraitist, Has Nuptials
description: Virginia Kip Kegg, daughter of Virginia Kip Kegg of New York and Point O'Woods, L.I., and the late William Boyd Kegg Jr., was married yesterday to Dean Gillette Van Nest Jr., son of Mr. Van Nest of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Maude Haulenbeek Van Nest. The Rev. Martin Copenhaver, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Burlington, Vt., performed the ceremony in the Church at Point O'Woods.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TO USE BANK NOTE PAPER FOR CARDS
description: The Government will try to cut down on the counterfeiting of Social Security cards by printing them on bank note paper instead of cardboard, officials have announced.

title: Article 127936 -- No Title
description: Winford Coburn, who lost his arms on the job, will receive $1.3 million in a settlement with the machine's manufacturer. Zurn Industries, of Erie, Pa., agreed to the settlement with Mr. Coburn, 61 years old, Wednesday, according to Judge William White of Berrien Circuit Court. Mr. Coburn sued Zurn and the Erie Engine and Manufacturing Company of Erie after a 1979 accident at the Vail Rubber Company in St. Joseph. His hands were caught between rollers on a rubber-pressing machine.

title: Marches Held Elsewhere
description: Thousands of people marched in San Francisco and other cities today to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the March on Washington led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The San Francisco march drew 15,000 people to Golden Gate Park.

title: THE WORLD
description: With millions of dollars in United States aid and encouragement from President Reagan, the Nicaraguan insurgents seemed to be getting their anti-Sandinista act together last week. Government officials and diplomats in Managua said as many as 2,000 rebels had crossed into Nicaragua, launching hit-and-run attacks across three northern provinces that left scores dead on both sides.

title: A MAJOR RETROSPECTIVE SHEDS LIGHT ON COLUMBIA PICTURES
description: Lady Liberty its trademark, ''Gems of the Screen'' its motto, from the beginning Columbia Pictures appropriated a national icon and an anthem in order to define its image. This precedent might serve to explain the Columbia actress Kim Novak's confusion of national with corporate allegiance during a European publicity tour in 1956. Driving Miss Novak across the Alps, her starstruck chauffeur began a compliment: ''Miss Kim, I have had the honor and privilege to drive some of the great dignitaries of our time, the Duke and the Duchess of Windsor, Field Marshal Montgomery, and also your president -'' ''You mean Harry Cohn?'' Miss Novak interrupted.

title: THE MOVEMENT'S UNFINISHED BUSINESS IS A TOUGH AGENDA
description: TWENTY years ago yesterday, 250,000 people marched in Washington, petitioning for jobs and freedom for blacks. Yesterday, tens of thousands marched in Washington in the 20th Anniversary Mobilization for Jobs, Peace and Freedom, in memory of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream of a future day of harmony, and in support of a nuclear freeze resolution, passage of the equal rights amendment, opposition to loans to South Africa, homosexual rights and more. The Week in Review asked three people who worked for Dr. King's dream to talk about civil rights, the promise of then and the problems of now.

title: HUNTERDON HAS A WIDE FOLLOWING
description: CLINTON THE annual antiques show and sale at the Hunterdon Art Center here is a select offering with a prestigious reputation and a more than regional following. For collector and novice, it is an opportunity for an early fall excursion into the pleasures of country antiquing.

title:
STAMPS;
A NEW RED, WHITE AND BLUE FOR THE CIVIL SERVICE
description: Ared, white and blue commemorative observes the 100th anniversary of the United States government's establishment of a civil service. It ended decades of a corrupt spoils system and established a body of civil servants based predominantly on merit.

title: EX-STARS OF BOLSHOI CREATE A NEW LIFE
description: EVERY time the taxicab jolted to a halt as it inched its way through midtown Manhattan traffic, Leonid Kozlov scowled.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: -year-old girls, Pamela Rempell of Pine Brook takes dancing and piano lessons and is getting ready to start first grade.

title: PUTTING A CUSTOM ON PAPER
description: FOR the last eight years, the children of a

title: Westchester Journal
description: Banners of Freedom

title: SATELLITE SALE DRAWS INTEREST
description: Eighteen corporations have expressed interest in buying the nation's land and weather satellites.

title: O'Rourke Proposes 5-Part Airport Plan
description: A FEDERAL judge's decision last week to permanently enjoin the county's airport curfew law gave impetus to a search among county officials for substitute measures -- a search that actually began after the judge tipped his hand last July that an injunction was a "likelihood."

title: PHILADELPHIA SEES UNDERDOGS BATTLE
description: John J. Egan Jr., a man accustomed to dealing with substantial risks for high stakes, looked and sounded like a poker player with four aces.

title: 5 Vie for Seats in New Minority Districts
description: ERNEST S. DAVIS is the Assessor for the City of Mount Vernon. An architect by profession and a Democrat by party, Mr. Davis, who is 45 years old, says he spent the first of his 23 years in Mount Vernon "staying out of local politics."

title: THE NATION
description: Texas G.O.P.Is Left With aWide Open SpaceSenator John Tower of Texas, chairman of the Armed Services Committee and one of President Reagan's staunchest allies on military matters, staged what seemed like a tactical retreat last week.

title: Protesters in Chile Seek Ouster of Pinochet
description: More than 500 Christian Democrat supporters marched through downtown Santiago today calling for the ouster of President Augusto Pinochet.

title: No Headline
description: A year after graduating from the City University of New York, most of the members of the class of 1981 who responded to a survey were employed or attending graduate school. Those with jobs were earning an average of $16,000 a year.

title: Political Effect Debated in Resume Case
description: UNTIL last week, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke had expressed his philosophy as "you don't fix what ain't broken" while presiding over a county government largely bequeathed to him by Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello.

title: 2 BOXING GILDS ARE WON BY U.S.
description: A disappointing two weeks for United States amateur boxing ended today with only two gold medals in the Pan American Games.

title: Amy B. Goldman, Lawyer, Is Bride
description: Amy Beth Goldman, daughter of Dr. Leo Goldman of New York and Elsie Goldman of East Rockaway, L.I., was married yesterday to Joel Lawrence London, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar London of New York. Rabbi Chaim Etrog, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Ned A. Greenberg Marries Linda Ury in Connecticut
description: Linda Ellen Ury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry S. Ury of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Ned A. Greenberg, son of Mrs. Mindell Frankel of Chicago and Marvin Greenberg of Phoenix, Ariz. Rabbi Samuel Porrath performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Newington, Conn.

title: BIG BOARD'S ELECTRONIC GAINS
description: It was the mid-1970's, with electronics becoming the rage, when some Wall Street pundits sounded warnings that the New York Stock Exchange would wither, its tumultuous trading floor to be replaced by quietly humming computers, its majestic building to become a monument of a bygone era.

title: SUPPLIERS TO DETROIT FEEL MORE PRESSURE
description: As the auto industry climbs out of a wrenching four-year recession, its dealings with suppliers are being transformed, company executives and industry analysts say.

title: Ralph Hanover Triumphs Easily MONTREAL, Aug. 28 (UPI) - Ralph Hanover grabbed the lead at the quarter-pole today and breezed home to win the 17th edition of the $411,500 Prix D'Ete at Bluebonnets Raceway.
description: Ralph Hanover, who has been syndicated for $7 million and will be sent to Almahurst Stud Farm in Lexington, Ky., at the end of his 3-year-old campaign, has now won 14-of-18 starts.

title: MISS LAVELLE 'GROVELED' TO KEEP E.P.A. POST
description: Rita M. Lavelle, the Environmental Protection Agency official dismissed by President Reagan, says she ''groveled'' in tears while pleading for her job in a meeting with Anne McGill Burford, then the Environmental Protection Administrator.

title: POPS COMES BACK TO THE FAMILY
description: THE next best thing to Willie Stargell booming a home run is Willie Stargell booming a bon mot in the dugout. There are never enough inspirational superstars to go around, and Chuck Tanner knows where he can find one.

title: MUSIC: SLATKIN CONDUCTS MOSTLY MOZART'S FINALE
description: THE 1983 Mostly Mozart season came to a fitting close at Avery Fisher Hall this weekend, when Leonard Slatkin led the festival orchestra through music by Mozart, Beethoven and the all-but-forgotten Josef Myslivecek. If this year's festival has been a little shorter on Mozart than those of previous years, it has more than made up for it in other ways. It's been a long time since the festival has featured such an incisive, energetic and altogether excellent pick-up orchestra, and performances have been on a high level.

title: GALANOS KNITS LURING BUYERS
description: James Galanos didn't hear the hurrahs that greeted the sweater dresses and glittering tops that ended his fall and winter show at the Plaza Hotel recently. As the last model was dressed, he had left the dressing room to avoid the customary chitchat as everyone runs backstage after a fashion show to congratulate the designer.

title: SERVING HIS COUNTRY
description: As an 18-year-old seaman, John Smitherman was one of 40,000 American servicemen near the Bikini atoll in the south Pacific when two 20-kiloton atomic bombs were set off in a 1946 test operation known as Crossroads. It proved to be one for him.

title: STATEMENT ON BEGIN
description: Following is the text of the Cabinet annnouncement read by Cabinet Secretary Dan Meridor today on Prime Minister Menachem Begin's intention to resign, as translated by The Associated Press:

title: U.S. Juniors Win
description: The United States won the second world junior basketball championship by defeating the Soviet Union, 82-78, in the final today. The Americans were behind, 51-49, at halftime. They were led by Kenny Walker, a sophomore from the University of Kentucky, who scored 24 points.

title: TURKEY MOVES TO TIGHTEN CURBS ON NEWSPAPERS
description: The military Government has recently taken a series of actions against Turkish newspapers and journalists in what appears to be a tightening of press controls before parliamentary elections scheduled for November.

title: PRICE WINS SERIES BY 4 AS NICKLAUS IS 2D
description: Now Nick Price can forget his collapse in the 1982 British Open. The 26-year-old South African, a rookie on the PGA Tour, won his first American event today in a style that any professional golfer would be glad to emulate: four rounds in the 60's over the long and difficult Firestone Country Club, and a final round that included no bogeys.

title: PART-TIMERS UNITE
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'THE BEST OF TIMES,' A COMEDY
description: ''THE BEST OF TIMES'' wants to be a number of things, only one of them a comedy. It is supposed to be about the funny goings-on among the students at good old Grant High, but other elements - slices of life, pieces of drama - keep intruding. Presumably, this makes it a contemporary comedy. The half-hour pilot will be seen on Channel 2 at 8:30 tonight.

title: Nancy Falls Married To Martin Aronchick
description: Nancy M. Falls, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Falls Jr. of New York, was married at the Hyatt Hotel in New Brunswick, N.J., yesterday to Martin Charles Aronchick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney D. Aronchick of West Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leslie Merlin, associate minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg.

title: No Headline
description: Warner Pays $1,165,000 For Rights to 'August'

title: No Headline
description: Woman Is Thrown From Ride And Injured at Rye Playland

title: No Headline
description: Kindergarten Plans Lag in Two Districts

title: COSMOS TRIUMPH, 3-1, IN RAIN
description: The weather was foul and the play often matched it tonight as 19,868 rain-drenched people saw the Cosmos defeat the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 3-1, at Giants Stadium.

title: FLEMINGTON FAIR IS REALLY A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: Smack in the center of the state fair here, next to the acrobats and the demolition derby and away from the sound of the merry-go- round and the smell of caramel apples, Frank Stockton was pretending to be a farmer.

title: Police Investigate Killing in Paramus
description: The police today were questioning employees and acquaintances of a carpet-store owner who was found shot to death in his store Friday night.

title: CITY OPERA ORCHESTRA VOTES TODAY ON CONTRACT TO END 53-DAY STRIKE
description: The New York City Opera and its musicians reached a tentative contract settlement at 8:30 P.M. yesterday. The agreement is expected to end the 53-day-old strike against the company by the orchestra and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

title: ONE NUCLEAR FOE'S 'IDEOLOGICAL RIGIDITY'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RETURN OF CORDERO
description: ''DID you see that!'' said Sammy Renick. In the press box at Belmont Park on Saturday, Renick, the former jockey, had his binoculars trained on the track below.

title: Gromyko to Visit France
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, will meet with French officials in Paris early next month, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: 5 ASTRONAUTS SET FOR LIFTOFF TOMORROW
description: The machines and astronauts, including the first American black selected to fly in space, were reported ready today for the nighttime launching of the space shuttle Challenger early Tuesday.

title: FRENCH STILL ON CHAD
description: The skill and flexibility demonstrated by President Francois Mitterrand in response to developments in Chad contrasts with the Reagan Administration's myopia and intransigence. French policy has reflected a deeper understanding of Chad and a desire to limit Paris's conflict with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Washington seeks to ''punish'' the Libyan leader and neglects the Chadian dimensions of the war.

title: American Paintings To Travel to Louvre
description: The richness, diversity and technical accomplishment of American art, from before the nation's founding to the beginning of the 20th century, will be explored in ''A New World: Masterpieces of American Painting, 1760- 1910,'' which will be on exhibit in Boston's Museum of Fine Arts from Sept. 7 through Nov. 13.

title: INDIA TO PURSUE DOWN-TO-EARTH GOALS FROM 22,300-MILE ORBIT
description: Soon after the space shuttle Challenger rockets into orbit Tuesday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., if all goes as planned, the craft's computers will be ordered to bring to powered life its most important piece of cargo: Insat 1-B, India's one-of-a-kind earth satellite, which combines telecommunications, weather forecasting and television- broadcasting functions in a single package.

title: TRADERS CONFUSED BY THE FED'S MOVES
description: In recent years, investors and Wall Street firms have tried a full range of tactics - from hiring former Federal Reserve Board economists to conducting their own surveys of bank deposits - in an attempt to divine the future course of interest rates.

title: A DECADE OF CHANGE ALONG THE COUNTRY'S BYWAYS
description: For more than a half century, Betty Evenson would walk every morning from her little rural home here, raise the American flag and look out on the arid rolling rangelands that stretch clear to the horizon. ''It was my domain,'' she said.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.59

title: JAME'S 'BOSTONIANS' ON LOCATION
description: Henry James's ''The Bostonians,'' a novel published in 1886, is now being shot in New England as a Merchant- Ivory Productions film, with a cast that includes Christopher Reeve, Vanessa Redgrave, Jessica Tandy, Madeleine Potter, Nancy Marchand and Wesley Addy.

title: Washington WatchKenneth B. Noble Bank Services Under Review
description: WASHINGTON THE Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation

title: ART: HENRY MOORE SCULPTURES AT STORM KING
description: AN important chicken has come home to roost upstate at the Storm King Art Center in the form of a Henry Moore show, on view through Oct. 31. It was the British sculptor, or rather, photographs of his work on the Keswick Estate in Scotland, that prompted Storm King's previous owner, Ted Ogden, to transform these 200 acres in Mountainville, N. Y., a small town to the southwest of Newburgh, from farmland supporting a herd of Holsteins into a sculpture park.

title: ONE NUCLEAR FOE'S 'IDEOLOGICAL RIGIDITY'
description: To the Editor: It is difficult to ascertain whether Noel Perrin's essay is intended as theater, parody or simply a macabre joke. One can certainly understand the enormous frustration felt by anti- nuclear activists such as Mr. Perrin as the nuclear power industry obsti

title: Equatorial Guinea Elects a Parliament
description: The tiny West African country of Equatorial Guinea held its first parliamentary elections in more than 10 years today, but exiled opposition groups criticized the vote as a sham.

title: A STATEN ISLAND SOLUTION FIT FOR ALL OF NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Ratings
description: * Southern Corp.'s commercial paper rating has been lowered to prime-2 from prime-1 and its sinking fund debenture has been lowered to A3 from A2 by Moody's Investors Service.

title: CITY TEEN-AGERS TALKING UP A 'SAY WHAT?' STORM
description: Parks, corners, stoops. A summer in New York City is a summer on the streets for lots of teen-agers. It's too hot to go inside, there's no place else to go and they have plenty of time to talk. And the conversations of many teen-agers are filled with words and expressions that most people have never heard.

title: Ousted From a Dance, Gang Is Said to Kill 2
description: Street gang members who were ejected from a car club dance today opened fire from a moving car with several guns, killing two people and injuring seven others, the police said.

title: Bell Atlantic Selects 3: Bozell, Ketchum, Lewis
description: Bell Atlantic, one of seven regional companies to be formed as a result of the divestiture of the Bell System, named Bozell & Jacobs Inc., Ketchum Communications and Lewis, Gilman & Kynett Inc. to handle its accounts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What we have here is a beautiful experience: a conspiracy of former world leaders against present world leaders.

title: ; IF ADULTERATED HEROIN SEEPED TO USERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH POLICE JOBS ATTRACT COLLEGE GRADUATES
description: Gaynor Andrews, 21 years old, received a law degree at Oxford University in June. She now spends 18 hours a day marching, attending lectures, running races, polishing shoes and pressing the uniform that she will wear when she finishes her training for the West Midlands Police.

title: U.S. WINS MORE GOLD
description: United States speedsters ruled the track and gained six more gold medals today as the IX Pan American Games drew to a close.

title: Engineering Orders Off
description: New orders for West Germany's mechanical engineering industries showed a real decline of 15 percent in July from a year earlier, the industry's association said today. Domestic orders fell 28 percent from a year earlier and foreign orders fell 1 percent, it added.

title: OUTDOORS: LIVE BAIT OFFERS SIMPLICITY AND SUBTLETY
description: MANY who began their angling careers with a cane pole and a can of worms or a jar of crickets have nearly forgotten that fish dine on living things, not bits of fur and feathers or pieces of wood and metal.

title: Coach Withdraws Team From Field
description: With Montreal leading the Chicago Sting, 2-1, and 11:01 to play today, Coach Andy Lynch of the Manic pulled his team off the field, protesting a referee's rulings that gave Chicago three penalty-kick attempts.

title: MARCH IN CAPITAL IS SEEN SPURRING VAST COALITION
description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta said today that a coalition of environmentalists, women's rights advocates and blacks would emerge from Saturday's giant civil rights march here, and that it could help defeat President Reagan if he runs for re-election next year.

title: U.S. REMAINS QUIET ON BEGIN DECISION
description: Spokesmen for the White House and the State Department both said today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin's announcement that he intended to resign was ''an internal matter for the Israeli Government.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Squirrel Spectrum

title: Drossman Is Leaving A Della Femina Unit
description: Neil Drossman, a partner in Drossman Yustein Clowes Inc., a subsidiary of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, is leaving the agency to set up his own agency: Drossman Lehmann Marino & Reveley.

title: ISRAELI OPPOSITION M.P.'S WELCOME ANNOUNCEMENT BY BEGIN
description: Several opposition members of Parliament reacted to Prime Minister Menachem Begin's announcement today that he intended to resign by criticizing his policies and expressing the hope that he would indeed leave office.

title: Business Net Off in Japan
description: Recurrent profits of all Japanese corporations fell 6.1 percent, to 16,132 billion yen in the fiscal year 1982, which ended March 31, after a 12.8 percent decline in the fiscal year 1981 from 1980, according to the Finance Ministry.

title: MORRIS WINS 17TH, DOWNING BLUE JAYS
description: Chet Lemon's three-run homer off Joey McLaughlin with two out in the ninth inning gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-2 victory today over the Toronto Blue Jays as Jack Morris gained his ninth straight victory.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When a golf ball on a green is blocked by another ball, the one nearer to the hole is lifted and marked. Was there ever a time when the ''away'' player had to hit around the other ball?

title: FULFILLING A PROMISE ON DEREGULATION
description: C. Boyden Gray is a lean, amiably mannered 40-year- old lawyer from North Carolina whose job is to fulfill President Reagan's 1980 campaign promise to ''get the Government off the backs of the people.''

title: WCBS-TV Quits Korey for Della Femina
description: -TV said it had terminated its relationship with Korey Kay & Partners and had assigned its $3.5 million account to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: CENSUS FINDS SPURT OF RURAL GROWTH IN 70'S
description: More than a third of the homes in rural America were built between 1970 and 1980 as explosive rural growth over the decade reversed long-term trends, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: IN IRAN, HIJACKERS THREATEN THE HOSTAGES
description: Four hijackers holding an Air France jet at a Teheran airport have demanded that France cease military aid to the Governments of Chad, Iraq and Lebanon and release Lebanese prisoners from French jails, Iran's national press agency said tonight.

title: UNFAIR CABLE TV PROSPECTS
description: Acceding to pressure from cable television operators and borough politicians, New York City signed contracts on July 19 for cable TV franchises that condemn the outer boroughs to second-rate cable service until 1998. As agreed upon in negotiations between cable companies and a team of city negotiators, these systems will effectively exclude poorer residents, are less advanced technically and offer a narrower range of choices than systems in many other recently franchised cities, and award cable operators virtual monopoly control over programming.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mutual Aid on West 97th One little building remains on the Columbus Avenue site between 96th and 97th Street where work is expected to start this winter on the 11-story Park Gate Apartments. And that was vacated the other day by a center for the elderly known as Scout - Senior Citizens Outreach Unit Teams.

title: No Headline
description: Challenger Trials Stalled

title: COMMUNIST FRIENDS OF DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake in Puget Sound Area
description: A minor earthquake centered in a sparsely populated rural area near Puget Sound shook residents awake early today, but no damage or injuries were reported. The quake was centered 35 miles northwest of Seattle.

title: ONE NUCLEAR FOE'S 'IDEOLOGICAL RIGIDITY'
description: To the Editor: Noel Perrin may have been fa

title: Arnoux Captures Dutch Grand Prix
description: Rene Arnoux scored his third Formula One Grand Prix victory of the season today after leading for 31 laps following an accident that put the early leaders, Nelson Piquet and Alain Prost, out of the race.

title: CITY'S SUBURBS EMERGE FROM POLITICAL SHADOWS
description: After years in New York City's shadow, Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties have emerged as the city's rivals at the voting booth and in the halls of Congress and the State Legislature.

title: COMPUTER SYSTEMS APPLYING EXPERTISE
description: B y STEVEN J. MARCUS

title: AdvertisingPamela G. Hollie Foote, NCK and Altschiller
description: THE move by Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc. to acquire the NCK Organization Ltd., in a stock transaction later this year, should lead to a strengthening of Foote's international business.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CANNIBAL GALAXY. By Cynthia Ozick. 162 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Benefit to Fight Bans

title: No Headline
description: Manville Wins Court Ruling By The Associated Press A Federal judge has ruled

title: U.S. SAYS MARINES RETURNED FIRE AFTER START OF SHOOTING IN VICINITY
description: A spokesman for the Defense Department said today that the Pentagon had received reports that several mortar rounds had been fired over the United States Marine contingent in Lebanon and that there had been small arms fire in the area of the group.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: New York Study Blames Midwest for Acid Rain

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Vision Studies

title: 67 Arrested in Raid in Illinois On a Remote Dogfight Arena
description: The authorities in southern Illinois arrested 67 people from seven states at a remote dogfighting arena Saturday, interrupting what one official called a ''pitiful'' fight that killed two pit bull terriers.

title: BEGIN ANNOUNCES HE PLANS TO QUIT AS ISRAELI PREMIER
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin told his Cabinet today that he intended to resign.

title: News Analysis
description: The significance of the civil rights march Saturday that drew more than 200,000 to the Lincoln Memorial went far beyond a commemoration of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s vision for America two decades ago, according to a range of participants and outside observers.

title: POLAND TO RESTORE CEMETERIES
description: A group of Orthodox rabbis who recently returned from Poland have announced that they have obtained a written agreement from the Polish Government to help restore Jewish cemeteries that have been uncared for since World War II.

title: CITIZEN JOHN V. LINDSAY TURNS HIS GAZE ABROAD
description: ''You never get rid of the political bug,'' John V. Lindsay said the other day, ''but I've outgrown the need to run.''

title: Explosion of an Artillery Shell Kills 4 Hikers in Switzerland
description: An artillery shell, apparently lost during Swiss Army training exercises in the Alps, exploded today, killing a woman and three of her sons, authorities said.

title: Truck Driver Charged In Crash That Killed 4
description: A Tennessee truck driver has been charged with homicide by vehicle in a chain-reaction crash that killed four people, injured 10 others and turned the Pennsylvania Turnpike into an inferno, the state police said.

title: India Seeking to Join Key Antarctica Panel
description: The Government, after two years of discussion, has signed the Antarctica Treaty and is lobbying for membership on an influential committee that is to oversee development of the area's natural resources.

title: Dr. S. L. Helfand Wed To Dr. Sharon Inouye
description: Dr. Sharon Kiyomi Inouye, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mitsuo Inouye of Culver City, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen Lewis Helfand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Jay Helfand of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Jacob Pressman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Am in Los Angeles.

title: SOUTH KOREA'S BANKING SHIFTS
description: Banking, it is said, is the art of gauging risk, deciding whether a client has plans or dreams and then approving or denying a loan.

title: Soviet Leaders Urge Speedup in Technology
description: The Soviet leadership called today for a speedup in the development of new technology, saying that it was vital to keep up with the pace of the West.

title: Ex-Officer of D'Arcy At Margeotes/Fertitta
description: Robert S. Berman, former executive vice president, director of client services and general administrator of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York, has joined Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss Inc.

title: No Headline
description: Kill the 'Cop-Killer' Bullets ''Apple greens'' are bullets so hard that without their coating of light green Teflon they would tear up the inside of a gun's barrel when fired. That hardness permits them to penetrate the Kevlar vests credited with saving the lives of more than 400 police officers. Such penetrating bullets offer little advantage to the sportsman. Their only purpose is to kill human beings - whether policemen, presidents or popes - who wear Kevlar vests.

title: Continental Officer
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation has announced that Gail M. Melick, an executive vice president, has begun a medical leave of absence and will retire from the company by the end of the year. Mr. Melick, 55 years old, had been considered until last week a top contender to succeed Roger E. Anderson, Continental's chairman. Last Monday, however, the bank promoted David G. Taylor to vice chairman, indicating that he would become chairman when Mr. Anderson retires in 1986. Mr. Melick has been at Continental since 1952.

title: 3 Die in Tenement Fire
description: The authorities said today that arson may have been the cause of a fire that destroyed a rundown tenement building, killing three people, including an 83-year-old woman who leaped from a window.

title: No Headline
description: Steroid Use Said to Grow

title: 7 Hurt as Boat Explodes at Dock
description: A 33-foot power boat that had just refueled exploded today at a marina, injuring seven people, one of them critically, Suffolk County police said.

title: PACT SEEN IN BRAZIL LOAN TALKS
description: After months of delay, the negotiations that have held up commercial bank loans to Brazil may be at an end.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Texas Instruments Hires a Marketer

title: Sherrie Gail Levine Marries Dr. Harry Staszewski
description: Sherrie Gail Levine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Levine of Jersey City, was married yesterday to Dr. Harry Staszewski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Staszewski of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: Navy Trial Urged for Skipper In Alleged Homosexual Affair
description: A court-martial has been recommended for an officer accused of having had a homosexual affair with one of his crewmen, the Navy said Friday.

title: 2 INCHES OF RAIN DISRUPTS GROUND AND AIR TRAVEL
description: Thunderstorms dropped more than two inches of rain on the metropolitan area in a little more than an hour yesterday evening, stopping subway service on many lines and causing widespread flooding and extensive delays for weekend travelers on the ground and in the air.

title: BLATTY SUE TIMES ON BEST-SELLER LIST
description: William Blatty, author of ''The Exorcist,'' filed a $9 million suit Friday against The New York Times, claiming the newspaper has damaged sales of his new book by negligently leaving it off its best-seller list.

title: TRUCKS' RETURN TO I-95 SOUTH BRINGS COS COB SOME RELIEF
description: Two months after a section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge here collapsed, killing three people and forcing heavy vehicles to be detoured onto narrow local streets, the turnpike's southbound lanes were reopened to big trucks and buses today.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Never Too Old

title: No Headline
description: Let Connecticut Voters Vote Senator Lowell Weicker, a born agitator, has done it again and more power to him. The Connecticut Republican wants his state's party to open its primaries to independent voters.

title: Brig. Gen. Robert E. Hommel; Ex-Assistant Chief of Marines
description: Robert E. Hommel, a retired brigadier general and former assistant chief of staff of the Marine Corps, died of cancer Wednesday at Anne Arundel General Hospital in Annapolis, Md. He was 71 years old.

title: 20,000 IN PUERTO RICO MEET AND FORM NEW PARTY
description: About 20,000 people gathered in a baseball stadium here today to take part in the establishment of a new political party, the Puerto Rican Renewal Party.

title: F.B.I. TRAPS YOUTHS MEDDLING IN COMPUTER RACEHORSE DATA
description: A thoroughbred-listing service called in the Federal Bureau of Investigaton to trap a group of young Los Angeles computer raiders who had meddled with systems worldwide and were trying to get into the programming level of the company's computer, officials say.

title: MOTHERS FIND THE CHILDREN THEY GAVE UP
description: Twenty years ago it was common practice for unmarried pregnant women to seek refuge in homes for unwed mothers and then give their babies up for adoption. Today many of those women are searching for, and finding, the children they once surrendered.

title: RETHINK TRADE POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration recently proposed an American variant of the now famous Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry, and will likely push this proposal in mid-September. The trade functions presently spread throughout the Government would be combined in a cabinet-level Department of Trade and Commerce, permitting a more coordinated trade policy. But the organization of the department doesn't matter as much as the trade policy we pursue. And it is on this point that America badly need to reshape its thinking

title: Pakistan Police Block March Against Military Government
description: The police prevented an opposition march for democracy today, arresting two relatives of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the Prime Minister who was deposed and executed, and two others before their rally could start at Mr. Bhutto's tomb.

title: Judith Moldover Weds Bruce A. Cholst
description: Judith Ann Moldover, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Moldover of New York and Woodstock, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bruce Alan Cholst, son of Dr. and Mrs. Mortimer Cholst of New York. Rabbi Ruth Sandberg performed the ceremony at the Moldover home in Woodstock.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Boston Edison Co. has elected Stephen J. Sweeney president and Joseph P. Tyrrell and James M. Lydon excutive vice presidents.

title: Banker Quits Board Of Washington Power
description: C. Michael Berry, 63, a banker who was appointed to the executive board of the Washington Public Power Supply System by Governor John Spellman in June 1982, has resigned, citing his ''inability to get anything of importance done.''

title: No Headline
description: Time to Act on Airbags Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole has a chance to polish the Reagan Administration's tarnished image on auto safety and prevent thousands of deaths. Will she take it? A Supreme Court decision in June, ordering her to review the Administration's rejection of the ''passive restraint'' standard, offers a face-saving way to reverse policy on airbags. Mrs. Dole's failure to grab it is an ominous, if still inconclusive, sign that she is planning to fight rather than switch.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Sports World Special last Monday on the microfilming of documents from the early days of baseball gave the names of two writers incorrectly. They are John Thorn, the chairman of the 19th century committee of the Society for American Baseball Research, and Henry Chadwick, who covered baseball in the 19th century.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Soybean Problems Lift Prices
description: THERE is no better illustration of

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan I.B.M.'s Drop, MCI's Plunge
description: THROUGHOUT the past year, daily price

title: Diver Inflates 4,000 Bags To Refloat a Schooner
description: A diver who spent days stapling more than 4,000 plastic trash bags to a sunken three-masted schooner in Los Angeles Harbor began inflating the bags today in an attempt to refloat it.

title: THE KENNEDY ROCKER, STILL A FAVORITE
description: Perhaps the most famous piece of Presidential furniture is the Kennedy rocking chair.

title: 5 LEADERS EMERITUS TAKE A LOOK AT THE WORLD
description: An extraordinary gathering of former leaders, all involuntarily retired from office, assembled here this weekend to consider the state of the world and the transient quality of political power.

title: DIRECT HELP TO INDUSTRY IS DEBATED
description: Industrial policy, the increasingly vogue notion of developing Government policies to aid particular industries, drew fire from several noted economists here at a three-day symposium on industrial change and public policy.

title: People
description: * Linda P. Spikol has been elected a senior vice president of Kalish & Rice Inc., Philadelphia.

title: JULY ORDERS FOR TOOLS ROSE 19%
description: New orders for machine tools, a closely watched barometer of the nation's economic health, rose sharply in July, but shipments continued to plunge, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: Jim Walter's Founder Gives Up Chief's Title
description: James W. Walter, who founded what is now the Jim Walter Corporation in 1946 as a maker of shell homes, has relinquished the chief executive title. He remains chairman.

title: Bank Fails In Tennessee
description: State and Federal officials have closed the United Southern Bank of Clarksville, in the 11th bank failure this year in Tennessee.

title: Jail Faulted in Driving Drunk
description: Imposing mandatory jail terms for driving drunk is costly, causes overcrowding of jails and may not be the most effective deterrent, the Transportation Department said today.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Court Gesture Amid all the talk about slow and fast tennis courts, and which players should be favored on one or the other, contradictions sometimes show up. At the French Open last spring, for example, Yannick Noah beat Mats Wilander in the final. With his type of game, Noah was supposed to be better on a fast court and Wilander on a slow court, the kind they played on in Roland Garros Stadium. So the result was not according to the book.

title: CONCERT: BETTE MIDLER
description: BETTE MIDLER'S concert this weekend at Forest Hills Stadium was essentially the same show she gave last March at the Radio City Music Hall. The prices were near Broadway levels - $35 each for field seats - but there were no complaints, even from audience members who knew all the punch lines.

title: Miriam Wagenberg Is Wed
description: Miriam Wagenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Wagenberg of Teaneck, N.J., was married at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan yesterday to Ira Flatow, son of Mrs. Samuel Flatow of Franklin Square, L.I., and the late Mr. Flatow. Rabbi Stanley Fisch performed the ceremony. The bride is a manager for Globe Tanker Services Inc. in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Flatow is science correspondent for National Public Radio.

title: YANKS' MONTEFUSCO DEFEATS ANGELS, 7-3
description: John Montefusco had a successful Yankee debut today, beating the Angels, 7-3, and giving the Yankees only their fourth victory by a right-handed starter this season.

title: THE HAZARDOUS LIVES OF CATS ON BROADWAY
description: Kenneth Ard tore the cartilage in his knee, has been out of the show for three weeks and will have to undergo microsurgery.

title: GIANTS ROUT SWAN AND THE METS, 7-2
description: Craig Swan went to the mound yesterday hoping to salvage something from a poor season, but he lasted only into the second inning as the Mets lost to the Giants, 7-2, at Shea Stadium.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: JAZZ ON FILM Jazz on film does not bulk large in comparison with other subjects that have found their way into movies, but a heavy order is being served up today through Labor Day in the Agee room of the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street, near La Guardia Place (674-2560). There are 28 films in this Jazz Film Series, which is part of the Greenwich Village Jazz Festival, and they will take you through the history of the art from Duke Ellington to today, with evenings dedicated to blues, to tap dancing, to avant-garde. Among them are five films being seen for the first time in New York.

title: WHAT DIRECTION IS TENNIS GOING?
description: THEY are the real free agents, individuals who have no responsibility to a team and who are relatively unburdened by the rules and self-imposed restrictions that limit the movement, cramp the style and put salary caps on the potential earnings of other professional athletes. Because of this, tennis players in general have been portrayed as mercenaries exploiting a genteel game. In fact, the handful who dominate the sport have achieved self-determination, and parity with those who underwrite tennis.

title: TO GET ELECTRICITY, NICARAGUANS GO TO THE VOLCANO
description: At the foot of myth-shrouded Momotombo, Nicaragua's most famous volcano, Sandinista leaders inaugurated the country's first geothermic electric plant today.

title: TURKISH ART TREASURES MAY COME TO U.S. IN '85
description: ANKARA, Turkey

title: HEAVY SCHEDULE FOR TAX-EXEMPTS
description: This week's financings in the Treasury market consist of the regular Monday auction of three- and six- month bills, followed by a $6 billion auction of five-year, two-month notes on Wednesday, and a $7.75 billion sale of new one-year bills on Thursday.

title: Saatchi Executive Back At Compton as Chief
description: Edward L. Wax, executive vice president of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton International, will return from London to become president and chief executive officer of Compton Advertising Inc. on Sept. 6. Mr. Wax, who joined Compton in 1962 from Wells, Rich, Greene, is expected to strengthen the management team under Robert J. Jordan, who was named chairman last January.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week. Monday

title: Indians Trade Barker to Braves
description: The Cleveland Indians have traded Len Barker, the right-handed pitcher, to the Atlanta Braves, Cleveland's manager, Pat Corrales, said today.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:An Options Trader Seizes The Opportunity He Gets

title: U.S. ENVOY STARTS LATIN TOUR
description: The United States special envoy, Richard B. Stone, arrived here today on the first stop of a Central American tour that could include his second meeting with Salvadoran opposition leaders.

title: MARINES SHOOT BACK FOR FIRST TIME IN A FIRE FIGHT NEAR BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: United States Marines fought a 90-minute battle today with militiamen thought to be Shiite Moslems, a Marine spokesman said. There were no Marine casualties.

title: No Headline
description: Estelle Faden Is Married

title: 4 Killed in Crash On Rte. 9 in Jersey
description: Four people were killed here early today when a southbound station wagon had a tire blow out on Route 9, crossed a grass divider crashed into two oncoming vehicles, according to the police.

title: GENE MAYER WINS, BEATING GUNTHARDT
description: Gene Mayer, surging late, won the Hamlet Challenge Cup with a 6-7, 6-4, 6-0 victory today over Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland. Gunthardt won the first set on a tiebreaker, 11-9, and broke Mayer's service in the first game of the second set. But Mayer regained his form and ended the match by winning the last eight games.

title: PENN STATE-NEBRASKA THE CLASSIC OPENER
description: Finally reconciled to the Kickoff Classic, which they cannot avoid any longer, the coaches, Joe Paterno of Penn State and Tom Osborne of Nebraska, will display their 1983 teams in this new game Monday night, beginning at 9 o'clock, at Giants Stadium.

title: Texas Gets Tough Law On Transmitting Syphilis
description: As of Monday, Texans who know they have gonorrhea or syphilis and expose someone else to their disease are committing a crime, punishable by up to one year in prison and a $1,000 fine.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 29, 1983 International
description: Menachem Begin said he intended to resign as Prime Minister of Israel. Mr. Begin, who has been withdrawn and subdued for many months, stunned his Cabinet with his announcement. He agreed to postpone his formal notification to President Chaim Herzog until after he meets with members of his governing coalition today. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Administration responded to Prime Minister Begin's announcement by saying it was ''an internal matter for the Israeli Government.'' But considerable uncertainty was privately expressed by White House and State Department officials over what the announcement meant. (A6:3.)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, AUGUST 29, 1983
description: The Economy The idea of a national industrial policy, the notion of developing Government policies to aid particular industries, drew fire from economists, including two Nobel Memorial Prize winners, at a symposium on industrial changes and public policy. Many economists said the cure for the nation's ills lies instead in a more accommodative monetary policy and a tighter fiscal policy. (Page D1.)

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: As August draws to a close, all is quiet on Capitol Hill and at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, except for the buzz and chatter of the hardy summer visitors who wait in patient queues for guided tours. President Reagan is expected back in Washington Sept. 5.

title: TOLOMEO, 38-1, TAKES ARLINGTON MILLION
description: John Henry proved today that even at the age of 8 he is the best American grass horse in training, but the rugged gelding fell inches short of proving his superiority on a global scale.

title: Yacht Burgers
description: The recent elimination of the yacht Defender from the America's Cup trials off Newport, R.I., came as no surprise to Joel Richards. Mr. Richards is the 23-year-old grillman at Gary's Handy Lunch, a luncheonette off the beaten tourist path that is a favorite hangout for the 12-Meter crews.

title: Environmentalists Fly Balloon to East Germany
description: Two men from the Greenpeace environmentalist group flew into East Germany in a hot-air balloon today and were later returned to West Berlin.

title: U.S. SHIFT ON SHIP AID CITED
description: Maritime subsidies, used for 47 years to help United States shippers compete internationally, are largely being abandoned by the Reagan Administration, a policy that many industry officials say is costing American jobs and could threaten commercial shipbuilding in this country.

title: JETS WILL LIMP INTO OPENER
description: Perhaps things are not as bad as they seem for the New York Jets.

title: PLAYOFF TO PAT BRADLEY
description: Pat Bradley sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a playoff today to defeat Beth Daniel and win the Columbia Savings L.P.G.A. Classic.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: International Flavors

title: OSHA'S WAY TO PROMOTE WORKER SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: JO DURIE CAPTURES JERSEY TENNIS FINAL
description: Jo Durie of England defeated Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, 2-6, 7-5, 6-4, in the final of the Virginia Slims of New Jersey tennis tournament today for her first victory in a major tournament in her seven-year career as a professional.

title: KIDNAPPED GIRL AND AGCA IN POPE'S PRAYERS
description: Pope John Paul II prayed publicly today for a Vatican employee's 15-year-old daughter, who has been missing for two months, and for the Turkish gunman who shot and gravely wounded him more than two years ago.

title: Ford Motor Marketing
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to sell two foreign-made cars in the United States, beginning a year from now, according to Advertising Age magazine.

title: Young Girl Is Injured InFallOntoParkway
description: A young girl suffered head injuries and a broken hip yesterday afternoon when a woman apparently threw her from a 22-foot-high retaining wall onto the Henry Hudson Parkway in Manhattan, the police said.

title: RACE FOR EXCHANGE'S TOP JOB The 22-member board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange is starting to consider a replacement for William M. Batten, the exchange's 74- year-old chairman and chief executive whose contract expires next May.
description: Many people on Wall Street regard John J. Phelan Jr., the president and No. 2 man at the exchange, as a strong contender. But few are ready to say the race is over.

title: JUDGE IN BRINK'S KILLINGS: DAVID SMITH RITTER
description: Midway through jury selection last month in the Brink's robbery and triple murder trial here, Judith Clark, one of three defendants, rose to question a prospective juror. He was a retired dairy farmer with a seventh- grade education, about 65 years old, with small, intense eyes, no teeth and a weathered face.

title: TELEPHONE WORKERS BEGIN RETURNING FROM STRIKE
description: More than 500,000 striking telephone workers began returning to work today after the last two local phone unions and American Telephone and Telegraph Company affiliates reached tentative settlements early this morning.

title: FIERCE COMPETITION TO QUALIFY FOR OPEN
description: Huge purses and cheering crowds were not the motivation for the 192 tennis players competing at the National Tennis Center in Queens this weekend. Rather, it was the opportunity to play in the main draw of the United States Open that inspired the three rounds of fierce play, with 16 men and 8 women advancing into tomorrow's first round.

title: Ethiopian Guerrillas Free Swiss Hostages
description: Ten Swiss citizens who were held for nearly a month by Ethiopian guerrillas have been released, a rebel spokesman said Sunday.

title: MAREE SETS WORLD RECORD
description: Sydney Maree, who was born in South Africa and now lives in the United States, set a world record of 3 minutes 1,500-meter run today, beating the mark of 3:31.36 set by Steve Ovett in 1980.

title: PRIVATE COMPUTERS' INCOME DATA TO AID I.R.S. IN HUNT FOR EVADERS
description: The Internal Revenue Service is about to test whether computerized information about the life styles of American families can be used to identify individuals who fail to pay their income tax.

title: BRAVES AND DODGERS KEEP RACES INTACT
description: The National League pennant races remained virtually status quo yesterday when the top two teams in the West, the Atlanta Braves and the Los Angeles Dodgers, defeated the top two teams in the East, respectively, the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: FLOODS, FIRE AND 'THE BUBBLE ECONOMY'
description: Only two years ago, the sleek glass and steel skyscrapers crowding Denver's skyline were seen as symbols of the boom in energy exploration all across the Rocky Mountain region.

title: Vault and Rings To East German
description: Jens Fischer of East Germany was the only double winner, and Peter Vidmar of the United States captured four medals, including a gold, to highlight the men's individual finals today at the McDonald's international gymnastics championship.

title: BRIEFING
description: Fight Over Charity

title: MUSIC AND DANCE STAR IN FILM MAKER'S SHORT
description: It was one of those extravagant Manhattan evenings: a starry sky with light-dappled skyscrapers reaching up to it, a wide esplanade looking out over the Hudson River and two young lovers dancing on into the night. ''That was good,'' a voice called to the two as they sidled out of a clinch at the end of their dance, ''but just not great. Can we do it again?''

title: WHEN PRICES REACH AN ARTIFICIAL LOW
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers , twilight-night doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, 5:35 P.M. The Mets' second doubleheader in two days against the surging Dodgers pits Ed Lynch against Alejandro Pena, and Scott Holman against Pat Zachry, a former Met who has four victories and no losses this season.

title: Some Markets Closed
description: Stock, financial and commodity markets were closed for holidays yesterday in London and Hong Kong. As a result, tables for those markets do not appear in today's paper.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Buckhorn Inc., Columbus, Ohio, has appointed Roger W. Roth executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: LEISURE GROU INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $40,000 for the quarter and income of $50,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $30,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: ON BASE The art of baseball is not only the specialty of the stadium and the sandlot, it is also available in New York at a 57th Street art gallery, one in which sports often have an honored place on the wall.

title: SALVADORAN FOLLIES
description: '' 'To a civilian it may sound strange,' a United States adviser said, 'but one encouraging sign is that second lieutenants are starting to die out there. That means they are making mistakes, and their own mistakes are killing them, but they are leading the men and being aggressive.' ''

title: MASSEY CUTS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., citing the benefits of an aggressive cost-cutting program, said today that its loss for the second quarter narrowed to $11.3 million from $87 million a year earlier.

title: THE SAGA OF A $100,000 BEARER BOND LEFT IN A COPYING MACHINE
description: A 70- year-old retired man lost most of his life's savings when he copied his $100,000 United States Treasury bearer bond and left the original in the copying machine. He got the bond back today, and he was happy to pay a $25,000 reward.

title: Tass Reports on 'Shootout'
description: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that the United States Marines ''have turned to direct armed interference'' in Lebanon. It reported that marines had taken part ''in a shootout'' that flared up Sunday at the Beirut airport and said this ''convincingly shows'' that the United States ''is seeking to extract maximum profit from the Israeli invasion'' of Lebanon.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Alaska Housing Bonds Get Top Yield of 10 3/8%

title: 2 COSTA RICANS KILLED THIS MONTH FIGHTING BESIDE SANDINISTA TROOPS
description: The Sandinista Government announced today that two Costa Ricans were killed this month while fighting alongside Sandinista troops.

title: FAR FROM THE CLASSIC PUMP
description: High heels, low heels, round toes, pointed toes. Shoes to walk in, dance in or run in. This fall's shopper is faced with an extraordinary choice in shapes, materials, colors and adornment. A woman can no longer get along with basic pumps in different colors. Shoes have become the most important accessory, and are chosen not just for color or heel height, but also for the special mood of the clothes they're worn with. Shoes are to the present generation what hats were to their mothers in the 50's.

title: Italian Inflation Rate
description: Italian consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August after a 1 percent rise in July, the National Statistics Institute said today.

title: MARCOS'S DENIAL: SKEPTICISM PERSISTS
description: NewsAnalysis

title: Reynolds Metals
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would permanently close its Macauley can plant in Woodbridge, N.J. It cited overcapacity in markets served by the plant and high production costs for the move. The plant was built by Reynolds in 1966 and has a work force of about 265. Reynolds, based in Richmond, said it will begin scaling down the Macauley plant operation in October.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Rates Mixed in Light Trading
description: Short-term interest rates were mostly unchanged to slightly lower yesterday, while long-term rates rose modestly. Credit market participants said trading activity was light and might remain so until after the Labor Day weekend.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
AdvertisingN. R. Kleinfield Computers Take Aim At Schools
description: NEXT week, as children trudge back to school, a little-known British computer company will begin its push to get its own product enrolled in America's classrooms.

title: TRADE DEFICIT IN JULY WAS 3D WORST
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit expanded to $6.36 billion in July, the third-worst monthly deficit on record, the Commerce Department said today. The nation's growing economy, with an increased demand for imported goods, was cited as a major reason for the expansion.

title: NETWORKS PREPARING FOR BATTLE OF NEWS ANCHORS
description: The new battle among the three networks for the evening news audience will begin in earnest on Monday night when ABC and NBC join CBS with single-anchor formats. But already an opening shot has been fired.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Bridge:Pavlicek's Team Lost Bid For Third Great Victory Bridge:Pavlicek's Team Lost Its Bid To Win Third Great Victory
description: A unusual triple victory was in prospect at the recent Summer Nationals in New Orleans, but proved to be not in the cards. The East Coast foursome of Richard Pavlicek of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Bill Root of Boca Raton, Fla.; Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay of Narberth, Pa., had already won the Reisinger Teams last December and the Vanderbilt Teams in March.

title: TORY WINS KEY CANADA VOTE
description: Brian Mulroney, who hopes to become Canada's next Prime Minister, won a decisive victory in a parliamentary by-election today.

title: BUTTERFIELD EQUITIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
AUTO MAKERS FEAR BIG FINES IF FUEL ECONOMY RULES AREN'T CHANGED
description: The country's two largest automobile companies are now almost certain that only relaxation of Federal fuel economy regulations can save them from heavy fines, according to officials of the companies.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: AFTER what seems like years of

title: ODOMS, FERGUSON CUT BY N.F.L. TEAMS
description: Riley Odoms, Vagas Ferguson, Louie Kelcher and Russ Washington were among the veterans let go as each of the National Football League's 28 teams cut its roster to the regular-season limit of 49 players by yesterday's deadline.

title: Ovett Unperturbed
description: Steve Ovett , the English middle- distance runner, said he would decide later whether he would try to regain the world 1,500-meter record from Sydney Maree , a native of South Africa who resides in the United States. Maree was clocked in 3 minutes 31.24 seconds in Cologne, West Germany, Sunday and lopped 12-hundredths of a second off Ovett's world mark. Competing in the 1,600-meter relay in an international meet in London yesterday, Ovett said about Maree's record: ''I must admit, I'm not losing any sleep over it.''

title: 'PRECURSORS OF LIFE' FOUND IN METEORITE
description: An expert on the origins of life reported today that his laboratory had found all five of the chemical bases of human genes in a meteorite and had synthesized all five in a single laboratory experiment designed to show how they might have been formed in the primitive conditions on Earth billions of years ago.

title: THEATER: ORSON BEAN IN 'JEKYLL AND HYDE'
description: IN his analysis of ''The Strange

title: CARLSBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $259,000 for the quarter and $672,000 for the year.

title: GULF AND KAISER FORM A PARTNERSHIP
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that they had agreed to form a specialty chemicals partnership.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Phillies 8, Padres 6 Padres 6, Phillies 5
description: Mike Schmidt's two homers and Ozzie Virgil's three-run double helped Philadelphia gain a split of the doubleheader. In the first game, Sixto Lezcano's tripled broke a 3-3 tie for San Diego, and Luis Salazar hit a two-run homer in the eighth off Steve Carlton (12-14), who failed for the third straight time to gain his 298th career victory.

title: SCOUTING
description: Steeler Secrets

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $861,340 for the quarter and $1,312,855 for the 9 months.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions

title: State Told to Explain Plans to Add Prisons
description: Representatives of groups opposed to expanding New York's prisons have won a round in court in their challenge to plans to build more cells.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FOX-STANLEY PHOTO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Results for the latest first quarter include a gain on the sale of certain operations equal to 68 cents a share.

title: Charlotte Curtis The Kissinger Aura
description: -selling portrayal of Henry Kissinger as devious and power-hungry was this summer's literary furor. That thousands have bought the book but few seem to have read it is beside the point. Nearly everybody is still talking about it.

title: Digital Equipment
description: -The Digital Equipment Corporation's president said the minicomputer manufacturer would continue to build products for business and not for the consumer market. Kenneth Olsen, the president, told industry analysts that the company's goal is to produce the highest-quality products for the most critical customer and most critical applications. He said the company, which is experiencing declining profits, had no plans to enter the consumer market.

title: PAY-FONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PIZZA ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Including a gain of $242,402 from the sale of a store.

title: Foodarama Stock
description: Foodarama Supermarkets Inc. said Interstate Partnerships, a New Jersey partnership, had acquired 71,300 shares, or 5.3 percent, of Foodarama's stock.

title: OPIATE BLOCKER MAY HELP MEMORY
description: LABORATORY rats given opiate drugs are likely to forget events they experienced just before receiving the drugs. Many studies have demonstrated this in the last few years as well as the obvious corollary: Opiate antagonists - chemicals that block or reduce the effects of opiates - seem to give the animals better ability to remember.

title: MARINES IN BIERUT EQUIPPED FOR DEFENSE, NOT RETALIATION
description: Military Analysis

title: A LOCK FOR PANDORA
description: The Soviet leader, Yuri Andropov, has been pushing arms control lately. There are some encouraging signs. The American public needs to watch closely to be sure opportunities are not missed.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
FREDA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
MINNELLI STAGE MUSICAL
description: Liza Minnelli has signed a contract to star in ''The Rink,'' a new musical by the songwriting team of John Kander and Fred Ebb. ''The Rink,'' which will also star Chita Rivera, will begin a six-week workshop next Tuesday. Jules Fisher, the producer, said he hoped to bring the musical to Broadway this season, but that he planned to present it first at an Off Broadway theater.

title: West Virginia's Revenue Issue
description: A $40 million issue of West Virginia Housing Development Fund revenue bonds, rated A-1/Ax, was tentatively priced by a Goldman, Sachs & Company group with a maximum yield of 10 5/8 percent for bonds due in 2006.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PLAYERSMalcolm Moran; Broncos' Other Quarterback
description: Two days after he had first heard

title: Plungerom
description: A 21-year-old mother who apparently threw her child from a 30-foot-high retaining wall onto the Henry Hudson Parkway on Sunday plunged to her death yesterday from the roof of an apartment building in Greenwich Village.

title: VOYAGER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings were adjusted for a 6 percent stock dividend paid earlier this year.

title: Moi Re-Elected in Kenya
description: A second five-year term for President Daniel arap Moi was assured today when no candidates opposed him in a Parliamentary election in his home constituency. Mr. Moi, who survived an attempted coup last year, had been nominated as the candidate of the Kenya African National Union last week and his re-election as President was assured after he won the seat in the National Assembly.

title: SIKH PROTESTERS BREAK INTO OFFICES TO TRY TO SHUT GOVERNMENT DOWN
description: Thousands of Sikh protesters brandishing spears and swords attacked government offices and fought with policemen today in the northern state of Punjab. The violence came during daylong demonstrations called in an effort to prevent the state government from functioning.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 30, 1983 International
description: Two American marines were killed and 14 were wounded as savage fighting between the Lebanese Army and Moslem militiamen turned Beirut into an arena of exploding shells, machine-gun fire and snipers' bullets. The Lebanese Army met stiff resistance as it sought to gain control of Shiite Moslem neighborhoods in South Beirut. (Page A1, Column 6.) No change in the U.S. peace mission in Lebanon is called for, according to a Cabinet-level panel headed by Vice President Bush. The panel also told President Reagan, who is on vacation in California, that there was no need to increase the size of the 1,200-marine peacekeeping group. (A8:1.)

title: FILIPINOS THRONG TO CORTEGE FOR AQUINO
description: Hundreds of thousands of people lined roads today to show sympathy for Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader, as a motorcade carrying his coffin crept the 80 miles from his home province of Tarlac to Manila, where he will be buried on Wednesday.

title: SCOUTING
description: Double Take

title: TURBULANT TIMES IN FACTORING
description: For a staid, button-down industry largely unknown to the general public, the factoring business, primary banker to the garment and textile industries, has had its share of dramatic moments in recent years.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $48,000 for the quarter $216,000 for the year. The share earnings in year-ago periods reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 5.

title: VOICE OF THE VOICELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING
description: Arts Agency Accounts

title: NEW SMALL COMPUTER, SANS SCREEN
description: THE boom in portable computers sold packaged with a ton of software - launched by Adam Osborne in 1981, is taking on an explosive quality. Hardly a week goes by without some company, new or old (old companies are those founded a year or more ago), announcing its entry into this catchy market.

title: A 'MEDICAL CALUMNY' DIRECTED AGAINST HAITIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOSHEN JUDGE ALLOWS TESTIMONY FROM DEFENDANT IN FEDERAL TRIAL
description: The judge in the Brink's case being prosecuted by the state ruled today that a suspect in the $1.6 million robbery and triple murder could testify as a witness for three defendants.

title: U.N. Opens Conference On Palestinian Rights
description: Boycotted by the United States, Canada and Israel and downgraded by many Western countries, a United Nations conference on Palestinian rights opened here today under tight Swiss Government security.

title: Books: Saving a Few
description: HAVEN. The Unknown Story of 1,000 World War II Refugees. By Ruth Gruber. 335 pages. Coward-McCann. $15.95.

title: MX PANEL URGED TO ALTER ARMS TREATY PLAN
description: Representative Les Aspin urged the President's Commission on Strategic Forces today to put forward a new, ''bipartisan'' and more flexible proposal for a treaty to reduce intercontinental nuclear weapons.

title: RAVITCH ERA: DEBATE AND INNOVATION
description: Richard Ravitch's four-year tenure as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was marked by contention and controversy, as well as by independence and innovation.

title: TREATY THAT GRANTED AMERICA ITS FREEDOM BROUGHT TO NEW YORK
description: In London four days ago, a lead seal was put on a custom-made case containing Foreign Office Document No. 93/8/2. The Keeper of Public Records, case firmly in hand, boarded a westbound flight. That afternoon, in a richly paneled office overlooking Fifth Avenue, the seal was broken.

title: Soccer Forfeit Ordered
description: Ted Howard, the executive director of operations for the North American Soccer League, yesterday awarded a 1-0 forfeit victory to the Chicago Sting in their game against the Montreal Manic Sunday. The Sting trailed, 2-1, late in the game when Coach Andy Lynch of Montreal pulled his team off the field in protest of a referee's decision to order a Chicago penalty kick repeated twice.

title: Barry Commoner Vows To Back Jesse Jackson
description: Barry Commoner, the environmentalist who sought the Presidency in 1980 on the Citizens Party ticket, Monday endorsed the Rev. Jesse Jackson for President in 1984 and said he hoped to encourage the black minister to run for the office.

title: No Headline
description: Dutch Banker Is Arrested

title: Fish Spill Closes I-95
description: An overturned truckload of slippery fish blocked the northbound lanes of Interstate 95 on the New Hampshire-Massachusetts border for three hours Sunday night. The police said the driver was gone when they arrived late Sunday to find the truck, registered to a company in Nova Scotia, on its side with its haddock and halibut spilled. The lanes were reopened early today.

title: JUNKYARDS POLISH THEIR RUSTY IMAGE
description: Sealed in plastic, clearly labeled and laid out in neat rows along the rack, they are reminiscent of a display of vegetables in a supermarket.

title: CBS'S PAN AM BALANCING ACT
description: It is with some irony that CBS held

title: Telegram Promising Return Is Disclaimed by Mrs. Peron
description: Isabel Martinez de Peron, former President of Argentina, has disclaimed a telegram attributed to her that announced that she would return to Argentina this week, informants close to her said today.

title: RACE STRUGGLE CITED IN BRINK'S TRIAL
description: A defendant told the jury in the Federal Brink's trial yesterday that he was ''a soldier of the Black Liberation Army.''

title: JUDGE SELECTION FOR NEW YORK'S HIGH COURT: THE SYSTEM WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: FUEL PLANT CRITICIZED ON OUTLOOK
description: The General Accounting Office today reported that owners of the nation's first major synthetic fuels plant are understating their financial position.

title: NEBRASKA ROUTS PENN ST.
description: Penn State, the top-ranked team in college football last year, is no longer No. 1. The Nittany Lions were trounced tonight, 44-6, by Nebraska, the team most often mentioned as the potential successor to the No. 1 ranking for 1983.

title: Andropov Seeks Support Of Italy on Arms Offer
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi received a letter today from Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, seeking Italy's support for the latest Soviet offer to limit intermediate-range missiles in Europe.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Blackout Loans

title: No Headline
description: An I.O.U. for Mr. Ravitch For most New Yorkers, transit has come to mean trouble: stuck doors, or stuck trains, or the smell, or the strikes. To one New Yorker, transit has meant more trouble than anyone else. He is Richard Ravitch, who yesterday announced he was quitting after four years as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. They don't know it yet, but all those transit-troubled New Yorkers owe him heartfelt thanks.

title: Joffrey at City Center Oct. 18 to Nov. 1 3
description: The Joffrey Ballet will celebrate its 30th season at the City Center with a four-week season, from Oct. 18 through Nov. 13.

description: Jose Bergamin Gutierrez;Spanish Writer, Dies at 87

title: SATELLITE TECHNOLOGY WILL BEAM TV TO REMOTE REGIONS
description: DESPITE concern over a growing ''traffic jam'' in earth orbit, it has now become possible to allocate more than 1,800 television channels for direct broadcast to nations in the Western Hemisphere without having to worry about serious interference among them.

title: ARIAS SET FOR OPEN
description: Now that Jimmy Arias is ranked ninth on the international tennis computer, a career high, he is learning what life is really like at the top.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $449,010 for the latest 9 months and $20,149 for the year-ago period.

title: Tank Thief Stopped By Tear-Gas Attack
description: A 36-year-old transient stole a tank retriever from a National Guard armory and was on his way to visit relatives in Minnesota before he was flushed out by tear gas, nine miles into his trip, officials said today.

title: SCOUTING
description: Weighty Problem

title: Chinese-American Named for Bench
description: The city's first Chinese-American candidate for a judgeship was proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

description: Alumax Inc., San Mateo, Calif., said it had completed its plan to acquire the United States aluminum operations of Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann of Paris.

title: Jules N. Bloch Is Dead at 64; PartnerinNewYorkLawFirm
description: Jules N. Bloch, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Bondy & Schloss, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Eastchester, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: ; 'TOO FEW HOSPITALS FOR THE DOCTORS TO PUT THE PATIENTS IN'
description: To the Editor:

title: SIGMAFORM CORP.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PORT AUTHORITY PROGRAM MAY HURT THE CITY
description: There is an effort afoot in Albany to change the focus of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from port and transportation projects to commercial real estate development. Some have raised the fundamental philosophical question of whether the Port Authority should be in the real estate business at all, and whether public funds should be diverted from vital harbor, rail and mass-transit projects into office development, which the private sector seems to do pretty well.

title: HUNDREDS OF CONVICTS RIOT AT PRISON IN OKLAHOMA
description: Hundreds of inmates armed with knives and makeshift weapons rioted at an overcrowded prison tonight, ''going wild'' and setting fire to at least five buildings, the authorities said.

title: OPERA ORCHESTRA'S 32-TO-21 VOTE ENDS STRIKE
description: Members of the New York City Opera orchestra ratified a new, three- year contract yesterday. The vote, which followed what was reported to be an impassioned, sometimes angry discusssion, was 32 to 21.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: s

title: THE ISLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: RICE CLOUTS 3 TO GAIN A SPLIT
description: Jim Rice hit his third two-run homer of the game in the ninth inning tonight to give the Boston Red Sox an 8-7 victory over the Blue Jays in the second game of a doubleheader.

title: BEER DISTRIBUTORS SEEK ANTITRUST EXEMPTION
description: Opposition is mounting to a campaign by beer distributors for an antitrust exemption that would permit exclusive distribution rights in a territory.

title: Talking Businesswith Guffey of Kansas City Fed Western View Of Recession
description: When talk turns to recession, what comes to mind are the misfortunes of Detroit and other industrial cities, not of the Great Plains and Rocky Mountains. But the economic devastation of the last few years has reached that area, too, particularly in energy and farming.

title: Savings Units Gained in July
description: Savers deposited nearly $4 billion more in savings and loan associations in July than they withdrew, more than twice the net gain in June, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Rebels Attack Ethiopian Jail
description: Guerrillas of the Western Somalia Liberation Front, which has been fighting Ethiopian control of the Ogaden region for years, said they freed 198 prisoners in a recent attack against Jijiga prison. A spokesman for the guerrilla group, which is supported by Somalia, said 14 of the freed men were captured guerrillas.

title: China-Japan Oil Project
description: a Chinese-Japanese joint venture is close to starting commercial development of an offshore oilfield, the New China News Agency said today.

description: MINNEAPOLISPeople commonly start eating when

title: A GARDEN DEDICATED TO FRIENDSHIP
description: The view from the White House balcony over the Mall and out to the Jefferson Memorial is said to be one of many reasons that he who occupies the White House seldom leaves voluntarily.

description: Debt Issues

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 17, 1983.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Atlanta Fed Leader To 1st Nationwide

title: More Floods ExpectedFor Colorado River
description: Flooding is expected to continue along the lower Colorado River through January, officials of seven Western states were told today.

title: Reynolds Metals Backs 7 1/2% Issue
description: A $42.23 million issue of 7 1/2 percent pollution control revenue bonds of the Reynolds Metals Company was tentatively priced at 100 by an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

description: GENETICALLY engineered bacteria may be released into the environment soon for the first time in a controlled experiment outside the laboratory.
