title: VIETNAM MEMORIAL: TOUCHING, TEARS, ROSES, RAIN
description: Even now, nine months after it opened amid controversy over its design, the Vietnam Memorial is still the most emotional spot of ground in Washington.

title: 3 BROKERAGES CONSENT TO S.E.C. CENSURE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., Advest Inc. and McDonald & Company for failing to properly supervise three former employees who the agency says engaged in a scheme to misappropriate $2.3 million from their firms.

title: RUFUS A. ROBBINS
description: Rufus A. Robbins, president of Robbins Inc., a candy manufacturers' representative, died of cancer Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: EFFORT ON SEX-BIASED LAWS HAS LONG HISTORY
description: Last summer, as President Reagan prepared to end a White House news conference, a reporter stood up and demanded that he make public a report that ''shows the discrimination that actually exists on the books in Federal agencies and departments against women.''

title: ZUMWALT HEADS CLINIC DEVELOPER AGAIN
description: Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the retired Chief of Naval Operations, yesterday was named chairman and president of American Medical Buildings Inc., replacing its founder.

title: No Headline
description: F. J. (Steve) O'Neill,Owner of the Indians

description: ''The Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Treaty of Paris are our three Magna Cartas.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Many Voices on the Mall
description: Unlike the unified outpouring of civil rights and religious groups that carpeted the Mall in 1963, the people who marched in Washington Saturday represented a multitude of different organizations, causes and passions.

title: MILSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,159,000 due to reorganizational transactions effective May 1. c-Including a gain of $140,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SALVADOR AND REBEL OFFICIALS MEET IN BOGOTA FOR FIRST TALKS ON WAR
description: For the first time in the three-year-old civil war, Salvadoran Government officials met today with members of the Salvadoran left. The five-and-a-half- hour meeting took place this morning in Bogota, Colombia, according to a United States official there.

title: No Headline
description: Aware that he was the subject of a sculptor, Casey Stengel could not resist a few pirouettes on the Shea Stadium grass many years ago. The fans saw him dancing on the field before a game and encouraged him to even greater feats of footwork, the sculptor, Rhoda Sherbell, recalled yesterday.

description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

description: b-Net income.

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S., DROP PINOCHET
description: After 10 years, Chileans are demonstrating determination to get rid of their dictatorship. The United States, which played a role in destroying Chile's 142-year-old democracy and bringing military rule in 1973, cannot afford to be identified with the discredited regime's last brutal efforts to cling to power. Washington should clearly indicate it supports the broad-based, left-to-right opposition that has taken to the streets in monthly nonviolent protests since May to call for Gen. Augusto Pinochet's resignation and demand a return to democracy.

title: BODIES OF 2 BOYS FOUND IN JERSEY AFTER BIG STORM
description: The bodies of two teen-age boys from Passaic, N.J., were recovered by search parties along the Passaic River yesterday, apparent drowning victims of the thunderstorms that drenched the New York metropolitan area Sunday night.

title: NOT SINCE 30'S HAS BRITISH COLUMBIA BEEN SO RILED
description: Flush with an election victory, the government of this Pacific Coast province is proposing a barrage of actions whose cumulative effect is far more radical than anything Canada has ever experienced.

title: VETERAN WHO SAID HE KILLED DAUGHTER OVERSEAS IS ARRESTED
description: A man who told the police he had killed his 17-month-old daughter in a rage while stationed in West Germany and said he feared he might kill his baby boy was arrested today at a veterans' hospital by Federal agents.

title: TOP 2 EXECUTIVE POSTS ARE REALIGNED AT BATUS
description: Henry F. Frigon, executive vice president and chief financial and administrative officer of Batus Inc., was named president, effective Sept. 1. He succeeds Charles I. McCarty, 53, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: STATE UNIVERSITY GAINS NEW PRESTIGE
description: THE arrival of a new freshman class this week on the campuses of the State University of New York is an occasion for self-examination at the institution, which is celebrating its 35th anniversary.

title: Literacy Test Delays 1,200 Florida Diplomas
description: More than 400 members of Florida's class of 1983 have passed a literacy test and will receive high school diplomas, a state official said today.

title: ASSOCIATES URGE BEGIN TO FORGO PLAN TO RESIGN
description: Leaders of all the parties and factions of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's governing coalition met with him for two hours today in a carefully orchestrated effort to persuade him to abandon his plan to resign.

description: Update: A Happy Ending

title: No Headline
description: Death Perfumed New Jersey, which stopped electrocuting people in 1972, recently revived the death penalty, this time by lethal injection. Now the state is ready to start executing people again, a corrections official says, ''scientifically, with precision.''

description: b-Including a pretax gain of $1,603,000 on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $183,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DODGERS SWEEP METS AND TAKE FIRST
description: The Dodgers took over first place in the National League West last night with a 6-1, 7-3 sweep of the Mets before a crowd of 22,452 at Shea Stadium.

title: No Headline
description: Valor Without Glamor in Lebanon The Marines are no longer keeping the peace in Lebanon, only preventing a worse war and at a higher price. Caught in the crossfire of factional armies that have kept Lebanon ungovernable for a decade, the Marines are taking casualties for only a dim diplomatic vision: that forming a coalition of Lebanese tribes is preferable to partitioning the country.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO ORANGES?
description: TBone Schwartz's mother, Belle,

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Fairchild to Shut Plant
description: Fairchild Industries said today that a subcontract for work on the Boeing 757 aircraft had been terminated, and that as a result it would be forced to close its plant in Hagerstown and lay off 600 workers. A Boeing spokesman in Seattle said Boeing would produce the aircraft parts previously subcontracted to Fairchild, thereby saving at least 200 jobs at its own plants.

title: NEW HOMES' JULY SALES OFF 6.5% AMID RATE RISE
description: Sales of new single-family houses fell 6.5 percent last month, in the first monthly decline since February, the Government said today.

title: STANDING OVER THE APTITUDE TESTS
description: ''WE love prestige and money, but don't seem to care much about integrity.'' So commented a high school teacher in suburban New York on widespread cheating by students on Scholastic Aptitude and Achievement tests.

title: Nominee for C.A.B.
description: Barbara E. McConnell, executive assistant to the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, has been nominated to fill the vacancy on the five- member agency that was left by the resignation of Elizabeth Daley.

title: FROM SANTA BARBARA, SHOCK, GRIEF AND BLAME
description: The Administration, expressing shock and grief at the deaths of two United States marines in Lebanon, today condemned those responsible for the attack. An Administration official suggested that Syria and the Soviet Union bore some blame for the incident.

title: LESCARDEN INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
SYNCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interest acquisition since January 1983.

title: ANCHOR OF CIVIL WAR IRONCLAD RECOVERED OFF CAPE HATTERAS
description: The anchor of the Monitor, the Civil War ironclad that changed the history of naval warfare before sinking in a gale more than 120 years ago, was recovered yesterday from the ocean floor off Cape Hatteras, N.C.

title: No Headline
description: Caterpillar Sees '84 Gain PEORIA, Ill. Aug. 29 (Reuters) - The Caterpillar Tractor Company expects to show a

title: Contract Ruled Void
description: The lucrative contract that made Marshall Medoff the exclusive bargaining agent and sponsor-seeker for the Boston Marathon was invalidated by a Superior Court judge in Boston. Judge Robert L. Steadman ruled in favor of the Boston Athletic Association, which had sought to void the controversial contract. The judge said that the contract with Medoff, which gave him a virtual lifetime guarantee, was beyond the powers of the former B.A.A. president, who hired him, or the association's board of governors. It returns sponsorship of the race to the B.A.A.

title: RAVITCH LEAVING M.T.A. TO RETURN TO PRIVATE SECTOR
description: Richard Ravitch, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for the last four years, announced yesterday that he would step down from the job to return to private business and ''resume a more normal life.''

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DR. WILLIAM M. HITZIG, 78, AIDED WAR VICTIMS
description: Dr. William M. Hitzig, a prominent New York physician who aided Japanese victims of the atomic bomb and Polish victims of Nazi medical experiments, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center after a long illness caused by a stroke. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LIBERTARIAN PARTY OPENS PARLEY TO PICK 1984 SLATE
description: Without bands, banners and bunting, the unorthodox Libertarian Party quietly opened its weeklong national convention here yesterday in an unorthdox fashion, with two men debating abortion before an audience of fewer than 75 party members.

title: A NEW POLYMER PROCESS AT DUPONT
description: The Du Pont Company said yesterday that it had discovered a new process for manufacturing polymers, the molecular building blocks for plastics, paints and synthetic fibers. It said it expects to use the process in manufacturing new automotive finishes that could be brought to market within two years.

title: STUDY OF 85,000 VETERANS CALLS PESTICIDE EFFECT VAGUE
description: The Veterans Administration reported today that medical examinations and laboratory tests of 85,000 Vietnam veterans who fear they may have been exposed to Agent Orange have revealed no adverse health effects clearly related to the chemical defoliant or to its toxic contaminant, dioxin.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $2,453,000 on the loss from Japanese discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $14,371,000 from discontinued operations. Corrected from last Friday's editions.

description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $315,000 for the quarter and year.

title: LEASING-A LOOPHOLE THAT NEEDS PLUGGING
description: Anyone who has kept track of Congress's tax-policy meanderings in recent years knows that Congress has virtually abandoned the search for fairness in the tax code and instead has tried to use the code as a vehicle for behavior modification by offering ''special deals'' for certain kinds of behavior.

title: 28 People Hurt as Grenade Explodes in Pakistani Crowd
description: At least 28 people were wounded today when a hand grenade exploded in a crowd that had gathered for an anti- Government demonstration in a working-class suburb, doctors at a local hospital said.

title: NO POLICY SHIFT, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: A crisis management group agreed today that despite the deaths of two American marines in Lebanon there should be no change in the American peacekeeping role in that country, the White House said this afternoon.

title: BRUNNER IS NAMED TO START IN OPENER
description: Scott Brunner, the people's choice, turned out to be the favorite of Coach Bill Parcells as well. The quarterback in the only National Football League playoff game the Giants have won since 1958 was named today the starter for Sunday's opener here against the Los Angeles Rams.

title: UNITED STATES CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of 8 cents a share.

title: Wang Acquires 4.3% of Tymshare
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said it had acquired 530,800 shares, or 4.3 percent, of Tymshare Inc. in the open market at an average price of about $18 a share.

description: Q.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including extraordinary gains of $58,600 for the quarter and $143,600 for the 6 months and a gain of $118,000 for the 6 months from a change in accounting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, AUGUST 30, 1983
description: International Massey-Ferguson narrowed its loss to $11.3 million in the second quarter from $87 million a year ago, the company reported in Toronto. The improvement was attributed to a variety of cost-cutting measures by the company in the face of a continuing recession in the farm equipment market. Sales for the quarter were $401.1 million, compared to $518.2 million the year before. (Page D1.) The merchandise trade deficit widened to $6.36 billion in July, the third worst such deficit on record, the Commerce Department reported. Officials cited the increased need for imported goods generated by the expanding economy. A record $17.6 billion was spent for imported goods other than oil during the month. (D5.)

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: Goldome to Offer Stock
description: Goldome Bank for Savings said today that it plans to convert from a mutual organization owned by its depositors to a public stock company which will be owned by shareholders. Goldome's chairman, Ross B. Kenzie, said he could not immediately estimate how much capital could be raised or how many shares would be offered for sale. Goldome is the sixth-largest thrift institution in the nation.

title: TALKS HELD ON BALDWIN ANNUITIES
description: Arkansas and Indiana officials met yesterday in New York and Atlanta with insurance regulators from several states to discuss possible changes in the terms of annuities sold by subsidiaries of the Baldwin-United Corporation.

title: OLYMPIC LESSONS IN PAN AM GAMES
description: The IX Pan American Games ended tonight with colorful closing ceremonies and lessons for almost everyone.

title: Miss Navratilova Sued
description: On the eve of the United States Open tennis tournament, Martina Navratilova , the favorite, is facing a $2 million damage suit, based on a claim that she assaulted a photographer at last year's tournament and took his camera.

title: Stocks Mixed; Trading at 1983 Low
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in the slowest trading this year, as concern over the direction of interest rates continued to keep investors from making commitments.

title: West German Inflation
description: The West German cost of living index rose by three- tenths of 1 percent from mid-July to mid-August, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The index had risen by four-tenths of 1 percent in the previous monthly period.

title: MGM President Quits; Position to Stay Vacant
description: Joseph A. Fischer, named president of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company 14 months ago, said yesterday he was resigning to pursue unspecified personal interests. The announcement came only two days after Donald Sipes, chairman of MGM/ UA's United Artists subsidiary, announced his intention to step down.

title: WHISTLER'S MOTHER TO VISIT THE U.S.
description: ''Whistler's Mother,'' considered the masterpiece of the influential 19th-century American painter James Abbott McNeill Whistler, will arrive back in the United States today after an 18-year absence.

title: FIRST COED CLASS ENTERS COLUMBIA COLLEGE
description: The last all-male school in the Ivy League became a coeducational one yesterday when Columbia College enrolled women for the first time in its 229-year history.

title: Nigerian Ruling Party Heads for 4th Victory
description: President Shehu Shagari's National Party appears headed for its fourth straight general election victory, posting a strong lead in early returns from Saturday's National Assembly election, the Nigerian radio reported today.

title: G.E.-Army Deal
description: The General Electric Company won an $83.2 million Army contract for 385 T-700 series gas turbine engines, the Defense Department said. The Army also awarded $25.2 million to the Martin Marietta Corporation's Martin Marietta Aluminum Inc. to operate and maintain a Government- owned, contractor-operated facility, the department said.

description: b-After net foreign currency translation losses of $1.1 million for the quarter and $8.6 million for the 6 months and a provision of $600,000 for the quarter and 6 months for reorganization costs. c-After net foreign currency translation losses of $2.4 million for the quarter and $16.6 million for the 6 months and a provision of $10 million for the quarter and 6 months for reorganization costs.

description: Excerpts from ''Congress Off the Record,'' a collection of thoughts and anecdotes of seven members of the House of Representatives published by the American Enterprise Institute and edited by John F. Bibby, professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin. The four Republicans and three Democrats, who were first elected in 1978, were granted anonymity in return for their candor.

title: ADVERTISING

title: Relief Teams Search Basque Area for Bodies
description: Relief workers continued searching for bodies today while homeowners and shopkeepers dug away at mounds of mud and debris as northern Spain slowly recovered from weekend flooding that was the worst in 30 years.

title: KEAN SIGNS A BILL REQUIRING INDUSTRY TO LABEL CHEMICALS
description: Governor Kean today signed a chemical-labeling bill that he said ''gives New Jersey the lead in addressing the challenges posed by the complicated industrial environment in which we live.''

title: Cuomo Approves Bill Providing Foster Care
description: Governor Cuomo completed the traditional bill-signing period today as he announced approval of a measure to set up a pilot foster family project for disabled adults and the elderly.

title: SAN JOSE SCHOOLS CAN CUT PAY, U.S. BANKRUPTCY COURT RULES
description: A judge today declared one of California's largest school districts bankrupt, allowing the district to nullify contracts with its teachers and other employees.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 MARINES KILLED IN LEBANON AND 14 OTHERS ARE WOUNDED AS BEIRUT FIGHTING SPREADS
description: Two American marines were killed and 14 wounded this morning as fierce fighting between the Lebanese Army and Moslem militiamen turned this city into an arena of exploding shells, machine-gun fire and snipers' bullets.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Business People column Aug. 15 incorrectly described the operations of the Bradford National Corporation. It continues to provide certain data processing services for health care claims.

description: Nu-West Group Ltd., which reported a loss of $50 million for the first six months of 1983, said directors had agreed to consider selling the company's oil and gas interests.

title: CHADIAN REBELS OFFER TO TALK
description: The Libyan-backed rebels who hold the northern third of Chad have offered to negotiate a solution of the conflict with President Hissen Habre if all French troops supporting Mr. Habre's Government are withdrawn from the country.

title: No Headline

title: COMMODITY DISCOUNTERS RISE
description: Discount brokerage services, like those that have successfully grabbed a growing chunk of business from full-service stockbrokers, are invading the frenzied commodity futures trading markets.

title: FRIENDS SAY FEMINIST HEROINE IS SINCERE IF ECCENTRIC
description: When Barbara Honegger denounced President Reagan's commitment to equal rights for women as a ''sham'' and resigned from the Justice Department last week, she became an instant heroine to some women's rights groups.

title: No Headline
description: 2 Horsemen Buy Delaware Track

title: OFFICIALS' KILLING OF DOGS STIRS DEEP FEELINGS IN SMALL TOWN
description: Three months ago, two town constables and the dog-control officer went to the house of a 71-year-old farmer here. For two days, using shotguns and handguns, the constables killed 41 dogs and 2 cats owned by the farmer, saying the animals were ''malnourished, abused and neglected.'' Some of the dogs were shot in the kitchen of the farmhouse.

title: No Headline
description: Suzuki Weighs Venture in U.S.

title: DAZZLING LIFTOFF SENDS THE SHUTTLE INTO EARTH ORBIT
description: The space shuttle Challenger is set to embark on a six-day flight in which American astronauts are to test the vehicle's ability to maneuver heavy cargoes and transmit greater volumes of scientific data.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of SportsMonday yesterday about Sydney Maree's world-record 1,500-meter run omitted some words referring to his time. It was 3 minutes 31.24 seconds.

title: First Peoples Bank Is Sought
description: The New Jersey National Corporation said it had offered $28 million in stock to buy the troubled First Peoples Bank of New Jersey. First Peoples, based in Camden, said it would meet ''promptly'' with New Jersey National to discuss the offer.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The net income for the latest quarter and 6 months includes 5 cents and 9 cents a share, respectively, as a result of reduction of certain inventory levels accounted for on the LIFO method. The year-ago net income for the quarter and 6 months includes 10 cents a share as a result of such reductions.

title: FINGERMATRIX INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-The company is in the development stage and had no sales income in fiscal 1983.

title: HIJACKING IN IRAN: NEW DEADLINE
description: Four Arabic- speaking gunmen who seized an Air France jet over Europe on Saturday let one deadline pass today and set another as they negotiated with Iranian authorities at the Teheran airport.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $1,318,566 for the quarter and $2,187,824 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $437,534.

title: Maker of Lubricating Gel Recalls 25,000 Cases
description: The manufacturer of a brand of petroleum jelly has recalled 25,000 cases of the lubricant that can irritate the skin and cause a burning sensation.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Fund's Success Spurs Growth
description: PETER LYNCH, portfolio manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund, retains his big bet on Chrysler, the fund's spectacular winner last year, and he has also been building portfolio positions in Ford and General Motors, along with certain chemical stocks. Currently, he is very keen, too, on regional banks and savings and loan associations.

title: SERVED AS ADVISER TO 3 PRESIDENTS
description: Charles S. Murphy, a close adviser and confidant of President Truman who served in key White House and sub-Cabinet level positions under three Presidents, died of a heart ailment Sunday at Anne Arundel General Hospital in Anne Arundel County, Md. He was 74 years old.

title: OCCUPATIONAL ILLS: HOW ACCURATELY DIAGNOSED?
description: AMAJOR weakness of the American health care system is the lack of sufficient attention to occupationally related diseases, though health leaders have now begun to take important steps to help improve the situation.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DINOSAUR 'EMBRYO' IS FOUND
description: Remains of a dinosaur embryo have been found in its fossilized egg at a site where abundant remains suggest at least some dinosaurs were communal.

title: BOGUS DELIVERYMAN SLAYS EAST SIDE MAN AND WOUNDS FRIEND
description: A 42-year-old man was shot to death yesterday morning in the foyer of his apartment near Sutton Place by a gunman who pretended to be delivering a package, the police said.

title: ELEANORB.u8LOWMAN
description: Eleanor Barry Lowman, a painter of flowers and other still lifes, died last Friday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: People
description: * Hilary Hendler appointed station manager of WNBC-TV.

title: CHAPIN LEAVES AS HEAD OF SUCCESS MAGAZINE
description: After nearly a decade of working with W. Clement Stone, the Chicago millionaire and contributor to the Nixon election coffers, Dwight L. Chapin, who was President Nixon's appointments secretary, will step down today as president and chief executive officer of Mr. Stone's successful Success magazine, dubbed ''the magazine for achievers.''

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: E.E.C. Talks On Economy
description: European Economic Community cabinet ministers traded opinions today on how to solve their economic bloc's financial crisis but left serious negotiations for later.

title: CYANAMID ELEVATES 3 IN RACE TO THE TOP
description: The American Cyanamid Company promoted three officers yesterday to the position of executive vice president, creating what analysts said amounts to a contest for the presidency. They will also be members of the executive committee, which runs Cyanamid, a leading industrial corporation. The appointments, effective tomorrow, will increase the company's top management team to six.

title: CONSCRIPTION FOR YOUNG NICARAGUANS
description: Faced with what it says are continuing attacks along its northern and southern borders, Nicaragua is preparing to impose compulsory military service for the first time in the nation's history.

title: AGAINST DEFICITS, I'M SURE, MAYBE
description: Those of us who believe that $200 billion Federal budget deficits represent the most serious threat to the economic recovery of this country and - through soaring interest rates - to the industrialized democracies' economies, face a formidable and stubborn counterargument: the success of the massive deficit spending in World War II that pulled us out of the Great Depression.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 9.628 percent was set at yesterday's weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.459 percent at last week's auction.

title: AGE OF PARENTS BARS AN ADOPTION IN ITALY
description: AN Italian couple who had flown from Venezuela with a baby they wished to adopt were prevented from taking the child home because they were considered too old to be adoptive parents.

title: BACKGROUNDS OF 4 ON SHUTTLE
description: Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, commander of the eighth flight of the space shuttle, will be at the controls of the spacecraft Challenger when it makes the first night shuttle landing Monday, but it will not be the first time he has landed an aircraft in darkness.

title: McDonald's Complaint
description: Coach Sam Rutigliano of the Cleveland Browns has decided on Brian Sipe as the team's No. 1 quarterback, but Paul McDonald wants to be paid like a starter if he's going to stick around after this season. McDonald, unsigned as he enters the option year of his three-year contract, had a base pay of $60,000 last year, compared with Sipe's $265,000, according to statistics from the National Football League Players Association.

title: SCOTT MAKES UP LOST GROUND
description: The Scott Paper Company's decision last week to sell three profitable assets - its foam division, its Brown Jordan furniture division and 240,000 acres of Northwest timberland - was viewed by some as mainly an attempt to frustrate Scott's major shareholder, Brascan Ltd., which has said it wants to increase its stake in Scott.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net income.

title: Shoreham Facing New State Inquiry
description: The State Public Service Commission's special task force on the Shoreham nuclear power plant project will investigate the recent discovery of defects in the plant's emergency diesel generators. The investigation was ordered today by the commission's chairman, Paul L. Gioia.

title: No Headline
description: Salaam on Injured List Abdul Salaam, the starting defensive tackle who is suffering from a

description: Artist in Residence And at Work

title: FIVE SPARROWS, ALL MALE, SING FOR A FEMALE TO SAVE SPECIES
description: Only five dusky seaside sparrows were left in the world, and all five of those were males, so the experts said the bird was ''functionally extinct.''

title: Chargers Win Appeal
description: The State Supreme Court in California overturned a lower court's decree that had granted Dennis Partee , a former punter, $133,500 in back pay and damages from the San Diego Chargers. Partee had sued because, although his contract with the Chargers extended through 1976, he was cut just before that season when he suffered an injury. The trial court upheld his suit, but the higher court sided with the Chargers' appeal, saying that pro football is like any other business that crosses state lines and is therefore exempt from California antitrust laws.

title: NEW JAPAN EXPORT: BEER IN MINIBARRELS
description: Over the years, American beer drinkers have become accustomed to three basic forms - bottled, canned or draft. But now Japan's Suntory Ltd. is introducing its draft beer in the United States, and in the process it is test-marketing a new kind of container: a plastic minibarrel.

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: U.S. to Aid Repair Of Turnpike
description: State and Federal officials signed an agreement today that will provide Federal funds for the first time to help maintain and repair the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: CHOICES FOR THE ALLIES
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: Dow Up by 1.93; Trading Still Slow
description: Stock prices finished slightly higher yesterday in continued slow trading, with some of the technology and transportation issues posting the best gains.

title: PERILS OF FAME HAUNT SOME ATHLETES
description: Behavioral scientists share the average sports fan's interest in why there are such frequent reports about acknowledged drug- and alcohol-abuse problems and even criminal indictments of current and past athletic stars.

title: CALIFORNIA SURPLUS PRODUCES BARGAINS IN BLENDED WINES
description: THERE is a lot of surplus wine in California these days, and it's turning up in inexpensive blends marketed as simple table wines. There are dozens of these new, low-priced bargains around, and they constitute some of the best values on the market in years. Both reds and whites, they offer some very good drinking for $5 a bottle or less.

title: Somali Port Modernized
description: Work began today on a $20 million project, financed by the United States, to modernize the strategic Somali port of Berbera, the Mogadishu radio reported. The radio, monitored here, said the Somali Public Works Minister, Col. Ahmed Hassan Musa, laid the foundation stone of a 1,000-foot extension to the Red Sea port.

title: GLOSSER BROS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
THE DEAL GOES AGAINST THE GRAIN
description: In the saga of American-Soviet relations, another chapter has just been written. The ebullient face of Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block told the story: America is once again in the East- West trade game; we made a sale; we are on top, ahead of all our friendly competitors. For the next five years, irrespective of what the Russians may do - invade another country, start a limited war, purge dissidents, persecute Jews - American farmers will continue to supply Moscow with grain. At the Soviet Union's specific request, America committed itself not to impose an embargo during the life of the agreement.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ON THE LOT Columbia Pictures was created and run by Harry Cohn, who made it into a productive and well-known studio. Today, a retrospective of 175 Columbia Films made between 1929 and 1981 begins at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, near Astor Place.

title: Air Force Awards
description: The General Dynamics Corporation received a $552.3 million Air Force contract for production through 1985 of 480 F-16 fighter aircraft, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said that the United Technologies Corporation had got a $94.6 million Air Force award for TF30, TF33 and J57 engine spare parts, and that the Northrop Corporation received a $46.5 million contract from the Air Force for full-scale engineering development of the MX missile inertial measurement unit.

title: WELFARE HOTEL FAMILIES: LIFE ON THE EDGE
description: A foot-long stainless-steel carving knife is kept in the top drawer of a beat- up dresser in Room 832. Elizabeth Jackson, 21 years old, put it there.

description: Children's Magazine

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: -generation Fifth Avenue jeweler, oftens stands outside his store between 57th and 58th Streets, observing the scene in the European tradition. He observes Bergdorf's, Tiffany's, the Plaza and other swell places. He also observes a huge concrete pot in front of his store. The pot is filled with nothing green and this, Mr. Staal will tell you, is not because he hasn't tried.

title: NEW GAME IN TOWN: FACADEMANSHIP
description: All over town, the facades of old buildings are being incorporated into new buildings under construction. So much of this is going on that architects here have coined a new term for much of the building under way in historic districts: facademanship.

title: F.B.I. ATTACKS ORGANIZED CRIME IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it had begun its first major drive against organized crime in the New York City area and that it expected indictments soon of about 150 suspected crime leaders.

title: Savings Merger
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had approved the merger of the Suburban Savings and Loan Association of Wayne, N.J., into Anchor Savings Bank of Northport, L.I. The merger will create a $5.7 billion institution. Under terms of the agreement, Suburban, with $1.96 billion in assets, will be merged into a new stock savings institution owned by Anchor. To aid the transaction, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation will provide assistance projected to cost $50.9 million and will indemnify Anchor for undisclosed liabilities of Suburban and possible litigation.

title: McRae Vote
description: McRae Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. said shareholders had rejected a proposal to convert the company to a partnership, according to a preliminary vote count.

title: 'Meet the Moderns' Will Open Nov. 10
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic's 11th annual ''Meet the Moderns'' series for 1983-84 will feature the works of established composers as well as premieres of new works by emerging talents. The series, which will be directed by Lukas Foss, will offer four different programs, each of which will be given twice, in November, January, March and April.

title: COURAGEOUS DEFEATS LIBERTY
description: In the race to choose an America's Cup defender, Courageous defeated Dennis Conner's Liberty by 49 seconds today. Meanwhile, workers hurriedly installed fins on Conner's trial yacht in an effort to create a design as potentially formidable as Australia II's.

title: TERRORISTS ASSASSINATE CHILEAN OFFICIAL
description: Urban guerrillas killed the Governor of metropolitan Santiago today in an ambush that riddled his car with 62 rounds of automatic-weapons fire, the police reported.

title: BRIEFS
description: Cavanagh Communities Corp. , Philadelphia, said it had agreed to purchase seven hotels in Miami Beach, Fla.

title: No Headline

Careers; Charting The Road To the Top
description: JUMPING from job to job to get a bigger title and higher salary may not be the best route to the position of chairman or chief executive officer, according to a survey conducted by Russell Reynolds Inc., a management recruiting concern.

title: South Korea's G.N.P.
description: South Korea's gross national product is expected to grow by 8 to 9 percent in real terms in 1983, compared with an original forecast of 7.5 percent, the Bank of Korea said today. G.N.P. grew by 5.3 percent last year.

title: No Headline
description: A Flame Burnt Out Menachem Begin may not have thrown his last bombshell on behalf of Jews and Israel, but it demeans a fighter of integrity to demean his tired lament: ''I have not the power to continue, believe me.''

title: MANILA NAMES A 'HIRED GUN' AS AQUINO ASSASSIN
description: The authorities said today that a police investigation showed that the man who shot the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., was ''a notorious killer'' who had been used in the past by criminal syndicates and ''subversive elements.''

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 31, 1983 International
description: Moslem militiamen attacked Lebanese Army positions and members of the multinational peacekeeping force as gunbattles raged for a third successive day throughout West Beirut. Three French soldiers were killed and four were wounded. American marines were attacked at all three of the positions they hold near Beirut International Airport. West Beirut resounded with a continuous crackling of automatic-weapons fire and the explosions of rockets and grenades. (Page A1, Column 6.) The intensified attacks on marine positions caught Reagan Administration officials by surprise, they said, adding that the assaults raised new questions about the role of American forces in Lebanon. (A1:4-5.)

title: New Fraud Unit Set Up in Jersey
description: Governor Kean signed a bill today creating a division of insurance fraud prevention in the State Insurance Department.

title: ASTRONAUTS BEGIN BUSY SCHEDULE AFTER LIFTOFF TURNS NIGHT INTO DAY
description: The space shuttle Challenger, lifting off at night in a brilliant spectacle of sight and sound, carried five American astronauts into earth orbit early today. There they began a busy schedule, including the first tests of a $100 million data relay satellite that malfunctioned earlier this year.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of reporting and editing errors, an obituary of Donald V. MacDonald on Aug. 4 contained a number of inaccuracies. A corrective article appears on page B5.

title: FNI INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
Semiconductor Talks
description: American and Japanese trade negotiators will meet here on Sept. 7 to discuss measures to increase semiconductor trade between the two nations, Japanese Foreign Ministry officials said today. The meeting will be the third on semiconductors and microchips since July 1982, when the two nations set up a working group aimed at expanding exchanges of information on high technology.

title: ; PETS UNWANTED BEYOND SUMMERTIME
description: To the Editor:

title: CRYSTAL CATHEDRAL TO PAY BACK TAXES ON CONCERT RECEIPTS
description: The Crystal Cathedral, the base for a multimillion-dollar television evangelism effort, will pay $473,000 in back taxes, but a spokesman for the cathedraal's sponsors today accused state officials of religious harassment.

title: FIRST U.S. BLACK IN SPACE
description: The first black American to soar into space, Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr., has in his career followed a trajectory as sure and graceful as that of the Challenger. Fascinated as a child with things that fly, he pursued his interest to the point of taking a doctorate in aerospace engineering. A reluctant hero on the issue of racial barriers, the 40-year-old Air Force officer acknowledged his pioneering role at a recent news conference, but he stressed that he was more excited about being able to fly on the Challenger.

description: The dusty and withered farms of the Middle West were bathed with rain yesterday, but relief from the blistering summer of 1983 was expected to be temporary.

title: MONDALE WARNED AT CARTER MEETING
description: Former President Jimmy Carter met Walter F. Mondale on a Georgia mountaintop tonight and gave his former Vice President his political freedom.

title: New Housing in Japan
description: Japanese housing starts in July fell by 3.4 percent, to 101,224 units, from 104,786 a year earlier, the fifth consecutive monthly decline, the Construction Ministry said today.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Risk of AIDS Contact Brings Recall of Plasma
description: The Red Cross confirmed today that it had recalled more than 5,500 vials of a special plasma product used by hemophiliacs because one donor of blood for the product had died of AIDS.

title: Factory Orders Off 1.7% in July
description: Orders to factories fell 1.7 percent in July, only the second decline since they hit a low during the recession last October, the Commerce Department said today.

title: TV: REPORT ON SUFFOLK ENJOYING TERCENTENARY
description: THE nicest thing about ''Stories of Suffolk'' is that it scarcely mentions how chic it is in the Hamptons; the next nicest thing is that it manages to make Long Island look wholesome and at the same time a bit exotic, too. The half-hour WNEW-TV report, marking the 300th anniversary of Suffolk County, will be seen on Channel 5 at 8:30 tonight.

title: Quick Off-Field Moves
description: Throughout training camp and the exhibition season, Mark Reed was hoping to settle in with the Giants as a backup quarterback, and Mark Jerue was hoping to be a backup linebacker with the Jets.

title: STONE CONTAINER TO BUY FOREST UNIT
description: The Stone Container Corporation, a manufacturer of corrugated boxes and paper bags, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a large part of the forest products division of the Continental Group for $510 million.

title: CONSUMERS DISTRIBUTING CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Ford Outlay in Belgium
description: Ford Tractor (Belgium) said today that it would invest $12 million in a new, fully automated production line for parts of engines and gearboxes at its plant here.

title: HAZARDOUS WASTE EXCEEDSESTIMATES
description: The amount of hazardous waste being generated in the United States is nearly four times higher than previously estimated, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency disclosed today.

title: GUIDRY STRUGGLES, WINS 16TH
description: Manager Billy Martin gave second-guessers something to talk about tonight when he left Ron Guidry on the mound as the A's scored four runs in the seventh inning to wipe out a 4-1 Yankee lead. Martin stuck with Guidry through two more rocky innings while the Yankees rallied for a run in the eighth and three in the ninth to defeat Oakland, 8-5.

title: Jake Butcher Plans Appeal
description: Jake Butcher, the financier, says he will appeal a judge's order declaring him bankrupt because of debts totaling more than $15 million.

title: DONALD V. M'DONALD
description: Donald V. MacDonald, former manager of the commodities department of Fahnestock & Company, New York stockbrokers, died Aug. 1 at Emma Laing Stevens Hospital in West Granville, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Granville, N.Y. He formerly lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: 4 IN FRANCE'S FORCE KILLED; MARINES;  AGAIN IN FIRE FIGHT
description: Fierce gunbattles continued for the third day Tuesday throughout the streets of West Beirut as leftist Moslem militiamen attacked Lebanese Army positions and members of the multinational peacekeeping forces.

description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has named Alexander C. Stark Jr. president of the new telecommunications joint venture formed with N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken.

title: ANNUITIES PLAN FOR BALDWIN
description: A tentative plan to reorganize the insurance subsidiaries of the Baldwin United Corporation would force annuity holders to accept a smaller return on their investment, sources said yesterday.

description: About 400 pickets protesting the use of nonunion workers at a construction site temporarily trapped 45 workers inside a building today, and Gov. James J. Blanchard sent more than 100 state police officers to restore order.

title: 'OLDEST' AMERICAN FAMILY FARM KEEPS UP TO DATE
description: Hugh Tuttle is the latest but not the last of the Tuttles who have run the same farm here for 351 years - making it what is described as the country's oldest family farm.

title: CANCER SUIT BY URANIUM MINERS HEARD IN ARIZONA
description: Testimony concluded here Monday in a $30 million civil damage suit brought against the Federal Government in behalf of 85 Navajo uranium miners or their survivors. The plaintiffs contend that the Government failed to safeguard the miners from heavy doses of radiation in the 1950's, when the mining was part of a nuclear weapons manufacturing program.

description: More than 50,000 space enthusiasts from the United States and abroad today took advantage of a special telephone hookup to eavesdrop on conversations between Mission Control and the space shuttle Challenger in the first day of the flight.

description: Menachem Begin told his political colleagues today that he had exhausted his ability to function in his position and was determined to retire as Prime Minister and leader of the Herut Party.

description: THERE has never been a time when Americans were more conscious of the many uses of herbs and spices. One sweet herb that has found a place lately in many kitchens is basil, which 15 years ago was a rarity in the home.

description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Mike Torrez opposes Fernando Valenzuela, who, in the final meeting between the clubs, makes his only appearance against the Mets this season.

title: Economic SceneWilliam J. Baumol Competition Vs. Research
description: William J. Baumol is a professor of economics at Princeton and New York universities and has been a consultant to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and others. Leonard Silk is on vacation. MANY economists advocate vigorous competition as the most effective means to get to consumers the mix of products they want at the lowest sustainable prices. Deregulation of transportation by air, trucks and railroads, for instance, has been promoted in the belief that most of these markets are now reasonably competitive, and that substitution of competition for regulation serves the public interest.

title: 8 Seized Upstate In Cocaine Sales
description: Eight people were arrested in the Utica area today on drug charges.

title: New Publisher Named At TeenAge Magazine
description: Barbara Marks was named publisher of TeenAge magazine, a two- year-old publication written for, and by, high school students. Mrs. Marks had been advertising director, a position she will continue to hold.

title: Trudeau Opposes Delay In Deploying Missiles
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada said today that he had informed Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece that he disagreed with his recent proposal that the European Economic Community should support a six-month postponement in the deployment of American missiles in Europe.

title: NEBRASKA DISPLAYS A POWERFUL OFFENSE
description: Not since a 41-13 loss to Colorado in the second game of the 1970 season had Penn State been so rudely treated and jolted the way it was by a very impressive Nebraska team that rolled to a 44-6 triumph in the first Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium Monday night.

title: ISALY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $568,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DOCTORS NEED PROTECTION
description: In New York State, neurosurgeons now pay annual insurance premiums of $77,306, and obstetricians an average of $63,133, for the privilege of maintaining a practice without fear of paying millions of dollars in malpractice claims. Each year, of course, the premiums rise. Although doctors sometimes make mistakes for which patients should be compensated, most of the suits are filed by a few greedy patients and lawyers.

title: Puget Power Will Seek End to Nuclear Project
description: The Puget Sound Power and Light Company said today that it would ask its three private utility partners to abandon plans for $4.75 billion, twin nuclear power plants at Hanford, Wash., despite an investment of $400 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: FALL PREVIEW: NEW DISHES ON FIVE RESTAURANT MENUS
description: JUST before Labor Day New York is as quiet as it ever gets. Even restaurant kitchens are free of the usual frenetic activity that characterizes them during the height of the season. There is even time for chefs and their staffs to experiment with new dishes for the fall season.

title: THE MOVIE 'DANIEL': HOW CLOSE IS IT TO HISTORY?
description: Much of the movie ''Daniel,'' which opened in New York last Friday, derives from the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed for atomic espionage conspiracy in 1953. How close is the film to history?

title: BEGIN SAID TO DELAY PULLBACK A FEW DAYS AT U.S. REQUEST
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin was reported today to have agreed, at the request of President Reagan, to postpone for a few more days the partial withdrawal of the Israeli Army from Lebanon's Shuf Mountains. It was the second postponement in a week.

INMATE IS KILLED IN PRISON RIOTING
description: Hundreds of National Guardsmen, police officers and prison guards herded more than 700 manacled inmates away from a steamy, overcrowded prison today after a riot that left one convict dead, 22 people injured and five prison buildings heavily damaged.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Business People column yesterday misidentified a former member of the Civil Aeronautics Board. She is Elizabeth Bailey.

title: MRS. HARRIS IS AGAIN DENIED HER REQUEST FOR A NEW TRIAL A judge yesterday denied a request for a new trial for Jean Harris, who is serving 15 years to life for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower.
description: Mrs. Harris's new attorney, Michael Kennedy, petitioned for a new trial in April, arguing that his client had been too distraught to help her defense in her trial two and a half years ago and that her original lawyer, Joel Aurnou, had not provided an effective defense.

title: No Headline
description: Castle From the Air Perhaps it takes a New Yorker with a long memory to appreciate in full the miracle that has been wrought atop Vista Rock in Central Park. In 1870 Calvert Vaux, who designed most of the park's architecture, started work on its most important single structure, the Belvedere, a fairyland castle combining Moorish window arches, a crenelated Norman tower topped by a playful peaked roof, and a few Gothic keystones besides.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOTH SIDES REST IN U.S. BRINK'S TRIAL
description: Summations ended yesterday in the Brink's trial in Manhattan after a Federal prosecutor told the jury that ''the defense tried to twist the facts.''

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an equity loss in a British affiliate of $679,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss. d-Net income.

title: New Chinatown Jail IsApprovedbyJudge
description: A State Supreme Court justice has given the city permission to build a $101 million jail in Chinatown, despite the objections of community residents.

title: U.S. ROLE IN LEBANON QUESTIONED
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the intensified attacks on Marine positions in Beirut had caught them by surprise and had raised new questions about the role of American forces in Lebanon.

title: Nutri/System
description: Nutri/System Inc. said it had signed a memorandum of understanding to sell its Nutrient Cosmetic business to Channel Industries Ltd., a move that should decrease net income by $400,000 to $600,000 for its fourth quarter, ended July 31.

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $2,912 from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $359,076 on the disposal of a unit.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: NEWS of the Rolling Stones' new contract with Columbia Records, which will be worth as much as $28 million to the group, is the latest in a series of indications that the record business seems to be getting back on its feet.

title: Abortion Notice Law Thrown Out on Appeal
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit today barred enforcement of an Indiana law requiring doctors to notify parents before performing abortions on minors.

title: South Africa Suspends Student Quota System
description: The South African Government, bowing to protests from English- speaking students and academics, agreed to suspend a quota system imposed on nonwhite students attending white universities.

title: BOMBARDIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FORMER AIDE SAYS MANILA PLOTTED TO KILL HIM
description: A former Foreign Minister of the Philippines who now heads a group opposed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos charged today that the Philippine Government had plotted to kill him in the United States.

title: DRUG TESTS AT HELSINKI EVENTS NEGATIVE
description: Not one of 200 athletes who were tested at the world track and field championships in Helsinki, Finland, early this month, including all the medal winners, showed any traces of banned substances, the International Amateur Athletic Federation reported today.

title: MART OPERATOR DECLINES TO JOIN IN TIMES SQ. PLAN
description: In a move that adds new uncertainty to plans to redevelop Times Square, the nation's largest operator of wholesale merchandise marts has decided not to participate in construction of such a building on Eighth Avenue, the state's Urban Development Corporation announced yesterday.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Warner-Lambert
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said it had developed an antitumor antibiotic that has been effective against leukemia in small laboratory animals. The company said the new experimental compound, CI-920, is produced by a microorganism found in a soil sample collected in Sao Paulo. Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., said it had been able to isolate the compound, and was continuing experimental work.

title: Rally Raises Reward In Summer of Murders
description: More than 500 people concerned about 17 unsolved summer murders rallied today in support of a reward fund, already at $40,000, with a target of $100,000..

title: MISSISSIPPI VOTE WATCH: DIFFERING VIEWS
description: News Analysis

title: SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ruling on Citibank Deal
description: The Trade and Industry Department said today that Citibank N.A.'s acquisition of a 48.6 percent stake in Grindlays Holdings P.L.C. would not be referred to the monopolies commission. Earlier this month Citibank had agreed to exchange its 49 percent interest in Grindlays Bank for shares in Grindlays Holdings.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WILLIAM GOYEN, AUTHOR, DIES
description: William Goyen, an acclaimed novelist and short story writer whose prose was considered lyrical and visionary, died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles of leukemia. He was 68 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Cambridge Diet
description: The producers of the popular Cambridge Diet, citing criticism from doctors and dwindling sales, plan to seek reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, MONOPOLIES REIGN
description: The biscuit division of the Premier Group, one of South Africa's biggest food processors, was in deep trouble earlier this year. With losses mounting, it faced the prospect of closing a plant and putting 600 people out of work or ridding itself of the headache by selling the biscuit division.

title: First VLI Offering
description: The VLI Corporation, maker of a new contraceptive sponge called Today, said it planned to make its first public offering, of two million common shares, in October. The price was estimated at between $11 and $13 a share. The sale will be managed by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: Car Dragged From Lake Holds Bodies of Couple
description: A car dragged out of Lake Superior on a ship's anchor held the bodies of a man and woman who may be a couple who vanished five years ago today, the authorities said.

title: Storm Over Manic
description: Jacques Burelle , the vice president of the Montreal Manic of the North American Soccer League, has threatened to resign if Molson Breweries, which owns the team, fails to support his decision to cancel Saturday night's game against the Chicago Sting. Burelle wants the game canceled in protest of a league ruling that the Manic's game last Sunday was forfeited to the Sting because the Montreal players walked off the field in the second half after a dispute with Bob Evans , the referee.

title: UPBEAT CHRYSLER LIFTS SPENDING PLAN
description: The Chrysler Corporation is planning to increase its outlays for new models of cars and trucks over the next few years, Gerald Greenwald, vice chairman of the company, said today. Capital spending in the 1983-87 period will rise to $8 billion from a previously announced $6.5 billion, he told Chrysler executives at the annual new-car preview here.

title: AdvertisingN. R. Kleinfield McCall's Missouri Fairy Tale
description: LIKE countless others, Bonnie

description: Japanese Study Alaskan Oil

title: OF SHAPES AND STYLES
description: THE vegetable bounty of August has arrived at last. Garden-ripe tomatoes that only a few weeks ago were rarities to be cadged or ransomed are now almost too numerous to give away. Peppers - sweet or hot and in dozens of shapes and sizes - are plentiful. Eggplants have reached the peak of their extravagant late-summer production.

title: IN WEDGE OF HONDURAS, G.I.'S ARE SETTING UP SHOP
description: In the next six months, more than 1,500 United States troops, including a force of Green Berets, will be operating in two provinces wedged between El Salvador and Nicaragua.

title: AN 'ELATED' MISS SILLS TAKES STOCK
description: Yesterday morning, Beverly Sills, who has been the general director of the New York City Opera since 1979, sat in her office in the New York State Theater sipping coffee and answering congratulatory phone calls. It was only 9 o'clock, but Miss Sills had already been at work for hours.

title: James F. Lawrence, 76, Dies; FormerInvestmentCounselor
description: James Freeman Lawrence, a retired investment counselor who was active in the support of education and medicine, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Norfolk, Conn. He was 76 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and Charleston, S.C.

title: Tollhouse Cookies
description: Like thermos, aspirin, cellophane and shredded wheat, the term ''tollhouse cookie'' has become part of the American language. The product no longer has a valid trademark.

title: F.D.I.C. TO CONSIDER LIMITING BANK POWERS
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in an apparent attempt to expand its regulatory powers, said today that it was considering the adoption of new rules on the services banks may offer.

title: SOURCES OF SUPPORT FOR CANCER FAMILY
description: Simi Horowitz, who frequently writes about medical topics, was a contributor to ''Questions Patients Most Often Ask Their Doctors'' (Bantam, 1983).

title: New M.A.C. Bond
description: A $100 million bond financing by the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York was tentatively priced by a Salomon Brotheres group with a maximum yield of 9.95 percent for 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2008 at a price of 99 1/4. For shorter maturities, yields will range from 6.75 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 9.25 percent in 1993. The 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2003 were priced at 100.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Barrasso , one of three goalies for the United States national hockey team that is in training for next year's Olympics, has now decided to turn pro immediately with the Buffalo Sabre organization. . . .Judge Leonard Sandler of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has granted Carlos (Panama) Lewis an interim stay of the State Athletic Commission's action in revoking his licenses as a boxing manager and second. The order will remain in effect until final appeal papers are filed and a five-judge court can hear the case.

title: Sampson Injury Slight
description: It was only last week that the Houston Rockets invested $5 million to sign Ralph Sampson , the much-heralded center from the University of Virginia, to a four-year contract. So no one could blame the Houston coaches for holding their breath yesterday when, at a rookie-camp workout, he collided with another player and injured his left foot. But the X-rays proved negative, and by day's end a club spokesman was saying the injury was merely a strain.

title: VOLKSWAGEN ENDS TALKS WITH CHRYSLER
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G., West Germany's largest auto maker, said today that it had ended talks with Chrysler on a possible cooperative venture at Volkswagen's plant in New Stanton, Pa.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Just generally, a great time is being had by all.'' - Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Challenger. (B6:3.)

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Show Increases
description: Long-term interest rates rose by a tenth of a percentage point or more yesterday, while short-term rates were only slightly higher to unchanged.

description: The whole angry dispute is over what one engineer called a ''humble bridge,'' a one-lane bridge, a bridge over a country road so remote that it is traveled by only a dozen or so cars an hour.

description: More than two years ago it became obvious to Dr. Thomas Costantino and Dr. Marie C. Rosati, who share a Staten Island practice in cardiology, that they would soon outgrow the small building they occupy on Seaview Avenue.

description: A $41 million Federal grant will enable New Jersey to upgrade the computerization of its welfare system to eliminate errors and fraud, Governor Kean announced today.

description: Three construction workers were briefly stranded on a scaffold outside a midtown Manhattan office building yesterday when a fire broke out on the roof. No injuries were reported.

description: The Dodgers were not perfect last night, splitting a doubleheader with the Mets at Shea Stadium, but they were good enough to increase their lead over the Atlanta Braves in the fight for first place in the National League West.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE leading cause of new cases of blindness in the United States is a disorder that, until a year or so ago, very few people had ever heard of. It's called macular degeneration, and although the vast majority of its victims experience only a gradual vision loss, each year 7,900 people who are more severely affected become legally blind because of it.

description: It used to be, until the Sense of Humor Inventory, that when you told people a joke they divided into three categories: those who laughed, those who didn't and those who said ''That's funny.''

title: Afghan Rebels Kidnap Several Soviet Advisers
description: Afghan rebels kidnapped three or four Soviet advisers and killed an undetermined number of Government officials in an attack Aug. 20 at Logar, south of Kabul, Western diplomats said today.

description: A series of losses at American Medical Buildings Inc. led to Monday's management shake-up, the company's new president, Elmo R. Zumwalt, said yesterday.

title: MCENROE WINS IN SETS, IS FINED
description: John McEnroe threw sawdust at a spectator, was fined $1,850 but escaped in five sets, and Vitas Gerulaitis saved three match points and also survived a five-setter during another tumultuous start to the United States Open tennis championships yesterday.

title: A LEGAL SPECIALIST WILL JOIN THE TIMES EDITORIAL BOARD
description: Diane Camper, a former Washington correspondent for Newsweek magazine, will join the editorial board of The New York Times in mid-September, Max Frankel, editorial page editor of The Times, announced yesterday.

title: A TWO-TRACK APPROACH TO DEALING WITH RUSSIA
description: Whether purely by design or partly because of internal differences, the Reagan Administration is now pursuing a two- track policy toward the Soviet Union, a hybrid of confrontation and compromise.

title: SOME TEACHERS UPSET BY RACIAL ASSIGNMENTS
description: Gail Wolin knew exactly what she wanted. She lives in Hauppauge, in Suffolk County, and has two young children. So when she went to Public School 261 in Brooklyn yesterday, where officials of New York City's Board of Education are hiring new teachers for the school year, she asked for a job in Queens, the borough nearest her home.

title: ACTED ON BROADWAY AND IN TV 'LASSIE'
description: Jan Clayton, who played Tommy Rettig's mother in the original ''Lassie'' television series, died of cancer and other diseases Sunday at her home in West Hollywood. She was 66 years old.

title: SCREEN: 'BELOW THE BELT' AT FORUM
description: ROBERT FOWLER'S ''Below the Belt'' has a plainness and sincerity that mark it as this director's first feature film, which indeed it is. ''Below the Belt,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, also has a milieu all its own. It is set in the world of female wrestlers, a number of whom appear in the film and help account for its considerable color.

title: U.S. ENVOY CONFERS IN COSTA RICA WITH SALVADOR GUERRILLA LEADERS
description: Richard B. Stone, the special American envoy, met today with four Salvadoran rebel leaders at a ranch on the outskirts of San Jose.

title: GRIDDLE FOR BARBECUES
description: ALTHOUGH we are heading into the traditional last weekend of summer, there is still at least a month of good barbecuing weather ahead.

title: No Headline
description: Westinghouse Bid Is Studied

title: Iranians Block Takeoff Of Hijacked French Jet
description: Iranian authorities blocked the takeoff of an Air France jetliner early today after its hijackers said they would blow it up over Iraq, and the four gunmen threatened to kill their hostages unless France met a new set of demands, Iran's press agency said.

title: $100 Million Issue
description: A $100 dillion issue of the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation's floating rate, extendable notes due in 1998 were offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The initial interest rate for the issue will be announced Sept. 7 and will be adjusted weekly at three-fourths of a percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield at weekly sales of 91- day Treasury bills.
